title: Blue Cross of Connecticut Said to Agree to a Merger
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut has agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big Midwestern insurance company that is rapidly expanding across the country, people with knowledge of the deal said yesterday. The Connecticut insurer would become part of Anthem East Inc., based in Newark, along with Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans in New Jersey and Delaware.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN EXPLORATION CO., Houston, an oil and gas concern, acquired working interests in two oil and gas fields, the East Cameron Block 328 field and the High Island Block 116 field, in the Gulf of Mexico from an undisclosed private seller for $39 million.

title: What's the Girl's Side?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Original Lonely Guy in an Eccentric World
description: JULIUS KNIPL

title: Q&A
description: Squawking Geese

title: Union Head Criticized For Giving Concessions
description: Stanley Hill, the head of the city's largest municipal union was criticized by fellow labor leaders for failing to win more concessions from Mayor Giuliani before the city expands its workfare program. Several union leaders said they were disappointed that Mr. Hill failed to get the Mayor to make firmer promises -- like offering hundreds of permanent jobs to workfare participants.

title: Arabs and Israelis Arriving for Emergency Meeting
description: Middle Eastern leaders began to converge on Washington this evening for an emergency meeting called by President Clinton, as Israel indicated it was prepared to negotiate on some of the issues of greatest concern to the Palestinians, including troop withdrawal in the West Bank and lifting travel restrictions on Palestinians.

title: ADT Merger Is Abandoned In a Setback For Huizenga
description: Confronted with a steep drop in the value of its shares, Republic Industries said yesterday that it was abandoning its bid to acquire ADT Ltd., the nation's biggest home security business, for more than $4 billion in Republic stock.

title: Guard Says He Called Amy Fisher, But That's All
description: A prison guard, testifying in a civil suit, today denied Amy Fisher's allegations that they had an affair in 1993.

title: S.E.C. Accuses County in Arizona of Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, as part of a continuing investigation into municipal finance, accused Maricopa County, Ariz., yesterday of securities fraud in connection with the 1993 sale of some $48 million in general obligation bonds.

title: More Car-Pool-Only Lanes
description: Car-poolers on Route 287, one of the state's most congested highways, got 6.7 new miles of high-occupancy vehicle lane yesterday. The northbound stretch of highway in Morristown and Parsippany-Troy Hills, now open only to buses and to cars with two or more occupants during rush hours, connects to a 5.3-mile segment just north that opened last year.

title: A Lost Night for Eagles: Peete Is Out for Season
description: The stakes were high for the Eagles here tonight. It was an opportunity to share an early lead in the National Conference Eastern Division with the Redskins. But the most scintillating prospect was a chance to twist downtrodden Dallas, their nemesis, under their thumb.

title: Wheeling and Dealing in Taiwan's Backwaters
description: Several recent films have shown contemporary Taiwan in all its up-to-the-minute urbanized glory, but how many have poked their noses into the country's sprawling suburban backwater? Hou Hsiao-hsien's strikingly handsome film ''Goodbye South, Goodbye'' is set in what might be described as the Taiwanese equivalent of David Mamet territory. As its youthful characters scuttle around the country pursuing various shady money-making schemes, you could imagine their American equivalents wheeling and dealing in a dingier outskirt of Miami.

title: Archeology Is Destiny
description: To many Arabs, Israel's opening of the narrow tunnel along the western retaining wall of the Temple Mount was another example of Israelis' disrespect for Muslim holy places and intransigent rule over East Jerusalem. To many Jews, it was a symbol of their right to control their God-given capital. But both Jews and Arabs would do well to take a closer look at the tunnel -- not at the symbolism that now obscures it, but at the ancient stones themselves, witnesses to more than 2,000 years of Jerusalem's history.

title: Juror Selection Is to Begin for Rape Trial of Ex-Fugitive
description: Lawyers for Alex Kelly, the onetime high school wrestling star who fled to Europe when he was charged with raping two teen-age girls a decade ago, are due in court here on Tuesday to begin selecting a jury for a trial of one of the two rape cases.

title: Tight Jeans by Versace
description: At a time when status designer accessories are enjoying new popularity, a comeback for designer jeans was inevitable. And the best-selling jeans at both Neiman Marcus and Bloomingdale's carry the Versace Jeans Couture label.

title: Couple Scouring Murky Reservoir Find Fulfillment, and Lots of Bottles
description: Alberto Arroyo, the self-styled Mayor of the Central Park Reservoir, has hung around that body of water, now named for Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, for more than 60 years, and has seen many things. His ancient eyes sparkle as he tells of how two lonely-seeming people came first as individual joggers, then six years ago struck up a shy conversation. They fell in love, married and recently returned to the reservoir they love to sail off on a gloriously outlandish adventure.

title: Arafat Wants Israel's Vow Of New Steps Toward Peace
description: Fearful that a Middle East meeting scheduled for Tuesday in Washington may prove to be little more than a photo opportunity, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, tried to persuade the United States today to extract from Israel a promise that it is ready to take concrete steps to ease tensions in the region.

title: Torn Ligament Ends Season for Top Panther Pick
description: The Carolina Panthers, one of the surprise teams this season, received devastating news yesterday when it was disclosed that running back Tshimanga Biakabutuka, their No. 1 draft pick, will miss the rest of the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee.

title: Soup Kitchen Feels the Heat Of a New Law
description: HOW to explain the sudden change? The Rev. William Greenlaw says that he can't, not really. All he knows is that for about the last six weeks, coincidentally or not, the period since President Clinton signed the welfare-overhaul law, lines have grown a lot longer at the soup kitchen he runs out of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles, at Ninth Avenue and West 28th Street.

title: New Hard Line by Big Companies Threatens German Work Benefits
description: Shrugging off wide-scale worker protests over the last few days, Germany's biggest industrial corporations plan to trim back some of the most generous employee benefits in the world.

title: Mother Enters Plea of Not Guilty In Death of an Emaciated Girl, 4
description: Carla Lockwood pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to murder charges stemming from the starvation death of her 4-year-old daughter, Nadine.

title: Patterns
description: A Blow for Seventh on Sixth

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Heat of Lotus Attracts Insects And Scientists
description: THE sacred lotus, which gracefully raises its elegant flower above the murky waters where it grows, has long been revered by both Buddhists and Hindus. Now a study has recruited biologists as well as the flower's devotees. Researchers report that the lotus has the remarkable ability to regulate the temperature of its flowers to within a narrow range just as humans and other warmblooded animals do.

title: CHRONICLE
description: More news from the groves of academe: RICHARD WENDORF, the librarian of the Houghton Library for rare books and manuscripts at Harvard University, has been named the director and librarian of the Boston Athenaeum . He will succeed Rodney Armstrong, who will retire in February after serving 23 years in the post.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Politics Aside, Economy Is Shrugging Off Rise to $4.75
description: When Gloria W. Robinson, the top economic development official for the City of Detroit, was asked for the names of local companies that paid the minimum wage, she had to stop and think.

title: Looking for Romance But Finding the Science
description: Tonight's two-hour review of the life and work of Albert Einstein, which opens a new season of ''Nova,'' promises a peek into his youthful love letters. But don't be put off. Despite the attention to Einstein's failed early marriage to Mileva Maric (''There was a price that he and those closest to him had to pay for each and every triumph,'' the narrator says as though he were hawking a soap opera), the program's strength is in the great man's grappling with time and space, not with poor Mileva.

title: Pride of Puerto Rico Visible in Post-Season
description: For a whole summer, the sounds of salsa underscored the growing influence of Latin America on the Mets and Yankees. That flavor will be even more palpable -- and distinctly Puerto Rican -- tonight when the American League West champion Texas Rangers and the A.L. East-winning Yankees begin their playoff series at Yankee Stadium.

title: Master of the Sorrow That Knows No Hope
description: Historical stature comes in several forms. Among composers, there are those who change the world and there are those who report on it. Schoenberg, for example, brought to music a new alphabet, Stravinsky a new grammar. Both command attention for fast-forwarding musical progress or upending it altogether. Dmitri Shostakovich, on the other hand, was a witness. His music is psychic biography: a series of highly personal accounts written in a received language.

title: U.S. Consults Allies On All-African Force
description: Anxious about the possibility of ethnic massacres in Burundi, the Clinton Administration is consulting European and African nations about organizing an all-African army that could intervene in African crises without the need to send American troops.

title: Confident Climate Fosters New Art Galleries
description: Christopher D'Amelio and Lucien Terras quit their jobs at the Paula Cooper Gallery on the same day in June. Four years earlier, they had begun working for the venerable SoHo art dealer within a month of each other, spending their days nurturing clients, encouraging artists and organizing exhibitions. Having learned the ropes, they were now ready to set off on their own. Lately, they are not the only ones.

title: Life in Womb May Affect Adult Heart Disease Risk
description: MANY people with heart disease who have attributed their ill health to heredity or unhealthy habits may have yet another culprit to blame: their mothers' diets during pregnancy.

title: Progress on Gun Control
description: The continuing budget resolution just approved by Congress contains a sensible piece of gun-control legislation aimed at preventing spouse-beaters and child-abusers from purchasing or owning guns. President Clinton and the measure's chief sponsor, Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, deserve credit for standing firm against a last-minute Republican effort to weaken this worthy measure.

title: RELIANCE STEEL IN DEAL FOR SISKIN STEEL
description: The Reliance Steel and Aluminum Company agreed yesterday to acquire a privately held rival, the Siskin Steel and Supply Company of Chattanooga, Tenn., for $71 million. Both companies process and sell galvanized, hot-rolled and cold-finished steel and other metals. Siskin had $151 million of revenue in the year ended June 30, while Reliance had revenue of about $322.3 million in the six months ended June 30. Siskin will operate as a Reliance unit with its current management remaining in place, Reliance said.

title: Sangstat Says Drug Passed Clinical Trial
description: The Sangstat Medical Corporation said today that clinical trials had shown that its version of cyclosporine, Sandoz A.G.'s immune-suppressant drug, to be equally effective in preventing organ rejection in transplant patients.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: Executive Changes
description: CHEVRON CORP., San Francisco, said Ray Galvin would retire as corporate vice president and president of Chevron U.S.A. Production Co., its United States exploration and production unit, next year. Peter Robertson, 49, corporate vice president of strategic planning and quality, will replace Mr. Galvin, and Greg Matiuk, 51, will succeed Mr. Robertson.

title: Japanese Banks Forgive Big Loans
description: A dozen Japanese banks said yesterday that they were forgiving 1.68 trillion yen ($15.1 billion) in loans to housing lenders that went bankrupt on losses from their customers' speculative investing in the 1980's. The banks said the losses had already been taken into account in earnings.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Saturday with a chart showing the stock price of Archer Daniels Midland referred incorrectly to events on Friday. The company's announcement that it would pay more than $65 million to settle three separate lawsuits was made after the stock market closed; there was no market reaction that day.

title: Harvard Pays $775,000 to Settle Suit Over Laxness at Pharmacy
description: Harvard University is paying $775,000 to settle Federal claims of lax security and faulty record keeping that led to drug thefts at the university pharmacy used by its students, faculty members and staff, the United States Attorney in Massachusetts announced today.

title: Corrections
description: The credit listings yesterday with film reviews of ''Le Garcu'' and ''A Self-Made Hero,'' in the New York Film Festival, misidentified the theater where they are being screened. It is Alice Tully Hall, not the Walter Reade. ''Le Garcu'' is at 9 P.M. tomorrow and ''Hero'' at 6 P.M. today.

title: Umpires Vote To Boycott Over Alomar
description: Major League Baseball umpires voted yesterday not to work the playoffs, which begin today, unless Gene Budig, the American League president, suspends Roberto Alomar of the Baltimore Orioles for the first round of the playoffs. Lawyers for Major League Baseball, however, are expected to go to Federal Court today to force the umpires to handle their assignments in New York, Baltimore and St. Louis today and in Los Angeles tomorrow.

title: Jazz Giant Roving Around the Piano Keys
description: Tonight's tribute to the pianist Oscar Peterson at Town Hall, filled with friends and band members past and present, is a reminder of an era when jazz giants roamed the land. Mr. Peterson, now 71, was a member of a generation that came of age in the 1950's and defined the public perception of a music that was popular, but no longer part of pop culture. Along with the Modern Jazz Quartet, Miles Davis, Gerry Mulligan and Dave Brubeck among others, he represented the collective public face of jazz. These were stars whose appeal took them beyond the dedicated audience.

title: Excerpt From Address on Immigration
description: Following is an excerpt from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's address to a conference on immigration at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Finally, That Championship Season
description: As the front-office employees of the Texas Rangers celebrated at a party in the early hours last Saturday morning, one man approached the team's general manager.

title: Mellow Boss Lets Bats Do the Talking
description: There is a story, perhaps apocryphal, told by some New York sportswriters about George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the New York Yankees, and a side of him that is underpublicized. Several years ago, the story goes, an interviewer, having heard that Mr. Steinbrenner was a fan of the novelist Thomas Hardy, fished for confirmation by dropping the name of the heroine of Hardy's ''Return of the Native'' into a conversation about the former Yankee outfielder Dave Winfield.

title: Kiwi Declares Bankruptcy and Trims Routes
description: Kiwi International Air Lines, a low-cost carrier with problems inside and outside the company since it started in 1992, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday.

title: Alomar Issues an Apology
description: It didn't feel like home for the Orioles' Roberto Alomar. He was treated like an outsider today, jeered at a team workout that was open to the public at Camden Yards.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Harborside Complex Sold
description: The Cali Realty Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy the Harborside Financial Center office complex in Jersey City for $282.4 million in cash and debt. The purchase of the 1.9-million-square-foot office complex and adjoining land zoned for another 4.1 million square feet increases Cali's holdings by about 40 percent. Though Cali declined to identify the seller, a U S West Inc. pension fund, which is based in Englewood, Colo., is the owner of record of the office complex. The transaction is expected to close in 45 days. Cali, which is based in Cranford, holds properties in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania.

title: Muster to Make His Point With I.T.F.
description: THOMAS MUSTER, who stomped off the court during a Davis Cup match with Brazil and called the fans ''animals,'' will go to London on Oct. 7 to argue his case before the International Tennis Federation.

title: Corrections
description: A credits listing in Weekend on Friday with a film review of ''The Line King: The Al Hirschfeld Story'' misspelled the surname of the editor and associate producer. He is Angelo Corrao, not Carrao.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC ACQUIRING DUCATI MOTORBIKE UNIT
description: Cagiva S.p.A. of Italy said yesterday that it had signed a final accord to sell 51 percent of its Ducati motorbike division to Texas Pacific Group. Details were not given, but Cagiva said earlier this year that it had expected to sell the stake to Texas Pacific, an investment group led by David Bonderman, for about 500 billion lire, or $325 million. Cagiva and Texas Pacific are creating a company to manage Ducati, called Ducati Motor S.p.A. The company will produce and sell Ducati motorcycles. Cagiva, which is owned by the Castiglioni brothers, bought ailing Ducati in 1985 for $5 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Italy's 1997 budget referred incorrectly to a deficit reduction proposal presented last week by the Government. The $41 billion figure represented a package of taxes and cuts intended to halve the country's $79 billion deficit; the amount of the full budget has not been announced.

title: Degussa to Buy A Drug Maker, Muro
description: The German chemical and drug maker Degussa A.G. said yesterday that it would buy the 80 percent outstanding of the United States drug maker Muro Pharmaceutical Inc. for cash and stock. Degussa said the total purchase price for Muro, including the 20 percent it already owns, is $350 million.

title: Chess
description: The youngest American grandmaster, 19-year-old Gabriel Schwartzman, won the 1996 United States Open Championship in August in Alexandria, Va. The former Romanian star, who lives in Gainesville, Fla., scored 10 1/2-1 1/2 to top a field of 557 players. He was awarded the $5,000 first prize and seeded into the 1997 United States Invitational Championship.

title: 2 Big Pension Funds Complain To Archer About Board Plan
description: In a letter to the shareholders of the Archer Daniels Midland Company, two influential pension funds yesterday criticized the company's steps toward creating a more independent board as ''shallow.''

title: Mexican Justice
description: President Ernesto Zedillo has promised to enforce the laws of Mexico fully and impartially, even with top officials of his Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. The future of political and economic reform requires the fair administration of justice. But Mr. Zedillo and his party have repeatedly delivered a good deal less than that.

title: Congresswoman's Ex-Husband Jailed Again
description: One year ago, Joseph Waldholtz was married to this city's United States Congresswoman, was renting Henry A. Kissinger's town house in Washington, and was posing as the beneficiary of an imaginary $325 million fund, the Waldholtz Family Trust.

title: 3 Bickering Bosnian Leaders Finally Begin to Plan a Nation
description: Bosnia's new Government, brought to life with the assistance of the West, took its first small step today as the three former enemies elected to form its joint presidency held a meeting.

title: Falcons Extend George's Suspension
description: The Atlanta Falcons, unable to work out a trade for quarterback JEFF GEORGE, have extended his suspension for three more games because of comments he made to the news media.

title: Accord Near On Computer Secruity Codes
description: After several years of debate between the computer industry and American intelligence agencies, President Clinton has decided to permit American computer companies to export more powerful data-scrambling software but only if they establish a system that will enable keys to the code to be obtained by law enforcement officials with a court warrant.

title: Senate Fight Over Phrase Demonstrates Words' Effect
description: A behind-the-scenes skirmish erupted into a full-scale partisan battle in the Senate today over the ability of Federal Express workers to organize.

title: Netanyahu Seeks New Talks On 3 Major Palestinian Issues
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is convinced, he and his aides say, that the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, has already won an undeserved advantage in the battle for world opinion, but that Mr. Netanyahu is determined that world opinion would not dictate Israeli positions.

title: What Russian Crisis?
description: No matter the outcome of Boris Yeltsin's coming heart surgery, uncertainty about his ability to serve out his second term has jump-started planning and plotting to succeed him. On Saturday, his security adviser, Aleksandr Lebed, called for the President to step down until he has recovered.

title: A Hide-and-Seek Kiss
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole Advisers Attack Clinton's Foreign Policy
description: Seizing on the turmoil in the Middle East as the latest indication of President Clinton's foreign policy shortcomings, Bob Dole today convened his advisers to review world events and publicly assail Mr. Clinton's handling of crises around the globe.

title: Dollar Hits Highest Level In Two Years Against Yen
description: The dollar jumped against the Japanese yen yesterday, rising to its highest level since the start of 1994. But while the dollar is now 38 percent above its record 1995 low, analysts are not yet convinced that its long-term turnaround is at hand.

title: Hiring and Holding Teachers
description: New York City public schools are mainly known for crumbling buildings, crowded classrooms, security problems -- and vast numbers of teachers who quit the profession or leave for more attractive jobs elsewhere. Despite these disadvantages, New York's schools have maintained an edge over comparable systems -- like Los Angeles, Philadelphia and Chicago -- with higher math and reading scores and a college-matriculation rate that is twice the national average. Lately, the Board of Education has begun to tackle teacher attrition as well, through a creative program that could well serve as a model for inner-city systems everywhere.

title: THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: California

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in the Company News column of Business Day on Sept. 24 about an announcement by Mossimo Inc. on its third-quarter earnings described the company incorrectly. It markets men's and women's active wear and sportswear; it does not make No Fear T-shirts.

title: No Headline
description: ''People don't realize how normal New Yorkers are. They're just like everybody else.''

title: 'Buying' a Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Mental Health Contracts Questioned in Audit
description: The New York City Comptroller raised new questions yesterday about how the Giuliani administration awarded millions of dollars in contracts, contending that mental health officials had repeatedly ignored longstanding guidelines that are intended to prevent mismanagement and patronage.

title: Zedillo Lectures the Mexicans: Obey the Law
description: President Ernesto Zedillo is a self-described workaholic with ascetic tendencies and a missionary bent. He rises early, expels smokers from Cabinet meetings and forgoes the three-hour tequila lunches that drive public life here. Instead, he eats with his family in the official residence.

title: A Fraud Against Norway
description: A Red Bank man pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to a criminal charge for his role in a scheme to defraud the Royal Norwegian Air Force.

title: New Deal Had a Better Approach on Workfare
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS CORPORATION TO SELL STAKE IN FOX KIDS
description: The News Corporation plans to sell a $150 million public stake in its Fox Kids Worldwide Inc. unit, which creates and distributes ''Mighty Morphin Power Rangers'' and other children's television shows. The initial public offering would help finance acquisitions and overseas expansion for Fox Kids, which depends on ''Power Rangers'' for 44 percent of its revenue, including sales of toys and other merchandise. Fox Kids did not disclose details. The offering was disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Ex-Green Beret Colonel and Son Held in Attempted Kidnapping
description: A former Green Beret colonel, who helped negotiate an end to the Federal Bureau of Investigation siege at Ruby Ridge, Idaho, and served as a mediator in the Freemen standoff in April, was arrested yesterday on charges that he tried to kidnap a middle school student in Connecticut, the police said.

title: Unilever to Combine Units
description: Unilever N.V., the British-Dutch household products concern, said yesterday that it would combine its two United States food businesses, Thomas J. Lipton and Van den Bergh Foods. Unilever, based in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, said the new company, with annual sales of about $3 billion, would operate under the name Lipton, with headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The merger will begin in early 1997 and will be completed in 1998.

title: Bad Blood Surfacing for Padres-Cardinals
description: Among other things, the National League playoffs are about rushed laundry, dirty laundry, position rivalries, brother acts and a so-called monopoly of arms.

title: Look at Tuition Costs As Shackles From Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Contractor to Manage NASA Space Shuttle Program
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has signed a contract to turn over much of the operation of the space shuttle program to a private contractor, United Space Alliance.

title: Some Rebellious Harmony From a Button-Down Time
description: Among the gentlemanly post-collegiate folk groups that proliferated from the late 1950's until the advent of folk-rock in the mid-60's, none had the hip cachet of the Chad Mitchell Trio, which performed a reunion concert on Saturday evening at Symphony Space.

title: Illness Cancels Girls' Soccer
description: Girls' soccer games at Middletown High School North and at other schools that had recently competed against Middletown were canceled over the weekend after health authorities confirmed that a team member had come down with bacterial meningitis.

title: A Tale From The Brothers Gwynn
description: THERE'S magic in the air this morning.

title: One Fifth of Schools Put On Probation in Chicago
description: In an aggressive effort to renew faith in the country's third-largest school system, Chicago's school board today placed 109 of the city's lowest-scoring schools on academic probation. It was the the first time school officials here have used such a heavy stick in the long battle to improve the crumbling educational system.

title: Actions by States Hold Keys to Welfare Law's Future
description: America takes a leap into the unknown on Tuesday as major provisions of the new welfare law take effect. Whether the law will liberate people from dependence on Government, as Republicans contend, or increase poverty and misery, as liberal Democrats predict, is unknown, and perhaps unknowable, at this stage.

title: Prices Lower On Treasury Securities
description: Prices of Treasury securities turned lower yesterday for the second consecutive session, mostly on the strength of a housing report that surprised the market and again raised investors' concerns about inflation and higher interest rates.

title: New Afghan Rulers Impose Harsh Mores Of the Islamic Code
description: In the four days since Kabul fell to the Taliban militias, the capital's one million people have been plunged into the medieval labyrinth that is Taliban rule.

title: Cable, Cable, Who's Got The Cable?
description: IN print advertisements and television commercials, computer systems always look so neat. A square-jawed man or perky-nosed woman with hands on keyboard or mouse stares with satisfaction at the screen while . . . Wait a minute! How can there be anything on the screen? There are no wires or cables in the picture.

title: Interbrand Buys Gerstman & Meyers
description: The Interbrand Group, a corporate-identity consulting company with headquarters in London and New York, said yesterday that it had acquired Gerstman & Meyers Inc., a package-design and corporate-identity company in New York.

title: Mongolia Is Throwing Out 75 Years of Rusty Ideas
description: A small man sits in an enormous, wood-paneled office inside the austere and cavernous Government House here each morning, a tremendous amount of responsibility suddenly thrust in his hands.

title: Democratic Tide Is Eroding G.O.P.'s Stronghold in West
description: George Bush fared poorly against Bill Clinton in the West in the 1992 Presidential campaign, and four years later, Bob Dole is struggling to head off a similar debacle, especially in California.

title: MICRO WAREHOUSE SHARES FALL 18% ON ACCOUNTING NEWS
description: The shares of Micro Warehouse Inc. fell 18 percent yesterday after the company said accounting errors might force it to restate earnings for 1994 and 1995 and possibly take a charge of $18 million. Shares in the company, a computer and software retailer based in South Norwalk, Conn., fell $5.75, to $25.75, in Nasdaq trading of almost 5.9 million shares. The errors in Micro Warehouse's accounting procedures included problems with receivables from suppliers and vendors for defective goods and the rotation of its inventory. The company did not disclose what the restated results would be. Micro Warehouse reported net income of $28 million in 1994 and $45.1 million in 1995.

title: Islanders Lose Semak in Draft
description: The Islanders selected the former Devils center Jim Dowd from Vancouver and defenseman Corey Foster, a former No. 1 draft selection of the Devils, from the Pittsburgh Penguins in yesterday's National Hockey League waiver draft.

title: The Playoffs on (Almost) Every Channel
description: A year ago, Major League Baseball showed off its expanded playoff system, but decided to hide most of the games from a national audience by regionalizing them, thus turning baseball's post-season into a bad clone of the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament. Caution: geniuses at work.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: CHICAGO DOCK SHARES CLIMB ON TAKEOVER ANNOUNCEMENT
description: The shares of the Chicago Dock and Canal Trust rose more than 30 percent yesterday after the company said late on Friday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Newsweb Corporation for $150 million in cash and debt. The real estate company's stock rose $4.766, to $20.266. The closely held Newsweb planned to buy all of the stock of Chicago Dock for $21 a share in cash. Chicago Dock operates as a real estate investment trust. Newsweb is controlled by Fred Eychaner, who holds a 9.22 percent stake in Chicago Dock.

title: FEDERAL MOGUL SELLING A BALL BEARING PLANT
description: The Federal Mogul Corporation, a large auto parts maker based in Southfield, Mich., announced yesterday that it had sold its 900-employee ball bearing manufacturing operations to the NTN Corporation of Osaka, Japan. No purchase price was announced for the unit, which holds an estimated 2 or 3 percent of the $5 billion United States bearing market. The United States imposed duties of up to 212 percent on imported bearings in 1989 because of concerns that Japanese and other foreign companies were dumping bearings on the American market. The duties, since reduced to 5 to 20 percent, have prompted foreign manufacturers to build or buy more bearing factories here.

title: State Jobs, but Not on Paper
description: As one of the economy measures in Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's current budget, the state has stopped publishing a list of vacant Civil Service jobs. The list is available over the Internet, but two Democratic legislators say that is no help to many job-seekers who do not have access to a computer. Only 15 of the state's 400 libraries offer Internet access, the New Jersey Library Association said.

title: Locking In College Tuition
description: Under a bill to be unveiled today, parents who are afraid that future tuition increases will make a college education unaffordable would be able to lock in the price earlier in the state college system by paying tuition and housing costs in advance.

title: Psychiatrist and Social Worker Slain
description: A retired psychiatrist and his wife, a social worker, were found stabbed to death in their home in a wealthy section of Englewood, N.J., yesterday morning, and a man with a bloody shirt, described by investigators as their 30-year-old son, was seized two hours later in woods a mile away and was being questioned by the authorities.

title: Hazards Fixed, New Technical School Is Set to Open
description: Classes at the High School for Cooperative Technical Education are scheduled to begin tomorrow, more than two weeks after the Manhattan school's opening was delayed by the Board of Education because of building violations it deemed dangerous to teachers and students.

title: Despite a Selloff, a Good Quarter for Stocks
description: The 104th Congress will be remembered for overhauling the welfare laws, a higher minimum wage and two shutdowns of the Government. But to a select few investors who paid attention to minor legislation, it will also be remembered for creating a great investment opportunity.

title: Kmart Changes Its Tune, to 'Manhattan'
description: From the Manhattan-centered view of the universe, Kmart has long been one of the big symbols of the world Out There, a caricature of shopping-center culture at its height, or depth, twinkling mysteriously somewhere in the provinces under the downscale glare of a blue-light special.

title: Penn's Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Medical Rivalry Threatening Yeltsin's Chances for Recovery?
description: Boris N. Yeltsin is undergoing tests in a hospital here in preparation for the heart bypass operation he needs, and extraordinary efforts are being made to send medical personnel and equipment for the surgery. All of this raises a critical question:

title: A Real Problem With the Neighbors
description: Want to know why cable channels, especially HBO, keep winning all those Emmy Awards for their movies and the broadcast networks don't? Sneak a peek at ''The People Next Door,'' tonight's ''thriller,'' as the network labels it, on CBS.

title: Who Cares Whether a Political Adviser Is Gay?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Widens Attack on Cuts To Welfare
description: Significantly broadening his attack on the new Federal welfare law, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today that the law's denial of many social services to legal immigrants was both morally wrong and unconstitutional.

title: An Internet newcomer is making money by selling moving ads as part of screen savers.
description: ADVERTISING in cyberspace has not been a lucrative venture for many. But one Internet company thinks it has hit upon a formula that could work.

title: Buses vs. Merchant Parking
description: Since 1988, curbside parking along two of downtown Newark's main thoroughfares, Broad and Market Streets, has been turned into bus-only lanes during rush hours. The bus lanes eased traffic, but store owners have complained that their customers traveling by car can no longer pop into a store on the way home.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of credit offerings in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to the bonds being offered by the District of Columbia. They are $70 million of American University revenue bonds, not refunding bonds.

title: Frances Lear, a Mercurial Figure of the Media and a Magazine Founder, Dead at 73
description: Frances Lear, a mercurial figure in the media world who spent some $25 million she received in a divorce settlement to start a magazine named after herself, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73.

title: Arafat's War Option
description: Palestinians can choose between war against Israel or peace talks with Israel. They no longer can have both. Unless they learn that at the Washington conference called by President Clinton, the meeting will be simply a step toward one more Mideast disaster.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some people view jury duty as an onerous chore, one to be avoided if possible. But Gov. GEORGE W. BUSH of Texas was so eager to meet his civic obligation that he cut in line ahead of more than 300 other prospective jurors in Austin yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: INSIDE
description: A Plan for Coding Data

title: I.B.M. TO ACQUIRE AN INSURANCE SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: The International Business Machines Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Professional Data Management Associates Inc., which makes software for life insurers. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Professional Data Management makes Lifepro software, which processes life and annuity policies. The company, based in Indianapolis, also offers product support and testing facilities. Professional Data had sales of $12 million in 1995. I.B.M. expects to expand the personal computer-based Lifepro system to other I.B.M. systems. Professional Data Management, which was founded in 1984, also makes software used by property and casualty insurers.

title: It's Politics, So Everyone Must Be Corrupt. Right?
description: Rage, properly channeled, can definitely give birth to good, even great theater. Disgust, a more passive and distancing emotion, is far less likely to. (Would you rush to play called ''Look Back in Queasiness''?)

title: U.S. Switch on Mideast Resolution Left U.N. Envoy Chagrined
description: Switching signals on its own United Nations representative, the Clinton Administration tried unsuccessfully last weekend to stall Security Council action on the situation in the West Bank and Gaza after last-minute objections were raised by Israel.

title: Ogilvy, Mather Gets Lotus Account
description: The Lotus Development Corporation unit of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday named the I.B.M. agency, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, to handle its worldwide account, effective Jan. 1. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $20 million.

title: Messier Tunes Up By Scoring A Hat Trick
description: In only his second appearance this season in nine National Hockey League exhibition games, Mark Messier scored three goals last night for the Rangers in a 7-1 victory over the junior varsity of the Pittsburgh Penguins at Madison Square Garden.

title: In London Shows, Individuality Stands Out
description: Envy is such an odd sin. The British seem to feel this city has scored a coup, with big public companies (and American designers) like Gucci by Tom Ford, Donna Karan and Tommy Hilfiger staging runway shows during London fashion week, which began on Wednesday. But what the American press and buyers want during the New York show schedule is a few designers with the sort of subversive creativity that is the norm in London.

title: Underwriting Shrinks, and Thus Do Fees
description: Stock and bond underwriting shriveled in the quarter that ended yesterday, a sure sign that chief financial officers of some of the big investment banks are going to have to perform some fancy accounting footwork to dress up results.

title: Birger Lunde, Norway Seaman; Survivor of Nazi U-Boats Was 82
description: Birger Lunde, an officer in the Norwegian merchant marine who had three vessels shot from under him by German submarines during World War II, died Sept. 24 in the Norwegian Christian Home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 82 and lived in Great Kills on Staten Island.

title: Fish-Farm Escapees Threaten Wild Salmon
description: WILD Atlantic salmon returning to spawn in the freshwater streams of their birth now face a startling threat: interlopers.

title: Panama Still Wants Yankees to Go Home, but Not Right Away
description: Since World War I, Fort Amador has been the jewel of the American military presence here, dominating the Pacific Ocean entrance of the Panama Canal. But on Tuesday, the 207-acre site, which includes the residence of the United States Army commander, is to be transferred to Panamanian control.

title: Raiders' Losses Now Include a Player
description: The Raider mystique is gone, and so is defensive end ANTHONY SMITH, who refused to travel with the team for Sunday's game in Chicago. Could Coach MIKE WHITE, whose club is 1-4, be next to go?

title: Crisscrossing the Atlantic With Her Songs
description: Pamela Mann is a soprano from New York who has gathered a considerable musical education crisscrossing the Atlantic. Her training began at the Juilliard School, the Mannes College of Music and the American Opera Center, and it has continued with performing experience at opera houses in Austria, Italy and Switzerland. Miss Mann sang a recital at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon, helped along by the deft piano accompaniments of Wayne Sanders.

title: Giuliani Leading Democratic Rivals, Marist Poll Reports
description: Thirteen months before he can seek re-election, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is leading potential Democratic rivals, but he remains a polarizing figure, with white residents far more pleased with his performance than Hispanic and black ones, according to a poll released yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Finnegans Wake'' -- a great fishing novel?

title: Strike Cuts Circulation at 2 Detroit Papers
description: Circulation at the two striking Detroit newspapers has declined by more than 30 percent since workers went on strike in July 1995, according to the first audited subscriber figures since the strike, released yesterday.

title: De Benedetti Groups' Narrow Losses
description: The holding companies of the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti narrowed their pretax losses in the first half of 1996 as increases in earnings from their investments in auto-parts companies offset losses at Olivetti S.p.A. Compagnie Industriali Riunuite S.p.A., or C.I.R., said its pretax loss narrowed to 18.9 billion lire ($12.6 million), from 151.5 billion lire a year earlier.

title: Wetteland Honored as A.L.'s Top Reliever
description: JOHN WETTELAND of the Yankees won the Rolaids relief award for the American League comfortably, but JEFF BRANTLEY of the Cincinnati Reds needed a tie breaker to edge San Diego's TREVOR HOFFMAN in the closest competition ever for the award given to the top closer in each league.

title: As Milestone Nears, a Lament for a U.S. Decline
description: Between them, Frank Shorter, Bill Rodgers and Alberto Salazar possess one Olympic gold medal in the marathon and seven victories in the New York City Marathon.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Beleaguered Lloyd on Roster
description: Graeme Lloyd's inclusion was the most shocking one yesterday when Joe Torre made his post-season roster final. Lloyd will join Kenny Rogers as the only left-handers in the Yankee bullpen. David Weathers was selected as the last right-handed reliever and infielders Andy Fox and Luis Sojo were chosen as reserves when Jorge Posada was not picked as a third catcher.

title: 'Sesame Street' Licensing
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that it had entered a licensing agreement with the Children's Television Workshop to make and sell children's apparel that will be decorated with the characters from the ''Sesame Street'' television program. Financial terms were not disclosed. Kmart said the new line would be introduced in July. The Children's Television Workshop, which is based in New York, produces ''Sesame Street,'' an educational program carried on public television channels.

title: Dole, Disability and Discrimination
description: When Bob Dole spoke at a meeting of black journalists in Nashville recently, his running mate, Jack Kemp, introduced him this way: ''If you've seen, as Bob Dole has seen, people treat you differently because of a physical disability, you know how hurtful it is to be judged for what you seem, rather than who you are.''

title: Kemp Goes Hunting for Votes in Silicon Valley
description: Emitting high-speed streams of campaign oratory meant to fan the irritation that many in the high-technology industry feel toward President Clinton, Jack Kemp came courting in Silicon Valley today, pushing the Dole candidacy's promises of lower taxes and entrepreneur-friendly government.

title: Philanthropist Pledges Help To Immigrants
description: George Soros, the Hungarian-born philanthropist and international financier, said today he would give $50 million to assist legal immigrants in the United States.

title: Over on Gringo Alley
description: Last Thursday important business required me to encounter Sixth Avenue. What a hideous experience.

title: One Lineup Decision Awaited for Yanks' Opener
description: The eager Yankees strolled onto the freshly manicured field yesterday at Yankee Stadium, beneath blue and sunny skies and with a backdrop that oozed the sweet sounds of baseball. Balls popped into mitts, coaches whacked endless grounders and the players prepared, amid barren blue seats, for the opener of their first-round series against the Texas Rangers. Those seats will be filled tonight and the serenity will be replaced by the electricty of the post-season, perhaps the sweetest sound of all.

title: Ground Tests Loom for Ultimate Hot Rods, Supersonic Cars
description: ALMOST a century ago, a Frenchman set the first official speed record with a car when he blazed through a course at nearly 25 miles per hour.

title: SENATE APPROVES A BIG BUDGET BILL, BEATING DEADLINE
description: The Senate passed a catchall, end-of-session bill this evening that includes nearly $400 billion in military and domestic budget appropriations for 1997, $30 billion in savings, major changes to immigration laws and a hodgepodge of other legislation.

title: Distorted Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Blockbuster Drops Foote, Cone & Belding
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Group in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a unit of Viacom Inc., said yesterday that it had parted ways with the Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications in Chicago and realigned its account between Bernstein-Rein in Kansas City, Mo., and the New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: Union Head Is Assailed On Workfare Concessions
description: Stanley Hill, the head of the city's largest municipal union was criticized by fellow labor leaders yesterday for failing to win more concessions from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani before the city expands its workfare program.

title: Mind Control for PC's? I Think Not
description: THE hoopla for a $140 device called Minddrive says you can ''use your mind in a new way.'' The Other 90% Technologies Inc. calls its odd little peripheral ''the first computer product operated by human thought.''

title: The Shipping Subsidies Survive
description: For decades, taxpayers have spent billions subsidizing the American merchant marine fleet. The fleet is no longer vitally important in a military sense, and it is outperformed commercially by more efficient foreign-flag vessels. But for all the brave talk about budget-cutting, the best the Republican-led Congress has been able to do is cut those subsidies in half, to $1 billion over the next decade. The money would subsidize the operations of as many as 47 ships, about half the current number. That is still excessive.

title: Good Call, Bad Call, Jets Are Still 0-5
description: It's official, unofficially: That was a legitimate touchdown catch by Keyshawn Johnson that millions of Americans saw and the officials wouldn't allow.

title: On Arab-Israeli Patrol, Distrustful Comrades
description: When Inspector Itai Ben-Dov and his men climbed into their jeep on Sunday morning to resume joint patrols with Palestinian police officers, they felt they were crossing a deep divide.

title: McNabb Making His Coach Nervous
description: Football coaches worry. It goes with the job.

title: The Giants Finally Silenced the Vikings
description: It must have been nice for the Giants to see someone else frustrated on a Sunday afternoon. Minnesota's John Randle certainly was baffled during the Giants' 15-10 victory, and that led to a few bizarre incidents in what was a strange but highly successful game for the Giants.

title: Benetton Profits Rise, But Sales Are Flat
description: The Italian clothing manufacturer and retailer Benetton S.p.A. said yesterday that its profit rose 9 percent in the first half of the year even as its revenue held steady. Benetton said the improved profitability reflected cost containment and lower financing charges because of reduced debt.

title: A Double Standard?
description: To the Editor:

title: Formica Expands Carmichael Ties
description: The Formica Corporation in Cincinnati, a subsidiary of BTR P.L.C., has expanded its relationship with Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis by awarding that agency duties for Formica surface-product lines like laminate and Ligna wood surfacing. Those duties had been handled for two years by Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York.

title: 6-Year-Old's Kiss Aside, Sex Harassment Does Plague Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Departure at Daily News as Top Editor Leaves
description: Martin Dunn, the top editor of The Daily News, will leave the paper this month, becoming the latest of several senior editors to come and go since Mortimer B. Zuckerman bought the tabloid in 1993.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dollar Hits 111.40 Yen, Highest Level Since 1994

title: On Drugs, Bruises and Betrayal
description: Scrawl

title: UPN Forms In-House Ad Unit
description: UPN, the fledgling broadcast television network in Los Angeles, has formed an in-house advertising sales division. Perri Stein, 40, becomes senior vice president for advertiser sales and will be based in New York; there will also be regional offices in Chicago and Detroit. Ms. Stein joins UPN after 17 years at NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, where her most recent position was vice president for news sales.

title: Rangers Silence Stadium By Turning the Power On
description: In the days leading up to the Yankees' playoff opener against the Texas Rangers last night, they talked about how difficult it might be for the Rangers to play in the devil's den masquerading as Yankee Stadium. The Rangers would be playing a post-season game for the first time in their 25-year history, and it was too bad for them that they had to do it at Yankee Stadium. The poor unsuspecting visitors were in for perhaps the most traumatic experience of their lives.

title: Kemp Seeks To Narrow Gap With Women
description: From school choice to extra tax breaks to lower crime, Jack Kemp proffered a luxurious bouquet of pledges today in pursuit of the votes of women, who have tended to spurn the Dole-Kemp Republican Presidential ticket.

title: Ethics-Unit Overhaul Urged
description: An independent state agency yesterday called for the overhaul of a commission that was established to enforce ethical standards for members of the state administration.

title: Justices Agree to Hear Challenge to Georgia Law Requiring Drug Tests for Candidates
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear a constitutional challenge to a Georgia law that requires candidates for many state offices, including those of governor, state legislator and justice of the State Supreme Court, to pass a drug test as a condition of appearing on the ballot.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Patterns column on the Fashion page on Sept. 24 about speculation that Alexander McQueen will become the head designer for Givenchy misstated his age. He is 27, not 23.

title: U.S. Is Recruiting American Police to Join U.N. Force in Haiti
description: Stepping up its commitment to maintaining public order in Haiti at a time of growing insecurity there, the United States is recruiting American police officers for deployment as part of an existing United Nations peacekeeping force in that Caribbean nation.

title: M.L. Rosenthal Memorial
description: A memorial for the writer and teacher M. L. Rosenthal will be held on Saturday at 2 P.M. at New York University Law School, Vanderbilt Hall, Greenberg Lounge, 40 Washington Square South. Mr. Rosenthal died in July at 79. Among the friends and colleagues scheduled to speak at the gathering, which is open to the public, are the writers E. L. Doctorow, Sally M. Gall, Grace Schulman, Robert Stone, Barry Wallenstein and Theodore Weiss.

title: In Mamet's 'Edmond,' a Man on Empty
description: The great dumb-blonde performance in many New York seasons can (and definitely should) be seen at the Atlantic Theater Company these days. It comes not from a cushion-curved babe with a Marilyn manner but from a tall, big-shouldered man with the look of a golden Labrador retriever.

title: Football Player Mourned
description: About 2,000 mourners crowded into the Cornerstone Church of Christ yesterday for the funeral of Tahid Ramsey, a Snyder High School football player who died on Sept. 24. ''It was moving experience for many of the young people who admired him so much,'' said the Rev. Grady Dale, the pastor of the church. After an emotional two-and-half-hour service, the 17-year-old senior and team captain was buried at Bayview Cemetery. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Compromise Is Offered on Computer Security Codes
description: The Clinton Administration offered a compromise to the computer industry yesterday by holding out the possibility of removing all export restrictions on data-scrambling technology for companies that accept a new approach to allow law enforcement officials to unscramble coded messages. The new system is being recommended by an alliance led by I.B.M..

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Afghanistan's New Rulers Soft-Pedal Their Hard Line
description: After a harsh beginning that included hanging the corpse of the country's last Communist President in a public square, Afghanistan's new Muslim fundamentalist Government set out today to present a more congenial image to the world, in particular the United States.

title: The Mouse That Ate America
description: Having given us a theme-park America, it only follows that Disney is throwing itself a theme-park version of the Bicentennial -- a 15-month celebration of the 25th anniversary of Walt Disney World in Orlando.

title: Party Line on Environment
description: The 13 members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation voted mostly along party lines last year on 14 measures of concern to environmentalists, the New Jersey Environmental Federation said yesterday. At the top of the list were two Democrats, Frank Pallone Jr. of Long Branch and Rob Andrews of Bellmar, followed closely by Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood. Mr. Torricelli's opponent in the United States Senate race, Richard A. Zimmer of Delaware Township, was tied with Marge Roukema of Ridgewood as fourth worst, the group said.

title: Leave Abortion Issues to Medical Profession
description: To the Editor:

title: Earlier, and Better, Education
description: A task force of the Carnegie Corporation has recommended that virtually all children in the United States be enrolled in a preschool program at age 3 to improve their prospects for success in school and, ultimately, in life. Unfortunately, the task force did not estimate the total cost of such a program or suggest who should pay the bill, so its proposal is less a call for immediate action than a sensible long-term goal that deserves serious attention from policy makers and parents.

title: Report Cites Wetlands Threat
description: The Hudson-Raritan Estuary is a spawning ground for most species of mid-Atlantic fish and a nesting place and migratory rest stop for many types of birds. But the estuary, a series of bays and tidal rivers formed by the Hudson, Hackensack, Passaic, Raritan and Rahway Rivers, has lost 80 percent of its wetlands habitat to development, according to a report released yesterday by the American Littoral Society, an environmental group. The loss poses a threat to the wildlife that depends on it, the report said.

title: Surprise Changes For 2 Accounts
description: Two marketers and their agencies unexpectedly agreed yesterday to part company.

title: U.S. and France Face Off on Control of NATO Southern Command
description: PARIS  The United States and France are locked in a dispute about continued U.S. control of NATO's southern headquarters in Naples  a post that involves command of the U.S. 6th Fleet in the Mediterranean and has always been held by an American admiral.

title: A Dish That Is Easily Assimilated
description: This is the ultimate fusion dish: black-eyed peas from the South, a pepper from Mexico, and bok choy, fermented black beans, soy sauce, sesame oil and ginger from China.

title: Israelis vs. Palestinians: A Clash of 'Others'
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: Some have called Dallas's newest tourist attraction sick, but that has not dampened its success. For $25, Paul Crute will drive you in an open-top black limousine along the route President John F. Kennedy was following on Nov. 22, 1963, when he was assassinated.

title: No Defense Witness In Tennis Pro's Death
description: Lawyers for a pool mechanic charged with criminally negligent homicide in the death of Vitas Gerulaitis, the tennis star, rested their case today without calling any witnesses.

title: Bates Spinning Off Affiliate in Germany
description: Scholz & Friends in Hamburg, Germany, which has operated under the aegis of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C., said yesterday that it would be spun off as an independent agency under Cordiant.

title: British Labor's New Model
description: Only a few years ago, Britain's Labor Party seemed locked into a decline as inexorable as that of the coal mines and smokestack factories whose workers built its ranks. Now it has rebounded to a healthy lead in the polls based on a modernized, middle-class platform far removed from the old Socialist themes of nationalization, union power and unilateral nuclear disarmament.

title: Conflicting Dreams of Arabs and Jews Stoke Rage in Hebron
description: Hebron, with its pale stone houses, crumbling archways and sacred monuments, chafed under an Israeli-imposed curfew today while Israeli and Palestinian officials meeting in Washington worked to shape the next phase of this ancient city's existence.

title: AT&T Ready To Roll Out New Wireless Phone Service
description: The AT&T Corporation is expected to announce today that it will introduce a new generation of digital, wireless telephone service in 40 markets across the country within the next several months, according to several people familiar with the company's plans.

title: Con Ed Offers To Hold Rates For Five Years
description: The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday proposed a five-year freeze on electric rates and radical changes in operations that would allow all customers to purchase power from other suppliers by 2003.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about circulation at two striking Detroit newspapers misstated the average daily circulation for The Detroit Free Press for the period ended March 31. It was 351,438, a drop of 32 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier, not 251,438.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Jordan Dedicates Institute
description: The Chicago Bulls' MICHAEL JORDAN returned to the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill yesterday to dedicate the school's new institute for families, which will bear his name.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Thinking Big in Boston

title: Deal Confirmed for Blue Cross of Connecticut
description: In the latest salvo in the battle for the growing New York-area health care market, Anthem Inc., a big insurance holding company based in the Midwest, confirmed yesterday that it planned to add Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut to its Anthem East unit.

title: Norway's Third-Largest Conglomerate Formed
description: Aker A.S.A. and Resource Group International said yesterday that they would merge, forming the third-largest industrial company in Norway, with $3 billion in annual sales. The merger brings together one of Norway's most venerable companies with a fast-growing new company. Aker, a leading construction company, has roots in shipyards founded in the 1850's. (AP)

title: Camp Calipari Is for Optimists
description: It looked like a typical day of training camp, but the feeling was different. It was John Calipari's opening practice as the Nets coach. And after a successful eight-year run at the University of Massachusetts, Calipari enters his rookie season in New Jersey with as much to prove as any of his players.

title: JUDGE TURNS BACK EFFORT BY PEROT TO JOIN DEBATES
description: A Federal district judge today rejected Ross Perot's argument that the Presidential debates should be halted unless he was included, ruling that Mr. Perot had neither a legal nor a constitutional right to be part of this year's debates.

title: Both Epic and Feminist, From India
description: ''Fire'' may be a film, but its story of frustrated desires, love-starved women and the stifling bonds of tradition makes it resemble one of those fat best-selling novels that can fill a summer day at the beach with hours of undemanding pleasure.

title: Cuban Exile Says Festival Capped Lens
description: WITH a smile and a bow, Leon Ichaso handed out leaflets to the opening-night crowd at the New York Film Festival Friday night. Most people milling about the entrance to Alice Tully Hall took the handout, although a few stared straight ahead and strode by without wasting an ounce of New York cool.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARTHUR L. CARTER, the publisher of The New York Observer, has established a scholarship fund for journalism students at New York University to be known as, no surprise, The New York Observer Scholars Program. It is housed in, again no surprise, Arthur L. Carter Hall, headquarters for the university's journalism department. Provided with an initial four-year grant of $240,000, the fund will help four undergraduate and two graduate students a year.

title: Hours Before the Game, The Beer Starts to Flow
description: It was an early crowd. Very early. Like, it wasn't 5 o'clock yet. But there they were, hundreds of beer drinkers crammed around the bar at Stan's Sports Bar and Restaurant at 158th Street and River Avenue in the Bronx, in crucial proximity to Yankee Stadium, where the Yankees' game against the Texas Rangers would begin in something more than three hours.

title: Debt Agreement For Eurotunnel
description: The British-French Eurotunnel group, which operates a train link from England to the Continent has reached an agreement with 225 mostly British and French banks to restructure its estimated $14 billion debt, news reports said tonight.

title: Brooklyn Voters Will Get 2d Chance to Cast Ballots
description: Seeking to remedy election foul-ups that he said prevented or discouraged thousands of people from voting in last month's primary, a Federal judge ordered yesterday that scores of voting sites in Brooklyn be reopened on Oct. 10 to allow additional balloting.

title: Pettitte Will Try to Fill Familiar Role: Savior
description: When Yankee Manager Joe Torre chose David Cone to start the first game of the division playoff series against the Texas Rangers, nary an eye was batted. Not even by Andy Pettitte, the likely American League Cy Young Award winner.

title: From Graveside Grass, Back to Obsessive Love
description: THE BOOKSELLER

title: Co-op Boards' Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Kemp Misses Opening of Camp
description: Unhappy with his $3 million salary this season and unsure when he will join his teammates, SHAWN KEMP did not show up yesterday at the opening of the Seattle SuperSonics' training camp.

title: 3 MORRISON KNUDSEN EXECUTIVES RESIGN
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Denis M. Slavich, and two other executives had resigned. A month ago, Morrison Knudsen, the construction company based in Boise, Idaho, that built the Hoover Dam, won court approval for a reorganization that eliminated $360 million of debt and paved the way for the merger with the Washington Construction Group. Stephen G. Hanks, executive vice president and chief legal officer, will serve as acting chief financial officer, while the company searches for a permanent replacement for Mr. Slavich. Also, Thomas F. Kealey, senior vice president, and Gregg Crockett, vice president and controller, resigned to work at another company.

title: At the Nation's Table: Boston; The Sandwiches Of the Chefs
description: Just one block from Newbury Street, where trendy diners fight for tables at Boston's stylish restaurants, the average patron can walk into the Parish Cafe, slip into a seat at a sidewalk table and sample creations from the best chefs in town for as little as $7.95. The cooks may not be in the kitchen, but their favorite sandwiches are.

title: Spending Bill as Magnet
description: In the rush to adjourn, Congress's spending bill attracted an array of items, even with half of the proposed add-ons dropped. Page A12.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the impact of an increase in the minimum wage referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of people whose pay was expected to rise immediately. It was 4.2 million, not 2.6 million.

title: Defense to Use Alcohol As Issue in Rape Trial
description: Alex Kelly's lawyer began to outline a defense today that would claim a woman making rape charges drank excessively before engaging in consensual sex with Mr. Kelly 10 years ago.

title: Roundabout Postpones A Revival of 'Cabaret'
description: The Roundabout Theater Company said yesterday that its revival of ''Cabaret'' scheduled for January was being postponed because a deal to present the show in a cabaret space had failed.

title: Dole Plans Bus Tour Through New Jersey
description: In what would be his first bus tour in this campaign season, Bob Dole plans to roll through New Jersey on Monday and Tuesday in hopes of building support among swing voters and securing his Republican base in the state, campaign aides said.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: When Radio Ruled the Airwaves And Small Stations Thrived

title: Sensing a Lack of Respect, Cowboys Show Their Mettle
description: Apparently the talk of the Cowboys' demise was just a bit premature. Dallas, the defending Super Bowl champion, showed what it is made of Monday night when it rolled into a hostile Veterans Stadium, staked the Philadelphia Eagles to a 10-point lead, then ripped off 20 unanswered points and held on for a 23-19 victory.

title: Of Cutting Boards and Cleanliness
description: IS zapping a wooden cutting board in the microwave oven the best way to disinfect it? It depends on whom you ask.

title: Moneta Sleet Jr., 70, Civil Rights Era Photographer, Dies
description: Moneta Sleet Jr., who brought his camera to a revolution and ended up capturing many of the images that defined the struggle for racial equality in the United States and Africa, died on Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 70 and best known for his Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph of the funeral of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: A Venerable Spot Celebrates 20 Years
description: The Gordon restaurant didn't exactly get off to a rousing start. The first chef quit before the opening, and the second, armed with a butcher's knife, was last seen chasing a waiter down a nearby alley. For a sophisticated restaurant located in a neighborhood known more for pornographic bookstores than haute cuisine, it was hardly an auspicious beginning.

title: Israelis vs. Palestinians: A Clash of 'Others'
description: To the Editor:

title: Umpires Report to Work, but the Alomar Affair Is Not Over
description: Under a deal brokered by a Philadelphia judge, the umpires went to work yesterday -- 17 minutes late. However, their dispute with the American League over the suspension of Roberto Alomar for spitting in an umpire's face is far from over. If Alomar does not withdraw his appeal of the five-game suspension, which he may do, the lawyers almost certainly will be back in court on Friday.

title: Harold Claassen, Sports Editor, 75
description: Harold Claassen, a newspaper man for 45 years in New York who headed sports departments at both The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times, died yesterday at Lee Memorial Hospital in Fort Myers, Fla., following a long illness stemming from cancer complications. He was 75.

title: Speaking Up for Immigrants
description: At a time of rising attacks on immigrants as a blight on American life, it is certainly fitting for the Mayor of New York City to stand up for the values symbolized by the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's recent criticism of the new Federal welfare law, which cruelly cuts off basic social services even to legal immigrants, is welcome because it springs from much more than tradition and a spirit of charity. Mr. Giuliani rightly argues that punishing immigrants is self-defeating. It violates basic constitutional principles and overlooks the valuable economic and social contribution that immigrants make every day.

title: SOUTHERN SWITCHES TO JOINT BID FOR CAJUN ELECTRIC
description: The Southern Company has dropped its $1.04 billion bid for the bankrupt Cajun Electric Power Cooperative Inc. and joined a rival offer by the Northern States Power Company and the Zeigler Coal Holding Company. Together, the three companies offered $1.09 billion in an amended bid filed on Monday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Baton Rouge, La., where Cajun is operating under Chapter 11 protection. In June, Southern became the fourth energy company to submit a reorganization plan for Cajun. The field also includes the Enron Corporation, the Entergy Corporation and the Central and South West Corporation. The Zeigler-Northern States bid had already won the approval of the trustee overseeing Cajun's sale.

title: 2d Breast Cancer Gene Found in Jewish Women
description: A BREAST cancer gene, which geneticists had considered rare, now turns out to occur in 1 percent of Jewish women of Eastern and Central European origin.

title: Europeans to Fight U.S. Sanctions Against Cuba in Trade Court
description: In a rebuff to the Clinton Administration five weeks before the election, the European Union said today it would challenge in a new court of world trade the American law that has imposed sanctions on foreign companies doing business with Cuba.

title: In the spirit of autumn, discount airlines are offering a bounteous crop of low-priced fares.
description: THERE is now a harvest of low air fares to be reaped in markets in the Eastern third of the country, thanks to yesterday's start of Delta Express, the ambitious low-cost carrier arm of Delta Air Lines, as well as the resumption of flights by Valujet on Monday.

title: AMERICA ONLINE SHARES DROP ON EARNINGS FORECAST
description: America Online Inc. shares fell about 10 percent yesterday after the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that on-line and Internet rivals might cut into its earnings and revenue. Competition might force America Online to cut prices or increase marketing expenses, and it could lead to lower subscription growth and revenue, the company said. Shares of America Online fell $3.50, to $32, in trading of 5.4 million shares. The company's shares have lost more than half their value in the last four months because of investor concern about competition from rival services and direct-access providers.

title: Gaetti and Stottlemyre Get Cards Off to a Good Start
description: Gary Gaetti grew up in nearby Centralia, Ill., a fan of his beloved St. Louis Cardinals. But instead of being a hometown hero when he played here during the post-season nine years ago, he was viewed as a villain for helping the Minnesota Twins beat St. Louis and win the 1987 World Series.

title: Turkish Premier's Travels Raise Eyebrows in West
description: Pressing his campaign to forge closer ties with Muslim nations and evidently unconcerned about foreign and domestic criticism, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan of Turkey leaves on Wednesday on a trip that will take him to Libya and Nigeria.

title: Progress Is Reported in G.M. Contract Talks
description: The General Motors Corporation and its main American and Canadian unions are making steady progress in negotiations to produce new national labor contracts and to resolve disputes over the company's planned sale of auto parts factories, people close to the talks said today.

title: Court Orders Polls To Reopen in Brooklyn
description: Seeking to remedy polling-place foul-ups that he said prevented or discouraged thousands from voting in last month's primary, a Federal judge yesterday ordered scores of voting sites in Brooklyn to reopen on Oct. 10 to allow additional balloting. The order involves a dozen legislative and judicial contests in Brooklyn that were affected when hundreds of voting machines were delivered late.

title: Israelis vs. Palestinians: A Clash of 'Others'
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Scientists and Their Quadrennial Day in the Sun
description: With the election campaigns approaching their final month, some of the nation's 12,000 political scientists are enjoying their quadrennial semester of popularity.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about the performance of markets in the third quarter, referred incorrectly in some editions to the State Street Capital Markets Corporation, a market maker for two stocks that were among the quarter's biggest decliners. It is independent; it is not a unit of Metropolitan Life Insurance.

title: Pataki Defies Some Allies On Violence In the Home
description: Defying conservative allies, Gov. George E. Pataki signed an executive order today creating a task force to investigate domestic violence cases that could involve gay or unmarried couples.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Islanders' Rebuilding Begins With Defense
description: Long-suffering fans are not supposed to cry the familiar refrain, made popular long ago by the Brooklyn faithful, until the end of the season. That said, forgive the impulse of Islanders followers this season who might feel the constant need to blurt out, ''Wait till next year!''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rise to Records, With Dow Topping 5,900

title: All Is Forgiven (Even Alomar) as the Orioles Hammer the Indians
description: It was close. But it wasn't exactly unconditional love, not when certain requirements had to be met.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Emphasizing the Beauty Despite Terrible Sadness

title: High Court to Decide if the Dying Have a Right to Assisted Suicide
description: Entering a profound debate over the role of law and medicine at the end of life, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution gives terminally ill patients a right to a doctor's assistance in hastening death.

title: New Chairman At Continental
description: Continental Airlines Inc. said today that David Bonderman had stepped aside as chairman, a sign that the turnaround of the once-bankrupt carrier was complete.

title: Israelis vs. Palestinians: A Clash of 'Others'
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Into Colombia Jetliner Crash Urges More Automation
description: The National Transportation Safety Board concluded today that additional cockpit automation might have prevented the crash of an American Airlines jet that hit a mountain near Cali, Colombia, last Dec. 20, killing all but 4 of the 163 passengers and crew members on board.

title: Reebok is paying $13.5 million for a prime site in Canton, Mass., for a new headquarters.
description: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL Ltd. has agreed to buy 42 acres of land in this town southwest of Boston for a new headquarters complex that is expected to go into construction early in 1998.

title: Dole Stages a Dress Rehearsal for the Debates
description: Bob Dole turned his attention today to next Sunday's Presidential debate, staging his first full-run practice session in Washington and using a speech here to test themes for the coming encounter.

title: No Headline
description: ''The Israeli Government has spent the last few weeks insulting us and laughing in the face of our leaders, and they now want to break their own peace agreement and give us less than they promised.''

title: Suddenly, All the Pressure Is on the Yankees
description: David Cone crouched on the mound, turned his tired eyes toward the left-field fence to watch another home run drift into the dark night. He looked lost. It was supposed to be a special night for Cone, a night when his comeback story added another chapter and he could catapult the Yankees over the Rangers in the opener of their division series. Instead it was just a dark night. Dark and dreary.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: Voting Procedure Challenged
description: Lawyers for the Democratic State Committee will seek a Federal court order today to block a rule that they contend will discourage many poor people from voting in the Nov. 5 election.
