Under the guidelines, people whose residency is questioned by poll workers on Election Day will be required to go to the municipal clerk's office and present proof of their address before they can vote.

title: Gynecologist Loses Appeal for License
description: A Manhattan gynecologist whose license was revoked for negligence and incompetence in performing abortions lost an appeal to have his professional rights reinstated, the State Department of Health announced yesterday.

title: HFS NEGOTIATES TO BUY SECOND CAR RENTAL COMPANY
description: HFS Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating to buy a second car rental company as it nears completion of its $800 million purchase of Avis Inc. HFS's chief executive, Henry Silverman, declined to name the second company, but said he had been talking with three companies and hopes to announce the acquisition this year. HFS, in Parsippany, N.J., plans to complete the acquisition of Avis this month. The franchiser of hotels and real estate companies plans to sell 75 percent of Avis to the public next year. HFS's stock rose $3.50, to $70.50 a share.

title: Laura Epstein Social Work Educator, 82
description: Laura Epstein, an educator in social work who was retired from the University of Chicago faculty, died on Sept. 18 at her home in Chicago. She was 82.

title: DESTEC ENERGY CONSIDERS SALE, LIFTING ITS STOCK
description: Shares of struggling Destec Energy Inc. jumped almost 15 percent yesterday after the company said it was considering putting itself up for sale. Houston-based Destec, which is 80.7 percent owned by the Dow Chemical Company, said it had retained Morgan Stanley & Company to explore strategic alternatives for the company. Destec's earnings were dealt a blow after Houston Industries' Houston Lighting and Power Company did not renew a 10-year supply contract in 1994, and the Texas Utilities Company ended 10-year pacts in 1994 and 1995. In 1995, Destec's net income dropped to $34.7 million, from $110.5 million the year before. Shares of Destec rose $1.75, to $13.625.

title: Growing Pains at Micron Technology
description: Is Micron Technology Inc. finally growing up? That would seem to be the way to interpret Monday's announcement that three of the company's top managers had resigned from the board. According to the company, a memory-chip maker, the move will make way for new directors ''who can bring added outside industry expertise and experience.''

title: Please Don't Squeeze the Rock-and-Roll
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk
description: WHEN the conversation turns to Bordeaux wine, it's only a matter of time before someone brings up the classification of 1855. That was the ranking of top wine properties created by the Bordeaux Chamber of Commerce at the behest of the Exposition Universelle, a fair held in Paris that year.

title: Sense of Unity Is Showing Strain As Europe's New Currency Nears
description: As the pressure mounts on European Union members to qualify for monetary union in 1999, hopes for a happy family of nations sitting down together to share a common currency have dimmed this week amid another outburst of nasty infighting.

title: Apple Officer Sees Return to Profitability
description: The chief financial officer of Apple Computer Inc. said today that the company could return to profitability as soon as December as a turnaround plan improves Apple's gross margin.

title: The President and Congress: A Partnership of Self-Interest
description: As President Clinton bids the departing Republican 104th Congress godspeed and good riddance, he can reflect on having shared more legislative success with it than with the Democratic 103d Congress.

title: Eagles on Lookout for a Quarterback
description: While the Giants went through a one-hour practice today and the Philadelphia Eagles, their next opponent after this bye week, did classroom work, the Eagles' front office was working the phones looking for a quarterback.

title: NETANYAHU HOLDS TALK WITH ARAFAT FOR THREE HOURS
description: The Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, met face to face for three hours today at the White House and will meet again on Wednesday. The White House called the meeting constructive, but officials refused to provide details about the private conversation, which did not involve American officials.

title: French Far Right Thrives on Outrage
description: It is a ploy at which Jean-Marie Le Pen is now an acknowledged master. He makes statements certain to be attacked as racist or xenophobic by French newspapers and mainstream political parties. Once assured of the spotlight, the tart-tongued leader of the far-right National Front says he was misinterpreted, then turns his guns on the entire political establishment.

title: Raiders Still Fumbling The 'Football Thing'
description: Tomorrow makes it seven years to the day that Art Shell was named head coach of the Raiders, replacing Mike Shanahan. The Raiders had started 1-3 in 1989, they were playing the Jets and Shanahan was sacked after 20 games and an 8-12 record.

title: Banco Bilbao Buys Argentine Bank
description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya S.A. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in Banco Frances del Rio de Plata for $350 million. The move gives Spain's second-largest banking company, based in Bilbao, management control of Argentina's third-largest bank and enables it to take advantage of lending margins that are wider in South America than in Spain. Banco Bilbao also gains control of Argentina's top pension fund manager and expands into the southern part of the continent.

title: Key Witness Alters Her Testimony in Death Row Case
description: An important defense witness in the case of a former radio journalist and Black Panther now on death row testified today that she had seen two other men fleeing the scene where a police officer was shot to death but had withheld that evidence during his trial in 1982.

title: Squeeze Play By Umpires Is Justified
description: SEVENTEEN minutes. That's not long by baseball standards these days. Players kill 17 minutes just adjusting their uniforms. Television commercials nibble extra minutes between innings.

title: Knicks About to Add Players
description: The Knicks are about to add two or three more players to their training camp roster, including the 6-foot-11-inch journeyman center ERIC LECKNER.

title: Immigrants' Burden
description: In the last seven years, I have devoted considerable energy to support the creation of open societies in the former Soviet bloc. In those countries, the meaning of open society was easy to explain: It was the opposite of Communism. Open society was the United States, a country characterized by a reliance on the rule of law, a democratically elected government, a diverse culture and respect for people who are different. The truth, of course, was always more complicated. Yet the image and the ideal were inspiring, and they remain so to this day.

title: Council Says Citizen Mail Goes Ignored By Agencies
description: The City Council released a survey yesterday showing that many city agencies are failing to follow a basic tenet of public office: Always answer the mail.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELL COMPUTER CORP., Austin, Tex., a maker of personal computers, said it planned to open a second United States plant in Austin, increasing its payroll by more than 1,000 workers.

title: The Sandwiches Of the Chefs
description: Just one block from Newbury Street, where trendy diners fight for tables at Boston's stylish restaurants, the average patron can walk into the Parish Cafe, slip into a seat at a sidewalk table and sample creations from the best chefs in town for as little as $7.95. The cooks may not be in the kitchen, but their favorite sandwiches are.

title: Biosys Chapter 11 Filing
description: Biosys Inc., a biotechnology company, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because it has been unable to alleviate a chronic cash shortage. The company said it could not raise the financing necessary to cover losses from poor operating and market conditions. The company, which filed for reorganization last Friday, said it would operate as a debtor-in-possession and intended to formulate a plan of reorganization or liquidation.

title: Now Labeled as No. 3, Harvard Ponders Its Fall
description: Harvard is used to being No. 1. So it came as a rude shock to students when U.S. News and World Report, in its annual college ratings guide, ranked Harvard not first among national universities, as it has since the rankings started seven years ago, but a dismal third.

title: Leave Abortion Issues to Medical Profession
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, a Chocolate Souffle That's Ready in 13 Minutes
description: AS restaurant patrons, New Yorkers are demanding. Just ask Francois Payard, the executive pastry chef at Restaurant Daniel on the Upper East Side. ''Time is very precious in New York,'' he said. ''Diners have to go to theater, to parties. They don't want to wait 15 minutes for a chocolate souffle.''

title: Accounts
description: The Los Angeles/Orange County Mitsubishi Dealers Advertising Association to Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, to handle its account, which had been at Zimmerman & Partners, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which declined to take part in a review. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Suit Settled With Instructor
description: Canada's leading journalism school has settled an unusual case involving a writing instructor suspended last year for revealing that he was a part-time prostitute and for arguing in class that sexual relations between children and adults should be made legal.

title: Personal Health
description: GOOD news may travel fast, but bad news travels faster. Since birth control pills were introduced in the early 1960's, they have been the subject of thousands of reports on their actual and potential hazards. As a result, millions of women harbor a distorted view of the risks that may be involved in taking them and lack an appreciation of their known and potential benefits beyond their undisputed ability to prevent unwanted pregnancies.

title: Israel's Aggression
description: To the Editor:

title: Like Child-Rearing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Estrogen May Help Prevent Osteoarthritis
description: IN addition to protecting against heart disease and osteoporosis, estrogen replacement therapy may have another benefit for postmenopausal women: a large new study suggests that it lowers the risk of osteoarthritis.

title: Former Newsday Editor at Village Voice
description: Don Forst, a veteran newsman who was editor of New York Newsday until it folded last year, was named editor of The Village Voice yesterday.

title: Anti-Artist Fits Nicely In Museum
description: It may simply be that Switzerland has produced few artists of international renown, or perhaps it is that Jean Tinguely personified an anarchic streak buried deep beneath Swiss conventionalism. Either way, having made his name in Paris, New York and Venice as one of his generation's most original sculptors, Tinguely ended his days as a hero in his own land. When he died in 1991, he was even given a state funeral.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: JAZZ
description: Toward Extremes of Intensity, With Two Little-Known Cubans

title: Double Jeopardy for Gingrich
description: How much investigation is one group and one man forced to take? Since 1990, Gopac, a Republican political action committee, has been the subject of one inquiry after another, mostly at the instigation of complaints from Democrats.

title: Quartey And Jones Tune Up For Garden
description: Maybe they are the world's two best fighters. They shared a space on the West Side yesterday, oblivious to each other, perhaps because they will never meet.

title: Son Held in Double Slaying
description: A 30-year-old computer specialist was charged today with murdering his parents on Monday in their home in a fashionable section of Englewood.

title: INSIDE
description: Con Ed to Freeze Rates

title: McCaughey Ross's Husband Is Expected to Buy Weekly Newspapers
description: Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the investment banker who is married to New York's Lieutenant Governor, is expected to announce today that he is purchasing a controlling interest in a chain of weekly newspapers that extends from Manhattan to the East End of Long Island to Washington.

title: Officials Say Mafia Ran Crack Ring In Brooklyn
description: In a case that law enforcement officials said erodes the myth that the Mafia will not stoop to street-level drug dealing, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn announced the arrest yesterday of 40 people believed to be members of a crack-cocaine ring operated by the Lucchese crime family.

title: Please Don't Squeeze the Rock-and-Roll
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: He Must Be a Magician: He Made a Taxi Appear

title: Hebron's Deep History
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARC ROSEN, a cosmetics executive who is married to the actress ARLENE DAHL, spent much of the summer agonizing over the prospect of turning 50.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SAM HASKELL may be a powerful Los Angeles talent agent -- he is a senior vice president and West Coast head of television for the William Morris Agency -- but he has not forgotten his hometown, Amory, Miss.

title: ABC Promotes Anderson
description: ESPN's influence on ABC Sports grew yesterday with the appointment of STEVE ANDERSON as senior vice president of production. Anderson had been an ESPN senior vice president. The move follows by several months the appointment of STEVE BORNSTEIN, the president of ESPN, as the president of ABC Sports. ABC and ESPN are subsidiaries of Walt Disney Company.

title: Unabomber Suspect Indicted By a Grand Jury in Newark
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark yesterday indicted Theodore J. Kaczynski, suspected of carrying out deadly mail-bomb attacks against total strangers for 18 years, on charges that one of his devices killed a North Caldwell, N.J., advertising executive.

title: Singapore Company Buying Airbus Planes
description: Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, signed an agreement yesterday to sell as many as 24 jets in the A320 family to Singapore Aircraft Leasing Enterprise. The order could be worth more than $1 billion.

title: For a First Night at the Met, Pavarotti in 'Andrea Chenier'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's fashionable first-night audience was a blessing to be counted on Monday. The house's production of ''Andrea Chenier'' is scarcely six months old, but what an unhappy affair it is. The three long intermissions provided the evening's principal satisfactions, I am afraid to say. One's heart sank every time the house lights went down.

title: A Militia Leader's New Battle With Authority
description: For years, Bo Gritz, a former Green Beret commando and a leader of the far-right militia movement, has warned of government conspiracies to restrict freedoms and called for upright citizens to arm themselves and move to the Idaho hills to escape government tyranny and survive Armageddon.

title: MICRO WAREHOUSE AGREES TO BUY USA FLEX
description: Micro Warehouse Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire USA Flex Inc., a direct marketer of hardware and software for I.B.M.-compatible PC's, for an undisclosed amount of cash. USA Flex is an affiliate of Comark Inc., a closely held computer reseller based in Bloomingdale, Ill. The company has annual sales of about $100 million. Micro Warehouse, based in Norwalk, Conn., sells microcomputer hardware and software products. Shares of Micro Warehouse fell $2, to $22.75. Its shares also fell on Monday after it said accounting errors might force it to restate earnings for '94 and '95.

title: Israelis vs. Palestinians: A Clash of 'Others'
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Wines: Bigger and Better
description: AS New York winegrowers harvest their grapes, they are benefiting from political and agricultural revolutions that have turned the state into a source of wines that often rival those from France and Germany.

title: Big Merger Set In Health Care For California
description: Furthering the trend toward consolidation in managed care, two big California providers, the Foundation Health Corporation and Health Systems International, announced what they called a merger of equals yesterday, in the process creating a $6.4 billion company with nearly five million members.

title: UNITED DOMINION TO BUY SOUTH WEST PROPERTY
description: United Dominion Realty Trust Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire South West Property Trust Inc. for $312 million in United Dominion common stock. Under the deal, each South West share will be exchanged for 1.0833 share of United Dominion -- provided that United Dominion's average price during the pricing period is $13.875 or more. If that price is less, the exchange ratio will be increased to provide a $15 value for each South West share. The merger will combine South West's 14,975 apartment homes with United Dominion's 41,004 apartment homes. Before the announcement, United Dominion's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $14; South West was unchanged at $13.875.

title: Elderly and Poor Do Worse Under H.M.O. Plans' Care
description: Elderly people and poor people who are chronically ill tend to fare worse in health maintenance organizations, which pay a flat rate for each patient, than in conventional insurance plans, which pay doctors for each service, researchers reported today.

title: Bibi and Bill
description: The date is Nov. 10, 1996. Bill Clinton has just been re-elected President in a landslide. His first foreign visitor is Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. Here's what the President says to him:

title: Soybean Prices Fall Further On Good Harvest Prospects
description: Soybean prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday for the second day as improving prospects for the autumn harvest signaled that lean inventories were set to rise.

title: So Much for History: Texas Wins Game 1 From Yankees
description: The Yankees and Yankee Stadium are probably the best known team and facility in post-season sports history, but last night a team that was playing the first post-season game in its 25-year history walked off the field the winner.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Sunday with an article about Omiya, a small town in Japan, indicated the wrong town. The featured Omiya is nearly 200 miles southwest of Tokyo; a city of the same name is just north of the capital.

title: Bill to Revise Securities Regulations Ready for Clinton
description: The Senate approved legislation yesterday to streamline the regulation of mutual funds, investment advisers and stockbrokers.

title: Essex May Withdraw Funds
description: The First Union Corporation, the state's largest bank, is moving its regional headquarters out of Essex County, but it might not take the county's business with it. The county's Board of Freeholders will discuss a resolution today to withdraw more than $40 million in accounts and pension funds from the bank to protest First Union's impending move from Newark to the suburb of Summit.

title: $221 Million Lagoon Cleanup
description: More than 90 companies and government agencies have agreed to pay $221.5 million to settle a Federal lawsuit and help pay for the cleanup up of a toxic lagoon ordered closed in 1981, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Will the Gods Grant 6 Stars To a Moonlighting Chef?
description: LOTS of people work two jobs these days. And since mid-August, Alain Ducasse, the chef who has earned three stars from the Michelin Guide at Louis XV restaurant in the Hotel de Paris in Monte Carlo, has joined their ranks. Voluntarily.

title: Hill Throws Experience Into Post-Season Ring
description: Ken Hill of Texas, scheduled to oppose Andy Pettitte in Game 2 tonight, pitched for Yankees Manager Joe Torre in 1990 and 1991 when Torre managed in St. Louis.

title: Health and Other Blessings
description: Local community service programs, though they often get little notice, are a vital component of a public television station's lineup. Channel 13 in New York will spend most of this weekend doing live, local broadcasts of this type. The station's third annual Women's Health Day telecast, Saturday from 11:30 A.M. to 8 P.M., will feature medical experts in the studio offering information on women's health matters and a toll-free number that viewers can call for health care referrals.

title: Miami and St. Louis Trade
description: The Miami Dolphins and St. Louis Rams both sought to bolster glaring weaknesses yesterday as the Rams acquired offensive lineman BILL MILNER in exchange for tight end TROY DRAYTON.

title: Richard Carrigan, Scientist, Dies at 90
description: Richard A. Carrigan, a chemist and environmental scientist, died on Sept. 23 at the Tillers, a retirement home in Oswego, Ill., where he lived. He was 90.

title: SERVICEMASTER PURCHASES PREMIER MANUFACTURING
description: Servicemaster L.P. said yesterday that it had acquired Premier Manufacturing Support Services Inc., a provider of maintenance services to auto makers, for an undisclosed amount of cash. The closely held Premier, based in Cincinnati, is expected to report sales of about $90 million in 1996. Its specialty is maintaining the machines, or paint booths, used to paint cars. Premier serves car plants in the United States, Scandinavia, Mexico, Canada, Germany and the Czech Republic. Servicemaster provides housekeeping, maintenance and management services.

title: Course on Election in Making
description: The Presidential race is being examined as it unfolds by an unusual consortium of 11 universities, colleges and high schools in classes developed by a professor of rhetoric at Trinity College in Hartford, where the first debate of the campaign is to be held on Sunday.

title: With Boatmen's Deal, Nationsbank Returns to Its Roots
description: Ever since it was a pipsqueak bank here in central North Carolina, Nationsbank has always thought big.

title: While Lincoln-Mercury may not be trying for a new image, it's sure trying to sharpen the old one.
description: IN the past, the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury division avoided poking fun at those who drove a ''big cushy sofa on wheels,'' as one fresh commercial puts it.

title: Mubarak Says Bitterly That Israel Is Obstinate
description: Showing the bitterness that led him to shun the Middle East summit meeting in Washington, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt assailed Israel today for its ''obstinate acts'' and the ''discouraging'' statements of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Luxurious Dining With Wines to Match
description: Cellar in the Sky, the warmly elegant 60-seat restaurant-within-a-restaurant at Windows on the World, 1 World Trade Center, will start accepting reservations today. The restaurant is scheduled to open on Oct. 22. It will serve a seven-course dinner with five different wines Tuesday through Saturday for $125, plus tax and gratuities. The chef, Marc Murphy, is planning luxurious contemporary food to pair with wines chosen by Andrea Immer, the beverage director. Ms. Immer said an average of $50 worth of wine will be poured for each guest.

title: Russian Army May Prove Unreliable, Official Says
description: Russia's Defense Minister said today that the military was in disarray and warned that the Kremlin may no longer be able to count on it in a crisis.

title: A Heart That Knows The Blues
description: LUNCH isn't something Baby Jane Dexter takes lightly.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: That's Not All, Folks
description: In the increasingly competitive world of children's television, some good news for two cable networks could mean bad news for broadcasters.

title: Chrysler Sets Sales Pace While G.M. Lags
description: The Chrysler Corporation's cars and trucks continued to outsell the rest of the auto industry while the General Motors Corporation reported another month of lackluster sales today.

title: A Tribute to Lynda Gudde
description: A memorial tribute to Lynda Gudde, a choreographer, dancer and painter known for her Expressionist style, will be held on Saturday at 4 P.M. at St. Clement's Church on 423 West 46th Street, Clinton. Ms. Gudde died on Aug. 5 at the age of 54. The event at St. Clement's, where the Gudde Dancers used to perform, will include an exhibition of Ms. Gudde's paintings. Information: (212) 246-7277.

title: Labor Strife and Amputations Roil a Plastics Factory
description: Valerie Yerdon talks in a flat voice with no hint of emotion, describing how she lost the middle finger and index finger of her right hand.

title: Shrinking 'Dateline'
description: Some staff members on ''Dateline NBC'' are questioning NBC's commitment to the program because the network decided on Sunday to squeeze the hourlong news magazine into one 15-minute segment for viewers in about 25 percent of the country.

title: As Navy Divers Move On, T.W.A. Questions Remain
description: With the last concentrated field of wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 largely cleared, dozens of hard-hat divers -- those tethered to a ship on the surface -- donned scuba gear yesterday and fanned out to join the hunt for the last scattered fragments of the jumbo jet.

title: Yanks Looked at Burkett, but Rangers Bought
description: When John Burkett was pitching for the Florida Marlins two months ago, he heard the whispers.

title: Volkswagen Reports Higher Vehicle Sales
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that its sales for the first eight months of 1996 increased 12.7 percent, to 2.66 million vehicles, and that it still expected record sales in 1996. Speaking at the Paris car show, a VW management board member, Robert Buchelhofer, said vehicle deliveries in Western Europe, including Germany, were up 11.3 percent, while German vehicle sales grew 3.1 percent. In the North American market, including Mexico, Mr. Buechelhofer said, vehicle sales were up 14.7 percent while sales in Asia increased by about 22 percent. (Reuters)

title: Treasury Prices Higher On 2 Reports
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, as weaker-than-expected manufacturing and retail sales reports helped ease the concerns of investors that the economy might be growing fast enough to accelerate inflation, which would lead the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates.

title: Half Folk, Half Pop, All Soul
description: The first half of Mercedes Sosa's sold-out concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night was given over to folk music from Ms. Sosa's province, Tucuman, in the north of Argentina. One of the few places where indigenous culture has survived, the province clearly holds a sentimental attraction for Argentines, who absorbed the music with a rapture verging on the religious.

title: Neglect of the Mideast Is No Option for Clinton
description: Bill Clinton would have preferred, his aides said, to do other things.

title: College Board Revises Test to Improve Chances for Girls
description: Resolving a complaint that girls lose out to boys unfairly in the awarding of the prestigious National Merit Scholarships, the College Board has agreed to modify its Preliminary Scholastic Assessment Test, the main determinant in awarding the scholarships, the Federal Department of Education announced yesterday.

title: Jets Have A Willing Substitute For Jones
description: Just what the Jets needed. In their 0-5 season of big salaries and no payoffs, now they have lost Marvin Jones, their gifted middle linebacker, for five or six weeks because of a sprained right knee.

title: Fielder Watches The D.H. Go 0 for 4
description: The delicate decision to start Darryl Strawberry instead of Cecil Fielder as the Yankees' designated hitter in the opener of the division series against the Rangers last night was made on Monday night, but Joe Torre did not reveal it until yesterday.

title: Leave Abortion Issues to Medical Profession
description: To the Editor:

title: Travelers' Pet Peeve: Britain's 'Jailing' of Animals
description: Henrik Sorenson bitterly resented having to put his 12-year-old cocker spaniel, Mr. Bogie, into quarantine. But when he arrived here in June, Mr. Sorenson, an attache with the Danish Embassy, was forced by Britain's tough anti-rabies law to put his pet in a state-accredited kennel for six months.

title: Hamilton Has Knee Surgery
description: The Fran Fraschilla era at St. John's is starting with a limp.

title: Make That Order Coffee With Kitsch
description: The eight-foot coffeepot pouring brown water into a gargantuan mug is a good indicator of what's important at Lynn's Paradise Cafe: breakfast and kitsch. The owner, Lynn Winter, has decorated an entire side of this former grocery store in the Highlands neighborhood of Louisville, Ky., with a mural made of dried Indian corn depicting breakfast's three major food groups -- bacon, eggs and coffee. Out front, a gourd garden sways gently in the breeze as children frolic on colorful concrete pigs and elephants.

title: Reported Crimes Continue to Show Decline
description: With the New York City murder rate plunging for the third year in a row, Police Department crime statistics released yesterday suggest that the city's falling crime rate shows no sign of bottoming out and that the decline in most major crimes has actually accelerated.

title: Giuliani Fails to Find Humor in Joking Remarks About the Bronx by Rangers' Bush
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, New York's chief executive Yankee fan, is always ready to establish a bantering sports rivalry with another mayor or governor whose team challenges his own. Yesterday, however, that rivalry turned chilly when an out-of-town official appeared to challenge something the Mayor holds even more dear: the city's reduction in crime.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the growth of the A. H. Belo Corporation, a media company with properties including The Dallas Morning News, referred incorrectly to the background of Burl Osborne, publisher and editor of the newspaper. He had been managing editor of The Associated Press, not general manager.

title: HCIA falls off the growth curve and the reaction is brutal.
description: GROWTH is treasured on Wall Street, but the reaction can be brutal when a growth story is called into question.

title: Stocks Rise to Records as Dow Hits 5,904.90
description: Stocks rose to records, led by bank and financial shares, as the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 5,900 for the first time and optimism spread that interest rates would not rise and clamp down on profits.

title: Facing the Menace of Totalitarianism
description: The notion that art and politics are profoundly intertwined may seem remote to most Americans, give or take the occasional controversy over government support for the arts. But in Europe, where totalitarian states have trampled on free expression and appropriated the myths and rituals of art to serve their oppressive ends, it is a very different story.

title: Lubovitch's Fluid Language Makes Itself at Home on Ice
description: A versatile ballet and modern-dance choreographer, Lar Lubovitch is also adept as a choreographer for skaters. He demonstrated his expertise in a program called ''An Exhibition of Ice Dancing'' on Sunday night at the Sky Rink at the Chelsea Piers. The event, presented by the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company, featured champion skaters in ice dances from their repertories and two new solos by Mr. Lubovitch for Paul Wylie, a silver medalist at the 1992 Olympics.

title: Dutch Concern Drops Merger Plan With Philips
description: Royal PTT Nederland N.V., the Dutch mail and telecommunications company, said yesterday that it had ended talks with Philips Electronics on merging their cable television businesses. Royal PTT said there were ''insufficient grounds'' for cooperation. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Short Stay, Long Memory
description: Walter Evans Edge Jr. was not the most illustrious alumnus of Westminster School. Enrolling as a senior at the preparatory academy here in 1935, he stayed just a year and never received a diploma. Beyond that, he failed French.

title: Food Notes
description: More Dreesen's Doughnuts

title: Bad Backs and Bear Hunters Win Spending Bill Nooks
description: Buried deep in the 3,000-page catchall spending bill that Congress approved this week is $250,000 that Senator Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican, secured to help native Alaskans hunt polar bears, walruses and sea otters.

title: Decisive Game For MetroStars
description: Tonight could be the end of the MetroStars' inaugural Major League Soccer season, or it could be a ticket to the Eastern Conference finals, if the team can beat D.C. United at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington.

title: 80 Troopers Aiding Force In Bridgeport
description: Reacting to 10 slayings in Bridgeport in the last two weeks, city and state officials said yesterday that about 80 Connecticut troopers had been assigned to help patrol city streets.

title: On Second Thought, U.S. Decides Shipyard Subsidies Aren't So Bad
description: It took six years and endless arm-twisting for American trade negotiators to persuade Japan, South Korea and nearly every European nation to end one of the biggest forms of corporate welfare in the world: billions of dollars in government subsidies for shipbuilders.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Things That Just Won't Grow Up
description: THERE certainly couldn't be many antiques shops like it. All the items at Basil in East Hampton, L.I., are scaled for children (or more likely, for their fantasy-tripping parents). The things are not all old (the Arts and Crafts style bed, crib and high chair, above, are reproductions), but the flavor is definitely period.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Byars Blasts Johnson
description: KEITH BYARS has one big chip on his shoulder pads concerning JIMMY JOHNSON.

title: Indonesia to Contest Auto Trade Complaints
description: Indonesia said yesterday that it would defend its national car policy against complaints to be filed with the World Trade Organization, the Geneva-based group that governs world trade. Both Japan and the United States have said they will take complaints to the trade group. The European Union has expressed similar sentiments in the past.

title: A Rumpled Don Juan Of the Philosophy Set
description: Arnaud Desplechin's ''How I Got Into an Argument . . . (My Sex Life)'' spends three chatty, stubbornly beguiling hours in the company of Paul Dedalus, a man who truly loves women. Both Paul and the film would seem maddening if they weren't so passionately sincere, and if Paul did not gaze at the film's many beautiful young actresses with such an amazed, seductive gleam in his eye. Though the disheveled Paul (played with sly panache by Mathieu Amalric) is no matinee idol, it's not hard to see why he has three hours' worth of love and friendship to dissect here. His character burns with rueful romanticism and the film does too.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NOVACARE INC., King of Prussia, Pa., a health care concern, agreed to buy Advanced Orthopedic Technologies Inc., West Hempstead, L.I., a provider of rehabilitation care, for about $14 million plus assumed debt.

title: Torricelli Role Over Fugitive Is Questioned
description: The race for Senate took an unusual turn today, as the Democratic candidate, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, was forced to explain the role he played in helping the daughter of a fugitive businessman charged with bank fraud.

title: Torre Relies On Veterans, And Jeter, Too
description: By the time the Yankees ended the regular season, Manager Joe Torre seemed to have such riches on his bench that nearly every position had veteran players stacked in pairs, a roster of illustrious names fitting for a team with a $55 million payroll.

title: Escape in New York: Yankees Come Back
description: Once upon a time, only two days ago, the Yankees seriously pondered the notion of strutting through October and all the way to the World Series. But with the brawny image of Juan Gonzalez's intimidating swing imprinted in their memories Tuesday night and after two more early homers last night, the Yankees were simply pondering survival.

title: Let's Have a Real Debate
description: The Presidential and Vice-Presidential debates this month may or may not decide the election. But one thing is certain: They won't be true debates, and neither were any that preceded them, from Nixon-Kennedy in 1960 to Bush-Clinton-Perot in 1992.

title: Management Shifts At Interpublic Unit
description: The Anderson & Lembke unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies has realigned duties among top executives and reorganized its San Francisco office, which has suffered account losses.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: National Ratings Down
description: NBC's telecast of the Rangers' victory in Game 1 on Tuesday night generated an 8.5 Nielsen rating, down from 10.3 last year when NBC aired four regional games simultaneously. Each national rating point equals 970,000 TV homes. Locally, Dallas posted a 28.6 rating and New York a 19.4, up from a 16.7 for Game 1 of last year's Seattle-New York series.

title: Sony Says Studio Head Has Resigned
description: Alan J. Levine, the president of Sony Pictures Entertainment for the last two years, resigned today amid speculation that he would be replaced by John Calley, a respected longtime producer and studio executive with close ties to some of the industry's top directors.

title: REVCO'S BID FOR BIG B SAID TO DRAW COMPETITION
description: Fighting an unwanted takeover offer from Revco D.S. Inc., Big B Inc. said yesterday that a number of unidentified parties had shown interest in topping Revco's bid. Big B, based in Birmingham, Ala., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the other parties had signed confidentiality agreements similar to the one Revco rejected. They have indicated that they would be willing to pay more than the $15 a share offered by Revco, based in Twinsburg, Ohio.

title: Norwich Life Insurance To Sell Shares to Public
description: The Norwich Union Life Insurance Society of Britain said yesterday that it planned to sell shares to the public next year. Analysts estimated that a stock sale could value the policyholder-owned company at as much as $:3.5 billion ($5.5 billion).

title: U.S. Misled Hungarians in 1956 Revolt
description: To the Editor:

title: California an Early Surprise in the Pac-10
description: Pep rallies? In Berkeley?

title: Whitman Shift on Pollution
description: After months of protests from environmental organizations, the Whitman administration said yesterday that it would withdraw proposed changes to the state's water-pollution standards. A task force will be appointed to make rewriting the regulations ''an inclusive process,'' said Robert C. Shinn Jr., Commissioner of Environmental Protection. Under current regulations, state officials monitor pollutants as they are dumped into waterways. The proposed regulations would have eliminated specific limits on pollutants and fines for repeat polluters. Instead, officials would have been authorized to monitor the general quality of the waterways.

title: British Governor of Hong Kong Takes a Parting Shot at Beijing
description: The last governor in 157 years of British rule of Hong Kong delivered his final policy address to the colonial legislature today, combining a passionate defense of Britain's record with a denunciation of China's intentions toward the territory when its takes control next July.

title: Scandal-Ridden Miami, Facing Sudden Deficit, Is Cutting Back
description: Confronted with a newly discovered deficit amounting to nearly a quarter of the city's annual budget, Miami has frozen municipal hiring and ordered employees who have city-owned cars and cellular telephones to return them.

title: Palestinians Dismayed, Israelis Delighted
description: Palestinian leaders voiced dismay tonight at the results of the Middle East summit meeting in Washington, pronouncing it a failure and warning that it left their relations with Israel in a critical state.

title: Outcome: 'Please, Please' Give It Time
description: What little the emergency Middle East summit meeting of the last two days produced was best summed up in President Clinton's anxious plea to Israelis and Palestinians: ''Please, please give us a chance to let this thing work in the days ahead.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: Chances are RENALDO ABREU won't be tending plants in any of MARTHA STEWART's gardens in the future. Mr. Abreu, who from 1991 to 1995 was a gardener at Turkey Hill Farm, her estate in Westport, Conn., has taken Ms. Stewart to court, contending that she owes him overtime pay for nonhorticultural chores, including washing her cars, walking her dogs and cleaning her cat litter.

title: Dreamlike In Locale, Visual Style And Acting
description: Just when it looked as if there were no more ways to depict world-weary drug dealers under the Florida sun, Nick Gomez turns ''Illtown'' into a sleek metaphysical experiment in visual style. Making a major departure from the more conventionally boisterous tone of his earlier ''Laws of Gravity'' and ''New Jersey Drive,'' Mr. Gomez presents a cool, dreamy gangster's paradise with dark intimations of purgatory at every turn. The golf course where these hoodlums improbably meet would be spooky enough without its proximity to the River Styx.

title: U.S. JETS POUNDED IRAQI ARMS DEPOT STORING NERVE GAS
description: American intelligence reports show that the United States conducted an extensive bombing campaign during the Persian Gulf war against a sprawling ammunition depot in southern Iraq that was later determined to have then contained chemical weapons.

title: 2 1/2-Year-Old Shoots Himself
description: A 2 1/2-year-old boy who had been left alone with his sister, 8, shot himself in the stomach yesterday while playing with his parents' handgun, the police said. The child was being examined at Palisades Medical Center in North Bergen but was expected to survive, said Lieut. Al Oriente of the West New York Police Department. The boy's mother, who left the children unattended while she picked up another daughter at school, is likely to be charged for leaving the gun in a dresser drawer, Lieutenant Oriente said.

title: Donghia Bargains (Really!)
description: YOU wouldn't think to look for bargains from a to-the-trade-only dealer. But the Donghia Furniture and Textiles warehouse sale is worth noting. The public event, this year on Oct. 19 from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., will include fabrics, wallcoverings and furniture. The rattan armchair, shown above with a side chair, is from the discontinued Java line ($150, reduced from $750). Richard Giglio's tropical striped and floral-patterned fabrics (like ''Fast Flowers,'' above) are reduced to $5 to $8 a yard, from $57 to $65. The sale also includes fabrics from Pierre Frey and Manuel Canovas. At 485 Broadway (near Broome Street); (212) 925-2777.

title: From AT&T, A Cellular Service With A Jazzy Name
description: The AT&T Corporation announced with great fanfare yesterday that it would begin offering a new type of wireless telephone service in 40 markets across the country, under the brand name Digital PCS. The only problem is that AT&T's service is not exactly new and it is not actually P.C.S.

title: INTERLAKE SELLING ITS PACKAGING UNIT
description: The Interlake Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its packaging businesses, which had 1995 sales of $141 million, to Samuel Manu-Tech Inc. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The businesses include Interlake's United States plastic strapping and stitching operations and its Acme Strapping, Acme Gerrard and Pakseal businesses in Canada and England. Samuel Manu-Tech, based in Etobicoke, Ontario, makes and sells steel and plastic strapping in Canada and the United States. It also makes tubes and pipes and processes steel. Interlake, based in Lisle, Ill., makes metal powders and jet engine casings.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES BENEFITS COSTLIER THAN EXPECTED
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises said yesterday that the costs of its employee stock and benefits plan would be $19 million more in its third quarter than in the corresponding period a year earlier. The soft-drink bottler, which is 44 percent owned by the Coca-Cola Company, said the increase, which equals 10 cents a share, was caused by a 70 percent rise in its stock price this year, including 32 percent in the third quarter. Coca-Cola Enterprises' stock fell $1.625 a share, to $44, on the New York Stock Exchange. Coca-Cola Enterprises expects to spend less on stock-based compensation and benefits in the future.

title: Traitor's Sights Set on the Big Prize
description: In 1979, when she was 25 years old, Mary Eppler was an actuary analyst for a medical insurance company. She used to sit at her desk in Baltimore while other things besides statistics danced in her head: namely, race horses. So, she did the only sensible thing. She got a job working with horses.

title: Baseball Lures Eyes Of Texas
description: The Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys may still call themselves America's Team. But that begs a burning question here: Are they still Dallas's team?

title: Equipped for Service
description: AS the holidays loom, so do gaps in one's accouterments for home entertaining. Extra serving trays and a place to store or cool the wine are often forgotten until the last minute.

title: A Polka-Dot Defender at Glamour's Gate
description: CURATOR be damned, Arnold Scaasi pushes his hand under a chain-mail dress of coral and turquoise he designed for Mitzi Gaynor in the 1960's. She has let him borrow it for his new exhibition of 235 dresses and gowns at the New-York Historical Society, ''The Joy of Dressing Up: A Retrospective.''

title: Julia Waldbaum, 99, Owner Of a Chain of Supermarkets
description: Julia Waldbaum, an effervescent personification of motherly concern, homey wisdom and business savvy who helped build a supermarket chain from a butter and egg store in Brooklyn, died in her sleep on Monday as her son held her hand in her apartment in Floral Park, Queens.

title: INSIDE
description: Korean Spy Case Escalates

title: Take a Close Look at Dole's Tax Plan Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Europe Learns About Sex Harassment
description: When Iwona, a 21-year-old computer operator, landed a coveted job with a multinational company whose presence in Poland she considered a hallmark of growing economic success, she hoped to rise through the ranks.

title: A Doctor-Artist Adorns a Torah Ark
description: ON Saturday morning, Dr. Mark Podwal will be the center of attention at the Sabbath service at Temple Emanu-El on Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. The occasion will have nothing to do with his life as an Upper East Side dermatologist. Instead, it will be a celebration of his other flourishing career -- that of an artist.

title: Yankees Are Confusing Gonzalez for Gonzales
description: The story will come out eventually, so it might as well be told here first. In the first two games of their playoff series with the Texas Rangers, the Yankees thought they were pitching to Rene Gonzales when it really was Juan Gonzalez.

title: Troopers Aid Police On Streets of Bridgeport
description: About 80 Connecticut troopers have been assigned to help patrol the streets of Bridgeport, city and state officials said. The deployment comes in the wake of 10 slayings in the city in the last two weeks. The official response to the violence was more than an attempt to stanch the blood-letting in a struggling old industrial city. It was an effort to continue an encouraging trend in which crime has been declining for several years as Federal, state and local agencies have redoubled their battle against it.

title: Giants Use Unified Team Theory
description: When Michael Brooks joined the Giants three years ago, he wasn't exactly the friendliest of teammates. Brooks wasn't sure how he would be received after joining the team as a free agent from the Denver Broncos. So, to be on the safe side, for much of that season and on occasion after that, he kept a loaded gun in his locker at Giants Stadium.

title: The states aren't examplars of how to balance budgets.
description: 'Most states are required to balance their books,'' proclaims ''Plan for Economic Growth,'' the Dole-Kemp campaign document. ''Bob Dole believes the Federal Government should be required to do so as well.''

title: Alomar Hearing Is Off, and Umpires May Return to Court
description: The acting commissioner and the lawyer for discontented major league umpires yesterday engaged in sensitive negotiations aimed at keeping the umpires working the playoffs after the cancellation of the hearing scheduled for today on the appeal of Roberto Alomar's five-game suspension.

title: Seizing the Imagination With Moral Questions
description: THE NIGHT IN QUESTION

title: Gore to Explain V-Chip
description: The Clinton Administration's technology buff, Vice President Al Gore, will explain the V-chip and its effect on television to children and their parents during a campaign stop today at the Garfield Free Library, a spokeswoman said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday in the ''American Place'' series, about how the Presidential campaign is playing out in Stark County, Ohio, referred incorrectly to Don Singer, head of the local Job Training Partnership agency, who was quoted as saying, ''This is a place with a lot of independent voters who make up their minds right at the end.'' He is an unpaid adviser to the Clinton campaign in Stark County; he is not running the campaign there.

title: What 'Final Status'?
description: For each of those with an attachment to Jerusalem, there is a different Jerusalem, with a different sacred topography and a different meaning for each site and event. Although Arabs and Israelis live within the same city, each is oblivious to the existence of the other, or at least pretends to be. Each party to this conflict operates in a different dimension from the other, looking back to a different era of the past and living in a different present. And each party has its own name for each site, a usage it tries to impose to strengthen its possession and control.

title: Bank of Scotland Posts 24% Rise in Profit
description: Bank of Scotland P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 24 percent in the first half of the year to $:324.3 million ($507.5 million), up from $:261.6 million a year ago. The earnings were better than analysts had been predicting.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LOUISE BOURGEOIS was asked to create a sculpture for Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Battery Park City, which is being dedicated today.

title: A Scandal, A Scapegoat, An Injustice
description: IT would take more than one column to explore the ramifications of the Board of Education's troubled school-leasing program, better known as the school-leasing scandal. Scandal or program, it involves allegations of overpayment, sloppiness, waste and corruption in the leasing of available buildings to relieve overcrowding in New York City's jammed schools. And those are just some of the problems.

title: ABN Amro Wants to Sell Investment Banking Unit
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V., the Netherlands' biggest bank, said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its Dutch merchant banking unit Mees Pierson N.V. The bank said it had been approached by ''a number of parties.'' Analysts said ABN Amro had made great strides in international investment banking in recent years, while Mees Pierson had not performed as well as expected.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Yankees Owner's Request Irks the Rangers' Wives
description: George Steinbrenner incurred the wrath of some of the Rangers' wives Tuesday night when he asked them to stop standing and cheering during Texas's 6-2 victory over the Yankees. The Yankees' principal owner said they were obstructing the view of other fans in nearby boxes at Yankee Stadium.

title: Fed's Hard-Won Credibility Allows It to Take Small Risks
description: What is credibility worth? For the Federal Reserve, it's worth all the economic pain from nearly two decades of hard work -- and more. And the proof is in the way the market has reacted to the central bank's decision last week not to raise short-term interest rates.

title: Lacing 'Em Up
description: The N.H.L. regular season starts tomorrow night. Here is a scouting report listed in projected order of finish.

title: D.C. Ends MetroStars' Inaugural Season
description: The MetroStars' inaugural season in Major League Soccer is over.

title: It's a Wonderful Find: A 1928 Capra Silent
description: Four years ago, after a film lab in the south of France went out of business, the Cinematheque Francaise was asked to reclaim a stockpile of films it had stored there and practically forgotten. Claudine Kaufmann, who is in charge of inventory and restoration for the Cinematheque, recently recalled that she expected the worst when she and two colleagues were led to an isolated blockhouse nearly overrun with vegetation. But inside they discovered a canister labeled ''Bessie.'' It turned out to hold ''The Matinee Idol,'' a silent comedy directed by Frank Capra in 1928 and for decades considered lost.

title: Korean Spy Case Called More Serious Than Was Thought
description: What appeared last week to be a low-level spying incident between the United States and South Korea has grown into a more serious case, with prosecutors saying today that they would charge an American intelligence analyst with espionage, an accusation reserved for highly damaging breaches of national security.

title: What Connects Kabul to Los Angeles?
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea Delivers Warning in Sub Incident
description: North Korea warned American military officials today that ''serious consequences'' would follow the recent killing of North Korean commandos who sneaked into South Korea by submarine, American officials said.

title: New Rinks, a New City And Old Rule Revived
description: Like a glacier, the ice hockey business moves southward and westward, gradually but relentlessly. Last season's Winnipeg Jets are this year's Phoenix Coyotes. The former Quebec Nordiques are defending the Stanley Cup under their new identity, the Colorado Avalanche, provided to them last fall under the National Hockey League's franchise relocation and protection program.

title: Environmental Dispute Delays Spending Bill
description: The future of Sterling Forest, an undeveloped tract not far from New York City, was tangled up today with questions about logging in the Tongass National Forest in Alaska as a single Senator from that state refused to relax his grip on broad legislation affecting parks and public lands around the nation.

title: Robert Woolley, 52, Unorthodox Auctioneer
description: Robert C. Woolley, a longtime Sotheby's auctioneer who capped his sometimes staid and sonorous career by emerging as a witty and tart-tongued pitchman who wheedled, needled, cajoled and shamed his society friends into spending millions of dollars at charity auctions, died on Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 52.

title: Harassment in 2d Grade? Queens Kisser Is Pardoned
description: A 7-year-old Queens boy who kissed a classmate and tore a button from her skirt was suspended from school for sexual harassment, then reinstated, as chagrined school officials weathered a wave of criticism yesterday and said they would review the school system's harassment policies.

title: Budget Bill Extends Child Pornography to Computer Graphics
description: A little-known corner of the huge Federal budget bill passed on Monday was legislation that updates child pornography statutes by banning computer-generated depictions of children engaging in sexual conduct.

title: Accounts
description: * Royal Crown Co., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a unit of the Triarc Cos., to Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to handle the creative part of the Diet Rite soda account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $6 million. GSD& M, Austin, Tex., part of the GGT Group, had handled those duties and continues handling the media part of the account.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a Critic's Notebook article about a program of Shostakovich's chamber music at the Kaye Playhouse omitted the names of two members of the Manhattan String Quartet. They are Chris Finckel and John Dexter.

title: The No Frontier
description: Everyone is wondering what Jackie would have thought of Carolyn.

title: Johnson Day to Day With Injury To Knee
description: The Jets had a huge scare in practice today when their prize rookie wide receiver, Keyshawn Johnson, bruised and sprained his right knee. Johnson was listed as day to day, and the Jets did not rule him out of Sunday's home game against the Oakland Raiders.

title: Misusing Statistics
description: To the Editor:

title: Detective in Simpson Case Pleads No Contest to Perjury Count
description: Mark Fuhrman, the former Los Angeles Police Department detective whose testimony undermined the state's case in the murder trial of O. J. Simpson, pleaded no contest today in Superior Court to one count of perjury for lying at that trial about his use of a racial slur.

title: Pepper on a Roll Heading Into the Classic
description: Dottie Pepper is the hottest player on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. Not only has she won four of the last nine tournaments she has played, but she played a key role in the United States' victory over Europe in the Solheim Cup competition in Wales last month.

title: Built-In Fantasy: An Aspen Howdunit
description: SOMEWHERE near Aspen, on vast, undulating rangelands where elk and movie stars roam, there exists a house like no other in the world.

title: Prices Rise On Treasury Securities
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose to a six-week high yesterday, thanks to overseas buying and an economic report that fit the pattern of slower third-quarter growth.

title: Friendly's Review Down to 4 Agencies
description: The Friendly Ice Cream Corporation has narrowed a review for the broadcast portion of the account of its Friendly's chain of restaurants to 4 agencies from 10. The account, with billings estimated at $15 million, had been handled since 1988 by Elkman Advertising and Public Relations in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Philharmonic Resuming Live Radio Broadcasts
description: After eight years of radio silence, the New York Philharmonic is to return to the airwaves in January with the first of five concerts to be broadcast live from Avery Fisher Hall.

title: The House That Roars For Yanks
description: JUST as ball players rise to the occasion, so do stadiums.

title: Many Companies Hire Chaplains as Counselors
description: Strolling through a maze of conveyors, blades and packing equipment, the Rev. C. Alan Tyson seems oblivious to the thousands of chickens whirling around him in various stages of dismemberment. As Hudson Foods Inc.'s chaplain, he is focused on an entirely different inventory: the private fears and woes of the 1,600 employees at Hudson's processing plant here in Missouri's southwest corner.

title: Elster Turns Invitation Into a Welcome Party
description: Kevin Elster is like the man who came to lunch and stayed for dinner -- 162 days of dinner and then some more for dessert. In this instance, though, Elster's hosts are delighted that he came and ecstatic that he stayed.

title: L'Carriere Is Out of Gold Cup
description: L'Carriere, who ran second to Cigar twice and third once, suffered an ankle injury yesterday at Belmont Park and will not run Saturday in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: Robert Bourassa, 63, Dies; Led a Turbulent Quebec
description: Robert Bourassa, the former Premier of Quebec who led Canada's most turbulent province through some of its deepest crises and greatest triumphs and who introduced sweeping measures to preserve the province's French culture while firmly supporting unity with Canada, died today at Notre-Dame Hospital in Montreal. He was 63.

title: The Impromptu Mideast Summit
description: There has not been a summit meeting as volatile and unrehearsed as this week's Middle East talks in Washington since Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev briefly ventured into the uncharted territory of nuclear disarmament 10 years ago in Iceland. The precarious nature of the discussions between Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat became clear at a concluding White House news conference yesterday when President Clinton read a cautious statement, then warily answered questions while the Israeli Prime Minister and Palestinian leader sat silently and unsmilingly by his side.

title: Victim Families' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: A Downsized Professor, a Missing Wordsmith and Murder
description: Even a shamelessly overindulgent script can be salvaged, to a remarkable extent, by charming performances. There are two, contributed by Alan Bates and Sinead Cusack, in ''Oliver's Travels,'' a new four-part series on PBS written by Alan Plater (''Fortunes of War''). It rambles on for four and a half hours (tonight's episode is 90 minutes), about twice the length required.

title: Raid May Lead To Questioning On Rap Star
description: More than 20 suspected gang members, including a 22-year-old man the Las Vegas, Nev., police plan to question in the shooting of the rapper and actor Tupac Shakur, were arrested yesterday in raids in the Los Angeles area, law-enforcement officials said.

title: CLINTON SAYS TALK FAILED TO RESOLVE ISSUES IN MIDEAST
description: After an emergency two-day summit meeting, President Clinton said today that Palestinian and Israeli negotiators had failed to resolve any of their differences. But he said they had agreed to begin talks on Sunday on how to carry out stalled provisions from previous agreements -- in particular, Israel's overdue promise to withdraw its troops from most of the West Bank city of Hebron.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Aura of Sham Transactions
description: In the early 1990's, as the end of the cold war reduced the Pentagon's budgets, Aura Systems was one of the many military contractors that set out to raise the amount of civilian business they did. But Aura, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday, showed success in that regard only by engaging in sham transactions.

title: Bravery of Fighters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pop Life
description: Dolly Parton's 'Treasures'

title: Science Center Puts a Scientist at the Helm
description: It's a typical morning at the Liberty Science Center, which means that new things are happening all over the place. Schoolchildren are driving a car with square wheels, while others discover the joys of being a human spark plug. Moviegoers in the Omnimax theater are being pinned to their seats by the next generation of special effects.

title: Light Switches Disguised as Art
description: UNTIL houses are rewired and lights are operated by computer, the mundane light switch is one of those inescapable facts of life. The right switch plate in the right spot can create a stylish moment in a normally forgotten corner of a home.

title: The Bamboo Chair Sings a Sweet Song
description: WHEN William Lipton talks about Chinese bamboo furniture, he sounds more like a philosopher than a merchant. ''They say without meat, a man grows thin; without bamboo, he can't build a house,'' he said this week. ''And when you sit in a bamboo chair, it should sing. You know bamboo chairs were built to make that creaking sound.''

title: Toasting 1956, and a Crop of Fearless Teen-Agers
description: The dilapidated movie theater where Maria Wittner remembers feverishly making firebombs as a young fighter is now renovated with a plaque marking the headquarters of her resistance cell. The Hungarian Radio building where she fed bullets to fellow rebels as they took aim at police snipers is virtually a national monument.

title: Affordable-Housing Patterns
description: Black and Hispanic seekers of affordable housing in New Jersey have been less successful than whites, and the houses they find are more likely to be in urban areas than in suburbs, according to a study released yesterday by Seton Hall University.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In Milan, the Mood Shifts to Romance
description: The great informing principle for designer fashion through the 80's was Cinderella: wear this and you will be transformed.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: U.S. Misled Hungarians in 1956 Revolt
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Oh, Jane, See How Popular We Are'
description: LOOK, look.

title: An Artists' Retreat Is Extending Its Welcome
description: UNIVERSAL design is coming to the Millay Colony, the 600-acre home of the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay in Austerlitz, N.Y., which is now a retreat for artists. Michael Singer, an artist and landscape designer, has planned a new 3,200-square-foot building with a darkroom, two living quarters, a shared kitchen, and a library and composer's studio, all accessible to the disabled. The $400,000 building, scheduled to open in 1997, is part of a larger project that will include gardens with widened and heated paths.

title: It Worked for Swatch ...
description: TWO Swiss marketers, Jacques Irniger and Franz Sprecher, the team that conceived the Swatch watch in 1983, have turned their attention from wrists to table tops. The result is the Boplat collection of plates ($19 to $39), cups and saucers ($24 a set) and mugs ($16). They come in the sort of busy patterns that might have decorated a Volkswagen microbus in 1967. The Fantasia dinner plate (right) is part of a group with animal designs ($27). A Voyage series with an air-transportation motif will come out in November. The dishes are sold as open stock; a limited number of each design is produced, then discontinued. The triple-fired porcelain is made in Langenthal, Switzerland. At Leaf and Bean, 83 Seventh Avenue (Union Street), Brooklyn; (718) 638-5791. For other locations: (201) 983-8777.

title: At WCBS-TV, a Big Round Of News Staff Dismissals
description: WCBS-TV/Channel 2, a perennial third place in the local news ratings race, yesterday dismissed some of its best-known on-air journalists, including anchor persons John Johnson, Michele Marsh and Tony Guida, sportscaster Bernie Smilovitz and reporters Magee Hickey, Roseanne Colletti and Reggie Harris.

title: Voting-Rule Challenge
description: A Federal judge in Newark declined yesterday to block temporarily a rule that the Democratic State Committee contends will discourage many poor people from voting in the Nov. 5 election. Instead, Judge Maryanne Trump Barry told lawyers for the committee and the state that she would issue a permanent ruling tomorrow. Under the guidelines, people whose residency is challenged at the polls would have to go the municipal clerk's office and present proof of their address before they could return to their polling place to vote.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the financier George Soros's pledge of $50 million to help legal immigrants in the United States referred incorrectly to his humanitarian assistance in Bosnia. He offered $50 million in aid in December 1992, suspended it in May 1993 in protest over Western inaction and resumed it in July 1993.

title: Executive Changes
description: DATA BROADCASTING CORP., San Mateo, Calif., which provides financial market data to individual investors, said Mark Imperiale had been appointed president and chief operating officer. Mr. Imperiale, the chief financial officer, will hold that title until a replacement is hired.

title: Japanese Voters, Too, Get a Big Tax-Cut Promise
description: Borrowing a leaf from Bob Dole's briefing book, a Japanese opposition leader tried today to stimulate his sagging campaign by calling for big tax cuts.

title: National Breast Cancer Awareness Month has inspired extensive corporate advertising.
description: National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, observed during October, has inspired national advertising and promotional campaigns worth millions of dollars by companies that traditionally sell to women, like Lee Apparel and J. C. Penney, and others not usually associated with women's issues, like Boston Market.

title: Madeline's Following
description: BEMELMANS BAR at the Carlyle has become a popular place among the black-clad vanguard who work and shop at the European designer boutiques that have colonized Madison Avenue.

title: Union Signs 100,000 to Vote
description: In a voter registration drive aimed at delivering New Jersey to the Democrats, the 980,000-member state A.F.L.-C.I.O. said yesterday that it had registered 100,000 people since Labor Day. ''Organized labor is organized this time,'' said Donald Delio, president of the Mercer County Central Labor Council.

title: No Headline
description: ''Clearly Title IX doesn't reach a little boy kissing a girl. That's not pervasive harassment, it's not a pattern, it's not severe, and sometimes a kiss is just a kiss.''

title: Burmese Champion of Democracy Calls Crackdown Her Victory
description: As a small crowd of plainclothes security men waited in the rain outside, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi today called the military crackdown over the last few days a victory for her pro-democracy movement.

title: 2 Arrested in Mexico In Police Chief's Killing
description: Two men have been arrested and charged with taking part in the murder last month in Mexico City of a top federal police commander who had been assigned to track the Tijuana narcotics cartel, authorities said today.

title: Wet and Mild Texas Fails to Put Yanks Away
description: The inability of the Texas Rangers to take a commanding 2-0 lead in the first post-season series in their history was a case of mist and missed opportunities.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Geraniums From Seed

title: Tentative Debt Accord Rescues Eurotunnel
description: Eurotunnel, the operator of the tunnel under the English Channel, narrowly avoided bankruptcy today with an agreement on the ''basic principles'' of an accord to revamp $12.5 billion in debt.

title: Skirmish in Anti-Drug War: California vs. 'Doonesbury'
description: There are drug wars, and there are drug wars. And then, it appears, there are the pretty-much-symbolic drug-related spats.

title: Dollar Reaches 2 1/2-Year High Vs. Yen and Gains on Mark
description: The dollar rose to a two-and-a-half-year high against the yen yesterday as Japanese investors expressed their preference for American investments over the low interest rates on Japanese financial instruments.

title: United Airlines Narrows Review
description: The United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation in Elk Grove Village, Ill., has further narrowed a review on its account, with billings estimated at $100 million, to four finalists.

title: The Irish Are Ascendant Again
description: ''It is the manifestation of sheer, bloody genius,'' the Irish poet and Nobel Laureate Seamus Heaney said recently, with a laugh, from Adams House at Harvard University. ''Ireland is chic!''

title: Getcha Scorecard!
description: The most powerful person in the world this week is Jim Lehrer, moderator of Sunday night's first Presidential debate.

title: Toys 'R' Us to Purchase Baby Superstore for $407 Million
description: In one of the fastest consolidations of a retail superstore segment, Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the country's largest toy store, said yesterday that it would buy Baby Superstore Inc., for about $407 million in stock.

title: Report Assails School-Leasing Program
description: In another indication of lax controls within the Board of Education's troubled school-leasing program, a report by school investigators released yesterday concludes that the board conducted no systematic background checks of the landlords to whom it paid tens of millions of dollars in recent years for space to relieve severe overcrowding.

title: Dole's Advisers Debate Strategy Over California
description: A struggle has broken out among senior advisers to Bob Dole over whether his campaign should pump millions of dollars into competing in California or divert the money to other pivotal states, particularly in the Midwest, where Mr. Dole may have a better chance of winning.

title: U.S. Marine Corps Retains Thompson
description: The United States Marine Corps yesterday ended a mandated review on its account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, by retaining the J. Walter Thompson Atlanta unit of WPP Group, which has handled the account since 1946. Thompson Atlanta was awarded a one-year contract with four one-year renewal options. There were two other review participants, but their identities were not disclosed.

title: Fans and Henderson Are Awaiting Act II
description: Rickey Henderson hopes to be starting in left field Thursday when the San Diego Padres and St. Louis Cardinals play Game 2 of their three-of-five-game series at Busch Stadium. Henderson also won't mind if the fans in the left-field corner continue to boo and taunt him as they did in Game 1.

title: Strike Begins as Talks Fail With G.M. of Canada
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Canadian Automobile Workers union broke off talks and workers walked off the job at G.M. Canada assembly plants late Wednesday night and early this morning in the latest in a series of costly work stoppages for the company.

title: Company From Queens Buys Bronx Courthouse at Auction
description: The Bronx Borough Courthouse, a landmark Beaux-Arts building that a community group had envisioned as the centerpiece of a redevelopment plan, was bought at a city auction yesterday by an electrical supply company from Queens.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about budget cutting in the 104th Congress misstated the fate of the Japan-United States Friendship Commission. Congress changed the process of appropriating money for the commission, which is financed by a trust fund, but did not kill it.

title: Stakes High as California Debates Ballot Issues to Rein In H.M.O.'s
description: When Californians lament ''the casualty of the day,'' they are not referring to victims of gang violence, drug abuse or reckless driving. Rather, they are referring to people injured or mistreated by health maintenance organizations.

title: Seahawks May Trade Mirer
description: The Seattle Seahawks may be ready to trade RICK MIRER to the Atlanta Falcons for the suspended JEFF GEORGE.

title: Bridge
description: The results of junior competitions are a good way to predict performance at world level. The world junior team title, for players under 26, has been won twice by Britain, and two of its champions, Jason and Justin Hackett, are representing their country later this month on the Greek island of Rhodes. The other winners have been the Netherlands, the United States and Germany.

title: MOBILE-HOME OPERATOR SWEETENS ITS BID
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc., a mobile-home park operator controlled by the Chicago financier Sam Zell, offered yesterday to sweeten its bid for Chateau Properties Inc., another mobile-home company, which is the center of a takeover battle. Any improvement would depend on an agreement by the management of Chateau, which has already pledged to merge with another mobile-home park operator, ROC Communities Inc., to have discussions with Manufactured. Manufactured also extended until Oct. 23 its hostile tender offer to buy Chateau's shares for $26 apiece. So far, about 51 percent of Chateau's shares have been tendered, the company said. Chateau has rejected Manufactured's advances, as well as those of a fourth mobile home operator, Sun Communities Inc.

title: Jersey City Gains Jobs
description: Of New Jersey's major cities, only Jersey City has shown substantial economic growth in the last three years, Rutgers University professors said yesterday. Their study found that jobs in Jersey City rose 17.6 percent between 1992 and 1995, said James W. Hughes, dean of the university's planning school, and Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics. Paterson and Trenton showed modest gains, with Newark and Elizabeth flat. Mr. Hughes attributed Jersey City's growth to the relocation of Wall Street back-office jobs.

title: A 4.8% Rise For Morgan Stanley Profit
description: The Morgan Stanley Group, continuing a robust year, yesterday reported a 4.8 percent rise in earnings for the third quarter.

title: Top Investigators Assess Air Crash Inquiry Options
description: As divers recover the final bits of wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 from the ocean floor, the leading investigators in the case briefed senior Government officials today on their options for the investigation's next stage, including scanning the bottom with sand-penetrating sonar and then scouring it with clam rakes or giant vacuum cleaners.

title: Two 1963 Slayings Still Rouse Passions in Lodi, N.J.
description: The reason is Thomas Trantino.

title: AMENDED BID FILED FOR CAJUN ELECTRIC
description: The Central and South West Corporation and Entergy Inc. said yesterday that they had filed an amended $780 million offer for Cajun Electric Power Cooperative Inc. that has the support of Cajun's primary customers. The cash offer filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Baton Rouge, La., replaces an earlier bid of $405 million in cash and an estimated $500 million in future payments. The companies would pay as much as $20 million more to cover other bankruptcy claims and expenses. Central and South West and Entergy are trying to defeat a higher bid by a partnership of the Northern States Power Company, the Zeigler Coal Holding Company and the Southern Company, which has offered $1.09 billion for Cajun.

title: Hearst to Start for the Bengals
description: KI-JANA CARTER has lost his job.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, A Loft Tour and a Fiesta
description: Rand Retrospective

title: Who's a Centrist? Clinton, According to Helms Ad
description: Needled by Bob Dole as a liberal, Bill Clinton has found an unlikely witness to his centrist credentials in the battleground state of North Carolina: Senator Jesse Helms.

title: Doing a Mirror Dance, Backs to the Glass
description: The Trisha Brown Dance Company danced through an artificial cloud onstage in a stunning revival called ''Opal Loop,'' and Mikhail Baryshnikov made a spectacular local debut with the company.

title: Abducted Boy Who Was Reunited With Mother Is Taken Away Again
description: In another chapter in the case of a 13-year-old boy abducted by his father 12 years ago and reunited with his mother last week, the authorities disclosed yesterday that the boy, Leonard Joseph Cammalleri, had been placed with a foster family in New York City.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Record Bull Market, Any Way You Slice It

title: An Art Collector's Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Rests in Bronx Officer's Murder Trial
