description: Testimony ended yesterday without some much-anticipated courtroom drama in the case of a Bronx police officer accused of murdering a man he was trying to arrest. The defense chose to rest its case without calling the officer, Francis X. Livoti, to the witness stand.

title: The Devils Need Goals To Win Back the Cup
description: The Devils have assembled what is arguably the best corps of defensemen in the National Hockey League. Martin Brodeur is among the elite goaltenders. Coach Jacques Lemaire is a defensive guru. They may be quite capable of blocking shots and preventing goals, but heading into the new season the question remains: how often can the Devils put the puck in the net?

title: Dole Calls for Clinton to Release an F.B.I. Memo on Drugs
description: Broadening his assault on President Clinton's trustworthiness, Bob Dole today challenged Mr. Clinton to release a memorandum by his F.B.I. director that is reportedly critical of White House drug-fighting efforts. Mr. Dole also urged the President to disclose more of his health records.

title: Militia Leader Sought Arrest In Custody Case, He Asserts
description: Bo Gritz, the right-wing militia leader who was charged here this week in a kidnapping case, said today that he intentionally got himself arrested to draw attention to a child custody case in which he says two children were wrongly sent to live with pedophiles.

title: No S.E.C. Fraud Charges Expected on Denver Airport
description: After more than a year of investigation, the Securities and Exchange Commission has apparently decided not to accuse the Denver International Airport and its underwriters of securities fraud in one of its highest-profile municipal bond cases, people familiar with the investigation said today.

title: No More Mutilation
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Credits Tell a Story
description: WITH all the hoopla surrounding the ''The First Wives Club,'' it's easy to miss the first joke: the delightful subversion of the opening credits.

title: For Legal Immigrants, a Welfare Reprieve
description: Congress has given a reprieve to legal immigrants who receive food stamps, allowing them to stay on the rolls until April 1, and a few months longer in many cases, despite provisions of the new welfare law.

title: National Book Award Finalists Named
description: Finalists for the National Book Awards were announced yesterday. This year's competition drew a record level of submissions, with more than 870 titles offered by 214 publishers. Many of the nominated works explore family relationships, in settings that range from Lake Cabora Bassa in Mozambique to the Pocantico Hills of Westchester County in New York.

title: Take a Close Look at Dole's Tax Plan Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fragile Redwood Deal
description: A promising deal has been struck that could resolve a 10-year struggle to save part of what is left of northwestern California's ancient redwood groves. Some environmental activists argue that the deal gives away too much and can never be made to work, and in recent days they have stepped up their protests. Proving them wrong will require a lot more effort by Federal and state negotiators who have already invested heavily of their time. It will also require good faith by a company that is not known for environmental virtue.

title: A Controversy at First As Indians Lose Second
description: It was the umpires again. And another Alomar. This Alomar, though, kept as quiet as the infield grass, laying off the umpires when they did not make a call his team's way today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the wedding of Mortimer B. Zuckerman referred incorrectly to a position held by a guest, Linda Janklow. She is the current chairwoman of Lincoln Center Theater, not the former chairwoman.

title: Van Gundy Addresses Great Expectations
description: Six months ago, he was merely the man who picked up the flag after Don Nelson went down. His future was as uncertain as his limping team's playoff prospects.

title: Former MGM Owner Convicted of Perjury
description: The former owner of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., Giancarlo Parretti, was found guilty yesterday of perjury and evidence tampering by a Delaware Superior Court jury. Mr. Parretti, who lost control of MGM in 1991 soon after buying it with a loan from the French bank Credit Lyonnais, faces as many as 10 years in prison. Sentencing is scheduled for Nov. 18.

title: Police Seek Rapist On Upper East Side
description: The police said last night that they were looking for a man who had sexually assaulted and robbed three women on the Upper East Side over the last two months.

title: Skirmish Intensifies to Acquire a Rival Funeral Home Chain
description: Service Corporation International, its friendly but menacing offer for the Loewen Group Inc. rejected, brought a higher, hostile bid straight to Loewen shareholders yesterday.

title: A Spur to Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES IN DSC DROP 19% ON LOW SALES REPORT
description: The shares of the DSC Communications Corporation dropped almost 19 percent yesterday after the company said its third-quarter sales and earnings would not meet analyst estimates because of useless inventory and slower orders. The company, a telephone-equipment maker, also said it would take a charge of $60 million to write off ''customer-specific'' inventory and to pay for a restructuring. DSC said the inventory was mainly wireless products that could not be used because they interfered with military equipment in a country it declined to name. DSC shares dropped $4.375, to $18.75, in Nasdaq trading of 19.4 million shares. A year ago, DSC's stock was trading at more than $60 a share.

title: In a Well-Kept Part of Brooklyn, Crack Arrests Are Met With Concern
description: The Gold Star Pizzeria at Avenue O and West Third Street in Brooklyn sits on a corner virtually indistinguishable from those of dozens of family-owned cafes that dot the mostly middle-class landscape of Bensonhurst.

title: The Pitchers Prevail in Game 1, and So Do the Braves
description: The first team to go to the bullpen lost.

title: New Jersey's Boarder Babies
description: New Jersey officials have finally announced a plan to ease the plight of ''boarder babies,'' infants who remain in hospitals indefinitely for fear they will suffer abuse at the hands of their parents. The plan aims to recruit more foster families to take care of these infants and to provide more services to troubled families. But it is not yet certain that there will be enough money or monitoring of how the infants fare. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ought to move with more seriousness and urgency to address this problem.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Colorado

title: NEW OFFICER NAMED AT PUERTO RICO BOTTLER
description: The Pepsi-Cola Puerto Rico Bottling Company named a new chairman and said its former chairman and chief executive, Charles Beach, had given up control of the company. The bottler said a longtime director, John W. Beck, would succeed Mr. Beach, a cofounder. Mr. Beach and another company founder gave the chief executive, Rafael Nin, voting control of five million class A shares under a 10-year trust -- enough for majority voting at the company. The concern is a bottler for Pepsico, which does not have a stake in the company.

title: Ryder Sets Stock Buyback
description: Ryder System Inc. is planning to buy back up to six million of its common shares after the sale of its consumer truck rental business. Ryder said the repurchased shares would be held for general corporate purposes. The company has about 81 million common shares outstanding. The Ryder stock closed today at $29 a share, down 37.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: New York City Enters Fray In Rancorous Cable Feud

title: Salt Invades Water Supply
description: The saltwater that surrounds Cape May on three sides has been leaking into the drinking water supply. Two of the city's wells have already become unusable and the remaining one is in danger, David Carrick, superintendent of the city's water department, said yesterday. The city and several neighboring municipalities it supplies with water use 2.7 million gallons a day, he said. On Wednesday, the City Council authorized the sale of $5 million in bonds to finance New Jersey's first desalination plant, which could provide one million gallons of fresh water a day, Mr. Carrick said.

title: Girl Meets Girl. Dumps Boy.
description: In the genre world where a drop of red blood in a pool of white paint qualifies as ingenuity, ''Bound'' comes as a smartly stylish surprise. Directed by Larry and Andy Wachowski with a hard-boiled cunning reminiscent of the early Coen brothers, this crime story follows a typically scheming path while adding a little something extra: lesbians. It involves two women and a man in a deadly triangle that brings forth taunts like: ''What did she do to you?'' ''Everything you couldn't!'' This smoothly sardonic film also takes its money-laundering seriously enough to hang the cash out on a clothesline to dry.

title: Angry Umpires Say They Will Strike Today
description: Irate once again over the timing of Roberto Alomar's five-game suspension for spitting in the face of one of their colleagues, Major League Baseball umpires today reconfirmed that they will not work any more playoff games beginning Friday.

title: JAVITS OVERHAUL PRAISED IN AUDIT
description: The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, which in recent years had earned a reputation as a forbidding fortress of careless management, obstinate unions and excessive costs, is luring back trade shows after overhauling its operations and ridding itself of practices that often left exhibitors fuming.

title: Maddux Has Braves on the Verge of a Sweep
description: Greg Maddux can throw strikes wearing a blindfold. But he opted not to wear one tonight, and the Los Angeles Dodgers are suddenly on the verge of playing golf instead of baseball.

title: Irvin Practices With the Cowboys
description: MICHAEL IRVIN returned to the Dallas Cowboys yesterday, providing the listless Super Bowl champions with some of the spark they have been missing much of this season.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: First 2 Jurors Picked In 1986 Rape Case
description: Lawyers in the Alex Kelly rape case today selected two of the six jurors. After three days of jury selection in which several potential jurors have been dismissed because they expressed strong views about Mr. Kelly or the issues in the case, the selections today seemed to undermine defense contentions that it would be impossible to seat a fair jury here because of intense publicity.

title: People
description: * Marcella Rosen was named to the new post of executive vice president for advertising services at Freemark Communications, New York. She had been president at the Network Television Association, New York, which closed.

title: An Oasis of Casinos Lifts A Poor Mississippi County
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Rangers Are a Mix of Old and New
description: Among the 24 Rangers opening the season in Boston on Saturday night are six new faces -- three veterans and three rookies. Only 20 men play in any game but this is, nevertheless, an incomplete team, short of right wings and young defensemen.

title: No Answers By a Suspect In the Murder Of His Parents
description: Stooped, silent and guarded by seven uniformed deputies, 30-year-old De Witt L. Crandell 2d was ordered held on $10 million bail today on charges of murdering his parents on Monday morning in their Englewood home.

title: Restaurants
description: In the last year, the number of fish restaurants in New York City has steadily grown. Old favorites like Lundy's and Gage & Tollner have redecorated and reopened, while new restaurants like Aqua Grill and Blue Water Grill have sprung up. Raw bars have become standard in smart new restaurants. Meanwhile, one midtown Manhattan fish specialist has quietly been getting better and better. If you haven't been to Oceana lately, you might be surprised.

title: School of Americas Must Answer for Past
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: I Shot Andy Warhol

title: Gore Boasts Of TV Policy And Boosts Congressman
description: Vice President Al Gore came here to Bergen County today to hail Administration policies that he said were helping parents control the kinds of television programs their children watch.

title: Protecting Farm Workers
description: A surprising aspect of American labor's new vigor is the resurgence of the United Farm Workers. After a two-decade slide from its heyday in the 1970's, a union made up of hard-to-organize transients -- many of them illegal immigrants -- grew at the fastest rate of any union last year. But the U.F.W. still claims only 26,000 members out of roughly 1.6 million farm workers. For those not in the union, conditions are as appalling as ever.

title: Full Steam Ahead for Bills' Smith
description: Is Bruce Smith the most dominating player in pro football today? Ask opponents who have tried to block him this season. Each week he has been sacking the quarterback and forcing a fumble to set up the winning field goal here, blocking a field goal that turns out to be the margin of victory there.

title: High and Low Jinks, in Search of a Scoop
description: HACKSBy Christopher S. Wren287 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: Yankees Must Continue Keeping 'I' Out of Team
description: When the Yankees played their last regular-season series, they were presented with a stark contrast to their concept of team by a franchise that no longer knew how to spell the word.

title: Securities Buyback Set by Morgan Grenfell
description: Morgan Grenfell Asset Management Ltd. received permission from regulators to buy back securities held by several United States investment funds, including a pair run by Dean Witter, Discover & Company, as part of an attempt to avoid the spread of its unlisted securities scandal to the United States.

title: So Commonplace, And Yet, Surreal
description: SO brilliantly spontaneous are the people in Henri Cartier-Bresson's photographs, so clever at allowing themselves to be caught in the perfect place at the perfect time, that you sometimes wonder whether they weren't part of a troupe of traveling actors trained to pose especially for his lens. This thought, quickly dismissed as irreverent, was prompted again by ''Henri Cartier-Bresson in America, 1935-1975,'' billed as the first comprehensive exhibition of photographs taken by Cartier-Bresson in the United States.

title: Dramatizing a Composer's Moments of Emotional Tension
description: It makes little sense to talk about the greatest orchestra in the world. The great orchestras all possess their own particular, incomparable sound. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra has a golden timbre to match any in Europe. The Cleveland Orchestra is a feast of precision. The Vienna Philharmonic is a wonder of esthetic self-government, perpetuating its excellence without consistent direction from the podium.

title: Japanese Liquor Tax Is Declared Unfair
description: A panel of the World Trade Organization has decided that Japan's taxes on domestic liquor breach its rules, upholding an earlier ruling that the taxes are unfair, people close to the Japanese Government said yesterday. They did not say whether Japan would change its taxation system.

title: Financial Services Acquisition Talks
description: Fortis, a Belgian-Dutch financial services company, said yesterday that it was in talks with ABN Amro Holding N.V. about buying Mees Pierson N.V., a merchant banker. ABN Amro, the Netherlands' biggest bank, said on Wednesday that it was interested in selling Mees Pierson.

title: A Band's Beatle-ish Rise In Hanks's Directing Debut
description: Forfeiting the chance to make a long and self-serving historical pageant, Tom Hanks has taken something other than the standard movie-star route to directorial distinction. Mr. Hanks's debut feature, written and directed with delightful good cheer, is rock-and-roll nostalgia presented as pure fizz.

title: Scores of House Candidates Dancing the Texas Shuffle
description: Texas has had plenty of raucous free-for-alls in its electoral history, perhaps most famously in 1961, when 71 candidates jumped into a special election to fill the United States Senate seat vacated by Lyndon B. Johnson, who had become Vice President. Amid the ensuing fratricide among Democrats, John G. Tower became the state's first Republican Senator since Reconstruction.

title: Bank of Spain Trims Money Market Rate
description: The Bank of Spain announced yesterday that it reduced its key money market interest rate for the sixth time this year, bringing it down to 6.75 percent from 7.25 percent.

title: U.S. Discloses Pension Fund Rescue Plan
description: Seeking to blunt a threat to the battered pension fund covering 70,000 workers in the men's suit industry, the Government announced a rescue plan today that it said would protect employers and taxpayers as well as union retirees.

title: Lease Plan For Hospital Is Outlined
description: New York City officials yesterday released an outline of their proposed contract with a private company to run Coney Island Hospital, a public hospital, amid growing concern that the company, Primary Health Systems, may be poorly suited to the task. The deal is the first concrete move in the Mayor's ambitious effort to get the city out of the health care business by turning public hospitals over to private owners.

title: Gordon Wrecks Earnhardt's Car
description: ROBBY GORDON's bid to put a DALE EARNHARDT-owned car into the UAW-GM Quality 500 was stopped by a concrete wall yesterday in Concord, N.C.

title: Serb and Bosnia Leaders Pledge To Establish Full Relations Soon
description: Serbia and Bosnia pledged today to establish full diplomatic relations with each other soon, a long-awaited move seen as an expression of support by the Serbian President for the new Bosnia, which is struggling to emerge from nearly four years of war.

title: Myths of the Mideast
description: President Clinton has chosen his current top Mideastern priority and earnestly, almost desperately, announced it to the world.

title: Hard-to-Gauge National Forces Will Tug at House Races
description: The final five weeks of the battle for the House will have a lot to do with the blunders, master strokes, strengths and weaknesses of hundreds of individual campaigns. But strategists in both parties suspect that some broader political forces could prove to be far more decisive -- if they could only figure them out.

title: Gingrich Investigation Is No Double Jeopardy
description: To the Editor:

title: Always Lovable, Always Fathomless
description: Here are some favorite Brahms recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 to $18, for a single CD, to $25 to $32, for a double set, to $60 for a six-CD set; single tape cassettes cost from $5 to $11. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: NEXTEL TO PURCHASE PITTENCRIEFF COMMUNICATIONS
description: Nextel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Pittencrieff Communications Inc. for $159 million in stock. The agreement would further expand Nextel's wireless presence into the Southwest. Nextel is building a nationwide digital wireless network that will offer voice, data, paging and radio dispatch services over hand-held phones. Pittencrieff, based in Abilene, Tex., has licenses to provide wireless services to markets with a total population of 27 million people. Nextel will issue a maximum of 8.78 million shares for Pittencrieff unless its shares exceeded $19.36 each when the transaction closes. In that case, Nextel would issue fewer shares. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Nextel fell 37.5 cents, to $17.75.

title: Rangers Look Forward to Friendlier Confines
description: Fresh from two frenzied nights in New York, Darryl Hamilton had a suggestion for Texas fans who will attend the first home post-season game in Rangers history Friday night.

title: Ferry Companies Merging Some Service
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company of Britain and Stena Line of Sweden are merging some of their ferry service on the English Channel in a move to cut costs and compete more effectively with the channel rail tunnel.

title: Giuliani Pressures Time Warner to Transmit a Fox Channel
description: The Giuliani administration has thrust itself into the middle of a rancorous dispute between Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch by asking for permission to carry Mr. Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel on a public-access cable channel the city controls.

title: Keep on Trucking
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising Tone Of City Voting To Bosnia's
description: BOSNIA, recognizable to crossword-puzzle fans as a six-letter word meaning basket case, managed to carry off an election reasonably well last month. Bosnia benefited from the presence of international monitors.

title: Netanyahu Reported Ready to Make Gesture to Palestinians
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu returned to Israel today convinced that he had prevailed in Washington and reportedly ready to make some quick gestures to the Palestinians to demonstrate that he was ready to move ahead on peace.

title: WCBS and the Ratings Game
description: When WCBS-TV abruptly dismissed seven anchors and reporters -- including John Johnson and Michelle Marsh, the anchors with the most experience and highest salaries in the group -- it illuminated the intense pressure for ratings among local television stations in New York City, the nation's biggest market.

title: Walled In, Shrouded and Angry in Afghanistan
description: Since the Muslim clerics who now rule most of Afghanistan issued their decree last week forbidding women to work, a 34-year-old physician has walked to the clinic she runs in one of Kabul's poorest districts, just as she has for years, except that now she does so in fear of a beating, imprisonment or worse.

title: Milk mustaches jump off the page and onto the side of buildings.
description: THE popular ''milk mustache'' campaign by Bozell Worldwide is being broadened, but foes of faux facial hair who fear milk goatees or sideburns can relax. The campaign is just expanding from print into another medium.

title: To Mother Nature, Inferno Fans the Flames of Life
description: ''Oh, we seen a few elephants and a few giraffes and bleeding little else. And now there's no accommodations.''

title: WELLPOINT MAY BUY JOHN HANCOCK'S HEALTH UNIT
description: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. may be buying the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company's health insurance business as part of an expansion that could include more acquisitions. People familiar with the situation said that Wellpoint, a managed-health-care company, was close to buying the unit. The price was not disclosed. The Hancock unit, which earned less than $10 million last year and has more than 3,000 employees, would be a good acquisition if the price was relatively low, said Paul Goulekas of Conning & Company.

title: 7,500 G.I.'s Staying in Bosnia to Next Spring, Perry Says
description: Up to 7,500 American troops will remain in Bosnia until mid-March, Defense Secretary William J. Perry told a Senate panel today. He insisted to Republican Senators that this did not represent the beginning of an extended American military presence in Bosnia.

title: Police Experts Identifying Gangs, Feuds, Drugs and Personal Signatures
description: While patrolling a stretch of gang-contested turf in East Harlem last week, two police officers spotted two fresh blotches of graffiti on a side wall of Public School 149-207.

title: Calling D'Amato
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Yayoi Kusama

title: KIRCH GROUP TO BUY 7.5% OF NEW REGENCY PRODUCTIONS
description: The Kirch Group of Germany, controlled by the media entrepreneur Leo Kirch, said yesterday that it would buy 7.5 percent of New Regency Productions for about $64 million.The Kirch investment in the movie and television studio will occur in two stages, beginning with a 5 percent stake. Kirch and New Regency did not disclose further details. Kirch joins Kerry Packer and the Korean conglomerate Samsung Electronics as New Regency's largest investors.

title: Kodak in Talks to Buy a Wang Software Unit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and Wang Laboratories announced yesterday that Kodak was in negotiations to buy Wang's document imaging software business.

title: Jones Puts Purpose In Punches
description: Most fighters box to make a living and not to prove a point. Roy Jones Jr. boxes these days because he is looking for a reason. He already knows he is the world's best fighter.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Unwelcome to the Club

title: Daniel Ortega's Second Act
description: Few politicians seem less suited for a political comeback than Daniel Ortega. The dour leader of Nicaragua's Sandinista Front in the revolutionary 1980's, Mr. Ortega seemed allergic to charisma. His political judgment led him into such misadventures as visiting Moscow just before a Congressional vote on American aid to the contra rebels fighting his Government. The Reagan Administration's war on Nicaragua, compounded by Sandinista economic ineptitude, brought the country an inflation rate of 30,000 percent. Before he turned over the presidency to Violeta Chamorro in 1990, Mr. Ortega and other Sandinista leaders indulged in an ugly grab of property and houses. Yet despite all, he has pulled even with the front-runner in the current presidential race. Voting is later this month.

title: No Headline
description: ''Before, people pushed us for bribes, people wanted tips. It was corrupt. Now, nobody has their hands out. They are not fleecing us for the charges as much as they used to. And having the state police walk the halls is a good addition as well. It is good evidence that there is a new attitude.''

title: Does Valujet Pay Enough Attention to Safety?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Steep Plunge From Love to Madness
description: RISKY does not begin to describe ''Breaking the Waves,'' the raw, crazy tour de force that is the frenzied highlight of the New York Film Festival this year. Courting and sometimes winning ridicule, daring to fuse true love with lurid exploitation and pure religious faith, the Danish director Lars von Trier has created a fierce, wrenchingly passionate film about the struggles of a shy young woman who is goodness personified. Truly, bells ring in heaven for a heroine like this.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE FOOTBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Senate races in Southern states misstated the event that led to the election of Jesse Helms, a Republican, to the Senate from North Carolina in 1972. The incumbent Senator, B. Everett Jordan, was defeated in the Democratic primary; he did not retire.

title: For Listening, Learning and Celebrating
description: Brahms will be celebrated at various locations in Manhattan. All performances by the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall are sold out, but returned tickets are sometimes available. A series of free concerts and lectures is scheduled through early May at the Bruno Walter Auditorium, New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, 40 Lincoln Center Plaza; information: (212) 870-1630. Here is a sampling of events scheduled through November.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some Manhattan art shows:

title: Nokia and AT&T In Equipment Deal
description: Nokia said yesterday that it had received a $240 million three-year contract to provide mobile telephones to the AT&T Corporation's AT&T Wireless Service unit.

title: Broderbund Software Picks Chief Executive
description: Broderbund Software said here today that it had hired Joseph Durrett as its chief executive, ending a five-month search for an outsider to head the company.

title: U.S. Bans Visits, and ASEAN Members Show Doubts on Membership : Pressure Mounts on Burma's Junta
description: SINGAPORE  International pressure for democratic change in Burma increased significantly Thursday as the United States banned Burmese leaders from entering, and several Southeast Asian countries indicated growing disillusionment with the military regime in Rangoon.

title: Now It's Clinton's Turn to Step Off the Campaign Trail and Cram for Sunday's Debate
description: After a spirited rally with Buffalo Democrats, President Clinton today locked himself away for three days of practice for the first nationally televised debate of the campaign. His goal: to emphasize his record and do nothing to erode the steady lead he has held for months.

title: bclinton@kiwanis.4real.gov
description: Young cyberpols, imagine this: You debate with your friends about Bob Dole's 15 percent tax cut. You watch some real-time video of the candidates. You fire off a letter to your Congressman. Now here's the amazing part: Imagine that you do all these things without your computer.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Great White Hype

title: Sterling Forest Bill Passes
description: The United States Senate gave final approval yesterday to a broad package of legislation on parks and public lands, including financing to preserve Sterling Forest, after the White House promised to let an Alaskan company continue to cut timber in the Tongass National Forest for a few more years. New Jersey's Congressional delegation pressed for public acquisition of the forest, a 20,000-acre tract straddling the New York-New Jersey line. The bill authorizes $17.5 million to help buy the land from a private owner. $(Page A1.$)

title: Palffy Accepts Role as an Islander Captain
description: After the Islanders skated through their final practice before opening the regular season here Friday night against the Los Angeles Kings, Coach Mike Milbury today announced that three players would rotate as captains for the first part of the season.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of two Jewish holidays, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow, for Shemini Atzereth, which concludes Succoth, the Feast of Tabernacles, and Sunday, for Simhath Torah, which ends the annual cycle of the public reading of the Torah. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Big Retailer Is Said to Bid For Barney's
description: Dickson Concepts Ltd., a retail giant based in Hong Kong, has made an initial offer to buy Barney's Inc., several people close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Penn State Runner Is Making Gains
description: The workload has grown more challenging as the games have become more significant. Curtis Enis carried the football 28 times, the most in his career, during Penn State's narrow victory at Wisconsin last weekend.

title: Art in Review
description: Werner Drewes

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's influence in Albany misidentified the Senate committee he heads. He is chairman of the Banking Committee, not the Finance Committee.

title: Polish Poet Wins Nobel Prize
description: Wislawa Szymborska, 73, a Polish poet whose woirk reflects on life's daily quirks, won the Nobel Prize for Literature yesterday.

title: Tyson Fight Heating Up
description: A heavyweight title fight between Mike Tyson and Evander Holyfield was formally announced yesterday, and minutes later Tyson's camp assailed Holyfield for deserting Tyson when their man needed moral support.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Visions of Space and U.F.O.'s in Art'

title: Boy Dies of Injuries; Father May Be Charged
description: A 7-month-old from Queens who prosecutors say was assaulted by his father weeks after child-welfare officials had opened an inquiry on the family died of his injuries on Sunday. That raises a prospect that the father could face murder charges.

title: Always Lovable, Always Fathomless
description: NO ONE ever satisfactorily explained why the last musical season should have been so pervasively heavy in Beethoven. But it would make perfect sense for Brahms to follow, even if the 100th anniversary of his death were not approaching next April. He was, after all, almost morbidly aware of treading in Beethoven's footsteps.

title: A Flawed Encryption Policy
description: The new White House proposal to keep high-powered encryption software out of the hands of foreign terrorists and criminals is needlessly restrictive and probably unworkable. Though the new plan is better than previous Administration proposals, it risks doing more harm than good.

title: Appeals Court Refuses to Halt New Balloting
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday refused to cancel the planned reopening of voting on Thursday in primary elections in Brooklyn, but the possibility remained that the court could still cancel the balloting early next week, or could order that it involve more or fewer voters than now planned.

title: Lukas and Others Chase Cigar at Belmont
description: D. Wayne Lukas looked ahead to the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park tomorrow and saw it this way: five horses, including one of his own, running to catch one superhorse, Cigar.

title: INSIDE
description: Extended Stay in Bosnia

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Speedo Maker Drops Line Of Skiwear
description: The Authentic Fitness Corporation, which owns the Speedo sports apparel trademark in North America, said yesterday that it was abandoning the skiwear business, shuttering its outlet stores and restating its second- and third-quarter results to include additional reserves to cover potential losses on inventory and accounts receivable.

title: Wells Rich Picked By Citizens Telecom
description: The Citizens Telecom unit of Citizens Utilities in Stamford, Conn., said yesterday that it had named Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York as its first agency of record. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $17 million. Wells Rich, a unit of BBDP Group, which is being acquired by GGT Group P.L.C., was selected after a review that began with nine agencies and had been narrowed to Wells Rich and Houston Herstek Favat in Boston. Wells Rich will create branding ads to build awareness for the company's telecommunications services.

title: 'Ego Value' Inflates Yanks' Current Value
description: Determining what a buyer will pay for sports properties can be a pesky exercise. The Yankees may be sports' most storied team, with an even higher visibility than usual now as they compete in baseball's post-season. But their presence in the playoffs, or even the possibility of winning the World Series, is not a huge element of the team's current or future value.

title: Government Aid Lifts Credit Lyonnais Results
description: Credit Lyonnais S.A., France's state-owned bank, said yesterday that it had a profit for its first half because of assistance from the Government. The bank earned 67 million francs, or $13.1 million, up 86 percent from the 36 million francs it earned a year earlier.

title: Teacher Charged in Assault
description: A New York City teacher was charged with third-degree assault yesterday after a classroom argument at Public School 12 in Brooklyn in which a 10-year-old boy was slightly injured. The defendant, Judith Smith, 50, is accused of throwing a chair that struck the boy and bruised his leg. Ms. Smith, who lives in Staten Island, has been reassigned pending an investigation, the Board of Education said. Ms. Smith could not be reached by telephone last evening.

title: Don't Come to America Looking for a Handout
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Good of All, Study Those Ancient Bones
description: To the Editor:

title: Hands of a Lineman Tell Hard-Hitting Tale
description: Ron Stone points to his hands as if they are a road map of the season, and in a way they are. From finger to joint to bone, they show just how rough a year it has been on his hands, perhaps the most important part of the body for an offensive lineman.

title: Always Lovable, Always Fathomless
description: Here are some favorite Brahms recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 to $18, for a single CD, to $25 to $32, for a double set, to $60 for a six-CD set; single tape cassettes cost from $5 to $11. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: A Man, a Woman and an Atomic Bomb
description: Matthew Broderick has always radiated the boyish charm of a canny whiz kid ingratiating himself with the grown-ups by batting his eyes and doing adorably cute parlor routines. What prevents him from becoming an insufferable goody-two-shoes is his brash side-of-the-mouth cheekiness. It isn't easy having to be the teacher's pet. And Mr. Broderick always gives us a glimpse into the anxious, fragile side of this wide-eyed apple polisher with an ingenuous smirk.

title: CLINTON IN NORTH, AND DOLE IN SOUTH, STUDY FOR DEBATE
description: President Clinton and Bob Dole today headed into three days of secluded preparation for Sunday's Presidential debate, using their final campaign appearances to preview themes for the encounter: Mr. Clinton flaunted his domestic record, while Mr. Dole offered his toughest assessment yet of the President's foreign policy.

title: Yeltsin Chides Lebed Over Threat to Quit in Kremlin Squabble
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that his security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, had threatened to resign because of his dwindling authority and that he had urged him to stay on the job.

title: A Man Who Was Made For the Biographers
description: When Theodore Roosevelt traveled -- and he traveled a lot, through the Dakota Badlands, into little-known Africa, down the dangerous Amazon -- he made sure to take along a photographer and possibly a movie cameraman, which must have eased the work of the resourceful picture researchers for ''The American Experience.'' With adroit use of the photographs he commissioned and the cartoons his appearance invited, ''T. R.: The Story of Theodore Roosevelt'' brings back the man's irrepressible energy as well as the bustle of his times.

title: Put Re-Election Before Dole, Gingrich Advises
description: While arguing that Bob Dole would ultimately win a come-from-behind, late-breaking victory, Speaker Newt Gingrich said yesterday that he would advise Republican candidates in close Congressional races to do what was necessary for their own political survival -- even if it meant distancing themselves from Mr. Dole.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Luminous Bodies'

title: Court Halts Sandblasting on Bridges Until Studies Are Completed
description: A state court has blocked sandblasting on all New York City bridges, pending environmental studies and public hearings, in a ruling that deepens a controversy arising from lead-paint removal on the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Keeping the Tap Open For Thirsty Economies
description: Two years after Mexico's financial collapse, private capital is pouring back into emerging economies. But at the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which concluded today, the Mexican crisis loomed as large as ever.

title: City Hall Enmeshed In Cable News Battle
description: New York City has thrust itself into a rancorous dispute between Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch by asking permission to carry Mr. Murdoch's new Fox news channel on a public-access station. The cable company rejected the request, but city officials were not giving up.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Antonia's Line

title: Senate Approves Bill to Preserve Parks, Including Sterling Forest
description: The Senate approved a broad package of legislation on parks and public lands today, including financing to preserve the Sterling Forest on the New York-New Jersey border, after the White House promised to let an Alaskan company continue to cut timber in the Tongass National Forest for a few more years.

title: Battles on Ice And Campus
description: If F. Scott Fitzgerald had been born in 1966 instead of 1896, his predilection for heroic sports fantasies, his familiarity with the cruelties and joys of prep school life, his keen sense of social stratification, his chronic financial woes and his reliance on the monetary rewards of commercial fiction and Hollywood might well have led him to write a movie like ''D3: The Mighty Ducks.''

title: Nine Are Arrested in Drug Raid At a Brooklyn Treatment Center
description: Nine residents of a Brooklyn drug rehabilitation center were arrested yesterday and several ounces of crack cocaine were seized during a raid at the center, the police said.

title: Immigrant Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Executive Puts Stock-Only Pay to Ultimate Test
description: Jerre L. Stead has every reason to wince when he sees headlines about the mega-dollar salaries paid to chief executives. He is, after all, a chief executive himself.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resurgence of interest in Irish culture misstated the given name of a San Francisco financier who supports Irish cultural causes. He is Brian P. Burns, not John Burns.

title: Prices of Heating Fuels Soar As Forecasters See Cold Snap
description: Prices for heating oil and natural gas surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as forecasts for colder weather raised concerns about increased demand at a time of low supplies.

title: As They Do the Math, Indians Lose Some of Their Swagger
description: There was the hiss of showers running full blast down the hall, the splash of water in the bathroom sinks nearby, but no other sounds for the longest time.

title: Ice Seller's Killer Convicted
description: William Mercado, who peddled piraguas, or flavored ices, on the streets of downtown Jersey City, was a popular figure in the neighborhood, especially among children. But in November 1994, Mr. Mercado, 25, of Union City, died after being shot six times in the head. Yesterday, George Lucia, a member of North Bergen's Nomad motorcycle club, was convicted of manslaughter in Mr. Mercado's death. The prosecution had contended that the killing occurred because Mr. Lucia's 18-year-old daughter had complained of a sexual advance from Mr. Mercado.

title: A Gifted Man Who Put His Pain on Paper
description: THE easy observation about Antonin Artaud's drawings at the Museum of Modern Art is that they are sometimes artful in the intuitive way of the untutored artist. But this denies what is most significant about them, namely that they're not really like other art. Artaud even warned against considering them ''works of art, works of the esthetic simulation of reality,'' and we should take him at his word. He called them ''staggering blows given in all the directions of chance, possibility, hazard or destiny.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CRW FINANCIAL INC., King of Prussia, Pa., said its board had voted to sell its debt collection business and spin off its Casino Money Centers Inc. unit to shareholders.

title: High Spending Costs Schools
description: Two years ago, the Department of Education told local school districts that if they spent an excessive amount on administrative costs, they would be penalized. Yesterday, the department said the crackdown was working. Of the 600 school districts in the state, 54 that have budgeted more than $1,263 per pupil for administrative costs this year will lose a total of $2.7 million in the next school year. Last year, 73 districts were penalized $6.6 million.

title: Feet Planted in Spain but in Step With the World
description: The Ballet Ullate of Madrid proclaimed itself both proudly internationalist and fiercely Spanish when it made its New York City debut on Tuesday night at the City Center.

title: $25 and Under
description: The Sheraton La Guardia East was not what I had in mind. The sleek metal-and-glass hotel towers above the one- and two-story buildings in this pan-Asian neighborhood, and the modern, pleasant lobby could as easily have been in Ashtabula, Ohio, as in Flushing. The restaurant, fanned around a waterfall in an atrium one level below the lobby, is called La Cascade.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There's not much that FRANK FERRANTE, an actor and director who played the lead in ''Groucho: A Life in Revue'' 10 years ago, won't do in the name of Groucho Marx.

title: For Children
description: Do children ever consider what adults want to do? Only if it is suits them: otherwise, they wouldn't be children.

title: Talks Sputter as G.M. Strike Ends First Day
description: Negotiations between the General Motors Corporation and the Canadian Automobile Workers union showed little progress today after 15,000 assembly workers went on strike early this morning.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Goose Hunters Set Record
description: Hunters bagged a record number of Canada geese in the state's longest goose season to date, environmental officials reported yesterday. About 12,600 geese were killed from Sept. 2 to 30, said David Burke, supervising biologist for the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Will Buy Kindercare for $467 Million
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Kindercare Learning Centers Inc., the nation's largest preschool and child care company, for approximately $467 million, or $20.25 a share.

title: MOLSON TO SELL CHEMICALS UNIT FOR $188 MILLION
description: The Molson Companies, the Canadian brewer, said yesterday that it planned to sell its Novamax Technologies chemicals unit to the German chemical company Henkel K.G.a.A. for $255 million (Canadian), or $187.6 million. Molson said it would withdraw $20 million (Canadian) in cash from the Novamax business before signing a final agreement for the sale. Under the agreement, Henkel will pay one half of the proceeds to Molson, with the remainder to be placed in escrow and released incrementally as certain regulatory approvals are obtained. Molson said Noavamax had sales of $284 million (Canadian) in the year that ended on March 31, while the parent company had sales of $1.44 billion.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Trinity

title: New Yankees Emphasize Home Edge
description: THEY remember the flight last year, clear across the country, after playing a game they would have considered sensational if only they had won it.

title: Sales by Ford Aid a Strong September for Auto Makers
description: The Ford Motor Company reported today that sales of its cars and light trucks rose 7.3 percent in September, contributing to a stronger-than-expected gain for the auto industry last month.

title: A Legacy That Crossed the Ocean
description: It is strange that Berenice Abbott began her photographic career as an apprentice in Man Ray's studio, for she came as close as anyone to being the opposite of a Surrealist. She loved the stringent objectivity of the camera. The one thing she did share with the Surrealists was a fascination with Eugene Atget, the photographer who documented all of Paris, from its doorway moldings to its parks, in loving deadpan style.

title: A Piaf With a Camera Sings of Self
description: NAN GOLDIN, who is 43, has been the art world's photographer of the hour for several years now, admired for what is regularly called a ''warts and all'' punk style steeped in passion, immediacy and opulent color. In much of the writing about her, she comes across as as a kind of Piaf with a camera, a vulnerable, empathic survivor whose sensibility feeds on lived experience. Ms. Goldin's art is autobiographical not just at the core -- as all art is -- but all the way through as well, inside and out. So it is not surprising that ''I'll Be Your Mirror,'' her midcareer survey at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is an excessively autobiographical undertaking. But it is unfortunate.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Peter Brennan, 78, Union Head and Nixon's Labor Chief
description: Peter J. Brennan, a Depression-era house painter who rose through the construction trades, became one of New York's most prominent labor leaders for three decades and was Secretary of Labor from 1973 to 1975 in the Nixon and Ford administrations, died on Wednesday at the home of a daughter in Massapequa, L.I. He was 78.

title: Gingrich Investigation Is No Double Jeopardy
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitchcock at His Deepest
description: The revival event of the season is Alfred Hitchcock's brilliantly schematic, endlessly fascinating ''Vertigo.'' Newly restored to its rich, deep hues by Robert A. Harris (who also restored ''Lawrence of Arabia'' and ''Spartacus''), this prescient 1958 spellbinder can now be admired as the deepest, darkest masterpiece of Hitchcock's career.

title: A Shadow Over the Mideast: Arab Youths on a Short Fuse
description: A group of teen-agers wearing old jeans and dirty sneakers clambered up to the rooftops early this morning to let the Israeli soldiers below know what they thought of the summit meeting that ended the night before in Washington.

title: Art in Review
description: Andy Warhol

title: Rufus W. Youngblood, 72, Agent Who Guarded Johnson
description: Rufus W. Youngblood, the Secret Service agent who flung himself over the front seat and used his body to shield Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson during the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963, died on Wednesday at a hospice near his home in Savannah, Ga. He was 72 and was deputy director of the Secret Service when he retired in 1971.

title: Gill Hospitalized With Dehydration
description: KENDALL GILL, the Nets' shooting guard, spent Wednesday night in East Pasco Medical Center in Florida after suffering from dehydration and cramps following the team's evening workout. Gill received fluids intravenously and was released yesterday morning.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Robert Bourassa, a former Premier of Quebec, misstated one of the provisions of a 1974 law he helped push through the Quebec legislature. The law, which made French the province's official language, did not ban the use of English on commercial signs; that ban was imposed in 1977, after Mr. Bourassa had been turned out of office by the separatist Parti Quebecois.

title: Diner's Journal
description: If It Looks Like Pizza ...

title: Driver Gets in Train's Way
description: A New Jersey Transit train struck a car at a grade crossing yesterday, pushing it 200 feet, but the driver escaped serious injury, police said. The driver, Michael Bennett, 28, of East Rutherford, ignored flashing lights and bells, said Sgt. Paul Stuckey of the Hillsdale police. Gates are scheduled to be installed at the crossing on Oct. 19, officials said. About 800 commuters were delayed as much as two hours because of the accident.

title: Ayatollah California
description: To the Editor:

title: Use of Daily Election Polls Generates Debate in Press
description: In this week's episode of the perils of polling, CNN and USA Today found themselves tied to their daily tracking poll, trying to explain why President Clinton led Bob Dole by only 9 points on Saturday and by 25 points on Tuesday.

title: At WCBS, Ratings Were Bottom Line
description: The abrupt dismissal of seven anchors and reporters from WCBS-TV on Wednesday night not only shocked industry colleagues and viewers, but also illuminated the intense pressure for ratings among television stations competing in the enormously lucrative local news market.

title: Knee Surgery Sidelines Johnson for Four Games
description: Just when he figured that his brief but luminous National Football League career was ''ready to take off,'' Keyshawn Johnson instead underwent knee surgery today that will keep him out of a Jets uniform for the next four games.

title: Laborite Vows A New Future For Britain If He's Elected
description: Inspired by a promise from Tony Blair, its young leader, of an education-driven ''age of achievement'' for Britain, the Labor Party today wound down its annual conference outwardly united and supremely confident of victory over the Conservatives in coming national elections.

title: Boy in Harassment Complaint Is Linked to Other Incidents
description: As a 7-year-old Queens boy who had been charged with sexual harassment returned to school yesterday, a school official said that the boy had been involved in three or four other incidents with at least two girls. The second-grade boy, De'Andre Dearinge, had been suspended on Sept. 27 from Public School 104 in Far Rockaway after he kissed a classmate on the cheek and tore a button from her skirt.

title: Yanks Take a Deep Breath And Enter Tough Territory
description: Joe Torre owes manager-in-waiting, Jim Leyland, and former father-in-hiding, George Boehringer, a telephone call or a telegram of thanks. Those two disparate personalities were unexpectedly involved in helping the Yankees save their season, at least for now, with a 5-4 victory over the Texas Rangers in a dramatic and draining 12-inning game that ended early this morning in New York.

title: Olivetti, Seeking Turnaround, To Sell PC Unit and Other Assets
description: In a surprising reversal, Olivetti S.p.A. said it planned to sell its unprofitable personal computer division as part of a fire sale of assets intended to raise somewhere between $655 million and $785 million to shore up the troubled company.

title: Home Video
description: TV Oldies, Lots of Them

title: Art in Review
description: Gerome Kamrowski

title: Man Admits Role in Scam
description: A 22-year-old New Mexico man pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to a role in a nationwide sweepstakes scam that prosecutors said fleeced mostly elderly victims, including a New Jersey resident, of more than $200,000. Under the scheme, which operated earlier this year, people would receive calls from the ''National Awards Center'' informing them that they had won $75,000, but had to pay up to $11,000 in taxes on the prize -- in cash -- before they could collect, said Michael A. Guadagno, an assistant United States attorney. Troy Thompson of Albuquerque admitted in court that he was the man who picked up the money at a rented mailbox.

title: Agency Chiefs Scolded for Political Interference
description: Gov. John G. Rowland has reprimanded two state agency chiefs for inviting their employees to a rally for Bob Dole before the Presidential debate here on Sunday.

title: SFX BROADCASTING RAISES OFFER FOR MULTI-MARKET RADIO
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. raised its stock-swap offer again yesterday for Multi-Market Radio Inc., to $12.50 a share from $12. The offer is valued at about $146 million, including debt, an SFX spokeswoman said. SFX previously had raised the offer from $11.50 a share in July. Multi-Market shares fell 6.3 cents, to $12.688, while SFX shares fell 50 cents, to $45. The acquisition would combine two radio broadcasters founded by the industry veteran Robert Sillerman, who is chairman and chief executive of SFX. The New York-based radio station operator said the swap would give Multi-Market $12.50 in SFX stock for each Multi-Market share outstanding. The swap depends on SFX shares' trading between $32 and $44 before the transaction closes.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 4 about Erskine Childers, a longtime United Nations official who died on Aug. 25, omitted three survivors. In addition to his wife and son, he is survived by two daughters from his first marriage, Katrina Ann Selstad of Olympia, Wash., and Nicole Louise French of Concord, Calif., and a grandson, Joel Alexander French. His first wife was Sonia M. Childers. (This correction was delayed by attempts to reach survivors for verification.)

title: Pepper in Crowd Leading Wind-Swept Big Apple Classic
description: Swirling winds during the first round of the JAL Big Apple Classic had players donning sweaters and reaching for longer clubs.

title: Inside Art
description: A 1949 Pinup Girl

title: NBC Says It Lost Chance To Broadcast the Yankees
description: Major League Baseball yesterday refused to back down to an NBC Sports claim that it was assured the right to broadcast Game 4 of the Yankees-Texas playoff series in prime time, switching it from an ESPN afternoon telecast.

title: Torre Ponders Lineup Shuffle
description: Joe Torre, concerned about a couple of slumping veterans, said today that he was considering lineup changes ranging beyond the usual preparation for a left-hander.

title: Reduced to Sifting the Silt For T.W.A. Jet Crash Clues
description: Seventy-eight days after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, investigators said today that they remain bereft of conclusive evidence showing that the catastrophic blast aboard the jet was caused by either a criminal act or mechanical failure.

title: On-Line Advertising Standards Proposed
description: The interactive-media coalition formed by the trade associations for agencies and advertisers has proposed standardizing advertisements for on-line media.

title: When Actors Try Directing
description: It's the punch line of some of Hollywood's hoariest jokes: everyone wants to direct. Oscar voters have an especially soft spot in their hearts, and sometimes their heads, for the marquee value of actors turned directors. Last year's Oscar for live-action short went to Christine Lahti, for ''Lieberman in Love.'' The award helped glamorize a category whose films are rarely seen.

title: How Clashes Erupted Into Pitched Battles
description: The Palestinian students set off from this West Bank city at about noon last Wednesday for a march protesting the opening of a tunnel entrance in the Muslim quarter of old Jerusalem. Barred at the Israeli checkpoint from leaving the Palestinian area, they battered the outpost with stones and the edgy soldiers inside fired into the air. It seemed like the long-familiar choreography of the Palestinian uprising.

title: Always Lovable, Always Fathomless
description: Here are some favorite Brahms recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 to $18, for a single CD, to $25 to $32, for a double set, to $60 for a six-CD set; single tape cassettes cost from $5 to $11. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: Agency Switches By 2 Marketers
description: Two marketers have changed agencies on their accounts.

title: Dole Campaign Will Be Bringing Out Its Secret Weapon: the Candidate's Sense of Humor
description: It was only a few seconds after he fell off a makeshift stage recently in Chico, Calif., observers say, that Bob Dole began to joke about it. He was still joking about it yesterday at a campaign stop in Johnson City, Tenn.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 6
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Dominique Wilkins Joins the Spurs
description: DOMINIQUE WILKINS, who had a turbulent year playing in Greece last season, reached agreement yesterday on a contract with the San Antonio Spurs for the National Basketball Association's minimum salary of $247,500.

title: Game-Winning 'Liner' Puts Cards in Command
description: It was not a mammoth shot, a laser line drive or a towering home run that put the St. Louis Cardinals one victory from their first National League Championship Series since 1987. No, it was a nubber off the end of Tom Pagnozzi's bat in the eighth inning today, a ball that floated just beyond the reach of Padres pitcher Trevor Hoffman and gave St. Louis a two-games-to-none lead in the three-of-five-game series that is headed to San Diego.

title: The Cities Climb Back
description: As Henry Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, sees it, the long and devastating ''free fall'' of American cities is over, and the difficult climb back has begun.

title: Single-Family Homes in a Mix, All Maintenance-Free
description: Started a decade ago as a development that was to have more than 500 condominiums, Sterling Woods in Danbury, Conn., had progressed as far as 87 residences before the savings and loan debacle and a real estate recession shut down construction and sales in 1990.

title: CHATEAU PROPERTIES REJECTS SWEETENED BID
description: Chateau Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected an offer by the billionaire Sam Zell to sweeten the terms of his $387 million bid for the manufactured-home community owner and had decided to proceed with a plan to merge with ROC Communities Inc. A combined Chateau and ROC would create the biggest company in the business of renting land to the owners of manufactured homes, with 160 properties in 30 states containing about 50,000 sites. Mr. Zell's concern, Manufactured Home Communities Inc., is the biggest now. Chateau agreed to buy ROC in a stock swap in July. Mr. Zell made his first bid for Chateau about a month later.

title: Polish Poet, Observer of Daily Life, Wins Nobel
description: Wislawa Szymborska, a self-effacing 73-year-old Polish poet who collects trashy postcards because she says trash has no pretensions, won the Nobel Prize for Literature today.

title: Oklahoma Bomb Case Moves To Question of Separate Trials
description: Prosecutors in the case against Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols want a single trial, arguing that the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City resulted from a single conspiracy and that 95 percent of the evidence applies to both defendants.

title: Always Lovable, Always Fathomless
description: Here are some favorite Brahms recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 to $18, for a single CD, to $25 to $32, for a double set, to $60 for a six-CD set; single tape cassettes cost from $5 to $11. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: Analysts cheer the new direction at Hilton Hotels.
description: LONG regarded as well managed but overly cautious, the Hilton Hotels Corporation has recently dispelled most doubts about its ability to react to opportunities with a whirlwind of acquisitions, buyouts and marketing alliances. And Hilton is hinting of more deals to come.

title: 'Another Such Victory'
description: The Washington summit meeting was a public-relations triumph for Prime Minister Netanyahu. He conceded nothing and emerged smiling. His Cabinet Secretary told Israel Radio: ''The results are a great success from the point of view of the Government of Israel.''

title: 28 Arab 'Refugees' Slip Into Sarajevo
description: American and NATO officials are trying to determine how 24 Iraqis and 4 Jordanians landed here in a Jordanian military plane and nearly slipped off unnoticed.

title: Day 1 for New Knicks
description: When the Knicks begin their first day of workouts on Friday at the College of Charleston, Patrick Ewing's baseline fall-away will have some company. There is Larry Johnson's turnaround jump shot in the lane and Allan Houston's pillowy 20-footers from around the perimeter. There is Chris Childs's penetration off the dribble and three rookies -- John Wallace, Walter McCarty and Dontae' Jones -- who can put the ball in the basket with ease.

title: Thief Didn't Have a Prayer Against the Torah Task Force
description: The burglar always wore a yarmulke. He walked into synagogues in Manhattan and Brooklyn, asking for a place to say a prayer, and he walked out with one or more Torahs, the sacred scrolls that contain the five Books of Moses, hidden in a large duffle bag.

title: Always Lovable, Always Fathomless
description: Here are some favorite Brahms recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 to $18, for a single CD, to $25 to $32, for a double set, to $60 for a six-CD set; single tape cassettes cost from $5 to $11. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Flipper

title: Fiddling to a Better Life
description: Nothing would be easier than describing ''Small Wonders'' as the inspirational story of a dedicated violin teacher working among the children of three public schools in East Harlem.

title: CHRONICLE
description: INGRID CROCE, the widow of the singer Jim Croce, who died in a plane crash in 1973, is attempting to bring his name and his voice back into public consciousness with an unusual mix of words, music and food.

title: Pirates Choose Lamont as Manager
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates didn't look beyond their dugout to find JIM LEYLAND's replacement, hiring GENE LAMONT, the third-base coach, yesterday as their third manager in 20 years.

title: Faces From a Fictional Melting Pot
description: ART reflects the culture it comes from, we know. But sometimes, for better or for worse, it has ambitions to shape that culture as well. Such is the case with the work in an inspired and offbeat exhibition titled ''New World Orders: Casta Painting and Colonial Latin America,'' at the Americas Society.

title: Battling Senatorial Candidates To Debate, but Very Carefully
description: After trading charges and countercharges for weeks in often sharp-edged advertisements on radio and television, the two candidates vying for the New Jersey Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley are to meet face to face for the first time in a debate tomorrow afternoon.

title: Bond Prices Dip Ahead Of Job Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mostly lower yesterday, with the only increase coming in the longest maturity.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: What Campaign?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Art in Review
description: Tom Wesselmann

title: Leyland to Make His Choice Today
description: There will soon be two losers and one big winner in the JIM LEYLAND derby. Leyland, who spent yesterday studying three offers that would very likely make him baseball's highest-paid manager, expects to choose his new team today.

title: MCKESSON PLANS TO ADD FOXMEYER HEALTH UNIT
description: The McKesson Corporation said yesterday that it would pay out $400 million to acquire the ailing drug unit of the Foxmeyer Health Corporation, to expand its United States pharmaceutical distribution business. Foxmeyer placed its Foxmeyer Drug Company unit in Chapter 11 protection in August. McKesson will pay up to $80 million in cash and provide an additional $30 million to Foxmeyer Drug through a participation in the company's financing agreement with GE Capital Services, allowing the purchase of about $100 million of additional inventory. McKesson will also assume $290 million of Foxmeyer's secured debt. McKesson shares rose $3.375 yesterday, to $49.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: On the Sidelines, Many Third-Party Candidates Are Hoping to Make a Point
description: When Bill Clinton and Bob Dole face off in their first debate on Sunday, Ross Perot will not be the only Presidential candidate sitting on the sidelines.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Wednesday about a 50th-birthday party for the cosmetics executive Marc Rosen given by his wife, the actress Arlene Dahl, included an erroneous reference, supplied by his office, to his current position. He is president of his own firm, Marc Rosen Associates. He left Elizabeth Arden in 1989.

title: Judge Rejects Interview Plan In Bomb Case
description: Timothy J. McVeigh's effort to burnish his public image before he goes on trial in the Oklahoma City bombing was rejected today by the Federal judge who will hear the case.

title: S.E.C. Closes Its Investigation of Denver Airport
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, as expected, said today that it had closed its two-year investigation into Denver's sale of $3.9 billion in airport bonds without making any charges.

title: Eleanor Roosevelt Honored in Hometown Today
description: Eleanor Roosevelt was born and died in New York City, and spent big intervals of her life here. Today, she comes home -- as a statue in Riverside Park.

title: Genital Ritual Is Unyielding in Africa
description: Marthe Bleu is 12 years old, a shy, pretty girl with a heart-shaped face, dressed in flip-flops and a lacy white pinafore trimmed in pink satin. But already her body is taking on the soft, rounded shape of womanhood. And these days she wants more than anything to do what she believes stands between her and being grown up. She wants to have her genitals cut off.

title: Environmentalists Say Deal On Redwoods Is Inadequate
description: When officials announced a tentative agreement last weekend to protect a 7,500-acre swath of redwoods in Northern California, they hoped it would end a decadelong struggle over the fate of the last stand of the old-growth trees in private hands.

title: No-Smoking Section: Entire Village?
description: On balmy, sunny days like these, Claudia Lohaus enjoys spending the noon hour in the plaza outside the Friendship Heights Village Council building, a tidy little park with lots of trees, flowers and a fountain in the middle.

title: Cardinals' Eckersley Proves He Can Still Make a Difference
description: A brief chat with Dennis Eckersley last spring told Tony La Russa all he needed to know about the way his longtime closer in Oakland was approaching his new life with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: How Dole Fell
description: To understand why Bob Dole's Presidential quest is D.O.A. at the first debate, don't listen to pundits or White House spin artists but to a conservative Republican strategist in his party's trenches. A 103-page campaign document commissioned by Americans for a Republican Majority -- the political action committee headed by Tom DeLay, the House majority whip -- tells everything you need to know about why the Dole-Kemp campaign has failed.

title: At Practices, A Candidate Is Modest . . .
description: In a community that prides itself on being a venerable debating society, President Clinton's practice encounters for his confrontation with Bob Dole on Sunday night are being conducted in private. So one can only catch intimations of how he is doing.

title: In the End, How Will Cigar Be Remembered?
description: BY 4 o'clock Thursday afternoon, Tim Jones and Simon Bray had finished a long day's work. As assistants to Bill Mott, the trainer, Jones and Bray had supervised the feeding, the hot walking, the cooling down and the grooming of 20 race horses in their stable at Belmont Park. The horse receiving fastidious attention was the one they call Cigar.

title: A 'Gone With the Wind' In China, Without War
description: ''Temptress Moon,'' set in 1920's China, is a sensuous cinematic whoosh of opium smoke, lily pads and seductively lowered eyes. In evoking Shanghai's decadence during the pre-Communist era, the film, Chen Kaige's follow-up to his acclaimed epic, ''Farewell My Concubine,'' conjures a world of fabulous dance halls and elegant corruption, all seen through a gauzy, opiate haze. Beautiful women swoon in the arms of icy, white-suited gigolos. Exquisite revenge is exacted by lacing an enemy's opium with arsenic and turning him into an immobilized, ashen ghost of his former self.

title: Devils Open Against Red Wings
description: The Devils will open their season at home tonight, but unlike last year, there will be no banners raised to the ceiling of Continental Arena. The Devils' goal for 1996-97 is to erase the disappointment of last season, when they failed to make the playoffs after winning the Stanley Cup.

title: New York Legislature Needs Reform, Not Raises
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Officer Charged in Murder
description: A New York City police officer was charged with murder yesterday in the Westchester County village of Dobbs Ferry after the authorities said he shot a man to death during an off-duty fight over a parking spot in front of a delicatessen owned by the officer's father.

title: The Personalities, and There Are Many, of Peter Pucci
description: It is hard to envision a choreographer with more personalities than Peter Pucci, at least on the evidence of an evening of new and recent dances presented by Peter Pucci Plus Dancers on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea).

title: Film Festival Regrets
description: To the Editor:

title: Presenting the IgNobels, UnPrizes Satirizing Weak Science
description: What was surprising about the IgNobel Prizes this year was that the winners of two of them actually accepted them. Usually winners ignore the prizes completely.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Sept. 23 about a boy accused of painting swastikas on a nature trail in Mamaroneck, N.Y., referred incorrectly in some editions to his father's employer. The police did not specifically identify the family. According to the French Consulate General in New York, the father is not an employee of the consulate.

title: Pierce Takes 3-Stroke Lead Over Pepper and McGann
description: The swirling winds that made a mockery of the opening round of the JAL Big Apple Classic died down today and so did the scores, at least somewhat, during the second day of the 54-hole tournament.

title: Some New Yorkers Don't Welcome Kmart
description: To the Editor:

title: Step to Raise Liability Limit In Air Crashes
description: The Transportation Department took a big step today to eliminate the $75,000 limit on airlines' liability in international air crashes that has been specified by the Warsaw Convention since 1966.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: INSIDE
description: Concern Over Pope's Health

title: Common Sense on Harassment
description: Despite a flurry of confusing publicity, New York City's Board of Education has taken a calm, sensible step in deciding to review its guidelines on sexual harassment. Clearly, common sense dictates that a 7-year-old pupil should be more delicately disciplined than a teen-ager. In the now-celebrated case of De'Andre Dearinge, the principal of Public School 104 in Queens suspended the second grader for what she described as sexual harassment. On the incomplete facts now before the public, it appears that a suspension for misconduct or disruptive classroom behavior may well have been warranted, but the ''sexual harassment'' label seems out of place. There ought to be a distinction between acts by unruly children in the primary grades and intrusive behavior by older students.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7

title: Dramatic Gold Takes Cup
description: Dramatic Gold won a narrow stretch duel tonight to capture the $750,000 Buick Meadowlands Cup, the richest thoroughbred race ever held in New Jersey.

title: Campaign Debate Gives Hartford An Opportunity to Promote Itself
description: In the minds of city leaders here, when Bob Dole and Bill Clinton square off in their debate on Sunday, there will be one clear winner: Hartford.

title: Top Educator Is Leaving To Open School in Boston
description: Deborah Meier, an innovative educator who spearheaded the creation of dozens of experimental public academies in New York City in recent years, is leaving the city's school system with plans to open a new school in Boston, saying she has grown restless with the pace of change in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the selection of a Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine referred imprecisely to the Episcopal Bishop of New York, Richard F. Grein. Anita Lemonis, director of communications for the Diocese of New York, says the Bishop is considered a centrist, not a traditionalist.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Cream of the C.H.S.F.L.

title: Clintonian Speeches: A Guide for Listeners
description: In nearly four years as President, Bill Clinton has made thousands of speeches: short ones, long ones, big ones, little ones, good ones, bad ones. But in a way, he has made just one speech -- over and over and over again.

title: Bridgeport's Battle
description: State troopers have joined city police officers in manning roadblocks in Bridgeport, Conn., hoping to stem the drug trade believed to be behind several murders that have stunned the faded industrial city. And everyone from the Governor down insists that Bridgeport is not about to return to its bad old ways.

title: Extend the Work Year
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Tribute, Old Talent Plays Off Young
description: The ''All-Star Tribute to Oscar Peterson'' at Town Hall on Tuesday night yielded some isolated crackling moments, but not much sustained energy. The sold-out concert, which is to be released on the Telarc label early next year, wound through a handful of Mr. Peterson's original blues pieces, dotted with standards and spot performances that seemed to have no connection to Mr. Peterson. That's normal for benefit concerts, which this was (some proceeds went to the Jackie Robinson Foundation, which provides scholarships for black college students), but it was odd for a tribute to a musician who's still playing ably.

title: Accord on a Voting Rule
description: State officials agreed yesterday to modify a rule that the Democratic State Committee said would have discouraged poor urban residents from voting. The regulation would have forced people whose eligibility was questioned to go to the municipal clerk's office to provide proof of an address change before they could vote. Under the settlement, these voters would sign a statement affirming their new address. The addresses will be checked later, and paper ballots with false statements could be withdrawn, said Angelo Genova, a lawyer for the Democratic committee. Judge Maryanne Trump Barry of the Federal District Court in Newark is expected to sign the agreement on Monday.

title: In Bridgeport, Stopping Cars To Stop a Wave of Killings
description: ''I got a weapon,'' State Trooper Brad Bopp shouted in the chill darkness, reaching into the back seat of a battered brown sedan. ''It's live, live!''

title: Ex-Police Chief Sentenced
description: Robert A. Spina, the former Police Chief of West Orange, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for tipping off the target of a drug and child abuse investigation in 1991. Mr. Spina, 41, who resigned after he was convicted in August, has also been charged with abusing his wife, Suzanne, and endangering their children, but Judge Harold W. Fullilove of the Superior Court has not set a trial date on those charges.

title: Would-Be Judges Stalled
description: Faith S. Hochberg, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, was nominated for a Federal judgeship in November, but the Senate adjourned on Thursday without confirming her and 27 other judicial candidates. Dan Maffei, a spokesman for Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat who nominated Ms. Hochberg to the bench, complained that the confirmation process had become more partisan. Only 17 judicial nominations were confirmed this year, he said, compared with an average of 55 during each of the last four Presidential election years. But Jean Lopatto, a spokeswoman for the Senate Judiciary Committee, defended the record of the 104th Congress, saying that 73 of 105 nominees were confirmed.

title: Brannon Charges, Straight Into Jones's Punishing Left Hook
