description: Roy Jones Jr., seeming more concerned with fighting boredom than opponents, lectured the Madison Square Garden crowd on boxing last night in an unusual public forum. And then he taught Bryant Brannon a cruel lesson, halting him in the second round of their supermiddleweight bout.

title: Mathematics Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre's Faith Rewarded
description: The Yankees' Joe Torre, a players' manager in the most traditional sense, refuses to abandon the guys who got him into the post-season in his first year in the Bronx.

title: U.S. Weighs Tougher Reaction to Burmese Crackdown
description: The Clinton Administration is struggling to decide whether the intensified crackdown on political activity in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, amounts to the ''large-scale repression'' of the democratic opposition that, according to a new law, would trigger a ban on all new American investment there.

title: Judge in Homicide Trial Implies Perjury by Officers
description: In a withering assessment of the defense's case, a judge suggested yesterday that police officers had lied on the witness stand to protect a fellow officer accused of strangling a Bronx man in a dispute over a late-night football game.

title: A Stolen Dali Drawing Resurfaces After 13 Years
description: Thanks to an alert art collector and an honorable New York City gallery owner, a drawing by Salvador Dali, the Spanish Surrealist, that was stolen 13 years ago was in police custody yesterday.

title: European Union Seeks To Protect Small Airlines
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it was considering a fairer system for allocating times for airplanes to take off and land. The commission, the executive agency of the European Union, said it had not set a deadline to produce a plan but that discussions were part of an attempt to keep large airlines from abusing market dominance.

title: Skip Away Bidding to Be Superhorse's Kryptonite
description: He may not have the best pedigree. He hasn't worked out over the track at Belmont Park, and he won't. He isn't even eligible for the Breeders' Cup, so this is his final appearance of the year. He is the classic case of here today and gone tomorrow.

title: The Ups and Downs Of U.S. Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way to Defuse the I.R.A.
description: Last Monday, just after the Irish Government had hyped an impending Irish Republican Army cease-fire, the British police carried out raids on I.R.A. suspects in England that netted 10 tons of homemade explosives, two pounds of Semtex explosive and several ready-to-go car bombs. British intelligence had indicated that the I.R.A. was about to launch attacks that, unlike the after-hours bombing in London's Canary Wharf in February, were intended to kill people, possibly prominent politicians.

title: Lowery Provides Glimmer Of Hope
description: Pro football, an unforgiving sport, can also be redemptive. So on Sunday, when the Jets play host to the Oakland Raiders, Nick Lowery will be going for the National Football League career record in field goals.

title: . . . Another Is Gregarious
description: At the Seaview Hotel here, the Crystal Ballroom often used for bar mitzvahs and weddings -- was transformed today into a debate preparation studio with a few blue curtains and television lights.

title: Bond Prices Surge as Drop in Payrolls Indicates No Rate Rises
description: Treasury prices surged yesterday after the September employment report bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates this year.

title: Pina Bausch? Funny? Yes. And Sad.
description: Heartbreak may always bring the same pains. Yet the heart can break in many different places, and the process is not without its humor.

title: The Knicks Are Off and Running at Camp
description: The first practice lasted three and a half hours. Afterward, Larry Johnson's shorts were stained with blood. Patrick Ewing, who talks about winning a title at the start of every preseason, sounded less naive.

title: Sixth Avenue Support
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''I think the Holy Father is finding it difficult to learn how to be an old man. It is not a role he had prepared himself to play. And we are going to have to accustom ourselves to an older, less vigorous Pope, which is something of a shock given what we are used to seeing.''

title: Parking Rules
Yanks Change Their Luck in a Desperate 9th
description: The Yankees jumped out of the dugout as soon as Mariano Duncan's single dropped safely into center field. They screamed, they pumped their fists, they hugged each other and they exhaled. Mostly, they exhaled. The Yankees were not supposed to win, not after the way they performed in the first eight, treacherous innings. But they did. Somehow, they did.

title: U.S. REPORTS DROP IN RATE OF BIRTHS TO UNWED WOMEN
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, the rate of births among unmarried women declined in 1995, and for the fourth year in a row the teen-age birth rate dropped, the National Center for Health Statistics said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Haydn Proctor, 93, a Judge And New Jersey State Senator
description: Haydn Proctor, a longtime New Jersey official who operated at the highest levels of all three branches of state government, died on Wednesday at a hospital near his home in Lakewood, N.J. He was 93, and before capping his public career with 16 years on the State Supreme Court had been president of the State Senate and Acting Governor.

title: High Canada Aide Quits After Somalia Scandal
description: Canada's Minister of Defense resigned today, a day after an army official testified that top military officials had altered documents to cover up responsibility for the beating death of a Somali teen-ager at the hands of Canadian peacekeeping troops in 1993.

title: Inmates to the Rescue
description: They were serving sentences for robbery, receiving stolen property, weapons possession and assault. But when four prisoners on road cleanup detail Thursday saw two trucks collide and burst into flames on Route 3 in Clifton, they did not hesitate to help, the police said. The minimum-security prisoners, along with John Ortiz, a senior corrections officer, sprayed the burning trucks with fire extinguishers and pulled the two drivers to safety, The Associated Press reported. No one was seriously injured.

title: With a Mind for Facts And a Soul for Jazz
description: In a small radio studio on the ground floor of Riverside Cathedral in upper Manhattan, the music ends and the on-air light goes on. Phil Schaap names the musicians on the record (which he pronounces ''rekkid''), takes a deep breath and 14 minutes later wraps up an ad-libbed concentrated history of Miles Davis's career, heading toward the moment in 1955 when Davis crossed paths with John Coltrane.

title: Beliefs
description: ''He talks of his death freely and with a smile,'' said Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger, the archbishop of Paris. ''There is no fear in the face of the void.''

title: Cable News Feud Has Personal and Political Roots
description: In backing Rupert Murdoch's fledgling cable news channel against Time Warner, the Giuliani administration has waded into a corporate grudge match that sounds as though it was dreamed up in Hollywood.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Responding to Burmese Repression
description: A new law went into effect this week requiring President Clinton to impose an American investment ban on Myanmar if its already repressive military regime extends its crackdown against dissent and democracy. The timing was exquisite. Myanmar, as Burma was renamed by its current rulers, is currently being shaken by the worst repression of the last five years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHECKFREE CORP., Columbus, Ohio, a provider of electronic commerce services and software, sold its securities certificate and accounting software subsidiary to Sungard Data Systems Inc., Wayne, Pa., for $20 million.

title: Judge Praises Umpires, but Won't Allow a Strike
description: The militant, weeklong effort by major league umpires to force the immediate suspension of Roberto Alomar ended today when a Federal judge told them they could not strike the remaining games of the playoffs and World Series. As a result, the umpires worked the two American League games today and said they would work through the rest of the post-season.

title: Corrections
description: Poetry excerpts yesterday with an article about Wislawa Szymborska, winner of the 1996 Nobel Prize for Literature, omitted attribution. They were from ''View With a Grain of Sand,'' an anthology of translations by Stanislaw Baranczak and Clare Cavanagh, published by Harcourt Brace. A front-page excerpt with a cross-reference to the article also came from the anthology.

title: Suspect Is Back in Jail
description: A Bronx man who was freed on bail on Thursday after being jailed in the death of a police officer was jailed again yesterday for not completing the deal he had made with his bail bondsman that led to his release.

title: Peaceful Man With a Flair for Violence
description: Chemistry project: Take the powdered contents of a small box of Jell-O. Add water.

title: Dole Hopes Whitman's Magic Works for Him
description: Christine Todd Whitman is the Republicans' good-luck charm. In Michigan, in Florida, almost everywhere, party operatives inoculate themselves against discouraging polls and apathetic voters by recalling the New Jersey Governor's stirring last-minute escape from what seemed sure defeat in 1993, largely on the strength of a pledge to slash taxes.

title: Japan's Forgotten People Try to Make Voices Heard
description: Shigeru Kayano has a slightly different take on the history of northern Japan than the school textbooks.

title: Japan Agrees to Talk In Photo Film Dispute
description: Japan said yesterday that it had conditionally accepted a United States request for talks on a dispute over photographic film and paper under the auspices of the World Trade Organization. The Government said Japan accepted the United States request only if there were similar talks about the United States market.

title: A Decimal Yes
description: To the Editor:

title: ARIS INDUSTRIES SELLS DIVISION TO PAGE HOLDING
description: Aris Industries Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its Perry Manufacturing unit to the Page Holding Company for $40 million in cash, $12 million in debt forgiveness and $4 million of assumed Perry debt. Aris said it had used the proceeds to reduce its debt obligations to Heller Financial Inc., its senior lender, from about $53 million to $1 million. Aris Industries, based in New York, owns and operates Europe Craft Imports Inc., a designer and importer of men's outerwear and sportswear.

title: We're No. 3!
description: Of course, denial is always the first stage of coping with any sort of trauma, and Harvard's initial reaction to its precipitous drop from No. 1 to No. 3 in the latest U. S. News and World Report guide to American colleges proved no exception.

title: JOB MARKET WEAK AS ECONOMY EASES, BUT WAGES ARE UP
description: The job market weakened in September, confirming a slowing of the economy, as payrolls unexpectedly fell by 40,000 and the unemployment rate inched up, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A Dominican Leader Receives an Official Embrace
description: As he rushed between appointments yesterday, Leonel Fernandez Reyna took a moment to reminisce about his days as a grocery delivery boy on the Upper West Side. He even managed to come up with a name: Mr. Meyers, the owner of the store where he worked on Amsterdam Avenue, between 95th and 96th Streets.

title: If Pope's Pain Is Clear, Its Causes Remain Murky
description: For months now, the news from the Vatican has fluctuated up and down, like the line on a patient's chart. Some weeks, Pope John Paul II looks better, but on the many days when he seems weak, vague and older than his 76 years, the whispers start up again: ''Il Papa sta male''; the Pope is not well.

title: Chilly Scenes From Lonely People's Lives
description: Andre Techine's densely woven ''Voleurs'' (''Thieves'') is full of wintry people, all of them somehow cheated or bereft of love. In a film that jumps through time and switches narrative perspectives as if studying the cold, hard facets of a crystal, Mr. Techine explores the intricate connections among these characters with a somber, penetrating wisdom that is the film's main reward.

title: G.O.P.'s Good-Luck Charm
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is the Republicans' good-luck charm. In Michigan, in Florida, almost everywhere, party operatives inoculate themselves against discouraging polls and apathetic voters by recalling Mrs. Whitman's last-minute escape from what seemed sure defeat in 1993, largely on the strength of a pledge to slash taxes. If it worked for her, Republicans say, bravely whistling their happy tune, it can work for Bob Dole -- at least in New Jersey, a swing state with an aversion to high taxes. $(Page 1.$)

title: Constitutional Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: For Philadelphia Blacks, Clinton Is 'the Lesser of Two Evils'
description: Derrick Rhamad is the kind of voter the Republicans say they have been dreaming about to help them retake the White House next month. He is a 32-year-old black bank investigator, who advocates boot-strap capitalism and a strong military. He denounces ''welfare dependency,'' high taxes and soft-on-crime liberals.

title: Thinking, Not Just Feeling, Required
description: There are times when Trisha Brown is almost impossibly exasperating. Take her new ''Twelve Ton Rose,'' presented by the Trisha Brown Dance Company on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the troupe performs through tomorrow (30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene) in a 25th-anniversary season. Why give such a silly name to a dance so filled with mystery and beauty that it promises to become a signature work for the choreographer? Is there a subtext about a very heavy flower or a truck-driving woman? As it happens, the title refers to Anton Webern, to whose music the piece is set, and his compositional 12-tone rows.

title: STOCK OF THE GENSYM COMPANY FALLS SHARPLY
description: The stock of the Gensym Corporation plunged more than 40 percent yesterday, a day after the company, a software maker, said it expected third-quarter earnings to fall below Wall Street's forecasts. The company, based in Cambridge, Mass., said it expected to earn 3 cents a share in the three months that ended on Monday, compared with 3 cents in the same period a year ago. Analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. had predicted 12 cents a share. The company also predicted revenue of $8.9 million, up 18 percent from the 1995 period. The company attributed its failure to close a number of significant orders in the quarter for the disappointing forecast. Gensym shares fell $8.50 to close at $12.50 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: The Ups and Downs Of U.S. Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: City Hall Threatens Action if Time Warner Rejects Channel
description: The Giuliani administration stepped up the pressure yesterday in its effort to persuade Time Warner to carry Rupert Murdoch's new 24-hour cable news channel in New York City, suggesting that a refusal by Time Warner could influence a city panel that will be reviewing the company's lucrative cable franchises next week.

title: The Personal Care Business Has Outpaced the Demand
description: Just a few years ago, banana hair cream and berry-based lipstick seemed the perfect ingredients for a new business venture.

title: Canada Strike Could Close G.M.'s Plants In U.S. Shortly
description: The General Motors Corporation has been quietly stockpiling auto parts in preparation for this week's strike by the Canadian Automobile Workers union, but may still be forced to begin closing factories in the United States by the end of next week if the strike continues, G.M. and union officials said today.

title: When Gambling Calls the Shots
description: Imagine the public outrage if state governments began to rely heavily on liquor sales to pay for vital programs, raising revenue by encouraging people to drink more and even advertising new alcoholic concoctions on billboards.

title: In Her Own Words
description: ELIZABETH DOLE

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Buckeyes Face Big Test Against Nittany Lions
description: The league is nothing like it was in the good old days around here, when the approach to a Big Ten season was to continue to improve and keep people healthy until deep into November, when Ohio State and Michigan would determine who would earn a Rose Bowl bid.

title: A Civic Heart Is Sold Off In 'Bake Sale'
description: SEVERAL hundred bargain hunters filed into the auditorium at Police Headquarters, where the city was selling vacant lots and buildings on Wednesday. As the pony-tailed auctioneer recited the rules, Anna Vincenty turned around and whispered some last-minute advice to her friend Yolanda Garcia.

title: CHARTWELL RE IN TALKS TO ADD ARCHER GROUP
description: The Chartwell Re Corporation said yesterday that it was in discussions to take over Archer Group Holdings, which runs syndicates at the Lloyd's of London insurance market. Shares of Archer Group rose 20 pence, to 81.5 pence, on the London Stock Exchange. Shares of Chartwell, based in Stamford, Conn., rose 87.5 cents, to $26, on the New York Stock Exchange. Terms were not disclosed. Archer had a market value of about $:31 million, or about $50.8 million, after the takeover news pushed the stock up.

title: 3 Are Killed In Shootings In Brooklyn
description: Two would-be robbers burst into an apartment in a housing project in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn around noon yesterday, touching off gunfire that killed two men in the apartment and a teen-age boy across the street, the police said.

title: Gay Political Advisers
description: To The Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks and Bonds Rally On Weak Employment Data

title: Six Charged With Fraud In 2 Stocks
description: Six men, including a former lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission, have been indicted on charges of securities fraud involving two Nasdaq companies.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Rangers Hope It's Their Turn to Rally
description: For the Rangers, it was the sweep that got away. Eight outs away.

title: The Berlin and Brahms, Measuring Each Other
description: It makes little sense to talk about the greatest orchestra in the world. The great orchestras all possess their own particular incomparable sound. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra has a golden timbre to match any in Europe. The Cleveland Orchestra is a feast of precision. The Vienna Philharmonic is a wonder of esthetic self-government, perpetuating its excellence without consistent direction from the podium.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the compensation of Jerre L. Stead, chief executive of Ingram Micro Inc., referred incorrectly to terms of his stock options. As the article noted, he will be allowed to make his stock purchases at the initial offering price, not at a reduced price.

title: Roller Coaster Verdict
description: A Brick Township couple on Thursday was awarded $1 million for injuries the wife suffered in 1993 when a roller coaster car stopped short of the ride's first peak and slid backwards. The accident at Jenkinson's South Family Amusement Center in Point Pleasant Beach left Joy Bearden, 27, with permanent damage to her left arm, her lawyer, Marguerite A. Maggs, said yesterday. Mrs. Bearden's husband, Glen, 26, was treated for whiplash. The Beardens presented evidence that the system that was supposed to prevent the car from slipping failed because of negligent maintenance, Ms. Maggs said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL STUDIES SALE OF SOME UNITS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is considering the sale of some business units at a time when profit expectations for the company are falling. The nation's second-largest steelmaker hired Salomon Brothers Inc. as a financial adviser to explore selling Bethlehem Structural Products, Bethforge and Centec, which have 1,345 employees. The company is also considering keeping those businesses running or shutting them down and then trying to sell them.

title: Alomar's Lightly Slapped Wrist
description: The ugly incident in which Roberto Alomar of the Baltimore Orioles spit in the face of an umpire and later made cruel references about the tragic death of the umpire's son has now been pushed offstage in an unsatisfactory manner. By any reasonable standard of justice, Alomar should have been punished promptly and suspended for a suitable number of games. That is the only way to deter further abuse of umpires and insure that they can control the game. But cowardice by baseball officials has allowed him to finish the season, participate in the playoffs and postpone a decreed five-day suspension until the regular season next year, when it will mean little to him or his team.

title: Fichaud Shines in Goal, But Isles Cannot Score
description: Eric Fichaud deserved better. He had better get used to it.

title: Acquittal In Death Of Gerulaitis
description: A Suffolk County jury found a 34-year-old pool mechanic not guilty today of criminally negligent homicide in the death of the tennis star Vitas Gerulaitis, who was overcome by carbon monoxide from an improperly vented pool heater in September 1994.

title: Guilty of Lottery Kickbacks
description: The former national sales manager of Gtech, which has operated New Jersey's lottery since 1984, was convicted yesterday of taking $169,500 in kickbacks from a consulting firm in Atlantic County. The executive, J. David Smith, was accused of paying inflated fees to Benchmark Group Inc., of Linwood, so that some of the money could be funneled back to him. A Federal jury in Newark returned split verdicts on the owners of Benchmark, convicting Steven Dandrea, of Longport, of bribery, conspiracy and other charges, but acquitting Joseph LaPorta, of Williamstown, of the same charges.

title: Rogers Is the Enemy In His Own Backyard
description: Kenny Rogers lives two minutes from the Ballpark in Arlington, close enough to see dozens of tents snaked around the stadium for fans waiting to purchase possible Rangers World Series tickets.

title: An I.R.S. Ruling Ruffles Airline Industry Feathers
description: The Internal Revenue Service has ruled that money a regional airline spent on periodic engine inspections should be treated as a capital investment and not an ordinary business expense, a ruling that the airline industry says could cost it more than $1 billion between now and 2004, if it were applied nationally.

title: On the Trail, Dole's Wife Seeks Votes Of Women
description: Elizabeth Dole is on a one-woman mission to exterminate the ''gender gap'' that is plaguing her husband.

title: Leyland Hired; Collins Fired
description: The careers of two longtime minor league managers who found success in the National League went in opposite directions today.

title: In Milan, Trading In Suits For Chiffon
description: The models are so sought after here, chased by paparazzi and hounded for autographs by groupies, that when they eat at Bice at night, they hide at a back table in the kitchen and serve as eye candy to the chefs.

title: Charles P. Bean, 72; Physicist Analyzed Superconductivity
description: Charles P. Bean, a physicist known for his analyses of superconductivity and magnetism, died on Monday in Fairfax, Va. He was 72 and lived in Niskayuna, N.Y.

title: Another Brush With Disaster, Another Late Comeback
description: Maybe the Yankees are a product of their environment, the one in the Bronx that George Steinbrenner questionably says is dangerous. The Yankees, after all, obviously like to live dangerously.

title: Foes Take Steps To Cut Tension In West Bank
description: Palestinian policemen and Muslim clerics joined efforts to prevent any disturbances in the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, and the Israeli Army moved tanks out of sight to reduce tensions.

title: Slower Trading to Cut Earnings for Yamaichi
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company said yesterday that it had cut its earnings forecast because of declining brokerage commissions and lower profits from trading. Yamaichi is the second of Japan's four largest brokerage firms to cut earnings estimates. On Sept. 17, the Nikko Securities Company also cited slower trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: Boys and Girls Require (A) Equal Scores or (B) Equal Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Needs Solo Discipline
description: NOW that the umpires had to be ordered by a Federal judge not to spit on their own integrity -- which they were willing to do in their threat to strike the playoffs -- Bud Selig, the acting commissioner who is always slow to act, has called a Nov. 14 meeting to thrash out guidelines for future incidents similar to Roberto Alomar's expectorations.

title: Bridge
description: Taking part in the world junior team championships often involves a trip to an exotic locale. The 1995 event was played on the tropical island of Bali, in Indonesia.

title: At a Ceremony in Kenya, A Harsh Rite of Passage For a Brother and Sister
description: When the sun broke over the wheat fields and pine forests of the Samburu highlands this morning, the sound of warriors singing rose up from the Lelesit family compound, an eerie chant about blood and pain that seemed to belong to another age.

title: Sterling Forest, Saved
description: The Senate's last-minute decision to approve an omnibus parks bill was a victory for common sense and bipartisan cooperation. The bill authorizes $17.5 million to help purchase Sterling Forest, an important watershed on the New Jersey-New York border, from a private developer.

title: Where to Watch or Hear Candidates' Debates
description: WASHINGTON  The debate Sunday between President Bill Clinton and his Republican challenger, Bob Dole, will be broadcast live outside the United States on television and radio, as will the second debate, on Oct. 16, and the vice-presidential face-off, on Oct. 9.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an accord between Bosnia and Serbia referred incorrectly to the Yugoslav federation. It now consists of Serbia and Montenegro, not Serbia and Macedonia.

title: South African Atrocity Panel Subpoenas 9 Former Officials
description: Unable to get former top military and police officials to testify voluntarily about the atrocities of the past, South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission began to issue subpoenas today, including one to a former Minister of Law and Order.

title: Tiptoe In the Minefield
description: Once I made the mistake of describing something as imbecilic. I forget what it was. Probably something a Congressman had said or done. Maybe the hula hoop, possibly a new TV sitcom. No matter.

title: Ads Preview New Jersey Debate
description: New Jersey's candidates for the United States Senate stayed out of sight on the eve of their first public debate. But while Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican from Delaware Township, and his Democratic opponent, Representative Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood, were preparing today for the face-off, their camps unveiled new television advertisements.

title: Daly Says He Still Drinks
description: Ever since the P.G.A. Championship in August, the whispers on the PGA Tour had been growing louder week by week. With each missed cut, every bad round, the persistent talk was that John Daly, admitted alcoholic and former Tour problem child, was drinking again.

title: No C and No A for Gretzky. Just a Regular Blue Jersey.
description: It wouldn't be accurate to call it a demotion. Wayne Gretzky was never a captain or an alternate captain for the Rangers. So he didn't lose something he already had on the eve of the regular-season opener.

title: M.K. McCutcheon, Times Executive, 40
description: Michael K. McCutcheon, executive director of labor relations at The New York Times, died yesterday at his parents' home in Manhattan. Mr. McCutcheon, who was 40, committed suicide, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: Taking part in the world junior team championships often involves a trip to an exotic locale. The 1995 event was played on the tropical island of Bali, in Indonesia.

title: Wall Street Bears Lose 2 More Voices
description: Uncle.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Green's numbing article on the perceived failure of the safe-sex message should raise the consciousness, if not the hair, of readers in general and those with special concern regarding the AIDS epidemic. Yet, as one who spent several years in the trenches, trying not only to get out the ''just say no'' message (and other sensible, even enjoyable, options) but also to put it all in a context of basic realities, it is difficult but not impossible to marvel at young men who virtually insist on exposure to H.I.V. infection.

title: Tonight's Debate
description: The debate in Hartford tonight between President Clinton and Bob Dole will begin at 9 P.M. It will be broadcast on the ABC (Channel 7 in New York), CBS (Channel 2), NBC (Channel 4) and PBS (Channel 13) television networks, and on CNN and C-Span. National Public Radio will also broadcast the debate.

title: Region's Economic Mood Turns a Corner
description: THE list of Long Island woes has become familiar: High taxes, high electric costs, traffic congestion and the loss of military jobs and contracts have combined to sap the vitality of one of the country's richest regions.

title: Hopeless in Chandrapore
description: August 17, 1924: 'A Passage to India' by E. M. Forster

title: Forget Pearl Harbor
description: THE eight teachers walked into a hot and stuffy classroom on the fourth floor of University Heights High School in the Bronx and, as always, they were in for a pressure-cooker afternoon. They took their seats at a round brown table, arranged their favorite books, videos and photocopied packets in a stack in front of them and began to wrestle with the question: What should the students know?

title: Army Runs Away From Yale in 2d Half
description: Michie Stadium was filled to the lip today on a beautiful afternoon for football, and for a while Yale gave Army some competition.

title: SCORES COUNT
description: I am impressed with Johnson's dedication and success; there is a great deal in the Science Skills Center that is worthy of replication. However, his characterization of progressive education is not accurate.

title: Lions Remain Perfect By Trouncing Crusaders
description: From bad, to mediocre, to downright impressive. That's the route the Columbia University football program has traveled over the past decade. Once the laughingstock of Division I football, this season the Lions sit at the top of the Ivy League standings. With the help of a dominant running game and a stingy defense, the Lions today extended their perfect start to this season with a 42-16 victory at Holy Cross.

title: Wounded Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Door to Danger, a Booming City
description: Real estate developers often come fishing for tax breaks to build in this desert town, citing the location -- 17 miles down valley from almost half of the nation's chemical weapons.

title: Chain Letter
description: September 20, 1964: 'Herzog' by Saul Bellow By Julian Moynahan

title: Book Review 100 Years
Adventures in Antiques, Back at the State Armory
description: AFTER a three-year hiatus the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society Antiques Show (formerly the Connecticut Antiques Show), returns during the coming weekend to the State Armory, at Capitol and Broad Streets in Hartford.

title: For Reliable Fare, There's Chelsea
description: CHELSEA TRATTORIA**

title: Ordinary People
description: September 11, 1983: 'Cathedral' by Raymond Carver

title: The Young and Their Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Nothing Tough About It
description: IF YOU CAN ROAST A CHICKEN, YOU CAN COOK. Because if you can roast a chicken, you can serve a dinner for company just as easily as a satisfying family supper or a simple repast. After all, chicken can be plain, as any backyard chef who's ever waved a brush full of barbecue sauce will tell you, or it can be fancy, with truffles, compound butters and rich, delicate sauces.

title: Mississippi Mud
description: October 9, 1932: 'Light in August' by William Faulkner

title: First, You'll Need A Jumbo Stocking
description: WITH five fewer official shopping days on the Christmas calendar this year, why waste time as you look for a gift for your favorite terrier, to say nothing of the pals at the office?

title: 9 Years on Market, Marcos Estate Is Sold
description: WHEN Imelda Marcos went to her estate in Center Moriches in the early 1980's, workers ran out and bought and planted thousands of dollars of flowers.

title: A U.S.-to-Mexico Underground Freeway
description: Jose Navarro reaches into a bin at the offices of Alliance Against AIDS, the Tijuana clinic he helps run, and pulls out a brown bottle containing AZT, the anti-H.I.V. medication. It once belonged to an H.I.V.-positive person in San Diego who no longer uses it, either because of side effects or death. With help from local physicians like Jose Brecino Robles (pictured above), Navarro will distribute the pills without charge to needy H.I.V.-infected people in Mexico, where their cost per bottle comes to a month's wages for many patients.

title: Seymour Cray, Computer Industry Pioneer and Father of the Supercomputer, Dies at 71
description: Seymour R. Cray, a computer industry pioneer and the father of the supercomputer, died yesterday at a hospital near his home in Colorado Springs. He was 71 and had been in the hospital since an automobile wreck two weeks ago.

title: That Nixon-J.F.K. Poll
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-op Board Asks: Who's In Control?
description: EARLIER this year, the board of the Adee Towers co-op in the Bronx rejected five applicants. Ordinarily, such an action would be subject to little scrutiny -- it is a well-known fact of co-op life that boards can reject applicants for just about any reason other than race, age, sexual preference, marital status, religious belief or physical disability.

title: Brenda Platek, Donald J. Tobias
description: Brenda Norma Platek and Donald Jerome Tobias were married on Thursday at the home of Barbara Platek, a sister of the bride, in Ithaca, N.Y. Paul L. Grennell, a town justice in Caroline, N.Y., officiated. The bride's father, Dr. Richard A. Platek of Ithaca, an associate professor of mathematics at Cornell University and a minister of the Universal Life Church, led a public celebration yesterday at Wagner Vineyards in Lodi, N.Y.

title: All at Sea
description: December 1, 1900: 'Lord Jim' by Joseph Conrad

title: Broncos' Davis Runs to Head of Class
description: Broncos running back Terrell Davis is proof that the National Football League draft is really an inexact science. Davis was drafted by Denver in the sixth round last year. He rushed for more than 1,000 yards as a rookie, has four straight 100-yard rushing games so far this season, tying a team record held by Bobby Humphrey, and leads the league in rushing with 573 yards.

title: Privatization at Issue in County
description: IN the wake of widely reported problems last summer with privatized health care services at Westchester County Jail, the County Executive's office is trying to win over critics of its newest privatization project involving Westchester's computer system.

title: Sticking With Small Companies
description: THE beating taken by small-company funds in the last quarter may have tested the resolve of long-term investors to stick to their guns. But four of the five investment advisers managing hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times still see opportunities in that sector and have raised their small-stock allocations for the fourth quarter.

title: Car Leases Clarified: At Least a Stab at It
description: IF the prospect of leasing rather than buying a new car has you cowering in confusion, you are not alone.

title: Kristin Morsman, Frank Boynton 5th
description: Kristin Kjaer Morsman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kimball Harrison Morsman of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to Frank David Boynton 5th, a son of Mrs. Jeffrey E. Fisher of Leland, Mich., and the late Mr. Boynton 4th. The Rev. Eugene C. Bay performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church.

title: Airport Shopping
description: To the Editor: Eric A. Taub offered a nice overview of duty-free shoppingin the Practical Traveler column (''Is Duty-Free Bargain-Poor?'' Aug. 25) in noting that a good buy is hard to find.

title: Trust and Friendship, Opera and Fable
description: IN case you don't get what Aldo is up to, he'll tell you not to feel bad. ''I'm deep'' is his matter-of-fact explanation for misbehavior that mixes high intensity with low buffoonery.

title: When Teaching the Arts Becomes Social Work
description: THE CONCEPTUAL ARTIST Tim Rollins would like to think of himself as a kindly Geppetto, guiding a group of troubled, underprivileged Bronx teen-agers into adulthood through the ministry of art. The recent documentary ''Kids of Survival: The Art and Life of Tim Rollins and K.O.S.'' even shows a work called ''Pinocchio'' made of tree logs inset with eyes and constructed by Mr. Rollins and his charges. The film tries to portray Mr. Rollins as a social worker-Geppetto in paints.

title: A Recipe That Uses More Than an Apple a Day
description: It happens every fall: On a weekend day when the sky is blue and the air is crisp, people who normally can't find the energy to go to the grocery store wake up with an irresistible urge to go apple picking.

title: . . . Another Goes His Own Way
description: Jakob Dylan wants to make one thing clear: he's just like everybody else. He became interested in music, ''like most people,'' at the age of 12 or 13. He listened to his older brothers' records, something he says ''every youngest brother does.'' He began taking guitar lessons, ''like everybody else,'' at 13.

title: Swapping Land With the U.S.
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation wants to expand its mining operations in Morenci, Ariz., but the copper company won't be paying cash for the 3,758 acres of surrounding Government land it needs.

title: From the Looks Of It, It's the Year of the Cat
description: FEW of the many cars that I test-drive each year, except for some oddities like the AM General Hummer and the Oscar Mayer Weinermobile, actually stop traffic. But the 1997 Jaguar XK8 created such a stir wherever we went that I feared it might literally result in bloodshed.

title: House Call
description: March 8, 1925: 'Arrowsmith' by Sinclair Lewis WHEN an author with the overwhelming popularity and intelligent following of Sinclair Lewis breaks a three years' silence, we approach the result with lively expectancy tinctured ever so little with apprehension. No one has ever made of the novel so potent an instrument for social satire or administered, through its medium, so many rough jolts to national complacency. In respect of sheer ground won his position is unprecedented. His first serious work (it is impossible to regard the early novels as anything save 'prentice-pieces -- ''brouillons,'' in French phrase) showed the surprising direction his attack had taken and was to take. The next proved that it had simple resources of conviction at its back and was likely to be pressed far. Incidentally it furnished the language with a new word and hard pressed intellectuals with a weapon of great range and efficacy. To say ''Babbitt'' -- ''Babbittry'' today is to utter a phrase that has all the force of an incantation.

title: In Puget Sound, a County's Prohibition on Jet Skis Is Overruled
description: Nine months after San Juan County imposed the nation's first ban on jet skis and other water bikes from its tranquil waters in the upper Puget Sound, a judge has overturned the ban on the ground that it violated state laws allowing the use of the personal watercraft on common waterways.

title: Ross Perot Barred, Again
description: When he was first excluded from this year's Presidential debates last month, Ross Perot and his aides expressed great optimism that the nation's courts would swiftly redress what they called a flat-out injustice. But their hopes were dashed last week when a United States District judge rejected their claims less than two hours after hearing their arguments.

title: Devils Make Last Season Look Like a Bad Dream
description: The Devils did not waste any time trying to put last season's failure behind them.

title: BENEFITS
description: Human-Rights Dinner

title: A Small-Cap Fund Sails Through the Turbulence
description: While large-capitalization stocks lost 7 percent between their June high and their July low, small-cap issues lost about 15 percent. But one small-cap mutual fund emerged relatively unscathed.

title: Medical Care: How Shipshape?
description: WITH a vigorous nudge from the American Medical Association, the world's biggest cruise lines agreed last month on standards for medical personnel and facilities aboard ship. While many vessels already meet these levels, cruise line officials agree that there will be a lag before all ships do. But lines that regularly sail to the United States are expected to conform within two years.

title: A Missed Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Along Came a Spider
description: October 19, 1952: 'Charlotte's Web' by E. B. White

title: Schools Coping With Crime Among Students
description: A TRADITIONAL pre-graduation prank day at Fox Lane High School in Bedford crossed the line into vandalism and caused thousands of dollars' worth of property damage.

title: The Candidate
description: September 22, 1991: 'Mating' by Norman Rush

title: Clinton-Dole, at The Bushnell
description: APPEARING at The Bushnell in Hartford tonight: The Great Debate, starring Bill Clinton and Bob Dole, face to face in a building already legendary for playing host to all sorts of celebrities.

title: Skirting Fees In a Takeover
description: SHAREHOLDERS of the five Mutual Series funds have been sent proxies to vote on the proposed takeover of the Heine Securities Corporation, adviser to the funds, by Franklin Mutual Advisers. The shareholder meeting is scheduled for Oct. 25.

title: SCORES COUNT
description: Recently, I taught my final English class in a Virginia prison. All but two of my students were black men, and most were products of Washington public schools. I had wanted to be innovative and progressive in my approach, but I found that I had to begin with grammar (nouns, verbs, clauses, commas, all the old-fashioned stuff), even in supposedly college-level courses.

title: Barrymore Stand-Ins With an Air of 'You Can't Take It With You'
description: MEMBERS of a great theatrical family are musing about the way it was. ''Those were the days,'' the flamboyant star, Anthony Cavendish, says to his mother, Fanny Cavendish, a legend in her own time. She echoes the reminiscence.

title: Cyber-Retailers Hitting the Web For Wider Markets
description: THE doors of the Cyberian Outpost computer supply outlet in Kent have been locked for months now. The storefront scene is one all too familiar in Connecticut: Yellowing display posters, dusty windows, a floor strewn with boxes.

title: The Right Way to Use And Hone a Felling Ax
description: WINTER will soon be here. Many homeowners need to lay in a supply of firewood for their fireplaces or wood stoves. Ideally, firewood should be cut a year in advance so that it has time to dry and cure before burning. You should already have enough firewood for this year, but you'll want to gather more for next year.

title: Cristina Stoddard, Robert V. Walsh
description: Cristina Lee Stoddard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Stoddard of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Vincent Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Walsh of Little Silver, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers, the senior pastor, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich. The Rev. Charles F. X. Dolan, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Our 100-Year Affair With Books
description: To read through one hundred years of The New York Times Book Review, as some of us have been doing for the past several months, is to be reminded, forcefully, that nothing lasts. The 98 bound volumes containing the Book Review so far are in part a chastening catalogue of once-famous books and authors now utterly forgotten.

title: Don't Forget Northville School
description: Imagine my delight when I ran across an article (''June Lessons Make for a Smooth First Day,'' Sept. 8) that dealt with my town of New Milford. The article did a nice job covering a program at John Pettibone School that has helped students and staff make that all-important first day back less chaotic and nerve-racking.

title: Getting Into the Right Sandbox
description: ATTENTION, private-school shoppers: If the process of sorting through nursery schools and kindergartens for your child is simply too much, consultants with a very narrow focus are waiting to take even this chore off your hands.

title: Many See Election as Warm-Up for Kemp
description: The candidate bounded forth, mis-introduced as ''Bob Kemp'' but well enough known by the skeptical black audience to be greeted with a smattering of decidedly wary applause.

title: Help for Depression Put in the Foreground
description: AS National Mental Illness Awareness Week opens, attention is being focused on new ways of treating depression, and returning its victims to functioning lives.

title: BATHROOM LIBERATIONISTS
description: By next summer, there should be no need for a men's-room massacre -- at least not at the New York State Theater.

title: Negative Ads Don't Work Here
description: DEMOCRACY is still relatively new here in the land of grassy plains and animal herders, so it's full of surprises.

title: Fielder's Single Puts Final Touch On 3d Comeback
description: Mariano Duncan was sandwiched among three dozen soggy teammates in a pulsating Yankee clubhouse when he took a bottle of Champagne, hoisted it above his head, sprayed more of the bubbly and then toasted an unrelenting, unsatisfied team.

title: Magnificent Obsession
description: August 17, 1958: 'Lolita' by Vladimir Nabokov

title: Jordan's 9th-Inning Homer Fuels Cardinals' Sweep
description: The football player was all over the place.

title: Making It New
description: January 23, 1927: 'Personae: The Collected Poems of Ezra Pound'

title: Stricken
description: August 1, 1948: 'The Plague' by Albert Camus

title: Miss Staffa-Healey and Mr. Howe
description: Almendra Louisa Staffa-Healey, a daughter of Harriet Staffa of Bubion, Spain, and John Healey of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Howe, a son of Pilar Leon and John Howe, both of Madrid. Roger W. Walker, an East Hampton, L.I., town justice, officiated there at the home of Elinor Brisbane Philbin, the bride's maternal grandmother.

title: Pioneers Wanted; East River Views
description: 2BR, HI FLR, AC, OVRSZ WNDWS, SPECTAC RV VU, INDOR PRKNG, HLTH CLB, TENNIS, ADJ TO PARK, 5 MIN TO GRND CENTRL. $25,000.

title: Mustaf and Sonics Part
description: For the second time in eight days, JERROD MUSTAF is out of a job. The Seattle SuperSonics announced Friday that the National Basketball Association had ruled the Sonics could not claim Mustaf on waivers because the club is over the salary cap.

title: Clinton Admits F.B.I. Criticism
description: President Clinton today conceded that a memorandum from the Director of the F.B.I. that has been sought by Republicans was critical of Government anti-drug efforts, but he said it focused on longstanding organizational questions, not the Clinton Administration.

title: In Village, Shock and Grief Over Killing of a Counselor
description: Neighbors, colleagues and friends of Charles C. Campbell remember a friendly man who was good with children and rarely lost his temper. So they reacted with shock at the news that Mr. Campbell, a 39-year-old garbage man and part-time youth counselor, was dead, shot three times on Thursday after a dispute over a parking space.

title: Relationships Between Women and Men
description: Paul Ickovic: Between Men and Women

title: Damnation by Faith
description: May 25, 1941: 'Darkness at Noon' by Arthur Koestler

title: You Can Go Home Again, but You May Be Behind, 0-2
description: Maybe she just got tired watching her husband lose coin flip after coin flip the past two Septembers, but Ellen Melvin, who is married to the Texas Rangers' general manager, has an idea for a new way of determining the home team for a playoff for the playoffs.

title: Baby May Make 3, but in Japan That's Not Enough
description: It is not that the young women strolling the meandering alleys of this sun-dappled farming village in southern Japan are lazy or dishonest or impolite. No, the problem, at least as old folks and local officials see it, is just that they have almost stopped having babies.

title: Plans Fade for New Role for Former College Campus
description: PLANS to establish an Irish cultural center on the grounds of the former King's College campus here seem to have permanently derailed.

title: A Star Is Dusted
description: To the Editor:

title: Scaasi, Scaasi, Everywhere
description: THE beacon sweeping the sky outside the New-York Historical Society at Central Park West and 77th Street for Monday's opening of ''Scaasi: The Joy of Dressing Up'' may have been a little much. But compared to what was sweeping into the building, it was nothing. After all, the dress code for the event (to benefit the society and the Breast Cancer Research Foundation) was Scaasi.

title: Crossed Knife and Fork Sent Wrong Signal in Sicily
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hint of an Adieu From the U.S. Envoy Has Paris Guessing
description: Pamela Harriman, the United States Ambassador to France, set tongues wagging across Paris this summer by hinting that she might resign and return to Washington next year.

title: Jazz on Canvas
description: A PAINTING need not be about only the things you can see. It can just as easily concern things that you hear, experiences of sound as well as sight. At least, that's the assumption under which Serena Bocchino has been working. In doing so, she has placed herself in the tradition of such esteemed predecessors as Whistler, who often titled his paintings ''nocturnes'' or ''symphonies,'' and Mondrian, whose last works were inspired by the boogie-woogie music he heard in his New York City exile in the 1940's.

title: Consciousness Raising
description: September 6, 1970: 'Sexual Politics' by Kate Millett

title: Consumed by Fire
description: May 16, 1943: 'Four Quartets' by T. S. Eliot

title: No Ordinary Criminal
description: May 19, 1963: 'Eichmann in Jerusalem: A Report on the Banality of Evil' by Hannah Arendt

title: For Some, Ballet Is a Source of Joy
description: After reading Talia Carner's ''Lessons from Life in a Tutu'' (Aug. 25), I want to say to her -- ''You're wearing your tutu in the wrong class.''

title: June Yin and Michael Yang Li
description: Dr. June Yin and Dr. Michael Yang Li, residents at New York University Medical Center in New York, are to be married today at the Hotel Lexington in New York. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Christina Capriotti And Adam Kibel
description: Christina Capriotti, a daughter of Phyllis and Alfred J. Capriotti of Newtown, Pa., is to be married this evening to Adam Phillip Kibel, a son of Lili and Henry Kibel of New York. Justice E. Leo Milonas of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is to officiate at the St. Regis in New York.

title: BUT COUNTESS, WE'VE ONLY JUST MET
description: ON Aug. 17, three and a half weeks before the Cunard Countess was sold to an Indonesian company called Awani Cruise Lines, I boarded the cruise ship in San Juan, bound for the Lesser Antilles. From my taxi on the waterfront under a gray, menacing sky, the Countess looked inviting. She was slim-lined and brightly white, with a raked red and black smokestack: a brand-new-looking toy. And next day we were to set out on a Caribbean Capitals cruise, packing six island visits into seven days, including what the brochure described as ''a relaxing day at sea.''

title: Park-Goers Avoid Beloved Hippo After Rats Move In
description: Even for a seasoned city dweller, it was too much. A few weeks ago, Elizabeth Martin took her 14-month-old daughter to one of the girl's favorite neighborhood playgrounds, the Hippo Park in Riverside Park at 91st Street, so named for the hippopotamus sculptures surrounded by sandboxes, slides and swings. During the hottest days of summer, some of the sculptures spurt water from wide-open mouths to the delight of youngsters.

title: Spare and Sumptuous
description: The ornaments that grace the homes we live in express the idiosyncrasies of our lives. They are more than colorful trophies of family history and adventures; they provide texture to our visual storytelling. That texture was missing from the dogmatically pared-down style of reverential minimalism, the monastic chic that prevailed at the beginning of the decade. Now, a discreet new ornamentalism is on the rise, a subtle shift that combines the spare with the sumptuous. It is intuitive collage, a modern blending of whatever works. The references are often eccentric, sometimes formal, always individual. This new direction can be found in a cavernous northern California warehouse bejeweled with a colorful mysticism, and in a TriBeCa loft where a playful connoisseurship reigns. It is in the exoticism of a lodge in the Catskills, and the exuberance of a sleek, steel California kitchen. The best of the new ornamentalism is both restrained and telling. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: No Hothouse For This Flower
description: The sacred lotus, which Buddhists and Hindus have revered for centuries, has the remarkable ability to regulate its temperature, just as humans and other warmblooded animals do, according to a study in the current issue of the journal Nature. Researchers discovered that lotus flowers can hold a temperature of 86 to 95 degrees Fahrenheit even when the air temperature drops to 50 degrees. Like a shivering animal, a blossom burns off carbohydrates to keep warm, cranking away at one watt. Forty blooms can generate the heat of a living-room light bulb; 70 give off the warmth of a human being at rest reading a newspaper. Scientists suspect the flowers heat up to lure their cold-blooded insect pollinators. CAROL KAESUK YOON

title: At Garage Sale, Less Is More
description: GARAGE sales bring out the worst in people. The sellers are gripped by the fantasy that the junk they have been hoarding in their basements for 20 years is worth real money. The buyers imagine that they are going to get a bargain. Both sides are wrong.

title: A Nifty Curve Ball, No Windows Broken
description: IT was the summer of 1953 and 13-year-old David Mullany Jr. had gotten so good at hitting baseballs through his neighbors' windows in Fairfield that his father decided there had to be a better -- and more neighborly -- way. His only son should play baseball, of course, but not to the detriment of fragile objects.

title: How Communities Become Divided By Race and Class
description: The unseen forces that divide residential communities by race and class will be examined by the historian Kenneth T. Jackson in three lectures this month at Columbia University. ''We just assume that poor people will live in one place and rich people in another,'' Dr. Jackson said. ''What is it about the American system and its history that created this common assumption, and what has put other countries on different courses?''

title: Christopher Plummer Reigns As Barrymore
description: WITH THE CONFIDENCE of the superb actor he has become, and in the trim of an athlete, Christopher Plummer is here in a new play, giving an achingly funny, memorably strong and debonair performance that with any luck will astonish Broadway later this season.

title: Checking Out Ford's New 'Ka'
description: At the Paris Car Show, which opened last week, Ford's new Ka mini-car drew some interest. No, it's not ''Ka'' as in ''cah'' -- ''Ka'' means ''vitality'' in old Egyptian.

title: Dina Piergrossi, John Cannistraci
description: Dina Piergrossi, an assistant New York State attorney general, was married yesterday to John C. Cannistraci, an assistant counsel with the New York City Department of Environmental Protection in Corona, Queens. The Rev. James Villa performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: In Some Work Situations, Push Really Comes to Shove
description: Every once in a while, stress in the workplace bubbles over. Office fights may not be pretty, but some of them are bizarre, and all of them seem memorable.

title: Colleen Hopkins, C.M. Grazioso
description: Mary Colleen Hopkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hopkins of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Michael Grazioso, a son of Maureen Grazioso of Hazlet, N.J., and Anthony Grazioso of Jersey City. The Rev. John T. Farrell performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in New York.

title: If I Were Borough President. A Fantasy.
description: LAST weekend at the New York Film Festival, my seats even farther back and toward the sides than last year, my applications for the opening and closing films rejected yet again, I bleakly thought: If no one helps me, I will end up seeing the French last wave from a curb on Broadway. How sad it is being shuffled off for newer, richer, better-connected customers.

title: Boy, 15, Dies After Being Hit In a Game With Friends
description: Fifteen-year-old Troy Scerbo of Central Islip, L.I., joined a group of teen-agers known as the Third Degree several months ago because he thought they might protect him from the bigger, rougher neighborhood kids who had recently beaten him up.

title: Lisa Napolitano, Thomas Obermaier
description: Lisa Ann Napolitano, a daughter of the late Nancy A. and Dr. Michael J. Napolitano, was married yesterday to Thomas More Obermaier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto G. Obermaier of New York. The Rev. Florence W. Pert performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: Elaine Moustafellos, Gregory Gallousis
description: Dr. Elaine Moustafellos and Dr. Gregory Moschetti Gallousis, both physicians, were married yesterday at St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church in Jamaica, Queens. The Rev. Nicholas Soteropoulos performed the ceremony.

title: Why Isn't She Singing?
description: JUDY KAYE comes to ''The Royal Family'' at the McCarter Theater fresh from her summer performance in another joyous non-musical comedy co-written by George S. Kaufman: ''You Can't Take It With You'' at the Connecticut Repertory Theater in Storrs.

title: Yankee Fan in Photograph Objects to 'Foul' Label
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Go Hunting, Loaded for Beer
description: What Gene Sullivan was hearing around the neighborhood was beginning to bother him: teen-agers from the public and private schools on the Upper East Side could walk into neighborhood delicatessens and buy beer, and not even be asked for proof of age.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Politics and Shoe Leather: A Party With No Campaign

title: Inside the 1997 Budget: Give and Take
description: Before adjourning last week for its campaign recess, Congress passed a giant spending bill to keep the Government running with the start of the 1997 fiscal year, which began on Tuesday. President Clinton had demanded that Republicans revise their budget plans and shift $6.5 billion to a variety of programs and projects he favored. In the end, he got much of what he was seeking. Here is a breakdown of those expenses and the steps taken to pay for them.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Riesling

title: The Long Joy Ride
description: September 8, 1957: 'On the Road' by Jack Kerouac

title: 'Forget the Gods and Read the Rest'
description: October 7, 1990: 'Omeros' by Derek Walcott

title: Labor and Academia In a Campus Meeting
description: The buzz was undeniably there, although no one expected it to be.

title: Log Cabin Days
description: February 14, 1926: 'Abraham Lincoln: The Prairie Years' by Carl Sandburg

title: The Perfect Hostess
description: May 10, 1925: 'Mrs. Dalloway' by Virginia Woolf

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Sponsoring a Child
description: To the Editor: As a longtime non-traveling reader of the Travel section, I want to commend you for the important and worthwhile articles by Gretchen Dykstra and Nicholas D. Kristof (''Meeting the Girl in the Picture''). I cannot recall any similar articles in the section describing families abroad directly assisted by Americans of conscience. I hope there will be others from time to time.

title: Rangers Salvage Tie In Debut Of Gretzky
description: Wayne Gretzky didn't score a goal or get an assist tonight in his debut as a New York Ranger. He didn't even put a shot on goal. But he did display his legendary creativity with a steady stream of nifty passes and positional moves that sometimes befuddled his teammates and even his coach.

title: The $146,530 Question: What Will the Neighbors Think?
description: THE best thing about the 1997 Aston Martin DB7 is the paint job. Wait, that's not a put-down: the DB7 Volante (translation from Jeeves talk: convertible) has many other virtues. Still, the paint -- coat after luscious coat applied by subcontractors at Rolls-Royce -- looks like Chinese lacquerware or a special effect created in Hollywood by Industrial Light and Magic.

title: Public Records, at a Price
description: The Division of Motor Vehicles wants to be able to sell motorists' records unless a motorist specifically says no. What do you think of this idea?

title: Grand Opening
description: This sculptured staircase looks as if it popped from the pages of the Brothers Grimm. Leading to a tower on each side, it might well be the path to some isolated maiden. But the only young woman living here is steeped in the contemporary world: she's Kara Varian Baker, a jewelry designer whose hand-carved creations are sold at stores like Bergdorf Goodman and Barneys New York. Baker's work is inspired by architectural forms, from angular portals to arches -- the very elements that she and her business partner, Lee Smith, decided to bring to their northern California home.

title: Life in the Secret Annex
description: June 15, 1952: 'The Diary of a Young Girl' by Anne Frank

title: Jill Moskowitz and Seth Gardner
description: Jill Robin Moskowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Moskowitz of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Seth Evan Gardner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Gardner of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: For Some, Ballet Is a Source of Joy
description: What a dreary picture Talia Garner paints of ballet classes for adults $(''Lessons From Life in a Tutu,'' Aug. 25$). She has taken class three times a week for five years with the same 10 women and doesn't know them. She dashes ''into the dressing room moments before the start of class.'' Her ''fellow dancers rarely speak.'' Not even her family ''will ever see $(her$) perform.'' Before the end of class, she throws a temper tantrum because of the resin on the floor and storms out before the reverence (not, as she says, a bowing to an imagined audience but rather an expression of gratitude to the teacher).

title: The War on Women
description: October 27, 1991: 'Backlash' by Susan Faludi

title: Where the Money Goes: A Family Seeks Financial Order
description: AT a large cherry table in the tastefully spare conference room of Welsh & Welsh, financial planners, Bob and Tracy Tierney of Richmond pore over pay stubs, old bills, canceled checks and scraps of paper. They are trying to divine where their money has gone.

title: From Sheryl Crow, Hopes and Fears for a New Tomorrow
description: THE MILLENNIUM approaches, even in Hollywood, and Sheryl Crow's new songs are a sampler of end-of-the-century hopes and fears. On her second album, ''Sheryl Crow,'' she's thinking about visitations from angels and wondering if she can find some kind of faith. At the same time, she feels as if she's living in a fallen world, corrupt and dangerous, that's a long way from the golden age of 1960's idealism. And as a Los Angeles pop professional, she takes a jaundiced look at stardom.

title: Caught! P.S. 41 Finds New Jerseyans Secretly Enrolled
description: It usually works the other way around, but two children from the suburbs have been caught sneaking into the New York City public school system. The two, a fifth- and sixth-grader who live in New Jersey, were allowed to stay in P.S. 41 in Greenwich Village after they agreed to pay $1,835.59 in tuition to the Board of Education.

title: An 1852 Dublin Hotel Reopens, Redone
description: The Clarence Hotel, dating from 1852 and situated on the Liffey River in the Temple Bar section of Dublin, has reopened after an 18-month, $8 million renovation. Its new owners includes the Dublin businessman Harry Crosbie and Bono and the Edge, two members of the rock group U2. Previously a 70-room hotel, it now has 50 large rooms, with oak furniture, leather chairs, hand-rolled colored glass in wrought-iron bedside lamps and nickel-plated desk lamps and candle sconces, satellite television, VCR and computer and fax machine connections.

title: Alomar Connects In Oriole Clincher Over the Indians
description: They taped sheets of clear plastic up in the Orioles' clubhouse. No one wanted the players' leather jackets and suede shoes to be stained by Champagne.

title: From Beer to Prozac, Perks Abound
description: SURE, there is a health plan for employees at Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., but it probably doesn't make anyone feel better on the way out the door at night. That is what the ice cream is for: three pints, fresh from the freezer, free, for everyone, every day.

title: At Schuetzen Park, a Bit of Germany and a Tradition of Charity
description: Around the turn of the century in Union Hill, a town later absorbed into Union City, the minutes of town meetings were written in German, a reflection of the number of German immigrants in Hudson County.

title: A Study in Scarlett
description: July 5, 1936: 'Gone With the Wind' By Margaret Mitchell

title: Sherman's March to Disaster
description: November 1, 1987: 'The Bonfire of the Vanities' by Tom Wolfe

title: Kathryn Frohling And Phillip Railey
description: Kathryn Doyle Frohling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien O. Frohling of North Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday to Phillip James Railey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Railey of Fairfax, Calif. The Rev. Edward J. Ciuba performed the ceremony at Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church in North Caldwell.

title: On a Mission In Miami
description: Pat Riley and Alonzo Mourning posed for the cameras at a recent photo session, side by side, showing their million-dollar smiles.

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, Sharpen Your Pencils
description: LIKE a roomful of over-age S.A.T.-takers, the Pleasantville Recreation Center prickled with tension before the first Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament on a recent Friday night.

title: A Diner That Lives Up to a Lot for a Little
description: MANY modern-day diners are deceiving unwary patrons. They used to be places that offered large portions, low prices and rib-sticking food, where a $20 bill bought enough for three or four people to eat bountifully.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: A Flood From the Soul
description: June 30, 1912: 'The Brothers Karamazov' by Fyodor Dostoyevsky

title: BATHROOM LIBERATIONISTS
description: Anyone who says that it is hard to make friends in Los Angeles has never stood in line for the ladies' room at intermission. There is a bonding that occurs as we move from the ritualistic ''If women designed these buildings . . . '' to analysis of the first half of the performance and, ultimately, to sharing intimate experiences. I for one would not sacrifice this companionship to storm the men's room.

title: Crossed Knife and Fork Sent Wrong Signal in Sicily
description: To the Editor:

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: As a married woman, I realized from Green's article what dating would be like (a very competitive, lifelong sexual hell) if heterosexuals didn't have the option of getting married.

title: One Race, Many Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: A Discreet Ornamentalism
description: At the end of the last century, when she was still more Newport than novelist, Edith Wharton railed against the tasteless flourishes that festooned the high-Victorian rooms she frequented: polar bear rugs on veneered parquet floors, Oriental carpets on tufted sofas, palm trees in giant jardinieres. The manifesto she wrote with Ogden Codman Jr., ''The Decoration of Houses'' (1897), generally considered the first guide to home design, called for classic proportions and interiors sensitive to their architectural surroundings. ''We have passed from the golden age of architecture,'' she wrote in disgust, ''to the gilded age of decoration.''

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Home Design/Magazine Part 2

title: In Search of Lost Shareholders
description: IT was as if Brant Cover had won the lottery. Practically overnight, he became $44,000 richer, thanks to a friend who, while reading a local newspaper, happened to spot the name of Mr. Cover's deceased mother and notified him. The name was in fine print on a list of lost shareholders whose funds had been turned over to the state of New Jersey.

title: Back in Prints
description: Like a dutiful, old-fashioned wife, wallpaper has followed behind paint for most of this century. The reasons boil down to minimalist tastes and technological advances in the paint industry, namely the introduction of latex. The decorator Elsie de Wolfe's biting words, in her 1913 book, ''The House in Good Taste,'' are classic: ''To me, the most beautiful wall is the plain and dignified painted wall. ... If I could always find perfect walls, I'd always paint them and never use a yard of paper.''

title: Learning to Love Furniture From China
description: THE SALE TWO WEEKS AGO OF Ming and Ching chairs and tables at Christie's in New York that totaled $11.2 million did more than set records. It signaled the coming of age in the marketplace for Chinese furniture, which had long been overlooked by collectors.

title: Dam's Inexorable Future Spells Doom for Yangtze Valley's Rich Past
description: Two years after the start of construction on the world's largest dam in the scenic Three Gorges area of central China, the extensive rescue effort envisioned to save some of the country's best-known cultural antiquities has yet to begin. It has become mired in a rancorous dispute pitting hundreds of historians, archeologists and other scholars against Government engineers who are racing against time and a shortage of financing to complete the mammoth project.

title: Catskill Collage
description: Bo van den Assum's house nestled in the Catskills is the kind of place where you might expect to find a country-cutesy look -- cozy quilts and cast-iron doorstops shaped like Scotties. Instead, there's a gritty, exotic atmosphere that seems anomalous in this crisply whitewashed lodge. It looks as if a traders' caravan of night visitors has crashed for the weekend.

title: War Effort
description: A company of night club entertainers, including Benny Goodman and his band, put on a tremendous show to raise money for War Bonds in THE GANG'S ALL HERE (1943). The lengthy and lavish production numbers are all by Busby Berkeley, who also directed. This is pleasant milling around that brings together familiar musical performers of the period with some spiffy songs . But it's Alice Faye's picture, with her schmaltzy version of ''A Journey to a Star.'' And Carmen Miranda's (above), who wiggles at random but keeps her skyscraper firmly balanced doing a bizarre ''Lady in the Tutti Fruitti Hall'' that will knock your socks off -- SATURDAY at 10 A.M. on Cinemax. Howard Thompson

title: Fifth Ave. Watchdogs Eye Mickey
description: On Fifth Avenue, you can have 28 American flags snapping smartly over the front of Saks Fifth Avenue. Or you can have four elegant white awnings shading Cartier. Or you can have Atlas holding up a giant clock over the entrance to Tiffany's. But you can't have man-size brass moldings of Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse and Pluto the dog jutting out a good six feet over the front door of the Disney Store.

title: Looking History in the Eye
description: January 29, 1989: 'The Satanic Verses' by Salman Rushdie

title: Viewers Miss Stirring Finish
description: Viewers of the Northwestern-Michigan game on WABC-TV/Ch. 7 yesterday missed the Wildcats' winning field goal when the station cut away at 3:30 P.M. for ABC's network broadcast of the Penn State-Ohio State game.

title: Guilty Pleasures
description: February 23, 1969: 'Portnoy's Complaint' by Philip Roth

title: Rome
description: TRAVELERS returning to Rome after several years' absence are bound to notice the scrubbing being administered to the city's churches, monuments and palaces. Gone is much of the greenish-black grime that once covered so many buildings. The travertine apse of Santa Maria Maggiore and the facades of the Gesu, the Chiesa Nuova and a host of churches along the Via del Corso, such as the Baroque gem of San Marcello, reveal architectural details that had been hidden for decades under a thick veil of oily soot.

title: What Beauty Lurks in This Ancient Icon's Face?
description: SHE WAS THE EGYPTIAN queen who wasn't Cleopatra but who defined female beauty for all time with a single image of her fabulous 3,000-year-old face.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Safari in a Strange Land

title: Brooklyn Center Represents New Era for Black Churches
description: To the Editor:

title: A Poem, 40 Years Long
description: FOR FOUR DECADES, THE BEATNIK SAGE GARY SNYDER worked on his epic 40-poem cycle, ''Mountains and Rivers Without End.'' Now it is finally finished, and in bookstores. Begun well before any of his 16 other volumes of poetry and essays, Snyder's new book is full of references to the Native American and Chinese myths and ecological concerns that characterize his work. It also touches on his years spent as a Yosemite mountaineer and trail worker, as well as his decade studying Buddhism in Japan.

title: Taking a Hard Line Amid the Wreckage
description: FOR more than two months, as the families of those who died aboard Trans World Airlines Flight 800 have waited to learn the disaster's cause, many have asked another question: How will they be compensated for their grief?

title: In Scarsdale, Food Takes Southwest Cast
description: STONE lions flank the staircase leading to this tidy restaurant with lovely greenery-filled front windows. The proportions and hard surfaces of the room make it quite noisy at busy moments, but off-peak diners will have the pleasure of quiet, enough to hear the delicate splashing from the wall fountain beneath a cascade of philodendron spilling from the ceiling.

title: Antiquities Near the Beaten Path
description: WHEN it comes to surging crowds and pitiless sun, midtown Manhattan in August has nothing on Ephesus or Pergamon during summer tourist season. Corralled, jostled, baked and ultimately soaked at the gateside concessions, the modern visitor can hardly share the impressions of such early modern travelers as William Lithgow, who came to Ephesus in the early 17th century and wrote of finding a lonely ruin ''pleasantly adorned with gardens, fair fields and green woods of olive trees, which on the sea do yield a delectable prospect.''

title: A Hymn of Hate
description: October 15, 1933: 'My Battle' by Adolf Hitler

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 15 about shopping for antiques misidentified a Newtown antiques store. It is the Mill, not Grist for the Mill.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holiday of Simhath Torah, which ends the annual cycle of the public reading of the Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: After reading your article, it hit me again how we first react to bad news by ''killing the messenger.'' Accepting the truth can hurt, but it hurts much more to reject it. So once again it comes down to personal choice. We are responsible for what we choose to do and for the consequences.

title: Show Traces Career of Master Builder With a Pound Ridge Focus
description: THE designer and builder Vuko Tashkovich is known in northern Westchester for his dramatic modern houses, 27 of which are set amid the forest hideaways here. Working with his wife, Stefanie, he has forged his own path for more than 30 years, eschewing the usual architectural career for something he considers more independent.

title: A 225-Year-Old Church Celebrates With 18th-Century Music
description: ON Sept. 4, 1771, Francis Asbury set sail from Bristol, England, to take the teachings of the Methodist Church to America. Nearly two months later he landed in Philadelphia and shortly thereafter rode on horseback throughout New York City and Westchester, bringing the church to the people. On his death in 1816 he had covered 275,000 miles of the United States and had helped found many congregations -- including the Asbury United Methodist Church on Scarsdale Road here.

title: Lawsuit Dismissed
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit filed by the 1950 National League rookie of the year, SAM JETHROE, who sought pension benefits from major league baseball. Jethroe's lawyer, JOHN PUTTOCK, said the case was dismissed on Friday by United States District Judge SEAN McLAUGHLIN.

title: INSIDE
description: Harbor Cleanup Is Set

title: The Hunt For Senor Octubre
description: IN their bullpen beyond left-center field, the Yankee relief pitchers warmed up behind and below the word ''Target'' in big white letters. And they indeed were the target. If the Rangers had been able to batter them, the Yankees would not be in the American League Championship Series now.

title: Future Shock
description: February 7, 1932: 'Brave New World' by Aldous Huxley

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: I was troubled by Green's use of Mark Ebenhoch as a figure in this cautionary tale. Although Ebenhoch's seroconversion lends poignance and drama to Green's article, it also reinforces the idea that uninfected gay men are ''statistics to be.''

title: Corrections
