description: The puzzle solutions on page 93 of The Times Magazine today omit a hint for the diagramless puzzle on page 94. It should say, ''No. 1 Across begins in the fifth square of the top row.''

title: The Whole Sick Crew
description: April 21, 1963: 'V.' by Thomas Pynchon

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 about the movie ''Grace of My Heart,'' which dramatizes the world of American pop music in the 1950's and 60's, misstated the year in which the song ''Hey There,'' sung by Rosemary Clooney, was a hit. It was 1954, not 1956. The article also misstated the relationship of Gerry Goffin, who was a co-writer of two new songs for the film and was a model for one of its characters, to Louise Goffin, a co-writer of one of the songs. He is her father, not her husband.

title: Canonizers Behind Closed Doors
description: For nearly 80 years the Modern Library - the Random House imprint that grew to prominence under Bennett Cerf - has served as something like God's own varsity team of great books. This summer, the library's editorial board (directed by Harry Evans, Random House's president and publisher) gathered at the Century Association to debate 20 new picks for 1997. The titles will start appearing in January, and were chosen from a list suggested by a crew that included the novelist A.S. Byatt, Daniel Menaker (the Random House editor who handled ''Primary Colors''), the writer Christopher Cerf and the historian Edmund Morris. Aside from being a bookworm's dream afternoon, the event offered a rare glimpse at the factors - taste, clout, timeliness, profits and, of course, a pure love of literature - that help shape a contemporary canon.

title: Strolling Along The River Thames
description: An idea dating back to the 1930's of putting to use an old towing path was finally realized this summer. A trail now exists all along the River Thames, from its source in the Cotswolds to the North Sea. The last segments to be completed were 16 miles of new riverside paths and three footbridges.

title: Hot-Stock Epilogue: The Boss Gets Less
description: It was one of the hottest initial public offerings in years, and it showed that Wall Street thought the company was worth a lot more than the insiders did. Now it looks like the insiders were right.

title: A Shanley Double Bill in Purchase
description: CALL it a miniature John Patrick Shanley festival on two stages separated by some 20 miles and some artistic distances.

title: Skip Away Will Nip at Favorites, and Fingers
description: His trainer, Sonny Hine, calls Skip Away an ornery horse who would pass up a carrot to take a bite out of one of his human handlers. On Friday, he nearly trampled some chickens who made the mistake of crossing the road in front of him -- no joke, said Hine. Yesterday morning at Belmont, Skip Away bucked all the way back to the barn after his workout, and yesterday afternoon in the Jockey Gold Cup, the 3-year-old speedster took a serious bite out of the legacy of the wonder horse, Cigar.

title: In Decaying Rubber Mountains, Old Tires Haunt the State
description: At ground level, visitors to this rural township in the Pine Barrens can see cranberry bogs, blueberry fields and the Carranza Memorial, a tribute to a Mexican pilot who crashed here in the 1920's. But from the air, Tabernacle offers a more conspicuous landmark: New Jersey's biggest tire dump.

title: 27 Up, 27 Down On One Perfect Day In October
description: The gangly, big-eared party guy with the brush cut and the nickname of Gooney Bird won 3 games and lost 21 for Baltimore in 1954. Jimmy Dykes, his manager there, could not rope him in. ''The only thing Larsen fears is sleep,'' he said.

title: Uproar Over an A. & P. Splits East Hampton
description: A PROPOSAL to relocate and expand the A. & P. in East Hampton is setting off a debate about the resort community and prompting allegations of manipulation, class differences and muzzling of public opinion.

title: Charlotte Kenny And C.P. Morello
description: Charlotte Louise Kenny, a daughter of Dr. Janice M. and Ben R. Kenny of Yardley, Pa., was married yesterday to Christopher Paul Morello, the son of Irene and Robert J. Morello of Pleasantville, N.Y. The Rev. James Zwernemann, a Lutheran pastor, performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Budget Delivered and Signed, Congress Goes Home
description: In the budget that was approved last week, President Clinton got less money than he hoped for but walked away with a better budget deal than he could have imagined when Republicans took control of Congress two years ago.

title: Home Is Where The Heart Isn't
description: THE idea was to supply a jolt of 212 energy to the laid-back land of 213, to bring the bumper-car mentality of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive to Rolls-Royce Rodeo Drive, to show some fondness for sack-suited Sutton Place in the natural-shoulder neighborhood of Melrose Place.

title: Let Our Children Go
description: THREE WEEKS AGO as the city was debating John Cardinal O'Connor's proposal to move failing public-school students into Catholic schools, the Episcopal Bishop of New York criticized the Cardinal for starting a competition that could ultimately destroy the public schools. ''I am opposed to any such competition,'' Bishop Richard F. Grein wrote in a letter published in The Times. ''A good public-school system is essential to this city and to this country.''

title: A Cry, Without Tears, for His Beloved Country
description: UNDER NORMAL circumstances, almost any writer would enjoy the attention that the Nigerian Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka has been getting lately. After a hugely successful run in England, his newest play, ''The Beatification of Area Boy,'' starts a five-day run Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Meanwhile, his latest book, ''The Open Sore of a Continent: A Personal Narrative of the Nigerian Crisis,'' has been widely reviewed and praised.

title: Rego's Big Day Lifts St. Joseph-Montvale
description: New Jersey

title: Paid or Volunteer Crews? An Uneasy Fit at the Firehouse
description: ALTHOUGH it has become something of a corporate mecca -- estimated daytime population is about 200,000, about double residential population -- Stamford still retains some of its small town flavor. Perhaps nowhere is that more manifest than at ''The Big Five'' -- the five volunteer fire companies that trace back to a time when Stamford had separate city and town governments.

title: Plaid, Chatty As Ever
description: Race-track plaids of the ''Guys and Dolls'' era, checks and tattersalls have emerged as an early fall look for pants. The trousers are jean-cut with slim legs, and the colors are autumnal: brown, beige and burgundy with accents of red and green. The wearers add casual solid-color sportswear tops like turtleneck twin sets or leather jackets. (The plaid does all the talking, and the top quiets it down.) But one young man, right, added a contrasting plaid shirt.

title: he City of Fiendish Evangelists
description: May 18, 1952: 'Wise Blood' by Flannery O'Connor

title: The Supreme Test of His Mettle
description: June 20, 1948: 'The Gathering Storm' by Winston S. Churchill

title: Jewel Box
description: For most new york couples, decorating an apartment of only 500 square feet would be an issue of what to leave out, not what to add in. But Todd and Amy Hase were not afraid to break rules or use grand gestures in this minuscule Manhattan walk-up. They chose a rich, smoky palette (inspired by the fur of their cat, Meowski), completely blocked one of the apartment's two windows and placed seating in the center of the living room. Their boldest gesture, however, was introducing a piece of Oriental splendor that makes strolling through the space feel like crossing a threshold into another century: a 200-year-old Chinese wedding bed whose gold-leafed surface gleams gemlike from its dark surroundings.

title: Policy Clashes Doom California School Chief
description: State Education Secretary Maureen DiMarco, a charter member of Gov. Pete Wilson's Cabinet, resigned last week, after months of feuding with the Governor's aides over policy.

title: The High Court Drama Begins
description: With a docket packed with important cases touching on some of the most difficult and controversial issues of the day, the Supreme Cort opens a new term tomorrow amid a heightened sense of drama, and even apprehension. The justices themselves greatly added to the suspense surrounding the term last week by adding two cases on physician-assisted suicide to the calendar.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE
description: A State Supreme Court judge has rejected the rent increase Metropolitan Life imposed last year for the 147,000 defective windows the company installed three years ago at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling middle-income projects it owns on First Avenue between 14th to 23d Streets. Justice Herman Cahn last week ordered the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal to re-examine Met Life's application for a rent hike based on the $30 million it spent on new double-paned windows, which began to implode shortly after their installation in the two complexes, which together have 110 buildings. ''This victory bolsters the notion that people shouldn't have to pay for broken and defective merchandise,'' said Jack Lester, an attorney representing the tenants. Metropolitan Life says it plans to appeal the decision. In the meantime, residents will not have to pay the estimated 6 percent rent increase.

title: The 'Littery Supplement' Comes of Age: A History, of Sorts, of the Book Review
description: When Adolph S. Ochs acquired control of The New York Times in 1896, one of the first things he did was establish a separate book section. He was intent on improving the paper's coverage, and the world of books was one area where it seemed to him that there was more going on than the previous owners of the paper had allowed for. He was right. The closing years of the 19th century were a period of spectacular growth for publishing, matched by a steady expansion of the reading public. Books were multiplying, and books were news.

title: Giants Drop Thompson
description: The San Francisco Giants bought out the contract of second baseman ROBBY THOMPSON on Friday, making him a free agent. Thompson, 34, has a .257 career batting average in 12 years with the Giants, but he has not played 100 games in a season since 1993 because of injuries. The popular player's best season was 1993, when he hit .312 with 19 home runs and 65 runs batted in.

title: The Adventures of Macon Dead
description: September 11, 1977: 'Song of Solomon' by Toni Morrison

title: Jabs Are Sharp but Familiar In New Jersey Senate Debate
description: In a heated exchange that united the ideas, attacks and issues that have dominated the campaign, New Jersey's candidates for the United States Senate faced off in their first debate yesterday.

title: Meet Arizona's Happiest Taxpayers
description: WHAT'S surprising is not so much that this conservative law-and-order state seems to have legalized the sale of marijuana, but that it took even the most ardent of the state's pot smokers nearly a decade to figure it out.

title: Lasorda Improving
description: TOMMY LASORDA was reported in excellent condition yesterday after undergoing a second angioplasty on Friday. Dr. MICHAEL MELLMAN, the Dodgers' team physician, said it is not unusual for an artery to close again after angioplasty.

title: The Unsung Glories of Degas's Twilight Years
description: RENOIR ONCE SAID THAT IF Degas had died at 50 he would have been remembered as an excellent painter, no more, but that after 50 his work had broadened and ''he really becomes Degas.'' Well, Degas turned 50 in 1884, by which time he had painted most of the pictures we remember him for. Degas after 1884 and until his death in 1917 has always been something of a mystery. So what was Renoir talking about?

title: Finding the Route to Riches in the Automotive Air-Bag Industry
description: ONE day soon, many cars will have more air bags than doors. But to cash in on the growing use of these safety devices, investors must pick their spots carefully.

title: Illness as Metaphor
description: May 8, 1927: 'The Magic Mountain' by Thomas Mann

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: We will always need multiple approaches to public health campaigns if we want to reach the majority of the people. ''Just say no'' campaigns work for some, while they are too simplistic for others. The challenge for public health is to develop appropriate campaigns that target specific audiences.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: ''Flirting With Suicide'' was insightful about the demons that in one form or another lurk under all our beds. Jesse Green's prose and Mark Ebenhoch's bravery merit not only admiration but also at least a few moments of serious contemplation about the course and purpose of our own lives.

title: Gonzalez's Big Series Turns Into a Footnote
description: In the end, Superman cried.

title: Correction
description: A heading on Sept. 15 for a table listing the 50 largest commercial leases so far this year described them imprecisely. The transactions shown were limited to Manhattan.

title: Katharine Downes And David Keep
description: Katharine Appleton Downes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Downes of Milton, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. David James Keep, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Pliny Marcena Keep of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Samuel Sewall Rodman 3d, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Go East, Young Dude, in Search of a Pool
description: If this is a sitcom pitch, call it ''Flushing Baywatch'': Six California surfers wash up at Queens College to lead its water polo team (did you know it had one?) to a national ranking. Why did they come here? Is their coach the real Tark the Shark? What about babes? How could this happen?

title: Special K.
description: October 24, 1937: 'The Trial' by Franz Kafka

title: Sponsoring a Child
description: To the Editor: I am glad that Gretchen Dykstra had such a positive experience with Save the Children. Mine has been quite the opposite. But then again, I am not the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District.

title: How Bay Ridge Galvanized Against a Movie Theater
description: As soon as a development firm started to fax news releases in April announcing its plan to transform an empty lot on Narrows Avenue into an eight-screen United Artists movie theater, the Bay Ridge network of community groups clicked.

title: Braves Slug Away at Nomo To Finish Sweep of Dodgers
description: There was a silly notion going around late in September that the Atlanta Braves might be a vulnerable world champion. They did not play well in September -- going 12-15 -- and entered the playoffs without the momentum they usually generate during the last month of the regular season.

title: 2 Governors Plan Cleanup For Harbor
description: In a move that could end a threat to the regional economy and quell a longstanding environmental dispute, the Governors of New York and New Jersey have agreed to clear five million tons of silt from clogged shipping channels in New York Harbor over the next 12 months and to share the burden of disposing of harbor mud that is too contaminated to be dumped in the ocean.

title: Dust Bowl Blues
description: April 16, 1939: 'The Grapes of Wrath' by John Steinbeck

title: White Memorial, Another View
description: In the article concerning the White Memorial Foundation, I am referred to as one who ''opposed the bicycle path.'' That reference is due to my letter to the editor of the local newspaper wherein I questioned the logic of spending over half a million Federal tax dollars on a bicycle path in Litchfield.

title: For Poor, Life 'Trapped in a Cage'
description: On a corner of Clinton near Delancey, up a narrow stairway between a pawnshop and a Dominican restaurant, Ana Nunez and her three children live in a single, illegal room that suffocates their dreams of a future.

title: The Poison Around Us
description: September 23, 1962: 'Silent Spring' by Rachel Carson

title: 'Let's Do It'
description: October 7, 1979: 'The Executioner's Song' by Norman Mailer

title: DOLE CAMP LOOKS TO COMING DEBATES AS A LAST CHANCE
description: Frustrated that their candidate is still bogged in second place, Bob Dole's advisers consider the nationally televised debates that begin Sunday night as his last best chance to reverse his electoral fortunes in a campaign that President Clinton has dominated from the start.

title: Miss D'Agostino And Mr. Ross
description: Elizabeth Anne D'Agostino, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen I. D'Agostino of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married last evening to George Cannon Ross Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Michael F. Ford performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: George Washington, First Farmer
description: ''George Washington: Pioneer Farmer,'' a new permanent exhibition devoted to the first President's farming practices, opened last month at Mount Vernon. The four-acre working farm is designed to educate visitors about 18th-century farming and to show a side of Washington left out of most history books.

title: TV Spectrum Auction
description: To the Editor:

title: Not With a Bang but a Gurgle
description: THE notice was posted on the weathered wooden wall of my elevator like a proclamation from Martin Luther. ''On June 1, new toilets will be installed in the building. Please sign up for a convenient time.''

title: Alixandra Horne, Richard Coolidge
description: Alixandra Battle Horne, the daughter of Meade Bridgers Horne of Tarboro, N.C., and Wright Horne of Moorestown, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Lawrence Coolidge, the son of Camilla and Nathaniel Silsbee Coolidge of Boxford, Mass. The Rev. William Emory Smyth performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Tarboro.

title: 9,700-Year-Old Bones Back Theory of a Coastal Migration
description: Human bones found in an island cave along southern Alaska appear to be the oldest ever found in the state, and they lend weight to the idea that North America's earliest people might have traveled by boat along the Alaskan coast instead of taking an overland route south.

title: At War With Themselves
description: February 25, 1951: 'From Here to Eternity' by James Jones

title: TV and Radio Abruptly Silenced by a Glitch
description: It was their moment in the national spotlight, but it proved a quiet one.

title: 100 Years of Books
description: The New York Times Book Review celebrates 100 years of publication with a special centennial issue that includes more than 70 significant reviews since 1896, reprinted as they first appeared (only shorter), with a historical introduction by John Gross.

title: A Fine Madness
description: May 28, 1922: 'Ulysses' by James Joyce

title: The Open Door of Norwalk's Police Chief
description: DURING his first year as Norwalk Police Chief, Harry W. Rilling has attempted to make his department more open and accessible, something that traditionally, especially in urban communities, is not exactly a priority for top officers.

title: Suddenly, a Mood of Danger in the Mideast
description: THE grim expressions at the Middle East summit meeting in Washington last week were born not just of despair at the violence in the West Bank and Gaza that has intercepted the trajectory toward peace between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Germaine Matters
description: April 25, 1971: 'The Female Eunuch' by Germaine Greer

title: A History Project Goes Beyond the Classroom
description: If this year's campaigns have made you tired of politics, maybe Mark Wise, a 30-year-old history teacher at J. P. Stevens High School in Edison, is the candidate for you. Mr. Wise, running as an independent for Bill Bradley's United States Senate seat, acknowledges that he is not a politician, has no intention of becoming a Senator and doesn't even ask people to vote for him.

title: A and A
description: Italian Antique Car Race

title: Realtors See Gold in Site Of Palladium
description: The Palladium, once New York's hottest dance club, has long since fallen off the A-list party circuit. Even before its owner, Peter Gatien, ran into trouble with the law this year, the cavernous disco was losing its luster as supermodels, celebrities and club kids flocked elsewhere. Now the Palladium's strobe lights may soon be switched off for good.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 8 about Bill Cosby's new television series misidentified the university from which he received an Ed.D. degree. It was the University of Massachusetts, not Temple.

title: Remains of the Day
description: December 30, 1945: 'Brideshead Revisited' by Evelyn Waugh

title: One First Lady Salutes Another at Statue's Unveiling
description: Thousands of New Yorkers turned out yesterday to applaud a statue of Eleanor Roosevelt at the southern tip of Riverside Park, at 72d Street. They swayed to ''Happy Days Are Here Again,'' cheered a stream of politicians and gasped when the eight-foot-tall statue was unveiled.

title: Elderly and Poor Suffer Under H.M.O. Plans
description: Researchers reported last week that elderly people and poor people who are chronically ill fare worse in health maintenance organizations than they do in conventional insurance plans. But the findings seem unlikely to slow the remarkable growth of H.M.O. enrollment.

title: Self-Doubt At Last for The Swiss
description: THE sustaining myths of Switzerland suddenly seem as vulnerable as that apple on the young Tell's head.

title: Local Law 10 And Scaffolding
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Upon a Time, When High Schools Were Palaces
description: NINETY years ago, an enormous Beaux Arts building went up on a hill overlooking the Hudson River. It had Corinthian columns, terrazzo floors and a vestibule lined with English marble. It could have passed for a palace, or at least a palatial estate.

title: Gang Scourge Beaten Back In Hartford
description: THE city is all dressed up to dazzle guests arriving for the first Presidential debate tonight. The Civic Center is surrounded by potted mums. The storefronts smell like fresh paint. The sidewalks are scrubbed so clean they look like a movie set.

title: Southwest Airlines Heads for the Northeast
description: At the rate it's going, Southwest Airlines may have to change its name. Having built a reputation for offering low fares and frequent flights around the Southwest, the airline has slowly been expanding eastward.

title: White Memorial, Another View
description: I read the article (''3,800 Acres, All Private, Meant for the Public's Pleasure,'' Sept. 15) on all the magnificent beauty of the White Memorial Foundation property in Litchfield as well as the foundation's successful fight to keep a proposed nearby bike path from harming its beauty and peace.

title: BATHROOM LIBERATIONISTS
description: Go for it, girls (The Big City: ''Bathroom Liberationists,'' by John Tierney, Sept. 8)! My male New Yorker attitude is ''Hey, whaddevah.'' I have no problem with using a ladies' room myself if the men's room is booked solid.

title: The Music That Casts The Spells Of 'Vertigo'
description: NEARLY FOUR DECADES after its commercially indifferent first run, ''Vertigo'' has become the most widely celebrated of Alfred Hitchcock's films. It is prized not simply for its razor-sharp suspense technique but also for its air of mystery, its tragic dimension, its literary layering of memory and obsession.

title: From a Herricks Perspective, a Film Maker Zooms In in 3-D
description: Jeffrey Marvin did not attend Herricks High School in the late 1960's because he thought it would lead to a career in film making. But the producer of ''Cosmic Voyage,'' the latest IMAX movie,now at the Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, was surrounded by major film makers of the future at the New Hyde Park School.

title: Why the Wheels Stopped Turning
description: SIDE from celebrity, what do Jerry Seinfeld, Muhammad Ali and Manuel Noriega share?

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Green's article was profoundly moving and for me, an accurate picture of the state of mind, the fears and the anxieties of the community of gay men, of which I am a member. Sitting in a coffee shop, reading the words of Walt Odets, I wept with recognition.

title: Lesa Barkowsky, Gregory Starkins
description: Lesa Ann Barkowsky, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward R. Barkowsky of Snyder, Tex., was married last evening to Gregory Clifford Starkins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford E. Starkins of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. John McMullen performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Ray James, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: HARD COVER

title: Losing Our Shirts
description: A FEW weeks ago, I went to the cleaner's to leave a bundle of blouses and shirts. Plopping my garments on the counter, I noticed a large sign in the storefront window: ''Shirts cleaned for $1.10.'' A modest bargain, especially by late-1990's standards. I felt the glow of satisfaction that comes from frugality.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Idaho

title: Brooke M. Wentz, Alfredo E. Alias
description: Brooke Marie Wentz, the daughter of Keith Edward Wentz and Dr. Lydia Maria Seebach of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Alfredo Edward Alias, the son of Sarah Agnes Boatner of the Bronx. The Rev. Jeffery Zurheide performed the ceremony at the Wilton Baptist Church in Wilton, Conn.

title: Finding Mozart's Deeper, Darker Moods
description: IT WAS NO DOUBT the closest that that blithe creative spirit Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart ever came to the titanic compositional struggle that represented just another day at the office for Beethoven. Yet as an excellent new recorded survey demonstrates once more, the series of six string quartets that occupied Mozart for two and a half years, beginning in 1782, also proved perhaps the most profoundly revealing music that ever flowed from his prolific pen.

title: Deborah Aiges and Julie Lokin
description: Deborah Schure Aiges and Julius Jay Lokin are to be married today in their apartment in Manhattan. Rabbi Joel S. Goor is to perform the ceremony.

title: 2d-Grade Kissing: Milk, Cookies and Lust!
description: To the Editor:

title: Bribe to 'Big Man' Brings Big Trouble
description: From the department of how to make a bad day worse: During a recent undercover operation, when officers of the 19th Precinct issued summonses to deli clerks for selling beer to a minor, they also checked the delis' liquor licenses. For the M & M Delicatessen, at First Avenue and 92d Street, that's when the trouble began.

title: ON A LAZY RIVER IN LAOS
description: THE Mekong River flows lazily through southern Laos, bordered by thatch-roofed villages, swaying palm trees and from dawn to dusk, fishermen rowing in the lee of one or another of its 4,000 islands. There are no roads, no bridges, no smokestacks. Now and again, a ferry just big enough for three or four cars slowly crosses from one bank to the other; the rest of the time, the only sights and sounds are those of the river and the birds. At night, the flickering flames of oil lamps light the windows of the few houses on the banks.

title: An Appeal to Save China's Past
description: Two years after the start of construction on the world's largest dam in China's scenic Three Gorges area, the extensive rescue effort that had been envisioned to save some of the country's best-known cultural antiquities has yet to begin. Instead, it is mired in a rancorous dispute pitting hundreds of historians and other scholars against Government engineers who are pushing to complete the mammoth project.

title: A FREIGHTER THAT IS MORE LIKE A YACHT
description: TRAVELERS shouldn't choose a freighter trip expecting to see the world; what they mainly see is the ocean. The itinerary for my 52-day voyage late last year aboard the Americana of Ivaran Lines from New Orleans to Buenos Aires was intriguing: seven ports in Brazil and one in Venezuela, three in the Caribbean and two in Mexico.

title: Seung-Hee Hyun And Paul Kang
description: Seung-Hee Hyun, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sang Yul Hyun of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Sung-Uh Kang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Doo Young Kang of Colorado Springs. The Rev. William H. Pindar performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Georgie Porgies and Other Outlaws
description: No sooner had the television news trucks rumbled out of the small town of Lexington, N.C., where school officials had suspended a 6-year-old for kissing a girl on the cheek, than another boy, this time in the world's media capital, got the hook last week for an unwanted kiss.

title: Connected in England
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from England I can tell you that American cell phone use is nothing compared to the use in Britain. It really seems as though every fifth person is using one. Even in the tiny village of Woembly, Herefordshire, a woman was chatting away as she led her horse through the village. As we fought our way through the crowds on Oxford Street, people were glued to their phones.

title: Of Hacks and TK
description: READER-FRIENDly novelists whose characters wander through arcane worlds are now adding a new element to their work: glossaries, defining words not in most readers' vocabularies or available in standard dictionaries.

title: Yankees Rally to Beat Rangers; Face Orioles for the League Title
description: Bernie Williams hit two homers as the Yankees came from behind to beat the Texas Rangers, 6-4, yesterday and win the American League Division Series by three games to one.

title: When Life Became Journalism
description: March 13, 1932: '1919' by John Dos Passos

title: True or False? Iceland Is in NATO
description: Foreign policy has been the one issue missing in action from the Clinton-Dole Presidential contest. Bob Dole's criticism of the Clinton foreign policy has been limited to drive-by shootings (Clinton has a ''photo-op foreign policy''), ridiculous cheap shots (Clinton has been too hard on the Israelis) or just feckless whining. As a result, Mr. Clinton has not really been pressed to address some of the most pressing foreign policy issues of the day. This is not healthy. The Clinton Administration has already committed the country to several major foreign policy endeavors scheduled to unfold just after the election, which the U.S. public and Congress have barely discussed. If Mr. Clinton wins a landslide victory based solely on his domestic policies, he will be free to interpret this as a landslide for his foreign policy initiatives as well, in which case the U.S. public could be in for a few surprises.

title: Viva Big Apple
description: A smidgen of Las Vegas is coming to New York (in the form of a Vegas themne restaurant in Times Square), but the real mutual-imitation action is in Vegas, where the New York - New York hotel-casino, slated to open in December, stands out even on the architecturally overblown Strip. And yes, that's Miss Liberty out front - minus her head. Cost for this ersatz skyline: $460 million.

title: Tattooing: More Female Clients Enter a Formerly Male Realm
description: BIG JOE KAPLAN learned the tattooing trade 35 years ago at Sailor Barney's in Coney Island, putting his mark on what he describes as the bad and the ugly. He still tattoos the good, the bad and the ugly, but today more than half his clients are women.

title: Leveling the Playing Field For Smart Girls
description: Since 1956, when the National Merit Scholarship Corporation was set up to select academically talented students, it has given more than $652 million in awards. But FairTest, a nonprofit group in Cambridge, Mass., filed a complaint with the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights, charging that the selection method was unfair to girls, because it begins with the College Board's Preliminary Scholastic Assessment Test. Boys outscore girls on that test, although girls earn better grades in high school and college. Last week the College Board said it would modify the P.S.A.T. next year, adding multiple choice questions on writing -- an area where girls do slightly better than boys. If that fails, the Education Department said it would look at other approaches. KAREN W. ARENSON

title: Old Bakery, New Twist
description: SOME places you find with your eyes. Ducktown, Atlantic City's visually disappointing Little Italy, you find with your nose.

title: Too Loose? Or the Way to Go?
description: IN the last few years, New York City has become a hub of school reform, with the addition of more than 60 new public schools, the largest expansion of the system in half a century.

title: Trendy Ambiance and Manhattan Views
description: AT certain hours, Bedford Avenue seems calm for a thoroughfare. But at other times, as when it is so crowded there are lines for Sunday brunch, you could maybe -- maybe -- mistake it for a Manhattan streetscape.

title: The Courage of His Conventions
description: February 12, 1946: 'The Berlin Stories' ('The Last of Mr. Norris' and 'Goodbye to Berlin') by Christopher Isherwood

title: Gooden Stays Off Roster
description: Dwight Gooden's fleeting chances of contributing during the post-season probably fizzled forever today when Yankee Manager Joe Torre said the weary pitcher would not be on the roster for the American League Championship Series. Gooden acknowledged that throwing another pitch this season is a long shot.

title: A 'Normal Kid' With Magical Powers
description: SMALL, pert and possessed of a high adorability quotient, Melissa Joan Hart looks younger than her 20 years.

title: The Adams Family
description: October 27, 1918: 'The Education of Henry Adams'

title: Sheila Kearney, A.H. Davidson
description: Sheila Jane Kearney and Anthony Hilton Davidson, both corporate lawyers, were married yesterday in Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. William Carr, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Egan Chapel of St. Ignatius Loyola on the campus of Fairfield University. Rabbi Evan C. Radler took part in the service.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: AS four superior films illustrate this week, it never hurts to have a fine screenplay.

title: Hermine Baron, 83, a Top Bridge Player
description: Hermine Baron, one of America's top-ranked female bridge players, died in Los Angeles on Sept. 27. She was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: The Rehnquist Reins
description: WHEN THE SUPREME COURT RECONVENES tomorrow morning, William H. Rehnquist will mark his 10th anniversary as the 16th Chief Justice of the United States. The Rehnquist Court's first decade may best be remembered for such surprisingly ''liberal'' decisions as the 1992 reaffirmation of Roe v. Wade and this year's vindication of gay rights in a case from Colorado. In both exceptional cases, Rehnquist was in dissent on the losing sides, but those outcomes are unrepresentative of his winning record in crucial, if less publicized, areas of the law.

title: Fichaud's Acrobatics Keep Isles in Opener
description: On opening night in Inglewood, Calif., his play was bravura, his reviews were all raves. His coach called his performance ''gritty.''

title: A Boy's Best Friend
description: September 21, 1913: 'Sons and Lovers' by D. H. Lawrence

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Green's article may well have the effect of exacerbating homophobia, since the permissive attitudes lying behind it are exactly what many of us have been taught to reject.

title: A World of One's Own
description: February 22, 1953: 'The Second Sex' by Simone de Beauvoir

title: How Keaton Commanded His Life's Last Stage
description: THE ONLY TIME Buster Keaton and Charlie Chaplin worked together, with Keaton in a small part in Chaplin's 1952 film, ''Limelight,'' they had a revealing off-screen conversation.

title: Karen Carpenter's Second Life
description: THE TAPE HAD BEEN BURIED for three years, behind the colonnades of stuffed animals, Disney memorabilia and ''I Love Lucy'' videos that lined Karen Carpenter's luxe Century City condo. These were the appurtenances of a time when she was pop music's own cuddly toy: as one-half of the Carpenters, she was queen of the lovelorn, an Edith Piaf in Tricia Nixon's clothes, and for a few years in the early 70's practically the most popular singer in the world.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 6, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 2 THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (Viking, $23.95.) The disappearance of a 3-year-old boy brings a family anguish and redemption. 2 1 6 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) Vice President Jack Ryan has problems after the deaths of the President and most of the Cabinet, Congress, the Joint Chiefs and the Supreme Court. 3 2 3 JACK AND JILL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Alex Cross on the trail of serial killers at large in Washington. 4 6 136 THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life. (+) 5 5 8 SERVANT OF THE BONES, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $26.) A dark angel seeking redemption makes a perilous journey from ancient Babylon to modern Manhattan. 6 3 19 THE RUNAWAY JURY, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $26.95.) A woman in a Mississippi Gulf Coast town sues a tobacco company for causing her husband's death. 7 7 18 FALLING UP, by Shel Silverstein. (HarperCollins, $16.95.) Poems and drawings, for children and grown-ups, celebrating strange characters and experiences. 8 4 9 THE LAST DON, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $25.95.) The aging head of a Mafia family makes plans for his heirs' activities in Hollywood and Las Vegas. 9 8 22 THE TENTH INSIGHT, by James Redfield. (Warner, $19.95.) A journey through the Appalachian Mountains provides answers to life's enigmas. (+) 10 11 2 LEGEND, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $23.) A bride-to-be in modern-day Virginia suddenly finds herself in 19th-century Colorado. 11 10 2 MY MANY COLORED DAYS, by Dr. Seuss. Illustrated by Steve Johnson and Lou Fancher. (Knopf, $16.) Ways of looking at feelings and moods. 12 9 12 CAUSE OF DEATH, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $25.95.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta investigates the mysterious death of a reporter and a murder that involves her own niece. 13 16 2 DIRT, by Stuart Woods. (HarperCollins, $24.) A gossip columnist's travails with a member of the social scene who is apparently determined to get even with her. 14* 13 21 HOW STELLA GOT HER GROOVE BACK, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $23.95.) A divorced black woman finds romance on a Jamaican holiday. 15 12 4 THE BURNING MAN, by Phillip Margolin. (Doubleday, $23.95.) A young man tries to recover his father's respect while serving as a public defender in Oregon. Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Nonfiction 1 1 23 THE DILBERT PRINCIPLE, by Scott Adams. (Harper Business, $20.) A satirical look, in words and cartoons, at the current foibles of business and management. (+) 2 2 2 THE RUN OF HIS LIFE, by Jeffrey Toobin. (Random House, $25.) An account of the O. J. Simpson trial by a journalist and former prosecutor. 3 3 12 UNLIMITED ACCESS, by Gary Aldrich. (Regnery, $24.95.) Events in the Clinton White House as reported by an F.B.I. agent formerly on duty there. (+) 4 5 31 UNDAUNTED COURAGE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The story of how Thomas Jefferson sponsored Lewis and Clark's exploration. (+) 5 7 127 MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga. (+) 6 4 2 HOW GOOD DO WE HAVE TO BE? by Harold S. Kushner. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) How a new understanding of guilt and forgiveness can change our lives. 7 10 3 ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $24.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood. 8 6 5 ALL TOO HUMAN, by Edward Klein. (Pocket, $23.) The marriage of John and Jacqueline Kennedy. 9 1 SLOUCHING TOWARDS GOMORRAH, by Robert H. Bork. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $25.) An indictment of modern liberalism, by the former judge, for recent declines in American culture and social life. 10 8 DRINKING: A LOVE STORY, by Caroline Knapp. (Dial, $22.95.) A journalist recalls her addiction to alcohol. 11 8 53 EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, by Daniel Goleman. (Bantam, $23.95.) Factors other than I.Q. that contribute to a successful and happy life. (+) 12* 9 16 OUTRAGE, by Vincent Bugliosi. (Norton, $25.) The reasons, according to the former Los Angeles County prosecutor, that O. J. Simpson was found not guilty. (+) 13 1 BOY CLINTON, by R. Emmett Tyrrell Jr. (Regnery, $24.95.) A journalist's critical look at the political career of the President. (+) 14 1 JAMES HERRIOT'S FAVORITE DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) Ten tales recounted by the Yorkshire veterinarian, who died last year. 15* 8 DOMINIQUE MOCEANU: AN AMERICAN CHAMPION, by Dominique Moceanu as told to Steve Woodward. (Bantam, $14.95.) The autobiography of the gymnast. (+) 16* 14 4 BETWEEN HOPE AND HISTORY, by Bill Clinton. (Times Books/Random House, $16.95.) The President states his vision for America in the 21st century. (+) Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 2 MAKE THE CONNECTION, by Bob Greene and Oprah Winfrey. (Hyperion, $18.95.) Ways to improve one's life physically and mentally. 2 3 29 THE ZONE, by Barry Sears with Bill Lawren. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $23.) Diets to prevent disease and enhance mental health. (+) 3* 2 176 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $25.) Improving communication and relationships. (+) 4 4 27 SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+)

title: Dole Concludes Debate Preparation by Asking Bush for Advice
description: Bob Dole wrapped up his debate preparation today by turning for help to the one Republican who really knows what Bill Clinton is like on the Presidential debate stage: George Bush, who debated Mr. Clinton three times in 1992.

title: How Much To Pay for Security?
description: WHEN it comes to auto insurance, one of the more perplexing decisions is whether to buy coverage against theft and vandalism.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SCULPTURE SHOW

title: Sponsoring a Child
description: To the Editor: I recently had an experience similar to that of Gretchen Dykstra, the author of ''In a Poor Land, Boundless Generosity'' (Aug. 11). I was sponsoring two children from a family in the Katmandu Valley in a private school near Bouda, six kilometers from downtown Katmandu. Instead of just visiting them and doing the usual tourist route (I had been to Katmandu the previous year) I decided to spend six weeks volunteering as a teacher at their school.

title: For Sabre Group, Some Long-Term Reservations
description: THE AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, will soon offer stock in Sabre Group, its successful airline-reservation business. But while the offering may be a good short-term buy, the prospects are less clear for the long-haul investor.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: LISBON OFF SEASON -- T.A.P., the Portuguese airline, as part of its Discovery Vacations program, is offering a Lisbon package, including round-trip air fare from New York, that starts at $499 a person for three nights, $609 for six nights. Prices, based on two people sharing a room, are good from Nov. 1 to Dec. 12 and Jan. 6 to March 27. They include hotel room, transfers from the airport, daily Continental breakfast and hotel service and taxes; airline departure tax of about $37 is extra. Five hotels in Lisbon proper and two in Cascais are among the choices; the most expensive, the Tivoli Lisboa, costs $669 for three nights, $919 for six. Information or reservations: (800) 247-8686.

title: Carole Hedgepeth, Gregory Johnson
description: Honora Carole Hedgepeth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace C. Hedgepeth of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Gregory Tyrone Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Johnson of Rocky Mount, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Calvin O. Butts 3d performed the ceremony at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Manhattan.

title: Broadway Babies
description: Hollywood transformed Edna Ferber and George S. Kaufman's rather fragile theatrical piece into the far more soundly contrived STAGE DOOR (1937). Gregory La Cava directed this marvelous comedy drama of a Manhattan boarding house for aspiring theater actresses that makes every minute and line count. Katharine Hepburn and Ginger Rogers set the pace for a super cast that includes Andrea Leeds, Adolphe Menjou, Constance Collier, Lucille Ball, Ann Miller, Eve Arden and Gail Patrick. Kaufman always called this ''Screen Door.'' Fair enough. But it's intelligent, durable carpentry -- SUNDAY at 9 P.M. and SATURDAY at MIDNIGHT on Channel 21. Howard Thompson

title: A Hometown Tribute To a Composer's Life
description: WHEN George Walker's grandmother died 50 years ago, he composed the plush Barber-like ''Lyric for Strings (Lament),'' his first orchestral work. This year, ''Lilacs,'' for voice and orchestra, his uncompromising, contemporary setting of verses from Walt Whitman's lament for Abraham Lincoln, won the Pulitzer Prize for music. Clearly, mourning becomes Dr. Walker.

title: An Issue for A Reluctant High Court
description: THE few lines of type it took last week for the Supreme Court to announce that it would rule on the issue of physician-assisted suicide transformed the Court's new term.

title: When 'Welfare Reform' Means Less Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: When Boards Say 'No Deal' To Holders
description: IMAGINE that somebody knocks on your door and offers to buy your house for more than you thought it was worth. You want to take the money, but your real estate broker prevents you, insisting that the price will go up. A year passes, and you're still waiting.

title: Alexa Kule, Richard Gashler
description: Alessandra Kathleen Kule, a daughter of Mary Jo and Christopher Kule of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to Richard Andrew Gashler, the son of Barbara and Richard Gashler of Glen Rock, N.J. The Rev. Edward Kane performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: The Pentagon's Quark
description: Why does it take 5,000 troops to help 15,000 troops withdraw? The Pentagon found itself in the midst of a pre-election cow-flap last week when it announced that 5,000 more American troops were headed for Bosnia, just two and half months before the 15,000 American troops already there are supposed to come home.

title: The Kindest Cut
description: Here are some of the many things I swore I'd never do: own a station wagon, dye my hair, be a housewife, leave New York City, identify with my body, have plastic surgery. Now I've done them all. Two months before my 50th birthday I lost a breast to cancer and started breaking solemn vows and making new ones. Mastectomy was the cure; plastic surgery was the magic.

title: Jhan Robbins, 76; Wrote Biographies
description: Jhan Robbins, a freelance writer and the author of a dozen books, including several biographies, died on Sept. 27 at his home in Columbia, S.C. He was 76.

title: As the Way of All Flesh Goes South
description: WOMEN, particularly baby boomers whose acquisitiveness in the last two decades brought boom times to the fashion industry, are revising their values: they're not cutting them to fit this year's fashions.

title: Niche Publishers Grow, and Aim For Specialties
description: CHILDREN and teachers walking, riding or driving to school each morning are increasingly filling their bookbags and briefcases with books by publishers with a familiar address. And some of those educational publishers are looking forward to expansion and a future with even more diverse offerings.

title: Kissing Cases Highlight Schools' Fears of Liability for Sexual Harassment
description: While the recent suspensions of two little boys for kissing girls were widely seen as excessive, they highlight the confusion that is sweeping schools as educators grapple with a growing fear that they may be sued for failing to intervene when one student sexually harasses another.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Latino Center Nearly Done - But Money Is a Problem
description: Over the summer carpenters were screwing in sheetrock and banging nails, working on a $5.3 million project to renovate an imposing red brick school in East Harlem, creating studios and performing space for Latino artists: painters, sculptors, actors, musicians and dancers.

title: Alexandra Boyle And Paul Jeffers
description: Alexandra Catherine Boyle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Boyle of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to Paul Edward Jeffers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Jeffers of Winston-Salem, N.C. Msgr. Vincent W. Jeffers, a great-uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: NORFOLK TERRIER SHOW

title: A Tale From Underground
description: April 13, 1952: 'Invisible Man' by Ralph Ellison

title: Williams Gambles on the Bases, Thrives at the Plate
description: Willie Randolph laughed. Then he laughed even louder.

title: Walking, Digging, Looking to the Past
description: VOICES from the past may seem to come to life as Connecticut celebrates its fourth Archeology Awareness Week beginning next Saturday and running through Oct. 20. Among the activities are exhibitions, lectures, film showings and 71 walking tours designed to educate participants about the state's archeological treasures and to share the state's history. Most events are free and are geared to adults and children in eighth grade and older.

title: Where Do All the Insects Go To While Away the Winter?
description: As I dug up my Yukon Gold potatoes last weekend, I saw a few monarch butterflies on my butterfly bush, and I thought of them flying all the way to Mexico to winter in the mountain forests. Maybe they were from New England, stoking up on my late bloomers, the asters and the zinnias, before soldiering on.

title: The Rough Rider and the Easy One
description: Twenty years ago, during an out-of-town tryout of the musical ''1600 Pennsylvania Avenue,'' I was intrigued by the actor Ken Howard's ability to transform himself from President to President with the aid of a quickly applied prop or two, and adroit changes of voice and gesture. Although he was big and blond, he needed only to clamp on some pince-nez, and snap his teeth at the audience to become a creditable Theodore Roosevelt. The audience burst into applause.

title: Cook the Geese
description: The nip in the evening air heralds another cycle in the suburban critter wars. Summer has faded away, and with it the conflict between the rights of coyotes and the safety of the family poodles. Soon we will say hello to the deer, farewell to the shrubbery. Then comes spring and the annual goose debates.

title: 'It Was War, and We Had to Expect It'
description: November 10, 1946: 'Hiroshima' by John Hersey

title: Jeannette Price, Michael Titowsky
description: Jeannette Burdon Price and Michael B. Titowsky were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. William Starr, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony.

title: That Magic Bus Runs More Often
description: NEWS flash for Frizzle fans: beginning tomorrow, ''The Magic School Bus,'' the animated public television series about the adventures of a wildly eccentric science teacher and her class, will be broadcast on Channel 13 every weekday afternoon at 3:30 as well as Sunday mornings at 10.

title: It's Fall. Do You Know Where Your Mr. Softee Driver Is?
description: These are the dog days for drivers of Mr. Softee ice cream trucks. As the warm afternoons of early autumn wane, so does the familiar chime of the Mr. Softee theme.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 22 with an article about the theater season in London misstated the surname of an actor in the play ''Art.'' He was Ken Stott, not Stutt.

title: Pauline Frommer, Mahlon Stewart
description: Pauline Hadley Maud Frommer, the daughter of Hope Arthur and the travel writer Arthur Frommer, both of Manhattan, was married last evening to Mahlon Kline Stewart, a son of Joly and James Stewart of Broad Axe, Pa. Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated at Wave Hill in Riverdale.

title: Niche Investing: A Flurry of Action in a Specialized World
description: IN February 1987, John C. Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group, told a financial industry gathering that specialty funds -- mutual funds that invest in specific industries or sectors -- would not last through the 1980's because they relied too heavily on speculative bets and were prone to high expenses. They came and went once before, in the 40's, as investors chased returns among funds -- and they will die again, he said.

title: Christine Lamson, Thomas McPhillips
description: Christine Marie Lamson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Lamson of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas William McPhillips, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. McPhillips, also of Scarsdale. The Rev. Joseph S. Dietz performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: That Reminds Me....
description: July 5, 1925: 'The Guermantes Way' by Marcel Proust

title: Leslie Murdock, Joshua Grotstein
description: Leslie Susan Murdock, a management consultant, and Joshua Seth Grotstein, an executive at Prodigy, the on-line service, were married yesterday at the Harvard Club in New York. The Rev. Dr. James Zwernemann, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Dennis Tobin.

title: The Presidential Stretch
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON gazed out recently at a crowd that had gathered to see him in Seattle despite a driving rain, and he marveled at its size.

title: Of Plays About Politics And Politicians at Play
description: SIGNS THAT THIS IS AN election year are popping up on Broadway and off. The humorist Douglas McGrath opens his one-man show, ''Political Animal,'' tomorrow at the McGinn/Cazale Theater. Theresa Rebeck's new play, ''View of the Dome,'' a satire about Washington, recently opened at New York Theater Workshop. On Thursday, Christopher Durang's new comedy, ''Sex and Longing,'' directed by Garland Wright, opens at the Cort Theater on Broadway under the auspices of Lincoln Center Theater; Sigourney Weaver stars in this satirical look at Washington and the right wing. The spring will bring the Lincoln Center Theater production of Wendy Wasserstein's new play, ''An American Daughter,'' about a senator's daughter awaiting confirmation of her appointment as Surgeon-General.

title: First Among 'First Wives'
description: DI, darling, you owe us a big one. We're the people who got up at 5 in the morning to drink Champagne while you marched down the aisle at St. Paul's all those years ago. Since then, we've huzzahed your every hairdo, bought every biography, championed your every cause and, most of all, defended the prince-dumping operation. We even have drawers full of those dumb polka-dot socks that you used to wear.

title: Mary Ann Berger, Hugh H. Shull 3d
description: Mary Ann Berger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Berger of Ulster Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Hugh Henderson Shull 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Shull Jr. of New York. The Rev. Gerald J. Gallagher performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: Classical Brief
description: DVORAK: 'THE SPECTER'S BRIDE'

title: Jennifer Kelly, William Geddes
description: Jennifer Ann Kelly, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon Randolph Kelly of Mendon, Vt., was married yesterday to William Grant Geddes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Geddes Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Amelia C. Pitton performed the ceremony at Grace Congregational United Church of Christ in Rutland, Vt.

title: Starks Is Making Houston's Job Easier
description: Allan Houston had heard about the hothead stories and had occasionally seen the disturbing highlight clips to back them up. He knew what people thought about John Starks.

title: Bosnian Serb Leaders Boycott Swearing In of Unity Government
description: In a rocky start for the new national Government intended to help unify Bosnia, Bosnian Serb leaders refused today to take part in the ceremony to swear in legislators and the three-member Presidency.

title: A Neighborhood That Puts Its Moxie Where Its Mouth Is
description: As Charles Otey puts it, practically all of the current moxie in Bay Ridge stems from the bridge.

title: Godfather of Exotic Modernism
description: ''I CAN DESIGN A CHAIR, A table, a couch, a desk, to fit any curve, crevice or aperture of any room,'' the New York designer James Mont declared to the editors of the Art Digest in 1934. He also boldly, if inaccurately, claimed credit for the den, the can opener, the stainless-steel kitchen and the first modern rocking chair. Delusions of indispensability aside, Mont made an indelible mark on mid-century decorations, his exotic sense of style -- and relentless self-promotion -- fueling an ornamented, Asian-style modernism that is being appreciated anew by dealers and collectors.

title: Reigning Cats and Dogs
description: IT may be difficult to discern any real differences between the Presidential candidates on welfare, crime or drugs. But there is one stark choice. Does the American public want a cat or a dog in the White House?

title: Bearing Witness
description: January 10, 1988: 'The Drowned and the Saved' by Primo Levi

title: This Year's Mr. Smith
description: IT IS THE FRIDAY NIGHT OF LABOR DAY weekend and darkness is slowly coming to the streets of El Paso. Victor M. Morales is looking for a place to eat, but first, far more urgently, Morales, Texas's Democratic nominee for the United States Senate, is looking for just a few more votes. ''Excuse me, sir,'' he says to a passer-by, handing the man a black-and-white flier proclaiming that ''Victor Morales has been recognized for his honesty, fairness and enthusiasm'' during his 18-year career as a public-school teacher. ''Hey, you're that guy in the truck, right?'' says the man, giving Morales a thumbs-up and a promise to go to the polls for him Nov. 5. ''We need somebody like you.''

title: Memoirs of a Crusader
description: October 4, 1931: 'My Fight for Birth Control' by Margaret Sanger

title: Forgiven and Befriended By Victim, Attacker Dies
description: Chris Carrier recently went to visit his ailing elderly friend at a nursing home in North Miami Beach. He took along a pound of the friend's favorite fish treat, smoked amberjack, comforted the man and made sure that he was warm and well taken care of. It was the last time that he saw his friend, who died later that night.

title: Treating the Excesses of Sick Pay
description: WHILE workers walked off their jobs throughout Germany last week over a sudden reduction in their sick pay, many companies in the United States have been trying to control the benefit in a more subtle way.

title: Rising Above Politics
description: BOB DOLE, in his Presidential campaign, has invoked the memory of Harry S. Truman, the patron saint of underdogs. Stock traders, on the other hand, have reason to regret the Truman upset.

title: The Young and Their Options
description: To the Editor:

title: A Farewell to Flappers
description: April 19, 1925: 'The Great Gatsby' by F. Scott Fitzgerald

title: Symphony on Stage
description: THE Stamford Symphony and its music director Roger Nierenberg are readying their first pair of subscription concerts at the Palace Theater. The pianist Misha Dichter will be the visiting performer in Grieg's Piano Concerto; Schumann's ''Genoveva'' Overture and Brahms's Third Symphony complete the program.

title: On the Lawn and Deep in the Woods, a Smorgasbord of Mushrooms
description: More than 2,000 species of fleshy fungus grow in New Jersey.

title: Retail Liquor Store Fights Industry Decline
description: IN 1970, Dale Rosen received one of the 5,070 liquor licenses issued by the New York State Liquor Authority, which permitted him to open a retail liquor store. By 1995, almost half -- 46 percent -- of all liquor stores that had opened in 1970, were gone.

title: The Candidates Reiterate Their Views on Several Major Issues of the Day
description: Following are excerpts from the debate between Representative Robert G. Torricelli and Representative Richard A. Zimmer, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Baseball's Glory Days Are ... Now
description: A FRIEND OF MINE USES THIS POP quiz to illustrate the difference between baseball and other sports:

title: WINDOW DRESSING
description: Christian Dior's lace and tulle dress with pearl, rhinestone and arabesque embroidery by Giantfranco Ferre. Model, Elena Koudoura. All hair and makeup on these pages by Serge Lutens for Shiseido.

title: Be All That You Can Be: Your Future as an Extortionist
description: THROUGH the 1980's, the United States Army trained Latin American police and military officers in techniques that the Pentagon now acknowledges were ''clearly objectionable and possibly illegal'': torture, extortion, censorship, false arrest, execution and the ''neutralizing'' of enemies.

title: First-Rate Returns on Third-World Bond Funds
description: CAN emerging-markets debt stage a three-peat?

title: A Little More Room At the Inn? Yes and No.
description: AFTER 56 consecutive months in which the hotel occupancy rate exceeded that of the same month in the previous year, the United States lodging industry finally experienced a downturn -- dropping to 73.9 percent this July from 74.1 percent in July 1995. Those are the latest figures available from Smith Travel Research, which tracks U.S. lodging industry performance.

title: Denise Stevens And Mark Jones
description: Denise Elaine Stevens, a daughter of Elaine Stevens of West Belmar, N.J., and the late Walter Stevens, was married yesterday to Mark Alan Jones, a son of Jeanette Jones of Mays Landing, N.J., and John Paul Jones of Kinnelon, N.J. The Rev. Leonard Lang, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Church of St. Rose in Belmar, N.J.

title: Morality and Invention
description: February 27, 1983: 'The Complete Poems: 1927-1979' by Elizabeth Bishop

title: Multitude of Events Filling the Calendar
description: WHAT seems to be the busiest day on the fall calendar has arrived, leaving music lovers with an embarrassment of riches. Going chronologically through only some of today's events:

title: American Accused of Spying For South Korea
description: In public, Washington and Seoul tried to shrug off the significance of what both sides said was a minor case of spying by a civilian analyst at the Office of Naval Intelligence who is accused of passing classified documents to a military contact at the South Korean Embassy. But last week, when lawyers for 56-year-old Robert C. Kim, a Korean-born, naturalized American citizen, made a strong bid to win his release on bail, the Government acknowledged that the South Korean effort to steal intelligence from its closest ally and protector had escalated into a more serious case. Prosecutors said in court papers that they would seek to indict Mr. Kim for espionage, a charge reserved for highly damaging security breaches that could send Mr. Kim to prison for life. One top Administration official said the still-murky case posed a larger unanswered question: Did South Korea's spy effort go beyond Mr. Kim? DAVID JOHNSTON

title: The Young and Their Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Laurie E. Cowan, Richard B. Marion
description: Laurie Elizabeth Cowan was married yesterday to Richard Brockington Marion at Glenn Memorial United Methodist Church in Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. John Simmons performed the ceremony.

title: Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Wolfe - and now Benetton
description: EVERY new store tries to make a splash, but it will be hard to match the new United Colors of Benetton flagship store, which will open late this month at 597 Fifth Avenue.

title: Thais Handlin, Vincent Francis
description: Thais Ananda Handlin, the daughter of Dr. Diane Handlin and Dr. James Handlin of Plainfield, N.J., is to be married today to Vincent Francis, the son of Vincent and Margaret Francis of Bridgewater, N.J. The Rev. Michael Carr, the bride's maternal uncle, who is a United Methodist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Westwood, a catering establishment in Garwood, N.J.

title: Opening Nights And the Fete Against AIDS
description: Celebrations for Scaasi designs and opera, and an annual benefit.

title: Is Strategy More Crucial Than the Candidates?
description: To the Editor:

title: Witness Files Complaint as Yarmulke Is Banned by Texas Court
description: A man who is an Orthodox Jew has filed a complaint with the Texas Commission on Judicial Conduct after a judge asked him to remove his yarmulke or be prevented from testifying as an expert witness.

title: Pia Babusis and Ian Hunter
description: FRIENDS say that John W. Hunter 3d was always so nervous around women that his personality would change completely in their presence.

title: Provocative Ballet by Way of Tough Love
description: SOME PEOPLE ARE SURE OF things, yet aren't convincing at all. Jean-Christophe Maillot, the 35-year-old artistic director and resident choreographer of Les Ballets de Monte Carlo, whose weeklong engagement at City Center begins on Tuesday, is so sure of what he is sure about that he tends to be quite convincing indeed.

title: Al Pacino, Slouching (Again) Toward Shakespeare
description: Al Pacino, who is 56 and has been a movie star for a quarter century, has a favorite story about acting. It took place in 1972, the year he'd come to stardom as Michael Corleone in ''The Godfather,'' and he was performing in a Boston production of David Rabe's ''Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel.''

title: Once Doubleday Was a King, Now House Gets a New Look
description: THE clanks and squeaks of heavy machinery pierced the summer air in Garden City as a significant segment of Long Island history joined the ranks of the down-sized.

title: Connected in England
description: To the Editor: Ralph Schoenstein's article, ''Alas! We're All Connected,'' (July 28) reminded me of sitting in a village pub in Buckinghamshire, England, this spring. Waiting for our traditional Sunday lunch my husband asked me to look back at the bar where a group of young people, pints in hand, were catching up on the week's doings. Lined up in front of them on the bar were at least five, if not six, cellular phones. When the publican brought our meals, I asked him what happens if the phones all ring at once? We laughed and reminisced about our youth in the 50's in England when most homes did not have a telephone let alone sons and daughters on the move!

title: Northwestern's Improbable Comeback Shocks Michigan
description: It was a remarkable comeback, and for Northwestern, it was another special victory.

title: Cigar's Furious Homestretch Rally Falls a Bit Short
description: Cigar made a noble but losing farewell to racing in New York yesterday when he was beaten by a head by Skip Away in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: The Body Politic
description: he pianist Glenn Gould once said that what is common to all puritanical societies, like our own, is the belief that art is a dangerous thing and the artist essentially a ''jeopardized being -- very likely to come to a bad end.'' He might just as well have been talking about style.

title: Real Magic
description: March 8, 1970: 'One Hundred Years of Solitude' by Gabriel Garcia Marquez

title: Buckeyes Continue Roll By Pounding Penn State
description: The Ohio State Buckeyes are making a farce out of the top of the national football polls.

title: A Scandal? What's the Sound Bite?
description: GORDON C. KOHN wrote the book on scandals (''Encyclopedia of American Scandal,'' Facts on File, 1989). He knows scandals, up, down and sideways. Scandals ''R'' Him. Need to know what a scandal was about? Ask.

title: Pierce Is Unlikely Winner in Big Apple
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 5

title: A Federal Contribution To Charter Schools
description: New Jersey's first charter schools could be operating next fall, and to help with start-up costs, the Federal Government will provide $947,368.

title: Vincent Balletta Jr., Appellate Judge, 69
description: Vincent R. Balletta Jr., a former Associate Justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, died on Friday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 69.

title: From the National Academy, an Exhibition for Fairfield
description: THE National Academy of Design in Manhattan has been having annual exhibitions since its founding in 1825. But this year has seen a significant addition: a selection of works has traveled out of the Academy's town house on Fifth Avenue to the Walsh Galley of Fairfield University. This marks the first time a portion of the exhibition has gone to a campus gallery. The sampler of selected award winners was conceived and organized by the Walsh Gallery's director, Philip Eliasoph, who has done scholarly work at the National Academy.

title: For a Retired Couple, 5th Avenue Is The Avenue
description: WHEN they bought it, the place looked like bomb-scarred Beirut, said Thomas Bagg, the retired head of a major oil company's tax department, surveying what is still a very rugged apartment.

title: To Build a School
description: NEW JERSEY'S newest elementary school crouches among the fields here, barely visible from the road. It is long and low, with wide hallways and classrooms around a grassy courtyard. But the things that set the Copper Hill School apart from older schools -- a geothermal heating system, for example, and 40 miles of wiring to support a sophisticated computer network -- are invisible to residents of this town, who are footing the $14 million bill.

title: Sparing the Udmurt
description: November 24, 1991: 'Rebuilding Russia' by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Sept. 22 about a tour of Chelsea art galleries incorrectly described the occupations of two of the people who were to act as tour guides. Stacey Winston and Christine Wachter currently have an art gallery, Winston Wachter Fine Art, on the Upper East Side. They are not ''former art dealers.''

title: BOSNIA'S LAST BEST HOPE
description: After years of cringing at the term ''ethnic cleansing,'' I finally realized just how horrendous it is when I saw the phrase ''ethnic cleansers'' on your cover (''Bosnia's Last Best Hope,'' by Scott Anderson, Sept. 8).

title: Will Fund Investors Prove to Be Faithful or Fickle?
description: WHEN Raymond DeVoe, market strategist for Legg Mason Wood Walker, visited Japan in 1989, he heard the same story at least two dozen times. ''Everyone talked about how different Japanese investors were,'' he recalled last week. ''They were in for the long term, and nothing would be likely to make them sell their stock investments.''

title: Your Lunch Was Yummy. So How Was Mine?
description: MY former accountant tried to explain why none of his clients were making big profits any more. ''The trouble with this economy,'' he complained, ''is that everybody is eating everybody else's lunch.''

title: A Huntington's Mohegan Mission
description: NEXT Saturday the Mohegan Indians of eastern Connecticut will open a big and opulent casino in Montville, near the banks of the Thames River, hoping to emulate the success of the Mashantucket Pequot casino in Ledyard, on the other side of the Thames, that has become the most successful one in the world.

title: The Tango, Al Fresco And Intense
description: Cheek to cheek, chest to chest in rigid embraces, couples swayed and paused across the floor. Men in black guided women in heels and sleek hose to the sensuous sounds of the accordion-like bandoneon. Hips swiveled, legs kicked back, toes pointed and feet intertwined. Faces crinkled as bodies yielded to the passion and addiction of the Argentine tango.

title: Colgate Trounces Brown To End Losing Streak at 16
description: Colgate 44, Brown 27

title: The Great Ruminator
description: February 20, 1955: 'The Shield of Achilles' by W. H. Auden

title: Storing Butane Lighters Near Homes Questioned
description: MAY a building next to a residential area be a warehouse for two million butane lighters?

title: Carpool Lanes Save Time But Cost Violators Money
description: Carpoolers, rejoice. On Monday, the State Department of Transportation opened its latest stretch of high-occupancy vehicle lanes on Interstate 287 in Morris County. By the end of the week, almost 1,000 vehicles a day were using them, said John Dourgarian, public information officer for the department.

title: When Newspeak Was New
description: June 12, 1949: 'Nineteen Eighty-four' by George Orwell

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: The Cult Of the Fund Manager
description: ALTHOUGH most companies eventually must confront the sudden departure of a key executive, mutual fund sponsors are particularly vulnerable to the problem. The situation has been aggravated by a series of rulings starting in 1994 by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has made it easier for portfolio managers to gather up their track records and take them along when they head for the door.

title: A Home Development Is Under Way, 14 Years Later
description: AFTER 14 years of negotiation and litigation, earthmovers are preparing to turn 200 wooded hillside acres in Roxbury Township into a large residential community.

title: Melissa P. Barrett, James G. Rhodes
description: Melissa Parker Barrett, the daughter of Dolores Barrett of New York and Henry R. Barrett 3d of Waccabuc, N.Y., was married last evening to James Gibson Rhodes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Rhodes 2d of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: New Testimony Given on Republicans' Files
description: A former junior Clinton Administration official has testified that other members of the White House personnel security office were aware that confidential background files on Republicans had been obtained from the F.B.I. even though the Republicans had left the Government.

title: Dramatic License in the Corridors of Power
description: LET'S START WITH THE EASY PART. The sets of ''Spin City,'' the new ABC sitcom about New York's City Hall, look much like the real thing.

title: Oops!
description: Look back over 100 years and you're bound to think of things you might have done differently, as this sampling from reviews amply suggests. We've probably slipped up just as badly in more recent years, but history hasn't informed us yet.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: An Institution Born Of Blood, Sweat, Tears
description: To the Editor:

title: I Am Woman, Serve Me Turkey Neck
description: ''We're all out there acting rough and . . . cussing up a storm,'' says a stogie-puffing Demi Moore in the current issue of Cigar Aficionado. Demi is talking tough from the set of ''G. I. Jane,'' in which she smashes the barriers to become the first female Navy SEAL. Tough indeed, but we have to wonder if Demi -- or for that matter, scads of other women who lately seem smitten with all things smoky, liquory, beefy and guy-y -- could cut the bright yellow mustard in truly manly venues, those quintessential New York spots where the cigars smell like smoldering sneakers and the food is often mere backwash in a sea of existentially forlorn maleness. To get at the truth, we sent an iron-willed, iron-stomached woman reporter into the maw. Here's what she found.

title: Corrections
description: Two Charles Addams drawings in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday, with an article about a New York Public Library show of Addams's work, appeared without necessary credits. The caption also misidentified the magazine in which one drawing originally appeared.

title: These Paranoid Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Ouchterloney And Mr. Yu
description: Megan Jule Ouchterloney, a daughter of Elizabeth and Robert D. Ouchterloney of New Milford, Conn., was married yesterday to James David Yu, a son of Dr. Sook Hie and Dr. Dai H. Yu of Penn Valley, Pa. Canon Harry Krauss performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Clara Wu And Joseph Tsai
description: Clara Ming-Hua Wu and Joseph Chung-Hsin Tsai were married Friday evening at the Park Avenue Christian Church in New York. The Rev. Keith Boyd, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Continental Fare With Hits and Misses
description: THE large, lofty restaurant on Manhasset Bay strongly resembles a sleek, beached luxury liner. Port Washington residents recall it as the site of Jimmy's Backyard, a 25-year veteran.

title: In Japan, Art and a Museum Breathe as One
description: TRY TO VISIT the Nagi Museum of Contemporary Art in the rain, when the drops form rippling circles within the square enclosure of a shallow pool and the steel wires that rise from the pool in gentle loops make it seem as if the drops have bounced off the surface back into the air, freezing into glistening silver arcs.

title: New Screen Personalities
description: The GoldStar Fashion TV, a 13-inch set introduced this year, is a funky and fun design in a realm of electronics not known for style. With its modernist curves and short lunar-module legs, the Fashion TV looks like a sci-fi movie prop. Yet its design harks back to a future envisioned three decades ago. It's the sort of television Judy Jetson might have watched.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Having sex without a condom is a choice Mark Ebenhoch chooses to make. His behavior is not due to ''inadequate'' AIDS awareness campaigns. He's an educated man, not a ''victim.'' You don't have to be perfect to protect yourself from AIDS, just responsible.

title: Red Cross Has Course On AIDS
description: THE American Red Cross, which is usually associated with activities like first aid training and disaster relief, is also providing free educational programs about H.I.V. and AIDS to high schools and middle schools, businesses and community groups.

title: New Signals in Cable Deal
description: Since 1993, Chinese immigrants who have Time Warner cable television service in Queens and Brooklyn have enjoyed access to Chinese-language programs provided 24 hours a day by the Chinese Communication Channel. But a dispute between the company and Time Warner may jeopardize some of their favorite shows.

title: Suburbs' Soccer Moms, Fleeing the G.O.P., Are Much Sought
description: If the catch phrase that emerged from the Republican sweep in the 1994 elections was ''angry white men,'' then what will it be this election season?
