title: The 15 Lives of 'Cats'
description: Maybe you've seen the show, maybe not. But you've seen the poster. Eight men and seven women wearing rags and wigs and felt and fur, faces flattened and whitened and whiskered by makeup, crouching and stretching and huddling against one another, hissing and mewling at the camera. Stripes, spots and paws against a black backdrop.

title: Ump Accepts An Apology
description: Umpire John Hirschbeck hadn't been heard from since Roberto Alomar spit in his face a week ago and enraged him by talking about the death of his son. But today, four days after Alomar issued a statement of apology, Hirschbeck and his wife, Denise, accepted it.

title: Rentals Thrive in a College Town With Big-City Airs
description: IN a dusty industrial corner in this small city on the Charles River, two 22-story rental buildings are rising in what is Cambridges's largest market-rate apartment project and the largest residential development under way in metropolitan Boston.

title: Crime and Punishment and Explanation in Full
description: March 3, 1940: 'Native Son' by Richard Wright

title: F.Y.I.
description: Snakes and the Big Apple

title: Up From Thuggery
description: September 11, 1966: 'The Autobiography of Malcolm X'

title: Secular Hobbitism
description: October 31, 1954: 'The Fellowship of the Ring' by J. R. R. Tolkien

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Peekskill Creates District To Boost Downtown
description: ANITA CREEM, owner of the Submarine Gallery here, knows what makes for a good tuna sandwich: lots of mayonnaise and plenty of dressing extras. But these days, Ms. Creem is as likely to be fielding phone calls about entertainers for the autumn and winter festivals in downtown Peekskill as she is stuffing subs.

title: By Train to Montreal, Through Autumn
description: The Adirondack train linking Penn Station in New York with Montreal got refurbished equipment this fall from its sponsors, Amtrak and New York State. The smooth-riding Heritage cars, formerly coaches on the New York-Philadelphia Clocker trains, have been redecorated and fitted with luggage and ski racks. As a way to see autumn colors along the Hudson, around Saratoga Springs or Glens Falls, Lake George or Lake Champlain, and north near Lake Placid, this trip of 381 miles one way is hard to beat. Stops along the route include Poughkeepsie, Rhinecliff, Saratoga Springs, Glens Falls, Port Kent on Lake Champlain and Rouses Point near the Canadian border.

title: Ms. Provenzano And Mr. Merrick
description: Therese Laura Provenzano and Alistair Guy Claude Merrick are to be married today at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., by its pastor, the Rev. Brian McKeon.

title: Warm Up Salads With Cooked Beets
description: BEETS, with their deep red color and earthy flavor, are among my favorite fall vegetables. They make wonderful warm salads paired with peppery vegetables like watercress or endive, and they can be flavored with herbs, orange sections, toasted walnuts, sesame seeds or pecans. The greens are delicious, too, cooked and tossed in a vinaigrette dressing. Both beets and their greens are good served as part of an antipasto with prosciutto, bresaola, smoked fish or a coarse country pate.

title: Master Builder
description: May 16, 1943: 'The Fountainhead' by Ayn Rand

title: For Aspiring Teachers, a New Emphasis on Practice Time
description: For most of New Jersey's aspiring teachers, the routine goes like this: choose a liberal arts major in the first year of college, and apply to the education program during sophomore year. Take a mix of liberal arts and education courses, and devote one semester of senior year to student teaching.

title: DIARY
description: UNEMPLOYMENT

title: Testimony: Murder on the Corner
description: Spontaneous violence once ruled the streets now the target of an intense anti-drug campaign. Below is one murder in 1991 as described in testimony by Raul Vargas, a hit man from Washington Heights. Francisco (Freddy) Medina carried out the killing at the behest of a member of the Wild Cowboys known as Platano.

title: Smallest Receiver Is Jets' Big Hope
description: They came to the Jets this season with their reputations and fancy numbers (both in dollar signs and receptions). Jeff Graham. Keyshawn Johnson. Webster Slaughter. And then there was Wayne Chrebet, a muscular little guy from the school across the street, annoyed that he was being tagged with a Cinderella label that overshadowed what he really was: a football player.

title: Giuliani Choice: Vote Expected For Dole Ticket
description: The days grow cool, the political ads grow hot and the seemingly endless dance of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani around his Presidential endorsement is drawing to a close. His friends have already begun laying the groundwork for an announcement this month that he will vote for Bob Dole and Jack F. Kemp, returning in body if not fully in spirit to the Republican fold.

title: Simpson Witness Pleads No Contest
description: Here's the latest score card in the O. J. Simpson case as of last week: Mr. Simpson was acquitted of the double murder of his former wife and her friend; the Los Angeles Police detective who gathered some of the most incriminating evidence against him became a felon.

title: This Scoreboard Is a Research Assistant, Too
description: FOR serious mutual fund investors, keeping track of a diversified portfolio and researching new holdings can be quite a chore. But for investors who also have a powerful personal computer with a big chunk of hard-disk space available (about 46 megabytes), help is at hand from Value Line Publishing, the independent research organization.

title: After a Tough Battle, Water Wins Once More
description: Making New Jersey's regulatory climate more friendly to business has been a priority for Governor Whitman. But none of her proposals to do so has provoked as much public debate and dispute as the administration's recommendation to ease environmental rules that protect water quality.

title: Gimme Shelter
description: November 20, 1977: 'Dispatches' by Michael Herr

title: Jeanne Moreau: Behind the Mask Of a Femme Fatale
description: ON A RECENT GOLDEN afternoon in this city, Parisians might have seen Jeanne Moreau brushing through the tall doors of her apartment building with a handsome young man trotting at her heels, toting bundles of small couturier bags.

title: A Maverick Edges Toward The Mainstream
description: SHORTLY AFTER the Chilean film maker Raul Ruiz arrived here last month to teach at Duke University, Hurricane Fran swept across North Carolina. But for a man who has made 94 movies in the face of military dictatorship and exile, a natural disaster merits barely a footnote. Asked how he was faring without electricity after the storm, he replied dryly, ''It's special.''

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-16

title: The Tragedy of the Age
description: April 25, 1903: 'The Souls of Black Folk' by W. E. B. Du Bois

title: Foster Care Is for Children, Not for Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparks Won't Go Easy On His Arizona Friend
description: When the Giants play the Cardinals in Arizona next month, there may be some awkward moments for Phillippi Sparks. Sparks, a native of Arizona who almost signed with the Cardinals as a free agent last season, has a house there. So what does a good capitalist do with a house he won't live in for six months out of the year? He rents it.

title: White Flight
description: June 7, 1981: 'July's People' by Nadine Gordimer

title: Multicultural Dining In San Francisco
description: IF there is a theme to this fall's dining landscape in San Francisco it is diversity. Supper clubs, sprawling American grills, Cal-Asian hybrids, haute vegetarian, modest bistros -- all can be found in this compact, vertical city. And some of the locations are unexpected.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 6, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE GREEN MILE: COFFEY ON THE MILE, by Stephen King. (Signet, $3.99.) The sixth and concluding installment of a thriller set on death row. 2 3 THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Scientists visit a Costa Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs; a sequel to ''Jurassic Park.'' 3 12 THE FIRST WIVES CLUB, by Olivia Goldsmith. (Pocket, $6.99.) Three women conspire to get even with the men who divorced them. 4 1 THE JUDGE, by Steve Martini. (Jove, $6.99.) An attorney defends a judge he doesn't like against murder and other charges. 5 52 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) A murder trial recalls the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. (+) 6 8 ''L'' IS FOR LAWLESS, by Sue Grafton. (Fawcett, $6.99.) Kinsey Millhone on the trail of the cash and culprits involved in an old bank heist. 7 7 MORNING, NOON & NIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $7.50.) The mysterious drowning of a respected tycoon reveals a tangle of scandals. 8 8 THE GREEN MILE: NIGHT JOURNEY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The fifth installment of a serial thriller. 9 2 COME TO GRIEF, by Dick Francis. (Jove, $6.99.) Sid Halley, champion jockey turned investigator, probes the suicide of a revered racing figure's mother. 10 3 THE HEIR, by Catherine Coulter. (Topaz, $6.99.) The stormy courtship and marriage of an earl and his cousin in 18th-century England. 11 6 MELODY, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $6.99.) A young girl, her father dead, is deserted by her mother and left with eccentric relatives. 12 14 THE GREEN MILE: THE BAD DEATH OF EDUARD DELACROIX, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The fourth installment of a serial thriller. 13* 15 BEACH MUSIC, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $7.99.) An American living in Rome returns to South Carolina and tries to cope with his past. 14 24 THE GREEN MILE: TWO DEAD GIRLS, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The first installment of a serial thriller. 15 2 X-WING: THE KRYTOS TRAP, by Michael A. Stackpole. (Spectra/Bantam, $5.99.) The third volume of a ''Star Wars'' series. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 2 A FEVER IN THE HEART, by Ann Rule. (Pocket, $6.99.) Accounts of six crime cases that occurred in Washington and Oregon. 2 80 REVIVING OPHELIA, by Mary Pipher. (Ballantine, $12.50.) The dangers for teen-age girls. (+) 3 4 A CIVIL ACTION, by Jonathan Harr. (Vintage, $13.) A lawsuit brought by Massachusetts householders against industrial polluters. (+) 4 26 THE LIARS' CLUB, by Mary Karr. (Penguin, $11.95.) A poet recalls her troubled childhood. (+) 5 3 MY POINT . . . AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $6.50.) Observations on life by the television star and stand-up comedian. 6 29 HOW THE IRISH SAVED CIVILIZATION, by Thomas Cahill. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The story of monks who copied Western literature. (+) 7 19 SLEEPERS, by Lorenzo Carcaterra. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The true story, the narrator claims, of boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take. 8 10 MINDHUNTER, by John Douglas and Mark Olshaker. (Drew/Pocket, $6.99.) The memoirs of the former leader of an F.B.I. team that studies the behavior of serial killers and assassins. 9* 14 NEW PASSAGES, by Gail Sheehy. (Ballantine, $12.95.) How changing social conditions and longer life expectancies affect our lives. (+) 10* 17 SPONTANEOUS HEALING, by Andrew Weil. (Fawcett, $12.95.) How the body heals itself. (+) 11 672 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) Inspiration. (+) 12* 18 A GOOD WALK SPOILED, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $13.95.) The P.G.A. Tour. (+) 13* 24 PAULA, by Isabel Allende. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) The novelist tells stories of her family's life as she tends her fatally ill daughter. (+) 14* 142 CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (Harper Perennial, $12.) Daily spirituality. (+) 15* 106 EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Bantam, $5.99.) A woman's near-death experience. (+) 16* 12 MY AMERICAN JOURNEY, by Colin L. Powell with Joseph E. Persico. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The autobiography of the former general. 17* 1 IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.) The First Lady on ways to create a better society for children. (+) Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 2 IT'S A MAGICAL WORLD, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $14.95.) A new collection of ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 106 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE SOUL, compiled by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Stories meant to ''open the heart and rekindle the spirit.'' (+) 3 55 WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING, by Arlene Eisenberg, Heidi E. Murkoff and Sandee E. Hathaway. (Workman, $10.95.) Advice for parents-to-be. (+) 4 24 DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (M. Evans, $12.95.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)

title: Sources
description: A Selective Directory of the Architects, Designers and Dealers Featured in This Issue

title: No Headline
description: ''You think where the country's going to be in 10 years. You aren't so me-centered. Before, I thought how it was for me -- taxes, Social Security, balancing the budget. Now, I'm thinking about them -- drugs, education, medical reform. You get that mom focus.''

title: Elizabeth Schmidt and Eric Liftin
description: Elizabeth Hun Schmidt, the daughter of Katherine R. Schmidt of Colorado Springs and Benno C. Schmidt Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Eric Andrew Liftin, the son of Leni Liftin and John M. Liftin, both of New York. Justice Rena K. Uviller of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Why Ailey Wasn't Blinded by Broadway's Lights
description: Alvin Ailey made history in modern dance, but he got his start in New York, at 23, on Broadway in the musical ''House of Flowers.'' Then came a role in the musical ''Jamaica.'' In this excerpt from ''Alvin Ailey: A Life in Dance,'' published this week by Addison-Wesley, Jennifer Dunning describes that time.

title: Seminar in Fiction Teaches Focus
description: IN the book-lined living room of a house nestled discreetly off Route 129, an audience of five sits tentatively on the edge of their seats. All eyes are on the dark-haired woman reading a chapter aloud from her novel-in-progress. As her scene builds slowly in an emotional crescendo, she stops reading abruptly. Everyone in the room gasps loudly. The author is missing pages of text. She recovers, however, and picks up where she left off.

title: Jones Gives Lessons In and Out Of the Ring
description: Everyone who has seen Roy Jones Jr. do his jetes and plies and soliloquies while beating up opponents has been wondering: what else can this remarkable fighter do to make it interesting?

title: Bar's Turn to Get Proof of Age
description: The bar-genealogy battle continues apace. Questioned by an amateur historian about its venerable age, McSorley's Old Ale House, the ''wonderful saloon'' chronicled by Joseph Mitchell and painted by John Sloan, amassed new evidence to defend its birthright.

title: The Faces and Voices of a Paterson Neighborhood in Transition
description: The changes that time inevitably brings can be measured in matters as big as a Presidential election or as small as who moves in next door. Cianci Street in Paterson represents change of the incremental kind. Once dominated by Italian-Americans, over the years the street has become the home of new immigrant groups: Argentines, Puerto Ricans, Peruvians, Dominicans.

title: Q. & A.
description: Paying Tax To Record Mortgage

title: The Admirable Glasses
description: September 17, 1961: 'Franny and Zooey' by J. D. Salinger

title: Dubliners Outraged At Sellers Of Heroin
description: Night after night, for weeks now, thousands of angry Dubliners have been marching up to the doorsteps of people they suspect to be drug dealers, shouting, cursing and demanding that they leave the neighborhood. The police stand by, not making arrests, merely keeping the demonstrators in line.

title: When the Experts Check In
description: Companies with problems often hire consultants to come up with ways to make repairs. Sometimes the suggestions are wise; sometimes they are not. But employees tend to become nervous when these outsiders start roaming the office. What happened when your company hired them? Were resumes flying out the door? Were the consultants' recommendations on target, or ludicrous? Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Afghanistan Reels Back Into View
description: IN the months before Afghanistan's new rulers marched him from a United Nations compound in Kabul and summarily beat, shot and hanged him, Afghanistan's last Communist President, Najibullah, spent much of his time preparing a translation into Pashto, his native language, of a 1990 book about Afghanistan, ''The Great Game,'' by the English writer Peter Hopkirk.

title: Rockefeller In-Law Raises Cash for Town
description: BEING part of the Rockefeller family does not give George F. Gumina, the so-called philanthropic coordinator of Greenburgh, instant access to people and cash, but it has given him access to the Rockefeller family's experts on fund-raising.

title: Giving Recognition to the Entrepreneurial Spirit on the Island
description: AS a managing partner of Long Island's largest accounting concern, KPMG Peat Marwick, Lawrence Waldman founded the Entrepreneurial Spirit Awards. The awards, created to foster business development on Long Island, recognize the 50 largest privately held companies on Long Island, based upon total revenue, and the 25 fastest growing privately held companies, based upon revenue growth over the prior year. They will be presented tomorrow for the 10th year by KPMG Peat Marwick and Hofstra University.

title: The Good Life: A Rainy Summer and a Wealth of Fungus
description: The New Jersey Mycological Association's annual Grete Turchick Foray and Picnic has not even begun yet, and the baskets are already filling up.

title: Hearty Portions, Some Serious Desserts
description: NEWTOWN is not known as a mecca of fine dining. That's what makes G.P. Cheffields Mediterranean Grille and Bar such a pleasant discovery.

title: Look Forward, Angel
description: September 22, 1940: 'You Can't Go Home Again' by Thomas Wolfe

title: Not a Movie to His Name, But That's Hollywood
description: JOHN POGUE'S NAME HAS NEVER scrolled across a movie screen. But you wouldn't know it from a visit to the sun-dappled bungalow at 20th Century Fox, where this 31-year-old writer is plotting his career with the panache of a young Orson Welles.

title: When There's an Option to Buy a Lot, Then Build
description: AT the 78-acre Penmor Farm subdivision in Muttontown, where sales of houses starting at $1 million began two months ago, purchasers have the option of buying one of the 23 lots instead of a house -- and hiring their own architect and builder.

title: SCORES COUNT
description: Sara Mosle's article on Michael Johnson was one of the most exciting I have read in a long time (''Scores Count,'' Sept. 8). It gave me hope that students today can rise to the challenge of intense learning and academic discipline, regardless of background.

title: Tracing Origins of Gift to a College
description: MARYMOUNT COLLEGE, situated on a hilltop here, recently received its biggest corporate grant ever -- $375,000 from the Pepsico Foundation -- to develop a master plan for future buildings and renovate its campus concert hall.

title: A FLEET OF OPTIONS
description: THE fall-winter cruise season brings a fleet of new offerings. At least eight more ships will be in service by this time next year, including the first of the new 100,000-ton superliners, Carnival Cruise Lines' Carnival Destiny. Carrying 2,600 passengers in larger than average cabins and a broad range of restaurants, lounges and entertainment areas, including a 1,500-seat theater, she is scheduled to enter service on Nov. 24.

title: Television Cameras May Survey Public Places
description: In a move to help prevent crime, the Police Department is considering a plan to mount 24-hour surveillance cameras in Central Park, subway stations and other public places, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Erin Cavanagh, John Manahan 3d
description: Erin Kathleen Cavanagh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Cavanagh Jr. of Oceanport, N.J., was married on Friday to John R. Manahan 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Manahan Jr. of Convent Station, N.J. The Rev. Benedict Worry performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Precious Blood in Monmouth Beach, N.J.

title: Good Dog, Spot! Sell the Product!
description: IF you've been seeing spots lately, don't call the eye doctor: advertising and fashion have discovered a mottled muse, dalmatians.

title: Forgettabilia
description: One victor in the 1996 Presidential race is already known. It is Mort Berkowitz, a Times Square-based designer whose ''Hillary RODMAN Clinton'' button easily wins Best of Breed, placing Dennis Rodman's two-tone hairdo on the First Lady's head. When Hillary mentioned the button during her convention speech, its black-market price shot up to $75.

title: Now Playing: Movies Worth Talking About
description: SO the new television season has arrived, and it's worse than the old television season. Forget about calling the script doctors; it's time to page Dr. Kevorkian.

title: Rental Rates
description: To the Editor: Last September, I rented a Hertz midsize manual transmission car at Shannon Airport. The Hertz agent at the airport had agreed to match our prearranged Avis rate of 119 Irish pounds (about $200) for the week. With additional charges (tax, an extra driver, etc.), I expected a final bill of about $300. I signed a contract without careful scrutiny, trusting in the honesty and integrity of Hertz. When the credit card statement arrived, I was shocked to find a charge of close to $1,600 rather than the expected $300. The agreed-upon weekly rate had been entered in the contract as a daily rate, a charge completely out of line with prevailing car rental fees.

title: Finding Still More Life in a 'Dead' Idiom
description: BY NOW, MILTON BABBITT IS accustomed to the polemics his work has generated. Yet Mr. Babbitt, an unreconstructed Serialist composer and imposing musical theorist who turned 80 in May, speaks charitably of colleagues who have castigated him. He views the current contentious state of contemporary music with more sadness than anger. Indeed, he is at a loss to explain it. Mr. Babbitt professes unqualified expertise on only two subjects: American show tunes of the 1920's and 30's, and beer.

title: SCORES COUNT
description: Johnson's back-to-basics focus makes sense only if those basics are skills necessary to get and keep a good job, with or without a traditional four-year-college degree.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Laura Espinoza-Watson
description: Espinoza-Watson plays for the Colorado Silver Bullets, a barnstorming women's professional baseball team that recently completed its third season -- compiling a respectable 18-34 record against men's minor league and amateur All Star teams.

title: Love It, Hate It, the Ubiquitous Salvia Persists
description: THE summer flower show has wound down, cool weather is forcing many annual plants to give their last performances and seed pods are beginning to outnumber blossoms, a sure sign of an end of the season.

title: Chairwoman Of Adelphi Defends Role On Insurance
description: Adelphi University's chairwoman, under criticism for handling the school's insurance through a brokerage she owns, says her firm has made little profit on the account.

title: A Short, Fresh Take on Topics of the Day, and Free, Too
description: BREVITY and clarity have been raised to an art form in the half-sheet flyers passed out on the southeast corner of the New Haven Green every Thursday at noon.

title: At Center Stage, Vying for Control of Center Court
description: The way to win in the game of squash is to seize control of the center of the court.

title: Picture It: There You Go Again, Mr. Major
description: To the Editor:

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: I cannot tell you how affirming it was to read ''Flirting With Suicide'' (by Jesse Green, Sept. 15), a thoughtful, in-depth exploration of gay men's lives and the issues that concern us, in a publication of such prestige.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Tea for 2, or More
description: MY daughter is acting ornery. Only one thing will cure her: tea at the Hilton. A day in the hotel's celebrated spa will cure me, but it isn't part of the package.

title: Genuine Imitations
description: Mention reproduction furniture to a dealer of fine antiques, and he might well wrinkle his nose as if you'd suggested replacing the Hope Diamond with a zircon. But not all reproductions are fresh off an assembly line, and not all are new. Of course, an original piece by a great master has value and cachet, but can't more youthful versions -- some of them now antiques themselves -- be far more practical and just as ornamental?

title: For Many White Men, Clinton's the Reason To Vote for Dole
description: Ask Republican men in this stronghold of conservatism why they are voting for Bob Dole in November, and the odds are they will tell you first that Bill Clinton is a promise-breaking, policy-shifting politician whose charm and sweet talk have cast a dangerous spell on much of America.

title: A Worthy Composer Made of Rich Human Cloth
description: MOVING INTO A NEW CENTURY (forget the millennium) begins to feel like moving into a new home. It is time to tidy up the old one a bit, to make an honest inventory and appraisal of its fixtures and contents before displaying it to the potential buyer, posterity. Fastidious tidiers are, in fact, already at work in the music studio, sorting, dusting and polishing, and at least two of them have fastened on the same curio: the Bavarian composer Karl Amadeus Hartmann.

title: Awakening
description: March 21, 1903: 'The Story of My Life' by Helen Keller

title: Unquestionably Great
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Art: A Piece of Cake
description: THE party started like this: 300 artists were asked to decorate pieces of cake.

title: Playing by the Rules
description: Republicans call it the Invisible Campaign. Democrats call it Brigadoon.

title: Too Big to Write Smaller
description: January 10, 1926: 'An American Tragedy' by Theodore Dreiser

title: Oil Spill Tarnishes the Image of Maine Lobster
description: Most people do not eat steamed Maine lobster for breakfast. But that was what Gov. Angus King did on Friday morning to demonstrate that the famous local lobster is still safe to eat after one of Portland Harbor's largest oil spills.

title: GUN PLAY
description: David Updike's reflection upon his own ''gun-besotted'' past made me wonder (Lives: ''Gun Play,'' Sept. 15): Do kids who play with water balloons grow up to become Unabombers? Should we ban balloons? Or perhaps even water?

title: The Wizard of Dreams
description: August 8, 1920: 'A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis' by Sigmund Freud

title: Playing The Classics To Commuters
description: Q. Let me just make sure I've got your name. You are . . . ?

title: Chilly Welcome In London
description: ''DON'T worry, we've packed Windbreakers,'' my mother assured me last April on the eve of her visit to London.

title: Your Guts on Candid Camera
description: IT isn't exactly ''E.R.'' But Dr. Glenn Deyo, a general surgeon in Tacoma, Wash., videotapes all of his laparoscopic surgery. And he tells his patients that if they'd like a tape of their operation, he'll make a copy for them.

title: Kansas City Is Rediscovering Its Downtown Area
description: ALTHOUGH Utilicorp United was a loser in its recent fight to merge with Kansas City Power and Light, it should find some consolation come mid-November when it moves into a new corporate headquarters that is the latest crown jewel in the rebirth of this city's downtown.

title: Sick of It All
description: April 23, 1933: 'Miss Lonelyhearts' by Nathanael West

title: Kansas Death Trip
description: January 16, 1966: 'In Cold Blood' by Truman Capote

title: Elegance to Spare
description: A 2,000-square-foot loft is hardly big enough to contain all the ideas that Tim Haynes and Kevin Roberts have generated in the course of their six-year design collaboration. Their TriBeCa home is a compendium of new ways to accommodate workaday needs while at the same time suggesting a certain grandeur. The pigeons that used to roost in the beams would be shocked at the transformation.

title: In Pastoral Western Rwanda, Ethnic Foes Engage in Murderous Tit for Tat
description: The wooded hills and lush valleys of western Rwanda seem to be a picture of peace, an agrarian scene of long-horned cattle, swollen streams, banana farms and hardy peasants.

title: Fielder Became Yankees' Significant Other
description: Has a player ever moved as quickly from an afterthought to a most significant player in a post-season as Cecil Fielder?

title: Thawing Out Cold War History
description: WAS the Soviet Politburo determined to squash the 1956 Hungarian uprising right from the start? Did the broadcasters on the C.I.A.-financed Radio Free Europe excoriate Imre Nagy, Hungary's reform Communist leader? Did the Chinese encourage the Soviet Union to crack down on the Hungarians?

title: Jazz Days
description: March 11, 1928: 'Home to Harlem' by Claude McKay

title: Yankee Game Over, Rush Begins
description: Yankee Stadium became Camp Yankee in the Bronx last night.

title: Pictures of Norfolk & Western Reflect Triumphs of Choreography
description: THE news from the Candace Perich Gallery here is of steam locomotives photographed in black and white by O. Winston Link. Although 4 of the 24 works lining the walls are contact prints depicting railroad workers, the rest are sizable images of engines hauling cars through valleys and across bridges or pausing for refreshment at sidings. Taken at night and on sunless days, the pictures are triumphs of choreography in which smoke billows neatly and figures are few and far between. At the time of my visit, the 82-year-old photographer was on duty at the gallery, wearing an engineer's cap and a shirt patterned with trains.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Green's article was as interesting for what it left out as for what it included. Nowhere in the author's remarks or in the solipsistic conversations of the homosexual men he interviewed was there any mention of the cost of their reckless behavior to society at large.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: Anne Robinson And Peter Ayer
description: Anne Turner Robinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Robinson of Beaver, Pa., was married last evening to Peter Eisold Ayer, a son of Jutta M. Ayer of Bradford, Mass., and James C. Ayer of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. Dean Elliott Wolfe performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: Clinton Finds the Northeast Just as Cozy as Home Turf
description: There is no better gauge of President Clinton's political potency in Pennsylvania, or in the entire Northeast, than in the changed behavior of this city's Democratic Mayor, Ed Rendell.

title: 'Worth the Fighting For'
description: October 20, 1940: 'For Whom the Bell Tolls' by Ernest Hemingway

title: State Officials Conclude Some Provisions of the Welfare Law May Be Unconstitutional
description: State officials have concluded that many options given to them by the new welfare law conflict with longstanding interpretations of the Federal Constitution and state constitutions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Sept. 8 showing a detail of Jasper Johns's painting ''Between the Clock and the Bed,'' which will be in a retrospective of his work at the Museum of Modern Art later this month, was reproduced upside down and reversed. The light area in the upper left corner should have appeared in the lower right.

title: A Shaky Peace in Northern Ireland
description: By now, the Northern Ireland peace talks were supposed to be addressing the political issues at the core of the conflict. Instead, they are going nowhere, haunted by the Irish Republican Army's reckless decision to resume deadly bombing attacks in Britain and all but paralyzed by a Protestant Unionist demand to revise the compromise disarmament formula on which the talks are premised.

title: Land Clash Pits Indians Vs. Oilmen In Colombia
description: Late in the 17th century, a group of Spanish missionaries and tax collectors journeyed to a mountainous area about 30 miles southwest of here. Their goal was to establish control over a village of Uwa Indians.

title: New-Age Fascism
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Lowest Air Fares listing on Sept. 22 for the New York-London route omitted an airline under the heading ''Discount Fare.'' The airline, British Airways, matches the lowest available fare, $289.

title: Memories: Dealers in the Backyard
description: For Victor Rodriguez, Mott Haven's drug world existed right in his own backyard.

title: Patricia Davenport, Herman Watts
description: Patricia S. Davenport and the Rev. Herman H. Watts, the senior minister of the Friendship Baptist Church in Harlem, were married in his church yesterday by the Rev. Calvin Owens, a Baptist minister.

title: INSIDE
description: FYI 2

title: Blitzkrieg in the Drug War: 200 Arrests, and, Yes, a Dent
description: When the Secret Service descended on the area around the Moore Houses , ''the people from the neighborhood swore the President was coming,'' said Capt. Nicholas Witkowich of the 40th Precinct.

title: What the 'Applause' Dream Team Has Wrought
description: THE great musical, even the merely good musical, has a singular life, begat by inspired collaboration. See ''Gypsy'' in a makeshift tent and you'll come away crowing, ''What a show!'' See ''Applause'' in a mega-theater and you're apt to ask, ''What?''

title: Modell's Looking For New Ideas
description: Modell's Sporting Goods in New York is seeking creative ideas for its advertising campaign, with annual spending of $12 million.

title: Immigrants' Plight, Boy's Conscience
description: Almost everyone should be able to identify with the wrenching moral quandary facing Igor (Jeremie Renier), the 15-year-old protagonist of Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne's casually devastating film ''La Promesse.'' A skinny blond youth who has barely entered adolescence, Igor works for his father, Roger (Olivier Gourmet), in a construction business outside Antwerp, Belgium, that employs and ruthlessly exploits illegal immigrants.

title: Ex-Athlete Declines Post
description: Only two weeks after being nominated for a seat on the state Sports and Exposition Authority, Bernard King, the former star forward for the New Jersey Nets and New York Knicks, has declined the post. Mr. King, whose nomination stirred up new reports of his 1980 conviction for sexual abuse, wrote to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman on Friday asking that she withdraw his nomination ''for personal reasons,'' Carl Golden, the Governor's spokesman, said yesterday. The nine-member authority runs the Meadowlands sports complex, Monmouth Park race track, the state aquarium in Camden and other facilities.

title: Clear-Cut Greed
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Hope on Third-World AIDS
description: Progress is rare in the fight against the spread of AIDS in the developing world. In the last six years, the number of people infected with the AIDS virus globally has doubled to more than 25 million, with 85 percent of them in Africa and Asia. Until an effective vaccine is developed, there is no hope for eradicating the disease. But there is at least reason for cautious hope that its rate of growth can be stemmed. Researchers now have evidence that programs in Thailand have cut the rate of transmission of H.I.V., the AIDS virus -- the first such proven success. Uganda also shows indications that the AIDS transmission rate is slowing. While not every nation will be able to copy these achievements, they deserve to be studied and their lessons adapted worldwide.

title: Gretzky's Home Debut Is Less Than Great
description: WAYNE GRETZKY would have been great even if his family name had never prompted the alliterative and literary nickname The Great Gretzky. No hockey player has ever maneuvered the puck like him.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL JACKSON, the pop star, has arrived in Tunis for his first concert in Africa. Organizers said the concert, part of Mr. Jackson's ''HIStory II'' tour, would be held today at Tunis's main stadium, El Menzah, the Reuters news agency reported.

title: Microsoft Pushing To Alter Standard For Digital TV
description: A last-minute lobbying push by the Microsoft Corporation, seeking to block or modify the planned technical standards for the next generation of television, has goaded members of the Federal Communications Commission into a search for a way to accommodate the software giant and its computer-industry allies.

title: With Party Conference Near, Tories Suffer New Setbacks
description: The hurdles that Prime Minister John Major must clear to unite his demoralized Conservative Party and lead it to victory in the coming election have been raised higher at an acutely inconvenient moment -- the eve of the Conservatives' annual conference.

title: Finding Complexity in a Seemingly Simple Bride
description: Teresa Stratas's cancellation rate has become so legendary that even compulsive gamblers may be skittish about taking odds that she will appear at the Metropolitan Opera when she is advertised in a starring role. So presumably few operagoers were surprised when she bowed out of the Met's revival of ''The Bartered Bride'' on Tuesday evening because of a throat infection. But Ms. Stratas's absence, while an inevitable talking point during the evening's two intermissions, did not overshadow the truly lovely performance by her understudy, Gwynne Geyer, or the return of Smetana's charmer to the Met stage for the first time in 18 years.

title: Politics of Independent Film Makers
description: The documentary form, in its infinite variety and sometimes troubling methodology, gets two vigorous workouts this evening with ''Raw Footage'' on the Independent Film Channel (to be repeated on Friday on Bravo) and ''Smashed'' on MTV.

title: New Software Seeks End To Long Waits on Internet
description: Marimba Inc., an eight-month-old company, will formally introduce new software today for distributing information much more quickly over the Internet.

title: Asthma and Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Spurred by U.S., Two Sides Open New Talks to Save Mideast Peace
description: Spurred on by Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Israelis and Palestinians sat down today to the urgent negotiations they agreed on at last week's summit meeting in Washington in an effort to salvage their peace after the recent gunbattles in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: Jets Make Hostetler Feel Right At Home
description: Jeff Hostetler returned home today and won.

title: The Frenzied Fans Get Extra-Special Villain
description: And now for the Splendid Spitter versus the Frenzied Fans. It is a matchup Major League Baseball officials could not even have daydreamed of in their most optimistic wishes for attractive post-season pairings. Bring back fans alienated by the still unresolved labor dispute? This will do it. Stir up conversation and debate, always good for a sport seeking attention? The inane talk shows won't have enough time for all of the calls and all of the wild-eyed words. Television ratings? They'll go through Nielsen's roof.

title: A Weak Housing Agency Seems to Be a Step Behind
description: Last December, Sonia Surens called the New York City housing agency's emergency phone line to report that her troubled building in Bushwick, Brooklyn, was falling apart. The rear wall was bulging outward by at least a foot, like a swollen belly; it had detached from the foundation, opening a crater in the building's base. And her kitchen was disintegrating.

title: Afghanistan's Professional Class Flees Rule by Ultra-Strict Clerics
description: Since the Taliban militia forces overran this capital 10 days ago and proclaimed a Muslim fundamentalist Government, a ghostly exodus has begun among the Kabul middle class.

title: H.M.O.'s Offer Advantages to Elderly and Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: A computing pioneer works to raise the 'collective I.Q.' of organizations.
description: IF not for Douglas Engelbart, a great many of the technical innovations we consider integral to the personal computer revolution would not exist. While Dr. Engelbart was working at what was then called the Stanford Research Institute, during a remarkable run of creativity that began in the early 1950's and continued throughout the 1960's, he invented many seminal products and concepts that we take wholly for granted today -- the computer mouse, hypertext, groupware and many others.

title: Q&A /Jean-Philippe Beja : China Patriotism Cuts Both Ways
description: Recent efforts by Japanese rightists to assert Tokyo's sovereignty over the uninhabited Senkaku Islands, also claimed by China and Taiwan as the Diaoyus, have unleashed a wave of protests against the Japanese in Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan and China itself. Jean-Philippe Beja, head of the French Center for the Study of Contemporary China in Hong Kong, spoke with Kevin Murphy of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Updated, Yes, and That's Not All
description: Questions of property obsess the arts. Composers sue over stolen melodies, Hollywood writers over the origins of an idea, book publishers over plagiarized passages. So to whom does an opera like ''The Rake's Progress'' belong?

title: New Knick Is Making His Mark
description: Buck Williams, a league diplomat, a labor leader and one of the more congenial and well-liked people in the National Basketball Association, quickly passed his initiation with the Knicks today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. Dispute in Canada Hinges on Issue of Control

title: Huddled Masses, Longing for Yankee Tickets
description: What is the true measure of a Yankee fan's devotion? Is it the willingness to bed down on a concrete mattress through a chilly night amid the snoring of beer-bloated strangers? Or the mettle to court the wrath of spouses, parents or employers for the chance of a seat in the distant clouds of the upper deck?

title: Pie In The Sky
description: Going into the first debate, Bob Dole was hobbled by one problem above all. What was meant to be the foundation of his campaign for President, the promise of a 15 percent cut in income taxes, had turned out to be a loser. Doubly so.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Coming Soon: Good Oriole, Bad Oriole
description: They were sitting side by side, their chairs a bat length apart. It's perception that separated them.

title: What's Cool on Line? The E-mail Basket, Please
description: In the peculiar lexicon of the Internet, ''cool'' has become the prime adjective to distinguish between the wheat and the chaff among the 300,000 or so sites on the World Wide Web. Members of the emerging Web design industry wore their synthetic finery last Thursday to toast the best in their field at the Cool Site of the Year Awards held at Webster Hall, a nightclub in the East Village in Manhattan.

title: North Korea Reports It Has Arrested an American in a Spy Case
description: North Korea said today that it had arrested an American citizen and would imprison him for espionage.

title: In Primary Repeat, A 2d Chance to Vote
description: In the annals of New York City election history, the primary contest of 1996 will undoubtedly go down as one of the most bizarre. The polls reopen on Thursday -- a month after the original primary day -- as though the election were merely being extended.

title: Green Bay's Simple Game Plan: Outjump Them in the End Zone
description: This was like watching a game of marbles in which one guy is shooting the normal ones and the other guy is shooting golf balls.

title: Subway Shops To Hal Riney
description: The Subway Franchise Advertising Board, which oversees ad operations for the Subway chain of sandwich shops, has retained Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland, the Chicago office of Hal Riney & Partners, to handle its account, which has been at that agency for five years. Billings were estimated at $85 million.

title: 70 Years Later, a Melodrama Is Back
description: ''Fedora,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon after an absence of 70 years, is no masterpiece. It doesn't aim to be one. Setting ''Fedora'' against the historical backdrop of anti-czarist uprisings in Russia of the 1880's, Umberto Giordano fashioned a solidly constructed, musically lush melodrama, teaming with moments of dramatic conflict and unconcerned with psychological complexities. The score is a savvy piece of theater music, thick with opportunities for soaring singing and thin on counterpoint.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about provisions in the catchall spending bill approved by Congress last week misidentified a Democratic sponsor of a $225 million appropriation in the budget of the National Institute of Standards and Technology. The sponsor was Representative George E. Brown Jr. of California, not Representative George Miller of California.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 28 about Donald J. Trump's purchase of 55 Wall Street misstated the building's connection to Herman Melville. While he did work as a customs inspector there begining in 1866, he did not work on ''Moby-Dick'' there; the novel was published in 1851.

title: Democrats Hoping to Regain Ground Lost to G.O.P. in '94
description: Home at last, the Congressman from the Fifth District went immediately to a comfortable retreat: the open airwaves of daytime radio. But then came the calls. People said he was out of touch, that he was a party-line robot, that his votes were not mainstream.

title: Hebron Jews Voice Fear Of Attack by the Police
description: Robert Ludlem, a yeshiva student who lives in a Jewish enclave in the heart of Hebron, has few doubts about what could happen should Israeli soldiers hand over most of this city to a Palestinian police force.

title: For Woods, The Wait Is A Short One
description: In the game of golf, and in the city of Las Vegas, there are supposed to be no sure things, no ''can't miss'' propositions. But just as he has throughout his astounding career, Tiger Woods chose the perfect time and place yesterday to lay waste to another bit of conventional wisdom.

title: States' Power Among Hard Issues On Supreme Court's New Agenda
description: Even before the Supreme Court added two cases on physician-assisted suicide to its docket, the new term that opens on Monday was notable for the range and significance of cases already on the calendar.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Another Plan for Kings County Hospital: Dare It Succeed?
description: The plan to rebuild Kings County Hospital Center is becoming to New York what the construction of the Great Pyramids was to ancient Egypt: a legendary, long-running public works project.

title: Anchor Ousts Chief, Agrees to Sell Assets
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation has removed its chief executive and reached agreement to sell its assets to the Ball-Foster Glass Container Company.

title: Credit Offerings Expected During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, a 10-year note being auctioned Wednesday and a one-year bill to be auctioned Thursday.

title: Peace in Jerusalem Isn't Just One Side's Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: A Decorous Debate
description: The big political question about last night's Presidential debate was whether Bob Dole could use it to juice up his floundering campaign by delivering some sort of oratorical body blow to Bill Clinton. The more important question was whether the two candidates would give the public a powerful picture of what they would really do as President over the next four years. On both these counts, this was not a debate likely to last for a long time in the national memory.

title: Undecided in New Jersey
description: Many voters in New Jersey say they are unimpressed with the promise of a tax cut and are undecided about whom they will vote for in the Presidential race. Page B1.

title: Advertisers gather for their 87th annual conference to proclaim that 'brands are back.'
description: THE nation's largest advertisers, taking a cue from a venerable name-brand cereal, are focusing their 87th annual conference on the branding of champions and the championing of brands.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Wednesday about a runoff mayoral election in Florida misstated the jurisdiction in some editions. It is Dade County, not Miami.

title: Two Lives Entwined, Onstage and Off
description: ''Suzanne Farrell: Elusive Muse'' makes something that is blessedly a good deal less elusive than usual in matters concerning Suzanne Farrell, the last great inspiration for George Balanchine, who revolutionized ballet and was one of the century's certifiable geniuses. Anne Belle and Deborah Dickson, who directed the documentary, smoothly incorporate the life and art of Ms. Farrell and Balanchine, chronicling her rise to fame as a teen-age ballerina in the early 1960's with home movies and snapshots of her as a child and haunting, breathtakingly beautiful archival stills and films of her as a young performer. These alone would make ''Elusive Muse'' a must-see work for anyone interested in dance or the creative process.

title: Isles Miss Big Chance But Show Good Signs
description: Just a few more seconds and the Islanders would have accomplished their goal: a .500 West Coast road trip to open the season.

title: No Headline
description: ''Tenants of bad housing cannot function, because of the problems in their homes. Until the code enforcement system is pronounced to be in crisis, and then fixed, they will remain the ultimate victims of a poor quality of life in this city.'' ANNE PASMANICK of the Community Training and Resource Center. $(B5:1$)

title: U.S. Sentencing Due Today in 1985 Hijack
description: The F.B.I. agents assigned to apprehend a Palestinian hijacker landed secretly in Nigeria on the night of July 15, 1993. Their unmarked Gulfstream jet, its lights dimmed, stopped at a remote corner of the airfield.

title: Trade vs. Cultural Identity in Canada
description: Canada knows that by charging excise taxes of 80 percent on Canadian editions of Sports Illustrated and other American magazines, it can keep those publications off the nation's newsstands and out of its advertising market.

title: Bridge
description: For the last 30 years, two Los Angeles experts were joined in friendly rivalry for the title of America's top-ranked female player, as measured by master points. It was held for a decade by Mary Jane Farell, but she was overtaken in 1975 by Hermine Baron, who was still just ahead, with 22,645 points, when she died Sept. 27.

title: CLINTON AND DOLE, FACE TO FACE, SPAR OVER MEDICARE AND TAXES
description: President Clinton briskly defended his stewardship last night as improving the lives of ordinary Americans while Bob Dole tried to chip at his record by saying that average people had become worse off in the last four years and would prosper with Mr. Dole's proposal for a major tax cut.

title: Silicon Graphics to Unveil A New Supercomputer Line
description: Displaying evidence that their February merger is moving forward quickly, Silicon Graphics Inc. and Cray Research plan to announce on Monday the first of a new line of supercomputers intended to blend the two companies' technologies.

title: Argentine Unions Threaten Strike on Labor Law Changes
description: The rift between President Carlos Saul Menem and Argentina's labor movement -- the rank and file of his Peronist Party -- has widened with a vow by unions to stage another national strike over Mr. Menem's efforts to change labor laws.

title: All-Out Drive Courting Second-Primary Voters
description: In the last few days, Sonja Preston has received a steady stream of telephone calls and campaign literature in the mail urging her to vote in a local primary election she thought had been finished a month ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 23 about the International Monetary Fund's role in possible financial crises in developing countries misstated the opinion of the Institute of International Finance, a banking research and lobbying group. The group favors ''modest financing'' by the fund to countries in trouble; it opposes future bailouts on the scale of the I.M.F.'s rescue of the Mexican economy in 1994.

title: New Life for Ferry Terminal
description: The ferry terminal in Perth Amboy has stood, unused and rotting, for 33 years. But a complete overhaul of the 92-year-old terminal begins today -- followed soon, officials hope, by commuter ferry service to Manhattan. The $847,000 project, scheduled to be completed by next spring, is being paid for by the Federal Government. Perth Amboy's Mayor, Joseph Vas, said the work was starting not a moment too soon. ''I'm amazed the terminal is still standing,'' he said yesterday.

title: Eugene O'Neill Center May Get Remains of Tycoon Who Chased Him Off It
description: In the summer of 1914, a love-struck, 26-year-old Eugene O'Neill wrote a poem for his girlfriend, Beatrice Ashe, titled ''Upon Our Beach'' -- homage to the romantic days they spent at a secluded cove here.

title: With winter a whisper away, the question is how much vitamin C should a person take each day?
description: AN vitamin C prevent colds? Protect against cancer? Reduce the risk of Alzheimer's? If so, how much should a person take, and how often? For how long?

title: The Team Has Changed, Not La Russa's Formula
description: To Tony La Russa, the National and American Leagues taste exactly the same -- like Champagne.

title: 2 Major Marketers In Consolidations
description: Two major consumer marketers have consolidated the accounts of two well-known brands.

title: For the Confederacy's Last Widow, a First Dance With Southern Fame
description: At the end of a narrow rural lane, in a place where only chirping birds break the silence, a last fragile link to the distant American Armageddon struggled with her memory.

title: Man of Shifting Images, But a Russian Always
description: STRAVINSKY AND THE RUSSIAN TRADITIONS

title: Celebrity Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Free Agents Take a Harrowing Free Fall
description: EARLY in the third quarter, three security guards stood solemn vigil outside the Jets' locker room. Inside, Neil O'Donnell, the Jets' $25 million quarterback, sat on a training- room table with an ice pack on his right shoulder.

title: Perot Has His Say on a Familiar Stage, but Not the One He Wanted to Be On
description: Ross Perot appeared this evening not on a stage with a President, but in a studio with the television host Larry King, bashing the political system that had excluded him and warning about the corrupting influence of special interests on Washington.

title: Nantucket Officials Reject Supermarket
description: A seven-month fight over whether to allow the construction of a large supermarket complex on this island ended on Friday, when the local Planning Board voted unanimously against it.

title: New Jersey Voters: Undecided and Uninspired
description: John Sakelaris does O.K. for himself. He runs the Lyndhurst Diner, a chrome-and-glass Deco box that is THE place in town to meet and eat. Life should be cozy. Except that in the last three years, Mr. Sakelaris said, as Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has lowered state income taxes by the promised 30 percent, his local property taxes have climbed to the stratosphere like a helium balloon.

title: Jets Lose O'Donnell and Their 6th Straight Game
description: The improbable ruin of the entire Jets' off-season passing-game revision continued today when quarterback Neil O'Donnell was lost for up to six games and wide receiver Webster Slaughter was sidelined for perhaps a month.

title: Spanish Ballet With Hints of Flamenco Tradition
description: The second program presented by Ballet Ullate of Madrid, which ended its debut season at City Center yesterday, was obviously chosen for its Spanish inspiration.

title: Messier Ejected as Rangers Lose at Garden
description: When Brian Burke walked through the corridor next to the Rangers' locker room after last night's game, a technician handed him a videotape. Burke put the cassette in his duffel bag.

title: The Asian Connection
description: On April 12, 1993, Associate Attorney General Webster Hubbell received a call from the Indonesian businessman James Riady, a former client, and the Arkansas lawyer and Clinton golfing partner Mark Grobmyer. Both men had, a month before, been seen in Indonesia's East Timor, a human-rights hellhole.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: In the Heat of Debate, Political Jabs and Jokes
description: The only concession Bob Dole made to Bill Clinton tonight had a withering edge to it as he made a point of underlining his decision to address him as ''Mr. President'' in the first place.

title: Buckeyes Could Cloud Championship Picture
description: So now we know what a computer has in common with a panel of the nation's most influential college football coaches: neither can be expected to think.

title: Vincent Balletta Jr., Appellate Judge, 69
description: Vincent R. Balletta Jr., a former Associate Justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, died on Friday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 69.

title: At the new Fox News Channel, the buzzword is fairness, separating news from bias.
description: TODAY, the Fox News Channel is up and running, joining CNN, CNN Headline News and MSNBC as 24-hour-a-day cable news channels.

title: Watson Still Waits For His Vindication
description: From Baltimore to Atlanta to St. Louis, front offices are celebrating their continuing success in the 1996 baseball season. And guaranteed, if general managers like Pat Gillick, John Scheurholz and Walt Jocketty aren't being nominated for sainthood, they are at least being thought of as executives of the year.

title: The Press Cops Out
description: In early February, after I announced my ultimately unsuccessful candidacy for the House seat in the Ninth Congressional District, I was bewildered when The Charlotte Observer showed no interest in an interview. The Democratic primary, with three candidates, was the only real contest in The Observer's prime circulation area.

title: Chiropractor's Beef
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Should Protest Afghan Women's Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia Aide Sentenced
description: President Ernesto Samper's former campaign manager, Fernando Botero, has become the second campaign official to be sentenced on charges stemming from the procurement of millions of dollars in donations by leaders of the Cali cartel to insure Mr. Samper's election victory in 1994.

title: Why European Computer Makers Flop
description: When Olivetti S.p.A. announced on Thursday that it was putting its personal computer division on the block, it joined a long line of European computer makers that had dropped out in the face of strong American competition.

title: Candidates For Senate Use Truth, Of a Sort
description: Truth is to political campaigns what military music is to music: a distantly related phenomenon.

title: . . . and Steam Locomotive
description: New Jersey Transit's Main Line hasn't seen a steam locomotive for decades. But for the next three weekends, a 50-year-old locomotive will steam from Hoboken to Port Jervis, N.Y., to raise money for a state railroad museum. The 434-ton, 5,000-horsepower Chesapeake & Ohio No. 614, one of the last passenger steam locomotives produced, will haul special excursion trains, said Ross Roland, a member of the New Jersey Railroad and Transportation Museum Commission. The commission expects to recommend a site for the museum sometime this fall.

title: Voter Registration to Close
description: New Jersey residents who want to vote in the Nov. 5 election have until the end of the business day today to register. Prospective voters can sign up at their town hall or county clerk's office.

title: A Tribute to Brennan, A Justice With an Impact
description: If you doubt that producing a television documentary about a man of ideas can defeat even the worthiest intentions, tune in ''Mr. Justice Brennan,'' on PBS tonight. This one-hour tribute to the liberal Supreme Court justice who served from 1956 to 1990 seems to go on as long as he did. It's a testimonial dinner without the chicken.

title: Is That Glass Half Empty, or Half Full?
description: From the moment the red light went on last night, Bill Clinton played the optimist and Bob Dole, his Republican rival, played the pessimist.

title: Yankees Set Sights on a Familiar Foe
description: The sweaty, drenched Yankee uniforms were pressed, cleaned and hanging neatly in lockers today. Any lingering hangovers from Saturday night's celebration at their team hotel in Arlington, Tex., after winning the division series had dwindled. The Yankees had to switch their focus from exhilaration to analysis as they pondered the Baltimore Orioles and the growing possibility of showcasing themselves in the World Series.

title: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: The Braves Keep Firing On All Cylinders
description: John Smoltz poured beer down Chipper Jones's back. Ryan Klesko shook his hair soaked in suds. Had the Atlanta Braves not celebrated their three-game sweep of the Dodgers in the National League Division Series, it would have shown an underappreciation for what they had just accomplished: a record fifth straight trip to the National League Championship Series.

title: Yankee Fans And Images: Time for Test
description: THIS is a test. Or will be.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DANIEL BARENBOIM, the pianist and music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and the Berlin Staatsoper, was looking forward to a rare easy day today. He had only one engagement: to play the tango at the Argentine consulate on West 56th Street. Mr. Barenboim is part of a tango trio that recently made a record, ''Tangos Among Friends,'' released by Atlantic Classics.

title: They Have No Passports! It's O.K. They're Runners.
description: Today, just a month after Congress agreed to double the size of the Border Patrol and provide more helicopters, weapons and fortifications, one of the world's most closely guarded border crossings opened for a horde of more than a thousand dashing across from Mexico.

title: 34 Universities Agree to Set Up Another Internet
description: A group of 34 universities agreed last week to create a new national network for higher education, to be called Internet II, which will offer higher speeds and more reliable service than the current Internet.

title: Exploiting Breast Cancer Won't Cure It
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike by G.M. Auto Workers Focuses on Who Wields Power
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Canadian Automobile Workers union are engaged in a struggle over who really runs the company, which is making it difficult to find a solution to a four-day-old strike.

title: Sunset's New Face on the Tried and True
description: Rosalie Muller Wright, the new editor in chief of Sunset magazine, cheerily dismisses the notion that the changes she is making at the 98-year-old publication are any big deal. Sunset's sweeping redesign, she maintains, is largely a matter of cleaning up ''the magazine of Western living'' to make it easier for the 1.4 million people who buy it to find what they are looking for.

title: Dole's Debt to Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Ovitz's Past Haunts Disney's Future
description: The setting was a private dining room at Dreamworks on the Universal lot. At the luncheon table sat two of the most formidable power brokers in Hollywood, Michael Ovitz, president of the Walt Disney Company, and David Geffen, the billionaire mogul and a founding partner at Dreamworks.

title: Don't Mow the Rare Flower
description: The Pine Barrens gentian, a tiny, five-petaled indigo flower, is a Federally endangered species. And there is only one place in New Jersey where it can be seen without going on a long hike: along Dover Road in Lacey Township. But for years, Ocean County road crews have mowed the gentian down as part of their routine maintenance. This year, however, under pressure from the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, the county agreed not to cut the grass where the gentian grows. And now, at the height of its blooming season, the little flower is flourishing. ''There must be 800 of them along both sides of the road,'' said Theresa Lettman, project manager for the alliance. ''With all the rain this summer and the county not mowing the area, it must have been perfect for them.'' ANDY NEWMAN

title: Seeking Surfers and Saving Souls
description: The marriage of evangelical Christianity and cyberspace is updating the goal of Martin Luther's Protestant Reformation -- to make every man a priest -- by making every priest a potential publisher.

title: INSIDE
description: No. 1 for Woods

title: First Debate Fails to Deliver a 'Memorable Moment'
description: So what moment of last night's debate will serve, in campaign seasons to come, to demonstrate (as commentators on all channels have been telling viewers for a week or more) that what counts is the memorable moment?

title: More Bills on Sex Offenders
description: The state prison for sex offenders at Avenel is becoming an increasingly popular target for politicians. Last month, two lawmakers proposed a statewide referendum on whether to close the prison. Today, an Assembly committee will consider two more bills. One would transfer inmates at the Adult Diagnostic and Treatment Center to state prisons if they refuse to undergo treatment for their sexual disorders. The other measure being considered by the Law and Public Safety Committee would prohibit Avenel inmates from possessing pornography. A state panel found last year that child molesters at Avenel were allowed to keep pornography because counselors felt it would encourage their sexual interest in adults, said Jennifer Beck, an aide to one of the bill's sponsors, Assemblyman Joseph Azzolina, Republican of Middletown.

title: I.E.S. Edwards, 87, Noted Expert On Treasures of Tutankhamun
description: I. E. S. Edwards, a British expert on the treasures from the tomb of Tutankhamun, the ancient Egyptian king, died on Sept. 24 in London. He was 87 and lived in Deddington, near Oxford.

title: Colts Rally, But Lose To Bills In Overtime
description: The Indianapolis Colts have made the comeback part of their strategy, so there was no surprise today when they spotted the Buffalo Bills a 10-0 lead and then came roaring back in the second half with 13 unanswered points to go up by 13-10 midway through the fourth quarter.

title: After Busy Weekend, Pope Enters Hospital for Surgery
description: After a weekend packed with ceremonies, audiences and public appearances at which he appeared in relatively good health, Pope John Paul II entered a Rome hospital tonight to undergo surgery for what his doctors say is an inflamed appendix.

title: Untapped Power
description: I once asked a Democratic politician in New York why the Democrats didn't make an all-out push to increase the voter registration rolls, since it seemed apparent that a large majority of the new voters would vote for candidates of his party.

title: Pitney Bowes Is Marketing A Digital Copier by Minolta
description: Pitney Bowes Inc. will introduce a line of digital copiers tomorrow that are made by Minolta but carry the Pitney Bowes name.

title: Sides Negotiating In Ex-Officer's Case
description: Manhattan prosecutors have been negotiating a plea agreement to settle sexual assault charges against Desmond Robinson, the former transit officer who was shot by a colleague while working undercover.

title: For Mexicans In Edgy Area, Quiet Election
description: The state of Guerrero, one of Mexico's most violent and backward, held relatively peaceful and orderly elections today.

title: Gay Issues Return in Rematch for Senate Seat
description: Just as he did six years ago, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina has mounted an advertising blitz this week that attempts to link his opponent, former Mayor Harvey Gantt of Charlotte, to a variety of homosexual causes.

title: Unmanaged-Care Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The New York Stock Exchange tables in Business Day on Saturday and in Money and Business yesterday, as well as the listing of the week's most active Big Board stocks yesterday, misstated Friday's closing price and the daily and weekly change for the stock of Chrysler. It closed at $30 on Friday, up 25 cents from Thursday and up $1.875 from the previous Friday; it did not close at $26.875.

title: Nasty Little Gang of Boys In the Low Life of Taipei
description: ''There are two types of people, crooks and dopes,'' sneers Red Fish (Congsheng Tang), a teen-aged Taipeian wheeler-dealer whose corrupt, formerly wealthy father has gone into hiding after declaring bankruptcy. Red Fish is the soul, if you can call it that, of ''Mahjong,'' the Taiwanese film maker Edward Yang's frantically scribbled hate letter to the boom town in which he grew up.

title: Malaysia Readies a Crackdown on Illegal Workers
description: KUALA LUMPUR  A decade of rapid economic growth has provided abundant jobs and rising living standards in Malaysia, but it has also created for some an unwelcome side-effect: a flood of illegal migrants smuggled in by land and sea, mainly from Bangladesh and Indonesia.

title: Skip Away and Cigar Still Spirited After Duel
description: Both Cigar and Skip Away, the 3-year-old colt who beat him by a head in the Jockey Club Gold Cup, were healthy and frisky yesterday on the morning after their duel at Belmont Park. But the issue of a return match in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic in three weeks was still unresolved because, Sonny Hine said, ''I don't know if it's worth putting up $480,000 to try to beat Cigar again.''

title: Two Upstart Networks Courting Black Viewers
description: When the two would-be television networks, UPN and WB, announced their new prime-time schedules last spring, one trend was impossible to miss. In seeking to build a base of viewing that would make them at least somewhat competitive with the four established broadcast networks, both UPN and WB were relying heavily on comedies with black casts.

title: The End of Special Education?
description: School boards from Maine to California cringe at the mention of Shannon Carter, the learning-impaired ninth grader who won a momentous Supreme Court victory three years ago. Dissatisfied with Shannon's education in the Florence County, South Carolina, public schools, her parents placed her in a private academy -- then sued the county for tuition. The Court ruled for the Carters, saying the county had failed to provide an ''appropriate public education,'' as required by the Federal Individuals With Disabilities Education Act. Earlier rulings allowed reimbursement for private schools approved by the state; the Carter decision expanded the list to any and all schools that might be appropriate to the child's disability. The county paid up. Then came the deluge.

title: A New Newsroom Contract
description: After four years of negotiations, the state's last remaining unionized newspaper finally has a contract. Staff members at The Jersey Journal ratified an eight-year pact on Saturday with Advance Publications, the newspaper arm of the Newhouse publishing empire.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Gangs Descend, to Pick Bosnia's Carcass Clean
description: Even during the three and a half years of war, Vraca Park was the meeting place for heroin addicts in Sarajevo who shared needles and collective stupors that, at times, must have seemed attractive to even this city's most sober citizens.

title: Kenneth Muir Is Dead at 89; British Expert on Shakespeare
description: Prof. Kenneth Muir, a British authority on Shakespeare and his world, died on Sept. 30 in Birkenhead, England, where he lived. He was 89.

title: As Consumer Electronics Evolve, Can Japan Rule?
description: Hiroki Shimizu calls it the ''data refrigerator.'' The Victor Company of Japan plans to sell next year a digital version of the VHS videocassette recorder that can store as many as two dozen movies, or a year's worth of ''E.R.'' episodes, on a single tape.

title: A Final Fumble Costs Kansas City
description: When the Chiefs and Steelers clashed here tonight there was the feeling from the start that the game game would swing on a turnover. Both teams preach getting the turnover. It is the foundation of both.

title: SINTER TO ACQUIRE PRESSED POWDER UNITS
description: Sinter Metals Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Maag Holding A.G.'s United States and European precision pressed powder metal units for about $215 million. Sinter said the acquisition of Maag's United States unit, Powder Metal Holding Inc., and its German unit, Krebsoge Sinterholding G.m.b.H., would make Sinter the largest supplier of precision pressed powder metal components in the world, with expected 1997 sales of $400 million. Sinter's stock rose $1.625, to $23.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The acquisitions would add 11 production plants to Sinter's seven plants, the company said.

title: From Checketts's Corner, No Predictions on Knicks
description: Having watched the Rangers struggle over the weekend and knowing what he knows about sports and business, Dave Checketts understands that money does not buy championships. His annual visit to the Knicks' training camp today confirmed the theory. Checketts has every reason to like this team a lot, but like everyone else, he will wait and see. Which means no grandiose predictions in October about a title.

title: America Is Again Trampling on Its Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: How Allen Ginsberg Thinks His Thoughts
description: Sometimes the poet Allen Ginsberg still fantasizes about his old Columbia College friend Norman Podhoretz, who became the conservative editor of Commentary magazine. In Mr. Ginsberg's fantasies, Mr. Ginsberg is yelling at Mr. Podhoretz that the C.I.A. is selling drugs in Los Angeles and yelling that Mr. Ginsberg's epic poem ''Howl'' cannot be read on the radio during most daylight hours because of Federal limitations on obscenity. And he is warring with Mr. Podhoretz, who once called beat poets like Mr. Ginsberg ''know-nothing bohemians,'' about the very nature of poetry itself.

title: Forrest C. Pogue, 84; Wrote an Epic Study Of General Marshall
description: Forrest Carlisle Pogue, a historian and the author of a monumental four-volume biography of George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff in World War II and later Secretary of State, died on Sunday at Murray-Calloway County Hospital in Murray, Ky. He was 84 and lived in Murray.

title: Off Broadway's Circle Rep Posts Its Closing Notice
description: Faced with a large debt and little hope of financial assistance, the Circle Repertory Theater, a mainstay of Off Broadway for 28 years, announced yesterday that it had gone out of business.

title: Democrats by Default
description: Two or three times a week during the early 1900's, as the latest steamship reached Baltimore with its cargo of Polish immigrants, a laborer named Aleksander Obrycki sprung into his personal ritual of welcome. Newly naturalized himself, he met the latest arrivals at the dockside, guided them to the Polish enclave of Fells Point and began instruction in the glories of democracy.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Temple

title: In Spin Wars After the Debate, Clinton Campaign Takes Lead
description: It was not the grove of little red signs, perched at the ends of sticks to mark and identify each Clinton spokesman for reporters swarming for comment when the Presidential debate ended here Sunday night.

title: Acquisition in Vision Care
description: TLC The Laser Center Inc. said today that it intended to buy 20/20 Laser Centers Inc. for about $33 million. TLC said 20/20, based in Bethesda, Md., operates nine laser centers in the Northeast and Florida. TLC, a Toronto-based operator of vision-care clinics, said that with the addition of 20/20's centers, it expects to have 36 clinics operating by the end of 1997, covering 23 states and three Canadian provinces. TLC said 20/20's revenues are expected to be $7.5 million in 1996.

title: U.S. FILTER TO BUY MAKER OF WATER TREATMENT EQUIPMENT
description: The United States Filter Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire United Utilities P.L.C.'s processing equipment division for $195 million. The unit, which makes water treatment equipment, had revenue of about $270 million for the year that ended on March 31. The division has 13 operating units in Britain, the United States, Germany, Canada, Mexico, Brazil and Australia. Shares of United States Filter, a provider of industrial water treatment systems based in Palm Desert, Calif., were up $1.50, at $34, on the New York Stock Exchange. United Utilities is a British water and electricity utility.

title: Judge Assails but Acquits Officer In Man's Choking Death in Bronx
description: A Bronx judge yesterday acquitted a police officer in the choking death of a man during a confrontation over a late-night football game, even as he assailed the officer's behavior and said he had failed his ''sworn responsibility to be a peacemaker as well as a peacekeeper.''

title: Netanyahu Hints at Delay in Further Pullbacks After Hebron Move
description: As Israelis and Palestinians opened urgent talks on the long-delayed redeployment of Israeli troops in Hebron, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced today that once this issue was resolved, he hoped to move directly to negotiations on a final settlement with the Palestinians.

title: Quakers and the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: British Factory Output Falls Unexpectedly
