description: British manufacturing output fell unexpectedly in August, the Government reported yesterday, casting fresh doubt on the strength of the nation's economic recovery. Manufacturing output fell three-tenths of 1 percent in August from July and stood nine-tenths of 1 percent below its level in August 1995, the Office for National Statistics said. Economists had forecast an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Accounts
description: Maximizer Technologies Inc., Vancouver, British Columbia, to Rizzuti, Beckman & Lyman, Dallas, to handle the account of the developer of sales force automation software, which had been handled by Evans Group, Seattle. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: 1,096 Mammal and 1,108 Bird Species Threatened
description: SINCE 1960, when it started a card file on 34 rare animals, the Species Survival Commission of the World Conservation Union has kept a rapidly growing list of threatened wildlife on every continent. The Red List, as it became known to conservationists, was updated last week using revised criteria for determining the risk of extinction, and the news is grim: 1,096 mammals, nearly one-fourth of all known species, are considered threatened, as are 1,108 birds, more than 11 percent of the world's bird species.

title: INSIDE
description: Corruption in South Africa

title: Uecker Didn't Exactly Win an Emmy as a Player
description: Some announcers who will call the League Championship Series for NBC and Fox have interesting connections: Fox's Tim McCarver played for the Cardinals and called L.C.S. and World Series games in 1990 and 1991 with Jack Buck, the father of Joe, one of his Fox boothmates. ''It's hard to believe Joe is just 27,'' McCarver said. ''It seems like he's more like 50.''

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Oklahoma

title: The Campaign That Forgot A Whole City
description: THANK goodness for television (not something you hear every day from a newspaper). Thank goodness because until the candidates held their televised debate on Sunday night, the Presidential campaign was mostly a rumor as far as New York City is concerned.

title: Lousiana-Pacific Sets Income Charge
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said today that it would take a $215 million charge against third-quarter earnings to cover expected costs for shutting some of its plants and settling lawsuits. The charge will reduce Louisiana-Pacific's per-share earnings by $2 a share and will result in a loss for the quarter.

title: Muster Will Not Face Davis Cup Suspension
description: THOMAS MUSTER avoided a suspension over his Davis Cup walkout when the International Tennis Federation decided yesterday in London that the $8,000 fine it had already imposed was enough punishment.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: After Nips And Tucks, What Is 'Roseanne'?
description: For the last few years the sitcom ''Roseanne'' and the star Roseanne have been dancing around a tricky question, How can a rich, powerful, surgically revamped Hollywood star remain a working-class heroine? This season the show is confronting that question with a plot twist that might be the smartest, or the worst, thing the show ever did. The fictional Conner family won the lottery, $108 million worth. Roseanne Conner had a fast, tongue-in-cheek plan for spending the cash. ''I'm getting me a ton of plastic surgery,'' she said.

title: Benoit's Status Unclear
description: The ankle injury the Nets' DAVID BENOIT sustained in practice Thursday could be more serious than it first appeared. Benoit left the Nets in Tampa, Fla., and flew back to New York after a magnetic resonance imaging exam yesterday. The Nets' team doctor will examine Benoit to determine the damage to his Achilles' tendon.

title: Buckling Up With Chic
description: The belt is always with us, to hold up pants if for nothing else. But it's also being used now to give a new look to jackets and to cinch long skinny sweaters even closer to the body.

title: Accuser's Therapy Records Sought in Rape Case
description: Defense lawyers for a man accused of raping a teen-age girl in 1986 are demanding that a psychological counselor turn over the therapy records of his accuser.

title: Art Bending the Tyranny of Reality
description: Ambiguity can be irritating and even dangerous in the real world, but in art it is often the force that keeps a work lingering in the memory while the mind puzzles over the possibilities. Benjamin Britten recognized this and filled his operas with relationships that are never fully explained and are open to a breadth of interpretations.

title: Investment 'Vulture' Leaves Blackstone
description: Mikael Salovaara, a well-known ''vulture'' investor whose feuds with business associates have led to accusations that he engineered a sham transaction to further a pending lawsuit, has resigned from Blackstone Group, the merchant bank and advisory firm led by a former Commerce Secretary, Peter G. Peterson.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Not Much in Common But the Desire to Win
description: ''Frontline'' begins its new season with a two-hour look at what makes Bob Dole different from Bill Clinton or vice versa. Relying on biographers, journalists, acquaintances and even cartoonists, ''Choice '96'' traces the men's contrasting public personas to their hometowns, their religions, their war or antiwar experience, their mentors and their defeats. It turns out they have almost nothing in common except for the not uncommon ailment of craving to win.

title: Rolls-Royce to Sell A Canadian Unit
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said yesterday that it planned to sell Bristol Aerospace, a Canadian aircraft-maintenance company and engine maker that employs 960 people.

title: Dole Stumps in New Jersey
description: With the first debate behind him, Bob Dole went back to the campaign trail yesterday, rolling across New Jersey on his first bus tour. ''This is a great way to start the post-debate effort,'' he said at a high school rally in Toms River during the first of four quick stops across the state.

title: Consumers' Borrowing Slows Sharply
description: Consumer borrowing grew at a much slower pace than expected, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Perot Demands That Clinton Unequivocally Rule Out Pardons
description: After a month and half of sounding the alarm about the Federal debt and other issues, Ross Perot today sharply attacked President Clinton, asserting that he should unequivocally rule out Presidential pardons for associates who are in jail for Whitewater-related crimes.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM EXPECTS LOSS FOR THE REST OF THE YEAR
description: Hammered by sagging prices, the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation said yesterday that it expected to post a loss for the rest of the year. Analysts have expected major aluminum makers to post lower earnings because of weaker prices. Aluminum dropped 22 percent, to 65 cents a pound in the quarter from 83 cents a year earlier, because of sluggish demand and rising inventories. Kaiser, based in Houston, said it would lose about 14 cents to 20 cents a share for the quarter, compared with a profit of 14 cents a share in the corresponding period a year earlier. The company also expects to report a loss for the fourth quarter that would substantially exceed the loss in the third quarter. Kaiser's stock fell 87.5 cents a share yesterday, to $10.625.

title: 12 Witnesses to History at Its Most Frightening
description: ''Emigration, N.Y.,'' Egon Humer's absorbing three-hour documentary about the flight of Austrian Jews to New York in the face of Nazism, tells a painfully familiar story of persecution, escape and survival. Maybe familiar isn't the right word, since every Holocaust survivor's recollection has its own searing personal resonance. No matter how many horrifying testaments one hears, they never lose their power to stun us with a picture of humanity at its fiendish worst.

title: League Reviewing Messier's Hard Hit
description: The Mark Messier matter remains under review by the National Hockey League, and a decision on a possible suspension is expected to be announced before tonight's Rangers-Panthers game in Miami.

title: Figures Sculptured in Stone and Clay
description: Trisha Brown is not a choreographer who invites viewers to sit back and let the dancing wash over them. ''Newark'' and ''For M.G.: The Movie,'' two works on the program that closed her company's season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday, require keen looking.

title: Pettitte Gets First Shot at Clipping Orioles' Wings
description: Andy Pettitte gazed at the row of million-dollar pitchers he was lodged among during spring training in Tampa, Fla., and spoke with reverence. There were David Cone, Kenny Rogers, Jimmy Key, Dwight Gooden and Melido Perez lined up locker by locker, and Pettitte sheepishly placed himself on the bottom of the list. He talked about himself like a bat boy who had wandered into the wrong section of the clubhouse.

title: Caught With the Grease
description: I had just finished a plate of bacon and eggs sunny side up. It tasted so good that I decided to fry up a little scrapple. Treat myself to sort of a breakfast dessert, as it were.

title: PACCAR BUYING DUTCH TRUCK MAKER FOR $543 MILLION
description: Paccar Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., said yesterday that it planned to buy the Dutch truck maker DAF Trucks N.V. for 933 million guilders, or $543 million. DAF Trucks had 1995 sales of $1.7 billion and 5,000 employees. The deal also includes a 25 percent stake in the Belgian-based company DAF Trucks Vlaanderen N.V. Paccar makes heavy-duty trucks under the names Kenworth, Peterbilt and Foden. It had 1995 sales of $4.6 billion and profits of $253 million.

title: Isle Furor Stirs Chinese Nationalism in Hong Kong
description: A wave of emotional, and sometimes fevered, Chinese nationalism is washing over Hong Kong, a surge of patriotism that has found a focus in Japanese claims to a sprinkling of islands near Taiwan and the drowning of a local man trying to reclaim those islands for a China to which this British colony does not yet belong.

title: Italy Plans to Sell More Shares of ENI
description: The Italian Treasury's director general, Mario Draghi, said yesterday that the Government would sell an additional 10 percent of ENI S.p.A., the state-controlled energy company. It will sell 700 million shares, or 8.75 percent, and an additional 105 million shares, or 1.25 percent, if there is enough demand.

title: As Shares Slip, So Do Phone Deals' Worth
description: ''Cash is king,'' Robert Maxwell used to say. And although the late British media mogul did not heed his own words in making deals, his motto is timely for today's frenzied deal-makers.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on Saturday, about the closing of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the sale of Denver International Airport bonds, misspelled the surname of the director of the commission's municipal securities division. He is Paul S. Maco, not Meco.

title: Army School Abets Violence Against the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Game Film Too Ugly For the Jets To Watch
description: The videotape would merely replay the obvious. So when the Jets walked in today to sit down as a team and watch Sunday's debacle against the Raiders, Coach Rich Kotite told them to go home.

title: 2 Mitsui Companies In Chemicals to Merge
description: Two major chemical makers from the Mitsui industrial group of Japan said yesterday that they would merge next Oct. 1 as they try to cope with declining profits in the struggling Japanese chemical industry. Mitsui Toatsu Chemicals Inc. and Mitsui Petrochemical Industries Ltd. will become Mitsui Chemicals Inc., Japan's second-largest producer, with sales of more than 700 billion yen ($6.4 billion).

title: HFS to Buy Biggest Time-Share Company for $625 Million
description: HFS Inc. has agreed to buy Resort Condominiums International for about $625 million, giving it ownership of a company with about a 70 percent share of a business that markets time-share resort properties.

title: PHYSICIANS RESOURCE BUYING 2 LARGEST RIVALS
description: Physicians Resource Group Inc. of Dallas said yesterday that it would buy its two largest rivals -- American Ophthalmic Inc. and the eye care division of Equimed Inc. -- for a combined $124 million. The moves would give Physicians Resources 136 doctor practices and 44 ambulatory surgery centers under management, with annual revenue of about $378 million. The company's stock was up $1.75, at $23.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Physicians Resource expected to pay $54 million for Equimed's eye care division. Physicians Resource planned to buy privately held American Ophthalmic, based in Winter Park, Fla., for about $70 million, including $35 million of cash and about 1.5 million shares.

title: Justices Skeptically Review Law Requiring Cable Systems to Carry Broadcast Stations
description: The Federal Government's defense of a law requiring cable-television systems to carry the signals of most broadcast stations found a skeptical audience at the Supreme Court today as the Justices, formally opening their new term, questioned whether the law violates the free-speech rights of cable systems.

title: 3 Oil Giants Discuss Union Of Operations
description: Three major oil companies are negotiating an alliance to combine $10 billion in refining and marketing operations that would include more than 22,000 gasoline stations, and account for about 15 percent of the market of petroleum products in the nation.

title: Recycler Purchase Studied
description: Schnitzer Steel Industries said today that Federal regulators had asked for more data on its plan to buy the Proler International Corporation of Houston. Schnitzer is a scrap recycler and Proler is in environmental services.

title: Farm Labor's Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: With Mixed Feelings, Iran Tiptoes to the Internet
description: In a special office where Iranian computer experts are devising just how much access their compatriots should have to the Internet, English words scrawled in felt pen fill a large white bulletin board across one wall.

title: U.S. Agrees With Norway To Aid Russia In Atom Plan
description: The United States and Norway have agreed to provide technical aid and financing to help Russia dispose of nuclear submarine reactors and other radioactive waste that was dumped in the Barents and Kara Seas by the Soviet Union.

title: 2 Get Nobel for Work On Immune Response
description: THE 1996 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded yesterday to two scientists who discovered how the immune system recognizes cells that are infected with viruses.

title: Johnson Has to Admit He's Glad to Be Here
description: Davey Johnson began answering the question he thought he had been asked.

title: Loss at Advanced Micro Smaller Than Expected
description: The results were reported after the stock market closed. But in after-hours trading, shares of Advanced Micro surged 87.5 cents to $15.75.

title: In Sterling Forest, Joy at Sparing of Trees
description: The shimmering lakes in this sprawling woodland are crystalline. Towering maples and oaks bow along winding roads, forming a trellis of magenta and ocher leaves. In warmer weather, locals say, all that can be heard is the chatter of crickets, but today the dominant sound is the whisper of trees.

title: Who You Are: Sometimes It's Clear, Sometimes Not
description: When we are gone, what remains of us? Who then is the custodian of our presence on earth?

title: City Hall Sees Cable Battle By TV Titans
description: In an unusual venting of vitriol between two media giants, Time Warner and the News Corporation took their long-running feud to City Hall yesterday, lambasting each other before a panel that is reviewing whether Time Warner should be allowed to keep its valuable cable franchises in New York City.

title: New York City Works Against Itself on Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: When Designers Take Cues From Art
description: As the stone-faced front row in Milan registers the next ruffle, near the exposed nipple, beneath the sheer pastel fabric of the fishtail dress, there is no visible effect. Unlike dramatic, creative moments on runways that earn applause or the rare twitching smile, the effect of banality on the stone faces is not apparent to the naked eye. It happens purely on the inside of the audience: a little bit of interest, a little faith and a little belief in fashion dies.

title: Those Unsung, Busy or Flexible
description: Andy Bey's 'Ballads'

title: Trump Sells Hyatt Share To Pritzkers
description: Donald J. Trump sold his half interest in the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York to the Pritzker family's Hyatt Corporation yesterday for $140 million, bringing to an end an often rancorous, 17-year partnership in a landmark property that marked the developer's rise to prominence.

title: Cold Northeast Weather Spurs Rise in Prices for Heating Oil
description: Heating oil prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as cold weather in the Northeast bolstered demand at a time of lean inventories.

title: Two Girls, 16, Are Slain After House-Sitting in Finger Lakes Region
description: Two high school cheerleaders were slain after house-sitting overnight on Thursday at the home of one of the girls in the Finger Lakes hamlet of McLean, N.Y., the state police said yesterday.

title: 2 Blasts on British Army Base in Ulster Hurt 23 and Cloud Talks
description: Two explosions on a British Army base in Northern Ireland wounded 20 soldiers and 3 civilians today, further damaging the already floundering peace effort in the British province.

title: Childs, Johnson Already Ailing
description: Jeff Van Gundy said he was not concerned. Still, two of his new Knicks are slightly ailing after only four days of training camp.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Kashmir Still Awaits Free and Fair Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Just Shabby and Dismal, Illegal Apartments Can Kill
description: For $400 a month, Renee Oates got a window tickled by the leaves of a plane tree and wall-to-wall carpeting, albeit worn and rust-colored. She got smooth white walls and a lock on her door that worked.

title: Juvenile Penguins Go Beyond Safe Area
description: USING satellite telemetry, scientists have tracked juvenile emperor penguins from their natal colony at the Ross Sea in Antarctica to distant ice-free waters in the Southern Ocean, outside the area where they are protected under international agreements.

title: South Africa Scandal Over 'Sarafina' Spotlights Corruption in the A.N.C.
description: For a while, Sarafina was back. She was no longer that spunky Soweto schoolgirl fighting the injustices of apartheid in a hit Broadway show. She was all grown up -- a social worker teaching the dangers of unsafe sex in a lavish musical that was supposed to tour South Africa to carry the anti-AIDS message to the illiterate.

title: A 'Swan Lake' With Male Swans Is a Hit in London
description: When it opened at Sadler's Wells last year, Matthew Bourne's provocative version of the most classic of classic ballets was immediately labeled the ''gay Swan Lake.'' It was not surprising: Mr. Bourne's swans were not dainty dancers in tutus, but fierce, bare-chested men in feathery pantaloons.

title: Herbert M. Singer, 89, Dies; Lawyer and Philanthropist
description: Herbert M. Singer, a lawyer and philanthropist who supported community and medical causes in New York over 40 years, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Flirts With 6,000, And Nasdaq Sets a Record

title: Chess
description: A 13-year-old French boy, Etienne Bacrot, decisively defeated the 75-year-old former world champion Vasily Smyslov in a six-game exhibition match in Albert, France. Remarkably, Barcrot won four games, drew two and lost none in the confrontation, which was held Sept. 5 to 10.

title: Suddenly, the Giants Are Optimists
description: When Philadelphia quarterback Rodney Peete went down against Dallas last week and was lost for the season, what do you think was the reaction of the Giants? Probably a moment of silence for Peete, followed by several moments of excitement. A team that looked completely out of it a few weeks ago was suddenly back in the division race.

title: Internet Gets Voters Closer to Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Was Character?
description: Bob Dole entered Sunday's Presidential debate with two political handicaps. He emerged with three.

title: The Blues, Burnished By the Years
description: From suave flirtations to bitter breakups, Joe Williams is summoning the delights and pains of love in his monthlong engagement at Rainbow and Stars.

title: Missing 5% Of Flight 800 Is Held Crucial
description: While divers have recovered all but 5 percent of the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 from the Atlantic Ocean, senior law enforcement investigators say that many of the missing pieces are from an area of the Boeing 747 that could tell them whether the cause of the crash was sabotage or a mechanical failure.

title: Basic Research Is Losing Out As Companies Stress Results
description: When Greg E. Blonder joined Bell Laboratories in 1982 as a physicist just out of Harvard, no one said a word about products or selling. ''They asked their usual job interview question,'' he said. '' 'What would I work on if I had an empty room and an unlimited amount of money?' '' He spent his time measuring the behavior of electrons at 1 degree above absolute zero, which is very cold. ''Not many products exist in that situation,'' he conceded.

title: Will Reggie Join Yogi's Boycott?
description: GEORGE STEINBRENNER, who too often thinks he is a Yankee icon, seems to find a way to alienate real Yankee icons.

title: Clinton Shows That He, Too, Has Support Of Executives
description: Relaxed and folksy on the day after the first Presidential debate of the campaign, President Clinton today showcased his support from business executives and then barnstormed through New England to lure Northeastern Republican moderates to his side.

title: Devils Miss Their Leader in Lackluster Game
description: The Devils and the Flyers played tonight without their captains and spiritual leaders, and the game lacked the intensity, tension and aggression it usually has with Scott Stevens matched against Eric Lindros.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The proceedings were becoming awfully solemn the other night at a party at the United Nations celebrating the 1,100th anniversary of the establishment of Hungary. EVA FORSYTH decided she had to do something. She is a Hungarian-born bridal-dress designer and manufacturer and one of 10 people who were being honored by the American Council of the World Federation of Hungarians, which gave the dinner.

title: The Missing Sermon on Taxes
description: Publicly and privately, Bob Dole has been getting the same advice over and over from Republicans such as House Speaker Newt Gingrich, former Vice President Dan Quayle and, most likely, from his own running mate, Jack Kemp. Their message is simply that if you are going to run on a tax cut, then get on that issue and stay on it. They want Mr. Dole to hammer voters incessantly with the message that President Dole will swell their wallets.

title: Patterns
description: Loehmann's Discretion

title: Profit Taking Pushes Bond Prices Down
description: Treasury prices retreated yesterday as investors moved to consolidate recent gains, particularly those made on Friday following an employment report that showed unexpected weakness.

title: Taking a Deep Breath, for 'Traviata'
description: What Franco Zeffirelli's grandiose productions at the Met need for sure is big performances to fill them. Alas, few of those were forthcoming when Mr. Zeffirelli's 1989 staging of Verdi's ''Traviata'' returned on Wednesday evening after a three-year absence.

title: Drug Substitutions Add to Discord Over Managed Care
description: When Tony Catizone, 66, tried a widely used blood pressure drug, the result was disaster: His pressure soared and he had a stroke. Yet after a hospital doctor prescribed a newer drug that kept his pressure at safe levels, his mail order pharmacy, to save 30 cents a day, switched the retired Chicago city worker back to the first medication without telling the doctor.

title: Afghans Draw U.N. Warning Over Sex Bias
description: In an unusual step for an organization that often tries to avoid collisions over human rights, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali warned the new Islamic rulers in Afghanistan today that the United Nations objects to the extreme discrimination they practice against women. He warned of ''serious repercussions'' for the foreign aid programs there.

title: Accused Pleads for Bail
description: A Russian immigrant accused in the killing and dismemberment of her husband issued an emotional plea on Monday to be freed on bail, swearing she would not try to escape.

title: No Excuses From an Injured O'Neill
description: Paul O'Neill has a chronic pain that shoots through his left hamstring whenever he tries to push off and swing and whenever he pursues a fly ball. While O'Neill refuses to use the injury as an excuse, it has sapped his productivity and turned him into the player most likely to be benched in the American League Championship Series.

title: Ortega Deserves Victory in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''We are eating our seed corn. If this continues, we will no longer be the nation that is on the cutting edge of new technologies, new products and new markets. For the moment, we still are, but that can't last.''

title: Martha Stewart and Philip Dusenberry have the same advice: It's all about making a compact.
description: ALTHOUGH the Contract With America may have hurt the Republican Party's chances in the coming election, the nation's largest advertisers were urged yesterday by a taste-making entrepreneur and a top advertising agency executive to enter into contracts with consumers.

title: TI of Britain Bids For Forsheda of Sweden
description: The TI Group, an auto- and aircraft-parts maker, said yesterday that it had offered $:189 million ($298 million) for Forsheda A.B., a Swedish maker of sealing systems and industrial products. Forsheda's largest shareholder, Agora Holding A.B., said it would accept. Agora controls 63.6 percent of the Forsheda voting rights and 20.6 percent of the capital.

title: Terrorist Sentenced to Life in Prison for Deadly 1985 Hijacking
description: A Federal judge today sentenced a Lebanese-born Palestinian to life in prison for the deadly 1985 hijacking of an Egypt Air flight from Athens to Cairo in which 60 people were killed.

title: 2 Countries, 2 Auto Unions, 2 Contrasting Styles of Bargaining
description: Basil E. Hargrove, the president of the Canadian Automobile Workers union, shook his fist and bellowed at a meeting last Friday in Toronto with several hundred cheering union officials, describing all the disputes that had led to the current strike against General Motors. He wore a dark blue wool suit with a denim shirt and a deep blue tie covered with dice, playing cards and even a slot machine.

title: Corsicans Say They Set Bomb In Bordeaux
description: A militant Corsican separatist group that broke off secret talks with the French Government in August said today that it was responsible for a dynamite bomb Saturday night that damaged the city hall in Bordeaux, where Prime Minister Alain Juppe is Mayor.

title: Crime or Error in Judgment? A Homicide Charge That's Tough to Call
description: Criminally negligent homicide -- the least serious of criminal charges involving a person's death -- is an elusive and ambiguous concept that has often left juries perplexed and appellate judges divided.

title: Saving New York Harbor
description: Yesterday's agreement between the Governors of New York and New Jersey to clear the shipping channels in New York Harbor is of great importance to the regional economy. The agreement is only a first step in a huge undertaking. But it starts a process that could preserve the local maritime industry, which provides the area with $20 billion in annual revenue and nearly 170,000 jobs.

title: A Killer Is Killed. Is Talk Radio to Blame?
description: For 14 years, the murder of 5-year-old Ursula Assaid at the hands of her mother's boyfriend has haunted central Florida.

title: Behind a Suburban Facade in Queens, A Teeming, Angry Urban Arithmetic
description: By day, the neighborhood holds its secret close, presenting the same front it has for decades: tidy parallel lines of two- and three-story houses with tiny but verdant front lawns and a sliver of driveway space between them.

title: Exploring Undersea Birth Throes of a New Hawaiian Island
description: RISING from deep within the earth is a jet of molten rock that cuts gargantuan holes in the Pacific seabed, forming new volcanoes and eventually whole new islands as well, its brood including Maui and Oahu. Each year, the jet, the earth's most intense, spews enough lava to build a road that would circle the earth twice. It has been thundering and exploding and erupting lava for tens of millions of years.

title: HEARTPORT SHARES SURGE ON NEWS OF F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: Heartport Inc. of Redwood City, Calif., said yesterday that it had won the right to market its minimally invasive heart surgery systems in the United States, sending its shares surging. The Food and Drug Administration cleared Heartport's endovascular cardiopulmonary bypass system and key components of its port-access systems. The systems allow doctors to perform heart surgery with only a few cuts between the ribs instead of having to crack open the chest, the company said. The company's shares rose $6.75, or 23 percent, to $36.50, in trading of more than 1.5 million shares.

title: 2 L.I. Makers Of Software Plan to Merge For $1.2 Billion
description: Computer Associates International Inc., one of the world's largest software companies, continued its buying spree yesterday with a $1.2 billion cash bid for Cheyenne Software Inc., a maker of mass storage software for business computers.

title: Guilty Plea in Fatal Shooting
description: A motorcycle gang member told a judge yesterday that he wanted to plead guilty in the fatal shooting of a Gloucester County police sergeant. Judge Joseph Lisa of the Superior Court told the defendant, Robert Simon, that the plea would be accepted today if Mr. Simon still wanted to enter it, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Cooperative Jam, and Then a Song
description: Moe's three-hour set at the Supper Club on Thursday night started with delicate brilliance. Chris Mazur played pattering cymbals; Rob Derhak added a rising bass line, and Al Schnier and Chuck Garvey layered on guitar parts: pealing short phrases, long melodic lines, tremolo notes and then strummed chords. The music arose out of a cooperative impulse; a song would arrive later.

title: In Debate's Aftermath, Coffee and No Surprises
description: Perhaps the first debate of this Presidential campaign will change the minds of some voters, but if that is the case, it was awfully hard to find any evidence of it here, whether you were looking at the oldest newsstand downtown or the just-opened Borders in The Strip, a suburban shopping complex so new, trucks are still busy spraying the dirt green.

title: 3 Cheers for Collins (and Michigan)!
description: Colts quarterback Jim Harbaugh said he heard the quips on the football pre-game shows about how two Michigan quarterbacks -- Harbaugh and Bills quarterback Todd Collins -- would face off in the Indianapolis-Buffalo game and what a disappointing showdown it would be.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Where there's one Tisch, there are sure to be others these days, naming buildings, receiving honors, celebrating family occasions.

title: Afghan Driven From Kabul Makes Stand in North
description: Just beyond this mud-walled town, around a bend in a gushing river and into a plunging gorge, a battle has begun that could prove to be the decisive military encounter of the Afghan war.

title: Federal Taxation Shows It Has 2 Faces
description: States in the Northeast and the Midwest usually receive less from Federal spending than their citizens send to Washington in Federal taxes, but the shoe is on the other foot for many Southern states. Connecticut and New Jersey had the biggest gaps last year, while New Mexico, Virginia and Mississippi gained most.

title: Research Uses Grow For Virtual Cadavers
description: HE was a 39-year-old convicted murderer, executed in Texas by lethal injection. She was a 59-year-old woman from Maryland who died of a heart attack. In life, they never knew one another. But in death they have been united by a common wish, a parting gesture of good will that has earned them a status they probably could not have begun to anticipate: immortality, in cyberspace.

title: Second Biggest 'Donor State'
description: New Jersey pays more in Federal taxes than it receives in Federal dollars, and ranks as the second biggest ''donor state'' in the country next to Connecticut, according to a new study. In 1995, the state got back 67 cents for every tax dollar it sent to Washington -- $3,828 per person in spending compared with $5,711 in taxes -- Herman B. Leonard, a professor at Harvard University and a co-author of the report, said yesterday.

title: Yeltsin's Heart Surgeon in Action Performing a Coronary Bypass
description: In the same immaculately clean, high-technology operating room at the Cardiology Center here where Boris N. Yeltsin is expected to undergo heart bypass surgery in the next few weeks, his surgeon, Dr. Renat S. Akchurin, performed a similar operation on a 36-year-old man on Thursday.

title: Rock Layers Challenged As Clues to Ancient Life
description: THEY are rocks that intrigue biologists as much as geologists. Called stromatolites, they come in the shape of domes and knobs, spreading platforms and rising pillars embedded in limestone formations. Some look like huge Galapagos tortoises half-buried in sand or petrified sponges or large stone mattresses. But it is their interiors, constructed of many distinct layers of accreted sediments and often exposed in outcrops, that draw the most attention, especially from scientists investigating the earliest life on Earth.

title: McCann-Erickson Hires Head of New Unit
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York said yesterday that it would hire Stan Rapp, a longtime direct marketing agency executive, to head a new worldwide direct-marketing unit as chairman and chief executive.

title: Motorola Posted Income Drop Of 58.5% in Third Quarter
description: Motorola Inc., the semiconductor and wireless communications giant that shocked high-tech investors this summer by reporting declining profits for the second quarter, today reported an even sharper earnings decline for the three months that ended Sept. 30. It also warned investors that earnings in the current quarter might be hurt by charges to cover restructuring moves aimed at cutting costs.

title: Irvan Has Concussion
description: ERNIE IRVAN was released from Carolinas Medical Center in Charlotte, N.C., yesterday after an overnight stay after a crash at Charlotte Motor Speedway in which he was knocked unconscious for four minutes.

title: Loan for Be-Bop Birth Site
description: State development officials said yesterday that they would provide the actor Robert De Niro and his partners with a $300,000 loan and other incentives to help resurrect Minton's Playhouse, the jazz club where be-bop was born, in Harlem.

title: Best Products to Shut 81 Stores and Let 4,500 Workers Go
description: The Best Products Company, the struggling Richmond-based catalogue-showroom retailer that sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month, announced yesterday that it would close 81 of its 169 stores and would dismiss 4,500 employees, or 45 percent of its work force.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: Magellan Cuts Bonds to Pre-Vinik Levels
description: Fidelity Investments' Magellan Fund cut its bond holdings in August back to its level before its former manager, Jeffrey N. Vinik, went on a bond-buying spree that hurt returns.

title: S.E.C. Charges an Official Of Philadelphia Exchange
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a member of the board of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange -- and until recently head of its conduct committee -- with cheating customers.

title: A Plan for Special Education
description: One of the most hotly debated elements of the Whitman administration's school spending plan would be eliminated by a bill being pushed by educators and advocates for the disabled. The bill would do away with the proposed 10 percent limit on the number of students in a district who would be eligible for a full state subsidy under the special education program.

title: Executive Changes
description: DATA BROADCASTING CORP., San Mateo, Calif., named Mark Imperiale to the new positions of president and chief operating officer.

title: High Court Reviews Cable Systems Law
description: The Federal Government's defense of a law requiring cable-television systems to carry the signals of most broadcast stations found a skeptical audience at the Supreme Court yesterday as the Justices, formally opening their new term, questioned whether the law violates the free-speech rights of cable systems.

title: High-Flying Quintiles to Buy Innovex in $747.5 Million Deal
description: The Quintiles Transnational Corporation, a rapidly growing drug research company that is a Wall Street favorite, said yesterday that it planned to buy Innovex Ltd. of Britain for $747.5 million in stock.

title: Burmese Lift Cordon
description: The authorities today removed police checkpoints set up nearly two weeks ago to bar access to the residence of the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, witnesses said.

title: Equity Residential in Deal
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust said today that it acquired 13 apartment complexes totaling 3,304 units for a total price of $166.6 million. Equity Residential, a Chicago-based real estate investment trust, said it will enter the suburbs of Minneapolis and St. Louis as a result of the transactions. Equity Residential now owns or has investments in 231 properties with 68,712 units in 31 states.

title: Q&A
description: The Washboard Effect

title: Notre Dame Women Are No. 1 Again
description: Notre Dame's women's soccer team vaulted to the top ranking in the country with a 2-1 victory over North Carolina and a 2-0 triumph over Duke in capturing the Duke Classic in Durham, N.C., over the weekend.

title: Mrs. Roosevelt's Rallies
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WRIGHT MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY INC., Arlington, Tenn., a closely held maker of orthopedic products and instruments, bought the calcium sulfate processing business of United States Gypsum Co., a unit of USG Corp., as part of a strategy to develop human skeletal repair technology.

title: Changes in Focus Ruled Out by Apple
description: The chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., Gilbert Amelio, said today that the company planned to focus on making personal computers and shrugged off suggestions that its machines could not compete with ones run on operating systems made by the Microsoft Corporation.

title: A Courtroom Haunted by the Turmoil of the 60's
description: THE LAWS OF OUR FATHERS

title: High Rises to Be Demolished
description: An additional 1,458 units of high-rise public housing, now considered symbols of a failed policy that intensified urban blight, are to be demolished in Newark, where 2,200 units have already been razed.

title: Lasorda Leaves Hospital
description: TOMMY LASORDA is out of the hospital for the second time in recent months, promising to adopt a healthier diet.

title: A Candidate Of the Right, Running For Laughs
description: It has reached the point that American politicians aren't just fish in a barrel for would-be sharpshooting satirists: they're dead fish in a barrel. In an era of instant comedy and pervasive, prickly cynicism, the morning's headlines about Presidential candidates are the evening's one-liners on television. Moreover, you usually get the jaded feeling that you've heard the jokes before, whatever they are.

title: Court Rejects Challenge to the Whitewater Counsel's Authority
description: Siding with the Whitewater independent counsel, the Supreme Court today rejected the appeals of former Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas and two associates who had challenged the authority of the special prosecutor to charge them in a criminal case that was not directly related to the Clintons or the Whitewater land deal.

title: Torricelli Attacks Rival on N.R.A. Comments
description: Trying to reverse the tide of charges about his own ethics, Representative Robert G. Torricelli accused his Republican opponent in the United States Senate race in New Jersey today of not telling the truth about donations involving the National Rifle Association.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in some editions of the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about employee dismissals by Semitool Inc. misstated the number of workers affected. It was 150, not 1,500.

title: Stream Repairs Worsened Flood Damage, Anglers Say
description: The flood that swamped the western Catskills last January seemed insatiable, plucking trees out by their roots, plunging bridges into streams, wrecking homes and stores and leaving eight people dead.

title: Big Salaries Are Paying Off
description: It probably comes as no surprise to the owners who have pushed for management's revolutionary revenue-sharing plan, but the teams in the two League Championship Series have four of the five highest player payrolls in the major leagues.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: A New Regime in Afghanistan
description: The Islamic fundamentalist movement that gained control over much of Afghanistan with a recent string of military victories has brought a measure of stability to the country for the first time in years. But the arbitrary actions of the Government formed by the Taliban, as the movement is called, have also stirred anger in Afghanistan and uneasiness in the region. The United States and other countries that helped Afghanistan rid itself of Soviet troops must now try to persuade its inexperienced rulers to stop the export of drugs, weapons and terrorism. The Taliban leadership also needs to recognize that mistreatment of women in the name of Islam is wrong.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.S. Said to End Inquiry of Litton
description: Litton Industries said today that the Justice Department had ended an investigation of its Guidance and Control Systems unit's billing practices without taking action against the company or its employees.

title: Ink-Jet Printers That Function as Photofinishers
description: IF the computer and photographic industries have their way, the world will shortly embark on a frenzy of digital picture-making. People will take snapshots with digital cameras or capture photos with scanners or ask the photofinisher for help in turning images on film into a bunch of bits. Photo software will help make Junior's overbite a trifle less pronounced, his nose a trifle less prominent. Then the pictures will whisk away to Grandma via E-mail or the personal home page.

title: Federal Government Uses North's and Midwest's Dollars to Aid the South, Study Says
description: Many states in the Northeast and the Middle West pay more in Federal taxes than they receive in Federal spending, while many Southern states are subsidized by the Federal Government, a new study shows.

title: Excerpts From Ruling in Trial of Officer
description: Following are excerpts from Acting Justice Gerald Sheindlin's decision in State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday, acquitting Officer Francis X. Livoti of criminally negligent homicide, as provided by the Office of Court Administration.

title: Viacom and Hubbard Swap TV Stations
description: Viacom Inc.'s Paramount Stations Group unit and Hubbard Broadcasting Inc. have concluded a deal to swap Paramount's WTOG television station in Tampa, Fla., for two Hubbard stations in upstate New York.

title: How to Get From Here to There
description: HUMAN conception typically involves a chaotic dash by tens of millions of sperm seeking a path to a single egg. Some researchers believe that so many sperm are required because not one of them will stop to ask for directions.

title: Sales License Is Extended
description: Sonus Pharmaceuticals Inc. said today that it had extended Abbott Laboratories' sales license for an ultrasound contrast agent to include Europe, Latin America, Canada, the Mideast, Africa, and certain Pacific countries. Abbott agreed to pay $34.6 million for the expanded license. Abbott also agreed to pay Sonus a royalty ranging from 36 percent to 42 percent of annual net sales of the product, called Echogen. The agent is injected into patients before diagnostic examinations with ultrasound equipment to improve the quality of images.

title: Marjorie Shostak, 51, Author Who Wrote of Tribal Woman
description: Marjorie Shostak, a woman from a traditional family in Flatbush whose book about a bold older woman from the !Kung San tribe in Africa's Kalahari Desert rode an early wave of women's studies and injected new life into techniques of anthropology, died on Sunday at DeKalb Medical Center in Atlanta. She was 51.

title: Foote, Cone Gets $65 Million Account
description: Tambrands Inc., the marketer of Tampax tampons, said yesterday that it had named the Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $65 million. The account, which will be managed by Foote, Cone's New York office, FCB/Leber Katz Partners, had been handled by the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group in New York since 1993.

title: DOLE, FULL OF ZIP, GOES AFTER VOTERS FROM NEW JERSEY
description: With the first debate behind him, Bob Dole went back to the trail yesterday to seek new vigor for his campaign, rolling across New Jersey on his first bus tour and into Manhattan in a motorcade at rush hour.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: High Court Allows Seizure of Hotel And a School Rule
description: The Supreme Court has let stand without comment two cases brought on appeal from Westchester County and New York City. They involved a Mamaroneck high school's requirement that its students perform charitable work and a Federal seizure of a drug-infested single-room-occupancy hotel in Manhattan.

title: An Error the Official Scorer Cannot Take Away
description: Roberto Alomar, the Baltimore Orioles' second baseman, entered the 1996 season as a baseball player who happened to be blessed with a great career and a great reputation.

title: Hardy Perennial Leads Utah Contest
description: For 12 years, Merrill Cook, a jovial explosives manufacturer, has soldiered stoically through Utah's political desert, spending $3 million on six successive efforts to win elective office -- and losing every single try.

title: You're Wonderful, You're Beautiful, You're Who?
description: Who else but Jeanne Moreau could inspire a film as rapturously in love with its star as ''The Proprietor,'' a high-toned, cotton-candy fantasy about an artistic grand dame wafting like Glinda the Good Witch over some very fancy real estate?

title: A Cake of Courage
description: To The Living Section:

title: Rain Gives Yankees An Extra Day Game
description: The tropical storm that soaked the New York region yesterday will bring an extra day of afternoon baseball to Yankee Stadium. Game 1 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles was postponed last night, and will be played this afternoon at 4:07, with only the possibility of a shower. Game 2 will be played tomorrow afternoon, originally a travel day, at 3:07.

title: Sunbeam Selects Ogilvy & Mather
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said yesterday that it had selected Ogilvy & Mather Chicago to handle its account, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at more than $10 million. John DeSimone, investor relations director at Sunbeam in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said that Ogilvy Chicago, which is owned by the WPP Group, was awarded the account after a review lasting a month and a half that had been narrowed to Ogilvy and one other undisclosed agency.

title: Caminiti to Have Shoulder Surgery Today
description: San Diego Padres third baseman KEN CAMINITI is scheduled to have surgery today on his torn left rotator cuff. The team doctor, JAN FRONEK, estimated rehabilitation will take five to nine months, which means it is possible Caminiti could be ready by opening day next year.

title: As Towns Lose Allure, Nomads Are Nomads Again
description: When the wind died down at sunset, and the raspy moan of a camel was all that upset the starkly clear and quiet air, Altankhuyang gazed out at the arid landscape that stretched as far as the slender clouds on the horizon.

title: Cadillac hopes its new performance-oriented luxury Catera will revive its languishing image.
description: CADILLAC and its ad agency, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, are trying to convince baby boomers who like driving small, performance-oriented German-built luxury sedans that a newfangled Cadillac is really their dream car.

title: Armstrong Acknowledges Cancer Battle
description: Lance Armstrong, the star American bicycle racer and former world champion, said from his home in Austin, Tex., yesterday that he has testicular cancer, that it has spread to his abdomen and lungs and that he started 12 weeks of chemotherapy on Monday.

title: Hispanic Groups Prepare To March to Washington
description: At 1 this morning, in the smudgy darkness of Salazar Park, Crisanto Campos was waiting patiently for a bus that would make him this country's latest version of a Freedom Rider, on a journey that would end in what Latino organizers are calling La Marcha, the march.

title: Coming In From the Cold
description: THE little brass plaque implanted next to his table at the Montcalm Hotel's restaurant reads: ''Frederick Forsyth (author of 'The Day of the Jackal') regularly entertains spies and assassins at this table.''

title: Eating Well
description: CAREFUL followers of conventional wisdom have always bought tuna packed in water and the large, economy size of everything. Conventional wisdom says that canned tuna in water has fewer calories and fat than tuna in oil and that economy size is cheaper than regular size.

title: Support for Rural and Inner-City Libraries
description: Bill Gates of the Microsoft Corporation, taking a page from Andrew Carnegie's drive to help build public libraries across America during the age of steel, is to announce today a program to help connect some of those libraries to the information age.

title: NEW YORK LOSING MILLIONS FOR LACK OF WELFARE PLAN
description: While Republicans and Democrats argue in Albany over the future of the state welfare program, New York State has been losing an estimated $1 million a day since Oct. 1 because it has not filed a plan showing how it intends to comply with the new Federal welfare law.

title: On Volatile Social and Cultural Issues, Silence
description: The contours of the final weeks of the Presidential campaign seemed clear when this race began a year ago: The Republican candidate would use divisive social issues -- chiefly, affirmative action, immigration and welfare -- to drive President Clinton to the left and ultimately off the edge of the electoral map.

title: Cooking Without Gas: At Home Off the Range
description: UNTIL the gas was turned off, I was never quite able to put my finger on why my wife and I had a toaster oven, apart from the fact that if somebody manufactures something for the kitchen, I want it. And I would maintain that I generally find some use for it. Immersion blender attachment for the hand mixer? Electronic scales? Instant-read thermometers? I've used them all, at least once.

title: Gum Disease in Pregnancy Linked To Premature Low-Weight Babies
description: ALTHOUGH it may seem improbable, infection in the gums of a pregnant woman may lead to a more than sevenfold increase in her risk of delivering a premature baby of low birth weight, according to findings published yesterday in The Journal of Periodontology.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: No Anti-Hispanic Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an effort by New York City to persuade Time Warner to carry the Fox News Channel misstated the channel's availability in the city. (An article on Saturday and the Media column in Business Day on Monday repeated the error.)

title: Gore and Kemp Practice Jabs for Tonight's Encounter
description: Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp brushed up today on the eve of a 90-minute debate that many politicians in both parties view as perhaps a preview of the possible combatants in 2000.

title: Making the Berlin Philharmonic His Own
description: The great Berlin Philharmonic of yore is back, to judge from its series of Brahms concerts at Carnegie Hall, which ended on Monday evening. But it is back in no simple way. And not incidentally, the orchestra's music director, Claudio Abbado, seems finally to have achieved a level of inspired and exhilarating performances that many a frustrated listener has long awaited from him.

title: Lost Literary Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTCORP AGREES TO BUY 51% OF CSK AUTO
description: Investcorp S.A., based in Bahrain, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 51 percent controlling interest in CSK Auto Inc., a retailer of auto parts and accessories. Financial terms were not disclosed. CSK Auto, based in Phoenix, operates stores under the trade names Checker, Schuck's and Kragen in 14 Western states. Investcorp said CSK Auto had sales of more than $770 million in the last 12 months. Investcorp has also arranged for a $125 million loan for working capital. CKS's current owners have agreed to provide an additional $50 million loan for an accelerated store expansion program.

title: Biker Admits Killing Officer
description: Against the advice of his lawyers, a biker persuaded a judge yesterday to allow him to plead guilty to murdering a Gloucester County police officer and face execution. Lawyers for the biker, Robert Simon, said their client had been coerced into admitting guilt in the fatal shooting of Sgt. Ippolito Gonzalez in May 1995 to save his co-defendant, Charles Staples. But under questioning from Judge Joseph F. Lisa of Superior Court, Mr. Simon denied that he had been threatened or subjected to pressure, The Associated Press reported.

title: Andrew Salter, Behavior Therapist, 82, Dies
description: Andrew Salter, a psychologist who helped develop the theoretical underpinnings and clinical applications of behavior therapy decades before the field became popular, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Your Dollars at Work

title: INSIDE
description: I.R.A. Admits Bombings

title: Down From Poverty: Mexico to Manhattan
description: Down a dim hallway in Washington Heights, behind a flimsy padlocked door, Juana Castillo sits on an unmade bed, looking at photographs from home. She skims past familiar snapshots of her Mexican village, a place of plodding burros and salt-sprinkled mangoes, but her weary eyes linger over one image in particular -- of her eldest child, Erendida. In the little girl's untroubled smile, she sees all the loss and heartache of her family's life in the 12-by-15-foot room that has become their home in America.

title: Corrections
description: An article on September 30 about a televised debate between Congressional leaders incorrectly described the source of money the AFL-CIO is spending on advertisements. It comes from increased assessments by the Federation on member unions, not from increased per-person dues.

title: Orioles Flip-Flop Wells and Mussina
description: Davey Johnson, the Baltimore Orioles' manager, took advantage of yesterday's rainout at Yankee Stadium to switch his pitchers for Games 2 and 3 of the American League Championship Series. Johnson moved the left-hander David Wells to Game 2 and pushed the right-hander Mike Mussina back to Game 3, the first game in Baltimore, on Friday night.

title: Possible Third Start for Pettitte Seems Washed Out
description: Barring an unexpected and improbable development, Andy Pettitte yesterday most likely lost his chance to become the first starting pitcher to earn three victories in a league championship series.

title: N.A.S.D. Panel Says Broker Manipulated Stock Trading
description: How in the world does a tiny young brokerage firm on Long Island make more than $53 million in the course of just 14 months?

title: The War in the Wings
description: Something was clearly missing in The Debate That Changed Nothing, but what? Perot non sequiturs? A wallow in Whitewater? A panel full of self-aggrandizing TV anchors? A gaffe suitable for permanent exhibition in the Ford-Dukakis-Quayle Video Hall of Shame?

title: Giuliani Is Urging Fans to Give Alomar the Silent Treatment
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city's most prominent Yankee fan, called on his fellow fans yesterday to mute their reaction to Roberto Alomar, the second baseman of the Baltimore Orioles, when the teams play the first two games of the American League Championship Series at Yankee Stadium this week.

title: Murdoch Gets Pataki Support In Cable Fight
description: Rupert Murdoch, locked in a bitter battle to get his 24-hour news channel onto Time Warner's cable systems in New York City, has picked up two new allies: Gov. George E. Pataki, who made a personal plea on Mr. Murdoch's behalf to Time Warner's chairman, and the State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, who aimed an antitrust investigation at the company yesterday.

title: A Mediterranean Salad Redolent of Oranges
description: This one-dish salad should be served warm or at room temperature. The touch of orange from the rind adds a perfume and slightly bitter sweetness that pull all the flavors together. For vegetarians, this makes a delicious main-dish salad without the chicken and with vegetable stock in place of chicken stock.

title: Police Won't Open Fire, Arafat Promises Israel President
description: Paying his first public visit to Israel, the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat met today with President Ezer Weizman and announced that he had given ''permanent orders'' to his police force not to open fire at Israeli soldiers.

title: Police Charge Neighbor In Kidnapping of 2 Girls
description: A 31-year-old man has been arrested in the disappearance of two high school cheerleaders, one of whom lived in the house next to his in this quiet upstate community.

title: Ward Prepares for a Season Without His Mentor
description: It's not that he is still a backup, that the Knicks have committed themselves to another point guard for the next several years. Charlie Ward can deal with that.

title: Using Televised Ads as Rifles, Campaigns Aim at the Elderly
description: This state's famously numerous elderly voters began getting special attention from the Presidential campaigns this week, as the advertising war shifted to a new stage.

title: Wives Not in the Club
description: To The Living Section:

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a graffiti mural on Thursday with an article about charges of drug dealing in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, was published in error, and the caption misstated the cause of death of the young man honored by the mural. According to the Medical Examiner's office, the man, John Joseph Vite, died of natural causes; his death was not related to drugs. The Times regrets the error.

title: Renewed Primary Voting Is Canceled in Brooklyn
description: New York City's botched primary election, which became a roller-coaster ride of polling place foul-ups and court challenges, took another sharp turn yesterday when, after new court rulings, officials canceled plans to reopen balloting at more than 100 polling places in Brooklyn.

title: Trying to Still the Echoes of a Tribe's Last Stand
description: Horace Axtell, a Nez Perce tribal elder, holds a staff that has 14 brown-and-white bald eagle feathers attached to it, like the teeth on a comb. They flutter in an unrelenting prairie breeze as he explains their significance.

title: Young Talent Displays Its Spirit in a Gala That's Full of Banter
description: It was definitely not your run-of-the-mill dance gala. For starters, the event on Monday night at the Kaye Playhouse benefited an unusual organization, Career Transition for Dancers. And the young talent on view was highly diverse, ranging from Carlos Acosta and Lauren Anderson, spellbinding young stars of the Houston Ballet, to the members of the Riverdance troupe from Ireland.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE last car of an IRT No. 1 local traveling south from 96th Street. Two muscular construction workers in their mid-30's and sporting baseball caps, brims turned to the back, are chewing the fat.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the suspension of a 14-year-old Ohio teen-ager for giving a Midol tablet to a classmate misstated her given name. She is Kimberly Smartt, not Cindy.

title: Report Says City Missed Chances to Save Girl
description: An internal investigation of the city child welfare agency's handling of a case in which a 4-year-old starved to death last August has uncovered evidence that a caseworker failed to check repeated reports of neglect, that another caseworker examined the wrong child during a visit and then monitored the family by telephone, and that no meaningful supervision was provided by agency superiors.

title: Use Game A Tickets Today
description: In light of last night's rainout, tickets for the first game of the American League Championship Series at Yankee Stadium marked Game A will be honored today when the Yankees and Orioles play at 4:07 P.M.

title: Police Battle Surge in Cheap Heroin
description: Despite escalating efforts by the New York City Police Department to fight drug dealing, Federal and local law enforcement officials say increasing supplies of cheap and potent heroin have entered the city in recent months to be sold in the city and around the metropolitan area.

title: Blockbuster Will Acquire Irish Chain of Video Stores
description: Viacom Inc.'s Blockbuster Entertainment Group unit, which met with securities analysts yesterday, announced two acquisitions without disclosing the terms of either deal.

title: Drug Use Is Up in High Schools
description: After a steep decline throughout the 1980's, marijuana use among the state's high school students rose sharply from 1992 to 1995, officials said yesterday. The latest three-year survey of students in grades 10 to 12 found that 42.1 percent of them admitted having tried the drug at least once, up from 27 percent for the previous three years, said Roger Shatzkin, a spokesman for the State Attorney General's office. In addition, 4.7 percent said they had used heroin, up from 1.6 percent in 1989.

title: The S.E.C. is set to undo a rule that was an invitation to abuse.
description: IT may be the worst regulation ever passed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, in terms of the invitation to abuse that it presented, but back in 1990 no one foresaw the problems. Now the S.E.C. is finally ready to force disclosure of the ways companies are using -- and misusing -- a rule meant to make it easier for American companies to sell securities overseas.

title: Seahawks Can't Make a Deal for George
description: The suspended quarterback JEFF GEORGE remained a member of the Atlanta Falcons yesterday as the National Football League trading deadline passed without George agreeing on a new contract with Seattle.

title: School to Develop American Drivers
description: BARRY GREEN, the team owner who won the 1995 Indianapolis 500 with the Canadian driver JACQUES VILLENEUVE, announced the formation of Indy-car racing's version of a PGA Tour qualifying school yesterday. The Team Green Academy will annually invite 25 promising young American drivers to an advanced racing class in Las Vegas, Nev. That group will be winnowed down to two winners, based on speed as well as such criteria as communication skills with mechanics and ability to withstand pressure. Those drivers will receive full financing to compete in one of Indy-car racing's minor league series.

title: TCW CONSIDERS SALE OF MONEY MANAGEMENT UNIT
description: The TCW Group Inc., which owns the Trust Company of the West, a money management company in Los Angeles with about $50 billion in assets, is considering a sale of the Trust Company, among other options. In a letter to clients, Robert Day, chairman and chief executive of TCW Group, wrote, ''Now is an appropriate time to conduct a more open, formal evaluation of how we can best capitalize'' on the company's strengths. The closely held TCW, which oversees accounts for some of America's biggest pension funds, wants to expand its presence abroad, where it manages about $10 billion in assets, Stephen McDonald, a managing director at TCW, said.

title: Bronx Judge Explains Acquittal of Officer in Choking Death
description: With protests echoing from the streets outside the Bronx County Courthouse to Congress, a Bronx judge went to unusual lengths yesterday to explain his decision to acquit a police officer in the choking death of a man in a dispute over a late-night football game.

title: Browser Moves By Microsoft Make Even Netscape Blink
description: Less than a year after turning its sights on the Internet upstart Netscape Communications, the Microsoft Corporation appears to be gaining the upper hand in the so-called Web browser war.

title: Next Up for the Braves: Life With Time Warner
description: The Atlanta Braves who since 1976 have been the property of Ted Turner, the former America's Cup skipper known as Captain Outrageous -- are about to find out about life as buttoned-down corporate citizens.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: CABARET
description: The Limits of Success And the Reason to Go On

title: 20% of France Telecom To Be Put Up for Sale
description: France will sell about 20 percent of the state-owned telecommunications concern, France Telecom, in April, the Telecommunications Minister, Francois Fillon, said in an interview published yesterday. The sale, which is expected to be France's largest initial offering, will be aimed mainly at private individuals, Mr. Fillon said in the interview with the financial daily La Tribune Desfosses.

title: Corrections
description: The Chess column diagram in Science Times yesterday represented two white pieces incorrectly. Bishops, not rooks, should have appeared on squares a4 and b6.

title: Fringe Benefits From Oil Give Alaska a Big Payday
description: Politically conservative it may be, but Alaska is the only state in the nation where redistribution of wealth is written into the state Constitution. The Last Frontier State pays people to live here, and never before will so much have been paid to so many.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Vendors Lose Round in Suit Over Sites at the Atlanta Olympics
description: More than 50 street vendors who thought they would be floating on a sea of Olympic dollars this summer, but ran aground instead, lost a round today in their efforts to reclaim their lost investments in vending sites.

title: Croatia Chief Seeks to Muzzle A Radio That Aided His Rise
description: A retired Croatian general, critical of President Franjo Tudjman's drive to turn this small country into a military power in the Balkans, took to the airwaves today to spell out what he said was the folly of such a course.

title: Vigilantes Should Hold Their Fire
description: BASEBALL'S great morality play moves to the Bronx. After heavy rain postponed the first game of the American League Championship Series, the Greek chorus will be prepared today to hector Roberto Alomar for spitting on an umpire two weeks ago.

title: The Downside of an Upturn
description: The United States economy, although growing too slowly to satisfy every registered voter, is a ball of fire compared with the economies of Western Europe and Japan. One vital source of this strength is the robust American capacity to fail.

title: Theater in Review
description: Infusing an Ionesco Classic With a Cartoon Spirit

title: Levi Strauss Hopes to Match Performance of Dockers
description: Last December, after production had already begun on Levi Strauss & Company's new Slates men's dress pants and only months before the shipping deadline, the company halted production to change the fabric of half the product line, increasing the wool content by 10 percent.

title: Cable Interference
description: Part of the obligation of any top official in New York is to help businesses create new jobs. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Gov. George Pataki and Attorney General Dennis Vacco have exercised poor judgment by demanding that Time Warner cable television allow the New York-based Fox News Channel to be shown to local television viewers. Since the Fox News Channel is owned by Rupert Murdoch, a political supporter of all three men, their actions involve a conflict of interest. Beyond that, Mr. Giuliani's threat to revoke Time Warner's license and Mr. Vacco's launching of an antitrust investigation are improper government interventions promoting one commercial programmer over another on cable television.

title: Corrections
description: A television review of ''Frontline'' yesterday mistated the surname of the correspondent on a segment of the CNN program ''Democracy in America '96.'' He is David Lewis, not Donald.

title: OROAMERICA IN TALKS WITH MICHAEL ANTHONY JEWELERS
description: OroAmerica Inc., a maker of 14-karat gold jewelry, based in Burbank, Calif., said yesterday that it was in talks to be acquired by Michael Anthony Jewelers Inc. for $7.50 a share in cash and stock. The transaction would be worth about $46.9 million, based on 6.25 million OroAmerica shares outstanding. OroAmerica's shares rose $1, to $6.50, in Nasdaq trading; Michael Anthony, based in Mount Vernon, N.Y., rose 18.75 cents, to $3.4375, on the American Stock Exchange. OroAmerica said the discussions with Michael Anthony were preliminary and OroAmerica said it had hired Koffler & Company of Los Angeles to advise it on improving its market value.

title: Calor Reports Offer By Biggest Shareholder
description: Calor Group P.L.C. said yesterday that SHV Holdings N.V., its biggest shareholder, had offered to buy the 48.4 percent of Calor, a British bottled gas maker, that it does not already own for $:245 million, or about $383 million.

title: Tirade by Qaddafi Stuns Turkey's Premier
description: Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's effort to bolster Turkey's ties with radical Islamic countries exploded in his face this week as he sat silently while the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, publicly harangued him about Turkish policies.

title: Strahan Will Turn Down Giants' Four-Year Offer
description: Michael Strahan will turn down the Giants' latest offer, one that would have made him the team's highest-paid veteran defensive player. Strahan and his agent, Tony Agnone, will probably stop negotiations with the team until after the season, when Strahan becomes an unrestricted free agent.

title: New Season for Smoltz Beginning With Game 1
description: He has lived the kind of regular season most pitchers can only dream about. A 24-8 record and a league-high 276 strikeouts have made John Smoltz the favorite to win the National League's Cy Young award, an honor that has belonged to his teammate Greg Maddux for the last four years.

title: Turkey Adrift
description: Turkey's new Prime Minister, Necmettin Erbakan, is not likely to return to Libya anytime soon. In a disastrous encounter last Saturday with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the erratic Libyan leader, Mr. Erbakan badly undermined his authority at home and damaged Turkey's relations with the United States. If his Government survives the resulting furor in Ankara, Mr. Erbakan would be wise to reconsider an impulsive diplomatic strategy that far exceeds the limited electoral mandate of his Islamic-oriented Welfare Party, which represents barely one-fifth of the Turkish electorate.

title: Lowe Group Buys Minority Interest
description: The Lowe Group in London, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had acquired a ''substantial minority interest'' in the agency holding company GGK Occidental in Vienna. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Wanted: A Master Builder Named Ron Wolf
description: Word is the Jets are looking at Ron Wolf and Ron Wolf is looking right back at the Jets.

title: Fighting Euphemism and Optimism
description: DOING BATTLE

title: Ted Bessel, 57, Dies; Pursued 'That Girl' In Television Sitcom
description: Ted Bessell, the actor who starred with Marlo Thomas in the television comedy series ''That Girl'' and was a director of the ''Tracey Ullman Show,'' died on Sunday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 57.

title: Personal Health
description: CHRONIC fatigue syndrome appears to be a centuries-old disorder with a modern name. Previous ''conditions'' with nearly identical symptom patterns have included febricula, the vapors, neurasthenia, chronic brucellosis, hypoglycemia, myalgic encephalomyelitis, chronic candidiasis and chronic mononucleosis.

title: I.R.A. Says It Set Bomb That Wounded 31 at Barracks in Ulster
description: The Irish Republican Army acknowledged tonight that it had detonated the two bombs that wounded 21 soldiers and 10 civilians on Monday at the British Army's headquarters in the British province of Northern Ireland.

title: No Headline
description: ''People in the Lower 48 ask me what I do for a living. I get a big kick out of saying, 'I'm giving away money to people.' ''

title: The Creative Bonus of Neglect
description: Fashion magazines love to make lists and to compile oracular predictions about the next great designers, the new establishment, the coming generation, the ''in'' crowd, the most powerful people in fashion. It's mostly about picking pets and inventing a pecking order.

title: Finally Finding a Mate, in Working-Class London
description: Don't be alarmed if during the opening moments of ''Beautiful Thing,'' you have the dislocating sense of being catapulted back three decades to the mad, mod world of ''Georgy Girl.'' That's because the cheery voice on the soundtrack belongs to none other than Mama Cass Elliot belting ''It's Getting Better,'' a late-60's hit whose jangly folk-pop sound echoes the theme song from the movie that made Lynn Redgrave a star.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Week in Review on Sunday about presidential pets misstated the Humane Society telephone numbers for a benefit poll on whether voters prefer a cat or a dog in the White House. The numbers are (900) 680-DOGS and (900) 680-CATS. Each call costs 75 cents, with profit of 25 cents for the society.

title: For Chirac's Mark On Culture in Paris, An Ethnic Museum
description: When it comes to building cultural monuments, President Jacques Chirac may be hard-pressed to match his predecessor, Francois Mitterrand, who left an expanded Louvre Museum, the Bastille Opera, a new National Library and a host of other ''great works.'' But this week Mr. Chirac made a start, announcing plans to create a major new museum for African, Oceanic and pre-Columbian art.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Shares traded lower here today. At the end of the session at the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 167.70 points -- or eight-tenths of 1 percent -- to stand at 20,870.83. On Tuesday, the Nikkei index fell 122.48 points, or about six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: POP
description: Wooing a New Generation Of Hispanic Audiences

title: Serving Art and Revolution
description: Although their subjects are individuals linked to revolution through art, the two documentaries playing in a program tonight at 9 at Alice Tully Hall in the New York Film Festival leave different impressions.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : A Pair of Intrepid Volunteers Cleans Deep in Central Park
description: George and Catherine Parry have been drawing a lot of curious looks as they scour the depths of Central Park Reservoir in New York.

title: Vendex Will Sell Off Stake in Koninklijke
description: Vendex International N.V., a Dutch retailer, said yesterday that it was selling its 36 percent stake in Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer N.V., which is valued at about 620 million guilders ($362.6 million), to finance international growth. K.B.B. owns the De Bijenkorf department stores in the Netherlands and the toy store chain F.A.O. Schwarz in the United States.

title: Four Men in One Body, And It's Mastroianni's
description: The movies have always been the quickest, most pleasurable way for us to imagine ourselves as other people. But until the Chilean director Raul Ruiz's elegantly surreal film, ''Three Lives and Only One Death,'' they have generally shied away from reflecting on the very thing they do so well. Those films that do address the subject are usually Faustian horror stories of identity exchange or dark Jekyll-and-Hyde fables of personality transformation.

title: A Question of Listings
description: Rupert Murdoch and Roger Ailes have taken pains to say that the new Fox News Channel, a 24-hour cable news service owned by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation and headed by Mr. Ailes, would be ''fair and balanced'' in its news reports.

title: A Last-Minute Goal Gives the Rangers a Tie
description: Playing their third game in four nights, without their captain and in the den of the defending Eastern Conference champions, the Rangers tonight used adversity as an ally.

title: Of Senate Votes, Candidates and Scalded Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Zimmer Takes On Torricelli in Ad That Mimics TV News
description: Richard A. Zimmer's campaign unveiled a new television advertisement for his race for a United States Senate seat in New Jersey, but before it was even broadcast, it had created a stir.

title: 2 Drug Companies Name Agencies
description: Two drug companies have named agencies for products awaiting approval.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AL HIRSCHFELD, the caricaturist, turned 93 on June 23. But he had no time to celebrate then, so BRENDAN GILL, the author and critic, will give him a birthday party tonight at Cafe Nicholson on East 58th Street.

title: Coverage of Debate
description: Tonight's debate between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, will be broadcast live on ABC, CBS, NBC and PBS, beginning at 9 P.M., Eastern time.
