The cable channels CNN, C-Span and MSNBC will also carry the 90-minute debate live from the Mahaffrey Theater in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Chief Is Named at Greystone
description: Michael Greenstein will be moving from one troubled institution to another when he becomes chief executive at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital in November. Since last year, Mr. Greenstein -- whose appointment was announced yesterday -- has been director of quality management at Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn, which has been plagued with so many escapes that it barely averted being shut down last summer.

title: No Problem Is Seen As Pope Has Surgery
description: Pope John Paul II's appendix was removed, and his doctors said they found no traces of any new or serious ailment.

title: Don't Set Black-Oriented TV Programs Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Lose Benoit, Probably for the Season
description: David Benoit did not choose the Nets for the money, but for a chance to increase his future value with immediate playing time as a starter.

title: Sony Names Its New Team To Run Studio Operations
description: The Sony Corporation, whose six years in Hollywood have been marked by overspending, inept leadership and poor box office results, today announced a new management team to run its studios, headed, as expected, by John Calley, president of United Artists.

title: Mignon Eberhart, Novelist, 97; Blended Mystery and Romance
description: Mignon G. Eberhart, a highly prolific author of mystery novels who specialized in stories that combined romance and suspense, died yesterday in the Nathaniel Witherell nursing home in Greenwich, Conn., where she lived. She was 97.

title: ALLSTATE TO TAKE EARNINGS CHARGE OF $262 MILLION
description: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that it plans to take a $262 million charge, or 58 cents a share, in the third quarter for discontinued business and to pay claims from companies forced to clean up pollution and asbestos. The company, the largest publicly traded home and auto insurer, plans to take the charge so that it can increase its reserves for discontinued lines and coverage by $405 million. Allstate, based in Northbrook, Ill., said it plans to focus on its core businesses of auto, home and life insurance. Shares of Allstate rose $1.375, to $52. The company's reserves for asbestos removal claims would be increased by about $75 million, while reserves for cleanup of contaminated soil would be increased by $170 million. Those reserves would rise to about $1.2 billion, among the largest in the industry.

title: On Comeback Trail Before 18th Birthday
description: Three years ago, Erin Davis of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was celebrated as the first freshman runner to win the Foot Locker national high school cross-country title. When the euphoria died, the celebration was over. Davis, 15 years old, had nowhere to go but down.

title: Rensselaer Institute Tries Innovations in Teaching
description: Many colleges talk about improving undergraduate education, but experts on academia say that few have done as much about it as Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, a science and engineering university near Albany.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Not Innocent, Not Guilty: No Comfort
description: IT was a dreary dawn in the Bronx yesterday, and not just because the sky was gray with the grim threat of rain. The deluge had already begun on Monday, when a Bronx judge acquitted Officer Francis X. Livoti in the choking death of Anthony Baez, unleashing outrage and disbelief from the dead man's relatives.

title: Georgetown Coach Seeks Gaming License
description: The application of the Georgetown basketball coach, JOHN THOMPSON, to operate an airport slot machine concession remains active despite earlier statements that he would withdraw his bid for a Nevada gaming license.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: The 'Breaking News' on Torricelli's Record, Sort Of
description: PRODUCER -- Larry Weitzner Media Group.

title: CHANGING TACTICS, DOLE CHALLENGES CLINTON'S ETHICS
description: In a daylong assault on President Clinton's ethics, Bob Dole turned sharply negative today, raising the specter of White House scandals that he had been avoiding, lacerating Mr. Clinton as someone whose ''word is no good'' and blaming him in a commercial for a ''moral crisis.''

title: Pairing Two Composers, One Neglected
description: The thematic title for the American Symphony Orchestra's concert on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall, ''The Composer's Voice: Influence and Originality in Hartmann and Mahler,'' had all the fire and wit of a college term paper, but the program itself was one of the more compelling this orchestra has presented in recent years. In a program note, Leon Botstein, the music director, drew comparisons between the two composers, but the theme seemed less important than the simple chance to combine segments of the repertory that strongly interested him.

title: Malaysia Moves to Rein In Radical Islamic Fundamentalism
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia is acting to curb radical Islamic fundamentalism and strengthen the modern form of the religion advocated by the government of Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad.

title: Dutch Publisher Buys Part of Blenheim Group
description: The Dutch publisher VNU said yesterday that it had acquired a 14.9 percent stake in the Blenheim Group at a cost of almost $:70 million ($108.5 million). VNU said it might expand its holding if another company tried to acquire the remaining shares in Blenheim.

title: An Irish Legend's Life And Mysterious Death
description: Mao Zedong studied the writings of Michael Collins on guerrilla warfare. So did leaders of the Soviet K.G.B. He was so revered by Yitzhak Shamir that the future Israeli leader used the code name ''Micail'' during Israel's war for independence.

title: Home Run Without Baseball
description: With a lot of help from the stars of country music and a bit of a boost from the people running Major League Baseball, CBS pulled the biggest upset of the new television season by winning the weekly ratings race.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Growth Expected in Chips, As Book-to-Bill Ratio Rises

title: Timor Isn't Indonesian
description: To the Editor:

title: Decision May Be Near on Olympic Blast Suspect
description: Federal agents have questioned a security guard who has been under suspicion in the Centennial Olympic Park bombing to decide whether to clear him, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Wal-Mart's Sales Stronger As Expansion Is Planned
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that sales at stores open at least a year rose a better-than-expected 5.6 percent in September.

title: Stand-Up Politics
description: Surely Elizabeth Dole can think of 10 good reasons why her husband, Bob, should be elected President.

title: American Brands Ends Tobacco Role
description: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its British-based Gallaher Tobacco business to shareholders, ending its role as a tobacco producer.

title: Physics in Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope's Appendix Removed; New Illness Denied
description: Pope John Paul II's appendix was removed today in a 50-minute operation that his doctors said found no traces of any new or serious ailment.

title: Elmer Berger, 88, A Foe of Zionism As Well as Israel
description: Rabbi Elmer Berger, a critic of Zionism and of the state of Israel, died on Saturday night in his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 88.

title: WEBSTER FINANCIAL TO BUY DS BANCOR IN STOCK SWAP
description: The Webster Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire DS Bancor Inc., the holding company for the Derby Savings Bank in Connecticut, in a $137 million stock swap. Under the deal, DS Bancor holders would receive about $43 of Webster common stock for each DS Bancor share held. The exchange ratio would be adjusted if Webster stock moved above $38.50 a share or below $31.50. Shares of DS Bancor rose $2.25, to $40.625, and Webster slipped 50 cents, to $34.75. Webster Financial of Waterbury, Conn., is the holding company for Webster Bank, which has 63 banking offices in central Connecticut. Derby Savings has 23 offices, mostly in southwestern Connecticut.

title: Accounts
description: Iona College, New Rochelle, to Adler Boschetto Peebles & Partners, New York, to handle its account, previously handled by CDHM Advertising, Stamford, Conn. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Theater in Review
description: Sister Makes the Audience Jump Through Her Hoops

title: Groups Try To Fashion A Congress
description: Her voice already explains giant squids to museum visitors and welcomes callers to MCI, but on Friday afternoon Melissa Leebaert, a professional narrator, was aiming for just the right blend of outrage and anguish for a political television advertisement.

title: For Burmese Drug Trade, Location Is Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: German Industry Agrees To Discuss Sick-Pay Cuts
description: Germany's biggest manufacturing companies, which infuriated unions in the last two weeks with plans to slash sick pay, have decided to talk instead of fight.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-8

title: Records Gap On Gulf War Under Scrutiny
description: The Pentagon said today that it was investigating an apparent gap in Persian Gulf war combat logs that should have recorded the destruction of an Iraqi ammunition bunker, an incident that may have exposed more than 15,000 American troops to nerve gas and other chemical weapons.

title: Sweet And Hot: The Blend That Jolts Sublimely
description: TRAVELING in west central India some years ago, we were passing the time in a restaurant outside the Poona train station awaiting the ironically titled Bombay Express. With the temperature over 100 degrees, cool drinks were definitely in order. So, we followed our rule of thumb and ordered what the locals at the next table were having -- in this case, an unfamiliar creamy white soft drink. As soon as the drink arrived, we both gulped it down -- and almost spit it out. The drink was as salty as Coca-Cola is sweet.

title: Only Arab Self-Interest Can End Israeli Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Notes
description: Making and Drinking Wine

title: Graf Withdraws From Zurich Tournament
description: STEFFI GRAF, forced by a knee injury to pull out of the Leipzig Open tennis tournament last week, will also sit out the European Indoors in Zurich next week, tournament organizers said yesterday. The world's No. 1 female player pulled out of the Leipzig tournament just hours before her semifinal match against fourth-seeded ANKE HUBER. Graf said the problem was a flare-up of a knee injury that has bothered her since Wimbledon in June. (AP)

title: How to Watch Tonight's Debate
description: A candidates' debate is very similar to an automobile race. People say they watch to see fine competitors performing at the very peak of their game, but in truth most of them are just waiting for a disaster.

title: Messier's Hit Earns 2-Game Suspension
description: Rangers General Manager Neil Smith registered a strong complaint about today's league-ordered two-game suspension of Captain Mark Messier, but Messier calmly accepted the punishment -- with a caveat.

title: Slow Auction Causes a Slip In Bond Prices
description: Treasury prices slipped yesterday after an auction of new 10-year Treasury notes failed to encourage buying.

title: 2 Theorists of Real-Life Problems Get Nobel
description: James A. Mirrlees of Cambridge University in Britain and William Vickrey, a Canadian-born professor emeritus at Columbia University, won the 1996 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for what the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences called ''their fundamental contributions to the economic theory of incentives'' in an area of microeconomics dealing with situations where decision makers have different information.

title: Help for Lace Embroiderers
description: Northern New Jersey's 120-year-old, $300-million-a-year lace and embroidery industry is experiencing tough times. According to state commerce officials, the embroiderers -- 400 mostly family-run shops in North Bergen and Union City and nearby towns, employing 4,000 people -- have seen sales drop 20 percent over 15 years because of cheaper foreign competition.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Polluted Ponds
description: To The Living Section:

title: Art Served on a Plate
description: FOR more than 30 years, visitors to restaurants in Italy who ordered certain regional specialties received a ceramic souvenir plate, which was included in the price of the food item. Now, 21 Italian restaurants in this country, including 13 in the New York area, will be offering the same kind of souvenir, but at a price: $12 a dish.

title: Lockheed Contract Ended
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation's $1.3 billion contract with the Internal Revenue Service for a sophisticated computer imaging system was canceled today.

title: Bee Loves Orchid; Little Beetle Works Very Hard
description: In a French meadow, showing off lots of leg and twitching antennae, a hot new crop of movie stars is ready for those close-ups, Mr. DeMille. Bugs are amazingly beautiful in ''Microcosmos,'' a rapt, witty nature documentary that uses high-powered lenses to invade their fractious world.

title: Defuse Youths' Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: More Stand-Up Comics, Real and Cartoon-Form
description: Comedy Central, the joint venture of Time Warner Entertainment and Viacom, is tickling the new television season with something new and something old. And as might be expected from the outfit that brought you ''Mystery Science Theater'' and the British sitcom ''Absolutely Fabulous,'' there's a heaping serving of laughs.

title: Plumbing the Physics of Tumbling Toast
description: To the Editor:

title: Eurotunnel Shares Fall After Debt Revamping
description: Eurotunnel's shares fell yesterday as investors reacted negatively to a debt restructuring intended to keep the Channel Tunnel operating company afloat. On the London Stock Exchange, Eurotunnel closed down 8.5 pence a share, at 105, in the first trading since trading had been suspended last week while the new debt package was arranged with bankers.

title: As Trial Nears For Militia, Some Charges Are Dropped
description: Four months after 12 members of the Viper Militia were arrested in a nationwide burst of publicity, Federal prosecutors in Arizona seem to be backing away from original assertions of a concrete conspiracy to attack government buildings.

title: New York Has Taught David Cone About Baseball, and Life
description: David Cone glided across cracks in the sidewalks, weaved around the pedestrians and used Greenwich Village to try to outdistance an exasperating loss that still burdened him. It was a cool night last October, and Cone walked alongside a friend who had coaxed him into leaving his East Side apartment for the first time in almost three weeks. But he was actually flying solo. Floating and wondering, oblivious to everything except a post-season baseball game in Seattle, a game that turned terribly awry.

title: Another Investor Suit for Chateau Properties
description: Directors of Chateau Properties Inc. have been hit with another shareholder suit over a planned merger with ROC Communities, a rival operator of mobile-home parks.

title: Merrill's Debt Is Upgraded
description: Moody's Investors Service raised its rating yesterday on the debt of Merrill Lynch & Company above that of any other securities firm because of Merrill's strength in investment banking and brokerage.

title: Yankees Will Go On Without Gooden
description: Dwight Gooden, tugged in different directions by disappointment and relief, learned yesterday that his season was over, ending speculation that he might again ride to the Yankees' rescue. Gooden will not be inserted on the active roster for the American League Championship Series against the Baltimore Orioles or on a World Series roster, the team announced yesterday.

title: Language Study Shifts Again: Chinese Is Up, Russian Down
description: In a dramatic shift in their choice of foreign languages to study, more and more American college students are taking Chinese and Arabic at the expense of French, German and Russian, according to a new study by the Modern Language Association of America.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Sunday about the Columbia-Holy Cross football game misstated Columbia's place in the Ivy League standing. Four teams, including Columbia, share first place with 1-0 league records. Including games played with teams that are not in the Ivy League, Dartmouth and Columbia have the best overall records, 3-0.

title: New Rulers Won't Ease Restrictions, Afghan Says
description: The militant Muslims who lead Afghanistan's new Government vowed today that there would be no relenting in their drive to create what is fast becoming one of the most repressive societies.

title: Wine Talk
description: SINCE it opened more than a decade ago, the Union Square Cafe on 16th Street has been on the cutting edge of innovation in food, wine and service. Like many other restaurateurs, Danny Meyer, an owner, has long been aware that many of his customers are uncomfortable with a wine list -- any wine list. For some time, he has been searching for a way to make ordering wine as easy as possible.

title: Residents Flee Plant Fire
description: Some 125 residents of the Warren County community of Washington were evacuated yesterday morning for about 80 minutes after a leak at a chemical manufacturing plant caused a small fire, officials said. The leak occurred in an area where workers at the BASF Wyandotte plant were mixing propylene oxide and ethylene oxide to form an agent used in detergents, toothpastes and mouthwash, Roy Busch, the plant manager, said.

title: 'Safe' in the Kitchen
description: To The Living Section:

title: They All Work
description: To the Editor:

title: E. K. Thompson, 89, Editor Who Helped Shape Life Magazine
description: Edward K. Thompson, a former editor of Life magazine and the founding editor of Smithsonian magazine, died on Monday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 89 and had lived in a nursing home in Somers, N.Y., for the last three years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KAISER ALUMINUM CORP., Houston, confirmed that it had distributed an internal memo to employees saying that it planned significant cost cuts and other measures to improve profits by the end of 1997.

title: Austrians May Challenge Muster's Fine
description: Austrian tennis officials yesterday mulled legal action over an International Tennis Federation decision to uphold a fine against THOMAS MUSTER for his Davis Cup doubles walkout. Muster and his manager expressed disappointment at the verdict.

title: The retail action heats up west of Eighth Avenue on 34th Street as B&H Photo leases a building.
description: IN a transaction that will help extend the 34th Street shopping corridor west of Eighth Avenue, B & H Photo, a major retailer of photographic and video equipment, has leased an entire 70,000-square-foot, two-story building that occupies the full block of Ninth Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Motorola Expects Chip Growth to Resume
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it expects growth to resume in the semiconductor industry next year, a prediction bolstered later in the day by the release of an industry report indicating a stronger-than-expected book-to-bill ratio.

title: Reich Has Experience In Rallying His Teams
description: Frank Reich is used to playing second fiddle. As a collegian at Maryland, he was the backup quarterback to his roommate, Boomer Esiason. In the National Football League, he starred as a 10-year backup to Jim Kelly with the Buffalo Bills, then spent last year as a three-game stand-in for the Carolina Panthers while the rookie Kerry Collins learned the job.

title: An Ex-Officer Admits Attack On Another
description: A former transit police officer pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor charge of assaulting a female officer who had counseled him during his recovery from a 1994 shooting.

title: Be prepared to pay a lot more, and pay in advance, to be in Hong Kong next summer.
description: HONG KONG will revert to Chinese rule on July 1, but airlines that fly there, as well as American hotel chains with properties there, say their planes and hotels are already rapidly filling up for the weeks just before and just after the change of sovereignty.

title: Oxford Health Plans to Cover Alternative Care
description: Oxford Health Plans said today that it would add alternative-medicine coverage to some of its health plans, making it the first company to form a network of practitioners offering services like chiropractic and massage therapy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SARAH FERGUSON, the Duchess of York, yesterday vehemently denied reports in British tabloids and on American television and radio newscasts that she had been placed on a suicide watch by Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Judge Rules a Man Was Assaulted by a Suffolk Official
description: In 1989, Maurice J. Mathie killed a man. As he was awaiting trial in the Suffolk County jail, he says, he was raped by the chief of security.

title: Wife Denies Killing Husband
description: When the police went to a Fort Lee apartment last weekend to serve David Clark with a restraining order sought by his wife, they found Mr. Clark's body instead, prosecutors say. The wife, Barbara Lopez Clark, 30, was subsequently charged with the multiple stabbing of Mr. Clark on Oct. 1, four days before she asked for the protective order, said Michael Maher, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor.

title: New in Aerobics: Pumping Rope
description: LISA WEBER, 23, started jumping rope when she was 10, and she hasn't stopped. In elementary and junior high school, she was on rope-skipping teams and competed in tournaments. ''Even now, in college, you see people doing it,'' said Ms. Weber, a senior at the University of Northern Colorado at Greeley. ''At my college, I have four or five former team members, and we get together to jump.''

title: Bibi and the King
description: They were all sitting around the dining table in the White House Blue Room last Wednesday. Benjamin Netanyahu had spoken, as had Yasir Arafat and President Clinton. After waiters passed out sorbet and fruit, only King Hussein was left to speak. It was the most important speech of the summit -- one Mr. Netanyahu didn't share with the Israeli public.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Falls 36.15 Points, Ahead of Earnings Reports

title: For Landlords, Hard Numbers and Obligations
description: In a tenement in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, tenants lay out a daily offering of rice and beans on hard hallway tiles. The food is given in thanks to Susie, a dog, who has taken over responsibility for killing rats from a landlord who has not been seen in years.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Waterlilies in Winter

title: Homebound French Artisans
description: SINCE 1950, exquisitely embroidered napkins, tablecloths and place mats by Penelope have been standard items in Paris's tony neighborhoods and French embassies around the world. Given the quality of the needlework, it seems only natural. What is surprising are its creators: homebound women that Penelope, a nonprofit group, provides with a salary and social support. The artisans' works will be in New York starting on Nov. 7, when a Penelope exhibition opens at Pierre Deux, 870 Madison Avenue (71st Street); (212) 570-9343. Penelope's Paris store is at 19 Avenue Victor Hugo; (011) 33-1-45-00-90-90. Prices for a tablecloth with four napkins start at $400 and run to $2,000 for a 12-napkin set.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lopez Comes Up Big With Bat as Braves Win Game 1 in N.L.
description: Javier Lopez admitted he was nervous. But it was a good nervous. ''When I'm nervous, I concentrate more,'' he said later.

title: Shunning the Sound Bite
description: Last Sunday night, Bob Dole did not do it. For whatever reason -- lack of passion, strategic miscalculation or oversight in the heat of the moment -- he failed to make much of a case for his proposed 15 percent tax cut in debating President Clinton.

title: Museums Weep For Their Tupperware
description: A YOUNG child at the Museum of Modern Art looks up at the 47D-1 helicopter designed in 1945, a symbol of design sophistication coupled with functional bravado that hovers like a guardian angel over the fourth-floor escalator. He wrinkles his nose and exclaims: ''Yuck! It's dirty!''

title: Bush vs. Whatshisname
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cable TV Fight, Mayor Plans to Put Fox Channel on a City Station
description: The Giuliani administration intensified its confrontation with Time Warner last night, announcing that because the company's cable systems refused to carry a 24-hour news channel started by Rupert Murdoch, the city would put the channel on one of its five municipal-run cable stations.

title: Goldman in Talks on Deal
description: Goldman Sachs Group L.P. is in talks to acquire Liberty Investment Management Inc., in the latest step to increase its asset management business, people familiar with the situation said yesterday. Liberty Investment, a Tampa-based money manager with almost $5 billion in assets -- mostly stocks -- might be worth at least 3 percent of assets, or $150 million, according to Eli Neusner, an analyst with Cerulli Associates, a Boston-based firm that tracks the money management industry.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 17 about the settlement of a libel case filed by Jorge Mas Canosa, the leader of a Cuban exile group in the United States, against The New Republic misstated the issue in the lawsuit. It involved wording in the headline and an overline, not in the article itself.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine to Dr. Peter C. Doherty and Dr. Rolf M. Zinkernagel misstated an affiliation of Dr. Doherty. He is with St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, not St. Jude's Medical Center.

title: Lawsuits Unlimited
description: Have you heard the latest lawyer joke? It's called Proposition 211, the California initiative that would make the state a haven for suits against companies by their shareholders.

title: AMOCO TO SELL STATIONS IN BULGARIA, POLAND AND ROMANIA
description: The Amoco Corporation will sell its gasoline retailing business in Poland, Romania and Bulgaria, just four months after opening its first service station in the region. The Chicago-based oil company had said it would invest more than $200 million to get back into Europe, but sales in central Europe fell short of expectations. Now the company's plans focus on growth in the United States, it said. Amoco, the fifth-largest United States oil company by market capitalization, said it would sell four existing sites and 14 under construction in the three countries.

title: Canada Strike Against G.M. Widens as Two Sides Harden
description: A week-old strike by Canadian workers of the General Motors Corporation spread further this evening, as the auto maker's chairman signaled that the company would not quickly back down in the dispute.

title: Walter Kerr, a Dominant Critic During Broadway's Full Flower, Is Dead at 83
description: Walter Kerr, a critic who for more than three decades was a major force in American theater, died yesterday at the Cabrini Nursing Home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 83 and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: A Hero Who Defies Mortality And Logic
description: ''Outis,'' Luciano Berio's extravagant new stage piece, is heavy thinking for the ear and the eye. Is there a real me underneath my clothes, it seems to ask, or am I redefined daily by the color of my shirt or my choice of shoes? Is my life a story -- with a beginning, an end and consequences in between -- or does it dangle in space and time, a collision of events?

title: Blame Men, Not Allah, Islamic Feminists Say
description: Are Muslim men allowed to beat their wives? Are men and women equal before Allah?

title: Dole's Attacks on Teacher Unions Hit Sour Note for Some Ohio Republicans
description: John P. Dougherty, the president of the Stark County board of commissioners, Scott Oelslager, the State Senator from this area, as well as Jim Craig, Ken McPeek, Sally Efremoff and Fred Krum, all longtime local school board members, are moderate suburban Republicans who voted for George Bush in 1992. And they have all had the same basic reaction as they have listened to Bob Dole repeatedly single out the teachers' unions as the major obstacle to education reform in this country.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Fell 28.9% in August
description: Japan's huge surplus in its current account, the broadest measure of trade in goods and services, shrank in August as the flow of foreign goods into the country continued to increase. The current account surplus dropped 28.9 percent, to 460.60 billion yen, or $4.14 billion, from a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. The surplus in merchandise trade alone decreased 27.8 percent, to 566.70 billion yen, or $5.10 billion, from a year earlier.

title: Japanese Market Closed
description: The stock market here was closed today in observance of a Japanese national holiday, Health Sports Day, and will reopen Friday morning. On Thursday, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues declined 167.70 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,870.83, the index's second consecutive daily decrease.

title: Common Cause Accuses Parties of 'Massive' Violations
description: In an attack on campaign spending practices, Common Cause accused the Democratic and Republican Parties today of breaking Federal election law by paying for television commercials for President Clinton and Bob Dole. The group urged the Justice Department to appoint an independent counsel to investigate.

title: A Tax Cut for Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: South Carolina

title: Robert Wilson Receives Lillian Gish Prize
description: The director Robert Wilson is the recipient of the 1996 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize. Established by the actress Lillian Gish, who died in 1993, the prize consists of a cash stipend of $200,000 and a silver medallion. It will be presented to Mr. Wilson at a ceremony next Thursday in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Pushes Bigger NATO Despite Qualms on Russia
description: Despite new uncertainties about the possible Russian reaction and the qualms of some NATO allies, the United States is pushing ahead with its plan to bring several former Soviet allies into NATO in 1999.

title: Bavaria, Acting Alone, Begins to Expel Bosnian War Refugees
description: Acting alone among German authorities, the conservative southern state of Bavaria today became the first to embark on a threatened forcible expulsion of Bosnian war refugees.

title: DeBrusk Is Suspended
description: Left wing LOUIE DeBRUSK of Edmonton was suspended for four games by the National Hockey League yesterday as a result of a slashing incident against Vancouver defenseman DANA MURZYN.

title: Grammatical? Not Him
description: To the Editor:

title: Bears Backup Is Out
description: Chicago's backup quarterback STEVE STENSTROM has a broken heel bone in his right foot and will probably miss the rest of the season.

title: Miami Passer Ready For Seminoles Part II
description: When Ryan Clement recalls his performance for the University of Miami last season in a 41-17 loss to Florida State, the quarterback describes it as ''personally the most embarrassing day of my life, as a ballplayer and as a person.''

title: New Factor In a Slaying: Racial Slur
description: A new witness has come forward to say that racial insults fueled the argument over a Dobbs Ferry parking space that led to the slaying last week of a black sanitation worker by an off-duty white New York City police officer, the authorities said today.

title: A Privatization Plan Challenges Cooperative's Long-Held Idealism
description: Forty-six years ago, when William Stern moved into Co-op Village, a complex of union-financed co-ops on the Lower East Side, it was a workingman's dream come true.

title: Taiwan's Islets
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Are Indicted in Plot to Smuggle Chinese Aliens Into New York
description: Breaking up a scheme to smuggle more than 100 illegal Chinese immigrants into Massachusetts and then transport them to sweatshops in New York, the United States Attorney's office here has indicted three Chinese residents of New York on charges of alien smuggling.

title: U.S., Fearing Security Risks, Delays Evacuation of Kurds
description: The Clinton Administration's plans to evacuate a second group of Iraqi relief workers from the Kurdish region of northern Iraq has been delayed amid concerns that some of the workers may pose security risks to the United States, officials said today.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: SBS TECHNOLOGIES TO ACQUIRE BIT 3 COMPUTER
description: SBS Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Bit 3 Computer Corporation, a privately held maker of computer networking products, for $24 million. SBS Technologies, a maker of electronic and computer products based in Albuquerque, N.M., said the purchase was contingent on an offering of its common stock, set to close Dec. 20. Bit 3 Computer had 1995 income of about $4.7 million before taxes on sales of about $12.5 million. SBS Technologies said costs associated with the purchase will reduce earnings in its second quarter ending Dec. 31 by $11 million, resulting in a loss for the quarter. In last year's second quarter, the company earned $776,000.

title: Pataki Ready To Outline Welfare Plan Next Week
description: Facing mounting pressure to respond to the new Federal welfare law, the Pataki administration said today that it would release a plan next week outlining how the state intends to comply with the law.

title: The Bet Is on High Consumer Demand and Low Inventory
description: Here is all that has to happen for retailers to have their best Christmas in years: No more than an inch of snow can blanket the Northeast in December; the stock market must continue to go gangbusters; stores will have to have whisper-thin stacks of inventory, and shoppers -- well trained to buy stuff only when it is on sale -- must suddenly agree to pay full price just for the fun of it. This with five fewer shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

title: Suddenly, Bats Are Welcome
description: THERE is a boom in bat house development, and bats couldn't be happier. Or so homeowners hope.

title: Bill Be Limbo
description: Bill Clinton has given us the Limbo Presidency. (Bill be limbo, Bill be quick, Bill go under the limbo stick.)

title: VALUE HEALTH IS PLANNING SPINOFF OF BENEFIT UNIT
description: Value Health Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its prescription-drug benefit unit, Valuerx. Valuerx generates 80 percent of Value Health's revenue, but it contributes very little to earnings. Value Health plans to go back to its roots as a managed-care company, retaining its mental health, workers' compensation and disease-management businesses. The company also plans to buy a workers' compensation managed-care company from Beverly Enterprises Inc. for $87.5 million and repurchase as much as $100 million in common stock. In a tax-free spinoff, shareholders will get an as yet undetermined number of shares in Valuerx, which will be publicly traded.

title: A Playground for Adults
description: It may be October, but on a corner in lower Manhattan a sort of spring has sprung.

title: Invisible Man at the Presidential Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Meaning of 'No'
description: To The Editor:

title: Police Sergeant Charged With Assault
description: A police sergeant was charged yesterday with assaulting a handcuffed burglary suspect on the Upper West Side in June by pushing him face down onto the sidewalk, according to the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Scandals Force the 2 Belgiums to Explore Inner Ills
description: The King of Belgium has just abdicated. Flanders in the north has declared its independence and French troops have rushed in to protect the French-speaking south. In Brussels, the headquarters of the European Union is being protected by several armies as civil war turns the Belgian capital into a new Sarajevo.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: VALUE HEALTH IS PLANNING SPINOFF OF BENEFIT UNIT

title: Champion of Democracy in China Draws 3-Year Sentence
description: The authorities sentenced without trial a pro-democracy activist, Liu Xiaobo, to three years in a labor camp today after he called on the Communist Party to honor promises to allow freedom of speech and assembly and the right to form political parties.

title: The Blue Line Between Rat And Right
description: OFFICER DAISY BORIA says it herself, without prompting. She has become what police officers call a rat. Two weeks ago, she contradicted her own partner during the trial of Francis X. Livoti, the officer accused -- and just acquitted -- of homicide. And last year, she filed a lawsuit charging the Police Department with sexual harassment.

title: Mexican Drug Wars Creep Near U.S. Border
description: The swaggering adolescent in cowboy boots shoved past a stream of American tourists and stepped into the nine lanes of traffic inching through the afternoon heat toward the United States border. Suddenly, he pushed a 9-millimeter pistol through a car window and fired four times at the driver's head.

title: From Uncle Sam, a Helpful Hint on Wedding Gifts
description: MOVE over, Miss Manners. The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has a tip for brides- and grooms-to-be: Forgo the flatware.

title: Less Than 20,000 Leagues Under
description: PUBLIC-SPACE advocates swear by strong lighting and easy-to-read signs. The new Arts et Metiers station, a Paris subway stop beneath the museum of the same name, instead courts mystery. The copper-clad walls are studded with ''portholes'' framing dioramas (left), and overhead, fake cogwheels, bathed in subaqueous light, turn slowly as trains enter the station. Transit officials feared that the murky atmospherics would cause ''a feeling of anxiousness,'' said the station's designer, Francois Schuiten, 40, a Belgian artist whose work is inspired by Jules Verne. ''But it's relaxing and quiet.'' Since the Conservatoire National des Arts et Metiers, on the Right Bank, charts the history of technology and engineering, handmade rivets were used alongside fiber-optic lighting, and standard-issue plastic seats were rejected in favor of carved wooden replicas. History fuels the future, the designer said, and ''that cannot be forgotten.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Orioles Find That Weirdness Never Ends
description: The Baltimore Orioles would like to leave the Twilight Zone. Now. But the Yankees won't let them.

title: A Temple Art Collaboration
description: To The Home Section:

title: Judge Backs Extradition Of a Palestinian to Israel
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to stop the extradition of a political leader of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group, from the United States to Israel, where he faces criminal charges that he financed and helped organize terrorist attacks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Presidential politics in New Jersey misspelled the surnames of the political correspondent for New Jersey public television and a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University who advises Republican candidates. The reporter is Michael Aron, not Aaron; the professor is Stephen Salmore, not Falmore.

title: The Killing of Anthony Baez
description: Judges rarely go public to defend their rulings, as Acting Justice Gerald Sheindlin did this week after acquitting a New York City police officer in the choking death of 29-year-old Anthony Baez. This media exercise could have been avoided if Justice Sheindlin's original opinion had been clearer in explaining how he reached his decision. As it stands now, the justice's post-trial explanations have further confused the public, undermining faith in a decision that was already difficult to follow.

title: Dole Hints About a 'Surprise' For Clinton at the Next Debate
description: Bob Dole said today that he might have some ''surprises'' for President Clinton when the two meet in their second and last debate next Wednesday in San Diego.

title: AMR RAISES OFFERING PRICE FOR RESERVATION SYSTEM
description: The AMR Corporation raised the initial public offering price for its Sabre Group Holdings Inc. unit to as much as $545.4 million in a sign of strong investor demand. The parent of American Airlines raised the share price for the initial offering of its reservations system to between $25 and $27 each, according to an amended Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The company had expected to sell shares for $20 to $23 each to raise as much as $464.6 million. AMR plans to sell a 15.8 percent stake in Sabre through an offering of 20.2 million class A common shares. AMR would continue to hold 107.3 million class B shares. Under the revised prices, AMR will receive about $495 million after expenses if the shares sell for $26 each.

title: NEW DETECTORS INDICATE SHARDS NEAR T.W.A. SITE
description: Using new bottom-piercing sonar, Navy salvage workers have located what could be additional wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800, buried under a few inches of sand on the ocean floor.

title: Their Own Banks, Wines and Style
description: IN the world of finance, the name Rothschild means private banking. In the world of design, it is a style: ''le gout Rothschild.'' Written by Pauline Prevost-Marcilhacy (Flammarion, $150), ''Les Rothschild'' is a picture-packed, scholarly study of 57 of the clan's houses, from ormolu-clogged chateaus to engaging follies like Robert de Rothschild's 1928 mirrored garden and children's rooms by Emile Ruhlmann. Missing, however, is the house that had the biggest impact on 20th-century decor: Philippe de Rothschild's Grand Mouton, a remodeled warehouse near Bordeaux that was a byword for 1960's luxury. It is a curious omission.

title: Among Persian Nomads, A Tale of Young Longing
description: From an isolated hut not far from a burbling brook, an elderly man and woman emerge, bickering in the familiar way of the long married about which of them is to wash their beloved gabbeh.

title: Researchers Now Doubt a Theory on Protection Against Malaria
description: An inherited blood disorder long believed to offer some protection against malaria may actually make children more vulnerable to early infections by the mosquito-borne disease, researchers said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: A 50th-Anniversary Premiere With a Changing Face
description: It is hardly news that the students at the Juilliard School perform with a measure of virtuosity and polish that some of their elders have reason to envy, but it can be easy to forget just how high that performance level is. The Juilliard Orchestra offered a reminder on Monday evening, when it played its first concert of the season at Avery Fisher Hall. Gerard Schwarz conducted, and the performance he drew from the ensemble was not only thrilling in an entirely visceral way but also showed the extraordinary responsiveness and coloristic scope that these young musicians already bring to their work.

title: Winning With a Boy's Help, Yankees Make No Apologies
description: One overzealous 12-year-old helped the Yankees rejoice on a day when all of their runs except Bernie Williams's game-winning homer were somewhat tainted. Still, after beating the Baltimore Orioles, 5-4, in 11 innings yesterday, the Yankees refused to apologize.

title: Microsoft Is Detailing Plans For Its Assault on Internet
description: It was in a speech on Pearl Harbor Day last December, that Bill Gates of Microsoft pointed to charts outlining his company's strategy for gaining a beachhead in the rapidly growing Internet market. Portraying Microsoft in the uncharacteristic role of an underdog, Mr. Gates singled out targets that included Netscape Communications, America Online, the Lotus division of I.B.M. and assorted Unix software companies.

title: A 'Net Surfer' Puts a Republican Spin on Torricelli's Record
description: This is a 30-second commercial that Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican nominee for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey, began broadcasting on Sunday. Mr. Zimmer's Democratic opponent is Representative Robert G. Torricelli.

title: Echoes of 'Mrs. Ferraro'
description: To the Editor:

title: Atom Plant May Close
description: The owners of the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant in Haddam Neck, one of four troubled nuclear complexes in the state, said yesterday that they will probably shut down the 28-year-old reactor because it has become too expensive to operate.

title: Alitalia Subsidy Draws an Inquiry
description: The European Commission ordered an official inquiry yesterday into Italy's plans to inject 1.5 trillion lire, or $1 billion, into its ailing national airline, Alitalia. The European Union's antitrust agency is worried that the bailout, to be paid by the state-owned holding company that controls Alitalia, contains state aid that the commission must approve.

title: European Rights Court to Hear Case of British Boy's Caning
description: The boy was 9 when his stepfather took a tall bamboo garden stake and beat him repeatedly, over a period of days, on the buttocks, calves and thighs. Now 12, the boy has gone to the European Court of Human Rights, arguing that Britain's corporal punishment statute -- which gave the stepfather the right to carry out the beating -- violates European law.

title: A 12-Year-Old Legend Is Born in Right Field
description: New Yorkers came to Yankee Stadium yesterday to boo Roberto Alomar of the Baltimore Orioles, who had made the mistake of spitting on an umpire two weeks ago. But they came away celebrating a controversial ''catch'' by a 12-year-old boy named Jeff Maier, a screeching 11th-inning home run by Bernie Williams and a 5-4 Yankee victory that added to the city's fabled baseball history.

title: From Alomar To a Kid, To 'Ber-nie'
description: IN the ancestral home of the Bronx cheer, which always sounded more like a cousin of the belch, a chorus of 56,495 Yankee worshipers raised the boo to an art form. And a tactical form.

title: Excerpts From Debate Between Vice President Gore and Jack Kemp
description: Following are excerpts from the debate last night in St. Petersburg, Fla., between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private company. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS.

title: How Did Man Get So Bad? Looking to the Apes
description: DEMONIC MALES

title: 11 Rikers Guards Charged in Beatings
description: Eleven corrections officers were charged yesterday with beating prisoners in Rikers Island's most notorious jail unit during a period of three years.

title: Dry Eyes for Ferre, Boos for Lagerfeld
description: Every eye, it seemed, was dry at the fare-thee-well collection of Gianfranco Ferre for the house of Christian Dior, where he has directed design for eight years. If designers deserved applause for persistence, then Mr. Ferre was entitled to the standing ovation he received at the end of the show. But the clothes hardly seemed to have elicited the designer's best effort.

title: Hispanic Stars Shining in the Pop Music Universe
description: After the Mexican mariachi star Vicente Fernandez performed at a full Radio City Music Hall last Friday, he kept right on going, to Washington, Chicago and El Paso, Tex., for a succession of sold-out concerts. By the end of his 19-concert tour, in Dallas on Nov. 10, he will have been heard by some 130,000 people, not all of them Mexican-American. Yet his tour will go mostly unnoticed by mainstream listeners in the English-speaking music world.

title: Stray Cable From Bosnia Creates Stir In Capital
description: Every day, American diplomats overseas send thousands of cables to their bosses in Washington, most of which quietly slide from in-box to archival files without making much of a ripple.

title: Sampras Caught in Eye of the Storm
description: It was about a month ago that Pete Sampras, transported for a joyful moment from what has been the most harrowing year of his life, won the United States Open and tossed his racquet into the crowd in an unrehearsed and, as it turns out, badly aimed gesture of celebration. Scant seconds after Sampras used it to batter Michael Chang into submission, the racquet completed its trajectory by landing in the stands and giving its recipient a black eye.

title: Investors Are Calling for WMX to Stick to Its Core Business
description: This morning, Phillip B. Rooney, the chief executive of WMX Technologies Inc., will be visited by Robert A. G. Monks, a principal of Lens Inc., an investment partnership that owns $25 million in WMX stock. Lens often comes down hard on the chiefs of companies that underperform, and Mr. Monks has no plan to coddle Mr. Rooney.

title: Afghan Force Counts Losses After Ambush Stalls Its Drive
description: Fighters of the Muslim force that has swept across Afghanistan counted their losses today after an ambush on a garrison in the mountains north of Kabul that seemed likely to stall their drive on the last provinces that have eluded their control.

title: Saving the Family Farm Means Giving Up Something, Too
description: ABOUT 20 miles west of Chapel Hill (where old poplars have been cut down for a parking lot) and a few miles south of Interstate 85 (where commuters zoom to Raleigh or Greensboro) is an endangered land of tall corn and lush pastures with cows and longhorn cattle. Quakers came here 200 years ago, when they ran out of land near Philadelphia, and their descendants still farm along roads (like Lindley Mill and Newlin) that bear their ancestors' names. Or that honor the town's first telephone exchange.

title: U.S. Ship Subsidies Enhance Global Status
description: To the Editor:

title: JACOR COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY REGENT COMMUNICATIONS
description: Jacor Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire closely held Regent Communications Inc. of Covington, Ky., which owns or operates 20 radio stations in five markets. Under terms of the deal, Jacor will issue Regent 3.55 million common shares, which are currently worth about $120 million, and warrants to buy 500,000 Jacor common shares at $40 apiece. It will also assume $64 million of Regent debt. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Jacor slipped 37.5 cents, to $33.75. Regent has radio stations in Kansas City, Kan.; Salt Lake City; Las Vegas, Nev.; Louisville, Ky., and Charleston, S.C. The company had revenue of $32.1 million in 1995. Including pending transactions, Jacor, based in Cincinnati, has 92 radio stations in 20 cities.

title: High Drama, Hi-jinks, High-Fives
description: Yankee Stadium offered up high drama this evening, giving baseball fans both a villain to boo and a hero to cheer, lessons to forget and to learn.

title: Now, Paris Is City of Angels
description: LEAVE it to the capital of style to have angelic graffiti. Appearing on doors, walls and scaffolding in the best Paris neighborhoods -- Saint-Germain-des-Pres, for example, and shopping streets near the Louvre -- is a series of whimsical angels, all dreamy smiles and wavy hair, drawn with pastels. Some images are dated, but all are unsigned and the artist is unknown. Property owners might not be pleased with this seraphic squad, but others find the angels a lyrical alternative to spray-painted gang tags. ''It is a kind of decoration, to make the town more beautiful,'' said Annette Huard, a civil engineer for the City of Paris.

title: Safety Group Reports Rise In Fatalities On Highways
description: Deaths involving drunken drivers rose 4 percent last year in the first increase in a decade, as overall traffic fatalities continued a three-year rise, the National Safety Council said today.

title: Inchcape Testing Unit Sold for $585 Million
description: Inchcape P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold its industrial testing business to Charterhouse Development Capital Ltd., a private investment firm, for $:380 million , or about $585 million. The sale is part of a plan by Inchcape to concentrate on its main international trading business, which deals in such goods as cars, food, liquor and clothing. Inchcape also plans to dispose of its Bain Hogg insurance unit. (AP)

title: Miscellany
description: Crispin & Porter Advertising, Miami, will be renamed Crispin Porter & Bogusky, effective Nov. 1, to reflect the contributions of Alex Bogusky, partner and creative director.

title: After Revival of New York Library, Fiscal Wonders at Brown
description: As president of the New York Public Library, Vartan Gregorian made his mark as a fund-raiser extraordinaire, the man who helped rescue the world-renowned public institution after it fell on hard times. But when he took over as president of Brown University in 1989, he vowed never to become chief fund-raiser.

title: Homosexuality and Analysis
description: To The Home Section:

title: Whalers Finally Trade Shanahan for Coffey
description: Hartford is finally in Brendan Shanahan's rearview mirror.

title: H.M.O.'s Switch Drugs, but Not Just for Price
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Comments by Fed Governor Send Treasury Prices Lower
description: After waffling through most of the trading session, prices of Treasury securities deteriorated yesterday after comments by Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor.

title: Walls With Personality
description: IN decorating, it's often the objects with personality, rather than pedigree, that triumph. Between posters and serious investments for the walls are a multitude of decorative options, some funky but all fine. Uncovering these ''treasures'' might take some hunting, but others are right under your nose.

title: Lindros Out 1-2 Weeks
description: The groin pull that has sidelined Philadelphia Flyers center ERIC LINDROS for the first two games of the season might keep him out of the lineup for another one or two weeks.

title: 13-Foot-Long Pet Python Kills Its Caretaker
description: A 13-foot python, kept as a pet in a Bronx housing project by two teen-age brothers who hoped to make careers out of caring for reptiles, killed one of the brothers yesterday afternoon, possibly having mistaken him for food.

title: Pint-Sized Sexual Politics
description: The nation's attention recently descended on two young boys charged with ''sexual harassment.'' A 6-year-old from North Carolina who kissed a girl was separated from his class for a day. Then a 7-year-old Queens boy was suspended for five days after kissing a girl and tearing a button from her skirt.

title: Corrupt Practices?
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurer to Curb Sales Of Policies on Coasts
description: A large insurer plans to curtail sharply the sale of new homeowner policies in coastal areas in East Coast and Gulf of Mexico states. The decision by Nationwide Insurance would be the most extensive retrenchment by insurers reeling from losses caused by hurricanes, earthquakes and other huge disasters.

title: Democrats Urge Veto of Measure Easing Pipeline Regulations
description: House Democrats and environmentalists are urging the Clinton Administration to veto legislation that would hold pipeline regulations to a cost-benefit test, saying it would unduly ease rules intended to prevent oil spills and gas explosions.

title: Isles Tied. Milbury Fit To Be Tied.
description: Islanders Coach Mike Milbury has warned everyone within earshot that his team has to learn how to win. There figure to be few doubters after tonight, when the Islanders fell a mere 1.5 seconds shy of their first victory of the season.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a Long Island teen-ager who died after being punched misidentified his school. He attended a culinary program at the Islip Learning Center, not Commack High School.

title: Economy Dominates Kemp-Gore Debate
description: Vice President Al Gore and his Republican challenger, Jack Kemp, faced off last night in a 90-minute debate that presented voters with rival economic messages and partisan cross-sniping over social issues like abortion and affirmative action that have received scant airing in the Presidential contest.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Rarely Heard Pieces for the Guitar
description: A Pairing With the Harpsichord

title: Japan Seeks to Resume Air Talks With U.S.
description: Japan has asked the United States to resume high-level talks on a dispute concerning the liberalization of the $6 billion aviation market between the two nations, a Japanese Transport Ministry official said yesterday. Japan is still awaiting a reply from the United States, said the official, who added that no date had yet been set.

title: Marvel's bad quarter raises doubts about Perelman's plans.
description: LEAVE it to Wall Street to find a way to make money on bad news.

title: British and Irish Premiers Say Ulster Talks Are Still On
description: The Prime Ministers of Ireland and Britain said today that efforts to achieve peace in Northern Ireland were certainly damaged, but not extinguished, by the I.R.A. attack on a British Army base in Ulster.

title: A Kewpie Doll
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher Drops In, But Africa Is Unmoved
description: Since Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrived in this West African country two days ago, he has seemingly struggled at each public appearance to erase the impression that this continent matters little to a Clinton Administration preoccupied with problems elsewhere.

title: Events: Antiques Shows And Sales
description: Indian and Asian Artworks

title: Shift at Top of Montgomery Ward Is Seen
description: Bernard F. Brennan, the chief executive of Montgomery Ward & Company, the troubled department store chain, will soon be replaced, people familiar with the situation said yesterday.

title: Enforcing Cigarette Laws
description: The Health and Senior Services Commissioner, Leonard Fishman, urged local and county health officials yesterday to start enforcing the law barring minors from buying cigarettes.

title: Comeback for Leonard?
description: Perhaps he only wants to know that someone still thinks he's worth $5 million. Perhaps it is only talk that often goes nowhere. But SUGAR RAY LEONARD is negotiating to make a fourth comeback attempt. At least, that's what HECTOR (MACHO) CAMACHO's promoter, MIKE ACRI, said yesterday as he discussed a possible bout between the two.

title: Torricelli Meets Elderly, Stressing Medicare
description: Seeking to portray himself as the candidate elderly voters can trust, Representative Robert G. Torricelli took his campaign for the United State Senate to a senior center in a church basement here today to note that it had been one year since his Republican opponent voted to cut the growth of the Medicare program.

title: Whoopi Goldberg Plans To Play Lead in 'Forum'
description: The producers of ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' announced yesterday that Whoopi Goldberg would replace Nathan Lane in the lead of the hit musical at the St. James Theater after Mr. Lane leaves the show on Feb. 9.

title: German Utility Spurns One Venture for Another
description: RWE A.G., a large German utility, abandoned a partnership with Viag A.G. and British Telecommunications P.L.C. yesterday, instead joining an alliance with Veba A.G. and Cable and Wireless P.L.C. The shift reshuffles the German telecommunications landscape barely a year before full competition is set to begin in that market.

title: Fox's 24-Hour News Is Oddly Familiar
description: With no truce yet in the battle over whether New York City cable customers served or disserved by Time Warner will be permitted to receive the new Fox News channel, the least a reviewer can do is offer a glimpse of what many New Yorkers are missing.

title: Teen-Agers Find Drugs Easy to Obtain and Warnings Easy to Ignore
description: Nicole, a high school junior with short brown hair, soft eyes and a delicate chin, has smoked marijuana since she was 13 years old. Many of her friends at her Massachusetts high school use it too, and sometimes her father joins her.

title: Clinton Signs a Wide-Ranging Measure on Airport Security
description: In a move to increase air safety after the crash of TWA Flight 800, President Clinton today signed an aviation bill that includes a range of new baggage-scanning, passenger-screening and counter-terrorism measures as part of a program of stepped-up surveillance at airports.

title: Discoveries of Superfluid Helium, and 'Buckyballs,' Earn Nobels for 6 Scientists
description: Six scientists, five of them Americans, shared two Nobel Prizes yesterday, one for founding an important branch of chemistry based on molecules shaped like soccer balls, and the other for discovering intriguing connections between the physics of the ultra-small and the ultra-large.

title: Richard W. Porter, 83, Led Early Space Effort
description: Dr. Richard W. Porter, an orchid-growing, clarinet-playing electrical engineer turned rocket scientist, who supervised the nation's first venture into space, died on Sunday while traveling by train from Washington to New York. He was 83 and lived in North Branford, Conn.

title: Films of Massine Ballets
description: Archival films of rarely seen ballets by Leonide Massine will be shown tonight at 6 at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, 40 Lincoln Center Plaza. ''The Good-Humored Ladies'' and ''Jeux d'Enfants'' will be shown at the free screening, as well as ''Capriccio Espagnol,'' directed by Jean Negulesco, and Massine's 1928 performance of the farruca from ''The Three-Cornered Hat.'' Information: (212) 870-1630.

title: U.S. Ship Subsidies Enhance Global Status
description: To the Editor:

title: Belated Beginning for the M.L.S. Semifinal Round
description: Major League Soccer has lost some momentum in its inaugural playoff campaign. Having to juggle stadium availability and conflicts with World Cup qualifying matches, the league will start its semifinals tonight, eight days after the conclusion of the first round of the playoffs.

title: Panel on Gulf War Ills Says Poor Records Hampered Its Inquiry
description: Scientific studies of illnesses reported by some veterans of the Persian Gulf War have been hampered by inadequate and scattered military medical records, an expert panel said today.

title: Pentagon Accused of 'Dismissive' Attitude on Gulf War Veterans
description: The staff of a special White House panel today accused the Defense Department of providing information to ailing veterans of the Persian Gulf war that was ''patronizing or dismissive'' of their concerns that they may have been exposed to Iraqi chemical or biological weapons during the war.

title: The Boss Is Back in His Element
description: Even if Yankee Stadium is not really George Steinbrenner's backyard, there was no mistaking who the host was yesterday afternoon as the Yankees took on the Baltimore Orioles in the first game of the American League Championship Series. And no matter how he reacted when the Yankees tied the score on Derek Jeter's tainted home run, or when they won it on Bernie Williams's blast, before the game took on its shape, Steinbrenner's well-established bluster was all in the service of, well, service.

title: Corning Will Plead Guilty to Medicare Fraud
description: In the one of the biggest Medicare fraud settlements involving a clinical laboratory company, Corning Inc. agreed yesterday in Boston to plead guilty to Federal fraud charges and pay $119 million in criminal fines and civil penalties.

title: Sleek American Style From Monte Carlo
description: Monte Carlo is a magic name in ballet history, most of which is best forgotten when looking at Les Ballets de Monte Carlo, the 11-year-old company that made a zesty and refreshing New York debut on Tuesday night.

title: Is It New and Fresh or Merely Strange?
description: Some clothes need to be digested. It sometimes takes two or three years after an idea appears in fashion before the eye adjusts to what the body will become with this new covering. Or sometimes, the eye adjusts immediately, the look is digested, and within the same two or three years there is a hunger for something not so familiar.

title: How to Make Pipelines Riskier
description: Given the rash of mishaps in recent years involving oil and natural gas pipelines, one might assume a deep Congressional interest in stronger pipeline regulation. There is no such interest. As they rushed to adjourn, both the Senate and House slipped through a bill tailored to industry wishes that weakens current rules governing pipeline safety. President Clinton would be wise to pocket-veto the legislation by refusing to sign it.

title: High Court Case Raises Issue of Stripping Charities of Tax Exemptions
description: A case that began as a minor tax dispute between a Christian Science summer camp and a small town in Maine had the eyes of much of the nonprofit sector focused on the Supreme Court today.

title: The Jets' Defense: Surrealism In Trenches
description: Decisions, decisions. Does Jets Coach Rich Kotite really have any of significance, or is he out of options?

title: Eugene Stockwell, 73, Missionary Leader, Dies
description: The Rev. Eugene Stockwell, a Methodist missionary and leader in international church work, died on Tuesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 73.

title: Indenet to Merge With Petry Media
description: Indenet Inc. in Los Angeles, a provider of support services to the television advertising industry, and the Petry Media Corporation in New York, which sells commercial time on TV stations, said yesterday that they had agreed in principle to merge. The combined company, not yet named, will be 59 percent owned by Petry shareholders and 41 percent owned by Indenet shareholders.

title: . . . and for Camby
description: As he hobbled off to the locker room in Barrie, Ontario, yesterday, MARCUS CAMBY was worried about an opportunity lost.

title: An American Place
description: Bob Dole's attacks on teachers' unions have upset some Republicans in Stark County, Ohio. Some who voted for George Bush say they will not back Mr. Dole. Page. D21.

title: Second City for Briton
description: The British runner PAUL EVANS, who lost the New York City Marathon by only five seconds last year, plans to skip the Nov. 3 event this year in favor of the Chicago Marathon.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article and a quotation sampler yesterday reporting Bob Dole's criticism of President Clinton's ethics quoted Mr. Dole as saying the President had been ''playing around'' while teen-age smoking and drug use were on the rise. The article said Mr. Dole had not elaborated on the comments.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BASF CORP., Mount Olive, N.J., a unit of Germany's BASF A.G., said it was exiting the magnetic tape business in North America, which will result in the elimination of 128 jobs and the closing of its BASF Magnetics Corp. operation in Bedford, Mass.

title: 'Magic Trick' Causes Orioles To Disappear
description: Among their 268 home runs this year, the Baltimore Orioles have hit no phantom home runs. But last night, in the first game of the American League Championship Series at Yankee Stadium, they became a victim of a phantom home run.

title: COGECO CABLE TO BUY ASSETS OF ROGERS COMMUNICATIONS
description: Rogers Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would sell several cable systems serving 300,000 subscribers to Cogeco Cable Inc. for the equivalent of about $255 million in cash, shares and notes. Rogers's chief executive, Ted Rogers, said the money, along with the pending sale of the Toronto Sun newspaper chain, would ''substantially improve the financial position of the cable group.'' Rogers, based in Toronto, provides cable service, and cellular and other mobile communications, It also has interests in radio and television broadcasting. Most of the cable systems it is selling to Montreal-based Cogeco were acquired when it bought Maclean Hunter Ltd. in 1994.

title: Progress on a Golf Course
description: For decades, the Hyatt-Clark Industries factory made steering-wheel parts and ball bearings for its owner, General Motors. But shortly after the factory was bought by its employees, it went bankrupt. The next owner stripped the building to a shell. When the building reverted to G.M. in 1989, the company found it was not profitable to rebuild a factory on the contaminated site straddling Clark and Cranford. So G.M. decided to build a golf course.

title: When politicians seek to please on medical benefits.
description: ''I TRUST the people,'' remonstrated Bill Clinton in response to Bob Dole's charge during Sunday's Presidential debate that he put more faith in government. ''But I do think we are right when we try to, for example, give mothers and newborns 48 hours before they can be kicked out of the hospital,'' Mr. Clinton added.

title: INVESTORS MAKE A NEW OFFER FOR SANTA ANITA
description: The Koll Company, a real estate concern, and Apollo Real Estate Advisors said yesterday that they had offered to buy the Santa Anita Companies, operator of the Santa Anita race track in California. Apollo is an investment management firm in New York. The bid offers a $14-a-share cash dividend to shareholders in exchange for a 55 percent stake in the company. The partnership put the value of the bid at about $19 a share. Santa Anita had already agreed to sell a 45 percent stake in the company over the next two years to a group led by Colony Capital, a Los Angeles-based real estate investment firm. Santa Anita shares rose $2.25, or 12 percent, to close at $20.50.

title: Late-Inning Heroics By Stars-in-Waiting
description: They won't quit, the rookie shortstop and the young center fielder who have blossomed slowly but bountifully.

title: No Comment by Samsung On Fokker Reports
description: Samsung officials declined to comment yesterday on reports that the company had offered to buy 70 percent of the bankrupt regional jet maker Fokker N.V. if the Dutch Government and Stork N.V. took the rest. A spokesman at the Dutch Economics Ministry said he was unable to comment on details of the plan.

title: People
description: David Wheldon, advertising director at the Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, was promoted to the new position of director for marketing for the Greater Europe Group. Ian Rowden, deputy advertising director, succeeds him.

title: Insurer Plans To Curb Sales Along Coasts
description: In a sweeping effort to reduce its exposure to natural disasters, one of the nation's leading insurers plans to announce today that it will sharply curtail the sale of new homeowner policies in coastal areas along the hurricane-vulnerable Eastern Seaboard and Gulf of Mexico, from Maine to Texas.

title: G.O.P. Bristles Over Perot's Criticism of Failure to Pass Balanced-Budget Bill
description: As he makes his second bid for the White House, Ross Perot has excoriated the Republican-run Congress and its Presidential candidate, Bob Dole, claiming they frittered away opportunities in 1995 and this year to enact their campaign agenda, the Contract With America, and its centerpiece, a balanced-budget amendment.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JENNIFER LARMORE, the rising mezzo-soprano, has a dog who is suddenly rising in the world of opera, too.

title: Breast-Feeding in Public
description: A bill that would insure that women have the right to breast-feed a baby discreetly in public will get its first legislative hearing today. The sponsor, Assemblywoman Shirley K. Turner, a Democrat of Ewing, said yesterday that the measure was drafted after she received complaints from two mothers who had been asked to leave a mall in Cherry Hill and a toy store in Princeton.

title: Sherrard Rips Reeves For 'Big Ten' Offense
description: His words may offer the keenest insight into how the Giants' offense is run and what has been wrong with it. And to some -- particularly to Coach Dan Reeves -- they will be stinging.

title: Officials Find Bones and Hint Link to Salinas
description: Investigators in a murder case that includes accusations against Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of the former President, announced last night that they have found an unidentified skeleton buried on a property Mr. Salinas used.

title: Pan Am takes to the sky with a familiar approach; Valujet opts for a new tack.
description: LAST month, two well-known airline names returned to the skies, and they are reintroducing themselves with fresh versions of old campaigns. One is moderating its own image, while the other is borrowing themes from its namesake.

title: 'E.R.,' the Show and the Brand Name
description: Quick, hum the theme song to ''E.R.'' Can't do it? Prospects may not be great for a new CD called ''E.R.: Original Television Theme Music and Score,'' a tie-in to the hit show. It's not likely that millions of people will be dancing to the thumping, heartbeat-simulating theme, but the existence of a soundtrack is a sign that ''E.R.'' has become a brand name.

title: Modern Acquires 2 Icons Of Pop Art
description: The Museum of Modern Art acquired two icons of American Pop Art yesterday, Andy Warhol's ''Campbell's Soup Cans'' and James Rosenquist's ''F-111,'' along with an early and important painting by Ellsworth Kelly from the 1950's.

title: Deadlock on Murder Charge
description: For the second time, a Superior Court jury was unable to reach a verdict on a felony murder charge against a man accused of participating in the botched March 1995 robbery in which a Franklin Township jewelry store owner fatally shot his wife. The defendant, Robert L. Williams, 21, of Sugar Creek, Mo., had admitted his role in the holdup and was convicted of conspiracy and other charges. But when it came to the murder charge, his lawyer, Paul Amitrani, argued that the store owner, Jeffrey Wolf, shot his wife deliberately.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Connecticut Atom Plant Likely to Close
description: The owners of the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant in Haddam Neck, one of four troubled nuclear reactors in the state, said yesterday that they would probably shut down the 28-year-old plant because it had become too expensive to operate.

title: Tasting Night Life And Apples
description: The dances of Jennifer Muller often resemble big paintings with bold brush strokes. They command attention. They bristle with energy. But they can turn monochromatic for lack of choreographic interplays of light and shadow.

title: New Editor Is Named at New York Magazine
description: One month after dismissing Kurt Andersen as editor of New York magazine, the K-III Communications Corporation announced yesterday that Caroline Miller, the editor in chief of Seventeen magazine, would be his replacement.

title: Behind Japan's Furor Over Tiny Isles, Gangland Fingerprints
description: As he relaxes in his office, smoke circling from an endless parade of cigarettes while he cheerfully explains that gangsters are sometimes very honorable people, Toyohisa Etoh seems an unlikely figure to have created an international mess.

title: Sabotage Found in School Fire
description: The state-controlled Newark School District has determined that sabotage caused an oven to burst into flames last month at a local elementary school, and they are trying to determine if a rash of breakdowns throughout the cafeteria system resulted from similar tampering, officials said yesterday. The thermostats had been ripped out of the ovens at Lincoln School, said Paul Henderson, a special investigator for the school district.

title: Justice Dept. Split Over Handling of Suspect in Atlanta Bombing
description: Officials in the Justice Department and the F.B.I. are debating whether to send the security guard who became a focus of the investigation of the Olympic Park bombing in Atlanta a letter saying they no longer suspect him in the lethal attack.

title: Correction
description: An Oct. 8 letter misspelled the surname of the Presidential candidate of the Natural Law Party. He is John Hagelin, not Hegelin.

title: The Umpires Claim a Victory
description: The agenda for the Nov. 14 summit meeting among baseball's top three officials and representatives of the players and umpires became hotter yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: ''I didn't mean to do anything bad. I'm just a 12-year-old kid trying to catch a ball.''

title: Keeping Promises to Honduras
description: In December 1993 Leo Valladares, the new human rights ombudsman of Honduras, asked American officials to declassify documents he needed for an investigation of a secret Honduran military death squad. Three years later he is still waiting for the bulk of the material, despite assurances from the Clinton Administration that his request would be promptly handled.

title: William Prince, 83, Who Acted On Broadway and in Hollywood
description: William Prince, a stage, screen and television actor who appeared on Broadway in ''I Am a Camera'' opposite Julie Harris and in plays by Eugene O'Neill and Edward Albee, died on Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 83 and lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: British Prudential Fund to Invest in Troubled U.S. Companies
description: PPM America, the Chicago subsidiary of the Prudential Corporation of Britain, is raising $300 million to invest in the securities of financially troubled companies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN BURSTEIN is one of six children, some of whom have become reasonably well known. But he is the only one in his family who goes to work every day in a bodysuit that bears the design of the human skeleton and internal organs.

title: No Esteem Issues for This Child Expert
description: MOVING briskly at 6:45 A.M. in a slow and sleepy New York, Dr. Sylvia Rimm is pulling her own suitcases on a collapsible luggage cart through the cavernous lobby of the Essex House. No one, not even a doorman, seems to notice this short woman from Cleveland in sensible heels, wire-rim glasses and a shapeless pink suit.

title: Bad News for Benoit . . .
description: DAVID BENOIT, the Nets' small forward who was suffering from a torn right Achilles' tendon, underwent surgery in Manhattan yesterday to repair the tear and had his right leg placed in a cast. Benoit will miss the season.

title: Knicks Grade A, Coach Says
