description: He wishes there were fewer cuts and bruises and he is a little miffed about the sloppy passing in practice. But after spending one week together with his new team, Jeff Van Gundy is convinced the Knicks have the collective personality to withstand the rigors of the season together.

title: A Leaner, Meaner 'Murder One'
description: Last season, the new and tantalizingly innovative series ''Murder One'' had as its defense lawyer hero Ted Hoffman (Daniel Benzali): bald, dour and forbidding. The reviews were great but the ratings sagged. So, turning cavalierly on a casting dime, ''Murder One'' returns tonight with a new defense lawyer hero, played by Anthony LaPaglia, great head of hair, high-spirited and warmhearted. Hey, this is television and you do what you have to do.

title: A Rehearsal for 2000
description: The Vice-Presidential candidates devoted most of their 90-minute debate last night to arguing about Bob Dole's tax plan, the value of government regulation and the future of the inner cities. It was the debate about vision that Mr. Dole and President Clinton might have had this week, but did not.

title: Calendar: Benefits, Exhibitions And Tours
description: Benefit Auction

title: Johnson Buys Company
description: Johnson & Johnson has bought Indigo Medical Inc., a maker of portable laser surgery systems, for an undisclosed price. The closely held Indigo makes low-cost lasers that are approved in the United States to treat urological conditions. In Europe, the company also sells lasers for treating enlarged prostates. Indigo, based in Palo Alto, Calif., was formed in May 1990 with the help of Johnson & Johnson's development corporation, which invests in start-up companies.

title: Absence of Outrage
description: In our last episode about the penetration of the White House by Asian interests, we saw how the President of the United States had been personally involved in the solicitation of an illegal campaign contribution of $250,000 by a foreign national.

title: When News Is Alarming to Children
description: WHEN Deirdre Toole of Pawcatuck, Conn., was bitten by a mosquito one day last month, her 5-year-old son, Connor, tried to reassure her. ''He said to me, 'Don't worry, Mommy,' '' Mrs. Toole recalled, '' 'that wasn't the kind of mosquito that results in brain damage or death, right?' ''

title: A New Sweetheart Of Sigma Phi
description: ALTHOUGH it is plunked down in the middle of fraternity row, the Sigma Phi house at the University of California at Berkeley defies the image of Greek life. No toga parties. No keggers. No stair diving.

title: Dole's Debt of Gratitude
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Ex-WCBS Anchors Are Hired by WNBC
description: Two television news anchors dismissed by WCBS-TV last week have been hired by WNBC, the station announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Agencies Lead Health Care Awards
description: Four agencies have taken top honors at the third annual Grand Global Awards competition for health care communications, sponsored by the New York Festivals.

title: Cash Ebbs for Equity Funds, But 1996 Pace Remains Torrid
description: Equity mutual funds took in an estimated $16 billion in net new investments in September, down somewhat from August's level but still on track to nearly double the overall contributions recorded by stock funds in any previous year.

title: A Skip Away-Cigar Rematch In the Breeders' Cup Is Unlikely
description: Sonny Hine said yesterday that he would run Skip Away in the Breeders' Cup Classic if he thought he had any chance of beating out Cigar for the title Horse of the Year. But he added that the feedback from his friends suggested he could not beat Cigar at the ballot box, so he doubted that Skip Away would run in the Classic.

title: NBC Hits For Cycle In Game 1
description: NBC's production of Game 1 of the Orioles-Yankees American League Championship Series approached perfection last night. Bob Costas was at the apex of his craft, with wonderful stories (who knew Yankee Manager Joe Torre was a spectator at Don Larsen's perfect game 40 years ago?). Joe Morgan transcended insightful. And, save for a few missteps, Bob Uecker was the perfect comic foil.

title: INSIDE
description: Drop in Child-Abuse Deaths

title: Child Abuse Kills Fewer In New York
description: Despite a rash of highly publicized child-abuse cases, the number of children dying at the hands of their parents has declined sharply in New York City and State in the last five years, leaving government officials and child-welfare experts at a loss to explain why.

title: Rights Trial for Livoti May Be Tricky
description: Having announced that they will consider reopening the case of the Bronx police officer who was acquitted this week of the choking death of an asthmatic, Federal prosecutors will probably turn to the same civil rights statute that was used to convict two Los Angeles police officers for the beating of Rodney King.

title: Bridge
description: At the end of an event, the winners are often asked for an interesting deal. David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., was asked that Tuesday night and had an unusual answer. Playing with Beverly Perry of Manhattan at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, he had just won the Jim Becker Memorial charity game, which attracted 68 pairs and raised more than $6,000 for the Gay Men's Health Crisis. In second place were Mike Kallman and Joyce Sillins, both of Manhattan.

title: Low Marks for Reactors
description: The chronically malfunctioning Salem I nuclear plant was rated the worst reactor in the nation and its neighbor, Salem II, was rated the eighth worst in a study released yesterday by Public Citizen, the Washington-based consumer watchdog. The study ranked 109 reactors on criteria like safety, violations and power failures, using Nuclear Regulatory Commission data for 1993 to 1995. While Salem I was operating, regulators recorded 7 emergency shutdowns, 15 system failures and 3 accidents that posed potential public threats, Public Citizen said.

title: '96-97 Bulls: Ready, Smart, Crafty
description: Sometime this season, the Chicago Bulls may encounter a problem they cannot handle. But while the rest of the National Basketball Association tries to figure out how to unseat them as champions, the Bulls have opened training camp confidently, almost smugly.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BEN VEREEN was jubilant about turning 50 yesterday. ''Life is good, so let's party, party animals,'' he said at a surprise luncheon given by TONY RANDALL at Sardi's.

title: Where Some See a Giant Defense, Watters Sees Running Room
description: A couple of years ago, Ricky Watters was running sprints with the hardest working man in football, Jerry Rice, on a rainy morning in San Francisco. Watters signed a contract in the off season with the Philadelphia Eagles, leaving the security of the 49ers.

title: Sickness In the N.Y.P.D.
description: One April morning in 1973 a veteran police officer named Thomas Shea pulled his service revolver and blew away a young black boy on a street in Jamaica, Queens. He shot the kid in the back. There was no chance of survival. Afterward, no one could figure out why the officer had done it. There was no reason for the shooting, no threat to Officer Shea of any kind. The boy's name was Clifford Glover and he was 10 years old.

title: A Mayor Asks Help On Illegal Tenancies
description: Faced with more than 1,000 illegally occupied homes in his village and a fire in an overcrowded single-family home last weekend that injured more than 14 tenants, Mayor Richard R. Wissler has asked for help from local prosecutors.

title: Garage Door Openers Found To Pose a Risk for Children
description: Despite Government standards designed to improve their safety, most automatic garage door openers in houses and apartment buildings pose a risk of serious brain injury or death to children, a study has found.

title: Boy Who Saved the Yankees Becomes a Man About Town
description: Jeffrey Maier, the 12-year-old boy with a black baseball glove who reached out of the Yankee Stadium right-field stands in the eighth inning Wednesday to rescue the home team from imminent defeat, was New York royalty yesterday. And the reporters and camera crews following him around would have done justice to Princess Diana.

title: IRON MOUNTAIN BUYS 3 DATA-STORAGE COMPANIES
description: Iron Mountain Inc. said yesterday that it was buying three smaller data-management companies for a total of $26.4 million as part of an expansion strategy. Iron Mountain offers to store and retrieve records for businesses and government agencies. The largest of the three acquisitions is Mohawk Business Records Storage of Minneapolis. Iron Mountain also acquired International Records Storage and Retrieval Service Inc. of Newark and the Security Archives Corporation of Los Angeles. Iron Mountain, based in Boston, is named after the company's earliest storage facility, an abandoned iron mine south of Albany.

title: Circus in a Square Angers Moscow's Big Wheels
description: It was supposed to be a headline-grabbing extravaganza that would bring the Big Top to Red Square and boost the sagging prestige of Russia's vaunted circus industry.

title: Yanks Outdraw Braves-Cards
description: NBC's broadcast of the Yankees' 5-4 victory over Baltimore Wednesday in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series outrated Fox's prime-time telecast of the Atlanta-St. Louis playoff game, which beat each of the NBC, ABC and CBS presentations of the Vice-Presidential debate.

title: East Side Apartment Burns
description: A fire broke out in a 35-story apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan early today, leaving one person seriously injured, fire and emergency medical service officials said.

title: The Netanyahu Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Woman in Latin Kings Gang Pleads Guilty in a Murder Plot
description: The leader of the female wing of the Latin Kings, one of New York City's most notorious criminal gangs, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to charges of conspiracy to murder and assault, less than a week before she and other gang members were scheduled for trial.

title: Inspired by the Troubadours
description: JUST once or twice every 5 or 10 years, there turns up in a dealer's gallery an exhibition so original, so comprehensive and so tightly focused that we have trouble believing it.

title: Mayor Seeks Immigration Coalition
description: Having received national attention for his vigorous stand in favor of immigration, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today announced the formation of a coalition of prominent New Yorkers to help him lead the fight against the provisions of two new Federal laws that he views as anti-immigrant.

title: Lots of Sweatshops Found
description: A crackdown on sweatshops this week in northern New Jersey has uncovered workplace violations at half of the 100 clothing manufacturers inspected so far, and three repeat offenders have been shut down, Peter J. Calderone, the State Labor Commissioner, said yesterday. Armed with new regulations allowing confiscation of illegally produced goods, inspectors seized mounds of clothing and found violations from below-minimum wages to employees being locked into their work places, Mr. Calderone said.

title: Art in Review
description: Jim Shaw

title: 2 Are Arrested in California Freeway Attacks
description: For nearly a month now, the mysterious, nocturnal snipers had been hitting the citizens of Los Angeles where they live: in their cars.

title: Of Star-Crossed Love, With Cross-Dressed Cast
description: ''Lilies,'' an extravagantly mannered revenge fantasy by the Canadian film maker John Greyson, raises the level of protest at religious prohibitions against homosexuality into a piercing operatic cry. This period drama set in a men's prison in northern Quebec in 1952, with flashbacks to a Roman Catholic boys' school 40 years earlier, suggests Jean Genet by way of ''Marat/Sade'' in its elaborate variations on the play-within-a-play format.

title: Nobels as a Lagging Indicator
description: It is gratifying that American scientists have once again dominated the Nobel Prizes for science and economics. Sweden's Royal Academy of Sciences announced that three Americans shared the Nobel Prize in Physics and that two other Americans shared the Chemistry Prize with a British scientist. Another American was named co-winner of the award in economics.

title: Young Talent From Points East and West
description: Despite growing competition from New York and Milan, Paris remains the international center of fashion. The evidence is in the number of designers from other European cities and from Asian countries that continue to flock here to try to muscle their way onto the fashion stage.

title: Judge's Hypothetical Question Is Cited in Bronx Officer's Acquittal
description: If there was a moment when the prosecution began to lose its case against a police officer accused of fatally choking a young man in the Bronx, perhaps it was on the afternoon of Oct. 1.

title: True North, back in the expansion mode, plans to buy and take public an interactive marketing unit.
description: MADISON AVENUE'S march into cyberspace accelerated yesterday with a double download of digital news from True North Communications.

title: Bundesbank Holds Steady on Rates
description: The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, left its benchmark discount and Lombard rates unchanged yesterday at its regular meeting. The discount rate remained at 2.5 percent and the Lombard financing rate, at 4.5 percent. The principal securities-repurchase rate, a money market rate, was also held steady at 3 percent.

title: Dollar Slips Against the Yen, Hurt by the Slump in Bonds
description: The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen yesterday, hurt by a continued slump in United States bonds that raised concern that foreign investors might pare their American holdings.

title: New Jersey Senate Candidates Dispute Facts in Fugitive Case
description: In the latest twist in a case that has entangled the Senate campaign of Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a former official at the American Embassy in Seoul confirmed today that the embassy knew in 1986 the whereabouts of a fugitive who had ties to the Congressman.

title: City Transmits News Channel In Cable Clash
description: The Giuliani administration began transmitting a 24-hour news channel on a city-run cable station late last night, over the objections of the city's dominant cable operator, Time Warner.

title: Standing Up for Immigrants
description: The Jersey City Council passed a resolution Wednesday instructing city workers not to turn in or arrest immigrant residents, legal or otherwise. The ''safe haven'' resolution flouts new Federal guidelines requiring workers to notify immigration authorities about illegal immigrants who seek services like police protection, hospital care and public education. Hudson County's welfare director, Carol Ann Wilson, has instructed her staff not to turn in illegal immigrants. Jersey City's measure is not binding and does not supersede Federal law.

title: Q&A:A Vintage Clothes Connoisseur : Hamish Bowles' Shopping Guide (folo)
description: LONDON

title: For Nuclear Power Plant, Bottom Line Is Death Knell
description: For many years, the debate about nuclear energy in America has been framed by concerns about the environment and dominated by complicated discussions of geology and water tables and the disposal of spent fuel rods.

title: Not This Time: Oriole Muscle Foils Yankees
description: No dramatic comeback. No perfection from the bullpen. No controversial twists provided by a 12-year old. No reason to think the World Series is a cinch. Did the D train stop at the wrong place yesterday?

title: Dole's Positive Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: PEPSICO NAMES OUTSIDER TO HEAD TACO BELL
description: Pepsico Inc. turned to an outsider yesterday to help increase sales by naming John Antioco, the former chief executive of the Circle K Corporation, to head its Taco Bell restaurants. Mr. Antioco, 46, succeeds John Martin, who was Taco Bell's chief executive for the last 13 years. Mr. Martin will become chief executive of Pepsico's casual restaurant chains, which include KFC and Pizza Hut. Mr. Antioco left in May as chief executive and chairman of Circle K, a convenience-store chain. The changes are effective in 60 days and come amid an extensive shake-up of executives at Pepsico.

title: AT&T's Board Likely to Act Soon on Choice Of a Successor
description: The AT&T Corporation plans to present a candidate for president and heir apparent to the chairman, Robert E. Allen, at a board meeting next Wednesday, according to several people familiar with the search effort.

title: Children at Risk, Despite Fewer Deaths
description: New York State's Department of Social Services reports a 50 percent drop in child-abuse deaths during the last five years. Coming on the heels of the highly publicized and horrific deaths of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo last year and 4-year-old Nadine Lockwood barely two months ago, the news is startling, and has left officials puzzling over possible reasons.

title: Powell Gives Dole Campaign a Lift in Ohio
description: Bob Dole brought what he called his ''Midwest common sense'' to Ohio today. That common sense seemed to dictate that he generate some excitement for his Presidential campaign, which he did by bringing along Gen. Colin L. Powell.

title: A Racist and Killer Or Just Misunderstood?
description: Timing does no favors for ''The Chamber,'' the John Grisham death row drama that arrives on the heels of a better death row film (''Dead Man Walking'') and a better Grisham adaptation (''A Time to Kill''). But this film's also-ran aspects are partly offset by Gene Hackman's superlative performance as a wily old racist whose grandson is determined to save him from execution.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section on Wednesday about a pamphlet suggesting places for jurors to eat near the courthouses in lower Manhattan misstated the telephone number and E-mail address for obtaining copies from the Citizens Jury Project, a division of the Vera Institute of Justice. The number is (212) 334-1300; the address is jvm@vera.org.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: M.L.S.

title: MARINER'S SHARES FALL ON LOW EARNINGS EXPECTATIONS
description: The shares of Mariner Health Group Inc. plunged yesterday after the company said it would take a third-quarter charge in expectation of lower Federal Medicare payments. The $10 million charge will push third-quarter and fourth-quarter earnings 20 percent below what analysts had expected, Mariner said. Shares of the company, a nursing-home operator based in New London, Conn., fell $5.9375, to $7.375, in Nasdaq trading of almost 10.6 million shares. Mariner said the charge would cover the cost of possible changes in the way the Government pays claims under Medicare.

title: Gaetti Slam Stuns Maddux and Braves
description: Facing Greg Maddux is usually a death sentence for the St. Louis Cardinals. The four-time Cy Young Award winner had dominated them over his eight previous starts, posting an incomparable 6-0 record with a 0.79 earned run average. That included a 2-0 record in three starts this year, when he gave up just two earned runs in 23 innings.

title: Olin Plans A Broad Shake-Up
description: Taking a series of steps it said would tighten its operating focus and maximize shareholder value, the Olin Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to spin off its aerospace and ordnance operations, sell its isocyanate chemical business and buy back as much as 10 percent of its stock.

title: Restaurants
description: ''May I help?''

title: Playing by the Rules Gets Rangers Nowhere
description: The Rangers are without a victory in their first four games and now even the updated rule book seems to be against them.

title: Small Japanese Savers Find the Return Barely Worth It
description: Gone are the days when Hisashi Ishigaki could spend the fruits of his bank savings on home repairs and new shirts. Now, the interest he earns barely buys a daily cup of tea.

title: Art in Review
description: Luc Tuymans

title: Orioles Protest Game 1, Citing Possible Loophole
description: The Baltimore Orioles formally protested yesterday their 5-4 loss to the Yankees on Wednesday in the opening game of the American League Championship Series. And they found a possible loophole to evade the prohibition against protesting an umpire's judgment.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Dartmouth

title: Brady and Reich Believe Sunday Could Be Their Day
description: They share a connection that goes beyond the football field. And as they learned in their Bible study class, adversity can be a spur.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: James and the Giant Peach

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 27 about Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, who was questioned in the 1989 mail-bomb murder of a Federal judge, referred incorrectly to his lawyer's knowledge of Federal searches for a typewriter on Mr. O'Ferrell's property. The lawyer, William Gill, who is suing the Federal Bureau of Investigation over the case, says he had known for years that agents sought the typewriter in an effort to prove that type on his client's letters and those connected to the bombing were the same; he did not learn this just recently. What he said he did learn was that in the later trial of another man, no typographic evidence was ever used, raising Mr. Gill's suspicions about the truth of statements used to obtain search warrants for the typewriter, which was never found.

title: Alomar Starting to Take His Loudest Detractors Out of Their Games
description: The boos grew weaker and weaker as the day progressed. The Yankee Stadium fans tried to maintain the volume they generated during Wednesday's first game and in the early innings of yesterday's second game, but Roberto Alomar began beating them into submission.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mired in the Land of Malls, And Itching for Meanings
description: Richard Linklater's fine new film ''Suburbia'' combines his talents with those of Eric Bogosian and brings out the best in both. Mr. Bogosian's venomously funny play, which he adapted himself for the screen, is given warmth and generosity by Mr. Linklater, whose elegantly fluid direction and great skill with actors are accentuated by the play's spareness. Mr. Bogosian's knife-edged humor and hairpin turns at the end of the play keep the material from meandering and guarantee the film its sting.

title: For Children
description: Medieval Festival

title: Big-City Life Out in Space
description: An adorable little girl named Chieko (Rachel Walker), who has grown up in the world's first space community, serves as the unofficial tour guide to the immaculate, energy-efficient world of ''L5: First City in Space.'' Set 100 years in the future, the 33-minute Imax three-dimensional film, which opens today at the Sony Lincoln Square Theater, portrays a science-fiction environment that looks so authentic it almost seems to exist already.

title: France Is Style, America Is JustBeauty
description: PARIS  As everyone knows, nations are over, just like history. This is the age of the world brand,the international consumer, fashion on the Web hitting every part of the Earth, street style in the global village.

title: China's Endangered Democrats
description: While the Clinton Administration is busy these days repairing relations with China, it cannot ignore Beijing's continuing abuse of citizens who speak out for wider democratic freedom. Yesterday the State Department rightly protested the latest wave of Chinese arrests. American concerns also need to be conveyed personally by top Administration officials.

title: They See the Future and It Works for Them
description: In a paroxysm of futuristic imagery, President Clinton joined Vice President Al Gore in Tennessee today for a campaign appearance suffused with references to the new century, the new millennium, cyberspace, web pages and even a mapping project for the ''genetic code of life.''

title: Classical Reticence Sprinkled With Unabashed Quirks
description: Among European ballet troupes that attempt to use the classical idiom in a contemporary way, Les Ballets de Monte Carlo will have to be taken more seriously than most. As the company's second program confirmed on Wednesday night at City Center (131 West 55th Street), the 11-year-old troupe still has some distance to go before reaching the top ranks. But the dancers are lively, excellently schooled and perform with a curious mix of alternating reticence and projection.

title: GULFSTREAM INITIAL OFFERING IS 37 MILLION SHARES
description: The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, the maker of corporate jets, sold 37 million common shares yesterday for $888 million, or $24 each, in one of the largest initial public offerings of the year. The price was at the high end of the expected range. The company, based in Savannah, Ga., had originally offered 28 million shares. Gulfstream's shares closed at $25.75 on the New York Stock Exchange after 11.6 million shares were traded. Gulfstream had been owned by the New York investment group Forstmann Little & Company since 1990. Proceeds from the offering will be used to buy back preferred shares and to repay debt.

title: RENCO GROUP OFFERS TO BUY WCI STEEL STOCK
description: WCI Steel Inc. said yesterday that its largest shareholder, Renco Group Inc., had made an offer to take the steelmaker private for about $69 million. Renco, an investment firm based in New York, owns 84 percent of WCI's common shares and is offering to buy the remainder at $10 a share. WCI reported an average 36.5 million shares outstanding in the three months ended July 31. WCI's stock rose nearly 12 percent, or $1.125, to $9.625 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. WCI, based in Warren, Ohio, said the deal was contingent on its refinancing $206 million of its debt.

title: Home Video
description: The Wide-Screen Version

title: Brazil Indefinitely Postpones Ruling on Indian Land Claims
description: A Government decision due today on whether to uphold Indian claims to a vast area in Brazil's northernmost state has been delayed indefinitely. Instead, the Brazilian Justice Minister visited the contested area for talks with Indian leaders, ranchers, and state and church officials.

title: Jessie Bernard, 93; Ideas Inspired Feminists
description: Jessie Bernard, a sociologist whose wide-ranging research and writings on women's issues provided scholarly foundation for the modern feminist revolution, died on Oct. 6 at a nursing home in Washington. She was 93.

title: The Look: Tough, Maybe Tattered
description: Somewhere among garage bands, grunge and glam rock lay the esthetic that was trying to emerge in the early 90's. Punk was being revived, deconstruction was up from the underground, and the Seattle bands were hot. Youth was leading fashion.

title: Dispute Over Gambling Panel
description: Should representatives of the gambling industry be allowed to serve on a new Federal commission that will study the social and economic effects of legal gambling? Responding to reports that House Speaker Newt Gingrich is considering naming J. Terrance Lanni, chairman of MGM Grand, to the panel, Representative Frank R. Wolf, a Virginia Republican and the chief House sponsor of the bill that established the commission, expressed his opposition yesterday. ''It would be difficult for anybody who comes out of the industry to make any recommendations that might be negative and then go back to the job he has,'' Mr. Wolf said.

title: BARELY FOUR WALLS
description: As they look to the future in an era of government retrenchment, many housing advocates and experts agree that the money and political will to develop decent, affordable housing will probably remain in short supply in New York City.

title: Atlanta Unit Defends Itself
description: Atlanta Olympic officials yesterday defended their heavy merchandising of the Summer Games, saying it enhanced the value of the event for future host cities.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: 2 Branches Of Islam Clashing In Nigeria
description: For years, the state of Kaduna in northern Nigeria has been a tinder box of religious passions, so when 17 people were killed there in religion-related violence that began in mid-September, few people were surprised.

title: Dole to Try Again in State
description: Bob Dole will make a third attempt on Sunday to visit Hamilton Township ''if Mother Nature cooperates,'' a spokesman said yesterday. Bad weather forced Mr. Dole to cancel appearances at the Switlik Parachute Company in Hamilton on Sept. 6 and at Kuser Farm Park on Tuesday. Dole will try again to visit the park, and also plans to march in Newark's Columbus Day Parade and campaign in Somerville. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Baltimore Survives Trip to Zoo
description: THE red light was flashing on Tony Tarasco's hotel phone yesterday morning. The message was from Richard Maier, the father of the 12-year-old boy who had deflected a fly ball into a home run, just above Tarasco's waiting glove on Wednesday.

title: California Connection Is Propelling Columbia
description: Bobby Thomason, a promising quarterback prospect from southern California, could hardly have been blamed for hedging on whether he should attend Columbia. ''My original visit in January of my senior year in high school was snowed out,'' Thomason said. ''Then when I came to visit the campus that March, it was snowing hard. And I said to myself, 'Do I really want to deal with this, and can I handle this type of weather?' ''

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Search for One-Eye Jimmy

title: Pennsylvania Lottery Extends Tierney
description: The Pennsylvania Lottery said yesterday that it had renewed a contract with Tierney & Partners in Philadelphia for three years with a further two-year renewal option. The assignment, with billings estimated at $18 million, has been handled by Tierney for 19 years. The decision came after a monthlong review that had been narrowed to Tierney, a unit of True North Communications; Elkman Advertising and Public Relations in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., and MARC in Pittsburgh.

title: Foreman Still Talking It Up
description: George Foreman preached the boxing gospel according to him yesterday as he came to New York to hype his Nov. 2 fight in Tokyo against Crawford Grimsley.

title: No Bark, No Bites
description: Adm. James Stockdale's startled ''Who am I? Why am I here?'' was the most memorable moment of the 1992 Vice-Presidential debate. Wednesday night's showdown between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp produced nothing to match it.

title: The Candidates And Hot-Button Bork
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Aetna to Trim 4,400 Jobs In Fourth Layoff This Year

title: 2 AFGHAN FACTIONS SIGN PACT TO FIGHT NEW KABUL RULERS
description: The last two military commanders holding out against the new rigorously Muslim Government in Afghanistan forged a formal military alliance here today. They vowed to set up a non-fundamentalist government in the nine northern provinces under their control.

title: Cybersites for News And Entertainment
description: Two companies have disclosed plans for Internet initiatives that are both scheduled to begin Monday.

title: Mormon Temples a Sign of Church's Growth Into Global Organization
description: On a bluff here above Utah Lake, with the snow-dusted Wasatch Mountains for a backdrop, the Mormon Church has raised a building whose pale granite surface reflects the dazzling Rocky Mountain sunlight. A gilt inscription atop one wall identifies it as ''the House of the Lord.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: Mirezi has been so expensively redone that it is hard to visualize the Markham in this space. The bilevel restaurant is Asian now, as you can clearly tell from the sleek design, the stones embedded in the walls along with adorable four-inch television sets playing what look like Hong Kong commercials.

title: Muffin-Baking Mom or Gun-Toting Killer? Or Both?
description: For eight years Samantha Caine (Geena Davis) has had the delusion that she is a small-town mom and schoolteacher, the kind who plays Mrs. Kris Kringle in the village parade and gets kissed under the mistletoe.

title: U.S. Lobbies African Lands To Weaken U.N. Chief
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher's trip to Africa this week is being watched with intense interest by officials and foreign diplomats here who see the visit as the Administration's last-ditch effort to find an African candidate for Secretary General.

title: New York's Hero Is Baltimore's Scapegoat
description: Victor Stinyard did not even wait for the question.

title: Iraq at Play: Eliza Doolittle Is Now a Belly Dancer
description: You can tell that the Baghdad rendition of ''My Fair Lady'' is going to be somewhat different when, five minutes into the musical, a male dancer brandishes a pistol and shoots his lithe female counterpart dead.

title: Fortuny Fabrics Once Again in Vogue
description: VENICE  The dramatic revival of interest in Fortuny fabrics has been one of the surprise fashion trends of recent years. And when one looks at the career of Fortuny himself and the vicissitudes of his enterprise, it is little short of miraculous that these sumptuous textiles with their complex and multifarious designsare still being manufactured today.

title: Energizer Bunny Returns to Roots
description: E. B., the drum-beating pink bunny that has kept ''going and going and going'' in a campaign for Energizer batteries, is returning to its roots in spots that began running this week.

title: Harry Rosen Is Dead at 92; Junior's Restaurant Founder
description: Harry Rosen, who founded Junior's Restaurant, the Brooklyn institution renowned for cheesecake so rich and creamy it made tough men swoon, died yesterday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 92.

title: Cone's Struggles Mirrored By Yanks
description: After two home-run pitches, the first by David Cone to Todd Zeile in the third inning and the other by Jeff Nelson to Rafael Palmeiro in the seventh, the Yankees and the Orioles are now 1-1 in the American League Championship Series that resumes tonight in Baltimore.

title: Ewing Sees Himself As a Knick To the End
description: The lasting image of Patrick Ewing from last season was that of a proud, beleaguered veteran slowly walking off the United Center floor with a towel draped over his head. He led the old Knicks off the floor for the final time.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL FINKELSTEIN, the chairman and chief executive of the Renaissance Communications Corporation, which was recently sold to the Tribune Company for $1.13 billion, has given $1 million to the Columbia University Law School to create new programs and classes in communications law. The donation will also establish the Telford Taylor Visiting Professorship for 1996-1997.

title: Columbus Day to Be Observed Monday
description: NEW YORK

title: The Nuclear Gamble
description: The Clinton Administration is taking a gamble with its reputation, which is its business. But the gamble deals with the spread of nuclear weaponry, which immediately makes it everybody's.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Preferred Stock

title: CONTINENTAL BUYING 60 BOEING JETLINERS
description: Continental Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it would buy 60 Boeing Company 737 jetliners to replace the oldest planes in its fleet. The order has a list price of $1.8 billion, although the size of the order and a bidding contest between Boeing and McDonnell Douglas reduced the price some, Gordon Bethune, chairman and chief executive of Continental, said. Neither Boeing nor Continental would confirm the purchase price. The airline, which is based in Houston, ordered Boeing 737-500 and 737-600 aircraft to replace 60 planes between July 1997 and December 1999. The order, combined with other recent purchases, will help Continental increase its capacity on domestic flights by 3 percent to 4 percent and twice as much on international flights by the year 2000.

title: Accounts
description: * Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, was given two accounts with combined billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million: Sauder Woodworking, Archbold, Ohio, previously at Ross Roy Communications, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., a unit of Omnicom Group, and Showboat Mardi Gras Casino, East Chicago, Ind., as its first agency.

title: Best Products to Sell Its Remaining Stores
description: The Best Products Company said today that it had agreed to sell all of its remaining retail stores to Schottenstein Bernstein Capital Group LLC and Alco Capital Group Inc., possibly pushing up its exit from bankruptcy.

title: Heating Oil and Natural Gas Fall in Price as Reserves Grow
description: Heating oil and natural gas futures tumbled yesterday after a rise in inventories eased concern that reserves would be low this winter.

title: Old-Time Rock-and-Roll
description: Marshall Crenshaw seemed old-fashioned when he emerged in 1982, singing pop songs that had the tunefulness and easygoing sincerity of the Beatles and Buddy Holly. Now, he's starting to sound classic.

title: 46 Charged in Stock Fraud Sting by F.B.I.
description: The brokerage house looked like any other small firm, with a couple of hustling brokers selling securities to investors. But in fact it was an operation set up by the F.B.I. to catch stock promoters who bribe brokers to buy stock in small companies.

title: Welfare Plan Nearly Ready
description: New Jersey officials should be ready by next Thursday to submit a plan showing how the state intends to comply with the new Federal welfare law, officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Media Business page on Wednesday about management changes at the Hollywood studios of the Sony Corporation misstated the location of the company's United States subsidiary. It is New York, not Park Ridge, N.J.

title: Where Labor and Business Overshadow a House Race
description: As Election Day nears in Arizona's Sixth Congressional District, there is a threat to the old saw that holds that all politics is local.

title: Two Lions Gnawing Away At 19th-Century Progress
description: ''The Ghost and the Darkness,'' a lion-hunting story set in 19th-century Africa, is the rare Hollywood action-adventure that becomes more surprising and exotic as it moves along. While it begins on an unpromisingly starchy note, the film soon picks up speed, color and nicely nonchalant humor as it tells a true story about near-mythic beasts.

title: Reading the Compass of Mideast Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackson Won't Discuss His Future With Yanks
description: Reggie Jackson, who had a profanity-laced argument with George Steinbrenner on the Yankees' team bus after Game 2 of the first-round series with Texas last Wednesday, said yesterday that he still had not discussed the incident with the owner and he was vague about his future with the organization.

title: INSIDE
description: 46 Charged in Stock Sting

title: K-III Appoints Three Publishers
description: The K-III Consumer Magazines division of the K-III Communications Corporation has named new publishers at three magazines.

title: From the New Deal to a Disgust With Government
description: THE INHERITANCE

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Fear

title: The Candidates And Hot-Button Bork
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Talks Are Fruitless, Arafat Warns
description: Yasir Arafat warned today that four days of negotiations regarding the Israeli pullout from Hebron on the West Bank had achieved nothing so far, and that therefore the Palestinians should be prepared ''to confront all possibilities.''

title: Labor-Backed Challenger Has Incumbent in Trouble
description: Representative Martin R. Hoke argues relentlessly that his Democratic challenger has sold out to special interests. But the special interest he means is the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and his 10th Congressional District is one of the heaviest labor districts in the nation.

title: At Last, Islanders Sign Green
description: Although change was the order of the day, the Islanders brought a familiar face back into the fold yesterday: center Travis Green, who agreed to a one-year contract worth $1.1 million, excluding performance bonuses.

title: The Tibetan Link
description: To the Editor:

title: Dear TV News Director, Here's How to Run the Show
description: Does the news that a few days after being dismissed by WCBS-TV, two local-news anchors have been hired by WNBC mean (a) WCBS-TV made a mistake, or (b) WNBC is making a mistake, or (c) that's show business? If you chose (c), you've been watching local news.

title: Clinton's Encryption Plan Fits Law and Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Rudolf Koppitz

title: Dying Zapatista Leader Is Focus of Only Accord So Far
description: The Government and the Zapatista rebels have narrowly averted the collapse of peace negotiations by agreeing to allow a terminally ill leader of the guerrilla army to travel to Mexico City to take part in a national Indian meeting.

title: Warner Drops His Ad Team For Trick Photo
description: Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, dismissed his advertising team today after the company used a computer to alter a photograph of his opponent in an attack advertisement.

title: Dole Campaign in Discord Over Attacking President
description: Jack Kemp's declaration at the Vice-Presidential debate that it would be ''beneath Bob Dole to go after anyone personally'' crystalized a continuing disagreement over one of the last critical decisions for the Dole campaign: how hard Mr. Dole should strike at President Clinton in their final debate next week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about retailers' expectations for the holiday shopping season referred incorrectly to one retailer, County Seat Inc. It is not operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Royal Monster, Are You Out There?
description: Al Pacino, an unlikely Mr. Chips, set out to invigorate ''Richard III'' in ways that would communicate his abiding love of Shakespeare and entice lay audiences to explore the Machiavellian twists of this forbiddingly knotty play. Mission accomplished: with all the makings of a monstrous vanity production, Mr. Pacino's quick-witted, illuminating ''Looking for Richard'' somehow emerges as a complete delight.

title: At the Armory Show, More Fun (and Risks) as Dealers Spruce Up
description: Dealers finally seem to be having fun exhibiting at the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show. Instead of bland, preciously self-conscious booths, many have richly colored walls and decorative motifs. It's as if the whole show, now in its eighth year, has had a face lift and is ready to strut its stuff.

title: Menacing Shadows Greet Dawn In Nigeria
description: Even the sunrise has been displaced.

title: House Republicans Say Administration Lied on Bosnia Arms
description: The political controversy over President Clinton's decision not to block Iranian arm shipments to Bosnia in 1994 was rekindled today as House Republicans released a report accusing Administration officials of lying to Congress and called for a criminal investigation into the matter.

title: How a Home Run Becomes a Foul Ball
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Old and New Turf
description: Christian Lacroix is nothing if not determined. He unleashed on Paris, yet again, a blizzard of pattern and color so dense as to leave one gasping for air. Ocimar Versolato, on the other hand, encouraged heavy breathing with his sexy draped dresses, and Sonia Rykiel looked back confidently to the previous decade to demonstrate that she remains the mistress of knitwear.

title: Challenging the Big Wink
description: A troubling aspect of this year's Presidential race has been the brazen circumvention of Federal campaign finance laws by both major parties and their Presidential campaigns. This bipartisan trickery has created a frustrating sense that between Supreme Court-sanctioned loopholes, Congressional inaction and a notoriously weak Federal Election Commission, nothing can be done to clean up campaign spending.

title: $25 and Under
description: Striking the Comfort Chord

title: Both Kemp and Gore Erred in Debate Over Policy on Mexico
description: When the Vice-Presidential debate turned to foreign policy, there was a sharp exchange of views over Mexico, with Jack Kemp accusing the Clinton Administration of causing Mexico's worst economic crisis in half a century, and Vice President Al Gore defending the Administration's actions with boasts that Mexico had already paid back all the money it borrowed.

title: Beyond Sardonic, to Hopeful
description: THE German artist Max Beckmann (1884-1950) once wrote about the purpose of art: ''What matters is real love for the things of the world outside us and for the deep secrets within us.'' Yet we rarely consider his allegorical paintings, with their dark woodcut-style lines and stained-glass colors, in so complex a light.

title: Viag to Continue In British Telecom Deal
description: Viag A.G. said yesterday that it would continue its telecommunications joint venture with British Telecommunications a day after its fellow utility, RWE, withdrew from the partnership. RWE joined with Veba and Cable and Wireless as companies jockeyed for position in the German telecommunications market, to be opened to competition in 1998.

title: Bear Stearns Sells Unit
description: The Bear Stearns Companies has sold its pension fund consulting unit, Bear Stearns Fiduciary Services, to the unit's management for an undisclosed sum. Bear Stearns said it would continue to work with its former unit, renamed Independent Fiduciary Services, in a joint venture. Fiduciary Services, which has offices in Washington and New York, reviews investment programs of big public and private pension funds.

title: South Africa Acquits Six In Massacre
description: The prosecution of 10 high-ranking apartheid-era officials accused of plotting the massacre of 13 people nine years ago seemed to be falling apart today as a judge acquitted six less important defendants and criticized the prosecutor for arguing ''blandly'' and failing to call needed witnesses.

title: Cox Fined Again by N.F.L.
description: Chicago Bears linebacker BRYAN COX was fined $87,500, or the equivalent of one game's pay, by the National Football League yesterday for his on-field misconduct in last Sunday's game against Green Bay.

title: PALL IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE GELMAN SCIENCES
description: The Pall Corporation, based in East Hills, L.I., said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Gelman Sciences Inc. Pall is the world's largest producer of disposable filters. The move comes a month after Gelman Sciences, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., agreed to be acquired by Memtec Ltd. of Australia for American depository receipts valued at $240.7 million. Gelman's filters are used in the health care industry, laboratory research, environmental monitoring and high-technology manufacturing. In a letter to Memtec, Gelman said that it had received an inquiry from Pall and that it would provide the information requested. Gelman said Pall had not yet made an offer. Gelman stock rose $3 yesterday, to $29.

title: WHITTMAN-HART PLANS 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: Whittman-Hart Inc. is planning a 2-for-1 split of its common stock in the form of a 100 percent dividend to be payable in December. The company statement said the stock dividend was dependent on shareholder approval. A special meeting of shareholders is planned Nov. 25. The company said the share increase would provide the company with additional available shares for future acquisitions, equity financings and stock dividends. Whittman-Hart provides strategic-information technology consulting and system integration services. Its shares rose $4 each yesterday, to $49, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Ford Places Top Designer On the Leadership Track
description: The Ford Motor Company today named Jacques A. Nasser, 48, to head its North American and European automotive operations, clearing the way for the urbane car designer to become the auto maker's top operating officer someday.

title: Stadium Security Becomes as Tight as a Glove
description: This was Arty Laurain's 43d year backing up the Yankees in the right-field seats, he said yesterday, his worn, old Rawlings eased into his hand and his lucky Notre Dame sweatshirt flagging his back.

title: Mannesmann Sells British Company Stake
description: The German industrial company Mannesmann A.G. said yesterday that it had sold its 9 percent stake in the the TI Group, a British engineering company, for 530 million marks ($346.7 million).

title: Designers Wake Up to Dressing Down
description: NEW YORK  Almost imperceptibly, the American fashion industry has awakened from the deeply satisfying success it enjoyed in the early 1980swhen women willingly paid dearly for imposingly designed clothes to find itself facing a tough new customer whois no longer enamoured with fashion.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Race the Sun

title: No Knee Surgery for Piazza
description: Los Angeles Dodgers catcher MIKE PIAZZA had a magnetic resonance imaging examination on his right knee earlier this week and will not need arthroscopic surgery at this time.

title: Touring the Canyons of Money and Dreams
description: YOU can get lost in lower Manhattan. The streets are not named after numbers. They disregard the Manhattan grid. They bend, twist and turn back on themselves, creating looming, demented perspectives on a scale Dr. Caligari never dreamed of. On Broad Street, home of the New York Stock Exchange, New York's usual system of street addresses is turned upside down: the numbers mount higher as you proceed south. This escape from logic affords immense delight, an oasis of irregularity within a city that offers little relief from the rigid, rectilinear grip of the civil engineer.

title: Paper Trail From Jail To Liberty
description: THIS is the weekend for remembering Columbus's coming to America by ship in 1492. Wu Lu Zhong also came to America by ship, five centuries later, but instead of having a day named after him he landed in prison for three years. His mistake was to live in an age when immigration policies are not as lax as they were for those who sailed on the Spanish monarchy's tab.

title: Blaming Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Stars Focus Their Firepower, and the Issue Is Abortion
description: Any film project with stars of the caliber of Demi Moore, Sissy Spacek and Cher is bound to create a buzz. But when that project is HBO's ''If These Walls Could Talk,'' look for an eruption. The subject is abortion. Even though the treatment is generally evenhanded, the Christian Coalition and other watchdogs are likely to step up their attacks on Time Warner, HBO's parent company.

title: SBC Selects Goodby, Silverstein
description: SBC Communications, a regional Bell telephone company, said yesterday that it had named Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco to handle a new long-distance telecommunications account with billings estimated at $80 million. Roland Ruiz, a spokesman for SBC in San Antonio, confirmed a report of the assignment in the Daily Fax edition of Advertising Age.

title: Dole's Public and Private Sides Are Mostly One and the Same, Advisers Say
description: Five months ago, when Bob Dole announced that he was resigning from the Senate, he said he looked forward to facing voters ''without office or authority, a private citizen, a Kansan, an American, just a man.'' The construction seemed to promise a glimpse of another side of Mr. Dole: an ordinary, casual, sit-around-the-table, private side.

title: Diane D. Montgomery, 62, Rights Proponent
description: Diane Dickerson Montgomery, a former psychiatric social worker and bank officer who was involved in civil rights causes since childhood, died on Sunday at her home in Chicago. She was 62 and also had homes in Lubec, Me., and Key West, Fla.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: In the Hamptons, Prices Are Soaring, but Not All
description: Some brokers in the Hamptons are cautioning people not to panic. It's not that the market is so bad -- but that it's so good.

title: Girl Scout Victimized
description: A 50-year-old woman was ordered to undergo psychiatric evaluation Wednesday after the authorities accused her of assaulting a 9-year-old Girl Scout who came to her house to sell cookies and nuts.

title: Corrections
description: A letter to the editor in The Living Section on Wednesday about a cookbook from the concentration camp at Theresienstadt transcribed the signature of the writer incorrectly. She is Myrna Goldenberg.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks were up slightly here this morning. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was 6.29 points higher, or three-hundredths of a percent, at 20,877.12. The market was closed on Thursday in observance of a Japanese national holiday, Health Sports Day, On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 167.70 points.

title: G.E. Reports 11% Increase In Third-Quarter Earnings
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that third-quarter earnings increased 11 percent over the period last year.

title: Aetna to Cut 4,400 More Jobs As It Shifts to Managed Care
description: Aetna Inc., in one of the largest job cutbacks in the health care and insurance industries, said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by 4,400 jobs, or 13 percent of its 33,700 employees. It was Aetna's fourth big layoff announcement this year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: 1 Economy, 2 Diagnoses
description: Listening to Jack Kemp and Al Gore debate on Wednesday night, it would be easy to conclude that the two men lived in completely different countries.

title: Fire at 30 Rockefeller Plaza Sends NBC Programs to 49th St. Sidewalk
description: Katie Couric did the ''Today'' program as a sidewalk standup. Network producers held curbside staff meetings. Writers scribbled outdoors in longhand, and anchors broadcast in a drizzle with firefighters scurrying in the background yesterday as an electrical fire poured smoke through a 70-story skyscraper and drove NBC from its headquarters at Rockefeller Center.

title: Loewen's Board Rejects a Hostile Offer as Stingy
description: The Loewen Group's board unanimously dismissed a hostile $3.2 billion offer from Service Corporation International today, calling it stingy, wrong-headed and anti-competitive.

title: No Headline
description: ''I have preached maybe to the point of obsession that there are three reasons why housing is in a crisis in New York City -- cost, cost and cost.''

title: AMRESCO BUYING MOST OF QUALITY MORTGAGE
description: Amresco Inc., based in Dallas, said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase most of the assets of Quality Mortgage USA Inc., a residential mortgage company in Irvine, Calif., for $65 million in cash. Amresco also filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 7.76 million shares in a public offering. Amresco, a real estate and consulting company, will use proceeds from the offering to repay borrowings for the acquisition of Quality Mortgage. Amresco shares closed at $21.4375, down $1.4375 for the day. The transaction, which was announced last month, originally was to include the acquisition of Calmac Funding Inc. for an additional $30.2 million. Quality Mortgage is a unit of Calmac and DLJ Mortgage Capital Inc. Amresco has decided not to buy Calmac.

title: Holders Back Time Warner-Turner Merger
description: Shareholders of Time Warner Inc. and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. approved the $7 billion merger of the two companies yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Sept. 14 showing the previous day's performance of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average misstated eight prices and percentage changes from the closing prices on May 22. The figures should have read:

title: Fighting Breast Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Mohegan Sun Will End Foxwoods' Local Monopoly
description: Michael Giguere sipped a Coke and looked ill. It was late Wednesday afternoon, and in a few minutes, 20,000 people would be streaming through the doors of Mohegan Sun, a giant new casino that is opening to the public on Saturday.

title: Buyer Says Isles Will Stay
description: After more than four seasons of absentee ownership -- some might even argue that there have been nearly two decades of it -- the Islanders announced yesterday that the current owners had ''agreed in principle to sell a substantial portion of the club,'' believed to be at least 82 percent, to John Spano, a 32-year-old Texas businessman.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 7
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Bonds May Look to Leave Giants
description: BARRY BONDS reportedly wants to be traded in the wake of his father's demotion by the San Francisco Giants.

title: Retail Sales for September Were Mostly Lackluster
description: Retailers reported another month of mixed sales results yesterday, adding to accumulating evidence that there are still too many stores decorating the country's landscape. Even those retailers that have done well all year but did poorly last month offered no excuses.

title: Capulets and Montagues As Rival Bronx Caterers
description: Just when you thought romance was dead and comedy was buried in the adjacent crypt, along comes ''Love Is All There Is.''

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Beckoning to the British

title: Treasuries' Prices Move Down Again
description: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday, the fourth consecutive decline, as concerns about inflation and interest rates grew before today's report on producer prices.

title: Michael Who? Irish Freedom Fighter and 'Big Fella'
description: Like the Irish freedom fighter and statesman at the heart of his sweeping new film, the writer and director Neil Jordan faces an uphill battle. Michael Collins, legendary in Ireland and less so in England, is largely a little-known figure to the audiences who made Mr. Jordan's two most recent films, ''The Crying Game'' and ''Interview With the Vampire,'' such runaway hits. More problematic is the elusive nature of a leader who experienced a sea change during his brief career, evolving from a pioneer of modern-day terrorism into a proponent of compromise and peace.

title: Dodgers Retain Russell
description: BILL RUSSELL, who succeeded TOMMY LASORDA as the Los Angeles Dodgers' manager at midseason, has been re-signed for two more years.

title: Wealthy Indonesian Businessman Has Strong Ties to Clinton
description: Last year, when Indonesia's Ambassador here wanted to arrange a rare meeting with President Clinton, he did not rely on the State Department or the White House, but turned to James T. Riady, a 39-year-old Indonesian businessman, for help. The Ambassador said he knew that the President's longtime friendship with Mr. Riady was how Mr. Clinton ''came to be familiar with Indonesia.''

title: Misfits and Mischief Makers In a Portrait of the Artist
description: In a production that gives every evidence of being a labor of love, Truman Capote's 1951 novel ''The Grass Harp'' has been brought to the screen. The result is a success: a sweet, wise, funny, poignant film that rides on a first-rate cast applying its considerable talents to the engaging tale of young Collin Fenwick (played as a teen-ager by Edward Furlong), who comes to live with his spinster cousins in a sleepy Southern town after his mother and father die in swift sequence.

title: A Private Dole?
description: When Bob Dole resigned from the Senate five months ago, his speech seemed to suggest that voters would get to see more of the private side of his life: a former Kansas Senator as ''just a man.'' But images of Bob Dole in situations outside of politics are few and far between in this campaign. Colleagues and aides say this is in part because he is an intensely private person, but also because his life is politics.

title: Kisses From Neil Diamond
description: When Neil Diamond performed at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Tuesday night, it was easy to tell when he was nearing the end of a song. An arm went up, preparing for the big final flourish on the last note and then, perhaps, a kiss flung to the crowd. Next, he flattered the audience or called for a sing-along. His voice, once a virile growl, now bottoms out like a transmission scraping a pothole, but he knew fans would gladly join in. On the arena circuit year after year, they applaud his mixture of grandiose pretensions and proud self-pity.

title: Blenheim and Reed Silent on Merger Report
description: Blenheim P.L.C., a British conference and exhibition organizer, and the British-Dutch publisher Reed Elsevier, had no comment yesterday on a newspaper report that Reed had offered to buy Blenheim for $:493 million ($772 million). The Daily Mail, citing ''informed sources,'' said Blenheim had received a bid of $:5.30 a share.

title: Monsanto Plans to Sell or Spin Off Chemical Unit
description: The Monsanto Company plans to sell or spin off its chemical operations and instead concentrate on its drug biotechnology lines and popular products such as Nutrasweet and Roundup, the company said yesterday.

title: Wells Withstands the Pressure at the Stadium
description: The great hockey goalie Bernie Parent, hidden behind a mask throughout a stellar career, was said to make his personality felt with a sinister laugh just when the opposition seemed more than ready to try to make him cry.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sir ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER also knows how to celebrate a milestone. With all three of his wives in attendance.

title: Art in Review
description: Philip Guston

title: Kissing Pupil Is at Center Of New Clash On Discipline
description: The Queens boy who kissed a classmate and became part of a national furor over the meaning of sexual harassment has become the subject of a new dispute over discipline between local school officials and the central school administration.

title: From Bad to Worse, A Life Slipping Away
description: Skinny, bug-eyed Steve Buscemi, the twitchy actor du jour of American independent films, makes a striking directorial feature-film debut with ''Trees Lounge,'' in which he also stars as a twitchy, hyperkinetic loser. This microscopic portrait of a Long Island town not unlike the actor's native Valley Stream, suggests Eugene O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh'' grafted onto a Billy Joel song by John Cassavetes. As it follows the downward spiral of Tommy Basilio (Mr. Buscemi), a 31-year-old unemployed auto mechanic who spends his days quaffing boilermakers in a neighborhood watering hole, you sense a life slipping woozily into the abyss.

title: A War's Children, A Practical Lens
description: FOR a long while, pictures of war were almost exclusively of men and battle sites, and pictures of the wounded were naturally of soldiers. The landmark year for photographs of injured children as emblems of war's inhumanity seems to be 1937. In that year the image of a screaming baby on a railroad platform after the Japanese bombed Shanghai electrified world opinion, and Robert Capa's photograph of a father carrying a wounded boy during the Spanish Civil War signaled intensified interest in civilian casualties. Three years later, the terrors of German bombing campaigns against Britain were brought home by Cecil Beaton's picture of a tearful little girl in bed, her head wrapped in a big bandage, her arms wrapped about a stuffed doll.

title: Little Paintings With Big Visions
description: SO far, the season's sleeper is ''In the Light of Italy: Corot and Early Open-Air Painting,'' at the Brooklyn Museum. Though full of intricate implications, it consists of 130 smallish, sometimes very small, works of sweet and simple perfection. Except for Corot and a few others, the 48 painters in it are obscure, and you're excused if you have never heard of Ernst Fries, Gilles-Francois Closson or Simon Denis. But I bet that after seeing their evocative and unlabored sketches of Roman ruins and stony Italian hill towns like Civitella and Olevano painted in an apricot light, you won't soon forget them.

title: Japanese Aide Gains Favor By Fighting the Bureaucrats
description: Traditionally, the most successful Japanese politicians have been wealthy, aristocratic or influential in the bureaucracy.

title: Archeological Fairness
description: To the Editor:

title: Durang on Desire, From Aahs to Oohs
description: IS there a Croix de Guerre for actors? If so, it should be pinned immediately on Sigourney Weaver, who is performing breath-stopping deeds of bravery at the Cort Theater, where Christopher Durang's unfortunate ''Sex and Longing'' opened last night.

title: Belmar Fire Delays Trains
description: A fire in a store near the train tracks in Belmar disrupted service at 4 P.M. yesterday on New Jersey Transit's North Jersey Coast Line, a railroad spokesman, Ken Miller, said. He said the fire, at a variety store named Good Stuff Cheap, was controlled by 5:30 P.M. Some rail passengers took the bus between Bradley Beach and Spring Lake.

title: End of a Charade
description: The Israeli-Palestinian peace process launched in Oslo has paid large economic and political dividends for Israel. In three years, foreign investment in its economy tripled. Israel exchanged diplomats with 38 more countries. Ties began with Arab states in North Africa and the Persian Gulf, and Jordan signed a peace treaty.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC., Islandia, L.I., a software company, acquired Digital Equipment Corp.'s Asset Works desktop computer management system. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: In Housing Battle, Faint Hope and a Few Bright Spots
description: Ana Nunez, paying $350 a month for a tiny, illegal room above a pawnshop on the Lower East Side, illustrates the harsh realities of housing for many of the poorest New Yorkers.

title: On Catwalks: Black, Male and Muscular
description: WASHINGTON  It's too early, and perhaps too optimistic, to say that black men are defining this fashion moment's standard of masculine beauty. But black male models have risen in prominence on the runway and in advertising.

title: Federal Express Knows Its Way Around Capital
description: As the Senate rushed to adjournment earlier this month, one odd and seemingly inconsequential item stood in the way: the insertion of a few words in a 1923 law regulating railway express companies.

title: Of N.Y.P.D. Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets' New Casualty: Graham
description: Jeff Graham joined the best players on the Jets today -- in the trainer's room.

title: Parents Are Ordered To Permit Girl's Surgery
description: The parents of Rachel Stout, the Fort Worth girl at the center of an international battle over parental rights and the merits of alternative medicine, have until 3 P.M. Saturday to consent to surgery to remove their daughter's severely ulcerated colon.

title: Plea Bargain Is Discussed In Rape Case of Ex-Fugitive
description: With his rape trial scheduled to begin on Tuesday, lawyers for Alex Kelly, the Darien man who fled to Europe after being charged with two sexual assaults a decade ago, were negotiating a possible plea bargain last night with prosecutors and a lawyer for one of his accusers. The talks lasted until after 8 P.M. and appeared likely to continue this weekend.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: In Success for Simpson, Judge Says Defense Can Assert Police Plot on the Bloody Glove
description: Handing a notable victory to O. J. Simpson's defense lawyers, a Santa Monica judge ruled today that they could assert in their opening arguments that a police detective had planted the famed bloody glove behind Mr. Simpson's guest house in an effort to frame him.

title: Robert Andrew Hingson, 83, A Pioneer in Public Health
description: Robert Andrew Hingson, a pioneer in the field of public health who made important contributions to anesthesia for safer, easier childbirth and to mass immunizations with the ''jet'' injection, died on Wednesday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Lake City, Fla.

title: Court Decides Microsoft Owes Some Benefits To Freelancers
description: In a decision that could make it harder for companies to treat workers as independent contractors, a Federal appeals court has ordered the Microsoft Corporation to pay employee benefits to hundreds of workers who, the court found, were regular employees and not independent contractors, as Microsoft insisted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Medical Waste Laws Sought
description: Twice last spring, medical waste has washed up on beaches in northern New Jersey -- once in Sewaren, in Woodbridge Township, and another time in Keansburg, where a 7-year-old girl stepped on a hypodermic needle.

title: Taking a Trip Back in Time To the Sleek Young Stones
description: In December 1968, the Rolling Stones and friends met in a North London television studio to film a concert, complete with fey late-60's flourishes like a fire-swallower, circus costumes for the rock stars and silly hats and smocks for the studio audience. The Stones were joined by the Who, Taj Mahal, Eric Clapton and other musicians.

title: From Former Yugoslavia, Revelry With Allegory
description: Emir Kusturica's wild, sprawling ''Underground'' begins with drunken revelry, the kind that erupts frequently throughout the course of the film and accounts for a good deal of its three-hour running time. If Mr. Kusturica, who won the Palme d'Or at the 1995 Cannes International Film Festival for this feverish, whimsical allegory elevated by moments of brilliant clarity, appears to be overindulging a taste for celebration, he has good reason.

title: Lagerfeld, Still Dynamic, Shares Spotlight
description: Few great film makers are really auteurs. Similarly, few collections are the singular product of a designer, unless he or she is at once an illustrator, pattern maker, draper, sewer, knitter and stylist.

title: MOHAWK INDUSTRIES TO BUY SOME DIAMOND RUG ASSETS
description: Mohawk Industries Inc. said yesterday that it intended to buy certain assets of Diamond Rug and Carpet Mills Inc. for up to $43 million. Mohawk, a carpet maker based in Calhoun, Ga., said the acquired assets would help it begin selling polypropylene products and expand its polyester product line. Mohawk said the purchase would be in accordance with Diamond Rug's reorganization plan under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.

title: Timorese Bishop and Exile Given Nobel Peace Prize
description: A Roman Catholic bishop and an exiled independence campaigner were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today for their work to end years of oppression and violence in East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that was invaded and annexed by Indonesia in the 1970's.

title: Giuliani Sues U.S. Over Welfare Law
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani filed a lawsuit against the Federal Government yesterday, challenging provisions of the new welfare and immigration laws that allow city employees to turn in illegal immigrants who seek services like police protection, hospital care and public education.

title: End the Union?
description: To the Editor:

title: Coya Knutson, 82, Legislator; Husband Sought Her Defeat
description: Former Representative Coya Knutson of Minnesota, a fierce champion of family farms, medical research and campaign finance reform and the creator of Federal student loans, died at a nursing home in Edina, Minn., on Thursday, her legislative achievements all but overshadowed by her vindictive husband's ''Coya, Come Home'' campaign that led to her defeat after two terms in 1958. She was 82.

title: Impact of Canadian Strike Extends Beyond G.M.
description: Toyota Corollas that are assembled in North America use a part manufactured at a General Motors factory in Canada that is now on strike, showing the increasing vulnerability of auto makers to labor walkouts as they buy more parts from each other.

title: Fewer Unwed Mothers
description: Last year the illegitimacy rate in America dropped for the first time in 20 years. The number of babies born to teen-agers also declined for the fourth year in a row. There may be several factors at work here -- more accurate reporting, for example, and wider use of contraceptives, particularly among teen-agers -- but the new data can only hearten all those who worry about the social, economic and personal consequences of illegitimacy.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the British poster artist Abram Games on Sept. 27 and the caption for a picture of a Games poster misstated the full name of the British women's army unit in World War II known as A.T.S. It was the Auxiliary Territorial Service, not the Army Training Service.

title: No Headline
description: ''This is South African justice. It has always been like this. I feel very bitter.''

title: A Deal That Brings Together 2 Players in Electric Power
description: It is surprising how far an aggressive electric power company must go these days to find a growing market. For the management of the Southern Company of Atlanta, places like Keti Bandar, Pakistan, and Sual, in the Philippines, are no longer just answers on a geography quiz.

title: When Rock and Fashion Converge
description: LONDON  Sandrae Lawrence provided additional research for this article.

title: Producer Data Show Prices Still in Check
description: Moderating prices for food and energy helped keep inflation at the producer level in check last month while consumers spent cautiously at a pace scarcely faster than when the summer began, Government figures showed today.

title: 7 in Paramilitary Group Arrested in West Virginia
description: Federal agents today arrested seven people associated with a paramilitary group in West Virginia in what the authorities described as a plot to plant bombs at several government sites in the state, among them the F.B.I.'s automated fingerprint center and the state capital in Charleston.

title: Rangers Seek a Victory, This Time With Messier
description: The Rangers will play their fifth game in eight nights this evening in Montreal, but their first with Mark Messier since last Sunday. Their captain served a two-game suspension for a dangerous body check from behind along the boards. When he left, the team's record was 0-1-1. As he returns, it is 0-2-2.

title: Putting In the Boot
description: Many readers are furious because this column has not denounced Roberto Alomar. It is rumored that I am soft on Roberto Alomar. There is a motion to expel me from the Society of Newspaper Columnists for defying orders for all members to assail the rottenness of Roberto Alomar.

title: Romantic vs. Modernist:A Tug of War
description: PARIS  A powerful collection from Karl Lagerfeld  dresses forming a liquid geometry or woven into spiderwebs of knit  set the modernist battle line of thespring summer season.

title: Medical Decisions for Yeltsin -- and for Us
description: As the news reports of Boris Yeltsin's health troubles indicate, the Russian President is facing two problems: a serious heart ailment and the difficulty of finding proper treatment in his own country. As we consider fundamental changes in American health care, we can learn valuable lessons from Mr. Yeltsin's situation.

title: Old-Style Board Faulted After Botched Voting
description: Long after most major cities have handed over their elections to nonpartisan professionals, the New York City Board of Elections remains a bastion of political appointees, a situation, critics say, that has crippled the agency's ability to handle the complex task of serving hundreds of thousands of voters.

title: Agriculture Prices Spiral Lower After Forecast of Bumper Crops
description: Soybeans led a plunge in agricultural commodity prices yesterday after Government crop forecasts for everything from grains to cotton to oranges exceeded expectations.

title: 200 Mailers Win Lifetime Jobs in Agreement With The Times
description: Officials of The New York Times and one of its unions announced a tentative agreement yesterday under which 200 workers would receive lifetime job guarantees and in return, the union would give The Times more flexibility to print the paper at plants in the Northeast outside New York.

title: McGraw-Hill to Sell Plant
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies will sell its William C. Brown printing operation in Dubuque, Iowa, to Quebecor of Montreal for an undisclosed sum. The plant is part of an education publishing unit McGraw-Hill agreed to acquire from the Times Mirror Company in July. The agreement with Quebecor is subject to the closing of the Times Mirror deal.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Presses Hebron Talks

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: After 3 Days in the Spotlight, Nobel Prize Winner Is Dead
description: For 50 years, William Vickrey was the ultimate absent-minded professor, a brilliant eccentric using abstract economic theory to find solutions to everyday problems. When he won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science on Tuesday, he seemed finally to have a platform from which to make his ideas widely known.

title: New England Senate Races Crucial to the Next Congress
description: All year, the consensus in political circles has been that the Senate races in Massachusetts and Maine would go down to the wire and be an important factor in deciding which party controls the Senate in the next Congress.

title: In Cooking the Geese, We Cook Our Goose
description: To the Editor:

title: Lindros Says He Will Return Soon
description: ERIC LINDROS will be back with the Philadelphia Flyers soon.

title: Childs Injured, Out 3-6 Weeks
description: The Knicks have suffered their first serious setback of the season. Chris Childs's crash course on running the team came to a screeching halt today when it was learned that the point guard had suffered a fractured fibula in his right leg that will sideline him for three to six weeks.

title: 2 Armored Car Guards Robbed of $52,000
description: Two armed men robbed two armored car guards of $52,000 at a Dunkin' Donuts parking lot in the Elmhurst section of Queens last night, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: The Diner's Journal column in Weekend yesterday misstated the telephone number for the restaurant Mirezi, at 59 Fifth Avenue (13th Street) in Greenwich Village. The number is (212) 242-9709.

title: Dentist Is Suspended
description: A Morris County dentist who was accused of fondling nine female patients while they were in his office has had his license suspended pending the resolution of the case, the state attorney general's office said yesterday.
