title: Around Midnight, When It's Your Turn to Be Seen:What's Hot in Parisian Clubs
description: PARIS  Sally Bowles would feel right at home at Cabaret. Liza Minnelli, a friend of the owners, was one of the first to try out the small stage at thisintimate new Paris bar where guests shimmy between tiny round tables, sup on caviar and areregaledby a revolving troupe of30cabarets acts featuring everything from rope tricks and performing poodles to magicians and tap dancers.

title: Fleet Street Fable Becomes Morality Tale (of Sorts)
description: Even by their own dubious standards, Britain's downmarket tabloids may have descended to a new low in sleaze in the last few weeks, setting off a fresh round of attacks, counterattacks and flagellation from politicians, the public and even the papers themselves.

title: Deutsche Telekom to Buy 35% of Islacom
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said yesterday that it would pay $243 million for 35 percent of Isla Communications Inc., a partnership that could alter the competitive landscape of the Philippines' telecommunications industry. ''Deutsche will really strengthen Islacom,'' said Alexis Cabel, an analyst at Angping & Associates Securities Inc.

title: Company Briefs
description: BAYER A.G., Leverkusen, Germany, a chemical and pharmaceutical concern, said its U.S. subsidiary Bayer Corp. is buying the iron oxide unit of Landers Segal Color Inc. of Passaic, N.J., to increase its presence in North America. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the About Real Estate column yesterday about rising house prices in the Hamptons omitted the first name and affiliation of a local real estate broker. He is Frank Newbold, a partner with Braverman Newbold Brennan Real Estate in East Hampton.

title: Train Conductor Acquitted
description: A New Jersey Transit train conductor was acquitted Thursday of charges that he forced a 41-year-old woman passenger to engage in a sex act in exchange for overlooking her attempt to pass a counterfeit ticket. The conductor, Bryan Dunda, 29, of Dunmore, Pa., still faces an investigation by the company.

title: New Law Bans Genital Cutting In United States
description: Congress outlawed the rite of female genital cutting in the United States just before it recessed two weeks ago, and directed Federal authorities to inform new immigrants from countries where it is commonly practiced that parents who arrange for their children to be cut here, as well as people who perform the cutting, face up to five years in prison.

title: Fu's Retirement Not Up to Her
description: Although the 19-year-old Olympic diving star FU MINGXIA may want to retire, her coach said it is not her decision. The coach, YU FEN, said athletes need permission of the government sports commission to retire, the state-run China Youth Daily reported yesterday.

title: 2 Fidelity Funds Invested in Company Involved in F.B.I. Sting
description: Two mutual funds managed by the Fidelity Investment Company are among the biggest investors in a small Canadian company whose chairman was charged Thursday with conspiracy to commit securities fraud in connection with a Federal sting operation.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the theater critic Walter Kerr on Thursday misidentified the first show he directed, early in his career. It was ''Touch and Go'' in 1949, not the 1954 ''King of Hearts.''

title: Songs In the Key Of Life
description: JOHN BELTZER used to worry about making the pop charts. That is, until he grew tired of writing songs about life and love that a fickle public embraced fleetingly, if at all. Before a record company spurned him but signed the young woman singer who had captured his heart. Before his fraternal twin, Julio, developed schizophrenia and jumped to his death from a building across the street from their basement recording studio in Forest Hills.

title: FORMER OFFICIALS CLEARED BY COURT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's first attempt to hold senior apartheid-era officials accountable for atrocities against blacks ended in acquittals today when a judge found Magnus Malan, the country's former Minister of Defense, not guilty of murder charges.

title: Toward Agreement on Hebron
description: Ten days after Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat met at the White House, the Middle East peace effort seems to be stirring fitfully. The talks that began this week between Israel and the Palestinians show signs of promise, and Mr. Netanyahu's Government has indicated it is ready to lift some of the restrictions that have prevented Palestinians from working in Israel for months. Both sides now need to proceed carefully but also quickly so tangible progress can be seen.

title: Conduct Unbecoming
description: In Sunday's debate, Bob Dole told President Clinton, ''I've never discussed Whitewater . . . I'm not discussing Whitewater now.'' But two days later, at a rally in Lyndhurst, N.J., Mr. Dole's warm-up act, Michael Chertoff, did discuss Whitewater.

title: The Wild, the Seductive, the Hip
description: It is remarkable that three designers with such relatively small and exclusive businesses -- Helmut Lang, John Galliano and Martin Margiela -- could have affected the 1990's as powerfully as they have. Take away the influence of those three, and Paris would still be awash in the boxy proportions of the 80's. Along with Karl Lagerfeld, they have stood as four points of fashion's compass for the first part of this decade: all roads of what looks new today lead back to one of them.

title: Officer Guilty In Gun Death At Restaurant
description: Despite his claim that he was not the one to pull the trigger, an off-duty police officer was convicted by a Manhattan jury yesterday in the accidental shooting death of a woman who had been celebrating her 25th birthday in a Washington Heights restaurant.

title: British Premier Instills Family Unity in His Fractious Tories
description: Conservative Party members arrived at their annual conference at this English Channel resort this week dispirited and divided, but Prime Minister John Major sent them home today believing in his parting pledge to lead them to victory in coming national elections.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Debate-in-a-Can

title: Everyone Loses Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Creditors to Join Barney's Case
description: Barney's Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January, will get help from its creditors in its battle with the Isetan Company of Japan.

title: East Timor Has Chafed for Centuries Under Foreign Rule
description: In 1975, as Portugal's colonial empire abruptly ended, East Timor won independence after more than 400 years of foreign rule. But within months, civil war plunged it into chaos and Indonesia invaded, annexing the country a year later and imposing a harsh new rule.

title: Construction Company In Germany Is Upbeat
description: Philipp Holzmann A.G., one of Germany's largest construction companies, said that business had picked up since midyear and that it expected to break even in the full year, though it would post an operating loss. The company said output, a measure of sales and work in progress, was 8.5 billion marks ($5.7 billion) for the first eight months of the year. That is down 1.1 percent from a year earlier, though better than the 4.6 percent decline in the first half. The company's management was also exonerated by its supervisory board of any misconduct for real estate losses.

title: Analysis of 23 Studies Suggests Abortion Can Slightly Raise the Risk of Breast Cancer
description: A combined analysis of 23 studies has suggested that induced abortion can slightly raise a woman's later risk of developing breast cancer. The reported increase in risk of about 30 percent is considerably less than might result, say, from having a family history of breast cancer or delaying childbirth until after age 30.

title: Reeves Is Still Being Criticized in Denver
description: The Broncos have cruised to the best record in the American Football Conference and own the No. 1-ranked offense in the league, so you would think some of their players would have better things to do than criticize Dan Reeves, the former Denver coach. But apparently they don't, and there is some Reeves-bashing going on in the Rocky Mountain State.

title: Ozawa and the Bostonians, With a Mahler Blockbuster
description: The misfortune of following Claudio Abbado and the Berlin Philharmonic into Carnegie Hall after their recent resounding success with Brahms fell to Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony on Wednesday evening. It seemed almost unfair to hold anyone else to the Berliners' standard, but of course to expect any less of the storied Boston Symphony would be the greater insult.

title: Dole Advisers Try to Find Right Degree of Toughness
description: William J. Bennett, a senior adviser to Bob Dole's Presidential campaign who has been prodding Mr. Dole to get tougher against President Clinton, said today that the campaign would soon raise the questions of public trust that Mr. Bennett said had blighted the Clinton Administration.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES OUTLINES BUYBACK PLAN
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it planned to buy back as many as 20 million common shares, or about 2.6 percent of its shares outstanding, which are worth more than $1 billion at current prices. The company, which makes pharmaceutical, nutritional, diagnostic and hospital products, said the purchase would be for general corporate purposes. It announced a similar-size buyback in September 1995. Abbott, based outside Chicago in Abbott Park, had 779.7 million shares outstanding as of Tuesday. Its shares gained $1.50, to $50.375, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: It's What Underneath That Counts in Milan's Transparency Scene
description: MILAN  When Milan does a trend, it does it writ large  that's what Italy's function is in the fashion firmament. Last week, true to form, it inundated the runway with a thousand transparent dresses and sheer knits for next summer. The reaction, mainly, from magazine editors and store buyers was: So what?

title: Beijing Now Sees Stronger Trade, Not Intimidation, as the Key to Quelling Taiwan Separatism
description: A top Chinese official said today that China had formulated a long-term strategy to contain the ''separatist'' forces on Taiwan by stepping up efforts to merge the economies of the mainland and the island.

title: Episcopal and Lutheran Bishops Hopeful on Unity
description: In the language of diplomacy, hopefulness is signified by the phrase ''cautious optimism.'' When the State Department uses the term, in talking about negotiations, it means that the outcome is uncertain but that agreement is possible.

title: Game 3 Slips Through the Orioles' Fingers
description: If they are not Batman and Robin, they nevertheless are the Dynamic Duo of the Yankees' post-season forays into Texas and Baltimore.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Columbus Day to Be Observed Monday
description: NEW YORK

title: Benjamin Is Back in Canada
description: BENOIT BENJAMIN, who started last season with the expansion Vancouver Grizzlies, was signed as a free agent yesterday by the Toronto Raptors. The 7-foot center, who has averaged 11.7 points a game in an 11-year career, will play a backup role with the Raptors, behind SHARONE WRIGHT, who has been hampered by a bad back. Benjamin signed a one-year deal for the National Basketball Association minimum $247,500. (AP)

title: Seize Control of Immigration Policy Now
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Arrested in '86 Bombing of Berlin Discotheque
description: Ten years after a bomb tore through a Berlin nightclub, killing three people including two American soldiers, German authorities announced today that they had arrested two people -- a German woman and a Palestinian man -- and issued arrest warrants for four Libyans in connection with the attack.

title: Progress at the Javits Center
description: Gov. George Pataki has made solid progress on his pledge to improve management and end corruption at New York City's Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Alitalia Accused Of Antitrust Practices
description: Italy's Antitrust Authority has accused Alitalia S.p.A. of engaging in practices that unfairly harmed start-up competitors.

title: Diamondbacks Set Their First Record
description: Jerry Colangelo, the managing partner of the expansion Arizona Diamondbacks, has championed the idea of a salary cap for baseball. But yesterday Colangelo blew the lid off amateur signing bonuses.

title: TIME WARNER WINS ORDER KEEPING FOX OFF CITY CABLE TV
description: A Federal judge last night halted Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to present Rupert Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel on a city-run cable station, putting a temporary end to an extraordinary struggle involving the Mayor and two of the country's most powerful media empires.

title: Senate Candidates at Forum
description: Voters who want to get a closer look at one of this year's more acrimonious Senate campaigns will have an opportunity Sunday, when Representatives Robert G. Torricelli and Richard A. Zimmer appear at a forum.

title: In Mad Pursuit of Moll Flanders, From Innocence to Depravity
description: In the midst of many recent Jane Austen movies, ''Moll Flanders'' arrives like a firecracker tossed into a tea party. This Masterpiece Theater adaptation is largely faithful to Daniel Defoe's glorious and ribald novel about a 17th-century woman, born in Newgate prison to a thieving mother, who lives by her wits. As a repentant Moll puts it in the book, her life became ''a horrid complication of wickedness, whoredom, adultery, incest, lying, theft,'' though all she was trying to do was keep herself alive and well-dressed. The Moll in this colorful, literate television film quickly grasps the connection between money and virtue: in her world, only the rich can afford to be good.

title: Asian Conservatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu Seen as Eager to Complete Hebron Talks Soon
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has advised Yasir Arafat that he is eager to complete negotiations on the West Bank city of Hebron by early next month, diplomats close to the negotiations said today.

title: WELLPOINT AGREES TO BUY BENEFITS OPERATION
description: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the group-benefits operations of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company for $86.7 million. There were rumors earlier this month that the deal was in the works. Wellpoint is a big health maintenance organization based in Woodland Hills, Calif. The Hancock operations provide administrative services to corporations that pay their own health care bills. The unit had revenue last year of $800 million. Wellpoint said it planned to retain all the Hancock unit's 2,950 employees, including about 600 in Boston. Hancock is a mutual insurance company with more than $100 billion in assets under management.

title: Guilty Plea in Cult Case
description: A Democratic candidate for the Freehold Township committee has agreed to plead guilty to charges filed in Idaho accusing her of kidnapping a member of a religious cult, a prosecutor said yesterday. The candidate, Joy DeSanctis, a private investigator, and her husband, Carmine, were accused of forcing the cult member, LaVerne Collins, to remain in a motel for a week while three other people tried to persuade her to leave the cult. Ms. Collins was a member of the Church Universal and Triumphant, said Roger Bourne, deputy prosecuting attorney for Ada County, Ida.

title: New Hambrecht Index Tracks Consumer Companies
description: What do Starbucks, Cannondale, Nike, Boston Beer and Ben & Jerry's have in common? Not their products, which are as diverse as coffee, bicycles, sports apparel, beer and ice cream.

title: Argentina's Military Reshuffle Makes It Clear President Is Boss
description: If there were any doubts about who controls the armed forces in Argentina, which has a long history of military dictatorships, President Carlos Saul Menem laid them to rest today when he forced three of the country's four top military officers to step down.

title: THIRD-QUARTER REVENUE EXPECTED TO BE UNCHANGED
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it expected its third-quarter revenue to be unchanged from a year ago because of weak North American new-car sales, falling tire prices and a stronger dollar. Goodyear, the largest United States tire maker, will still manage to post earnings within the range of analysts' estimates because lower manufacturing costs and raw-materials prices are helping to offset the weak revenue growth. The report is scheduled on Oct. 21. Goodyear projects net income of $166 million to $171 million, or $1.07 to $1.11 a share. A year ago, it earned $157.5 million, or $1.03.

title: New Charter Passed
description: South Africa's Constitutional Assembly passed an amended version of a new charter today and sent it on to the Constitutional Court for review.

title: F.B.I. to Ask Victims' Kin For Clues About Crash
description: In a further search for clues in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Federal investigators will begin interviewing relatives of the 230 victims in the next few weeks, and are considering offering a reward for information that helps them solve the mystery.

title: Neste Oy of Finland Reports a Loss
description: Neste Oy, a Finnish oil and chemical company, reported a loss yesterday of 26 million markkaa compared with a profit of 1.144 billion for the period a year earlier. Sales fell to 27.653 billion markkaa from 29.910 billion.

title: Game 1 Protest Is Denied
description: The Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles entered the third game of the American League Championship Series tonight still tied at one game each. That's because earlier in the day Gene Budig, the league president, denied the Orioles' protest of their 5-4 loss in the opening game of the series.

title: U.S. Benefits Go; Allure to Dominicans Doesn't
description: The line outside the United States Consulate here begins forming at dawn, and as the police struggle to keep order and vendors hawk lottery tickets it lengthens rapidly with Dominicans who hope to join relatives already living in the United States.

title: Orioles' Mussina Unravels In Eighth
description: For seven and two-thirds innings, the Orioles' Mike Mussina was thoroughly stifling the Yankees, pushing them to within four outs of absorbing a second straight loss in the American League Championship Series.

title: CABOT SELLS COAL UNIT TO NEXGEN RESOURCES
description: The Cabot Corporation sold its Tuco Inc. coal inventory and contract business to the closely held Nexgen Resources Corporation and the Republic Financial Corporation for $77 million. The purchase price is subject to adjustments, the companies said. Tuco owns the coal inventory at two coal-fueled power plants owned by the Southwestern Public Service Company of Amarillo, Tex. It also manages all aspects of acquiring, delivering and handling coal for Southwestern Public Service.

title: Larry Flynt, Patriot
description: Calling Bob Dole, William Bennett, Joseph Lieberman, Al and Tipper Gore and foes of depraved pop culture everywhere: The next Hollywood exhibit awaiting your moral outrage is being unveiled as the gala closing-night attraction at the New York Film Festival tomorrow night and by Oscar time will be playing at a multiplex near you.

title: TV Inquiry Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Special Education Needs Trained Instructors
description: To the Editor:

title: Larry Flynt, His Epiphanies Showing
description: This year's New York Film Festival concludes with ''The People vs. Larry Flynt,'' a blazing, unlikely triumph about a man who is nobody's idea of a movie hero. Smart, funny, shamelessly entertaining and perfectly serious too, Milos Forman's film describes the Hustler publisher and his many liberties, civil and otherwise. Above all, the film emerges as an object lesson in open-mindedness, winning a reluctant respect for its main character's right to crude self-expression just as Mr. Flynt has won his days in court.

title: Bird's-Eye View of The Truth
description: WE'RE back to baseball now.

title: U.S. Criticized Banks Owned by Family of Fund-Raisers for Democrats
description: The wealthy Indonesian family and its associates who raised millions of dollars for President Clinton and the Democratic Party have had their American banking practices repeatedly criticized by Federal regulators for unlawful activity, ranging from preferential loans to failure to comply with the law that bars money laundering, documents show.

title: Hasidic Couple Trade Accusations in Court
description: Last February, a Hasidic man was arrested in Rockland County and charged with beating his estranged wife into unconsciousness with a hammer.

title: ABRAXAS PETROLEUM IN CANADIAN GAS VENTURE
description: The Abraxas Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy Canadian Gas Gathering Systems Inc. for about $85 million. Abraxas, based in San Antonio, said Canadian Gas owned producing properties in western Canada consisting primarily of natural gas sites and processing plants. Canadian Gas Gathering Systems reported revenues of $10.6 million for the six months ended June 30. Abraxas said it would combine the Canadian company's operations with its Canadian unit, Cascade Oil and Gas Ltd. Abraxas is an oil and gas exploration company.

title: O'Neill and Boggs Sit This One Out
description: Reliability has turned to susceptibility. Consistency has caved in to chaos. Execution has fizzled into exasperation. The descriptions refer to how Wade Boggs and Paul O'Neill have deteriorated from fixtures to failures, and that is why the Yankees benched both left-handed-hitting former batting champions tonight against the Baltimore right-hander Mike Mussina in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series.

title: Christian Coalition Mailing Prompts Apology to Blacks
description: In a move that has been criticized as lacking racial sensitivity, the Christian Coalition has distributed a sample of an election pamphlet with photographs depicting a fictitious white candidate espousing views favored by the conservative religious organization and another fictional candidate, who is black, opposing them.

title: Turning Limits Into Virtues On the Way To Greatness
description: Sometime in the last 10 years, Abbey Lincoln came into greatness as a jazz singer. It wasn't an easy journey. Ms. Lincoln's life has been full of refusals and revelations; she's been a movie star on the verge of fame and rejected it. She has sung in the lowliest dives and the largest concert halls. Greatness usually makes itself felt before one's seventh decade. ''I'm a late bloomer,'' she says simply.

title: Where Green Is Good, A Topsy-Turvy Race
description: In Colorado, where reverence for the Rocky Mountains borders on a state religion, this fall's Senate race is turning environmental politics upside down.

title: 2 Japan Airlines See Shares Plummet
description: Shares in Japan's top airlines plummeted yesterday amid news that the Japan Airlines Company and the All Nippon Airways Company will report lower-than-expected earnings for the half year that ended in September. Japan Airlines shares fell 5.9 percent after the newspaper Nihon Keizai reported that the airline would suffer a 28 percent drop in operating profit for the half year.

title: Rhode Island Players Disciplined
description: The University of Rhode Island dropped two players from its football team, suspended four others and forfeited its next game to punish 31 players for an attack on a fraternity, university officials said yesterday.

title: New York Racing Association Subject of Inquiry
description: The State Attorney General is conducting a criminal investigation into the New York Racing Association and its president, Kenneth Noe Jr., for allegedly ignoring or circumventing competitive bidding procedures in the awarding of construction, paving and closed-circuit television contracts.

title: 2 Desperate Families Find an Escape
description: Two women whose wretched living conditions were described this week in a series of articles in The New York Times about the city's hidden housing crisis will soon reach goals that had eluded them through years of deprivation.

title: U.S. Presses Shaky Belarus to Honor A-Weapons Pact
description: The United States, its influence limited, is trying to prevent the former Soviet republic of Belarus from slipping into a dictatorship and reneging on its promise to President Clinton to give up its nuclear missiles by the end of the year.

title: Braves Have Been at Home in Busch Stadium
description: The Cardinals would seem to have everything in their favor as the National League Championship Series switches to Busch Stadium for the next three games. St. Louis got the split it wanted in Atlanta by beating Greg Maddux and the Braves, 8-3, Thursday night. Game 3 is set for Saturday afternoon, and the Cardinals will be in their home park, cheered on by a red sea of 56,000 fans.

title: Hurled by Tragedy Into Public Life, a Novice Learns to Cope
description: Carolyn McCarthy says she never expected her life to turn out like this. The rituals of a Congressional campaign do not come naturally to a nonpolitician: the 7 A.M. meet-and-greet with commuters, the constant fund-raising, the never-ending stream of issue papers.

title: Bridge
description: Half a century ago, a young woman who had just graduated from Cornell was watching a game at Yankee Stadium and got into conversation with a man in the next box. His name was Tobias Stone, and since she seemed to be an enthusiastic and knowledgeable bridge player, he took her under his wing. He taught her the Roth-Stone system, then at the forefront of bridge theory, and took her to her first national championship. Her victory in the World Mixed Pairs in Stockholm in 1970 was extraordinary, because her partner, Waldemar von Zedtwitz, had vision problems and could not see the dummy.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Loihi, an undersea volcano near Hawaii, misstated the area it covers. It is about 8 miles by 15.5, not 13 miles by 25. In addition, a caption misstated the size of the volcano area shown. It was about 6 miles by 13 miles.

title: Yankees Haven't Worn Out Their Rally Caps
description: The Yankees were four outs away from needing pitcher Kenny Rogers to rescue them Saturday from a do-or-die game on Sunday. Good luck. They were four outs away from needing at least one more miracle in a series in which they had already received one in the opener. Good luck again. They were four outs away from a frustrating one-run loss to the Orioles after a splendid start by Jimmy Key. But good luck and good hitting found the Yankees. So did the miracle at Camden Yards.

title: Shanahan Suspended After Debut
description: BRENDAN SHANAHAN, acquired by Detroit in a major trade two days earlier, was suspended by the National Hockey League yesterday for a cross-check of Edmonton's GREG DeVRIES in his debut with the Red Wings. The forward, who was also fined $1,000, missed Detroit's game against the Calgary Flames last night. (AP)

title: Arrest in School Bombing
description: A 16-year-old student was arrested Thursday night, accused of exploding a homemade bomb in a bathroom at Palisades Park Junior-Senior High School, police said. The device, which was made from two or three powerful M-80 firecrackers and planted above a ceiling, caused minor damage but no injuries when it was detonated Wednesday, Chief John Genovese of the Palisades Park Police said yesterday.

title: Price Report Revives Bonds After a Week of Uncertainty
description: After being pounded this week by investor fears of inflation and higher interest rates, Treasury prices rebounded yesterday in a shortened session.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7

title: Florida St. Up Against History And Miami
description: The last time Florida State beat Miami in the Orange Bowl, the notion of the Hurricanes as national champions was new. Miami's defeat gave its new coach, Jimmy Johnson, a record of 3-2.

title: Swiss Insurer Cleared To Sell in China
description: The Swiss President, Jean-Pascal Delamuraz, said yesterday that Winterthur Insurance had obtained preliminary approval to sell insurance in China. It is the first European company to do so. Winterthur, Switzerland's second-biggest insurer, has four representative offices in China and its Australian unit said last month that it had established a joint venture in China.

title: In Federal Subsidies, South Gets the Short Stick
description: To the Editor:

title: For Two Desperate Families, an Escape
description: Two women whose wretched living conditions were described this week in a series of articles in The New York Times about the city's hidden housing crisis will soon reach goals that had eluded them through years of deprivation.

title: 2 Timorese Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
description: Carlos Ximenes Belo and Jose Ramos-Horta -- a Roman Catholic bishop and an exiled independence campaigner -- were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday for their work to end years of violent oppression in East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that was invaded and annexed by Indonesia in the 1970's.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Heady Days at Poly Prep

title: A Symbol Out of Jail
description: Just a few years ago Charles H. Keating Jr. was the poster boy of the savings and loan crisis, a shady operator accused by the Government of having committed about every crime associated with the debacle. He was often described as the symbol of a crisis regulators attributed largely to individual criminals rather than fundamental problems in the industry.

title: Body Planted On His Ranch, Mexican Says
description: Raul Salinas de Gortari, the jailed brother of the former President, accused Mexican prosecutors today of planting a body on the grounds of a weekend retreat he owned, as an official autopsy showed that the body had undergone an earlier autopsy.

title: From Accessory Houses, A Virtual Reality Show
description: PARIS  It is the year 2001and a standing ovation greets the Louis Vuitton fashion show by its hip young American designer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Pressures Mexico To Halt Tomato Shipments

title: Nightclub Shut Down in Drug Inquiry Reopens
description: The Tunnel, one of two well-known nightclubs owned by Peter Gatien that were shut down by the police in August, reopened last night after Mr. Gatien reached a settlement with the Police Department's civil enforcement unit and the State Liquor Authority.

title: CulturalPhilanthropy: LVMH's Image-Builder
description: PARIS  In what promises to be the cultural highlight of the Paris season,the happy few hundred of the city's millionaires and mandarins, connoisseurs and commercially important peoplewill congregate Tuesday evening in the Grand Palais, the Belle Epoque exhibition hall, for the launch party of the year's most touted show:"Picasso and the Portrait."

title: Marijuana Club Leader Arrested in San Francisco
description: Two months after raiding and shutting down the nation's largest distributor of medicinal marijuana, state drug agents arrested its founder this morning and issued arrest warrants for five others involved with the operation of the market, the Cannabis Buyers' Club of San Francisco.

title: Winning Ugly
description: Jeffrey Maier, the 12-year-old who leaned over the right-field wall and helped the Yankees win the opening game in their playoff series with the Baltimore Orioles, is the toast of New York. And why not? He may be from New Jersey, but he is New York -- the perfect embodiment of a Yankee fan.

title: A Life Journey From Hut to Presidency
description: If ever a world leader seemed born to take up the cause that would define his life, it was Nelson Mandela, the South African leader whose story is chronicled in Jo Menell and Angus Gibson's admiring biographical film, ''Mandela.'' As one after another colleague, family member or friend recalls, Mr. Mandela, who is descended from royal blood, always had singular leadership qualities and a pronounced kingly aura.

title: 3 SENIOR EXECUTIVES OF HILTON HOTELS RESIGN
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it accepted the resignations of three senior executives whose conduct delayed a gambling license for its Kansas City, Mo., riverboat casino. Hilton was awarded a preliminary license yesterday, shortly after the company's chief executive, Stephen Bollenbach, told the Missouri Gaming Commission that the executives had resigned. Hilton is eligible for a permanent license after a trial casino cruise on Thursday. Commissioners delayed the license for the $115 million casino while they investigated Hilton's dealings with the Kansas City Port Authority. The executives who resigned are the former Hilton president and director, Raymond Avansino; the executive vice president of gaming, F. Michael O'Brien, and the senior vice president of development for Hilton's gambling unit, Mark Rousseau.

title: End the City's Debate Debate
description: The Presidential campaign has demonstrated something New York City would do well to remember. Pre-election debates are useful. They may not always be exciting. They are seldom decisive. But it is better to have them than not.

title: President Wins Tomato Accord For Floridians
description: Defusing a major political issue in Florida just weeks before the election, the Clinton Administration today pressured Mexico into an agreement that will set a minimum price for the tomatoes it ships to the United States, greatly easing pressure on the growers.

title: Boy, 12, Killed by Train
description: A 12-year-old boy was struck and killed by a New Jersey Transit train in Garfield yesterday afternoon when he and another child started across the tracks after waiting for another train to pass, officials said.

title: Pataki Vetoes a Bill on Police Promotions in New York City
description: Siding again with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani against the powerful police unions, Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill today that would have promoted hundreds of sergeants and lieutenants in New York City's Police Department.

title: It's Pumpkins Galore And Animals for Petting
description: IT'S pumpkin time all over the Island, and one of the biggest fall happenings gets under way Saturday with the Pumpkin Festival and 4-H Fair at the Suffolk County Farm and Education Center in Yaphank.

title: Don't Overlook The 'Little' Composer
description: To the Editor:

title: Marybeth Ashe And Peter S. Wise
description: Mary Elizabeth Catherine Ashe, the daughter of Dorothy and James Ashe of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Sebastian Wise, a son of Ann and John Wise of Berwyn, Pa. Deacon Arthur W. Eccleston officiated at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Taking a Shine to Rust-Oleum
description: THE economy, as usual, is a sphinx. Job growth is weak and that calms inflation fears, but wages are up and that raises such worries. For some investors, these mixed signals are a call to start hunting for all-weather stocks.

title: Homers Soar Where They Were 'Born'
description: TWO teams that symbolize the home run, the Yankees ever since Babe Ruth and this year's Orioles, are dueling for the American League pennant with big bats at 20 paces from the pitcher's mound and two blocks from where, in a sense, the home run was born.

title: An Apostle of Love Returns As a Pop Mystic
description: PERHAPS YOU THOUGHT that every vestige of the 60's had already been revived and marketed to within an inch of its cultural life. The Beatles ''Anthology'' projects have been ubiquitous; the Rolling Stones have staged huge, lucrative tours; the Monkees have reunited. Miniskirts, go-go boots and psychedelic drugs have all spun around the fashion cycle again.

title: No Decline At the Civic Center
description: The article (''Clinton-Dole, at The Bushnell,'' Oct. 6) states that, ''Now it is the Civic Center that is in decline, with progressively fewer and fewer attractions . . .'' In fact, nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Steelers' Strength Lies In a Special Secondary
description: So much time was spent bemoaning their departed players that the Pittsburgh Steelers lost what little time was left to scrutinize those the team had retained.

title: James Chapman, 80, Official Who Guided Indy-Car Racing
description: James P. Chapman, a confidant of Babe Ruth and one of the most influential men in the growth of Indy-car racing in the 1980's, died Thursday at the Georgian Bloomfield, a nursing home near Detroit. He was 80.

title: Court Makes Sidewalks Safe for Artists
description: Deciding a closely watched case that pitted freedom of speech against quality-of-life concerns about sidewalk congestion, a Federal Court ruled last week that artists have a First Amendment right to sell their art on the city's streets without licenses.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE UFA STORY

title: A Dog Track's Woes Added to a City's
description: WHEN the $30 million Shoreline Star greyhound race track opened in Bridgeport last fall after years of anticipation and amid considerable hyperbole, city and business leaders predicted it would attract large crowds and help spark an economic recovery in the deteriorating city.

title: Brown Shocks Princeton For Its First Victory of the Year
description: Brown 27, Princeton 23

title: East African Countries Keep Burundi Sanctions in Place
description: After a week of frenetic diplomacy, East African leaders decided today to continue an economic embargo of Burundi, despite requests from the United States that the sanctions be eased somewhat to bolster the credibility of Burundi's military leader, Maj. Pierre Buyoya.

title: Staying Power In the Midwest
description: JERALDYNE BLUNDEN WAS A WIDE-EYED teen-ager when she came east from Ohio and discovered modern dance at the American Dance Festival, in New London, Conn., in 1959. She went on to found the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company, one of the nation's most vital and accomplished small modern-dance troupes, which opens on Tuesday in its first season at the Joyce Theater. Ms. Blunden has had to struggle to keep such a company flourishing for nearly three decades, but she has succeeded, in part because the excitement of that first encounter has not deserted her.

title: Le Cirque Ringmaster Remembers
description: ''I'M just a ghost in the night,'' Daniel Boulud, the celebrity chef, said on Tuesday. ''I'm the Phantom of Le Cirque.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: The Uncles' Game
description: I HADN'T had a hit all day. My brother, Brian, who plays second base, said he saw me walking out to my position in right-center field with my hands open, as if I were having a conversation with myself. I was asking myself why, exactly, I insist on playing these games. I am 38 years old. Maybe it's time to stop.

title: Dr. Roma Gans, 102, Theorist On Teaching Children to Read
description: Dr. Roma Gans, an emeritus professor of education at Teachers College of Columbia University who wrote several classic texts on teaching children to read, died on Oct. 4 at the Springside Nursing Home in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 102.

title: It's Thailand Versus Hollywood in the War of the Planets
description: Anna and David Popermhem's little Thai restaurant would hardly seem a threat to the vast and wildly successful Planet Hollywood empire, which has almost as many restaurants as the 50 seats in the Popermhems' place. Still, the Popermhems have caught Planet Hollywood's attention and even its ire. For two years, lawyers for the chain have insisted that the couple change the name of their restaurant if they want to avoid a lawsuit. Company officials argue that the Popermhems, who called their restaurant Planet Thailand when they opened in 1994, are trying to piggyback on Planet Hollywood's fame.

title: A Hollywood Scene He Knows Too Well
description: WHEN Jon Favreau an aspiring actor and Queens native, sat down to type out his first screenplay, he followed the experts' advice and wrote about what he knew.

title: On English As Official Language
description: Re: ''E Pluribus Unum (Or Something),'' Sept. 15:

title: Where Problem Lies
description: First and foremost, I do not condone Roberto Alomar's reaction to the umpire and feel that his actions should be reprimanded. However, Alomar's actions are not the problem, but a symptom of the problem.

title: Musical in Makeover: 'Teddy and Alice'
description: GIVEN a direct line to the Old Rough Rider's press agent in the sky, the Seven Angels Theater in Waterbury is doing something truly deathless.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Pennsylvania Bill Would Bar the Use of Unmarked Police Cars
description: Police officers in Pennsylvania would no longer be able to use unmarked patrol cars to stop motorists under a bill proposed by a state legislator whose suburban district was the scene of a highly publicized killing this summer.

title: Ms. Bucksbaum And Mr. Adamson
description: Madelyn Helene Bucksbaum and Allen Paul Adamson are to be married this evening in New York. Rabbi Norman J. Cohen is to perform the ceremony at the Hudson Theater.

title: Esther Kaufman, Peter O. Harper
description: Esther Sophia Kaufman, the director of corporate development at WNET, Channel 13, the public television station in New York, is to be married today to Peter Oliver Harper, a marketing manager at Time Inc. in New York. Rabbi David Greenberg is to perform the ceremony, in which the Rev. Scott Hoogerhyde, an Episcopal priest, will participate, at the Bridgehampton (L.I.) Tennis and Surf Club.

title: Bogus Photo in Commercial Gives Virginia Senator a Headache
description: Despite a personal fortune of $150 million, Mark R. Warner had not been able to buy a break in his challenge to Senator John W. Warner, the popular Virginia Republican. But the unmasking this week of a bogus photograph in an attack advertisement by the Republican has shaken up the race and left the Senator a tad grouchy.

title: Kathryn Haynes, Jonathan Pelson
description: Kathryn Linley Haynes, a daughter of Mary A. Haynes of Naples, Fla., and Edward C. Haynes of Aventura, Fla., was married yesterday to Jonathan Andrew Pelson, a son of Barbara and Victor Pelson of Chester, N.J. The Rev. Gerome Hall, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with Rabbi Harold White at the Universalist National Memorial Church in Washington.

title: Marya Pollack, Mark D. Lehrman
description: Dr. Marya Esther Pollack, the daughter of Amy L. and Robert E. Pollack of New York, was married last evening to Mark David Lehrman, a son of Helen B. and Harold M. Lehrman of New York. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in New York.

title: Waiting by the Phone
description: To the Editor:

title: You Can Fight City Hall: Start a Petition Drive
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Roots

title: Amateur Groups Take Symphonic Challenges
description: SYMPHONIC opportunities are by no means limited to professional ensembles, as two concerts today make clear. At 4 o'clock in Valhalla, Victor Lionti conducts the Camerata Chamber Orchestra of Westchester Community College in the Brahms Second Symphony along with suites drawn from two operas, Bizet's ''Carmen'' and Gounod's ''Faust.'' The number to call for reservations is 785-6567.

title: Abby Pomerantz, David Rothschild
description: Abby Jill Pomerantz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Pomerantz Jr. of Elkins Park, Pa., was married last evening to David Dalsemer Rothschild, a son of Joan Dalsemer Rothschild and Stanford Z. Rothschild Jr., both of Baltimore. Rabbi Eliot Holin officiated at the Franklin Institute Science Museum in Philadelphia.

title: Detroit Power and Japanese Ingenuity
description: SO you promised Christopher (or Ashley) a new car if he (or she) maintained a B average during the junior year at Whatchamacallit U. Now, after that A- in the history of visual communications -- he nailed an honors grade with a term paper on ''The Brady Bunch'' -- it's time to deliver something really spiffy. Herewith, two suggestions for the boy or girl who doesn't have everything, but is working on it.

title: What's My Line? Good Question
description: ONE of my mother's favorite hobbies is to flip through my grammar school yearbook. There I am with a buzz cut, back in 1968, toying with the notion of becoming a geologist -- or a professional wrestler.

title: Q and A
description: Free Skiing at 70, Even 60

title: T La Rock and His New Posse
description: T LA ROCK, a 35-year-old from the west Bronx, walked slowly down the corridor arm in arm with Feyga Akselrud, his 87-year-old neighbor. T, 6 foot 4 inches tall, towered over her.

title: Lee Aydelotte, David M. Boffey
description: Dana Lee Aydelotte, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Thomas Aydelotte of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday evening to David Michael Boffey, a son of Sharon S. Boffey of Post Mills, Vt., and Dr. D. Barnes Boffey of Norwich, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Thomas A. Hughart officiated at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: THE TRICKLE-DOWN THEORY
description: I cannot join Michiko Kakutani's hand-wringing over the popular appropriation of classic art works (Culture Zone: ''The Trickle-Down Theory,'' Sept. 22). As a child in the 1960's, I got much of my first exposure to classical music through the background snippets in Warner Bros. cartoons.

title: What Is Made of Broken Promises
description: FOUR and a half years after an ambitious campaign was launched to revitalize the neighborhoods left smoldering by a three-day spasm of rioting here, the effort seemed last week to have come down to little more than a couple of sound bites in the Vice Presidential debate.

title: MADELEINE ALBRIGHT'S AUDITION
description: Sciolino's comparison of Madeleine Albright as Ambassador to the United Nations to Pamela Harriman as Ambassador to France (a political patronage payoff, as is sadly traditional in that post) was offensive.

title: Defund the Mud-Slinging
description: The Presidential campaign has been overshadowed recently by the odd psychodrama of the Bob Dole campaign arguing with itself over whether to engage in negative attacks on President Clinton's character. One day Mr. Dole asserts that the President's word is ''no good'' and that Mr. Clinton may not be morally suitable to lead the country. Another day he tells reporters almost plaintively that he does not wish to invite the perception that he is mean and personal. In the background are Republican aides promising that Mr. Dole will -- any day now -- unleash a fusillade of attacks, while Jack Kemp complicates their plans by asserting that attack politics would be beneath Mr. Dole's dignity.

title: Elisabeth Magnus, Barry Mitchell Jr.
description: Elisabeth Owens Magnus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Magnus Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Barry Peter Mitchell Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. George M. Reilly performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Wyckoff.

title: From Stable to Condo in the West Village
description: One of the city's first all-concrete buildings -- the 1909 four-story stable building at 140 Perry Street in the West Village -- has been converted to huge condominium lofts, designed to sell for between $600,000 and $1.75 million.

title: How Is the '96 Vintage? A Good, Not Great, Year
description: IN a hot, dry year, ''wine is made in the vineyard,'' producers say. But after a cool and damper-than-usual growing season, Long Island's 1996 harvest looks like much of it will be made in the cellar.

title: A Master of Windows, Frowning at His Reflection
description: WHEN Gene Moore decides to go window-shopping, display artists all over New York suddenly feel jittery -- as if they were walking on glass. That's because, for almost six decades, he was Manhattan's pre-eminent window dresser, creating innovative designs for Bergdorf Goodman, Bonwit Teller and Tiffany & Company, among others. Talk about a master class: when Mr. Moore stops by, you'd better pray your mannequins have their arms on straight.

title: It May Be a Closet Door, But It's Already Open
description: ON ANY OTHER SITUATION comedy, at any other time, it would have been a throwaway line, a bit of meaningless wordplay. But when spoken by the title character in ABC's ''Ellen'' during a recent episode, it seemed a coy signal of intentions, another baby step in the direction of a television milestone.

title: Eleanor Hamilton, Karl E. Vinacco
description: Eleanor Sarah Hamilton, a daughter of Margaret B. Howland of Marion, Mass., and Charles K. Hamilton of Mount Hermon, Mass., was married yesterday to Karl Erich Vinacco, a son of Ursula and Dominic C. Vinacco of Warwick, R.I. The Rev. Leon W. Schultz performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Providence, R.I.

title: Bernard Dubin, 88, a State Court Justice, Dies
description: Bernard Dubin, a former justice of the New York State Supreme Court in New York City, died on Thursday in Buffalo General Hospital. He was 88.

title: With a Dream (and a Ferrari), An Executive Takes Up Racing
description: TEN months ago James M. McCormick, a management consultant from here, decided that he needed a hobby. After spraining his wrist playing golf, he realized that was not his game, so instead he bought a Ferrari 355 and took up auto racing.

title: Silver Lining Dept.
description: To the Editor: Recently, I bicycled from Boston to New York to raise funds to combat AIDS. I booked a hotel room at the Altnaveigh Inn in Storrs, Conn., about 100 miles from Boston. When I arrived, the assistant manager, Debbie Kaufman, advised me that I did not have a reservation. I convinced her the hotel had made a mistake.

title: David T. Fisher, Fernanda L. Gordon
description: Fernanda Luisa Gordon, the daughter of the entertainer Rita Moreno and Dr. Leonard Gordon of New York, was married yesterday to David Tyler Fisher, the son of Linda K. Fisher of Ventura, Calif., and Dr. Duke Fisher of Pacific Grove, Calif. The Rev. Elda Unger, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Stonepine Estate Resort in Carmel Valley, Calif.

title: Off Camera, Very Much in the Spotlight
description: SARAH ARNOLD has good instinct. After 13 years in television news, she could, each weeknight, deliver the goods. It seemed to come naturally.

title: White House's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Handling Traditional Oil Varnish
description: MENTION the word ''varnish'' and most people think of polyurethane. Polyurethane varnishes are made by reacting a vegetable oil (linseed, soya or safflower to name a few) with polyhydric alcohol and diisocynate. A polyurethane finish is tough and resistant to household detergents and boiling water. In spite of these advantages, there are still compelling reasons to choose traditional oil varnish.

title: High Rents on Columbus Are Amsterdam's Appeal
description: Two years ago, when Danforth Houle and Richard Sandoval were looking for a place to open a restaurant, their first stop was Columbus Avenue. But Mr. Houle said the rents were just too high.

title: When Lawyers Switch Firms
description: To the Editor:

title: ID at Airports
description: To the Editor: I read Stella Vietrogoski's letter (Sept. 8) regarding her experience with photo ID requirements. My daughter and I had a very different experience flying Midway Airlines from Raleigh, N.C., to La Guardia Airport on Sept. 8.

title: Help on H.I.V. Roller Coaster
description: It has been a roller-coaster year for Ron R., an uninsured 45-year-old with AIDS, a $100,000-a-year medicine bill and no health insurance. Ron depends on the state's AIDS Drug Assistance Program, which pays for prescriptions for under-insured people with AIDS, for the drugs that prolong his life.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: How About That Yankee Homer!
description: Cool. Jeff Maier used the word to describe the critical moment when he, a 12-year-old New York Yankee fan from New Jersey, changed the course of fate. It was the curse of fate, if you listen to the Baltimore Orioles, who lost the game 5-4 to the Yankees last Wednesday. The boy reached out from the Yankee Stadium right field wall to snag the ball that became a homer by Derek Jeter, not an out by Oriole Tony Tarasco. So saith the umpire. The Yankees went on to win their first American League Championship Series game in 15 years. Tarasco protested, but baseball officials upheld the call Friday. New Yorkers know a win is win. Hey, the Yanks stole it fair and square with a little help from a fan. Besides, the lessons learned at baseball games these days are nothing to spit at. DARYL ROYSTER ALEXANDER

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the entrance to the Disney Store on Fifth Avenue misidentified the city agency that approved the life-size brass moldings of Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse and Pluto the dog above the entrance. It was the Department of Buildings, not the Board of Standards and Appeals.

title: 2 Peddlers, New Tension
description: As Deborah Harrigan stood on the corner of 13th Street and Seventh Avenue in front of St. Vincent Hospital's outpatient unit, surrounded by the works of Shakespeare, Aristophanes and Judith Krantz, she appeared to be a popular woman. On a recent balmy day, a well-dressed man in dreadlocks clasped her hands, laughed and kissed her on the cheek. Soon after, an elderly woman wearing a vivid pink blouse walked slowly toward Ms. Harrigan's book-lined table.

title: The War at Sea
description: Robert Wise's RUN SILENT, RUN DEEP (1958) is one submarine picture that really looks like a sub. We are there - down under in a power clash. Here's the spice. The feuding officers - Clark Gable (above) and Burt Lancaster - are two of Hollywood's aging macho kings, neither one giving an inch to the other. This kind of obvious, even amusing stardust not only fits the plot but also gives the picture special zing. Besides, the two happen to be skilled actors. Their sub is a lucky one, having just missed the Pearl Harbor attack. It's off to take on an enemy destroyer. The personalities add color, and the mounting tension, with a fine climax, is waterproof - SATURDAY at 1 P.M. on TNT.

title: A Different Kind of World Series Rookie
description: HIS father, Jack Buck, 72, has called the radio or television play-by-play of 14 World Series. His partner, Tim McCarver, 55, has called 7.

title: Board Errs, but Ballot Stands
description: A gaffe by the Board of Elections was not enough to get Julio C. Ramirez back on the ballot to challenge Leonard P. Stavisky, the longtime State Senator, for the 16th Senatorial District seat.

title: Gifted Get Marching Orders, but Parents Fight On
description: After a year of consideration and despite sometimes emotional appeals by many parents, Community School Board 3 voted last week to shift a popular program for gifted students from Public School 9, on West 84th Street, to Public School 166, five blocks away.

title: An Ethnically Diverse North Shore City
description: HIS wife has lived all over the world; together, they have lived with their three children on the South Shore of Long Island and, most recently, in Queens.

title: Crabbing in Jersey City Offers Perspective on Life (and New York)
description: Crabbing season is winding down at J. Owen Grundy Park in Jersey City. The park, a refurbished pier on the Hudson River in the financial district, is a popular spot with local fishermen and crabbers. Each morning from June through October, a few regulars toss crab nets baited with chicken into the river and pull up big Jersey blue crabs, and the occasional eel or fluke.

title: Hispanic March Draws Crowd to Capital
description: Waving flags of Mexico, El Salvador, Cuba and the United States, tens of thousands of Hispanic people marched here today, mixing ethnic pride with political protest against what they see as growing anti-immigrant and anti-Hispanic sentiment.

title: Split Over T.W.A. Crash's Cause Widens as the Inquiry Continues
description: Breaking with their counterparts from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, some senior Federal transportation safety officials now say they believe that a mechanical failure probably caused Trans World Airlines Flight 800 to crash, not a bomb or a missile.

title: In Princeton, a Brief Ivy Interlude
description: THE novelist F. Scott Fitzgerald once described Princeton as encircled by a ''ring of silence,'' with ''sordid Trenton'' 12 miles to the south and ''the suburban slums of New York'' 50 miles north. He was an undergraduate at the time, full of strong opinions and callow pretensions, desperate to kiss a pretty girl and get into the best clubs on campus. When he left the university early to join the Army in 1917, he went straight to Brooks Brothers in New York to replenish his wardrobe first.

title: Two Relative Unknowns Try to Make a Name
description: These are strange days in central New Jersey, where sightings of political giants, movie stars and anyone else who might stir up interest in the 12th District Congressional race are suddenly common.

title: An Actor Remembers His First Director
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Shows Focus on College's Past
description: PURCHASE COLLEGE is celebrating its 25th anniversary, and one of its most prominent components, the Neuberger Museum of Art, has mounted three exhibitions that focus on different aspects of the campus's history. True to this museum's mission, it features a lot of painting and sculpture, but two of the exhibitions are documentary, even didactic, in nature. As a group, the commemorative shows are entertaining, instructive and not a little nostalgic.

title: How Parents Can Lead Children to Music
description: YOUR 4-year-old child wants piano lessons. Is she too young? Getting your 10-year-old son to practice on the violin is a constant battle. What should you do? How much are private music lessons going to cost and how do you go about finding the right teacher?

title: Seeking Poetic Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Underused Jackson Heights Hospital to Close
description: Falling victim to the forces rocking many medical institutions, Jackson Heights Hospital in Queens will close on Dec. 10, eliminating the jobs of its more than 200 employees, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Survivor of Breast Cancer Writes About a 'Time Bomb'
description: KITTY HAMILTON always believed that she would get breast cancer, but she never thought, at 35, that she would find a lump.

title: New Reserve Stirs Animosities in Utah
description: To one Utah Republican running for Congress, President Clinton's designation of a Delaware-size chunk of desert as a national monument evokes painful memories of another Democratic President: James Buchanan.

title: Mosquito Controls, Another View
description: Although needed like a Band-Aid, Connecticut's approach to spraying all the mosquitoes with resmythrin for equine encephalitis (''Mosquito Controls Returning,'' Sept. 22) borders on futility, impossibility, ignorance and stupidity. This temporary solution is as obsolete as the well-publicized ineffectiveness of antibiotics against micro-organisms.

title: Lessons From the Watershed
description: Natural disasters often lead to bitter recriminations. This is peculiarly true of floods. The famous Wilkes-Barre flood of 1972 and the Mississippi River flood of 1993 led to fierce criticism of the Army Corps of Engineers, whose traditional methods of flood control were blamed for making matters much worse than they should have been.

title: Philadelphia Lawyers
description: A POLITICALLY active group of legal eagles called themselves trial lawyers; advocates of tort reform prefer to derogate them as the contingency-fee crowd. Others, stopping short of the meanspirited shyster (rooted in German scatology), blow them off as Philadelphia lawyers.

title: Trial Lawyers, Their Money and Their Influence Have Become Issues in the Campaign
description: The Christmas Party at the White House last Dec. 15 was a glittering affair, with nearly 300 of President Clinton's most generous campaign contributors arrayed at tables in the State Dining Room. But for three leading securities lawyers attending the gala, the best was yet to come.

title: The Lion Sleeps Tonight
description: For 30 years, the Lion's Head, at 59 Christopher Street in the West Village, was the neighborhood saloon of New York's hard-drinking newspaper and literary types -- the gritterati, if you will. But three years ago, the rent went up to $10,000 a month, and then Mike Reardon, the owner, found out he had lung cancer.

title: Uttering the R-Word
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I Know It Sounds Mad'
description: THE CONTROVERSY OF ZION

title: HOW TO MAKE A PH.D. MATTER
description: And this year's Marie Antoinette award for humane solutions to real-life problems goes to Louis Menand for his suggestion that we can alleviate the suffering of unemployed academics by diluting the requirements for the Ph.D. and giving it to virtually everyone, thereby unleashing thousands more job seekers onto a now thoroughly saturated market (''How to Make a Ph.D. Matter,'' Sept. 22). Such an idea could only come from an entrenched (tenured) member of the academy's ruling class. Off with his head.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-12

title: Armored Personnel Carrier Rolls Into County's Crime Arsenal
description: WHATEVER you do, don't call it a tank. The correct name for the new behemoth of the County Department of Public Safety here is armored personnel carrier. Tanks come equipped with weapons, but the new vehicle does not have guns. What it does have is steel-plated sides, which can stop a 50-caliber machine gun round at close range -- or, as Public Safety staff members put it, ''It is armored but not armed.''

title: The Empty Firetruck
description: THE aerial ladder swayed under Ron Manke, and he leaned out of the bucket, holding an unwieldy 30-pound power saw and struggling to keep his balance. Arms extended, straining against his harness, he cut a hole in the roof of the building to let the smoke escape. The saw bit into the inch-and-a-quarter decking with a grinding whine, jerking his arms forward.

title: Maya Sites Are Focus Of Yucatan Tours
description: Two nonprofit organizations are offering winter tours to Maya sites on the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico.

title: Children's Books
description: 'FIRE! FIRE!' SAID MRS. MCGUIREBy Bill Martin Jr.Illustrated by Richard Egielski.Unpaged. San Diego:Harcourt Brace & Company.$15. (Ages 2 to 6)

title: Growing Red Tide Imperils Shellfishing Along Texas Gulf Coast
description: An outbreak of red tide that has already killed more than 1.5 million fish and that scientists thought was dissipating last week, is instead expanding and threatening the fishing and tourism industries along two-thirds of the Texas Gulf Coast.

title: Kiss Brings Unwanted Fame
description: The players: a 7-year-old boy who kissed a girl and was suspended from school, a fictional teddy bear named Corduroy, an overwhelmed school district official, a local columnist and the paparazzi.

title: A Journey in Geometric Designs And Photographs That Confound
description: A Journey in Geometric Art

title: Catholic Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Call for Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: The Code of the West: Big Sky, Big Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Nautical Casual As Silk Stockings Go Out for Dinner
description: BISTRO LE STEAK +

title: Q. & A.
description: Increases Under Rent Control

title: Allana Yoelson And Matthew Egol
description: Allana Paige Yoelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Yoelson of Marlboro, N.J., is to be married today to Matthew Morton Egol, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Egol of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Nathan Schorr is to perform the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Society's Child
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Elizabeth Dighton, T. W. Stedman 3d
description: Elizabeth Mary Alice Dighton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dighton of Pittsfield, Mass., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Theodore Winthrop Stedman 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stedman Jr. of Farmington, Conn. The Rev. Edwin C. Lynn, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Classical Briefs
description: DONIZETTI: 'LA FILLE DU REGIMENT'

title: Roll Over, Elvis, Satchmo
description: THIS COLUMN GOT OFF TO A bad start, when I asked the United States Postal Service people in Washington to send me information about their forthcoming classical-music stamp issues via Federal Express. The material came promptly the next morning -- by way of Express Mail from the Postal Service, thank you.

title: As Serene as a Teahouse in Kyoto
description: IN A ROW OF SEDATE BROWNSTONES ON THE Upper East Side of Manhattan, one stands out. The tall windows, edged in black, look like hanging scrolls. The off-white facade, the dark gray sidewalk and the weeping Japanese pine by the front door merely hint at what lies beyond it. Inside is Kaikodo, one of the city's newest and most elegant art galleries, which opened six months ago in a modernized town house on 64th Street east of Lexington Avenue.

title: Housing Crisis Imperils Quality of Life for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookshelf
description: THE BEDUINS' GAZELLE. By Frances Temple. Richard Jackson/Orchard. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up) The setting is Fez, the year is 1302. Atiyah wishes he were back on the sands and dreams of Halima, whom he loves. She is lost in a sandstorm and rescued by a rival tribe. A short, elegant novel, involving Etienne, the young French pilgrim from the novel ''The Ramsay Scallop.''

title: Spacious Room With a View, Big Portions
description: FOR decades, Skipper's, the vast two-level restaurant facing Long Island Sound in East Norwalk, has been content to coast along with heavily battered, deep-fried renderings of fresh seafood.

title: Tales of Hope and Sorrow in Bloodied Ireland
description: ON THE EVENING OF 22 August 1922, the air still holding what remained of summer light but touched by an autumnal chill, Michael Collins, the Irish genius of irregular warfare who had for three years directed a guerrilla campaign against Britain, was killed by ambush at Beal na Blagh in the hills of his native West Cork. It was so in historical fact, and now in the climactic scene of ''Michael Collins,'' Neil Jordan's powerful and luminous film, which opened Friday.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: GANGSTERS

title: Stanford White's L.I. Architecture
description: The Stanford White story fails to mention the Breeze-Merrill mansion at Whitefield in Southampton.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday surveying opinions about The Village Voice referred incorrectly to one interviewee, Lisa Jones. She is on leave as a writer for The Voice; she has not left the newspaper.

title: Democrats Hope Candidates Ride Coattails
description: TWO years after a national conservative tide swept Long Island Republicans to an additional seat in Congress, Democrats are encouraged by a more moderate mood among voters that they feel will enable them to recover lost ground on Nov. 5.

title: A Man Mourning His Daughter Is Dedicated to a Sad Mission
description: Each time a red Mack truck passes him on the road, Chuck Schmidt steels himself for confrontation. He murmurs the license number as if it were a prayer, pulls alongside and struggles to see if the driver resembles the man who ran his wife and infant daughter off a Connecticut highway one snowy evening in April.

title: Unwanted Voice
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Katherine Grund And James Kane
description: Katherine Brooke Grund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Grund of Riverside, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Brassler Kane, the son of Jay Brassler Kane of Cos Cob, Conn., and the late Marion Albertson Kane. Canon Sydney Woodd-Cahusac performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church.

title: Compromise Alomar's Paycheck, Not the Game
description: O.K., the infamous spitting incident was more than two weeks ago. It's behind us, and baseball still stands. Let's take a look at the replay.

title: Public Transportation To Bradley Airport
description: Regarding the lead article (''Bradley Is Looking for Business,'' Sept. 29) about efforts to market Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks to Fairfield County, particularly ''hassle-free'' access.

title: L. Gerstein, 78, Ex-Leader of Synagogue
description: The Rev. Dr. Louis Coleman Gerstein, minister emeritus of Congregation Shearith Israel, one of the city's oldest congregations, died last Sunday while visiting relatives in Israel. He was 78 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Suzanne MacLachlan, W. K. Fletcher
description: Suzanne Louise MacLachlan, a daughter of Suzanne H. MacLachlan of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Robert Holt MacLachlan, is to be married today in Dover, Mass., to Webster Kitchell Fletcher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Saxton Woodbury Fletcher of Longmeadow, Mass. The Rev. Sarah Hobbs Maker, a United Church of Christ minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Dover Church.

title: F.B.I. Trap Snares a Wall Street Recidivist
description: Different laws get enforced in different ways. If the government knows you have a propensity to rob banks, it will lock you up as soon as your crime can be proved. And it will try to send you back to prison if you rob more banks after getting out.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Surely there are many more interesting and relevant stories to cover than a tiresome account of some silly gay men having unsafe sex. Ultimately, this article epitomizes the expression ''Who cares?''

title: Church Thriving In Outreach Mission To Neighborhood
description: ONLY the sound of a bicyclist or ball-playing youth disturbed the silence of a recent evening in this quiet neighborhood of frame houses.

title: Pope's Tremor Is All But Confirmed as Parkinson's
description: Vatican officials, in private conversations, now make it clear that Pope John Paul II has a form of Parkinson's disease, and one said this week that an announcement confirming the Pope's ailment ''could be coming shortly.''

title: Actress's Film Honors Her Heritage
description: THERE is very little that is willy-nilly about Willy-Nilly Productions, a theatrical group of 20 actors and crew members bolstered by merchants and homeowners who are helping out.

title: Simplest Solution
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Police-Corruption Charges Shake a Chicago Suburb
description: Just about everybody in this desperately poor Chicago suburb could see the illegal drug trade flourishing brazenly on street corners. They wondered why the local police did not see it.

title: Location, Location, Location: Why Not the Inner City?
description: IN accepting his party's nomination for a second term, President Clinton made a bracing challenge to American business: recognize the nation's inner cities as a huge, largely untapped market that can generate profits, and, in doing so, revitalize troubled neighborhoods.

title: The Many Faces of Islamic Law
description: SINCE they seized Kabul two weeks ago, the Islamic student-warriors of Afghanistan have brought to the capital the same harsh rules they had already imposed on other parts of the country. They have closed girls' schools and forced women to stay home from work. They have banned music, shut down movie theaters, ordered men to grow full beards and women to cover their entire bodies, even their faces. They have forbidden surgeons from operating on members of the opposite sex and reintroduced stoning as the penalty for adultery. When a group of men tried to flee the scene of a public hanging, they were beaten and forced to watch. One cleric even called for the killing of all alcohol drinkers.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: A Handle's Arc
description: Gucci's bamboo-handle bag, a status symbol of the late 1950's and early 60's, is enjoying a revival among a new generation. Some women are carrying their mothers' originals, or thrift-shop finds (above). Others are buying new versions of the style. Many of today's bamboo handles -- shaped in arcs or circles to slip over the shoulder -- adorn backpacks, tote bags and briefcases. The handles have become so popular that fake versions of the bags are starting to crop up among street vendors.

title: Once More, The Devils Let Victory Get Away
description: For the second straight time in a season that is three games old, the Devils lost tonight after taking a lead into the final period. They suffered a 4-2 defeat to the Dallas Stars by yielding three goals in the last period, just as they did against Philadelphia in their previous game.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: I am glad to see the word spreading about programs for H.I.V.-negative gay men. But I take exception to your statement that ''until 1995, there was not a single AIDS prevention program for gay men . . . targeted to those who were uninfected.'' That's a mighty broad stroke of the journalistic pen, and inaccurate. As a volunteer, and later as program director of the AIDS Response Program of the Gay and Lesbian Community Services Center, in good old conservative Republican Orange County, Calif., I helped develop ''Positively Negative,'' an H.I.V.-prevention workshop for H.I.V.-negative men. We worked with focus groups as early as 1991; it was available to a wider audience in 1993.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: JAMAICA

title: No Headline
description: ''I hear that in the cities, people vote on the basis of policies, or on the basis of the person running. But in local areas, it's not the policy or the person who counts, but the request from a friend or neighbor.''

title: Wrestling With Issues Of Art and Power
description: YOU know my songs, but you don't know you know me.'' That's Pee Wee talking: ''a man without music'' and without a saving grace.

title: $17 Million Project At Maimonides
description: Peach-patterned drapes and bedspreads, cherrywood detail and even a recliner for the expectant father are some of the ways Maimonides Medical Center will be making patients feel at home at its new birthing center next spring. Some of the comfortable touches in the new facility are a result of advice the hospital sought from those perhaps best in a position to offer it -- repeat patients.

title: Mining the Coal in Utah
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: MY FAVORITE WARBy Christopher John Farley.Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.

title: With Determination and Heart, a Coach Builds His Family
description: HE sits, a solitary figure. On the vast football field he is alone, seated in a hardback chair that someone had carried onto the field.

title: A Nature Show That Bucks the Tide
description: MANY television shows go to imaginative lengths to disguise the fact that they are shot in a studio. And science museums have a bag of tricks for creating the illusion that creatures in their exhibits are alive in the wild. So what perversity drives Eyewitness, a science series on the Public Broadcasting System that begins its second season on Monday at 8 P.M., to go out of the way to frame nature in such obviously unnatural settings?

title: The Social Fabric
description: Any other designer, upon learning that the opening night of his museum exhibition in New York coincided with the start of the spring collections in Milan, would have changed the date rather than throw a party to which the fashion press wouldn't come. Not Arnold Scaasi, whose 40-year career is the subject of a retrospective at the New-York Historical Society (through Jan. 5) and of a concomitant book, ''Scaasi: A Cut Above.'' So the trend spotters flew off to the land of Gucci and Prada, and Scaasi celebrated without them. Their absence was presumably no more conspicuous that night than their silence has been over the years: while other designers are regularly anointed in the pages of fashion magazines (regardless of whether or not women actually buy the clothes), Scaasi has built his success directly on ''the ladies,'' as he calls them, who are his loyal customers. They say that he understands them.

title: When It Isn't Time to Build, It's Time to Upgrade
description: THE oddly truncated building between Madison and Park Avenues and 24th and 25th Street has been given a $300 million new lease on life. The Depression-era building, which was never built to its full planned height because of the economic slump of the time, has been stripped down to the frame and exterior walls and rebuilt with upgraded elevators, electrical and mechanical systems and a cleaned limestone facade.

title: Mercy College Offers Acupuncture Training
description: HERBERT LAU is a man of science who left mainland China for the United States to earn his doctorate in analytical chemistry. For the last 20 years, he has worked in medical laboratories, most recently as the chemical director at the Corning Met-Path Laboratory in Buffalo.

title: Displaced Persons
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF MAVIS GALLANT

title: Strawberry's Shots Put Yanks a Game Away
description: When Darryl Strawberry's second home run vanished into the left-field seats in the eighth inning tonight, hundreds of Orioles fans streamed out of Camden Yards and went home.

title: Jeanette Lerman, Joseph Neubauer
description: Jeanette Lerman, the vice president of corporate communications at Time Warner Inc. in New York, was married on Friday to Joseph Neubauer, the chairman and chief executive of the Aramark Corporation, a provider of managed services in Philadelphia. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk performed the ceremony at the Americas Society in New York.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: POWERFUL moral currents swirl through the week's top movies, as lives, governments and the fate of nations hang in the balance.

title: Just What Is The Burmese Problem?
description: THE military rulers here, in what used to be called Burma, know they have a problem. Derided as thugs by Western nations, they recognize that even at home their harshest critic, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, is the most popular personality in the nation.

title: Ms. Moss, Mr. Chickering
description: Sara Jane Evans Moss, a clinical social worker, and Howell Drescher Chickering Jr., a professor of English, were married at their house in Amherst, Mass., yesterday by Mary Ellen Niles Howard, a justice of the peace.
