title: What Will Gates Give?
description: ONE OF THE UNSPOKEN RULES OF the very rich is never to talk about your money, or at any rate not in public. That is why it was so interesting when, one evening this August, Ted Turner decided to unburden himself to Maureen Dowd of The Times. Turner talked about how, two years before, he had given away $200 million to universities and environmental groups. ''My hand shook when I signed the papers,'' he told Dowd in Montana, where he has his big ranch, ''because I knew I was taking myself out of the running for the richest man in America.''

title: Touched by Death, Hip-Hop Turns to Dirges
description: DAYS AFTER THE RAPPER Tupac Shakur died from gunshot wounds last month, a music video was released showing what seemed like a premonition of his death: a vision of his own murder and ascension to a juke-jointlike heaven, replete with a pearly white piano and Miles Davis as Gabriel. The 25-year-old rapper in the video, however, was not so much creating something original as he was following other performers in an emerging subgenre of hip-hop music. Call it requiem rap.

title: Hollywood Dusts Off Its Claim To Glamour
description: For years now, the fanny-pack-toting innocents who ventured a few steps from Mann's Chinese Theater on their tour have stumbled upon the discovery that in a close-up, Hollywood -- the place, the decaying chunk of northwestern Los Angeles -- has little in common with the booming industry of the same name.

title: When Oratory Wasn't Mush
description: THREE hours and two vodkas after the conclusion of the Gore-Kemp debate, your correspondent snaps his fallback video fix into the VCR. He watches Huey Long cut loose once more with his ''share the wealth'' speech, taunting the nation's millionaires by name, demanding they use their riches to feed hungry Americans during the Depression. The great antic political speech, 200-proof, warms the heart; there is none of that focus-grouping the mother tongue into a sweet porridge of centrist gruel.

title: Faces of Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Poetic Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Elissa E. Greer And Alex J. Arko
description: Elissa Ellen Greer, a daughter of Estelle Greer of New York and the late Ernest Greer, is to be married this evening to Alex John Arko, a son of Louis Arko of Rock Hill, S.C., and the late Joan Arko. Arthur Steloff, a civil-marriage celebrant, is to officiate at the Streisand Center for Conservancy Studies in Malibu, Calif.

title: Garden City's Victory Gives Flatley No. 100
description: Long Island

title: Snuggling Snails and Other Splendors in the Grass
description: THE MOST EROTIC LOVE scene in the history of film may be between two snails who bump into each other in ''Microcosmos,'' which is all about the life-and-death dramas going on in grassy meadows and swampy ponds and so forth.

title: Baltimore Is Close To Home For Yanks
description: Sherman's march through Atlanta wasn't as thorough as what the Yankees have done to the Orioles here at Camden Yards this year.

title: A Boomlet of Babies Shows Up for School
description: SCHOOL officials around the state are sounding like the Old Woman in the Shoe. They have so many children they don't know what to do.

title: Alden Byrholdt And John Reith
description: Alden Jensen Byrholdt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Jensen Byrholdt Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to John Corrin Reith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Reith of Timonium, Md. The Rev. Dr. Elizabeth S. McDonald performed the ceremony at the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church in Washington.

title: Proud to Have a Role Model (and Be One)
description: WHO Glen D. Cunningham, 53 and unmarried, a lifelong resident of Jersey City.

title: Nancy Jones And Blaine Carter
description: Nancy Quarrier Jones, the daughter of Mrs. Philip Sidney Cook of Santa Fe, N.M., and Robert McKittrick Jones of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Blaine Dawson Carter, the son of Mrs. George Washington Carter of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mr. Carter. The Rev. Stuart A. Kenworthy, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Georgetown in Washington.

title: Orphans of AIDS, the Newest Victims
description: BY the year 2001, an estimated 58,000 children in the state like 6-year-old Bobby R. in this city -- will have lost their mothers to AIDS. Only in this child's case the loss will likely be twofold: both of his parents have AIDS.

title: Harvest Ice? Jab Corn? Find the Crowbar's Secret? Certainly
description: THE wagon, pulled by two sturdy Suffolk horses, bumped along the rutted roads of Blue Slope Farm in Franklin. Its passengers bounced past rows of tall corn, which rustled in the morning breeze, and past the long barn where more than 100 cows were lined up in stalls, their calves in separate quarters nearby.

title: How Seeds Get Around
description: HAVE you ever called the dog in from an afternoon's run in the meadow, only to find its fur matted with burdock? Or have you come in from a morning's weeding and found your trouser legs and shirt a mass of prickles?

title: Innocence Betrayed
description: The Seduction of Hillary Rodham

title: Foraging for Volunteers in High Schools, Restaurants and Roadsides
description: FOR years, Edward S. Cohn has been reading about the shortage of volunteers in emergency services. He knew about it firsthand as a former ambulance corps member in Teaneck and Waldwick, as well as from his years in the Ramsey Volunteer Fire Department.

title: Charlotte Ellertson And Paull Hejinian
description: Charlotte Ehrengard Ellertson, a demographer, and Paull Erskine Hejinian, an immigration lawyer, were married yesterday. The Rev. H. Scott Matheney, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Milton Goodman, 102, Creator Of Legendary Vodka Ad in 50's
description: Milton Goodman, a retired advertising executive whose ''It leaves you breathless'' campaign for Smirnoff vodka in the 1950's helped transform America's taste in alcoholic beverages, died at his home in Manhattan on Oct. 5. He was 102.

title: Report Finds Fault With Highway Spending
description: New Jersey is spending too much money on new highways and too little on repairing roads in shoddy condition, according to a report released last week by transportation advocacy groups.

title: Quick Fixes In the Bureau Of Potholes
description: Creeping through midtown traffic recently in his dark blue Ford Explorer, the city's new Transportation Commissioner, Christopher R. Lynn, was rattling off his accomplishments to a passenger when he suddenly told his driver to stop and called the agency's central dispatcher. ''I want this fixed by the end of the day,'' barked Mr. Lynn, staring up at a dangling parking sign.

title: A Singer and a Niche
description: FOR THE SOPRANO Harolyn Blackwell, typecasting has become a burden as well as a blessing. Thanks to her agile coloratura, diminutive stature and girlish charm, Ms. Blackwell, who admits only to being in her 30's, is the perfect soubrette: in operatic tradition, a vivacious, shrewd young woman who, though a servant, outsmarts the aristocrats. (Think of Despina in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte.'') Yet she yearns to move on to weightier, more dramatic roles.

title: Determination and Sweat Land a 'Duke' at the Met
description: FRANK LOPARDO BELIEVED IN HIMSELF and his talent when no one else did. It turns out he was right. Told by the Metropolitan Opera's young artists program, in his words, ''not to bother'' in 1981, Mr. Lopardo went on to build an international career as a tenor, and he opens on Monday evening at the Met as the Duke in Verdi's ''Rigoletto.''

title: Eagles' Duel Is Now Daily
description: It is hard to miss the newspaper dispute in Brooklyn Heights. Among the piles of free local papers lining the lobbies of the bakeries, banks and bars, two stand out. Both use the name Eagle in their sky blue standard. And, in a first, both are dailies.

title: The Last Tycoon
description: DOSSIER

title: Mr. Gates's Public Gift
description: Bill Gates, chairman of Microsoft Corporation and reputedly the richest man in America, has said he plans to donate more to charity than before. Last week, he indicated the pattern of the giving: public libraries.

title: Men Who Hope Too Much
description: 'Well, we did give money to Lugar, Wilson and Specter,'' says Richard Tafel (pictured above, left), ''but Dole won the primaries, and he's actually a pretty tolerant politician.''

title: An Old-Fashioned Dance to the Music of Time
description: YOU may never forgive yourself if you don't go, just once, to sample the simple joys of Roseland Dance City, at 239 West 52d Street, a world away from the big, new, shiny Times Square.

title: '93 Report By C.I.A. Tied Haiti Agent To Slaying
description: A Central Intelligence Agency report in 1993 suggested that one of its own agents, the leader of a right-wing Haitian paramilitary group, might have helped plan the killing of Haiti's Justice Minister.

title: Slight Rise in Math and Science Scores, Less in Reading
description: American students have continued a decade-long trend of gradually improved performances in math and science but have made little progress in reading and writing, a report released by the Department of Education said today.

title: Activities for Humanities Week
description: October is National Arts and Humanities month, and the New Jersey Council for the Humanities is celebrating with a week of programs around the state. All are free unless otherwise indicated. Here is a sampling.

title: Alvin P. Adams, Flashy Aviation Executive, Dies at 90
description: Alvin P. Adams, an aviation executive who came of age in the Roaring Twenties and never outgrew the roar, died on Oct. 2 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 90 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mill Workers' Homes Now a Delaware Inn
description: A village that housed workers at DuPont powder mills and factories in the 19th century is being converted into one of the more luxurious lodgings in the Brandywine Valley near Wilmington, Del. The Inn at Montchanin Village, which opened 22 of its planned 37 rooms and suites in June, is a cluster of simple structures, as befits their history; but interiors are lavish, with windows draped in elegant fabrics, bathrooms paved with marble. The decor takes some unexpected turns -- in the lobby, zebra-striped pillows are tucked into couches covered in a jungle print, and in the 55-seat restaurant, Krazy Kat's, the feline theme extends to the brocade in the waiters' vests.

title: A Giant of the New Surveys His Rich Past
description: IN AMERICAN ART, GRAND OLD men are always in short supply. The climate is too mercurial to support a pantheon of living icons. Fashions change. Careers go down in flames or sputter out. So when one of them has a career-summing retrospective, there's a charge of history in the air.

title: Julie K. Barten Roberto de Alba
description: Julie Karina Barten, a museum conservator, and Roberto de Alba, a book editor, were married yesterday in Olive, N.Y., at the country home of the bride's parents, Drs. Sybil and Harvey Barten. Rabbi Hirshel Jaffe performed the ceremony.

title: Anxiety Increases With the Number of Ranger Losses
description: Four weeks ago, in the new Molson Center, five Rangers participated in one of the most important and exciting hockey games of their lives.

title: Jennifer Garrett and Per R. Olsson
description: Jennifer Lee Garrett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Garrett of New York, was married last evening to Per Ragnar Olsson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leif Olsson of Orebro, Sweden. Judge Phylis Skloot Bamberger of the New York State Court of Claims officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Family and Friendship Guide Japanese Voting
description: Waiting for customers to buy his octopus dumplings, Yukihiro Hatta puffed on a cigarette and explained that elections never make a tad of difference, but that he always votes.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Columbus Day is tomorrow.

title: Hooked, Winged or Eaten, Seeds Get Around
description: HAVE you ever called the dog in from an afternoon's run in the meadow only to find its fur matted with burdock? Or have you come in from a morning's weeding and found trouser legs and the shirt a mass of prickles?

title: HOW TO MAKE A PH.D. MATTER
description: If getting a doctorate in English were like getting a law degree, then the average Ph.D. student would graduate with some $40,000 to $60,000 of debt. Young lawyers can afford to shoulder this burden, but what are grads in English or history supposed to do? Work off their loans as private tutors or editorial assistants? The current system may be flawed, but what Menand doesn't mention is that it also makes graduate education available to many students who couldn't otherwise afford it: ''$10,000 worth of debt'' for eight years of graduate school is a bargain!

title: Kemp Adds Bite to Attack on White House
description: With Bob Dole off the campaign trail and in strategy meetings with aides, Jack Kemp and Speaker New Gingrich assailed President Clinton and his Administration with a vengeance today on the issue of ethics.

title: RACES FOR HOUSE ARE SHOWING SIGNS OF GETTING CLOSER
description: The race for control of the House of Representatives, in some doubt for weeks, is showing signs that Democrats' chances are improving and that Republicans are struggling to undo the effects of millions of dollars of hostile A.F.L.-C.I.O. advertising.

title: When Your C.D. Is in Francs or Pounds
description: Q. I want to diversify my portfolio by investing in foreign currency. Will any United States bank sell me a certificate of deposit in Australian dollars?

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Silent Orioles
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jamie A. Levitt, Geoffrey W. Smith
description: Jamie Alison Levitt, a daughter of Joan and Dr. Robert Levitt of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Geoffrey Woodward Smith, the son of Sherley and Dr. Thomas Smith of Weston, Mass. Rabbi Bernard Perelmuter officiated with the Rev. Catherine Powell, an Episcopal minister, at the Albermarle Estate of the American Boychoir School.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Backfire

title: Bowden Finally Gets a Victory in Miami
description: This was the game, and the place, that Bobby Bowden once said would appear on his tombstone. That was how painful the heartbreak became for the Florida State Seminoles, who year after year would defeat nearly everyone but Miami, and would win nearly everywhere but here.

title: It's Time To Tune Up Job Benefits
description: ADAM and Margaret Ksiazak are facing a ritual that is becoming as regular for millions of American workers as the arrival of the new year.

title: Landscape Returns to the Foreground
description: LANDSCAPE was the favorite art form in America after the early 19th-century paintings of the Hudson River School emphasized that there was a lot of land out there and that much of it was dramatic indeed. But its domination ended with the rise of Modernism, meaning abstraction. Now, a general awareness that the environment needs to be taken care of and the widespread popularity of art that makes a political statement have combined to return landscape to the foreground.

title: An Educational Cause Sends Celebrities South
description: As head of West Coast television for the William Morris Agency, responsible for such shows as ''Roseanne'' and ''Murphy Brown,'' Sam Haskell is about as Hollywood as they come. But he has not forgotten his roots in small-town Mississippi.

title: It Can Feed a Village
The Media Titans' Battle: I Duck for Cover
description: IN the dream, my elected protector, Rudy, is in the schoolyard with two of the biggest bullies in the neighborhood, and I don't know if he is being brave or foolish or both, but I am screaming at him to back off -- don't get in the middle of their fight. I'm on the other side of the chain-link fence and as in most dreams like this one, my screams are silent. This is not organized crime, Rudy. These guys are huge. Sure, they can make you president, but they can also make you over, or make you dead. Worst of all, they can make a deal with each other and cut you out, and then tear down the fence and come after the rest of us.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page cross-reference last Sunday summarizing an article in the Arts and Leisure section about the screenwriter John Pogue misstated his age. He is 31, not 29.

title: As Lowery Reaches Record, His Career Is Up, and It Is Good
description: Nick Lowery remembered a time long ago, when he sat, worried, on the Jets' flight back to New York. He had messed up two field goals.

title: Bringing Out the Beast In Hollywood
description: WHILE Southern California is better known for sunshine than shadows, each October Hollywood goes Holly-weird, joining the rest of the country to celebrate Halloween, the latest mega-holiday. Evidence of the multibillion-dollar Halloween industry -- growing like some mutating organism from a 1950's science fiction film -- is everywhere: a drive through neighborhoods in late October will provide glimpses of homes and yards ghoulishly decked out with the kind of elaborate lighted displays once reserved for Christmas.

title: Angry? Not I, Said the Author
description: I HAD NEVER PUBLISHED A novel -- though I'd written one and begun another -- when I got a call one night from Todd Harris, an agent I'd never heard of, from Triad, an agency I didn't know. He'd been sent ''First Wives Club,'' my much-rejected manuscript, and had, unbeknown to me (but with my subsequent eternal gratitude) the brains and clout to present it to three producers, all women.

title: Company Kept False Logs on Driver's Hours
description: A Westchester propane company pleaded guilty yesterday to keeping falsified work records regarding a truck driver killed in a 1994 accident on Interstate 287 that injured 23 people, Federal prosecutors said.

title: The Prince of Death
description: CHASING THE DRAGONInto the Heart of the Golden Triangle.By Christopher R. Cox.336 pp. New York:A Marian Wood Book/Henry Holt & Company. $27.50.

title: Working With Traditional Oil Varnishes
description: MENTION varnish and most people think of polyurethane. Polyurethane varnishes are made by reacting a vegetable oil (linseed, soya or safflower, to name a few) with polyhydric alcohol and diisocynate. A polyurethane finish is tough and resistant to household detergents and boiling water. Despite these advantages, there are still compelling reasons to choose traditional oil varnish.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 13, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Scientists visit a Costa Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs. 2 2 THE JUDGE, by Steve Martini. (Jove, $6.99.) An attorney defends a judge he doesn't like against murder and other charges. 3 5 THE GREEN MILE: COFFEY ON THE MILE, by Stephen King. (Signet, $3.99.) The sixth and concluding installment of a thriller set on death row. 4 53 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) A murder trial recalls the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. (+) 5 13 THE FIRST WIVES CLUB, by Olivia Goldsmith. (Pocket, $6.99.) Three women conspire to get even with the men who divorced them. 6 4 THE HEIR, by Catherine Coulter. (Topaz, $6.99.) The stormy courtship and marriage of an earl and his cousin in 18th-century England. 7 8 MORNING, NOON & NIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $7.50.) The mysterious drowning of a respected tycoon reveals a tangle of scandals. 8 9 THE GREEN MILE: NIGHT JOURNEY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The fifth installment of a serial thriller. 9 3 COME TO GRIEF, by Dick Francis. (Jove, $6.99.) Sid Halley, champion jockey turned investigator, probes the suicide of a revered racing figure's mother. 10 28 THE CHAMBER, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $7.50.) A lawyer represents a racist who is on death row for his part in a 1967 bombing. 11 15 THE GREEN MILE: THE BAD DEATH OF EDUARD DELACROIX, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The fourth installment of a serial thriller. 12 25 THE GREEN MILE: TWO DEAD GIRLS, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The first installment of a serial thriller. 13* 1 YEAR OF THE TIGER, by Jack Higgins. (Berkley, $6.99.) The mission: to rescue a mathematician imprisoned in Tibet and enable the West to beat the Soviets to the moon. 14* 17 THE GREEN MILE: THE MOUSE ON THE MILE, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The second installment of a serial thriller. 15* 7 MELODY, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $6.99.) A young girl, her father dead, is deserted by her mother and left with eccentric relatives. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 3 A FEVER IN THE HEART, by Ann Rule. (Pocket, $6.99.) Accounts of six crime cases that occurred in Washington and Oregon. 2 81 REVIVING OPHELIA, by Mary Pipher. (Ballantine, $12.50.) The dangers for teen-age girls. (+) 3 5 A CIVIL ACTION, by Jonathan Harr. (Vintage, $13.) A lawsuit brought by Massachusetts householders against industrial polluters. (+) 4 27 THE LIARS' CLUB, by Mary Karr. (Penguin, $11.95.) A poet recalls her troubled childhood. (+) 5 4 MY POINT . . . AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $6.50.) Observations on life by the television star and stand-up comedian. 6 20 SLEEPERS, by Lorenzo Carcaterra. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The true story, the narrator claims, of boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take. 7* 1 HIGH TIDE IN TUCSON, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) Essays about motherhood, nature and other topics by the novelist. 8 30 HOW THE IRISH SAVED CIVILIZATION, by Thomas Cahill. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The story of monks who copied Western literature. (+) 9 1 LONGITUDE, by Dava Sobel. (Penguin, $10.95.) The story of John Harrison, the 18th-century Englishman who invented the chronometer. 10 11 MINDHUNTER, by John Douglas and Mark Olshaker. (Drew/Pocket, $6.99.) The F.B.I. team that studies serial killers and assassins. 11* 15 NEW PASSAGES, by Gail Sheehy. (Ballantine, $12.95.) How changing social conditions and longer life expectancies affect our lives. (+) 12* 673 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) Inspiration. (+) 13* 143 CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (Harper Perennial, $12.) Daily spirituality. (+) 14* 13 MY AMERICAN JOURNEY, by Colin L. Powell with Joseph E. Persico. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The autobiography of the former general. 15* 25 PAULA, by Isabel Allende. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) The novelist tells stories of her family's life as she tends her fatally ill daughter. (+) 16* 107 EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Bantam, $5.99.) A woman's near-death experience. (+) 17* 19 GOD: A BIOGRAPHY, by Jack Miles. (Vintage, $15.) Perceptions of the Old Testament Deity. (+) Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 3 IT'S A MAGICAL WORLD, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $14.95.) A new collection of ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 1 FUGITIVE FROM THE CUBICLE POLICE, by Scott Adams. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) ''Dilbert'' cartoons about life in and out of the office. 3 107 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE SOUL, compiled by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Stories meant to ''open the heart and rekindle the spirit.'' (+) 4 25 DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (M. Evans, $12.95.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)

title: A Spiritual Quest Realized But Not in Stone
description: ALL ARCHITECTURE, FOR Louis I. Kahn, was spiritual. The act of entering a work of architecture, the act of contemplating it, above all the act of making it -- these were all parts of a deeply spiritual quest for Kahn, a man who was not religious in the conventional sense but for whom architecture resonated with a passion that made it, for him, a route to the kingdom of heaven.

title: Gators Have No Mercy on the Tigers
description: When word leaked back to University of Florida Coach Steve Spurrier that the Louisiana State defensive coordinator, Carl Reese, was giving clinics over the summer on how to stop the Gators' offense, Spurrier seethed.

title: In Another League the Ducks Get the Deep Freeze
description: Beautiful Thing

title: At 82, Legendary Mediator Has a Vision for E. 64th St.
description: To cap his career, the legendary labor mediator Theodore W. Kheel says he is throwing himself and $12 million into a new project devoted to his favorite causes.

title: Of Gleaming Trout and Undying Friendship
description: Vic is dead and I am still trying to comprehend that unacceptable subtraction.

title: Back to the Classroom, With a Wealth of Experience
description: ACROSS the aisle, the solutions to calculus problems sprawl out across a blackboard. At lunchtime, opened textbooks reveal the details of 19th century American history and computer networking. Voices in the hall speculate: Who did you get for Intro to Chemistry? What's the prerequisite for Programming in C++? How many more credits until you graduate?

title: One Killed and 7 Hurt in Shooting at Illegal Club
description: A patron at an illegal East Harlem social club fired an automatic weapon into the crowded dance floor Friday night, killing a teen-ager and injuring seven other people, the police said.

title: President Signs a Bill to Restore the Everglades
description: Seeking to emphasize his sensitivity to environmental issues in an election year, President Clinton today signed a $3.8 billion Federal water projects bill that authorizes spending up to $75 million to help preserve and restore the Florida Everglades.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: How rare to see an article that explores with such sensitivity and honesty the tangled panoply of human feelings. Yes, survivors suffer too, whether the context is the Holocaust, plagues past or our present-day pandemic.

title: A Leader of '89 China Protest Held on Subversion Charges
description: Wang Dan, among the most prominent student leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989, has been charged with conspiracy to overthrow the Government, a capital crime.

title: At the True 'Trial of the Century'
description: OF all the trials proclaimed ''Of the Century,'' the 1925 trial of Tennessee v. Scopes was the true one. Its courtroom became the battleground for America's Hundred Years War, a slashing conflict of profound issues still being fought in local school districts and countrywide political campaigns.

title: Wendy Brewer and Stockie Rhawn
description: IN the fall of 1992, Gwendolyn Brewer's love life was so disappointing that she made a resolution to introduce herself to the next handsome stranger she came across.

title: Sweden Awards Its Nobel Prizes
description: By Friday, the world was richer by a brace of Nobel laureates. Already deemed wise by peers and the public, the men chosen became richer, too. Each prize was worth $1.12 million.

title: A Slow Boat to the World Series
description: By the time you read this, the Yankees-Orioles game should be over. Last night's Yankees-Orioles game, that is.

title: Fraternite
description: To the Editor: I returned to France recently for the first time since 1965. It was a most gratifying time for us. I had a chance to speak French in Paris, Blois and in Nice.

title: Where Wild Migrants Might Find Respite
description: PORCUPINES shimmying up tulip trees, ravens clanging like bells over valleys and hermit thrushes tweedling their flutelike songs at treetop level -- these are just a few of the things that Federal officials hope to preserve along the Connecticut River with the creation of a four-state national wildlife refuge.

title: Log On and Chat About Shoe Polish
description: AT the dawn of the graffiti age in the 1970's, New York City teen-agers spray-painted subway cars as a way to reach a mass audience extending from, say, the Bronx Zoo to Brooklyn College in a single hour. Today, their curlicues can loom across entire continents many times faster than a bullet train, traveling on what could be called the Information Supersubway.

title: On Mental Health, Companies Vary
description: WHEN a Lilco employee was having marriage problems that interfered with work, he went to the Employee Assistance Program at the utility.

title: On a Back Road From Siena
description: AS the network of superhighways has spread over Italy, there has grown up a kind of romanticism attached to the old avenues of communication, the surviving Roman roads, the byways. Their charm can be exaggerated, but last summer, when a friend and I had to go on business to a Tuscan town neither of us knew, a simple drive turned into a journey of discovery.

title: Williams Elevating The Level of His Game
description: Bernie Williams knows what it's like to await the birth of a child; he has three children. Now he has learned what it's like to play post-season baseball at the highest level of intensity and focus.

title: Lifted Lamp, Golden Door, Changing Rules
description: THEY start with a dream of seeing families -- usually their own -- reunited in America. They work extra jobs here, abandoning leisure time to save money. They sign one petition after another, promising to make even more sacrifices on behalf of loved ones. They wait and they wait, sometimes for a decade or more, until their turn comes.

title: With Childs Out, Ward Will Run Knicks' Offense
description: When asked how much Charlie Ward has improved, Jeff Van Gundy doesn't look at this season versus last season. It is much too confining a comparison, he says.

title: An Ailing Zapatista Gets a Triumphant Welcome in Mexico City
description: A small and ailing Indian woman known as Commander Ramona of the Zapatista rebels made a triumphant arrival in Mexico City's huge central square today, the first leader of the guerrilla army to appear at a demonstration outside the group's base in the southern state of Chiapas.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: STORYBOOK ART

title: All Alone in the City
description: APPROACHING EYE LEVEL

title: FACING THE MUSIC: If You Want to Dance
description: Compact disks are worth no more that 10 to 15 cents in raw materials, but when you figure in the costs of production, distribution and advertising, not to mention the music itself, the cents add up. If the prices charged by these Manhattan stores seem too high, take heart: in Europe and Japan, the average cost of a CD is $25 to $30.

title: The Off Season in the Hamptons Is Getting Busy
description: THE four-bedroom, fully furnished period house that Stephen R. Steinberg has rented for $1,200 a month since Sept. 15 in the center of Bridgehampton commands roughly $15,000 a month for the summer season.

title: Sometimes He Feels Like a Nut (It's Not Always Easy)
description: Standing on the brown-stained apron of his garage next to a growing, blackening heap of walnut tailings, feet clad in heavy work boots to tromp nuts out of their fleshy husks, Blake Patterson said he understood why the path to black walnut heaven is seldom traveled by the multitude.

title: Post Time, Dinner Time   A Grand View of the Ponies  And Some Good Steak, Too
description: EVEN the best restaurant won't lure my friend Jesse out to New Jersey, but the racetrack will.

title: South Africa Slow to Battle Spread of Tuberculosis
description: Collin Rass, a 27-year-old house painter, has tuberculosis that is resistant to drugs. If he were in a New York City hospital he would be isolated, breathing filtered air under ultraviolet lights.

title: Stanford White's L.I. Architecture
description: In ''Stanford White and His Life Under Scrutiny of Descendant'' $(Sept. 22$), the author refers to several of the great architect's enduring designs on Long Island. ''Roslyn Church in Roslyn,'' your reporter writes, ''was his last architectural effort before his death in 1906.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Music to Rehabilitate By

title: Quel Panama!
description: I FIRST VISITED PANAMA SEVEN YEARS AGO while I was researching an earlier novel of mine, ''The Night Manager.'' I wanted a place where my British baddie could plausibly pick up a very large shipment of cocaine without being bothered by overvigilant authority. I was talking tons. The drug-agency people in Miami assured me there was nowhere to touch the Free Zone of Colon: the best facilities, they said, a long tradition, privacy and plenty of official understanding.

title: Sometimes A Luxury Jet Serves God
description: THE Woodcrest Bruderhof have lived here for more than 40 years, and people still think of them as the Amish With Cars. Not so. Why, just the other day, members of this Christian pacifist sect were talking up big plans for their Gulfstream III executive charter jet.

title: Why No One in Japan Is Down on the Farm
description: THIS is one of the prettiest parts of Japan, where clean streams ripple down green hillsides and a gentle sea laps against a sleepy shore. People are uniformly pleasant and friendly, homes are large and inexpensive, and uncrowded roads make commuting easy.

title: Melanie Wine, Matthew Tolan
description: Melanie Anne Wine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry John Wine of Redding, Conn., was married yesterday to Matthew Christopher Tolan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Tolan of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Erik Rasmussen officiated at the Beach United Methodist Church in Westhampton Beach, L.I. The Rev. Dennis Keane, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: 80's Excess Raised to an Esthetic
description: FROM ''OEDIPUS REX'' TO ''King Lear,'' the great tragedies have always had a predilection for kings. After all, heroes who rule vast empires make for the most dramatic reversals of fortune. The choreographer Karole Armitage now adds to this regal set a modern American counterpart: Michael Milken.

title: Still, a Bad Call
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Torre on Phillies' List
description: Phillies General Manager Lee Thomas said he has Joe Torre's name on a list of candidates for Philadelphia's vacant managerial position, but conceded the Yankees will probably never let an interview occur. Besides, Torre insisted he is pleased working in New York and wants to honor the 1997 portion of his two-year, $1.05 million contract.

title: A Missing Issue In the Big Race
description: IT is possibly the most conse quential and the most neglected -- issue in the 1996 campaign: that the next President could shift the balance of the Supreme Court well into the next century.

title: The Family Dynamic Behind 'Gillian'
description: IN THESE DAYS OF spiraling costs and unstable studio regimes, it is something of a miracle when any movie actually gets made. But it is even more startling when a small, character-driven movie without twisters or alien invaders manages to find financing.

title: Children Need Principles, Not Patriotism
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plan for Parents Of Disabled Children
description: SUE and Ron McDonough of Carol Stream, Ill. had just moved into their new house three years ago when the financial advisers and life insurance agents began calling -- the fallout from the purchase of their home.

title: Also-Runnings in Senate Race Join to Be Noticed
description: Four independent candidates for Bill Bradley's seat in the United States Senate have formed a group called Voice, hoping to be included in more election-related forums, round-table discussions and debates before the Nov. 5 election.

title: John R. Sargent, Management Consultant, 85
description: John R. Sargent, a management consultant who advised many large companies on strategy and marketing, died on Monday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 and lived in Bronxville.

title: Stages Up and Down
description: IN case anyone thought the forecast for live professional theater in Westchester County would be pathetically scant, don't take heart: it is worse.

title: Momism
description: FRUITFULA Real Mother in the Modern World.By Anne Roiphe.260 pp. Boston:Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title: Eligibility Changes, Widening the Pool Of Potential Jurors
description: AS a lawyer, Neal Allen of Irvington is used to courtrooms. When he was recently summoned to the County Courthouse here for jury duty, however, the experience was disconcerting.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Dateline: TROYBy Paul Fleischman.Illustrated by Gwen Frankfeldt and Glenn Morrow.79 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:Candlewick Press. $15.99. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Get Thee to a Crisis Center? C'mon, First Wives, Get Even
description: WHY, OH, WHY IN THE world did ''The First Wives Club'' end with the three women opening a women's crisis center? Why weren't our heroines lounging on a faraway beach, with oiled young studs bringing them big drinks festooned with little paper umbrellas? Don't try to tell me Diane Keaton, Goldie Hawn and Bette Midler didn't want to be seen in bathing suits. That's why God made body doubles.

title: Not Criminal Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Plummer Does It All in Sun Devil Victory
description: The Heisman Trophy voters will want this game film.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn misstated the area's form of government in 1855, when it became part of Brooklyn. Williamsburgh, as it was then spelled, was a city, not a village.

title: Amanda Crider, George Sykes Jr.
description: Amanda Ann Crider, the daughter of Sara Ann Godwin of Hagerstown, Md., and the Rev. Dr. R. Frederick Crider of Baltimore, was married last evening to George Sykes Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sykes of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Stephen Bauman performed the ceremony at Christ United Methodist Church in New York.

title: Handoff: Fish to Finkelstein
description: Development pressures, from the Times Square revival to plans for Columbus Circle to a proposal to rezone Eighth Avenue, are likely to create a more contentious atmosphere between neighborhood groups and real-estate interests, says Lola Finkelstein, who will take over as chairwoman of Community Board 5 next month.

title: Mohegans Open Connecticut's Second Casino
description: First the tribal leaders smoked a pipe for luck. Then thousands came streaming through the doors to test some luck of their own as Connecticut's second casino opened to the public for the first time today.

title: Special Tax Breaks Enrich Savings Of Many in the Ranks of Management
description: Even as the Presidential candidates debate sweeping tax breaks, American businesses have beaten them to the punch. Companies large and small have been signing up executives and other top employees for a generous tax break not available to other Americans. Hundreds of thousands of people have become eligible, most in the last few years, at more than 24,000 businesses.

title: Lobbying at Murdoch Gala Ignited New York Cable Clash
description: The party under the tent on 48th Street in Manhattan was festive, but the host, Rupert Murdoch, was also a little bit angry. There he was, ballyhooing the debut of his 24-hour cable news channel, while the very viewers he most needed to establish this $165 million expansion of his media empire had almost no way to see it.

title: On the Trail, She's First Mom And Wife
description: For a few fleeting minutes here today, it seemed as if the Hillary Rodham Clinton of old were back.

title: AIDS Quilt of Grief on Capital Mall
description: A carpet of grief covered the nation's front yard this weekend.

title: Hamptons Film Fete Comes Into Its Own
description: THE Hamptons International Film Festival is growing up. The festival that was once as green and jittery as a college freshman starts its fourth season on Wednesday with the maturity and respect of a senior on his way to big-deal status on campus.

title: The Nuns' Story
description: SISTERS IN ARMS

title: What About Shiatsu?
description: Oxford Health Plans became the country's first managed-care company to set up its own alternative-medicine group, and some of its plans will cover yoga, acupuncture and chiropractors.

title: Prison for a Terrorist
description: An 11-year struggle to bring a Palestinian terrorist to justice in an American court ended last week when a Federal judge in Washington sentenced Omar Mohammed Ali Rezaq, 38, to life in prison for the 1985 hijacking of Egypt Air Flight 648.

title: Homework's Greatest Hits
description: For students, past and present: What was the best homework assignment you ever had to do? Or the worst? Why?

title: HOW TO MAKE A PH.D. MATTER
description: As a former English professor who is currently an attorney, I was intrigued by your headline ''How to Make a Ph.D. Matter.'' However, I was dismayed by the implicit suggestion that Ph.D. programs drop the dissertation requirement and become more like law school.

title: Carol Gould, Andreas Vietor
description: Carol Humphreys Gould, the daughter of Jean and William Stocking Gould 3d of Suffern, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andreas Haydn Vietor, a son of Effi Kosin Vietor of Fairfield, Conn., and David Butler Vietor of Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Edwin H. Cromey performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: Small Businesses Find A Friend in Big Banks
description: WHEN Berc Calgicioglu of Los Angeles wanted a new $30,000 line of credit for his downtown jewelry store, his bank of 14 years put him through the standard rite of borrowing.

title: Raw Russian Politics
description: Barely a day passes in Moscow now without Aleksandr Lebed or some other top Russian official publicly denouncing his colleagues or scheming to accumulate power while Boris Yeltsin awaits heart surgery. The maneuvering looks ferocious and coldly indifferent to the urgent economic and social needs of the Russian people, but compared with Kremlin politics in the Soviet era it seems almost benign.

title: Rockies Seek Solution to Roadblock
description: Baseball experts haven't solved the problem. Maybe it's time to turn it over to the psychiatrists. Somebody better figure out the Colorado Rockies' dual personality; otherwise, they may be doomed to repeat the performance that knocked them out of a repeat appearance in the playoffs this year.

title: Raccoons in the Attic? Try Rock 'n' Roll
description: LAURA J. SIMON is an urban wildlife specialist for the Fund for Animals, an animal protection organization founded and presided over by Cleveland Amory.

title: Nicole A. Kuckly, David J. Perez
description: Nicole Abby Kuckly, an interior designer, was married yesterday to David John Perez, a photographer. The Rev. Arlena F. Markinson, a nondenominational minister, officiated at Las Campanas, a country club in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Michaelangelo, Donatello . . . Pucci?
description: THE organizers of the first Florence Biennial have been a tad mischievous. They say that ''Time and Fashion,'' a citywide show of exhibitions and installations by artists and fashion designers, is merely an inquiry into how art and fashion ''overlap, interact, coexist and influence each other.'' And they solemnly deny that they are asking the question, Is fashion art?

title: Making Piano's 12,000 Parts Equal a Whole
description: Near Lincoln Center, in the gaudy Liberty Warehouse (the one with a Statue of Liberty replica on the roof), is an unexpected bit of Old World craftsmanship. There, the artisans of Klavierhaus -- German for keyboard house -- patiently rebuild and restore the most prized pianos.

title: Oldest Confederate Widow
description: Alberta Martin, a lively 89-year-old woman living in the Alabama countryside, is almost certainly the last living connection to the Civil War. For five years during the Great Depression, she was married to an elderly Confederate veteran and pensioner who, as a teenager, had fought under Robert E. Lee in the Army of Northern Virginia.

title: Dry on Snowdon
description: To the Editor: The weather gods of Wales have been kinder to me than to Daniel Lewis (''Peaks, Pubs and Plenty of Rain,'' Sept. 8). One May, I rambled through the treeless hills with only dew to dampen my spirits. Sheep far outnumbered humans, and traces of extinct peoples were visible to sharp eyes. Because Wales is moist and green in springtime I was surprised to find that the rocky trails and stone huts of Mount Snowdon resembled those of arid Greece. Advice to hikers making the Snowdon climb: wear sturdy boots, carry water, be prepared for some clambering on all fours during the last steep stretches -- and do your best to ignore the tacky snack bar and bored railway tourists that you'll find at the top.

title: A Guided Tour of the Tastes of the Mediterranean
description: John N. Soueid bounces from behind the register to show a first-time shopper around his store, the Phoenician Bakery Market on Georges Road in North Brunswick. He is eager to explain the difference between couscous and tabbouleh, and he quickly offers a nibble of one of the half-dozen types of baklava to a buyer who can't decide if she wants pistachio, walnut or almond.

title: Dara Schaefer, David Greenberg
description: Dara Rose Schaefer, a daughter of Marcia R. Schaefer of Montreal and Dennis A. Schaefer of Toronto, is to be married today to David M. Greenberg, the son of Dr. Milagros M. Greenberg and Dr. Michael L. Greenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner is to officiate at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Bedford Corners, N.Y.

title: Using a Mortgage In a Bridal Registry
description: SENSING that many newlyweds would rather have help buying a home than home appliances, the Government is moving ahead with a program that lets couples open bridal registries at lenders approved by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Development Becomes an Issue at Greenburgh Nature Center
description: THE wooded trails of the Greenburgh Nature Center here are so peaceful that a barbed-wire fence along the 33-acre property has lain bent and useless for years.

title: Advice for Diana: Have a Royal Time, but Invest Wisely
description: YOU are 35, recently divorced and alone for the first time in your adult life. But your settlement has undoubtedly helped cushion the blow: Because you are Diana, Princess of Wales, you have just walked away with $22.5 million, tax-free.

title: Lauren Alpert, Ronald I. Magnin
description: Lauren Esther Alpert, a daughter of Sharon and Jay Alpert of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married there today to Ronald Isaac Magnin, a son of Gayle Levanthal and Jerry Magnin, both of Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Gerald Brieger is to perform the ceremony at the Woodbridge Country Club.

title: He Found a Feather, And a Protector of Birds
description: To the Editor:

title: Blocked Youth
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that every misunderstood youth must be in want of a publisher. Or is it? Recently, MTV and Pocket Books (the forces behind ''Beavis and Butt-Head: This Book Sucks'') teamed up to sponsor a fiction-writing contest for unknown writers under the age of 24, promising the winner a juicy $5,000 advance. But with the contest deadline approaching this week, MTV's viewers have responded with a resounding: Huh? After receiving a handful of entries in the first month (an entry consists of three chapters from a novel in progress), the network has, as of early October, racked up 200 manuscripts. (Story Magazine, by comparison, averages 6,000 tries for each of its twice-a-year fiction contests.) What's the quality like? MTV won't say, but admits disappointment over the low turnout. ''Apparently they're taking their time,'' says Van Toffler, an MTV executive. ''There's no denying it. Literature is not the most popular art form with our audience.''

title: Stew Leonard's New-Store Proposal Divides a Town
description: STEW LEONARD'S -- the family-owned Connecticut supermarket famous for its petting zoo, singing robots, on-site dairy, bakery, plant nursery, Hoedown Restaurant and enormous range of foods -- has proposed a new $25 million store in the residential town of Orange.

title: The Boom in Park Slope
description: THREE years ago, Alan Marks, a Park Slope real-estate agent, would watch a one-bedroom apartment on Sackett Street, in an area known as the Lower Slope, languish on his list of rentals for longer than a month. Prospective tenants would take one look at the block, dotted with abandoned buildings and a few scraggly trees, turn up their noses and keep walking. It was dubbed ''Crackhead Street.''

title: A Warming Trend in Winter Homes
description: CHARTREUSE and rusty brown bunches of paper-thin ferns were clustered around the bottoms of beet-red, goldenrod and caramel-colored trees; children peered out the backs of husky station wagons, their setter dogs' heads stuck out side windows, ears flying, as mothers and fathers in plaid flannel shirts threaded their way along the back roads of Vermont and New Hampshire on a green-apple-crisp weekend. For many the goal was merely to explore, to raid the maple-sugar shacks and cider mills and discount-clothing outlets, and then swing the station wagons around and head back to New York City apartments and suburban split-levels -- to taste the countryside in autumn and return to the land of paved driveways and canopied apartment houses.

title: You Don't Need a Poll Tax To Subvert Voting Rights
description: Ed Rollins, the infamous campaign manager who caused a stir in 1993 when he said he had paid ministers to keep black voters away from the polls, lives his life these days in fear of setting foot in New Jersey. ''When I have to use the Turnpike,'' he said in a recent interview, ''I drive through the state really quickly.''

title: The Dow and 6,000: A Look Back
description: The Dow Jones industrial average ran up to 6,000 last week, and traded over that level on Monday and Tuesday. But sellers appeared, and the Dow has yet to close at that exalted level. By the end of the week, the Dow was back down to 5,969.38.

title: Help! The Car Alarms Won't Stop and The Cookies Are Soft!
description: IN a nation where a free market and freedom of expression exist in tandem, the possibilities for the telephone are endless. With just a few taps, anyone with a touch-tone phone and a problem can vent on someone else's dime.

title: Grand Delusions
description: Americans build monuments that honor the dead, that lift the spirit, that help sell foamy-spiky Miss Liberty headdresses. Sadly, though, some big ideas just don't cut it, and wind up on the statuary version of the Island of Misfit Toys. In honor of Christopher Columbus's big day - he inspired the most famously forlorn of these visions - here's a look at unbuilt edifices whose inscriptions should read: 'If I Only Had a Prayer.''

title: Pealing Bells, Bach to Madonna
description: THE tryouts are rigorous: Two months of intensive training, then the first cut, and finally, the selection. Those who make it have to have outstanding hand-eye and foot-eye coordination. They must be aerobically fit and unafraid of heights. And they must read music.

title: Legions Walk the Line Against General Motors
description: For General Motors, the nation's biggest company, the labor problems just keep coming. A 17-day strike last March by workers at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, forced G.M. to lay off 176,000 workers temporarily. Now a strike that began on Oct. 2 at several Canadian assembly plants has spread across Canada, with 26,000 workers on picket lines. G.M., which stockpiled Canadian auto parts needed by its American assembly plants, has only furloughed a couple of thousand workers so far. But with talks paralyzed in Canada, the walkout threatens to produce a massive wave of layoffs in the coming weeks. KEITH BRADSHER

title: Great Art in Small Places
description: THREE of us were standing in front of Piero della Francesca's fresco ''The Resurrection,'' and the only other person in the large, vaulted hall was a guardian, placidly sitting on a chair in a far corner.

title: Wendy M. Glass and Ari Rosenberg
description: Wendy Michele Glass, the daughter of Mrs. David E. Glass of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Dr. Glass, was married last evening to Ari Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Rosenberg of Bedminster, N.J. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: In Another League the Ducks Get the Deep Freeze
description: Microcosmos

title: Employment Workshop for Older Jobless
description: WHEN work disappears, depression is likely to take its place. So say those who conduct A.A.R.P. Works, a career-planning workshop for the unemployed. Aimed at helping people older than 50 find new jobs, the program is sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons.

title: Ms. Koehl, Mr. Binswanger
description: Carla Cleaver Koehl, the daughter of Mrs. Michael Maxtone-Graham of New York and Albert R. Koehl of San Francisco, is to be married today to Joshua Bacharach Binswanger, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Binswanger of Rockport, Me. Rabbi Bernard H. Mehlman is to perform the ceremony at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: A QUESTION FOR: Barry Hannah
description: Barry Hannah's 11th book -- ''High Lonesome,'' a short-story collection -- is being published this month by the Atlantic Monthly Press.

title: Kemp on Offense
description: Jack Kemp, casting off the mantle of restraint, assailed Bill Clinton's integrity as President, as did Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Line Play Can Make Or Break The Giants
description: This month, Giants offensive tackle Scott Gragg went to see a hero of his. He took a trip to the top of Madison Square Garden to listen to the conservative radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh do his show live. While Limbaugh ripped President Clinton, Gragg was able to sit in the studio and just listen. And smile. It's a toss-up as to what makes Gragg happier: pancaking Reggie White or getting to meet Limbaugh.

title: On the Roads: Trouble Spots to Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: In Another League the Ducks Get the Deep Freeze
description: That Thing You Do!

title: Bridgemarket Finally Gets Its Yes
description: It has been nearly two decades since developers started planning a fancy-food market within the yawning trusses of Queensboro Bridge. Neighborhood opposition, legal obstacles and financial difficulties conspired to keep the plan a plan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article last Sunday about ethnic conflict in Rwanda misstated the timing of recent events there. A rebel force led by the ethnic Tutsi minority invaded from Uganda in 1990, not 1991, and Governments led by members of the ethnic Hutu majority ruled until 1994, not 1991. The plane crash that killed President Juvenal Habyarimana, a Hutu, was in 1994, not 1991.

title: Florence From a Hilltop
description: THEY had it right, the Etruscans. They inhabited the aerie of Fiesole more than two milleniums ago, enjoying cool breezes and golden Tuscan sun high above the treacherously flooding Arno. They spurned the miasmal humors of what would become Florence, thinking it inconceivable that anyone would want to inhabit the valley below.

title: THE WARS OF ALEKSANDR IVANOVICH LEBED
description: ALEKSANDR LEBED, THE Russian peacemaker who has devoted his life to war, is rushing to Chechnya again, eager to conclude talks with his separatist adversaries and to end the searing conflict that his boss, President Boris N. Yeltsin, has summarily dumped in his lap.

title: Teaching Teachers to Talk About Gay Issues
description: Love. Sick. Happy. Perverse. Married. Weird.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about presidential pets misstated the Humane Society telephone numbers for a benefit poll on whether voters prefer a cat or a dog in the White House. The numbers are (900) 680-DOGS and (900) 680-CATS. Each call costs 75 cents, with profit of 25 cents for the society.

title: I Got Breast Cancer. Why Me?
description: NEVER in my wildest dreams did I think I'd be among the ranks of one in eight women on Long Island who get breast cancer. But diagnosed this past August at the age of 49, I find that I am, and like the 2,000 women a year who are diagnosed in this region, wonder how that could possibly be.

title: Hush of the Hives
description: The past few years I've begun to burn my beekeeping equipment. Frames and boxes, varnished with beeswax from years of use, keep the house warm. Other equipment I've stored in the barn. Chickens roost on the lip of the extractor, and last year a hen started setting in a settling tank. I'd love to start with bees again, but I've become discouraged by all the death.

title: Running Against Hillary
description: ''ELIZABETH DOLE SALUTES WORKING WOMEN,'' SAYS THE BANNER AT an insufferably humid picnic in Bowling Green, Ky., where the star attraction, in a long-sleeved silk blouse buttoned high up her neck, is massaging the crowd. ''You know something?'' Mrs. Dole says, seemingly delighted, drawing out the vowels in her creamy North Carolina drawl. ''I'm just so glad to be in Kentucky, where I don't need an interpreter!'' It's a line she uses all over the South, and as usual it gets a big, friendly laugh.

title: A Plea for Incivility
description: Bob Dole is basing his campaign on the idea of trust.

title: An Inevitable for Golf
description: The wonder was not so much that Tiger Woods won in just his fifth professional start on the P.G.A. Tour. It wasn't so much where he won (Las Vegas) or the score that he shot (27 under par) or even that the player he beat in a sudden death playoff, Davis Love 3d, is one of the best in the world. It was his manner: almost imperial, as though he, at the age of 20, were presiding over his own birth as the one who would both dominate and transcend the sport of golf. ''Now that he's gotten rid of that burden of the first win,'' said Jack Nicklaus, the standard against which all golfers are measured, ''there could be no stopping him.'' LARRY DORMAN

title: Helping Wineries Grow the Best Grapes
description: AS the Long Island wine harvest rolls into full gear, with the 17 or so wineries pulling their grapes for the 1996 vintage, Alice Wise, a small sturdy woman, is patrolling a two-acre vineyard in Riverhead, picking grapes by hand for her own special cellar, a basement winery the size of a large, walk-in closet.

title: Mary E. Noonan, Mark J. Robichaux
description: Mary Ellen Noonan, a daughter of Patricia and John T. Noonan of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Joseph Robichaux, a son of Shirley and Marcus Robichaux of Alexandria, La. The Rev. Robert Gerlich performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel of the Academy of the Sacred Heart in New Orleans.

title: Blundering Into War
description: ORIGINS OF A CATASTROPHEYugoslavia and Its Destroyers -- America's Last Ambassador Tells What Happened and Why.By Warren Zimmermann.Illustrated. 269 pp. New York:Times Books/Random House. $25.

title: Woman's Ex-Lover Shoots Her and Kills Himself
description: A former city bus driver who had been ordered to keep away from his former companion shot and wounded her outside a Bronx grocery store on Friday, then fatally shot himself in the head, the police said.

title: When There's Smoke ...
description: ON Oct. 27, people across the country will march through their houses and apartments setting their clocks back one hour for Standard Time. And, it is to be hoped, they will also check and change the batteries in their smoke detectors.

title: Robin M. Kass, Michael R. Banks
description: Dr. Robin May Kass, a resident in neurology at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, is to be married today to Michael Romero Banks, a lawyer in private practice in Bronxville, N.Y. Justice Joan B. Lefkowitz of State Supreme Court in White Plains is to officiate at Lyndhurst Castle, the Jay Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Kennedy Transfer
description: To the Editor: Images of travel increasingly are refracted through the discomfitted lens of the inconvenienced, the anxious, the sorely tried. On an attempt in late August to negotiate Kennedy International Airport for a change of carriers -- Air France to American -- here is what I saw and experienced:

title: 'No Trespassing' And 'City' Ways
description: I think it is interesting that the Connecticut Weekly has an article on municipal liability (''Liability Costs Curb Recreation,'' Sept. 22) and an article on the ''No Trespassing'' signs (''Where No Trespassing Signs Are as Numerous as Gnats,'' also Sept. 22).

title: The Irish Go on Roll, Regroup, Then Romp
description: With the first half expiring today, all Washington had to show for its trip to Notre Dame was one inconsequential first down. The Irish were up, 26-0, and the Huskies were about to collapse like a mobile home in a tornado.

title: DIARY
description: HEALTH CARE

title: Pros and Cons of the Three Theories on the Crash
description: In their efforts to test the three theories for the blast that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800, crash investigators have done everything from bringing in missile experts from a weapons testing range in China Lake, Calif., to shopping around for an aging 747 fuselage they might use for an experimental explosion in a fuel tank.

title: Filling Malls' Big Boxes: Armies of Silver Screens
description: MOVIE theater operators are on an expansion drive, and more theater complexes are showing up as the cornerstones of new and redeveloped shopping centers.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: ICEFIELDSBy Thomas Wharton.Washington Square/Pocket Books, paper, $12.

title: If Skip Away Passes Tests, It's on to Big Rematch
description: It is the return match for the heavyweight championship of the racing world, a mile and a quarter for a purse of $4 million. And Sonny Hine said yesterday that it would happen if his colt Skip Away passed two more tests, a workout and a blood test. If he does, he will challenge Cigar in the Breeders' Cup Classic.

title: Allison A. Hill And Keyes Edgar
description: Allison Anne Hill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hill of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Keyes Edgar, the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William Edgar 3d of Glenside, Pa. The bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville with that church's senior minister, the Rev. Dr. Pinckney C. Enniss.

title: The Humanities? Why, They're, Uh . . . the Reason for Humanities Month
description: Calvin Trillin, the writer and doggerel poet whose dinner speech on Saturday will kick off a week of activities honoring the New Jersey Council for the Humanities, hesitates when he is asked precisely what the humanities are.

title: Under New Law, Nursing Homes Might Reject Legal Immigrants
description: For the first time, nursing homes are checking the immigration status of applicants for admission, and they expect to exclude many elderly immigrants who will become ineligible for Medicaid because of the new welfare law.

title: HOW TO MAKE A PH.D. MATTER
description: Attribute no woe to my Ph.D. (anticipated arrival, 1997). Four years ago, I began my doctorate at the London School of Economics. Surely, this is not the only institution, England not the only country, where intellectual diversity is celebrated. From my colleagues in the departments of law and sociology, I have learned about nationalism in South Africa, the horrors of war crimes in Vietnam, European approaches to the pharmaceutical industry, even cultural aspects of lace making in Mexico.

title: INSIDE
description: Crime Numbers Fall

title: Fitzgerald's Curtain
description: To the Editor:

title: Adina Chouequet, George Young 3d
description: Adina Chouequet, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Chouequet of Margate, N.J., was married yesterday to George Haywood Young 3d, the son of Gen. George H. Young Jr., U.S. Army, retired, and Mrs. Young of Leavenworth, Kan. Judge Patrick J. Reardon of the First District Court of Kansas, officiated at the Memorial Chapel at Fort Leavenworth.

title: Twilight of Champions
description: THE SWEETHEART SEASONBy Karen Joy Fowler.352 pp. New York:A Marian Wood Book/Henry Holt & Company. $23.

title: Jay Zaslow and Samantha Rai
description: Samantha A. Rai, the daughter of Susan and Dr. Kanti Rai of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Jay Zaslow, the son of Lee Zaslow of Philadelphia and Dr. Berton Zaslow of Jenkintown, Pa. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Couple Buy New Home With Old Roots
description: THEY were decamping from the Upper West Side apartment he had grown up in and later had inherited and lived in with his wife. He was browsing through the cardboard boxes kept by his parents, boxes full of brittle documents, yellowing newspaper clippings and old yearbooks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about the responsibilities of estate administrators misstated the maximum value of small estates that may qualify for exemption from certain probate requirements in New York State. It is $20,000, not $10,000; the higher limit took effect in August.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: TOURIST OFFICE

title: Squatters' New Foe: Credit Union
description: These are desperate days for East Village squatters. Now that the Giuliani administration has routed the last holdouts from a series of city-owned tenements on East 13th Street, it is only a matter of time, squatters fear, before the city moves against the dozen or so squats that sprinkle the side streets east of Avenue A.

title: Lullabies and Good Nights
description: Celebrations for a magazine, an industrialist, a hair stylist, a photographer and a music hall (with thanks to Brahms).

title: New Shine for Diamond District
description: The diamond district is important: at least three-quarters of all diamonds that enter the United States, some $4 billion worth last year, pass through the district.

title: Farewell, Welfare State
description: WHEN the deadline approached for states to file their plans for complying with the new Federal welfare legislation, Tennessee was ready. Submitting a 60-page plan that reflected its reputation for innovation in improving and cutting costs in programs for the poor, the state was one of only 25 that met the Oct. 1 deadline. Most others, including New York, are going to be late.

title: How Those Dealer Add-Ons Can Add Up!
description: AFTER a tough round of bargaining, you've finally nailed down the price of that new car you want to buy.

title: Classical Briefs
description: 'IN GABRIEL'S GARDEN'

title: Produce Industry in SoHo Is Getting Like Hunts Point
description: To the Editor:

title: In Japanese Novels, It's Business as Usual
description: People who choose their art and entertainment out of a desire to have experiences of excellence and profundity make me feel humble: their tolerance for disappointment must be enormous. I'm motivated by a drive more easily satisfied: I watch or listen to or read new works simply in order to keep up with what's going on. As pop culture goes global, my Inner Anthropologist is having a field day. I love the wiggly dance music known as Afro-pop, partly because of the surprising way it sets steel guitars -- which Americans associate with the relaxed pleasures of country-and-western and Hawaiian music -- alongside talking drums and tribal rhythms. I'm not a big John Woo fan, but I am tickled by the way Hong Kong action films mix the American movie with French existentialism and then bounce it all back at us from the East, like signals from a telecommunications satellite we forgot we launched.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the construction of a park on a cement lot in Mott Haven, the Bronx, misstated its origins. The campaign to build the park was organized by the Parks Council, St. Benedict the Moor Community Center, St. Ann's Church and P.S. 30. The park pays homage to the late Rev. Roger Giglio, a local priest; it was not he who organized the campaign.

title: As You Think Research Synergy, Think Nylon
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Blames U.S. Position For Setback Over NATO
description: Prospects that France will rejoin NATO's military command structure have been seriously set back, French officials say, by Washington's refusal to consider putting a European officer in charge of the alliance's southern command, which includes the United States Sixth Fleet.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Minding Your Business column on Sept. 29, about withdrawals from individual retirement accounts, misstated the rules for using the recalculation method of figuring I.R.A. payouts. After an account holder's death, the balance of the account may have to be paid to the beneficiary by the end of the next calendar year, but only under certain conditions: The account holder's age must have been the sole factor in figuring the payout schedule, and the beneficiary must not be the spouse of the account holder.

title: The Perfectionist
description: PERFECTION MAY BE THE DREAM OF THOUsands of restaurateurs, but it is difficult to think of anyone who comes closer than Jean-Claude Vrinat. The owner of Taillevent restaurant in Paris will accept no less than perfect food and flawless service in an unimpeachable setting. Interestingly, it's what gives Taillevent its humanity, a certain je ne sais quoi so at odds with its impeccable, old fashioned cuisine.

title: Dana McCorvie, Philip Maniatty
description: Dana Lawrence McCorvie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Neal McCorvie of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Philip John Maniatty, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Connie S. Maniatty of Palm Beach, Fla. Barbara S. Schadt, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

title: Amy Fusselman, Frank L. Snider
description: Amy Fusselman and Frank Lyons Snider were married yesterday at the National Arts Club in Manhattan by Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: Russian Favorite: Leader or Peril
description: Gen. Aleksandr I. Lebed, blunt, powerful and popular, is battling with Kremlin rivals and his own contradictions. With Boris N. Yeltsin in failing health, he is the man most Russians want as their next leader.

title: Higher Authority
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: From 'Central' To 'General'
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: DIFFICULTIES OF A BRIDEGROOM

title: Out of Tons of Feathers, A New Idea for Diapers
description: One at a time, feathers are certainly light, but they quickly add up to a weighty commodity at a poultry rendering plant, which can process half a million pounds a week. That makes the chicken feathers a prime candidate for new roles, and a scientist at the United States Department of Agriculture says he has one: cushioning baby bottoms.

title: Opera: Love It And Lampoon It
description: THE BEST JOKES -- examples of what C. S. Lewis calls ''the Joke Proper,'' built around ''the sudden perception of incongruity'' -- are made by those who know, understand and, in some sense, love their subject matter. The best jokes about opera are made by those who get beyond the obvious humor potential of improbably large middle-aged singers cast as young lovers in improbably convoluted stories to the more subtle incongruities beyond.

title: Fleetwood Seeks to Entice Patrons
description: IN case anyone thought the forecast for live professional theater in Westchester would be pathetically scant, don't take heart: it is worse.

title: Disorder in the Court
description: THE LAWS OF OUR FATHERS

title: Decision Expected In Blacks' Suit Against Hempstead
description: DOROTHY GOOSBY of Hempstead ran as a Democrat for Hempstead Town Clerk in 1985 and lost to her Republican opponent.

title: A Perfect Ending for Columbia in Overtime Victory
description: Columbia just keeps turning back the clock.

title: Douglas P. Torre, 77, a Pioneer In Cryogenic Surgery Techniques
description: Dr. Douglas Paul Torre, a New York dermatologist and pioneering cryosurgeon long affiliated with Cornell University Medical College, died on Sept. 21 at New York Hospital. He was 77 and lived in Rowayton, Conn.

title: In Preparing Roses for Winter, Less Can Be More
description: Rose enthusiasts have many devices for putting their roses to bed and protecting them from winter's extreme weather. Some build boxes to enclose entire rose beds; some fit cones over each individual rose plant; others extol the advantages of wrapping all their shrubs and climbers in sheets of foam plastic.

title: Sanitation's DSNY Logo Isn't Recycled From You Know Whose
description: Next time you see your local sanitation engineer heaving trash into a truck, think of him as a triumph of substance, recyclable and otherwise, over style.

title: Cynthia Roselle, Trevor Koenig
description: Cynthia Dowling Roselle, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David P. Roselle of Newark, Del., was married yesterday to Trevor Marcus Koenig, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Lee Koenig of Laguna Niguel, Calif. The Rev. John W. Martiner, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: The Saints of Servitude
description: There's a lot in the press these days about ''the lessons of hard work.''

title: For Hispanic Poor, No Silver Lining
description: AS Federal agencies issued a torrent of cheery reports in the last few weeks about rising incomes, falling poverty rates and improvements in educational performance, one group bucked the trends: Hispanic people.

title: Pay Bills Early? Now It Can Pay
description: GE Capital made waves recently when it announced that people who pay off their bills completely each month would have to start paying an annual fee for the GE Rewards Mastercard.

title: BENEFITS
description: 'Woodlands Ball'

title: 'Take a Left,' Said the Car
description: YOU risk being identified as maximally weird if you pull a big white Ford Crown Victoria in to the breakdown lane under an overpass in Quincy, Mass., and sit there for 20 minutes talking insistently to an otherwise empty car.

title: Movies Are Like Babies
description: HELLO, HE LIEDAnd Other Truths From the Hollywood Trenches.By Lynda Obst.Illustrated. 246 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company. $23.95.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: RED, WHITE, AND OH SO BLUE

title: Tarot Lesson: Tomorrow Is Another Day
description: CAREER advice can come from several sources. To get a second opinion on my best move, I consulted Marie Miller, a spiritual reader in Greenwich Village. Like all of her clients who come in for a tarot card reading, I paid a $50 fee and anted up a $10 tip -- money earmarked for her grandchildren, she said.

title: A Chic, Affordable Milanese Restaurant
description: THE two-month-old Bice Med Grill on the southwest corner of the Smithaven Mall offers the quality of Bice and the value of Sbarro, which is much better than the other way around. Bice is a chic, prestigious, high-priced Milanese restaurant with branches in places like Manhattan, Milan, Paris and Palm Beach. Sbarro is an inexpensive, Long Island-based fast-food chain with hundreds of outlets that calls itself ''the Italian eatery.''

title: Auto Racing Icon Tries Political Track
description: Pat Bell, the big-haired proprietor of the Sassy Shears beauty salon in this Blue Ridge mountain town, has never voted for a Republican, not for any office.

title: Snapshot Without a Negative
description: SHOULD George M. C. Fisher share the blame?

title: Islanders Turn Back The Clock And Flyers
description: The prospective new owner was in the house. The seats were filled. The old logo was back on the home sweaters, as well as on the ice. As were some of the Islanders' greatest stars of the past, including the legendary Mike Bossy, who rarely visits these parts.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: AMERICA NEEDS A RAISE

title: MADELEINE ALBRIGHT'S AUDITION
description: When I met Madeleine Albright after a hiatus of several years (I am a former student of hers), she alluded to her modest weight gain by laughingly referring to herself as ''Waddlin' Albright'' (''Madeleine Albright's Audition,'' by Elaine Sciolino, Sept. 22). But don't let her intellectual self-deprecation fool you: her mind is as sharp as a razor.

title: Eagles Showcase a New Breed of Cornerback
description: Unless you have played cornerback in the National Football League, there are things that go with the position that you will never understand. That's why Troy Vincent was intrigued by the possibility of playing for Philadelphia Coach Ray Rhodes, once a defensive back for the New York Giants, and Emmitt Thomas, the Eagles' defensive coordinator and a former cornerback standout with the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Eternal Rest? Not in Argentina.
description: ETCHED in Latin above the white marble columns of the majestic Recoleta Cemetery, burial place of Eva Peron and other rich and powerful Argentines, is the familiar wish that they will rest in peace.

title: Are Well-Paid Trustees Putting Shareholders First?
description: Every mutual fund has a set of independent trustees who are charged by law to defend the interests of fund shareholders. Part of that job is to keep expenses down as much as reasonably possible.

title: Donna L. Sollitto, Vincent C. Ragusa
description: Donna Lynn Sollitto, a daughter of Gladys and James Sollitto of Valley Stream, L.I., was married there yesterday to Vincent Carl Ragusa, a son of Domenica and Vincent J. Ragusa of Brooklyn. The Rev. Robert Howard performed the ceremony at Grace United Methodist Church.

title: World Cuisines Meet at Former Gristmill
description: ZEPHS' has spent the last year isolated by the din and confusion of a flood-control project. As the dust settles and diners make their way to this historic brick restaurant (originally a gristmill), longtime clients might be dismayed by the loss of the tumbling brook, now diverted underground. Gone, too, are almost all of the ruined, overgrown brick walls and empty windows of abandoned workshops, the restaurant's picturesque back view. One stone wall remains, probably temporarily.

title: In a Debate, It's Themes, Not Facts
description: TO the untrained ear, the debate last Sunday night between President Clinton and Bob Dole and the one Wednesday night between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp must have sounded like people reciting gibberish.

title: A Case for Abortion Rights. No Apologies.
description: IT IS A DAMP MARCH MORNING ON a Los Angeles street and Cher yes, Cher of ''Moonstruck'' and Sonny and Cher -- is battling a string of disasters as she makes her directorial debut, filming a segment of ''If These Walls Could Talk,'' a three-part HBO film about abortion.
