Intermittent rain is drenching the actors. A camerawoman has slipped in the mud and fallen. Flight patterns from nearby Los Angeles International Airport have unexpectedly shifted, and the roar of jets is overwhelming every shot.

title: The Usual Future
description: EVOLUTION ISN'T WHAT IT USED TO BEThe Augmented Animal and the Whole Wired World.By Walter Truett Anderson.223 pp. New York:W. H. Freeman & Company. $22.95.

title: Bar Harbor Inn
description: To the Editor: Concerning Wayne Curtis's What's Doing on Mount Desert (Aug. 4): there is a quiet retreat in town in Bar Harbor. In a quiet red Victorian house three blocks from Main Street is the lovely Maples Inn. With only six rooms, the innkeeper, Susan Sinclair, pampers her guests. Wonderful breakfasts, cookies at 4 o'clock, plus lunch boxes and itineraries await her guests.

title: All in His Head
description: I WANT TO THANK MY BRAIN FOR REMEMBERING MEA Memoir.By Jimmy Breslin.219 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: THE TRICKLE-DOWN THEORY
description: Kakutani wisely sees through the miasma of mainstream mediocrity. Sorry to say, higher education has played a part in this. Let's blame mass education because more people today know fewer things on more topics. Everything is accessible, with little depth, time or appreciation of effort. It's the Cliffs Notes approach to life. Why study a complete work when you can skim it in a magazine or, better yet, wait for it to come out on video?

title: THE TRICKLE-DOWN THEORY
description: High culture has not been cheapened by popular culture. Rather, popular culture has become sophisticated by borrowing from high culture. Why is this bad? Do allusions to Fellini, even in an insurance commercial, necessarily cheapen Fellini?

title: John Richards 3d and Alison Oetting
description: Alison Marie Oetting, a daughter of Helen and Rudolph H. Oetting of River Edge, N.J., is to be married today to John Howard Richards 3d, a son of Joan H. Suscheck of Vail, Colo., and Mr. Richards Sr. of Rocky River, Ohio. The Rev. Robert J. Welsh is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: A Scandal Ripples Across the Atlantic
description: A SPREADING mutual fund scandal in Britain has quietly washed up on American shores, raising questions about who, if anyone, was guarding the portfolios of two equity funds that Dean Witter sold to United States investors.

title: Baseball, Straying From Values, Loses Comfort of Home
description: Somewhere between The Spit and The Scoop, major league baseball seems to have finally let go of whatever moral grip it still had on itself. Roberto Alomar's greatest crime was his punishment, not his crime. The so-called Angel in the Outfield should have been in school or at least not allowed to lie his way out. Doesn't the kid have parents? Doesn't the game have grown-ups?

title: Plain Geometry
description: Outstanding in their field: clothes that have simple shapes, clean lines and fresh angles.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Dave Barry in Cyberspace

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Green discusses the long ignored issue that AIDS, like drug addiction, is often a result of compulsive behavior. The notion that AIDS has a psychological dimension has been locked out of public discourse on the disease. It is a welcome sign that this is beginning to change.

title: Caroline Estey, Adrian R. King Jr.
description: Caroline Eshleman Estey, the daughter of John S. Estey of Eagles Mere, Pa., and the late Margaret G. Estey, was married in Philadelphia yesterday to Adrian Renz King Jr., the son of Carolyn D. and Mr. King Sr. of Drexel Hill, Pa. The Rev. Charles L. Glenn Jr., the bride's uncle, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Race Street Meeting House, at the headquarters of the Philadelphia area's Quaker community.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions with the Gazetteer chart on Sept. 29, about Brookville, L.I., referred incorrectly to three houses on the market. The one at 2 Norgate Road has three bedrooms and two baths (not two and one), and no maid's room. The house at 2112 Cedar Swamp Road has six bedrooms and five baths (not two and two). The asking price for the house on Beverly Road is $1.2 million, not $1.385 million.

title: Making History off the Court
description: ON A BRILLIANT AUTUMN AFTERNOON, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar stands in the hallway of his Japanese-style Beverly Hills home. A man who scored more points than anyone in basketball history and helped win three college championships and six in the N.B.A., more than Michael Jordan, Abdul-Jabbar is showing off his artifacts about black Americans. ''If I had led anything like a normal life,'' he says, ''I would have been a historian.'' Now the 49-year-old Abdul-Jabbar, who retired seven years ago, has finally got around to history, writing ''Black Profiles in Courage'' (William Morrow), about overlooked American heroes. ''My son was doing a black-studies project for school, and there was no really good sourcebook,'' he says. ''So I wrote one. I'm trying to say to black youth, 'Hey, this is your story, too.' '' But Abdul-Jabbar's feel for black history, as it turns out, is more intense than any textbook's.

title: Around the Country, Roads Worth Slowing Down For
description: A road can be a destination in itself, according to the Federal Government, which last month cited that criterion in naming six of the country's thoroughfares All-American Roads. They include the Pacific Coast Highway in California, with its views of Big Sur's dramatic seascapes, and the route from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., taken by the 1965 march for voting rights led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: A 'Rural Oasis' Pursues Its Destiny, One No at a Time
description: A ''rural oasis'' that is how this township is described in a proposed zoning ordinance that pledges to protect what makes this community special ''in a region otherwise characterized by suburban residential tract development, highway commercial uses, corporate offices and interstate highways.''

title: Sonia Toledo and Gavin Zeigler
description: Sonia Margarita Toledo and George Gavin Zeigler were married on Friday evening at Tavern on the Green in New York. The Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Some Humbling Times For a High-Tech Giant
description: FEW giant companies grow as fast as Motorola Inc. did in the early 1990's. In just the three years ending last December, sales of Motorola's semiconductors, cellular phones, pagers and other electronic equipment more than doubled, to $27 billion, and profits nearly quadrupled, to $1.78 billion.

title: At Woofstock '96, Frisbees and a Star
description: THE ALPO FRISBEE TEAM and Hank, the roller-skating Great Dane, will be among the attractions next Sunday at Woofstock '96, a dog walk through Central Park to raise money for abandoned pets.

title: America Seen Through the Printmaker's Eye
description: COUNTRY VIEWS, CITY VISIONS,'' at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University, is a modest-seeming show, a long row of 40 prints, mostly black-and-white. As an ensemble, however, the prints tell a sprawling story about America from the beginning of the 20th century through the 1930's. It's a constantly shifting saga, with images of grandeur and optimism contrasting with scenes that are stark and often grim.

title: Susan L. Arena, Jonathan Blaugrund
description: Susan Lee Arena, the daughter of Constance and Dr. Joseph F. Arena of Marblehead, Mass., is to be married today at her parents' house to Jonathan Lee Blaugrund, a son of Drs. Annette and Stanley Blaugrund of New York. Robert R. Wagner, a justice of the peace who is a cousin of the bride, is to officiate.

title: The Writer in Prison
description: Prison is essentially a shortage of space made up for by a surplus of time; to an inmate, both are palpable. Naturally enough, this ratio -- echoing man's situation in the universe -- is what has made incarceration an integral metaphor of Christian metaphysics as well as practically the midwife of literature. As regards literature, this stands, in a certain sense, to reason, since literature is in the first place a translation of metaphysical truths into any given vernacular.

title: The Front Page
description: MANHATTAN NOCTURNE

title: Belgian Artists' Show Heralds Anniversaries
description: More than 150 works by five of Belgium's best-known modern artists are on display at the Museum for Modern Art in Ostend through Feb. 2 in an exhibition called ''From Ensor to Delvaux.'' The exhibition is a precursor to retrospectives at the Museum of Fine Arts in Brussels over the next three years marking the 100th anniversary of the birth of Paul Delvaux (1897-1991); the 100th anniversary of the birth of Rene Magritte (1898-1967) and the 50th anniversary of the death of James Ensor (1860-1949). The two other artists whose works are now on display in Ostend are Leon Spilliaert and Constant Permeke. Ensor and Spilliaert were born in Ostend; Permeke painted there, and Magritte and Delvaux painted in Brussels.

title: But What Does It Have to Do With Jeans?
Predictable Fare Handled With Finesse
description: BRAVO! Nader. No, it is not something shouted at the curtain call of an opera, but the name of a restaurant. Still, the immodest moniker is not inappropriate. On recent visits to this Huntington newcomer, there were accolades aplenty.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 13, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 1 DESPERATION, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) Visitors to a small mining town in Nevada encounter terrifying forces. 2 1 THE REGULATORS, by Richard Bachman. (Dutton, $24.95.) title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A GOOD LIFE: Newspapering and Other Adventures

title: Sarah S. Cotsen, John M. Goldsmith
description: Sarah Sophia Cotsen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Cotsen of Buffalo, was married yesterday to John Meyer Goldsmith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold D. Goldsmith of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua E. Plaut, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Goldsmiths' house in Chilmark, Mass.

title: A Lecture for Turkey
description: Turkey's Prime Minister, Necmettin Erbakan, came to office in June with grand plans to forge an alliance of Muslim nations. His efforts have foundered as he has confronted the bitter conflicts that divide Muslim leaders. Last week he got an especially rude shock from Libya's Muammar Qadaffi.

title: Touches From Asia Accent Dinner Menu
description: THIS well-seasoned dinner menu for four takes its inspiration from Asia. Grilled baby chickens are rubbed with spices and sharpened with lime; the eggplant has definite hints of Sichuan Province, and rice, prepared Chinese style, is given a touch of sweet Polynesian pineapple to play off against the array of vibrant flavors.

title: Goodbye, Connecticut
description: Leaving a Doll's House

title: Smooth Operators
description: OPERATION MAD BALL (1957) is a wayout American-servicemen frolic that reflects an era of Hollywood farces made for the sole purpose of spreading good cheer. Herewith one of the better ones. There's a solid troop of fun makers stationed at a hospital base in Normandy. Their linchpin is Jack Lemmon (above) as the most inventive, most decorated private. Ernie Kovacs, in top form, is a suspicious and designing captain, and Mickey Rooney is an inspired hep cat. Together they make a silly ''operation.'' The director Richard Quine doubles neatly as a hillbilly sergeant in this contagiously light hearted and enjoyable film. Nutty but nice - SATURDAY at 10 A.M. on CINEMAX.

title: This Queen of Style Is Commandingly Funny
description: IF YOU STILL HAVE DOUBTS ABOUT the theatrical potential of single-character plays, make your way to the Westside Theater, where Mary Louise Wilson, in a gloriously wired performance as Diana Vreeland, is holding forth in ''Full Gallop.'' With a cast pared down to the irreducible minimum of one, ''Full Gallop'' is a discovery on the exotic order of coddled eggs served with beluga caviar. It's a taste you never knew you had acquired, and it's as delicious as it is rich. After last year's limited engagement at the Manhattan Theater Club, the production has returned for an open-ended Off Broadway run that should go on as long as Ms. Wilson cares to entertain us.

title: Thinking Ahead
description: JULIUS MANGER'S mausoleum, with its 30-foot dome and statues of angels, is an old-fashioned symbol of wealth and pride. Built in 1937, but in the style of an earlier century, it vies for social prominence in the Woodlawn Cemetery with nearby tombs of 19th-century tycoons like the department-store owner F. W. Woolworth and the society restaurateur Louis Sherry.

title: Correction
description: The Atlantic City column last Sunday, about Italian bakeries in the city's Ducktown section, reversed the names of two former owners of the Formica Bakery. Mario Formica, father of the current owner, is still alive; his brother Dominick Formica died after agreeing to sell the bakery to the current owner, Frank Formica.

title: In Search of Nazi Gold
description: What do two former SS agents, a Chilean revolutionary named for a famous bullfighter and a Swiss insurance investigator have in common? They're all in search of the 63 gold coins in the Wandering Crescent Collection, which disappeared from Nazi Germany in 1943. As the action in THE NAME OF A BULLFIGHTER (Harcourt Brace, $21) unfolds, these disparate characters converge on forlorn Tierra del Fuego and their lives become inextricably entwined. The Chilean-born novelist Luis Sepulveda, who has lived in Germany since 1980, has been wildly popular in Spanish-speaking countries and in Europe since the publication in 1992 of his novel ''The Old Man Who Read Love Stories.'' In this new novel, he melds Manuel Puig's romanticism with the ingenuity of Jorge Luis Borges -- and applies them to a picaresque search for lost gold whose wry denouement leaves a smile on the reader's face, in spite of the tragedies that precede it. It's Mr. Sepulveda's sure sense of narration (aided by Suzanne Ruta's fluid translation) that makes this novel so successful. ''The Name of a Bullfighter'' is a rare find: a thrilling, well-wrought work of literature that pulses with the excitement of the best detective fiction. Christopher Atamian

title: THE FIGHT FOR THE SENATE: 14 STATES TO WATCH
description: Republicans now hold a 53-to-47 seat advantage in the Senate. That means the Democrats must pick up a net of three seats if they are to win control, assuming President Clinton is re-elected and Vice President Gore gets the tie-breaking vote. The outcome probably hinges on the outcome in these 14 races, each of which at this stage could go either way. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

title: In Another League the Ducks Get the Deep Freeze
description: L5: First City in Space

title: Crime
description: Ruth Rendell understands the difference between sight and vision, and in her trenchant new suspense novel, THE KEYS TO THE STREET (Crown, $24), she trains her penetrating gaze on the homeless denizens who haunt Regent's Park in London. Residents of the exclusive neighborhoods abutting the park make a point of not even noticing wretches like Effie and Dill and Pharaoh and Roman. Only Mary Jago, a frail, sensitive young woman who has recently moved into the neighborhood as a housesitter, pays any attention to these street people -- until someone starts killing them and impaling their bodies on the spiked railings that surround the park.

title: It's Still a Dog's Life, But a Better One
description: Ordinances to force, or at least encourage, the spaying or neutering of pets are becoming more popular, and Camden now has one of the toughest on the books.

title: Cincinnati
description: Tom Wise, an actor in the 1920's Broadway comedy ''The Old Soak,'' once said there were only three streets in America: Broadway in New York, Market Street in San Francisco and Vine Street in Cincinnati. The ''Queen of the West,'' as Cincinnati came to be called, was throughout the 19th century a proud bastion of river commerce and culture, a lively, high-living town full of German immigrants.

title: Army Stays On Ground In a Rout Of Rutgers
description: What this Army team likes to do best, said both center Kyle Scott and tight end Ron Leshinski, is pound on the opponent. Pound and pound. That is exactly what the Black Knights of the Hudson did to Rutgers today before a slim crowd of 19,101 at Giants Stadium.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: The Perfect Yankee

title: Thomas Van Metre, 73, Doctor Who Remedied Allergies to Cats
description: Thomas E. Van Metre Jr., whose medical research made life easier for people with allergies, especially allergies to cats, died on Tuesday at his home in Ruxton, Md., near Baltimore. He was 73.

title: What Is the Real Crisis?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sam and Elizabeth, Guns and Art in Hartford
description: THE new exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is in part a portrait of Victorian New England in the industrial age, in part a profile of a vibrant, influential couple, Sam and Elizabeth Colt. ''Sam and Elizabeth: Legend and Legacy of Colts Empire'' tells its multi-faceted story through paintings, sculpture, furnishings, decorative arts, period photographs and manuscripts.

title: Aimee Atorino, Benton C. Bocklet
description: Aimee Jean Atorino, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Atorino of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Benton Charles Bocklet, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Barrington Bocklet of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Dennis Gallagher performed the ceremony at St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Dog Run Open to the Public Would Share Woes of Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: AN OLYMPIAN INJUSTICE
description: Max Frankel makes a strong and valid case against the media feeding frenzy over Richard Jewell (Word & Image: ''An Olympian Injustice,'' Sept. 22). However, there is another aspect of this affair that worries me. When will a security guard again notify law enforcement about a suspicious package at a public event? The press behaved like a boorish mob, true. But it was egged on by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which leaked information in its eagerness for an immediate solution to the case.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 about the glut of doctoral degrees misidentified the first year of a survey about the job-market experience of chemists who had earned Ph.D.'s. It was 1988, not 1888. The survey went up to 1994.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about the growth of the nanny business misstated the application of minimum-wage laws to nannies' pay. Under the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act, live-in nannies are entitled to the minimum wage for their time spent working; they are not covered by the law's overtime provisions, although some states do require overtime pay. Most nannies who do not live in their employers' households are covered by the Federal minimum wage and by the overtime provisions.

title: Follow The Money
description: A few days ago there was an intriguing article in Iraq's most influential newspaper, Babel, criticizing the Iraqi Government for lifting all the restrictions and roadblocks on trade between northern Iraq and the rest of the country. Why? Well, northern Iraq, when it was under U.S-allied control, had de facto open borders with the world and you could buy anything there. The rest of Iraq, though, was under U.N. economic embargo. So when Saddam Hussein's Kurds drove the pro-U.S. Kurds out of northern Iraq, and reintegrated it with the rest of the country, Iraqi traders went on a shopping spree. Suddenly, they could get all sorts of previously banned goods through northern Iraq. And how did they buy them? By selling their Iraqi dinars for dollars on the black market. And what happened to the Iraqi dinar? It dropped 30 percent, going from 1,150 to the dollar to 1,550.

title: Jeffrey A. Siegel and Sheera Karch
description: Dr. Sheera Beth Karch and Dr. Jeffrey Alan Siegel, both medical residents, were married last evening. Rabbi David Oler performed the ceremony at the Beth David Congregation in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Money and 'Teeth'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO MAKE A PH.D. MATTER
description: Menand offers a contradictory solution to the Ph.D. glut -- eliminate the dissertation. Sadly, it is the dissertation that effectively bars a third to half of all graduate students from getting their Ph.D.'s: they simply never finish one. Thus, eliminating the dissertation would double the number of Ph.D.'s on the job market, dramatically increasing competition while lowering achievement.

title: Help Has Arrived
description: So your company is in a bit of difficulty, and outside consultants are swarming over your offices, trying to fix what's broke. Maybe they'll find a way to cut costs and increase sales. Or maybe their suggestions will be incredibly awful. No matter what they recommend, their arrival is ominous and the mood around the office is heading south. What happened when the consultants came to your office? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 4 about changes in the commercial makeup of Austin Street in Queens referred imprecisely to past restrictions on who could live in Forest Hills Gardens, a planned community. (The error also occurred in an article in the City section on Sept. 3, 1995, about memories of Queens.) According to the Queens Historical Society, a widely known unwritten agreement restricted Forest Hills Gardens largely to white Christians until after World War II. A letter from a reader dated Oct. 3 points out that no written contract to that effect ever existed.

title: Sparkling Wine And Champagne
description: I have had many opportunities to meet Long Island winemakers and to enjoy their wines. In particular I have been attentive to their interest in sparkling wines and how they label them.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: ARE WE NOT MEN?Stories.By Brent Spencer.Arcade, $21.95.

title: Industrial Pollution Helps To Crowd Out a Way of Life
description: On the southern shore near Hook Creek, a crane noisily scooped up rocks with its claw, rumbling back and forth at an asphalt plant spewing thick smoke. To the east, scores of gleaming white spherical fuel tanks waited for trucks to deliver their contents to Texaco and Amoco stations.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Select Reserve

title: Pamela Reis And Kevin Hyman
description: Pamela Robin Reis, a daughter of Muriel Henle Reis and Arthur Reis Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Kevin Dale Hyman, a son of Sara and Larry Hyman of Calabasas, Calif. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at Studio 450, a party space in New York.

title: From Bubbles to Baubles
description: WHEN you're the guy who dreamed up the slogan ''Please don't squeeze the Charmin,'' there's not much you can do for an encore.

title: What to Do When the House Is Too Big and the Budget Not Big Enough
description: Patricia T. Gritman has spent most of her life in Ridgewood, a picturesque Bergen County village of broad streets, venerable old trees and Victorian houses. She learned to swim in the sandy-bottomed municipal pool and later sent her two children to the high school she attended.

title: In Another League the Ducks Get the Deep Freeze
description: D3: The Mighty Ducks

title: Close-Ups
description: At the forefront of the talented and committed photographers who burst upon the international scene in the 1930's was Robert Capa (1913-54), born Endre Friedman in Budapest. His photographs of the Spanish Civil War, which are considered groundbreaking for the immediacy with which they depicted soldiers and civilians caught in the chaos of war, gained him immediate, widespread recognition. Along with those he took during World War II (which include grainy images of American soldiers landing in Normandy), they are some of this century's more frequently reproduced and discussed shots. That his work is so familiar is due in large measure to the persistence of his younger brother, the photographer Cornell Capa, the founding director of the International Center for Photography. ROBERT CAPA: Photographs (Aperture, $50) includes a remembrance by Cornell Capa, a foreword by Henri Cartier-Bresson (who helped Robert Capa found the photo agency Magnum) and text by Robert Whelan, the author of a biography of Capa. The book seeks to broaden Capa's reputation beyond that of war photographer, but the majority of the images come from places -- like China, France, Israel, Italy and Indochina -- where war of one kind or another was being fought. Although Capa certainly did not celebrate war, he seems to have needed its intensity and danger to produce his best work, always following his own maxim, ''If your pictures aren't good enough, you're not close enough.'' The viewer senses something momentous taking place just out of the frame: the ground shakes from battle, an anxious crowd scans the sky, a dark-eyed girl looks up from her family's tattered bags -- symbols of refugee flight. Humor and warmth animate these pictures, as well as tragedy and loss, but the few images of ordinary life lack Capa's distinctive empathy. Rosemary Ranck

title: Edward Evantash, Karen Davidson
description: Dr. Karen Margaret Davidson and Dr. Edward Gordon Evantash, both obstetricians in Boston and instructors at Harvard Medical School, are to be married today at the Ocean Edge Resort in Brewster, Mass. Rabbi Donald Pollack is to perform the ceremony.

title: Congressional Races Are the Costliest Ever
description: With control of Congress up for grabs, the battle for the House and Senate has turned into a battle for money. And the same ''soft dollar'' loopholes that allowed money to pour into the Presidential race are now fueling Congressional races, making Federal campaign spending limits meaningless.

title: New Rental Pulls the Young to East Houston Street
description: ONE tenant is a 24-year-old promotion manager for a magazine, sharing an apartment with her college roommate. Another apartment has been taken by a just-married pair of 20-somethings working in financial services, she in New Jersey and he in TriBeCa. A third is the 34-year-old president of a small technology services company.

title: Mr. Chirac's First Great Work
description: France's ruling monarchs -- whether royal or republican -- have long understood that grandiose buildings are a good way of recording their passage through power. So it was no surprise last week when, after 17 months in office, President Jacques Chirac announced his first ''great work,'' a new $200 million Museum of Civilizations and Early Art to house collections from the Museum of African and Oceanic Arts and the Museum of Man.

title: A Tribe Continues Pursuing Bridgeport
description: THOUGH the Golden Hill Paugussett petition for Federal recognition as an Indian tribe was denied by the Bureau of Indian Affairs in September, Bridgeport property owners still live in the shadow of the state-recognized tribe's claim that they are the rightful owners of downtown Bridgeport. And tribal leaders say state residents have not heard the last of the tribe's plans to build a casino in Bridgeport.

title: Stressless Chic: Night Life Goes To the Lounges
description: When most people think of downtown night life, ''cozy'' is not a word that comes to mind. But if the continuing surge in lounge-going is any clue, late-night denizens are past cozy and heading toward mellow.

title: Chinese Spoken Here
description: If the relative popularity of foreign languages among college students appeared on a stock market, Chinese and Arabic would be hot performers, with Spanish showing growth potential and German, French and Russian in free fall.

title: A Fordham Starting Player Collapses Before Game and Dies
description: Homecoming weekend at Fordham abruptly ended yesterday after a starting defensive back died apparently of a heart attack during warm-ups at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: FLIRTING WITH SUICIDE
description: Jesse Green's article ''Flirting With Suicide'' (Sept. 15) had more relevance to my own efforts at staying H.I.V.-negative than anything I've read in the last 15 years.

title: High on Idaho
description: To the Editor: Susan Spano's tale of falling in love with the Sawtooth Mountains (Frugal Traveler, Sept. 8) recalled my feelings as I returned on Sept. 5 from a tour of Idaho. It is the best-kept secret in the Northwest: glorious lakes, magical mountains, endless blue skies and, best of all, not a tour bus anywhere, except ours.

title: NEW YORK & CO.
description: A Concerned Mother Opens Her Own Study Center

title: Gant Batters Former Team As Cardinals Seize the Edge
description: Ron Gant admitted today it took him a long time to get over the hurt he felt when the Braves unceremoniously released him in the spring of 1994 after he broke his leg in a motorcycle accident. He had come up through the organization and played five full seasons in Atlanta, a city where he still lives.

title: When Election Day Is Over, Only 15 Votes Really Count
description: Most New Jersey residents may not know Stephen (Skippy) Weinstein or Adeline (Addy) Lubkert, but when they pull the lever in the Presidential election next month, they will probably be voting for one of them.

title: Lessons in Love as a Leap of Faith
description: SOMEWHERE between the liberal, the liberated or the purely hip and the would-be regulators of life way over to the far right, there are the truly confused. They are wondering what's going on. Did the world turn around when they were out to lunch? Those are the incalculable but sincere masses whom Bill C. Davis's play ''Avow,'' in its world premiere at the George Street Playhouse here, means to address and presumably enlighten. But it may compound the confusion.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: FYI 2

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PREMIERE FOR JEEVES

title: A Bountiful Week of Orchestras
description: SIX Connecticut orchestras and another on tour from England make this an especially opulent symphonic week. The feast begins at 3 this afternoon in the Palace Theater in Stamford, where Roger Nierenberg conducts the Stamford Symphony in Schumann's ''Genoveva'' Overture, Brahms' Third Symphony and -- with Misha Dichter the guest soloist -- Grieg's Piano Concerto. A free preconcert talk will be offered 45 minutes before the concert by Mr. Nierenberg.

title: Spain Dismayed by Theft of Priceless Medieval Book
description: An international search is under way for a rare 10th century manuscript that was stolen in September from a church museum in a remote mountain town in northern Spain.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the congressional race in New Jersey's 12th District misstated a voter's reason for opposing the Republican candidate, Mike Pappas. The voter, Gertrude Dubrovsky, said she would not vote for Mr. Pappas because he opposes abortion (as the article stated elsewhere), not because he supports abortion rights.

title: A Dredging Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: $800,318 Is Tops for College Presidents' Pay
description: When Franklyn G. Jenifer resigned as president of Howard University in June 1994 to accept the presidency of the University of Texas at Dallas, he received $676,980 in severance pay, $113,818 in salary and $9,520 in benefits. The total of $800,318 made him the highest-paid college president in the nation that year, according to a survey of private colleges and universities conducted by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: The Internet Scores Big With Soccer Fanatics
description: Lilting BBC English fades in and out over the shortwave radio, the inflection of the announcer's voice the only tipoff to the result of Premier League soccer matches that took place thousands of miles away.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday summarizing 14 close Senate races reversed the party affiliations of the candidates in Arkansas. Winston Bryant is a Democrat, and Tim Hutchinson is a Republican.

title: Joseph M. LaRocca, 87, Leader In Rehabilitation of the Disabled
description: Joseph Mark LaRocca, who spent more than half a century working with disabled people around the world, died on Sept. 27 at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 87.

title: A New Look At 'Less Is More'
description: Ambition takes the guise of simplicity in Meredith Monk's ''Politics of Quiet,'' a music theater piece that was part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival. In the hour-and-a-half performance, Ms. Monk looks at the psychological and technological detritus of this century, examines the communal dynamic of past centuries and prepares a rite of passage into the next.

title: Cynthia Novack, 49, Dancer and Teacher
description: Cynthia Novack, an improvisational dancer and a writer and teacher, died on Sept. 27 at home in Manhattan. She was 49.

title: If V.P. Debate Was Substantive, Is That Bad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: 25-Year Low In a Measure Of Well-Being
description: The nation's social well-being has fallen to its lowest point in almost 25 years, and children and young people are suffering the most, according to an index developed by researchers at Fordham University.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in Business Day on Oct. 2 with an article about increased emphasis by Nationsbank on branch banking characterized the bank's operations incorrectly in some editions. It continues to trade currencies and derivatives.

title: All-Purpose Tax Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Saluting A Building By a Man Who Stirs Things Up
description: It's hard to know which took more bravado: the University of Cincinnati's decision to commission Peter Eisenman to design a new building for its College of Design, Art, Architecture and Planning, or Mr. Eisenman's resolve to treat the completion of his building as the most important event in American architecture since Frank Lloyd Wright convinced Solomon Guggenheim that pictures looked good in round spaces.

title: Stephen Friedman, Film Producer, 59
description: Stephen J. Friedman, who produced ''The Last Picture Show,'' ''Slap Shot'' and ''The Big Easy,'' died on Oct. 4 at his home in Brentwood, Calif. He was 59.

title: Vigilantes in Blue
description: The shopping center is tiny. It's at the intersection of Ashford and Ogden Avenues in the village of Dobbs Ferry, about 15 miles north of New York City. Behind a parking lot big enough for half a dozen cars is a hair salon, a nail boutique, a print shop, a liquor store and the Venice Delicatessen.

title: Rats and Squalor, at $800 a Month
description: New Yorkers are understandably appalled at the squalid and dangerous conditions exposed last week in ''Barely Four Walls,'' The Times's series on the scarcity of livable housing for poor families. The series documents case after case of children growing up in dilapidated, rat-infested buildings that violate nearly every applicable housing code. Meanwhile, the city's housing authorities stand helplessly by, hamstrung by a shortage of inspectors and a housing law that exempts even the worst landlords from serious punishment.

title: Dole, in New Jersey, Asks Whether He Should Attack
description: Going public with his quandary of how fiercely he should attack President Clinton, Bob Dole today put the question to voters in New Jersey.

title: Closing the Book on a Saloon for 'Drinkers With Writing Problems'
description: In more than a quarter-century behind the bar at the Lion's Head, Paul Schiffman forced more than a few drinkers out onto daybreak's doorstep at the close of a long and sorry night. ''We call them the lingerers,'' he said, a mixture of pity and affection in his old seaman's voice. ''The hangers-on, the lonely people who have nowhere to go and no one to go home to, who don't want to leave.''

title: Relax! You Don't Have to Scrap Scrapple
description: To the Editor:

title: Slim Hope for Missing Hunter
description: As hope dwindled in the search for a hunter who fell off a boat on Friday, the state police called off their divers yesterday and began dragging the Maurice River with grappling hooks. The missing man, Keith Messier Jr., 20, is believed to have suffered a seizure and fallen overboard, Officer Fred Hickman of the state police marine bureau in Bivalve said yesterday. Mr. Messier was hunting for rail, a marsh bird.

title: Welfare Mothers and Informal Day Care: Is It Up to Par?
description: New York City spends millions of dollars a year paying for child care for welfare recipients without any quality control, safety oversight or basic information about the people being paid to care for thousands of the city's most vulnerable children.

title: Dolphins Intercept Bills' Final Chance
description: The Miami Dolphins were in two-deep coverage in the secondary, and, after this play, they were in trouble that looked way too deep to overcome. Receiver Andre Reed had given the Dolphins the old stop-and-go move, had caught the pass and, 49 yards later, had reached the Miami 2. Dolphins cornerback Terrell Buckley made the saving tackle. There was only 1 minute 55 seconds left. Miami's 14-7 lead looked lost.

title: Judah Stampfer, Educator and Poet, 72
description: Judah Leon Stampfer, an educator, poet, novelist and translator, died on Oct. 4 at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mexico Drops Its Petrochemical Privatization
description: Abandoning what has been a central pillar of its economic modernization program, the Mexican Government today canceled its prolonged and troubled effort to sell the state-owned secondary petrochemical industry to private investors.

title: Irvin Is Average in Return, But Cowboys Beat Cards
description: After their faltering start this season, the Dallas Cowboys were sounding a bit like the President Bill Clinton of two years ago, who had to remind Americans that the Constitution still gave him ''relevance'' despite the Republican takeover of Congress. When the Cowboys hit the skids at 1-3, quarterback Troy Aikman weighed in with a similarly plaintive note: ''We still are world champions,'' he said, ''until proven otherwise.''

title: Police Officer Shot in Head On a Street Corner in Brooklyn
description: An off-duty housing officer was shot and killed in Brooklyn last night after he and a fellow officer tried to settle a personal dispute, the police said.

title: Afghan Fights Islamic Tide: As a Savior or a Conqueror?
description: If proof were needed that history takes curious turns, there is evidence in the heavy-set warlord with the shoe-brush mustache whose portraits loom over this old Central Asian city. Once a Communist general, he is now spoken of by people in northern Afghanistan as Pasha, a title used by some of the region's ancient kings.

title: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Are Set
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Salmon Are Thrown Away As Alaska Deals With Glut
description: At a time when coastal communities in most of the United States are left with the spectral remains of once-abundant fish runs, Alaska this fall is grappling with the opposite problem: salmon so bounteous that millions of fish are being thrown away.

title: Gun Violence May Be Subsiding, Studies Find
description: In what may be a significant turning point in the battle against gun violence, analyses of two new studies suggest that murders, robberies and assaults committed with guns dropped faster than violent crime over all last year.

title: New Households Form Slowly
description: New Jersey has been adding new households at a slower rate than most other states, the United States Census Bureau reported last week. About 66,000 new households were added between April 1990 and July 1995, giving the state a total of 2.8 million households, the report said. That figure represents a growth rate of 2.4 percent over that period, putting New Jersey in a tie with Maine and Iowa for 44th place. The fastest-growing states were primarily in the South, in the mountain states and on the West Coast. Nevada led the nation with a rate of 26 percent.

title: . . . But Not for a Senator
description: State holiday notwithstanding, some matters are too important to wait. Today, Senator C. Louis Bassano, chairman of the Human Services Committee, will be the first lawmaker to get a peek at the Whitman administration's plans for complying with the new Federal welfare law. Senator Bassano, a Republican from Union, will be briefed by William Waldman, the Human Services Commissioner, and members of the Governor's staff. With the state losing more than $3 million in Federal grants for each month that goes by without a plan, Mr. Bassano said, ''They're probably in a hurry to implement this thing.''

title: Parents Will Let Texas Girl Have Surgery
description: Steve and Patricia Stout, a Texas couple who have fought for alternatives to surgery for their 10-year-old daughter, gave doctors in North Carolina their consent this morning to remove the girl's severely ulcerated colon.

title: Prestigious and Liberal Irish Times Sails Ahead in a Troubled and Competitive Market
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 13

title: DANCE
description: An Art Is Combative

title: Gradual Shift to G.O.P. Leaves Texas Least Likely of the Big States to Support Clinton
description: Once upon a time, Texas was a Democratic stronghold that sent Democratic senators and Congressmen to Washington who reached positions of great power -- people like President Lyndon B. Johnson and Sam Rayburn and Jim Wright, both Speakers of the House of Representatives, and influential legislators like Olin Teague and Jack Brooks and Lloyd M. Bentsen.

title: No Thanks! And You Can Tell It to the Marines
description: The jetty that links this isolated Caribbean island to the outside world is a simple wooden structure in obvious need of repair. So when the United States offered to send a detachment of marines here to build a base for the Grenada Coast Guard and to repair the local school and clinic, residents might have been expected to welcome the proposal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about the appointment of a chief executive of Pepsico Inc.'s Taco Bell chain misstated the new role of the former chief, John Martin. He will head the company's casual dining unit, which consists of the California Pizza Kitchen, Chevys and East Side Mario's chains; the unit does not include KFC, Pizza Hut or Taco Bell.

title: The Traveling Archbishop
description: When Albanians go to the polls this week, Theodore E. McCarrick, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Newark, will be there. When a new Catholic seminary opens in Sarajevo, Archbishop McCarrick will be there, too. As chairman of the Committee for Aid to the Church in Central and Eastern Europe of the National Conference of Bishops, Archbishop McCarrick leads a group that has distributed about $31 million to churches in 22 countries in an effort to restore Catholicism after decades of dormancy under Communist rule.

title: Aloha to the GTE Party Line
description: When Barry Neal, a consulting meteorologist specializing in the Hawaiian Islands' air quality, decided he wanted to move a few years ago, he knew what he wanted: a home away from busy Oahu, in rural Ka'u, and the chance to telecommute to work.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here early today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 56.40 points -- a ittle more than one-quarter of 1 percent -- at 20,911.76. On Friday, the Nikkei gained 97.33 points.

title: Shunning Environmental Pleas, Clinton Signs Pipeline Measure
description: President Clinton has signed legislation on oil and gas pipeline safety, turning aside requests from environmentalists that he veto the bill.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Bernstein Setting of American Poetry at the 92d St. Y
description: For the last few years the administration at the 92d Street Y has debated whether presenting performances should remain a central part of its mission as a community center that also offers classes and athletic programs. Declining audiences and increased presentation costs weighed in favor of cutting the arts budget. And in recent years the Y has seen the departures of Omus Hirshbein, the visionary director of its performance program, and the New York Chamber Symphony, which Mr. Hirshbein and the conductor Gerard Schwarz started 20 years ago.

title: Knicks Plan to Sign Brooks
description: Taking less than two days to address their need at point guard, the Knicks have zeroed in on the veteran Scott Brooks. Though a team official said the deal is yet to be completed, Brooks is expected to sign a one-year contract for the league minimum salary of $247,500 within the next 24 hours.

title: Same Scene, Different Security, in Reopened Club
description: The girl in the electric blue boa was back. So was the pounding techno music and the huge disco balls spraying the dance floor with a kaleidoscope of whirling dots. But loyal patrons who returned to the Tunnel last night said the reopened nightclub was not the same.

title: Calipari Knows You Can't Always Go Back Home Again
description: It's easy to see how John Calipari could have grown comfortable in this tiny pocket of a town, where the trees are bursting in Crayola shades now.

title: Senate Candidates Torricelli and Zimmer Exchange Barbs Before a Jewish Audience
description: At a Senate candidate forum at a suburban synagogue, Representative Robert G. Torricelli received a hostile reception from some audience members who brought up an old speech he had made before a group that included people tied to the Hamas terrorist group.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When VAN CLIBURN speaks at the Broadway Baptist Church in Fort Worth tonight, he plans to tell the audience, ''If the Holy Scriptures are the word of God, then surely great music must be the breath of God.''

title: Autopsy of Fordham Player Proves to Be Inconclusive
description: An autopsy performed yesterday by the city Medical Examiner's office on the body of a 20-year-old Fordham University football player who died suddenly before a game Saturday proved inconclusive.

title: Torre Gets His Own Hot Fudge Sundae
description: HIS Yankee players were celebrating their American League pennant on Camden Yards' infield grass, but Joe Torre, who would be in a World Series for the first time in his 32 years in baseball, stayed in the dugout.

title: Clinton, in Detailed Interview, Calls His Health 'Very Good'
description: In his first interview about his health, President Clinton said that it was ''very good,'' that he had never had a serious illness and that he had controlled his three most pesky problems: hoarseness, allergies and weight. Sometimes, however, he misses comments in crowded areas because of a mild hearing loss.

title: Women Seen, Or Just Used, Through Art
description: A FEW days ago, three women wandered over to Riverside Park at dusk to look at the new statue of Eleanor Roosevelt. ''Nice,'' said one of the women. ''Looks just like her,'' said a second. ''It shows her quiet. Thinking. Good,'' said the third.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BETTY COMDEN, the lyricist and playwright, has more than the standard reasons to be touched by an award she will receive on Wednesday from the Momentum AIDS project. Her son, Alan Kyle, who died of AIDS in 1990 at the age of 35, was helped by its services, which include communal meals, counseling, psychiatric care and medical advice. A drug abuser, Mr. Kyle had contracted AIDS through the use of needles, and Ms. Comden described his decline in poignant detail in her memoir, ''Off Stage,'' published last year by Simon & Schuster.

title: In Toronto, U.S. Fugitives Find They Can Run but Can't Hide
description: They found Joyce Carolyn Stevens, wanted in Texas on charges of aggravated robbery and kidnapping, hiding in a third-floor room on Bloor Street here. Her partner, Rose Marie Turford, was picked up a couple of hours later while working the phones in a telemarketing office nearby.

title: Defense Carries the Giants So Far, Then Begins Snapping
description: After one of the worst offensive performances by a Giants team in the past 10 years, a group of Giants offensive players went to the house of running back Rodney Hampton tonight for some food and a little commiserating. Well, a lot of commiserating. With any luck, a shrink was there, too.

title: World Series Heads Back to Bronx
description: HE was sitting on a wooden bench in Baltimore's Pennsylvania Station, peaceful and alone on this Sunday morning, minding his own business despite being George M. Steinbrenner 3d.

title: Yankees in Series After 15 Years in Wilderness
description: With awesome power and precise pitching, the Yankees continued their stunning superiority over Baltimore today to create this picturesque scene at Camden Yards: a 6-4 victory that secured the elusive American League Championship and the Yankees' first World Series appearance since 1981. There will be more meaningful baseball played in the Bronx in October. The season is alive.

title: MUSIC
description: From Dances to Meditations,

title: Rene Lacoste Dies at 92; Gave Fashion the Alligator
description: Rene Lacoste, a member of the legendary Four Musketeers of French tennis, as well as the inventor of the metal racquet and the man behind a line of sportswear that became a status symbol, died Saturday in a hospital in St. Jean-de-Luz, France. He was 92.

title: Creation of Many Channels Sparks Home-Grown Productions
description: Inside a converted sawmill on the edge of this Rhineland city, television cameras swooped and zoomed on a recent afternoon, capturing the fun as a game-show host put questions to squirming contestants.

title: The New Isolationist?
description: Republicans love to re member 1980 the only time this century they beat a Democratic president. Bob Dole and Jack Kemp have been trying to reprise that campaign with their tax cut plan and their assault on liberalism.

title: A Tight Race For Governor In the Midwest
description: Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis, who is running for governor, won Bryan P. Norman's vote here at the West Side Nut Club Fall Festival, a weeklong carnival in the far southwest of the state that attracts visitors from all over the region.

title: Ignorant Investors Can Build Capitalism Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Smuggled Aliens Now Cross Mohawk Land
description: The Mohawk Indian reservation along the St. Lawrence River here has long been called Smugglers' Alley, an easy path to sneaking contraband into or out of the United States.

title: The True Co-op World
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharing a Muse of Fire in a Close Collaboration
description: Beneath the ardent collaboration so often lies the contest of wills. Mischa Maisky and Martha Argerich, who played as a cello-piano duo at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, have wills that look much alike: shared powers of assertion that literally leap out into the audience but in the end may be very different. It was an evening that left behind strong impressions of two performers. Beethoven, Stravinsky, Schumann and Shostakovich trailed in their wake, more or less as props.

title: TV Station Figures
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennant Doesn't Equal Job Security to Watson
description: The scene in the third-base dugout featuring General Manager Bob Watson was surreal. The Yankees were about to take the field, on the verge of reaching the World Series for the first time since 1981. But Watson still spoke like a man about to be fired. He did not seem flustered by the possibility.

title: THEATER
description: From the Gay 90's to Rock,

title: Croatia's Open Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Political Ads Leap From the TV Landscape
description: The best turkey of all is Butterball. Jimmy from GMC puts you comfortably in command. ''The Chamber'' is the best John Grisham adaptation yet.

title: Rigging the Test Scores Justifiably
description: The decision by the College Board to add a writing component to the Preliminary Scholastic Assessment Test, thereby boosting women's scores, is a justifiable effort to improve the ability of the tests to predict how well a student will perform in college. The change has been criticized as a spineless way to help women score better despite their inferior math skills. But the fact is that the tests consistently underestimate the college performance of women as compared with men. Adding a writing component, a move that was requested by colleges and universities for reasons unrelated to the gender gap, may well raise women's scores -- but only toward the level they should be at to predict college performance. If that turns out to be so, this commitment to improve academic validity will warrant applause, not ridicule.

title: The Supreme Court steps into a gray zone to consider ''virtual'' infringement on a patent.
description: IMAGINE a world in which just about every homeowner who wanted to build an addition or plant a row of shrubbery had to sue the neighbors to figure out the exact location of the property line. That is the world of inventors, where patents are often compared to deeds, with the big difference between them being that the boundaries of inventions are far fuzzier than those defining physical property. Frequently, a clear line of demarcation is established only through litigation.

title: Day Off for Some Schools
description: In most of New Jersey, Columbus Day is a school day like any other. But in Hackettstown and Rockaway Township, today is an unscheduled day off for students and a paid holiday for teachers, who are involved in contract disputes. State law allows teachers to take paid leave on state holidays that are not school holidays -- such as Columbus Day -- and teachers' unions in the two towns informed officials last week that all their members planned to take the day off. Teachers in Hackettstown, a district of about 1,800 students, have been without a contract since June.

title: Gingrich Vigorously Assails Democrats' Fund Raising
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich today stepped up Republican accusations that the Clinton Administration had solicited illegal campaign money from foreigners, and predicted that inquiries into the matter would make Watergate ''look tiny.''

title: The Riches of Cable
description: Like many disputes that mix politics and commerce, the battle raging between the Giuliani administration and Time Warner is ultimately over control of a precious resource. In this case, it is a relatively new and utterly man-made one: access to cable television distribution.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Privatization Program Is Canceled by Mexico

title: Savoring A True Season of Football
description: There are more than enough reasons to explain why college football does not need a National Football League-style post-season playoff. This weekend offered an important reminder of one of them. The season is a playoff, with its succession of shocks, surprises and scares lasting from before Labor Day to beyond Thanksgiving.

title: Holiday Today
description: Columbus Day is observed.

title: The Populist 'Me'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Wednesday about a party being given that night, belatedly celebrating the 93d birthday of the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld, misstated his birth date. It is June 21, not June 23.

title: Russian Opportunities
description: To the Editor:

title: Managers Staying Dry As Corporations Sink
description: For 20 years, Ralph DeKlotz worked as an engineer for Morrison Knudsen, the fabled construction giant that fell on hard times two years ago. When the company finally filed for bankruptcy last June, Mr. DeKlotz, 50, lost a third of his retirement nest egg because the company stock he owned in his retirement savings plan became virtually worthless.

title: Dream Rematch Hits a Snag
description: The possibility of a rematch between Skip Away and Cigar in the Breeders' Cup Classic, with tantalizing implications for Horse of the Year honors, hit a snag yesterday when Skip Away's workout at Keeneland was canceled because his trainer was ill.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: British Parties Vie for Votes of the Upwardly Mobile
description: Tony Blair, the leader of the Labor Party, remembers when he knew that the last British general election was lost.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: After months of work, a unit of the WPP Group lands some European assignments for Mazda.
description: AMBITIOUS and assiduous initiatives by the WPP Group to build a relationship with Mazda Motor, the Japanese auto maker, have at last paid off with plum assignments in Europe.

title: Bridge
description: The World Open Team Championship that begins on Sunday on the Greek island of Rhodes is likely to be won by the United States, Canada or one of the many strong European teams.

title: Games Wooing an Internet Audience
description: No one has as yet made a profit marrying multiplayer games to Prince Internet or built a business model with which to make money happily ever after.

title: Robert Alberts, 89, U.S. History Expert
description: Robert C. Alberts, a writer and biographer, died on Tuesday at St. Clair Memorial Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 89 and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: Technology And Travails Of Dow Jones
description: Wall Street is thriving again, as the stock market flirts with record highs almost daily. And the price of a key raw material in the newspaper business -- newsprint -- is now falling. Yet Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of the nation's dominant financial newspaper, The Wall Street Journal, is having a rough year.

title: Accounts
description: * General Aviation Team 2000, Washington, an organization founded by aircraft manufacturers, owners and pilots, to Tinsley Advertising, Miami, as the first agency to handle its national account. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: A Blow to European Nationalism
description: The nationalist quarrel between Hungary and Romania is typical of the ethnic conflicts that have bubbled to the surface in Central Europe since the fall of Communism. While rarely violent, it has been written off as one of those intractable hatreds history produces when ethnic and national boundaries do not match. But now the countries have signed a treaty that may help end this feud. Support for the treaty in both nations also reflects a welcome turn away from ethnic hatred. While racist politicians are gaining strength in Western Europe, attacking ethnic minorities is no longer a good way to win votes in Hungary or Romania.

title: Torricelli and Zimmer Spar on Mideast Affairs
description: At a Senate candidate forum at a synagogue in Livingston, N.J., Representative Robert G. Torricelli received a hostile reception from some audience members and came under attack for once giving a speech before a group that included people tied to the Hamas terrorist group.

title: Mechanic of Japan's Machine Politics Stalls a Bit
description: This should be Ichiro Ozawa's big moment, a chance to begin packing his bags for the move into the Prime Minister's residence.

title: AIDES TO DOLE SAY HE PLANS BIG PUSH TO WIN CALIFORNIA
description: Confronting polls that show President Clinton dominant in nearly every region of the country, senior aides to Bob Dole said today that they had tentatively decided to pour resources into California while pulling back in other important states like New Jersey and Ohio.

title: Hispanic and Italian Parades Staunchly Stake Their Claim on Fifth Avenue
description: Christopher Columbus, a vain and ambitious man who loved a parade, would surely be satisfied with the current state of affairs in New York City.

title: Rangers' Slow Start Brings Talk of Changes
description: For the first time in his three seasons as coach of the Rangers, the job status of Colin Campbell is a valid topic of doubt, debate and discussion. His team, with its marquee names and its high payroll, is off to an alarming start of 0-3-2 following Saturday's 5-2 defeat in Montreal.

title: Small Presses Thrive in the Diversity Niche
description: As a publisher of children's books, Harriet Rohmer has encountered many stories about children's perceptions of the world, but she found powerful resonance in a memory the Chinese-American novelist Frank Chin once shared with her about his childhood. Like many children, he was a fan of the Lone Ranger. But unlike most, he was convinced that under that black mask, the Lone Ranger was really Chinese.

title: Ammirati Team Moves to Saatchi
description: A top creative team at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York is leaving to take new positions at the New York office of M & C Saatchi.

title: Orioles Watch Dream Die
description: The last time the Yankees clinched against Baltimore, wrapping up the American League East with a 19-2 victory over Milwaukee on Sept. 25, at least the Orioles did not have to watch up close and personal.

title: The Rookie Mickens Learns N.F.L. Lessons
description: Two of the smallest Jets were in the spotlight today. One stepped up, the other was trampled.

title: New Data Standard May Help Speed Up Video on Internet
description: A coalition of 38 computer makers and software publishers led by the Netscape Communications Corporation and Progressive Networks Inc. plans to announce a new audio and video data standard Monday that will permit companies using the Internet to compete more directly with radio and television broadcasters.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Armand Hammer's Maze of Skulduggery
description: On a January day in 1979, shortly after admitting defeat in a bitter industrial war, the corporate mogul and art collector Armand Hammer brainstormed privately with his lawyer about some troublesome fallout. Several years earlier, he had passed off a $60,000 Goya painting as a million-dollar bequest to the Soviet Union. Suddenly, the transaction and a cash kitty it disguised threatened to become public, embarrassing him with his Soviet friends and entangling him with American investigators.

title: Jets Look Good Early, But Their True Colors Emerge Amid Confusion
description: The Jets' long trip to nowhere continued today as they fell 4 points short against a team in only its second year of play.

title: The Bean Show Must Go On
description: Nothing, it seems, can dampen the spirits of what organizers call the nation's only lima bean festival -- not even the sudden collapse of the local bean economy. Earlier this year, Hanover Foods, longtime buyer of nearly all of Cape May County's Ford Hook lima beans, announced that it would take its business elsewhere, forcing farmers to stop growing the beans. But though the beans in the soup and the bean-toss were store-bought, organizers of the West Cape May Lima Bean Festival reported that Saturday's jamboree was the biggest ever, drawing more than 7,000 bean lovers.

title: Return of Civility
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Gun Crimes Drop

title: Janice A. Burns, 33, Who Sought A Wider Understanding of AIDS
description: Janice A. Burns, a writer and speaker on AIDS who sought to awaken and educate a wider audience, especially young people, to its realities, died of the disease on Sept. 28 at St. John's Hospital in Yonkers.

title: Machines should help people become smarter, calmer, more subtle.
description: ALL right, just settle back. Take a deep breath,'' the computer commands in unctuous tones. And indeed, the deep rasping exhalation of an asthmatic emerges from the speakers. The screen shows a circular green disk under which are some other imperatives: ''Look deeply into the disk. If it seems to move, you may be in a trance. If it doesn't move . . . you may be deeper than you think.''

title: Working on the Railroad
description: Computerized station announcements, mauve and aqua color schemes, and the head of New Jersey Transit herself await commuters on the Morris and Essex rail line tomorrow. Shirley A. DeLibero, New Jersey Transit's executive director, will field questions and comments from riders on the first day of service for the railroad's new Comet IV train cars. Six of the cars, which cost $1.2 million apiece, will make their debut tomorrow on Midtown Direct trains, with 90 more to follow in coming months, transit officials said.

title: Contemporary Viennese Seeking New Traditions
description: Vienna, the capital of music in the 19th century, has played a distinctly smaller role in the 20th. Of course, Schoenberg, Berg and Webern loom large, but they found little sympathy in their native land. Since World War II, Austrian composers have had almost no international impact. Members of the so-called Third Viennese School spend more time poking fun at Viennese tradition than extending it.

title: Credit Offerings for the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: A Yankee Celebration Of Fine 1996 Vintage
description: The Champagne was being sprayed around the Yankee clubhouse, but George Steinbrenner wasn't there.

title: Too Modern for Old China, and Paying a Price
description: BOUND FEET AND WESTERN DRESS

title: OBITUARY: Tan Chee Khoon
description: Tan Chee Khoon, 77, a crusader against poverty who served three terms in the Malaysian Parliament from 1964 to 1978 and was respectfully called "Mr. Opposition" by the Malaysian press for his constructive criticisms, died Sunday.

title: A Tribute to Broadway From the Boston Pops And a 'Seinfeld' Star
description: After a two-night stand at Carnegie Hall with wistful, melancholic and downright funereal music by Barber and Mahler, the Boston Symphony gave its principal players the evening off on Friday and donned its party hat as the Boston Pops. Or you might argue the opposite: that after two nights of lofty and sometimes edifying contemplation, the orchestra finally got down to serious business, for the Pops is, among other things, the well-oiled money machine many another orchestra wishes it had in these parlous times.

title: 'Flat-Out Wrong'
description: Asked directly about a charge made in this column that President Clinton had been personally involved in the solicitation of an illegal $250,000 campaign contribution, press secretary Michael McCurry replied, ''That's flat-out wrong.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 28 about an arts conference in Chicago misidentified a project that helps young people from the inner city use community television; it also misidentified Chicago's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. The project for young people is Street-Level, not Streetwise; the arts commissioner is Lois Weisberg, not Lois Weisman.

title: DANCE
description: Like Fashion Models

title: G.O.P. Leaders in Show Me State Find Dole Elusive
description: The Dole campaign's tug-of-war over where to fight has led to a half-in, half-out strategy in some states that is perhaps most out in the open here in Missouri.

title: Pennant Elates Yankee Fans in an Almost Spiritual Fashion
description: The bus carrying the triumphant Yankees arrived at Yankee Stadium shortly after midnight, greeted by more than 4,000 fans celebrating their arrival and camping out to buy World Series tickets. An exuberant Wade Boggs jumped off the bus, dropped his bags and ran to the crowd dispensing high-fives.

title: Harry Glickman, WQXR Violinist, 86
description: Harry Glickman, assistant concertmaster of the NBC Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini and first violinist of the WQXR String Quartet for 25 years, died Oct. 6 at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Cardinal Comeback Has Braves In Trouble
description: Dmitri Young had been an unknown player in this drama called the National League Championship Series. At age 22, he had gone about his post-season workouts in relative obscurity even for someone 240 pounds. There were no interviews; no one asking him his thoughts on himself, the series or the Atlanta Braves. But that all changed with one swing of his bat tonight at Busch Stadium.

title: Religious Loophole
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Starting To Point Fingers
description: To preserve team unity, pro football players avoid pointing fingers at teammates who have not played well. But sometimes frustration takes over, as it did today for Giants middle linebacker Corey Widmer after New York's 19-10 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: In Popular Tongues, Spanish Stays Numero Uno
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER
description: Two Men Trapped

title: No Headline
description: ''I never felt comfortable, as a player or manager, watching the World Series. I always shut off the celebrations. To me, it was like watching someone else eating a hot fudge sundae.''

title: No Corks Popping at Giants Stadium
description: ON a gorgeous Sunday afternoon, fans of two of New York's pro sports franchises found themselves drifting between two worlds while sitting in Giants Stadium. One was the frustrating, mediocre world of Giants football; the other, the spine-tingling magic of Yankees baseball.

title: A Do-Good TV Family, Sort of Like the Waltons
description: Family entertainment. Family values. These are the codes with which various protest groups clobber television. In fact, prime time is cluttered with do-good programming, whether it be the entrenched ''Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman'' on CBS on Saturdays or the relatively new ''Moesha'' on UPN on Tuesdays. The schedule is crammed, happily, with shining object lessons for young audiences and their parents.

title: Hollywood's obsession with the opening weekend makes or breaks a film.
description: WEEKENDS are the cruelest time in Hollywood.

title: The New New Yorker: The Talk of the Town, Except on Madison Avenue
description: By most standards, The New Yorker is on a roll. Since Tina Brown took the helm in 1992, the magazine has won 6 National Magazine Awards and been nominated for 22. New Yorker articles and fiction have been featured in the Best American Essays and the Best American Short Stories series. Circulation has risen 38 percent, to 868,651, in four years, even while the cover price has gone up 51.3 percent, to $2.95. And The New Yorker has managed to maintain the sort of perpetual buzz that other publications would kill for.

title: Clinton's Sorriest Record
description: Bill Clinton has not been called to account in this campaign for the worst aspect of his Presidency. That is his appalling record on constitutional rights.

title: Power Game: Yankees Blast Off Into the Series
description: They who live by the club die by the club. No, not sword, club. The Yankees did not dissect the Orioles with a saber; they clubbed them, as in whacked, slugged, clobbered, mashed. The Yankees did not beat their swords into plowshares; they clubbed the Orioles into submission -- and the off season.

title: Ignorant Investors Can Build Capitalism Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Kemp and Farrakhan
description: Something seems to have happened to Jack Kemp -- some strange political virus taken over. But maybe it is worse. Maybe nothing has happened to him and he was always as he is now. If so, maybe it is best that he fulfill that longing and march right off to Louis Farrakhan's parade.

title: Charges Limit Otherwise Healthy Bank Profits
description: Three big American banks, including the First Union Corporation, said yesterday that third-quarter profits were buoyed by higher fees and lending but reduced by the cost of contributions to a revamped Federal insurance pool for savings associations.

title: Chrysler Earnings Top Forecasts, Lifting Auto Stocks
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported third-quarter earnings today that were considerably above analysts' expectations, as ever more Americans have been choosing sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks, which have high profit margins, over cars. The report produced a broad rally in auto stocks.

title: Travelers Earnings Increased 23% in Quarter
description: Travelers Group Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 23 percent in the third quarter as profits surged from its Smith Barney brokerage unit and property and casualty insurance businesses.

title: Israel's President on Visit to Soothe Egypt
description: Persisting in his self-appointed role as peace envoy, President Ezer Weizman of Israel traveled to Egypt today to reassure an increasingly distrustful President Hosni Mubarak that the Israeli Government would abide by its commitments to the Palestinians.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Will MADONNA now be learning the lyrics to the Barney song? Yesterday, she gave birth to a 6-pound-9-ounce girl at Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles, signaling a new phase for the pop star known for risque lyrics and stage antics.

title: Goldman to Elevate 115, but Not All to Coveted Partnerships
description: Jon S. Corzine and Henry M. Paulson Jr., continuing their make-over of Goldman, Sachs & Company, are expected to name the firm's first managing directors today.

title: THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: North Carolina

title: Clinton Relishes Signing Bills No One Could Possibly Hate
description: He may be ahead in the polls, but President Clinton chose not to sit on his lead today. Instead, he stood on it, atop a rickety platform covered with raggedy red carpet in the parking lot of the highway Holiday Inn here in the high desert, where he is preparing for his second debate against Bob Dole.

title: Morgan Ends Season On High Note for NBC
description: If things had gone differently, Joe Morgan might be calling the World Series for Fox. But NBC, which has only post-season games and alternate All-Star Games, exercised an option to keep him. So his year's television work -- mostly Sunday nights on ESPN -- ended Sunday on NBC with the Yankees winning the American League pennant.

title: Beryl Reid, Actress, 76, Dies; Gave Life to Varied Eccentrics
description: Beryl Reid, the versatile British character actress who won a Tony Award in 1967 for her performance in ''The Killing of Sister George'' and was one of the most popular stars on the London stage and on British television, died on Sunday. She was 76.

title: A Caffeine Jolt For the Braves' Sleeping Bats
description: One game from a premature end to his team's season, in a city prepared for a pennant celebration, Luis Polonia did his part to help the Atlanta Braves play one more game. As his teammates stepped onto the field at Busch Stadium for batting practice this afternoon, Polonia grabbed a bat and raked it along the top of the bat rack in the third base dugout. As Polonia disturbed the carefully arranged bats, knocking the knobs back and forth in their bins, his voice matched the noise he was creating.

title: Mexican Stocks Fall Sharply After a Rise In Interest Rates
description: Mexican shares dropped for the third session as the Bank of Mexico raised interest rates to defend the peso after the currency plunged to a 10-month low.

title: Tupperworn
description: Yikes! Plastic is mortal? In museums all over the world, post-war design collections are falling apart. Eames foam upholstery crumbles into sand. Bowls turn toxic. Tupperware smells gamy. (I thought it was me.) At the Museum of Modern Art, you can't see through the see-thru helicopter windshield anymore.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Wednesday and Thursday about the debate between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp misspelled the name of the theater in St. Petersburg, Fla., where the debate took place. It is the Mahaffey, not Mahaffrey.

title: Devils' Youth Movement Does Not Include Broten
description: If the Devils can't get it done with experience, they'll try to do it with youth.

title: Tailhook Scandal's Long Shadows
description: The 1991 Tailhook scandal, involving naval pilots who sexually abused female officers at a convention in a Las Vegas hotel, excited plenty of outrage at the time as an example of military attitudes and Top Gun libidos running amok. Tonight ''The Navy Blues'' digs into the impact it has had on the Navy.

title: Bond Market Closed
description: The United States Treasury market was closed yesterday in observance of Columbus Day. Stock and commodity markets, however, were open.

title: Is Clinton's Encryption Policy Naive or Shrewd?
description: To the Editor:

title: Eleanor F. Cameron, 84, Children's Author
description: Eleanor Frances Cameron, an award-winning writer of children's books, died on Friday at Hospice House in Monterey, Calif. She was 84 and lived in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Supply Side: The Whole Story
description: Two months ago, Bob Dole presented a plan to raise America's economic growth. Arguments against the plan were pressed even before it was announced and have been repeated many times since. Some are clever -- probably the best that could be mounted in favor of the do-nothing alternatives. But even the best of them do not stand up to serious economic investigation.

title: Patterns
description: African Inspirations

title: ARCHER DANIELS AGREES TO BIG FINE FOR PRICE FIXING
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company, long one of the country's most influential and politically powerful corporations, agreed to plead guilty to conspiring with competitors to fix the prices of two agricultural products and pay $100 million in fines, the company announced yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL LeCLERC, the president of the New York Public Library, will be inducted into the French Legion of Honor tomorrow by Gen. GILBERT FORRAY, grand chancellor of the legion. The ceremony will be held at the French Consulate on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: From Birth, Body Houses Microbe Zoo
description: IT is a love affair that begins at birth: the human and the microbe.

title: Deutsche Babcock Seess Revamping as Costly
description: Shares in the troubled German engineering company Deutsche Babcock A.G. fell yesterday after the company said that the cost of a revamping program would be higher than originally expected. Babcock's shares closed at 47.4 marks ($30.96), down 4.5 marks from Friday.

title: A Leningrad Link From a Caracas Troupe
description: The accent was on Marius Petipa on Friday night at Kaye Playhouse when the ebullient Ballet Metropolitano de Caracas presented two rarely seen pas de deux by the 19th-century Russian master choreographer.
