The dances promised an extra degree of authenticity, staged as they were by Vladimir Lopoukhov, the assistant director of the Caracas company and the son of Fyodor Lopoukhov, whose stagings of 19th-century classics for the Kirov Ballet in Leningrad were instrumental in preserving that ballet tradition. What was most interesting about the pieces, however, was the way they were performed.

title: Better Highways Will Cut Traffic Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: In Sun, a History Lesson on Parade
description: It was a perfect day for a history lesson: sunny and breezy with clear skies and lots of visual aids.

title: Asterix, France's Superman and Ego
description: In the land of Voltaire and Balzac, of Proust and Sartre, it is Albert Uderzo who has sold more books than any French writer before him. Albert Uderzo? Well, as Ian Fleming discovered with James Bond, invented heroes have a way of stealing the limelight. And in this case, it is actually Mr. Uderzo's comic strip character, Asterix, who is the crowd-puller.

title: Japan Airlines Stock Off On Reports of New Rival
description: The shares of the Japan Airlines Company continued their recent decline yesterday, this time reacting to news that the H.I.S. Company, a ticket broker, intended to start a new airline in Japan. J.A.L.'s shares have fallen 11.6 percent since last Tuesday. A new domestic competitor is only part of J.A.L.'s woes, according to Patricia Horvath, an airline analyst at UBS Securities Ltd. Rising fuel prices, a weak yen and an expensive retirement payout are other negative factors.

title: Jazz Without Structure, Yet Dominated by Structure
description: Leading a seven-piece group of horn players called the Brass Reeds Ensemble, the tenor saxophonist and composer Assif Tsahar ran through four quietly dense pieces on Friday night at Roulette. The musicians were all jazz-based improvisers, but this music took them into a zone bereft of riffing and syncopation.

title: U.S., Warily Eyeing Iraq, Urges Warring Kurds to Make Peace
description: Exasperated American officials, trying to forestall another confrontation with Saddam Hussein less than a month before the Presidential election, are trying to push warring Kurdish factions into a cease-fire and back to the negotiating table after a new shift in the balance of power in northern Iraq.

title: Williams Is Emerging In National Spotlight
description: Roberto Clemente was one of the best players of his era, an era that included Hank Aaron and Willie Mays, but he always felt his talent was not sufficiently appreciated beyond Pittsburgh's borders. Not until his 17th -- and, as it turned out, next-to-last -- season did Clemente gain the recognition he deserved. He did it by dominating the 1971 World Series and making it his national stage.

title: Four Western Senate Races Are Too Close to Call
description: The West, land of wide-open spaces, is also the land of wide-open Congressional races this fall, especially races that could help decide which party ends up in control of the Senate.

title: Middleman Companies Buff Metal and Shares
description: Michelle G. Applebaum, a Salomon Brothers analyst, still winces when she remembers Salomon's experience taking Olympic Steel public in March 1994.

title: As Snug as a Bug in the System
description: WHEN it comes to the propagation of bugs, computers may not have caught up with nature, but they are clearly closing the gap. A recent search of the World Wide Web with the Altavista program found more than 50,000 Web pages containing both the words ''computer'' and ''bug.'' But a follow-up search found twice that many containing the word ''bug'' but not ''computer,'' seeming to suggest that nature might be triumphing after all.

title: Transit Union Dissidents Feel Pressure
description: Last fall, Cecile Clue, a subway conductor, went to transit stations, offices and locker rooms with a clipboard and a pen, urging other transit workers to sign a petition to recall their union president, Damaso Seda.

title: Jacke's Fifth Field Goal Seals Victory
description: Brett Favre threw the football 61 times tonight a Green Bay Packers record. Jerry Rice caught two touchdown passes -- typical production from the San Francisco 49er star.

title: Bob Watson Deserves A Thank You
description: USUALLY it's the Yankee manager who is twisting in George Steinbrenner's wind. This time it's the general manager.

title: Let Private Sector Help Solve Housing Crunch
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''We don't want our city to look like the streets of New York or the shantytowns of Latin America.''

title: DIGITAL SYSTEMS IN $80 MILLION DEAL FOR VIEWSTAR
description: Digital Systems International Inc. plans to acquire the Viewstar Corporation for stock worth about $80 million. Digital is a computer software and services company based in Redmond, Wash. Viewstar is a maker of document management software in Alameda, Calif. Digital plans to swap 3.9 million shares of its common stock for the closely held Viewstar. Shares of Digital rose $1 yesterday, to $22.625.

title: From Pick-Up Games To Knicks Point Guard
description: The Knicks were not the only option for Scott Brooks. There was the anonymity of playing in the Italian League or in his favorite pick-up game in Irvine, Calif., featuring stockbrokers, real-estate agents and firemen.

title: A Thriving Fundamentalist Congregation Feels Most Comfortable in the Mainstream
description: ''In 1976 I prayed on it and felt that God would have me start a church,'' said the Rev. Joel Cochran, who at the time was a 28-year-old associate pastor for a conservative Akron congregation. So he returned to his home in nearby rural, northern Stark County, a place just beginning to suburbanize, and started going door to door.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Nuclear Plant Inquiry
description: The operators of the Salem Nuclear Generating Station are investigating the possibility that three radiation monitoring control cabinets were tampered with, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The investigation began last week after a worker noticed that three screws were missing from a circuit board inside the Salem II reactor, said Patricia Du Bois, a spokeswoman for Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which operates the reactors. The two Salem plants have been out of service for more than a year, and officials said the missing screws posed no danger to the public. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Small Agency Is Said to Win Acura Review
description: Acura, the luxury division of the American Honda Motor Company, has ended one of the biggest and most closely watched advertising reviews of the year, according to executives with knowledge of the decision, by dismissing the agency that had handled the brand since its introduction and awarding the account, with billings estimated at $125 million, to a dark horse finalist.

title: An Honest Mistake
description: MARK CALCAVECCHIA was disqualified from the Texas Open yesterday when he pointed out that he had signed an incorrect scorecard. The act of honesty cost him $10,817.

title: After Year of Taking Notes, Crew Is Eager to Act on Them
description: For Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, who arrived in New York City a year ago talking passionately of the need for a campaign like the civil rights movement to improve public schools, it has been a sobering year.

title: ALBERTSON'S STOCK FALLS 15% ON POOR EARNINGS NEWS
description: The stock of Albertson's Inc. fell 15 percent yesterday after the company, a food and drug retailer, said that it expected earnings to be below Wall Street's expectations in its third and fourth quarters. The company, based in Boise, Idaho, cited high costs related to its recent strategy to improve sales. Albertson's said earnings for the third quarter, ending on Oct. 31, would be in line with the 42 cents a share earned a year ago. Albertson's also projected fourth-quarter income to equal the 61 cents a share earned a year ago. Analysts were expecting 48 cents a share for the third quarter and 68 cents for the fourth, according to First Call Inc. Albertson's stock was down $6.50, to $36.125 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, where 3.9 million shares traded.

title: Clinton Steers Clear Of Tough Questions
description: President Clinton, flanked by firefighters at a speech in Albuquerque, N.M., announced that he had signed the Wildfire Supression Aircraft Transfer Act of 1996, a noncontroversial bill that would allow the Defense Department to sell surplus aircraft to private contractors to help them fight forest fires.

title: Bay Networks' Chief Leaves as Profits Lag
description: Bay Networks Inc. posted fiscal first-quarter earnings yesterday that lagged behind expectations and said its chief executive, Andrew Ludwick, had resigned as promised from the computer networking company.

title: Just Saying No
description: A new poll reports that most American young people don't want to grow up to be President. I have interviewed young people galore to find out why.

title: Shifting Tone of Campaign, Dole Presses the Ethics Issue
description: Bob Dole mounted a piercing attack on President Clinton's ethics today, comparing potential White House scandals to Watergate. He also demanded, reversing an earlier statement, that Mr. Clinton pledge not to pardon associates implicated in the Whitewater inquiry.

title: Nylon's Inventor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Kerr Farewell
description: To the Editor:

title: H & R BLOCK NAMES ACTING LEADER ITS NEW CHIEF
description: H & R Block Inc. yesterday named Frank Salizzoni to be president and chief executive of the corporation and chairman of its Compuserve Corporation unit. Mr. Salizzoni, 58, has been H & R Block's interim president and chief executive since mid-June, when Richard Brown left the company. Mr. Brown also served as chairman of Compuserve. Mr. Salizzoni, the former president of USAir Group, plans to expand Block's tax and financial services and separate Compuserve from the tax business. At Compuserve, Mr. Salizzoni replaces Henry Frigon, who has been interim chairman. The stock of Compuserve, which trails America Online Inc., has dropped 60 percent since April, when Block sold 20 percent of its shares at $30 each.

title: SEACOR HOLDINGS TO BUY 49 VESSELS FOR $141 MILLION
description: Seacor Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Smit Internationale N.V.'s fleet of vessels used to supply offshore oil exploration operations for about $141 million in cash, stock and debt. Seacor, based in Houston, said it would acquire the fleet of 49 vessels for $84 million in cash, 712,000 shares valued at about $35.4 million and $21 million in subordinated convertible notes. Smit, a Rotterdam-based marine salvage and offshore installation contractor that is part of the Royal Nedlloyd Group, owns more than 300 vessels.

title: Coyotes Sign Roenick For 5 Years, $20 Million
description: JEREMY ROENICK signed a five-year, $20 million contract with the Phoenix Coyotes yesterday, and the team said he would be in uniform last night for a home game against the Edmonton Oilers.

title: AT&T Is Seen Set to Name New President
description: The AT&T Corporation may announce a new president and successor to its chairman, Robert E. Allen, as early as tomorrow, several people with knowledge of the search effort said yesterday. And C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman and chief executive of Hughes Electronics Corporation, has emerged as the leading candidate for the job, these people said.

title: Account Shifts At D.M.B. & B.
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has lost and gained assignments in separate account consolidations.

title: Name of the Game: T-I-T-L-E
description: Ernie Grunfeld engaged one of his recent acquisitions, forward Chris Jent, in a game of H-O-R-S-E during training camp. Grunfeld dropped eight shots in a row from around the perimeter, each one from 18 feet or beyond. In playground vernacular, this is called ''money,'' being on target, hitting everything you throw up.

title: SHARES OF VANGUARD AIRLINES DROP ON NEWS OF A LOSS
description: The stock of Vanguard Airlines Inc. plummeted 41 percent yesterday after the low-price carrier said it would post a third-quarter loss and cut services to some cities. Vanguard, based in Kansas City, Mo., attributed the expected loss for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30 to adverse publicity surrounding the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 in July. The company also cited higher fuel costs, reinstatement of a 10 percent Federal ticket tax and slow September passenger traffic for its problems. Vanguard said it would cut services to unprofitable markets in a bid to improve results for the fourth quarter but did not elaborate. Shares of Vanguard were down $2.1875, to $3.0625.

title: The Right Skirt Is a Long Skirt
description: At a time when pants are dominating fashion, a skirt can look downright dowdy unless it's long and slim -- long meaning any length from the bottom of the calf to the ankle. These lengths look best with a fitted jacket or skinny sweater, hosiery in a matching color and clunky shoes or boots.

title: Fans Dig Deep and Give It All They've Got for Series Tickets
description: Billy Crystal got World Series tickets, but as a famous Yankee fan who served as master of ceremonies for the unveiling of Mickey Mantle's monument this summer, he had connections. A scalper named Willie managed to get eight bleacher seats for $25 each, and by lunchtime, he said, he had unloaded two of them for $125 apiece.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday about a former South African Defense Minister's acquittal on murder charges misstated a result of the verdict. It is a setback to the South African Government's efforts to hold former officials to account for abuses during the apartheid era, but it does not end the Government campaign.

title: COMMERCE BANCORP EXPANDS INTO NORTHERN NEW JERSEY
description: Commerce Bancorp said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire Independence Bancorp for $76 million, in a move to expand into northern New Jersey. Commerce said that it planned to issue 0.935 of a share for each Independence share, making its offer worth about $25 an Independence share. Independence shares, which climbed 16 percent last week on speculation of an acquisition, rose $1.50, to $21.50 in Nasdaq trading. Commerce's shares fell 37.5 cents, to $26.625. Independence has eight branches in northern New Jersey. Commerce, which is based in Cherry Hill, N.J., has 56 branches in southern New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: Victory by Yankees Ignites New Battle: A Fight for Tickets
description: With the Yankees in the World Series for the first time in 15 years, the hottest commodity in town this week is a ticket to the October Classic. Some pulled strings, while others shelled out hundreds of dollars to scalpers. The most determined waited in line at Yankee Stadium, in many cases missing work for the chance to pay from $25 to $70 apiece for seats.

title: Ecstasy In Songs Of the Sufi
description: Though hundreds of quality musicians from non-Western countries perform in New York annually, American pop culture seems to allow only one or two world music stars into its ranks each year. This year, the leading Pakistani singer of qawwali Sufi (or mystical Islamic) music, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, finally entered the mainstream, thanks to his collaboration with Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam in the film ''Dead Man Walking.''

title: A Candidate's Hit List
description: The Democrat who hopes to replace Mr. Torricelli said yesterday that McDonald's should not get a tax break to advertise Big Macs in Moscow. Steve Rothman of Fair Lawn outlined $20 billion in cuts in corporate subsidies that he would propose over five years if is elected.

title: A Rich (and Nasty) Father, Defined by His Tics
description: A REGULAR GUY

title: Richard S. Young, 69, Pioneer In the Study of Space Biology
description: Dr. Richard S. Young, a pioneer in the study of space biology who proved, with the help of the sex life of sea urchins, that life could go on in space, died on Oct. 6 at his home on Cape Canaveral, Fla. He was 69.

title: Now, the Big Show
description: There are plenty of reasons for New Yorkers to celebrate the Yankees' convincing triumph over the Baltimore Orioles in the American League Championship Series. The World Series will now return to the Bronx for the first time since 1981, a very long drought for fans who had grown accustomed to sipping from victory's flagon. It also means that there will be at least one more championship series in the House That Ruth Built while George Steinbrenner tries to persuade the city to build him a new house on the West Side of Manhattan or maneuvers to move the team to the New Jersey swamps.

title: Torricelli Accepts 'L' Word, But Also Says He's Moderate
description: New Jersey needs a senator who will work for a balanced budget while protecting Government programs that help the state the most, Representative Robert G. Torricelli said today in an extensive interview that detailed the case he has been trying to make to voters in the race for the open Senate seat in New Jersey.

title: Braves Stay Alive With a Blowout
description: The St. Louis Cardinals' pitching staff was starting to resent all the attention being paid to the Atlanta Braves' heralded pitching staff during this National League Championship Series.

title: Leadership Heir Advances As E.D.S. Seeks Visibility
description: Electronic Data Systems advanced a possible heir to the company's leadership today by giving John R. Harris responsibility for companywide marketing and strategy with the key mission of raising E.D.S.'s visibility now that it has been split off by General Motors.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Tops 6,000, Continuing Six-Year Surge

title: Victory in a War of Attrition
description: In New York State's Capitol, special-interest groups have a secret strength. They endure. Governors come and go. Even incumbent legislators, despite their 98 percent re-election rates, retire eventually. But the special interests remain, submitting the same bills year after year until they triumph by exhaustion.

title: Summer Woes Paved the Way to the World Series
description: There were many quiet and restless nights for the Yankees in August and September as their once-insurmountable lead crumbled like a sand castle on the beach. Joe Torre recognized the direness of the situation and recognized that the first-place Yankees were flirting with a fiasco.

title: Stars Come Out From Under
description: It's not easy being in the middle of the road. Traffic comes at you from both directions. On three albums released today, popular rock musicians try to get over a dark period, struggling with the ever-present burdens of fame, drugs and heartbreak.

title: Is Clinton's Encryption Policy Naive or Shrewd?
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Is Still Tough at the 15th Precinct
description: There was a time, back at its premiere in 1993, when ABC's ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' was considered controversial, apparently because it offered, among other licentious things, a shot of the bare buttocks of Dennis Franz. That was hardly an image likely to whip the country into sexual frenzy, but nudity watchdogs made the most of their panting opportunity.

title: Dresdner Bank Foresees Strong Rise in Profit
description: The chief executive of the Dresdner Bank A.G., Jurgen Sarrazin, has repeated his forecast for a double-digit rise in operating profit this year at Dresdner, Germany's second-largest commercial bank.

title: Microbial Life's Steadfast Champion
description: IT'S clear to me that if you wiped all multicellular life forms off the face of the earth, microbial life might shift a tiny bit,'' said Dr. Carl R. Woese, an evolutionary microbiologist who has devoted his life to convincing people, including other scientists, that microorganisms are in charge of nearly everything. ''If microbial life were to disappear, that would be it -- instant death for the planet.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARRY BOSTWICK plays the mayor of New York City on the ABC sitcom ''Spin City,'' and mayors, as everyone knows, have tightly scheduled lives. So it is fitting that Mr. Bostwick and his wife, SHERRI ELLEN BOSTWICK, had a baby by appointment yesterday. At Lenox Hill Hospital, Mrs. Bostwick gave birth by Caesarean section to a 7-pound-10-ounce girl at 9:01 A.M.

title: TRW Announces Layoffs And $233 Million Charge
description: In a move it said was taken to increase competitiveness in its automotive business, TRW Inc. said yesterday that it planned to eliminate about 2,300 jobs and close several plants. The company took an aftertax charge of $233.4 million in the third quarter to pay for the moves.

title: 2 Big Utilities In California Merge to Fight Competition
description: Two large California utilities, the Enova Corporation and Pacific Enterprises, announced yesterday that they would merge, forming the utility with the largest number of customers in the country.

title: Cyberspace, With a Laugh Track
description: AN emoticon, as everybody knows, is an icon representing an emotion that can be typed on a keyboard and included in an E-mail message. :-D, for instance, is a person laughing; you have to tilt your head to the left to distinguish the eyes, the nose and the mouth. :-D*, a noted computer expert assures us, is a person laughing so hard that he does not notice that a five-legged spider is hanging from his lip.

title: Atlantic City Turned Down
description: Last summer, Gary Sutley, a former Atlantic City detective who had exposed a cocaine ring within the Police Department, won -- with his wife, Donna -- a $3.1 million wrongful termination suit against the city. The judgment included what the couple's lawyer, Clifford L. Van Syoc of Cherry Hill, described as the largest punitive damage award ever made against a municipality: $1.8 million.

title: Philips Electronics Expects Weak Earnings
description: Philips Electronics N.V. does not expect to show an increase in operating income in the second half of this year compared with the corresponding period last year. The giant Dutch company said yesterday that it must accelerate its recovery and would provide details when it released its third-quarter results on Oct. 24.

title: The Giants' Offense Is Fooling No One
description: One play in the first half on Sunday probably symbolized what is wrong with the Giants and their offense. The Eagles blitzed out of a three-man front, sending seven players at quarterback Dave Brown. Coach Dan Reeves warned his players about this strategy last week and the offense practiced against it, albeit sparingly.

title: Consultant Who Left Clinton Team Joins VW
description: FRANKFURT  Dick Morris, the mastermind of Bill Clinton's re-election campaign who resigned after a supermarket tabloid reported his affair with a prostitute, has signed on as a consultant to Volkswagen AG in its public relations battle with General Motors Corp.

title: Hill, Holliday Unit Joins Gallo Roster
description: The E & J Gallo Winery has added Hill, Holliday/Altschiller in New York to its agency roster by naming that shop to create advertising for Hornsby's Pub Draft Cider, a new product being sold in 40 states. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Rite Aid to Buy Thrifty Payless for $1.3 Billion
description: In an acceleration of the wave of consolidation sweeping the drugstore industry, the Rite Aid Corporation, the second-largest druggist in the country, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc., a 1,007-store West Coast chain, for $1.3 billion in stock, plus the assumption of debt.

title: Is Clinton's Encryption Policy Naive or Shrewd?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Railroad Delivery
description: Work is expected to begin soon on the first leg of a 20.5-mile light rail system from Bayonne to Ridgefield, officials said yesterday. Federico F. Pena, the United States Transportation Secretary, will be in Bayonne today to sign a pledge of $604 million in Federal money for the southern half of the line and to hand over a $9.9 million installment. The rail line is scheduled to be completed in 2000.

title: Growth Pace Picks Up In German Economy
description: Gross domestic product in Germany expanded significantly in the third quarter, after rising 1.5 percent in the second quarter, the Economics Ministry said yesterday. The economy is ''back on a growth path,'' the ministry said in a summary of its October monthly report, to be released in full later.

title: City Police May Join Dominican Drug War
description: In an effort to stanch the flow of drugs to New York from the Dominican Republic and other Latin American countries, Police Commissioner Howard Safir plans to meet with the Caribbean island's Government to discuss setting up an office there to help track fugitives, officials said yesterday.

title: Effortless, Modern and, Oh, Yes, Intelligent
description: Were there any doubts that Narciso Rodriguez is fashion's latest ''it boy,'' his first show for Cerruti 1881 since he designed the wedding dress for the ''it girl'' would have swept it away. A crew from the television program ''Entertainment Tonight'' descended on the show, and the designer Azzedine Alaia and Liz Tilberis, the editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, showed up at a Cerruti show for the first time.

title: Eurotunnel Divides Management's Roles
description: Eurotunnel said yesterday that it had split its top management into two teams, one dedicated to increasing car-shuttle traffic and the other to drawing more rail passengers to use the English Channel tunnel. Eurotunnel said its board agreed on Friday that generating cash is central to its future under a debt-revamping accord reached last week.

title: The future, according to the marketer of Stolichnaya, will be filled with flavored vodka.
description: CARILLON IMPORTERS LTD., the marketer of Stolichnaya vodka, is hoping to infuse the phrase six-pack with a meaning beyond those familiar to beer lovers and body-builders.

title: 'I'm Going to Keep My Dignity': Excerpts From Torricelli Interview
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey being vacated by Bill Bradley, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times for about 90 minutes yesterday to discuss issues in his race against Representative Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican. Following are excerpts from the session.

title: Pfizer Posts 22.7% Rise In Earnings In Quarter
description: Pfizer Inc. reported a 22.7 percent rise in third-quarter earnings yesterday and cited surging sales of newer drugs including the antibiotic Zithromax and the antidepressant Zoloft.

title: Gently, With Hints of Motherhood
description: Never in recent memory has there been a season with so many symbols of fertility and fecundity on the Paris runways.

title: Chess
description: One of the two winners of the Donner Memorial Tournament, Julio Granda Zuniga of Peru, competed in impromptu style, while the other, Vasily Ivanchuk of Ukraine, displayed a deep grasp of the cutting edge of opening theory. Each scored 7-4 in the invitational, all-grandmaster event that finished in Amsterdam in early September.

title: Yankees Plan to Baby Strawberry's Hurt Toe
description: Darryl Strawberry injured the big toe in his right foot during the American League Championship Series with the Baltimore Orioles, but X-rays taken yesterday showed no fracture and the Yankees said the toe was merely bruised and should not prevent him from playing in the World Series. But Strawberry, who has had Achilles' tendon problems in his left leg, limped into Yankee Stadium yesterday for treatment and will be on a light workout schedule this week as the Yankees count down to the World Series opener Saturday night.

title: A Wide Open Playing Field for the 'Great Game'
description: After work, the second in command of Bosnia's secret intelligence service stopped by his young mistress's place, an apartment building scarred by wartime shelling and postwar graffiti.

title: Chartwell Re Offers To Buy Archer Group
description: The Chartwell Re Corporation, a reinsurance concern based in Stamford, Conn., offered yesterday to buy Archer Group Holdings P.L.C. for $:35 million, or $55.2 million. Archer Group is one of the largest managing agencies in the Lloyd's of London marketplace.

title: MICROSEMI TO ACQUIRE PRODUCT LINES FROM 2 COMPANIES
description: The Microsemi Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire certain product lines from the National Semiconductor Corporation and SGS Thomson Microelectronics Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Microsemi, based in Santa Ana, Calif., plans to acquire a portion of SGS Thomson's Radio Frequency Semiconductor business, including manufacturing equipment, a plant, 30 employees and the rights to make certain products. Microsemi plans also to acquire a diode assembly product line from National Semiconductor, including manufacturing equipment, inventories and product rights. Microsemi had assembled the product line under contract to National Semiconductor.

title: After Four Angry Years as a Wildcat, Rodrick Rhodes Finds Peace
description: He met the ''God of coaches'' six Midnight Madnesses ago. He was three weeks past 17, looking for a way station en route to Michael Jordan, and his appointment with the University of Kentucky was at precisely 12:01 A.M. He watched them load 20,000 into a gym, roll out a blue carpet, cut all but one strobe light and trot out the superstar to die for: Jamal Mashburn. ''It's over,'' Rodrick Rhodes said, hyperventilating over the telephone to his older brother, Reggie. ''This is the place for me. This the place.''

title: Torricelli States His Case
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, who has been attacked as ''liberal to a T'' in commercials for his Republican opponent, said yesterday that he supported liberal positions on some issues, like abortion, the environment and gun control. But he called himself moderate on other issues, including immigration. He said he favored continued Federal benefits for needy legal immigrants, but would exclude the children of illegal immigrants from public schools. In an extensive interview, Mr. Torricelli detailed the case he hopes to make in the race for Senate against Representative Richard A. Zimmer. $(Page A1.$)

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another actor, LeVAR BURTON, is talking about his daughter's birth, too, but she was born two years ago.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: INSIDE
description: Crew Reviews His First Year

title: Policing Issue: Who Guards The Guards?
description: FEW felt their hearts sink more than Nathaniel and Mary Gaines when Police Officer Francis X. Livoti walked last week in the choking death of Anthony Baez, the man who paid the ultimate price after a football hit a patrol car. When a Bronx judge set Officer Livoti free, pronouncing him not necessarily innocent of wrongdoing but also not guilty of homicide, the Gaineses could not help asking what now lay ahead for them.

title: Kramer Out for Season
description: Against his wishes, ERIK KRAMER's season has been declared over by the Chicago Bears. The quarterback, sidelined the last three games by two herniated disks in his neck, was placed on injured reserve yesterday.

title: CAMECO ADDS URANIUM HOLDINGS OF MAGNOX ELECTRIC
description: The Cameco Corporation, a Canadian mining concern, agreed yesterday to buy Magnox Electric P.L.C.'s uranium holdings in North America for $105 million. The acquisition includes all the outstanding shares of Power Resources Inc., a United States uranium mining company, and Central Electricity Generating Board Exploration Ltd., a company involved primarily in Canadian uranium exploration. The deal adds more than one million pounds of enriched uranium to Cameco's annual production.

title: As Zoning Debate Rages, Giant Stores Settle In
description: New York City is engaged in a great civics debate about whether to revise its zoning rules to encourage the development of big-box superstores like those in the suburbs. The stakes, both sides say, involve everything from the character of neighborhoods to the city's ability to set its own economic agenda.

title: Coast Guard Fails to Find Boat in Distress
description: The Coast Guard is searching for 16 people missing since Sunday, when they reported by radio that their 65-foot sailboat was sinking in the Atlantic off the Florida coast and that the crew and passengers were boarding the boat's life raft.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday, about the Rudolf Koppitz photography exhibition at the Houk Friedman Gallery, 851 Madison Avenue, near 70th Street, referred incorrectly to an American Pictorialist photographer. He is Clarence White, not Clarence Smith.

title: Powerful Bull Market Sends Dow To Its First Closing Above 6,000
description: Continuing one of the most powerful market advances in history, the Dow Jones industrial average rose past 6,000 yesterday, closing up 40.62 points at 6,010.

title: Some junk bond issues are outperforming many stocks.
description: EVEN with the horde of low-rated companies rushing to sell debt, some junk bond issues may offer investors better value and more promising returns than stocks, according to some Wall Street professionals who follow the securities.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times on Sept. 24 about advances in modem technology referred incorrectly to the status of Shannon's Law, which defines the theoretical maximum speed at which data can be transmitted over a noisy channel without errors. (The law mathematically described a limit, for the conventional public telephone network. of about 35,000 bits per second.) New modems are expected to exceed that limit by, among other tactics, exploiting the increased use of digital circuits by telephone companies and Internet service providers. They will not circumvent Shannon's Law.

title: Henri Nannen, Editor, 82, Hurt In Hitler Hoax
description: Henri Nannen, the founder and longtime publisher of the German magazine Stern, whose distinguished career was tarnished in a hoax over Hitler's ''lost diaries,'' died on Sunday in Hamburg, Germany. He was 82.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Wednesday and Thursday about the debate between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp misspelled the name of the theater in St. Petersburg, Fla., where the debate took place. It is the Mahaffey, not Mahaffrey.

title: Skip Away Status Is Unclear
description: Sonny Hine remained in St. Joseph's Hospital in Lexington, Ky., yesterday while his doctors searched for a kidney stone. His horse, Skip Away, did some galloping, but delayed the workout that might have thrust him into the Breeders' Cup against Cigar.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: Austria's Rightist Vote: No to Europe
description: Dramatic electoral successes on Sunday by Austria's anti-European far right placed governments on notice that austerity in the name of the continent's unity presents perilous risks at home. The results reflected growing fear among Europeans that the continent's moves toward economic and political union will erode their social well-being.

title: Fighters in Afghan Mountains Live for Next Battle
description: When a band of Afghan fighters rose before dawn today at a smoky inn in this village high in the Hindu Kush mountains, the prospect before them was much the same as it has been since the war here began with a Communist coup nearly two decades ago.

title: Accounts
description: Classic Sports Network, New York, to McCabe & Co., New York, to handle advertising for the cable television network, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Millicent Selsam, 84; Her Science Booklets Told Children Why
description: Millicent Ellis Selsam, an author who filled bookshelf upon bookshelf with primers seeking to still the nagging why's with which children tax their parents' patience and knowledge, died on Saturday at Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. She was 84 and lived in Manhattan and Fire Island, L.I.

title: Zut! British Infiltrate French Fashion
description: In what some here are bemoaning as a blow to French cultural pride, it was announced today that creative control of two of Paris's venerable couture houses, Christian Dior and Givenchy, will now be in the hands of British designers.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: It's a Tank! It's a Plane! (Actually, It's a Bus)
description: If it works for the Air Force and the Army, will it work for city buses?

title: For Clinton and Dole, A Nobel-Level Query
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Bacteria and Cheese

title: Mimi C. Thompson, 69, New York Volunteer and Philanthropist
description: Mimi Coleman Thompson, an officer and past board chairwoman of Planned Parenthood of New York City, who also had long associations with Hofstra University and New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died on Wednesday at her home in Old Brookville, L.I. She was 69.

title: Army And Navy Rolling Along
description: Army and Navy, lost souls amid the quasi-professionalism of Division I-A football in recent seasons, have found ways to win. Together the two service academies have captured 9 of 10 games this season, the most significant victory being Navy's over Air Force last Saturday, 20-17.

title: L'eggs Ends Ties With Cordiant Unit
description: The L'eggs Products unit of the Sara Lee Corporation in Winston-Salem, N.C., has unexpectedly ended a 25-year relationship with Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York by naming the DDB Needham Chicago unit of Omnicom Group as agency of record for creative and media planning assignments on its L'eggs hosiery lines.

title: Science and Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Players Having an Impact on Jets
description: Impact players make impact plays. And the Jets have run out of both. Until their injured players return, an 0-7 record can get worse -- especially with the Bills coming up Sunday at Giants Stadium.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: USAir in Negotiations for New Aircraft Orders
description: USAir Group Inc. is in talks with the world's three biggest makers of commercial aircraft to buy new planes, the company said today.

title: Charlotte Observer Did Candidate No Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: Figuring Out How to Feel Like a Man With Mamet
description: ''I've been waiting 15 years to do this play,'' said David Rasche, who is starring in the revival of David Mamet's ''Edmond'' at the Atlantic Theater Company. In the last few weeks, Mr. Rasche has won high praise from critics for his enactment of the title role as Mr. Mamet's beleaguered Everyman, who leaves his wife, is cast into the heart of darkness (read Times Square) and drawn further and further into its squalid reaches until he finally kills someone. At the play's end, Edmond finds redemption in prison in a homosexual love affair.

title: Stadium Delay for Team
description: Residents of Newark will get a chance tonight to express their views about a proposed $22 million baseball stadium in the city's Ironbound section. But there will be no minor league baseball in Newark until at least 1998: officials of the Atlantic League of Professional Baseball decided on Friday to call off their planned 1997 inaugural season. The reason, said Rick Cerone, owner of the Newark Bears, is that too many host cities do not yet have stadiums -- not just Newark, where the proposed site may be contaminated and some neighbors are opposed to the project -- but also Atlantic City, Bethlehem, Pa., and Islip, L.I.

title: 2 Australian Banks In $2.1 Billion Merger
description: St. George Bank Ltd. and Advance Bank of Australia Ltd. said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a transaction worth $2.65 billion (Australian), or $2.1 billion (United States). The banks said St George would offer the equivalent of $7.30 (Australian), or $5.77, for each Advance share, representing a 20 percent premium over the average Advance Bank share price of the previous five trading days.

title: Clinton Campaign Finds Harmony After Swift Exit by Morris
description: When James Carville and Paul Begala, the Clinton campaign consultants of 1992, turned up recently to help the President prepare for his first debate, it looked like the moment that many had predicted: the late-campaign return of the populist team to replace the departed Dick Morris.

title: Second Time Is the Charm
description: Anthony DeBenedictis of Seton Hall, who fell while competing on the Van Cortlandt Park cross-country course last year and failed to finish, ran away from the field of 90 yesterday to win the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Conference championships. DeBenedictis ran the five miles in 25 minutes 37.2 seconds and registered a 205-yard victory over Tom Kloos of Columbia.

title: New Fighting in Northern Iraq Causes a Jump in Oil Prices
description: Crude oil prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as renewed fighting between Kurdish factions in northern Iraq sparked concern that a broader military conflict could threaten Persian Gulf exports.

title: People
description: Don Maurer, senior vice president and account group head at McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C., was promoted to president, a new post.

title: The New Times Square: Magic That Surprised the Magicians
description: With a huge new Disney store on 42d Street near Seventh Avenue, the New Victory Theater entering its second season of children's productions in a magnificently restored historic theater, and retail stores and restaurants opening right and left, 42d Street and Times Square are turning into one of the hottest entertainment and shopping zones of any downtown in the United States. But what is most remarkable about this area is that it bears no resemblance at all to the scenarios laid out by planners, civic activists and politicians for most of the last two decades.

title: Earth's Dominant Life Form Is Also Its Smallest: the Microbe
description: DEEP in the heart of the Amazon jungle is a famous gold field known as Serra Pelada that lies far from the usual regions where the rare metal is mined. Discovered in the early 1980's, the find prompted many thousands of poor Brazilians to rush into the wilderness and, often digging by hand or with crude tools, to extract more than 100 tons of the precious metal. The episode is often referred to as history's biggest gold rush.

title: Moscow Sends Homeless To Faraway Hometowns
description: Behind the iron gate, in a squat red-brick building with barred windows, Viktor Ryazanov sits imprisoned in Social Rehabilitation Center No. 2.

title: Nextel Pondering 4 Agencies
description: Nextel Communications, a wireless communications company in McLean, Va., is seeking an agency to become the first shop to handle its account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: A Drug and Sports Scandal Swirls Near Argentine Chief
description: When his re-election campaign was slipping last year, President Carlos Saul Menem called on his good friend, the soccer star Diego Maradona, for an endorsement.

title: North Carolina Incumbent Finds Recipe for Success
description: He is a Democratic Governor from the South. Sensing shifts in the electorate, particularly after Republicans took control of the House in 1994, he has moved purposefully to the right. He now embraces tax cuts, time limits for welfare recipients and more prison time for violent felons, along with increased spending on education. He has alienated a few liberals, but they have nowhere else to go. And the polls show he is cruising toward re-election on Nov. 5.

title: Two Approaches to Repairing Cities
description: When Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp skirmished during last week's debate, Mr. Kemp accused the Democrats of not doing enough to improve the plight of American cities. Mr. Gore said the Democrats had done plenty.

title: When Justice Is Hard to Find
description: The acquittal last week of South Africa's apartheid-era Defense Minister, Magnus Malan, and 15 others for a death squad massacre in 1987 shocked South Africans who had presumed guilt. But in one sense the outcome was not surprising. New democracies everywhere have struggled in the search for justice for the crimes of past regimes.

title: So Far, States Aren't Rewriting the Book on Welfare Plans
description: State welfare plans filed with the Federal Government in the last seven weeks suggest that gentle breezes, rather than the winds of revolutionary change, are sweeping through the nation's welfare offices.

title: Accord Is Reached To Recall Pesticide Devastating Hawk
description: AN agreement between an international chemical company and environmentalists may help reduce poisoning that has killed thousands of hawks on the pampas of Argentina in recent years.

title: Houston Mayoral Candidate Wins a $5.5 Million Libel Verdict
description: After arguing that a television news report on the verge of an election five years ago destroyed his chances to become Houston's Mayor, a Texas politician won a $5.5 million libel verdict today.

title: Discovery On Cancer Of Prostate
description: FIFTY-FIVE years ago, a Chicago surgeon named Dr. Charles Huggins discovered that prostate cancer cells needed testosterone to grow. He showed that removing or blocking the action of this male sex hormone, or androgen, could cause prostate cancers to shrink and suppress their ability to spread. The finding brought him the Nobel Prize and made anti-testosterone therapy the standard treatment for advanced prostate cancer ever since.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: POMEROY COMPUTER RESOURCES INC., Hebron, Ky., which sells and provides services for desktop computers, acquired Communication Technology Inc. of Hickory, N.C., a computer network integration company, for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: Police Actions Are Questioned As Fight Leaves Officer Dead
description: An off-duty police officer who was fatally shot on a Brooklyn street Sunday night may have been conducting an unauthorized hunt for someone who had mugged his friend, officials said yesterday. Two of his fellow officers were suspended for their role in the incident and the subsequent investigation.

title: Surgery Set for Brown
description: Indiana Pacers Coach LARRY BROWN will have surgery for a double hernia today and will miss the team's trip to Europe for two preseason games. Brown will also undergo arthroscopic knee surgery, DAVID BENNER, a Pacers spokesman, said yesterday before Indiana's exhibition game against the Washington Bullets.

title: Study in Contrasts: Chanel, Givenchy
description: The Chanel show, which closed the Paris collections today, was a moving experience -- for the models, at least. In Karl Lagerfeld's funny and surreal show, a moving walkway served up the models to the audience without making them take a step. It was a little like standing next to a conveyor belt at an airport, as fashion's insiders will next week as they stream to New York for the American shows, which begin on Oct. 26.

title: Messier Coaxes Victory Out of His Teammates
description: Mark Messier has guaranteed victories in the past -- and delivered. He has called team meetings between periods -- and his teammates have responded.

title: Intel's Profits Rise Greater Than Forecasts
description: The Intel Corporation, buoyed by strong demand from personal computer manufacturers for its microprocessor chips, today reported third-quarter earnings that greatly exceeded the already sanguine expectations of Wall Street.

title: Corrections
description: A brief music review yesterday misidentified the composer of ''Dances of Galanta,'' on the current program of the New York Philharmonic. He was Zoltan Kodaly, not Leos Janacek.

title: Motorola Plans New Global Satellite System
description: Motorola Inc. plans to build a $6.1 billion satellite network during the next four years that can send voice, video and data to companies anywhere in the world.

title: Politics in the Movies? It's Like the Real Thing
description: As an unexciting Presidential campaign hobbles to the finish line, television entertainment grabs the fail-safe antidote: Hollywood. AMC's ''D.C. Follies'' looks at politicians through the prism of popular movies, including the scene in ''The Last Hurrah'' when Spencer Tracy reveals what is the greatest spectator sport in the United States. ''It's politics,'' he says, mercifully neglecting to add ''stupid.''

title: In Search of the Perfect Steak
description: A THOUSAND miles from the cattle ranches of the West, New York still reigns as the steakhouse capital of the country, a title it has held since the last half of the last century, when refrigerated railroad cars bearing beef began rumbling east from Chicago.

title: Bombardier Test Flight
description: Bombardier Inc. said today that its new long-range, global express business jet completed a successful test flight on Sunday. The $34 million aircraft can fly about 7,500 miles. The Canadian transportation equipment maker said deliveries are scheduled to begin in the fourth quarter of 1997.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Conrail to Merge With CSX,In Biggest Rail Deal Yet

title: Bond Prices Turn Mixed After Rally
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday, as traders consolidated their gains after the recent rally and the market awaited today's data on consumer prices.

title: Court Upholds Ouster of Judge for Misconduct
description: New York State's highest court today upheld the dismissal of a Nassau County Criminal Court judge accused of waging a campaign to discredit a lawyer.

title: Increase in Taxi Leasing Rates Would Cut Drivers' Profits
description: More than six months after they were authorized to charge riders higher fares, thousands of independent taxi drivers could see some of that money disappear, under a new plan that would force them to pay more to operate their cars.

title: Citibank Plans Global Campaign
description: The Citibank subsidiary of Citicorp has begun seeking an agency to create what it described as the first Citibank worldwide brand campaign. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at more than $100 million.

title: Seven Skeletons, and a Suburb in Shock
description: Fox Hollow Farm is a million-dollar estate in this exclusive Indianapolis bedroom community, a peaceful place where the sun sets over rolling green hills.

title: Group to Study On-Line Users
description: NFO Research Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it had formed a panel of more than 50,000 households to provide data about consumers who use interactive and on-line media and to conduct interactive market research.

title: Pregnant Immigrants Wait Out Policy Storm
description: The pregnant young women began to vanish from community health clinics in East Los Angeles several weeks ago, scattered by Gov. Pete Wilson's announcement that California would soon cut off prenatal care to illegal immigrants under the new Federal welfare law.

title: To Thine Own Self Be True
description: At 73, Bob Dole is a little long in the tooth to play Hamlet.

title: Sex Shops Greet Law With Wink, Nod and Lawsuit
description: The city law intended to restrict X-rated businesses takes effect in just over a week, but most of New York's 180 adult-entertainment establishments are making no plans to move or close.

title: Presidential Debate
description: With the second campaign debate scheduled for 9 P.M. Eastern time tonight, President Clinton yesterday brushed aside Bob Dole's attacks on his ethics. Page A15.

title: A Shaman's Tools: Ma Huang And Bloodroot Paste
description: WHEN I asked Dr. Andrew Weil what to do for hay fever, the plant-loving shaman with the Harvard medical degree suggested eating stinging nettles instead of taking antihistamines, which he said only suppress symptoms and can be toxic.

title: Foes of Ballot Proposal to Ease Council-Term-Limits Law Begin TV Campaign
description: Just three weeks before Election Day, a group largely financed by the cosmetics heir Ronald S. Lauder began an extensive television campaign yesterday to defeat a referendum the City Council placed on the Nov. 5 ballot to soften the city's existing term limits law.

title: Phils Interview Dent
description: BUCKY DENT, bench coach of the Texas Rangers, was in Philadelphia yesterday to be interviewed for the job of Phillies manager.

title: As Dole Weighs Tougher Image, Poll Finds He Already Has One
description: Bob Dole and his advisers have agonized publicly over how hard to attack President Clinton in their second and final debate tonight, but a majority of Americans have already concluded that Mr. Dole is more combative than Mr. Clinton and is spending more time attacking than explaining what he would do as President, according to the most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Born in Crisis, Conrail Defies Skeptics With Turnaround
description: Since Congress created Conrail in 1973 to try to salvage something out of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad and five other dying railroads, there have been numerous instances when it was close to being broken up and sold. Yet the railroad always managed to snatch another chance to demonstrate that it could become viable.

title: On the Road to Acclaim, a Chef Learns Lessons in Humility
description: THE people who work in Thomas Keller's kitchen here do not wear baseball caps backward -- or forward. There are no scraps of food on the floor. In fact, for a kitchen that is in the middle of preparing dinner, there is an eerie quiet.

title: Considering Plans to Blitz G.O.P. Territory
description: Seeking to make the most of President Clinton's steady lead in the polls, his aides say they are weighing how much Mr. Clinton should push beyond the traditional battleground states in the crucial last weeks of the campaign and into terrain long considered inhospitable to Democrats.

title: Trader to Be Penalized for Fraud
description: Kent A. Ahrens, a securities trader who made unauthorized bets against the stock market that resulted in losses of $137.6 million for a group of college endowment funds, has agreed to plead guilty to one count of fraud. He has also agreed to pay $182,000 to settle Federal securities civil actions, the Government said yesterday.

title: Mexico Confronts Rebels With Limited Crackdown
description: After guerrillas of the Popular Revolutionary Army began armed attacks in August, President Ernesto Zedillo pledged to fight them ''with all the force of the state.'' But he also recognized that he would be playing into their hands if the crackdown extended to legitimate opposition groups.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Yankees, Yankees, Yankees
description: THERE's no getting away from them, not even during a five-day interval without games. Nothing else matters. Nothing else happens. Until the World Series commences on Saturday, against an opponent to be named later, it's still Yankees, Yankees, Yankees, Yankees, Yankees.

title: Action by Rhode Island
description: Most of the 31 Rhode Island football players suspended following an attack on a fraternity house will be back on the field next week, a school spokesman said.

title: Kashmir Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Scythian Tomb Bares Hunter-Plunderers' Homey Side
description: A spectacular Scythian tomb, housing the remains of a prince and his gold and silver possessions, has been unearthed in a field 90 miles from here. Its discoverers say the find may change the way history regards one of the world's most celebrated nomadic cultures.

title: Pierre Franey, Whose Lifelong Love of Food Led to Career as Chef and Author, Dies at 75
description: Pierre Franey, who rose from pot scrubber in a Paris bistro to executive chef of the legendary Pavillon restaurant and later to a career as a New York Times food columnist and cookbook author, died yesterday in Southampton, England. He was 75 years old.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Starks Has 29 As Knicks Win
description: John Starks has apparently adjusted to his sixth-man role. He scored 29 points off the bench to lead the Knicks to their first preseason victory, a 99-87 triumph over the Houston Rockets, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Tensions Over Racism and Anti-Semitism Have Surfaced in Georgia House Campaign
description: Here in the suburbs of Atlanta, where blacks and Jews once fought side-by-side for civil rights, racial and religious tensions have come to dominate the Congressional campaign between Representative Cynthia A. McKinney, a black Democratic incumbent, and John Mitnick, her white, Jewish Republican challenger.

title: Perhaps Parker's Past Ended Just After Midnight
description: Ray Haskins was determined to do midnight madness justice this time: bells, whistles, balloons. Even artificial fog.

title: Sign of a Last-Gasp Empire: British Are the Coolies
description: His fingernails black with oil and his face weathered by work and dust, Bratt Kiddie scoured a plate of fried rice in a roadside eatery here in the village of Pui O. Behind him, over the forested hills of Lantau Island, is where the territory's new airport is being built at breakneck speed by tens of thousands of laborers.

title: Focusing on Minorities in Special Education
description: The University of Virginia will lead a nationwide effort to examine why blacks and other minorities are overrepresented in special education classes.

title: Real Estate
description: In what would be one of the largest corporate developments in Seattle in years, a leading biopharmaceutical company is planning a headquarters and research campus along the waterfront north of downtown.

title: The Year of Spending Dangerously
description: Why would a wealthy Indonesian family contribute huge sums of money to the Democratic National Committee? Presumably it wants access and influence, just like scores of businesses and rich individuals in the United States who lavish comparable contributions on the national parties as a way of helping either President Clinton or Bob Dole. Clearly the money from the Riady family and its associates has to be examined to see if it violated the Federal ban on political donations by foreigners and foreign businesses. It must also be determined whether any favors have been promised or carried out in return.

title: Personal Health
description: JENNIFER MONAGHAN of Brooklyn had been plagued with an arthritic hip that got progressively more painful for 20 years. By her late 50's, walking a few blocks with heavy groceries or walking empty-handed for a half mile meant crippling pain the next day.

title: French Papers Shut by Strike Protesting End Of Tax Break
description: Strikers shut down national dailies like Le Figaro and France-Soir, provincial newspapers and the news agency Agence France-Presse today to protest a French Government deficit-cutting plan that will phase out special tax breaks for members of about 100 professions, including journalists.

title: Refrain: Why Won't Clinton Open Medical File?
description: To the Editor:

title: Breaking From the Gate, Slowly
description: In Texas, horses have been a means of settlement and conquest, of livelihood and sport. Not until 1987, however, did horsemen overcome the state's Baptist preachers and persuade the Legislature to legalize betting on horse races.

title: No Headline
description: ''I could never have dreamed of finding something like this. In our sphere of research, this kind of find is like climbing Parnassus.''

title: Recasting a Workout for the Masses
description: FOR 40 years until his death in 1967, Joseph Pilates, a bombastic, cigar-chomping former German acrobat, taught a group of grateful professional dancers his own quirky conditioning and rehabilitation method at a tiny Manhattan studio. Little did he dream that 30 years later, fitness enthusiasts would clamor for the Pilates workout as the ticket to a long, lean dancer's physique.

title: UNITED COMPANIES AGREES TO BUY EMPIRE FUNDING
description: The United Companies Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Empire Funding Corporation for about $89 million in stock. United, an insurance and lending company based in Baton Rouge, La., said Empire Funding's direct relationship with dealers complements its retail operations. Empire originated about $256 million in loans for the 12 months that ended on Sept. 30. Under the deal, Empire Funding will receive about 2.6 million shares of United Companies, or about an 8 percent stake in the company. Shares of United slipped 62.5 cents a share, to $33.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Accounts
description: * Busy Body Fitness Warehouse, Dallas, to Kalis & Savage Advertising, Pacific Palisades, Calif., to handle its account, which had been handled in-house and by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: A Bland Presentation for Verdi's Tortured Spirits
description: The Metropolitan Opera gave its ''Rigoletto'' production a rest last season, and on Monday evening the Verdi favorite returned to the company's repertory. The performance was competent but uneventful and emotionally detached, as too many performances at the Met are these days. Not that ''Rigoletto'' is the only work affected by this workaday blandness, but where most of the company's productions have good nights and bad, this unobjectionably traditional staging by Otto Schenk has been unable to create sparks since it was introduced in 1989.

title: SFX BROADCASTING TO ACQUIRE 9 RADIO STATIONS
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Secret Communications L.P. for $300 million, adding nine radio stations in three new markets. Under the deal, SFX will get WDVE-FM, WXDX-FM, WDSY-FM and WJJJ-FM, all in Pittsburgh, two of which are under contract to be acquired by Secret. The company will also get WLTF-FM and WTAM-AM in Cleveland and WFBQ-FM, WRZX-FM and WNDE-AM in Indianapolis. New York-based SFX said it would rank No. 1 in terms of revenue in Pittsburgh, the 19th-largest radio market, and Indianapolis, the 36th-biggest market. The company would rank No. 2 in Cleveland, the 22d-largest market. Class A shares of SFX fell $2.125, to $45.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JACK F. CHRYSLER 3d may be a great-grandson of Walter P. Chrysler, the founder of the Chrysler Corporation, but he does not think there is anything remarkable about the fact that he has just taken a marketing job with another automotive company: Rolls-Royce and Bentley Motor Cars.

title: Memories That Transcend Games
description: The last time Wade Boggs played in a World Series, the decisive game ended with him sitting in the dugout at Shea Stadium with his head in his lap and tears pouring down his ruddy face after the Mets squashed the Red Sox.

title: Opening Act That Draws A Main Event Following
description: Though the Notwist were only the opening act on a four-band bill, most of the audience on Monday night at Tramps was there only to see them. It's a great accomplishment for a Bavarian band that has released three albums in Germany and only a five-song mini-album in America (on the independent label Zero Hour). One reason for the Notwist's underground popularity is that it is among a growing number of promising bands in Germany (others are Blumfeld and Tocotronic) who are intelligently dismantling rock conventions and structures to come up with an original sound endowed with its own unwieldy beauty.

title: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Needs More Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Bus Stop Too Close to Home
description: When Bernard Uleano bought his house on Teaneck Road 23 years ago, he said, he had no idea a public right of way extended 10 feet into his front yard. So he was shocked when he came home one day and found a New Jersey Transit bus stop sign in the corner of his finely manicured lawn. Now he must put up with buses blocking his driveway, passengers waiting for the buses damaging his lawn and the annoyance and health hazards of diesel fumes. Mr. Uleano, 64, a retired New York City sanitation worker, said the experience taught him that ''the government, at any level, can do whatever the heck they want.''

title: Giuliani and Murdoch
description: To the Editor:

title: Downsizing the Downsizing Crisis
description: Whatever happened to downsizing? Just months ago, tales of huge layoffs dominated the media, and with the approaching Presidential election came a litter of mostly negative solutions: corporation bashing, immigration bashing, free-trade bashing.

title: Judge Denies Formal Move For Deaf Jury
description: The defendant in the rape trial is deaf. So is his accuser. And so are most of the character witnesses.

title: Natural Gas Up on Speculation A Gulf Storm Will Limit Output
description: Natural gas prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on speculation that a storm moving through the Caribbean could disrupt production in the Gulf of Mexico at a time of cooler temperatures than normal for this season.

title: After an underdog agency gets the Acura account, heads turn on Madison Avenue.
description: The shock waves from the stunning conclusion to the review of the Acura account, with billings estimated at $125 million, continue to reverberate along Madison Avenue.

title: On Homeless, Moscow Takes Cue From West
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Moving Troops To Peacekeeping Duty From Ex-Soviet Site : NATO Base In Hungary Key Center For Bosnia
description: NATO, U.S. and Hungarian officials are quietly celebrating the success of the Western alliance's first operating military base on former Warsaw Pact territory: a former Soviet airfield in southwestern Hungary that has become the primary staging post for U.S. ground forces moving into nearby Bosnia.

title: Study Says Curriculum Lacks Focus In 2 Areas
description: An international comparison of math and science education finds that curriculum in the United States is ''a mile wide and an inch deep,'' according to a study released today by the Department of Education and the International Institute on Education.

title: NEC Opposes Dumping Inquiry
description: The NEC Corporation asked a Federal court today to suspend a Commerce Department investigation of complaints that the company had dumped supercomputers, contending that the department inquiry was prejudiced.

title: Store Arson Is Admitted
description: The former operator of a hardware store in West Orange pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to setting a fire in 1993 that destroyed the store and killed dozens of animals in a neighboring pet shop. John Notte was about to be evicted from the store by relatives who owned the building when he set the fire, said Aidan P. O'Connor, an assistant United States attorney. According to West Orange animal control officials, iguanas, hamsters, parakeets and rabbits burned in the blaze.

title: A Proud Bronx Basks In Yankees' Radiance
description: When she walks her dog, Karmelia Wilmot can see inside Yankee Stadium. On Saturday, baseball fans around the country will be focused on the same spot, in a sliver of the Bronx she calls home. For Bronx residents, the Yankees' success has had a particular resonance, in some ways typifying the borough's own resurgence after years as a dismal urban metaphor. For many, pride has overcome bittersweet feelings about a team that may see its future elsewhere.

title: U.S. Appeals Panel Delays Rules Allowing Full Phone Competition
description: In a major setback for the Government, a Federal court suspended new rules yesterday that govern competition in the local telephone business.

title: Blank on Bosnia
description: Normally when a foreign-policy issue involves 20,000 U.S. troops, a $4 billion price tag and an open-ended mission it has all the makings of a great election-year debate. But so far the decision on whether to maintain U.S. troops in Bosnia after the Dec. 20 date set by President Clinton for their withdrawal has barely registered in the campaign.

title: An Anniversary Tribute To the Million Man March
description: Beating the clock to commemorate the Million Man March on its first anniversary, Spike Lee taps into the cooperative spirit that galvanized the event. Acted by a strong ensemble cast and independently financed by a group of African-American investors (including Danny Glover, Wesley Snipes, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. and Mr. Lee), ''Get on the Bus'' shows off the shared commitment and can-do energy that suit its purpose.

title: Singer, Banned After Cuba Show, Wins $2.7 Million Verdict
description: A jury has awarded $2.7 million to a Brazilian singer who said her career was destroyed after she was prevented from performing at a cultural festival in 1989 because she had been branded a Castro sympathizer.

title: Berkshire Will Acquire Flightsafety
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Flightsafety International Inc., the leading pilot training company, for about $1.5 billion in cash and stock.

title: G.M.'s Earnings Nearly Doubled In 3d Quarter
description: The General Motors Corporation reported strong third-quarter profits today, as very low taxes, higher sales and cost controls more than offset a shrinking North American market share.

title: On the Question of Pardons, Dole Has Taken Both Sides
description: At the Presidential debate nine days ago, Bob Dole told President Clinton that he should have said ''no comment'' when asked whether he would pardon people who could face charges in the Whitewater investigation.

title: Food Notes
description: D'Agostino's New Venture

title: Don't Quote Kemp
description: To the Editor:

title: Kasparov Beaten in Israel, by Russians
description: If he hadn't been so angry, Garry Kasparov might have been proud of the lumps he took from the 25 Israelis he took on in a simultaneous chess exhibition this evening.

title: Bizet's 'Carmen': No Pain, No Gain? Or Not?
description: Pushing yourself beyond your capabilities may get results in sports. But it is an inevitably risky course for a singer. Opera isn't the Olympics and burnout can be irreversible. The New York City Opera's production of Bizet's ''Carmen,'' which returned to the company on Friday night, offered textbook examples of wise and unwise singing in this regard.

title: Lopez Adds Power Behind the Plate
description: Javier Lopez will be the Atlanta catcher when Greg Maddux pitches Game 6 of the National League Championship Series on Wednesday night, even though Eddie Perez was Maddux's ''personal catcher'' for the last part of the season.

title: 2 in Race for Senate Have Millions Left to Spend for Ads
description: New Jersey's two Senate candidates reported yesterday that they each have more than $4.4 million on hand for the final three weeks of what could be the most expensive Senate race in the country. Much of that money is expected to be spent on advertising that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman suggested earlier in the day was too negative and ineffective.

title: Skip Away Will Not Enter Breeders' Cup
description: The potentially great return match between Cigar and Skip Away went galloping into the sunset yesterday when the telephone rang in the hotel suite of Carolyn Hine, who owns Skip Away. She noticed the time: 6:20 in the morning.

title: U.S. to Revise Its Estimate Of Layoffs
description: Acknowledging a flaw in a key statistic in the debate over economic insecurity, the Labor Department said today that it would revise upward its tabulation of the number of layoffs in the mid-1990's after an academic researcher found a problem with the Government's figures.

title: Dreams of Sundance In the Hamptons
description: In the compressed life span of film festivals, the Hamptons International Film Festival, now in its fourth year, is entering its adolescence. That in itself is a victory of sorts.

title: Don't Ask, 'Where's the Curry Powder?'
description: Whenever I mention a dish with curry in the name, I receive a phone call or two asking where the curry powder is.

title: Seagram Promotes A Gin on Radio
description: Aggressive efforts by the Seagram Company to promote distilled spirits outside of media like print and outdoor advertising have been extended into radio.

title: Afghan Foes Drive Back Islamic Force Near Kabul
description: Less than three weeks after storming into the capital and proclaiming a strict Islamic Government for Afghanistan, the forces of the Taliban religious movement have suffered a series of sharp military setbacks that have raised doubts about their ability to hang onto their gains.

title: A C-Span for New York
description: Having failed to get Time Warner's cable systems to carry Fox's new 24-hour news station, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tried to put the network on a city-owned channel, only to be rebuffed by a Federal judge. His misguided effort raised an important question: What role should New York's public channels play in its political and civic life?

title: Dynamic Devils Duo: Brylin and Brodeur
description: The Devils mixed their new look at center with an old formula -- solid goaltending -- to stop one of the National Hockey League's most explosive teams tonight.

title: Rangers Know the Score vs. Penguins
description: The Rangers did not have much time to enjoy their first victory of the season. They had one beautiful fall day, to be exact.

title: Despite Strong Earnings Reports, Stocks Are Only Mixed
description: Stocks closed mixed after touching records yesterday, as investors began to question whether share prices already reflected a rosy outlook for profits.

title: New Police Chief in Camden
description: A new police chief was named in Camden yesterday, and he pledged to focus on alleviating the beleaguered city's drug problem and increase the visibility of the police. ''You will see a more active Police Department,'' The Associated Press quoted the new chief, William J. Hill, as saying. The appointment is provisional, pending a civil service exam.

title: JACOR COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE 4 IOWA RADIO STATIONS
description: Jacor Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four Iowa radio stations from Palmer Broadcasting L.P. for $52.5 million in cash. Cincinnati-based Jacor said it would purchase WHO-AM and KLYF-FM in Des Moines and WMT-AM and WMT-FM in Cedar Rapids. Shares of Jacor rose 50 cents a share, to $35.75, in trading on the Nasdaq.

title: Netscape Taking On Lotus With New Corporate System
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation announced a strategy yesterday of sidestepping the Microsoft's Corporation's assault on the Internet browser software market and competing directly against the I.B.M. Corporation's Lotus unit in the growing market for what is known as groupware.

title: UNITED NEWS AND MEDIA TO BUY BLENHEIM
description: United News and Media P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire the Blenheim Group, which organizes exhibitions, for 500 pence a share, a total of $:592.5 million, or $935.5 million. Last June, Blenheim announced it was in talks about a possible bid. People familiar with the talks said Reed Elsevier P.L.C. had offered 480 pence a share. United said it had received acceptances for 51 percent of the company. The Dutch publisher VNU, which last week built up a 15 percent stake in Blenheim, said it would sell its stake.

title: The Chancellor 'Survives' Year One
description: When he was named New York City's Schools Chancellor a year ago, Rudy Crew asked some students for tips on redesigning the system. Dr. Crew stipulated that mere ''tinkering with the edges'' was out of the question, and that only a revolution would do. But the Chancellor's freshman year brought some harsh lessons.

title: There's a New Leader of the Pack: A Healthy Beebe Is Catching On
description: If it was not a leg injury, it was a collarbone. If it was not a collarbone, it was a hamstring. Sure, Don Beebe made plenty of big plays for the Buffalo Bills in six seasons, but there always seemed to be an injury, whether big or small, to prevent him from making even more.

title: Looking Back on Years of Fear and Upheaval in China
description: It must be difficult to build a program that can accommodate Bright Sheng's ''H'un (Lacerations).'' Subtitled ''In Memoriam 1966-76,'' the 20-minute piece is a wrenchingly direct orchestral evocation of the Chinese Cultural Revolution and its horrors, a time the 40-year-old composer lived through before he moved to the United States.

title: Voter Registration Growing
description: New Jersey is making headway signing up voters under the so-called motor-voter law, a voting-rights group said yesterday.

title: SHARES OF U.S. ROBOTICS RISE ON RUMORS OF NEW MODEM
description: Shares of the U.S. Robotics Corporation rose almost 13 percent yesterday on rumors that the company would introduce a much faster modem, industry watchers said. In a brief announcement, the company, based in Skokie, Ill., said it would display ''new technologies'' today in New York. Investors and analysts immediately concluded the company would introduce its high-speed modem that runs at 56 kilobits a second. Currently, modems run at the slower speeds of 14.4 kbps, 28.8 kbps and 33.6 kbps. U.S. Robotics said the conference would include the presence of ''other leading manufacturers and Internet service providers.'' Shares of U.S. Robotics rose $8.875, to $78 on the Nasdaq.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Oct. 7 about a new union contract at The Jersey Journal misstated the extent of newspaper unionization in the state. While The Journal is the last paper with unionized editors and reporters, employees in various other departments are represented by unions at The Newark Star-Ledger, The Courier-Post of Cherry Hill and The Trenton Times, according to the New Jersey Press Association.

title: Dole Accuses Clinton of Devaluing Presidency
description: Bob Dole today portrayed President Clinton's Administration as an ethical failure, cataloguing a list of lapses under his watch and arguing that Mr. Clinton had in four years diminished the office of the Presidency.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Bob Dole's mounting attack on President Clinton's ethics referred incorrectly in some editions to a political contribution linked to the Lippo Group in Indonesia, which was returned by the Democratic National Committee. It was $250,000, not $25,000.

title: Webb Is Top Rookie
description: All that was missing was the official announcement, and that came yesterday: KARRIE WEBB of Australia is the Ladies Professional Golf Association's Rookie of the Year.

title: Barkley's Mouth Is in Midseason Condition
