description: Excepting Juwan Howard, Charles Barkley was the league's biggest wishbone the past few months. He was being pulled every which way until Hakeem Olajuwon's team finally snapped him up.

title: In the Bronx, Welcoming the World Series as a Reflection on Home
description: The game of baseball is a muddle and a mystery to Karmelia Wilmot, who immigrated to America from Jamaica two years ago. The rules for stealing bases, the strategies that prompt a batter to bunt -- none of it makes sense to her, despite her repeated efforts to watch the sport on television.

title: Nets Have a Big Problem At the Small Forward Spot
description: It's a shot as wide open as a deserted playground rim. And yet, no one wants to take it.

title: Young Lords: Vital in 60's, A Model Now
description: POLICE brutality. Decrepit housing. Young people fed up with no jobs and no future. Hispanic demonstrators taking to the streets to demand their rights. Sound familiar?

title: Study Says Networks Have Cut Violence
description: A major study released yesterday found that violence on network television declined in the past year. The finding led critics of the networks to say their efforts had been successful and television executives to insist that the problem had been overstated from the outset.

title: As American as Pate (and the French Are Biting)
description: THINK turkey, cranberry and sweet potato pate. Think vegetarian pate baked in triple-crust pastry. Think paella or even chicken ginger pate.

title: Refrain: Why Won't Clinton Open Medical File?
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Again, A Collection Of Old Jokes
description: You don't need a poll to predict the happiest outcome of the Presidential election. On Nov. 6, we should be rid of either Bob Dole age jokes or Bill Clinton fat jokes, those tiresome, knee-jerk routines that pass for humor in this campaign. Such stale, safe comedy is the last thing you'd expect from Dennis Miller, who can be as scabrous and funny a political satirist as anyone around. The best parts of his HBO series, ''Dennis Miller Live,'' are his ranting monologues and irreverent comments on the news. But his new limited-run series, ''Not Necessarily the Elections,'' is curiously flat. It has age jokes and fat jokes; it does not have Mr. Miller's acidic wit.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For 38 years, EDWARD DOWNES served as quizmaster for the live Saturday broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera, so yesterday about 100 friends and colleagues toasted him at a luncheon on the Grand Tier of the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Chase and Citicorp Register Solid Earnings for Third Quarter
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and Citicorp, the nation's two largest bank holding companies, recorded solid if not spectacular third-quarter earnings results yesterday, and analysts said the industry remained on track for a third consecutive year of record profits.

title: CONRAIL ACCEPTS $8.4 BILLION OFFER BY EASTERN RIVAL
description: Conrail Inc., the freight railroad that dominates the Northeast, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with the CSX Corporation, a far larger railroad that blankets the Southeast, Middle Atlantic and eastern Midwest.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: 2 Companies Pick Agencies
description: Two advertisers have made decisions on their accounts.

title: Fraschilla's Emphasis: Building a Program
description: Fran Fraschilla held his first practice yesterday at Alumni Hall, but before the first basketball could be heard bouncing on the court, the new St. John's coach made his main objective clear: ''I'm more interested in building a program than I am in building a team right now.''

title: Shedding Light on How Simpson's Lawyers Won
description: AMERICAN TRAGEDY

title: Jordan's King Visits West Bank to Bolster Arafat in Talks
description: King Hussein of Jordan returned to the West Bank today for the first time since he lost it to Israel in the 1967 war, promising the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, full support in peace talks and in his efforts to establish an independent state.

title: Food Additive Makers Said to Seek Settlement With U.S.
description: Strengthening the Government's effort to crack an illegal international cartel, certain producers of a widely used food additive have entered into substantive negotiations with the Justice Department to settle potential criminal charges of price-fixing, people with knowledge of the case said today.

title: From Big Eight to Jersey City State
description: Artis Garris looks like he might be an assistant manager of a Walgreen's drugstore, which he is 20 hours a week when he is not playing football or attending classes or studying. He is generous when he says he is 5 feet 10 inches and 200 pounds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Jet Offensive Line Desperate for First Aid
description: Before the start of this horror season for the Jets, the offensive line was a disaster waiting to happen. And a disaster of sorts did happen in Sunday's 21-17 loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars when center Dave Alexander, the team's most experienced lineman, suffered a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee and was lost for the season.

title: Zimmer Defends Positions
description: ''I am a pro-choice, pro-environment, pro-reform Christie Whitman Republican,'' Representative Richard A. Zimmer said Monday. He sought to counter attacks from his opponent, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, who has characterized Mr. Zimmer as an acolyte of Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, and a supporter of cuts to popular programs like Medicare, education and conserving the environment.

title: REYNOLDS METALS PLANS TO CUT 1,060 WORKERS
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it would cut 1,060 jobs under a plan to increase profits amid slumping aluminum prices. Reynolds, the second-largest United States aluminum producer, said it would reduce its 30,000-member work force by 3.5 percent through layoffs and attrition. Reynolds Metals expects to cut 750 of the jobs by the end of the year and the rest early next year. Reynolds Metals said the work force reductions were part of a plan to improve its pretax earnings in 1997 by $100 million, or $1 a share, by paring costs, improving production and cutting capital spending by $100 million next year. Shares of Reynolds Metals, based in Richmond, rose $2.375, to $54.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Benitez Conscious
description: The former champion WILFRED BENITEZ regained consciousness yesterday at University Hospital in San Juan, P.R., after lapsing into a coma last Friday at his home in the town of Carolina, a complication of brain swelling he has long been afflicted with.

title: Iraqis Make Shaw, but Not 'iggins, 'appy
description: To the Editor:

title: Spending in New Jersey
description: New Jersey's two Senate candidates said they each had more than $4.4 million for the final three weeks of what could be the most expensive Senate race in the country. Page B6.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Dr. Richard W. Porter, a rocket scientist who supervised the nation's first space venture, misstated the date of the Soviet Union's launching of the Sputnik orbital satellite. It was Oct. 4, 1957, not Oct. 14.

title: Texas Instruments' Earnings Fall Sharply
description: Indicating the continued uneven performance of the semiconductor industry, Texas Instruments Inc. came in with sharply lower earnings today even before a one-time expense that resulted in a net loss.

title: Japan Seeking Way to Evolve 2-Party System
description: Political candidates are doggedly bowing and pleading for votes across Japan in anticipation of elections on Sunday, as Japan engages in a national experiment aimed at producing a more responsive political system.

title: What A.D.M.'s Ads Didn't Tell
description: One of the country's most successful corporations, Archer Daniels Midland, agreed Monday to plead guilty to the shameful crime of victimizing customers. A.D.M., a huge food-processing business known for its benign television commercials, admitted that it had conspired with major competitors to jack up the price of lysine, a feed additive for livestock, and citric acid, a flavor additive and preservative. The price-fixing cost consumers million of dollars each year in higher prices for soft drinks, processed foods, detergents and other goods.

title: Immigrants Deserve Compassion, Not Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrants Deserve Compassion, Not Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinals or Braves? Yankees on the Fence
description: Talk about mixed emotions. One night Mel Stottlemyre is ecstatic because his team wins the American League pennant, and the next night he is in agony watching his son get battered in the first inning of the game that could put the two of them in the World Series together.

title: Zimmer Says He's a Centrist Who'd Shrink Government
description: Differentiating himself from his Democratic opponent in the race for the open United States Senate seat from New Jersey, Representative Richard A. Zimmer says that if elected, he would emphasize cutting government spending and taxes and making government less intrusive.

title: Tokyo Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks were slightly lower here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 18.07 points, or slightly less than one-tenth of 1 percent, to stand at 21,411.86. On Tuesday, the Nikkei index gained 400.68 points.

title: Vienna Boys Choir Hands The Baton to a Woman
description: The imperious male bastion of Vienna's music world has caved a little. Agnes Grossman, the first woman to direct the Vienna Boys Choir, was welcomed by her small charges with smiles and nonchalant shrugs today as they met in the gilded and chandeliered salon of the Augarten Palace.

title: Sprint and Ameritech Report Profit Increases
description: The Sprint Corporation and the Ameritech Corporation reported higher third-quarter earnings yesterday on revenue increases of slightly more than 10 percent.

title: Accuser Faces Rape Suspect, 10 Years Later
description: Ten years after she said she was raped by a Darien teen-ager, a young woman took the witness stand today to describe the terror she said was inflicted by Alex Kelly, who fled his first trial for the life of a ski bum.

title: Involvement of Third Officer In Fatal Shooting Is Explored
description: Police investigators are looking into the possibility that at least one more officer joined two others in an unauthorized search for a suspected mugger that led to Sunday's fatal shooting of an off-duty officer in Brooklyn, officials said yesterday.

title: Brazen Thieves Hit Mobsters' Homes, And Dons Don't See the Humor in It
description: After stealing all those chunky pinky rings and diamond-studded watches, Michael McLean might have realized that the cat burglary business had led him into dangerous territory.

title: Reports by Coke and Pepsi both puzzle.
description: The eternal rivalry between Pepsico Inc. and the Coca-Cola Company flared again yesterday, as the beverage industry archenemies released their quarterly earnings results on the same day for the first time in more than 20 years, provoking speculation that Coke was trying to steal Pepsi's thunder.

title: Yankees Pitchers Take Swings as Strawberry Sits
description: Darryl Strawberry looked groggy and sounded concerned as he limped out of the shower yesterday, the big toe on his right foot heavily wrapped. His teammates had just completed a three-hour workout at Yankee Stadium, but Strawberry missed it because he was lying on a trainer's table.

title: Business Travel
description: So-called smart cards, already popular in Europe, are coming to these shores in a big way now that I.B.M. and American Express are teaming up to use them for booking and checking airline, hotel and car-rental reservations. The cards have built-in memory chips that store and retrieve information rather than magnetic strips with very limited functions.

title: Patriots Sign Byars
description: KEITH BYARS signed with the New England Patriots yesterday, two weeks after being released by the Miami Dolphins and a month after his streak of 130 games with at least one reception ended.

title: Wine Talk
description: BORDEAUX chateau owners turn up regularly in New York, eager to show off the fruits of their vineyards and famous cellars. Anthony Barton, of Leoville-Barton and Langoa-Barton, who will be here later this week, brings something more: an association with Bordeaux and its wine that dates back more than 250 years.

title: TRW TO BUY IZUMI'S STEERING WHEEL AND AIR BAG UNIT
description: TRW Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the steering wheel and air-bag business of Izumi Corporation Industries for an undisclosed price. The acquisition would allow TRW to offer auto makers a unit for each passenger with a steering wheel and air-bag system, which would lower car makers' costs by reducing the number of supplier transactions, Gary Klasen, a TRW spokesman, said. Cleveland-based TRW is the largest producer of air bags in the United States, with about 33 percent of the market. Izumi Motors Ltd. of Japan owns a majority stake in Izumi, which has 800 employees in Yaphank, L.I., and has been a supplier to TRW for about six years. TRW's shares fell $1.50, to $91.125.

title: DEAL TO MERGE COPLEY REAL ESTATE AND ALDRICH EASTMAN
description: Copley Real Estate Advisers, a unit of the New England Investment Companies, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, Aldrich Eastman & Waltch L.P., for $67.5 million in cash and securities, which would create the third-largest real estate money manager in the United States. The combination of Copley and Aldrich Eastman Waltch, reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, would have more than $7.6 billion in real estate assets under management. New England Investment agreed to pay $62.5 million in cash and securities, and to issue a $5 million, three-year note for Aldrich Eastman Waltch. It also plans to pay about another $35 million over three years if the combined company meets revenue goals. Copley was created in 1982 by the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is now owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: Who Says Serialism Can't Be Kind to Listeners?
description: Milton Babbitt's Clarinet Quintet, which the Juilliard Quartet introduced at its 50th anniversary concert on Friday night at the Juilliard Theater, is a delight to the senses, a fast flow of lovely chords and spry rhythms, a thing of sweetness and light. It would be wrong to say that the grand seigneur of Serialism has given in to nostalgia or neo-Romantic regression; this new piece makes no obvious break with the mathematical procedures Mr. Babbitt has used since the late 1940's. But he has become generous, toward tradition and toward his listeners.

title: Young Children Left in Squalor; Mother and Friend Are Arrested
description: A 30-year-old Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday along with her boyfriend after she left four of her five children unattended for about six hours, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Title Character in 'Ellen' May Come Out as Gay
description: Producers of the ABC sitcom ''Ellen'' are discussing plans to have the main character disclose that she is a lesbian during the 1996-97 television season, several reports and a person familiar with the production say. No one involved with the show would comment on the reports, which appeared on Friday.

title: Evacuated Artists Plan Show
description: A dozen painters, sculptors, musicians and film makers who were evacuated last January from their lofts in a converted mercury vapor lamp factory will gather Sunday for a group show exhibiting their work and documenting their ordeal. ''The Grand Street Artists Mercury Refugees Exhibition'' will be at Hoboken City Hall from noon to 6 P.M.

title: Seeking Lessons for Today in the Story of Cain and Abel
description: Talk is cheap on television, but there's precious little conversation, a condition that Bill Moyers has waged a one-man campaign to rectify. Mr. Moyers can't be accused of thinking small. This time out he brings on writers, artists, scholars, translators, psychotherapists, even lawyers to take on the Old Testament. In 10 hourlong seminars, changing groups of guests reflect with him on the relevance of the world's most famous stories to our own time.

title: China Joins Criticism Of North Korea Sub
description: In a major step toward greater cooperation by China in rebuking North Korea at the United Nations, the Security Council expressed its ''serious concern'' today about the intrusion of a North Korean submarine into South Korean territory last month.

title: Welfare Plan Would Aid Some Immigrants
description: Legal immigrants who arrived before the new Federal welfare law took effect would be eligible for cash benefits under a welfare plan that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman submitted today to the Federal Government.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the development of the Times Square area referred incorrectly to the Disney store on 42d Street. It has already opened.

title: State Court Expands Human Rights Law
description: In a decision hailed by gay organizations and civil rights advocates, New York State's highest court significantly broadened the reach of the state's Human Rights Law today to protect people with H.I.V. from discrimination by dentists and doctors.

title: A 'Less Intrusive' Government: Excerpts From Zimmer Interview
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey being vacated by Bill Bradley, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times for about 90 minutes on Monday to discuss issues in his race against Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat. Following are excerpts from the session.

title: An Artist With Charm and the Impulse to Shock
description: A documentary film maker could scarcely ask for a subject better than Niki de Saint Phalle.

title: Cards Looking to Wrap It Up And Win Braves' Respect, Too
description: Their afternoon workout at Busch Stadium complete, the Cardinals headed to Atlanta today armed with a three-games-to-two lead in the National League Championship Series and carrying a huge chip on their shoulders for motivation.

title: With Education in Rare Political Spotlight, Mainstream Clinton Message Seems to Sell
description: Usually reduced to marginal, feel-good campaign homilies, education issues this year have emerged as a major focus in Presidential politics to a degree unmatched in any Presidential election in memory.

title: Who Owns Columbus
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole's Plan: Bet the Ranch on One Shot
description: A week ago, few people in the tight little world of big-time politics were talking much about California, despite its treasure trove of 54 electoral votes. After 27 Presidential trips to the state in less than four years, it seemed to belong to Bill Clinton, and Bob Dole was spending neither a lot of money nor a lot of time trying to take it away.

title: Yankees' 3 Wise Men: Torre, Zimmer and Stottlemyre
description: IN the Yankee dugout during a game, they always sit together. As the manager, Joe Torre is usually in the middle with Don Zimmer to his right, Mel Stottlemyre to his left. The three wise men of Yankee strategy.

title: HORIZON CELLULAR TO SELL LICENSES TO PRICELLULAR
description: Horizon Cellular Group said yesterday that it would sell cellular licenses in four Kentucky markets to the Pricellular Corporation for $116.5 million in cash and stock. The four areas have 23,000 subscribers and 756,000 potential customers. Horizon, a provider of cellular telephone service based in Malvern, Pa., said the transaction was expected to close before the end of the year. Pricellular, based in New York, owns cellular communications systems.

title: Graf Tax Questions
description: American officials have asked German authorities to tell them how much of STEFFI GRAF's income might be taxable in the United States, a state prosecutor in Mannheim, Germany, said yesterday.

title: In One Poor African Nation, Democracy Thrives
description: At every dusty intersection in this sweltering city of red clay streets and smoke-belching motor scooters, beggars with clouded eyes blinded by water-borne parasites or with limbs gruesomely twisted by polio cluster around stopped cars, pleading for a small donation for food.

title: Quarterly Earnings of 3 Big Brokers Rise
description: The good fortune that robust stock and bond markets have bestowed on Wall Street this year showed up again yesterday in sharply higher third-quarter earnings at Merrill Lynch & Company and at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

title: Magazine Editors Back Independence Policy
description: In the wake of several high-profile conflicts between editors and the companies that run their publications, the professional association of magazine editors today announced a pointed policy to preserve editorial independence and threatened punitive measures if those principles are violated.

title: Court Accepts Case Tied to Separation of Powers
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Congress exceeded its authority three years ago when it passed a law giving religion more protection against Government interference than the Court itself has found to be constitutionally required.

title: Accusing a Referendum of Misleading the Voters
description: In a 30-second television commercial, ''Scam,'' which began appearing yesterday, New Yorkers for Term Limits urged rejection of a City Council ballot referendum that would increase the limit on officeholders' terms to three instead of two, or 12 years instead of 8.

title: Sampling the Wares, on the Spot
description: RECENTLY, 67 Wine and Spirits, 179 Columbus Avenue (68th Street), took over the second-floor space that had been Jack Sprat's restaurant. It is now using part of what was the kitchen as a demonstration area for chefs, wine makers and others to give informal classes on food-and-wine pairings.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANKBOSTON, Boston, a bank holding company, agreed to acquire GBFC Inc., a specialty finance company, from Gordon Brothers for $40 million.

title: More Insurers Balk on Breast Reconstruction
description: LAST January, on the day before Mary McKilligan was scheduled to have the second phase of breast reconstruction after a mastectomy, her insurance company told her that it would not pay for the operation. Although coverage had been approved several weeks earlier, the company, United Community Health Plan in Latham, N.Y., said it was reversing its decision on the ground that the procedure was cosmetic and therefore not medically necessary.

title: Tribute to a Theater Executive Fills the House, as He Wished
description: Over the years, Bernard B. Jacobs, the longtime president of the Shubert Organization, would leave the memorial services for major theater figures, wondering about that unpredictable quantity that obsesses theater executives: turnout.

title: INSIDE
description: Court to Review Religion Act

title: Thousands Are Expected At Rally Set By Farrakhan
description: The Nation of Islam prepared for a crowd of thousands to gather today outside the United Nations to commemorate the first anniversary of last year's Million Man March, and, like last year's event, it has become a flashpoint for debate. Yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani denounced the rally's organizer, Louis Farrakhan, saying that his involvement tainted even a noble endeavor.

title: Don't Make a Worse Mess of Our Political Mud
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: Mexicana Airlines, Los Angeles, to Reynolds & Associates, Manhattan Beach, Calif., to handle its American general-market account as well as advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. The account had been divided between two Los Angeles agencies: Batey Ads USA and Cruz/Kravitz: Ideas. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million.

title: Workfare Job Threat Seen
description: Labor organizers said yesterday that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed welfare plan would harm people who currently hold jobs. The New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. said workers would be laid off or denied jobs so that the positions could be filled by welfare recipients who would continue to receive health and child-care benefits from the state. To protect workers from being displaced, the labor organization said that participants in the so-called Work First program should be paid the same wages as other employees performing similar duties. But Kathy Krepcio, director of policy and planning for the State Department of Human Services, said that the new Federal welfare law prohibited employers from getting rid of workers to hire welfare recipients.

title: The committee system as a way around rules against bribery.
description: WITH just 19 days until Nov. 5, political action committees are presumably eager to elect the best Congress that money can buy. But how can they be certain that legislators will deliver once they have taken the money? For that matter, how can politicians induce special interests to give them the wads of cash needed to get to Washington and stay there if they are barred from selling their votes?

title: Weakness Overseas Is Drag on Ford's Results
description: The Ford Motor Company reported third-quarter profits today that barely met analysts' expectations, while disclosing heavy losses in its European and South American operations and an unexpected drop in profits from car loans and leases.

title: Espy Is Linked To Illegal Gift In Indictment
description: A Federal grand jury in San Francisco has indicted an executive at a huge California agricultural cooperative on charges that he gave $10,780 worth of illegal gifts to Mike Espy, then Agriculture Secretary, and orchestrated a scheme to funnel illegal political contributions to Mr. Espy's brother.

title: The New Birthday Party
description: THE birth of Jeremy Tacchetti-Carelli was celebrated more like a family reunion than a medical procedure.

title: Man Is Sentenced in the Hiding Of Evidence in Terrorist Slaying
description: The mother of a yeshiva student killed in a terrorist shooting on the Brooklyn Bridge two years ago wept in a courtroom yesterday as the final defendant in the case pleaded guilty and was sentenced to probation.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Compaq Computer's Net Income Rises by 43%, But Stock Dips
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation reported strong gains yesterday in revenues, earnings and profit margins, which it attributed to successful new products, cost-saving efforts and an increase in its share of the personal computer market.

title: Farrakhan of Today Offers a Positive Message
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''Look at all the kids here. They were so used to being alone. They must have wondered what new world they had stumbled into.''

title: European Union to Join U.S. Trade Complaint
description: The European Union said yesterday that it would join United States efforts at the World Trade Organization to end what it contends is Japanese trade discrimination against foreign producers of film and photographic paper.

title: Back the New Exam
description: To the Editor:

title: Unexpectedly, Apple Halts String of Losses
description: Defying Wall Street predictions of yet another money-losing period, Apple Computer Inc. reported a $25 million profit for its fiscal fourth quarter today.

title: Thousands Rally at United Nations on 'Day of Atonement'
description: Seeking to show that the momentum sparked a year ago by a huge rally of black men in Washington remains alive, thousands of people gathered yesterday in the shadow of the United Nations to extol the successes of that gathering and to renew its calls for atonement and brotherhood.

title: Torre's Inflection Means Rogers's Season Is Over
description: With each sentence that Joe Torre uttered, it became more and more obvious to discerning ears that Kenny Rogers will most likely be excluded from the World Series roster because of the inflammation in his left shoulder that the Yankees will blame for his inconsistent pitching. The $20 million pitcher is about to become the $20 million cheerleader during the Series.

title: Papa Bear: The New Hemingway Has Hairy Paws
description: THE BEAR WENT OVER THE MOUNTAIN

title: Searing Images From Debates Past Are Continuing to Haunt Dole
description: If Bob Dole was skittish about going negative in Wednesday's debate against President Clinton, he had good reason to be.

title: Chambliss Is Ready for the Next Major Step
description: Chris Chambliss, the Yankees' one-time post-season hero and now their batting coach, had his heart with the club as it prepared for the World Series yesterday. But California was on Chambliss's mind, too.

title: Sears's Earnings Rise 22% On Strong Sales in 3 Areas
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 22 percent, increased mostly by strong sales of apparel, hardware and furniture.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions of Business Day yesterday with a brief report about Caterpillar Inc.'s third-quarter results misstated the percentage change in earnings from the previous year. As the article and a table noted, earnings rose 45.5 percent, not 5.5.

title: Upbeat Jets Have Johnson Again
description: It doesn't happen often, but Coach Rich Kotite became furious during today's practice of his 0-7 Jets.

title: Chamois, Suds and Cappuccino Foam
description: IN the San Francisco Bay area, which gave us acid rock and California cuisine, another trend may be emerging: the boutique carwash. At $9.95, it is a sensual soak for car and driver.

title: Many Roads to Mozart Over Jazzy Terrain
description: The barbarians are at the gates, some may think. It was one thing for Marcus Roberts to give full-blown jazz treatment to ''Rhapsody in Blue'' in his recent ''Portraits in Blue'' album; that was Gershwin. This is Mozart, and quintessential Mozart at that, with jazz specialists taking on the piano concertos.

title: Sleaze at the Top
description: Whose money is buying those anti-Dole TV spots saturating the airwaves, and what are the secret sponsors getting for their investment?

title: Russia's Tax Crisis
description: An ailing Boris Yeltsin was recently forced to deal with a problem that may prove more important to Russian stability than Mr. Yeltsin's heart troubles. Millions of Russian workers employed by the state have not been paid their wages or pensions for months because the Government is collecting only a fraction of the tax revenues it is due.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the Bavarian rock band Notwist, which performed Monday night at Tramps, misspelled the given name of a band member. As reflected in the review, he is Markus Acher, not Marcus.

title: How to Get Kiwi Air Refunds
description: Ticket-holders looking for refunds from the newly defunct Kiwi Airlines will have to take their place in line with the carrier's other creditors, company officials said yesterday. Travelers who bought tickets after Kiwi filed for bankruptcy Sept. 30 are considered preferred creditors and should send their tickets back to the airline for refunds, said Stan Brown, Kiwi's vice president for sales and marketing. Those who bought their tickets before Sept. 30, meanwhile, must file a claim with the Clerk of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Newark. The airline stopped flying Tuesday after failing to find an investor to keep it running during reorganization.

title: A retailer creates the wrong impression with a campaign meant to revive its lagging image.
description: THE Sharper Image Corporation is doing damage control to avoid, well, an image problem.

title: Beating Tickets, but Not the Authorities
description: It was a sales pitch aimed at the heart of every New Yorker who ever dashed back to a double-parked car a moment too late, or forgot which day the street sweeper was coming by. ''Tired of parking tickets?'' the business cards asked. ''Call the experts and save.''

title: Where to Find It
description: MOST people buy a home computer in spite of its appearance, but its blinking screen and hulking presence are doubly irritating if it occupies a choice piece of real estate -- a living room, for instance, or a bedroom. Even sleek new charcoal models like the Acer can be unwelcome reminders of work anywhere but in a full-fledged home office.

title: Crooked Walls Can Speak Volumes
description: KIND people and real estate agents would probably say that the house I grew up in had ''character,'' which is another way of saying that it was full of my father's construction missteps.

title: Heating Oil Drops as Traders Think U.S. May Insure Supply
description: Heating oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday amid speculation that the Federal Government might intervene to insure adequate supplies in the Northeast, sparing consumers from soaring heating bills this winter.

title: Hunt Adkins Wins Best of Show Award
description: For the second consecutive year, Hunt Adkins in Minneapolis took top honors, winning the best of show award, at The Show, a competition for advertising created by Minnesota agencies that is sponsored by the Advertising Federation of Minnesota and the Art Directors/Copywriters Club of Minnesota.

title: Citibank Expanding Vietnam Exposure
description: Citibank aims to expand its lending portfolio in Vietnam by 35 percent by the end of the year, according to Bradley Lalonde, Citibank's general manager in Hanoi. ''We hope we will be the largest foreign bank in Vietnam by January,'' he said yesterday. Citibank, a unit of Citicorp, opened its Hanoi branch in December 1995 and now has about $85 million in outstanding loans to Vietnamese clients. (Dow Jones)

title: Braves Win, 3-1; Force 7th Game
description: The Yankees' wait for a World Series opponent was prolonged again last night, this time by the man who has been the best pitcher in baseball over the past five seasons.

title: Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr., 76, Who Helped Save the Meadowlands
description: Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr., a businessman, philanthropist and former New Jersey State Senator who was instrumental in preserving the Hackensack Meadowlands, died on Saturday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 76.

title: Consumer Inflation Rises, but With Some Quirks
description: Consumer inflation quickened in September but the moderate increase was dominated by seasonal quirks and reimposition of the tax on airline tickets, a Government report showed today.

title: Peso Hits Year's Low In Mexico
description: The peso fell to its lowest level of the year today, continuing a weeklong slide strengthened by investor anxiety concerning Government economic policy after Sunday's decision to cancel a long-planned privatization of Mexico's petrochemical industry.

title: The Scent of Chamisa
description: When fall comes to the Southwest, the chamisa blooms, and suddenly a shrub that is inconspicuous most of the year seems to dominate the landscape. An old chamisa plant grows upright out of a weir of dead boughs, and its whip-like, pale green branches terminate in clumps of yellow florets, which brush against a walker's hips. When rain falls -- and Santa Fe recently got half an inch -- the scent of chamisa seems almost too portentous for the wind to ferry about. The odor is opaque, insidious, like ground fog. It infiltrates. It malingers. It loiters. Even with nostrils buried deep in the plant, a question persists: What does chamisa smell like?

title: Calendar: Tour, Shows and Discussions
description: Benefit House Tour

title: Rising Star in the Kremlin: An Ardent Pro-Capitalist
description: Deep inside the Kremlin, Anatoly B. Chubais is plotting how to carry out the next stage of Russia's democratic revolution.

title: STOCK PLUNGES ON CONCERN ABOUT NEW COMPETITION
description: The shares of Sun Microsystems Inc. fell almost 10 percent yesterday on worry that new work station computers from rivals using Intel chips and Microsoft software will cut into Sun's sales and earnings. Sun, which holds 45 percent of the work station market, bases its computers on its own technology. Its stock fell $6.875, to $63.125, in Nasdaq trading of 18 million shares. Late on Tuesday, Sun reported a 46 percent rise in profits, slightly better than expected. But analysts noted that Intel's results earlier this week beat the most optimistic forecasts. ''Sun didn't beat expectations strongly enough,'' said Martin Pyykkonen, an analyst at Furman Selz Inc., who removed the stock from the ''recommended'' list. Other analysts also downgraded the stock.

title: People
description: William J. Ludwig, executive vice president and executive creative director at Campbell-Ewald Advertising, Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to vice chairman and chief creative officer, a new post.

title: Tonight't N.F.L. Matchup
description: THURSDAY 8 P.M. GAME

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PLAID CLOTHING GROUP, New York, a men's apparel company that has operated under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since July 1995, will sell all its assets to Hartmarx Corp., Chicago, for an undisclosed amount.

title: P.F. Pasternack, 50, Surgical-Risk Expert
description: Peter F. Pasternack, a cardiologist at New York University Medical Center who made his mark in the study of risk assessment in surgery, died on Monday at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 50.

title: Zimmer Seat Fight Heats Up
description: A low-key campaign for the seat being vacated by Representative Richard A. Zimmer turned nastier yesterday when the campaign manager for the Republican candidate accused his Democratic opponent of shouting an obscenity at her and poking her in the arm. Patricia Flannery, manager for Mike Pappas of Franklin Township, demanded an apology from David DelVecchio, of Lambertville, saying he had become ''extremely agitated'' when she challenged a remark that he had made during a debate at Hunterdon Central High School.

title: Morgan Grenfell Officials Dismissed
description: Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, the investment banking unit of Deutsche Bank, dismissed the head of its asset management division and three other executives yesterday over a scandal involving bogus values placed on stock in three investment funds. Keith Percy, chief executive of Morgan Grenfell Asset Management, was among those dismissed in the case, which involved the fund manager Peter Young, who had been dismissed for gross misconduct.

title: AMR CORP. (AMR, N)
description: The AMR Corporation, parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that its third-quarter profits increased 23 percent over the corresponding period last year, because of higher prices and strong demand.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SEAN CONNERY, the graying actor who's still seen as a hunk years after his James Bond stint, caused a stir in his West End debut, and he didn't even deliver a single line, the Press Association in London reported yesterday.

title: Britain May Forbid Private Ownership Of Most Handguns
description: The British Government today proposed a ban on almost all privately owned handguns. The action came in response to widespread outrage after the massacre in Dunblane, Scotland, last March in which a man opened fire with four handguns at a primary school, killing 16 children and their teacher.

title: Pirates Won't Let Martin Go
description: AL MARTIN won't follow DENNY NEAGLE, CHARLIE HAYES and DAVE CLARK out of Pittsburgh's revolving door. The Pirates, who spent much of August shedding experienced players and cutting payroll, re-signed Martin yesterday to a two-year extension through the 1999 season.

title: The Master of Ambiguity
description: Bob Dole's 11th-hour decision to tilt his campaign toward highly volatile ''character issues'' has underscored the political conundrum Republican strategists have been long unable to solve and that now threatens to drive them and their candidate to desperation. Put simply: How has Mr. Clinton withstood the continued aspersions on his personal and political integrity, yet remained so far, far ahead in the polls?

title: A Rummagers' Haven
description: DECORATING devotees, turn the page. This report is aimed at collectors: obsessives who know that owning one of a kind is never enough -- it takes three, at least.

title: Same Space, But Hardly Same View
description: THE chance to compare three luxury apartments in the same line of one building is a design voyeur's dream come true. It's a kind of ''Three Coins in the Fountain,'' in which the stars are rooms instead of debutantes. And while the apartments, all duplexes, have the same good bones -- and started with nearly identical floor plans in the main rooms -- each has a distinctive look.

title: Jews Tell of Lost Holocaust Deposits
description: In a hearing room packed with television cameras and reporters from as far away as Jerusalem and Geneva, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato came to New York City yesterday to press his crusade over the fate of millions of dollars deposited in Swiss banks by Jews who later died in the Holocaust.

title: Gillette Acquires Czech Razor Maker
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that it had bought the Czech razor-blade producer Astra A.S. Astra, which employs 600 workers in Jevicko, east of Prague, makes about one billion blades a year and is the market leader in the Czech Republic and Slovakia. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Where the Shopping and Tunes Are Looney
description: SHOPPING is not what it used to be -- a quiet experience of coming and going, buying and leaving. At the renovated Warner Brothers Studio Store, at 1 East 57th Street, which opens its new floors on Wednesday, shopping is noise (and shrieking).

title: Strong 3d-Quarter Results Push Time Warner Stock Up
description: Time Warner Inc.'s president, Richard D. Parsons, said yesterday that he and the president and chief executive of U S West Media Group, Charles Lillis, had informal discussions about a settlement between the two companies over ownership of Time Warner Entertainment.

title: Dentists Must Treat AIDS Patients
description: New York State's highest court has just ruled that the state's human rights law bars medical professionals from refusing to treat patients infected with the AIDS virus. Gov. George Pataki, a frequent critic of the court, correctly hailed the decision as ''absolutely right.''

title: INSIDE
description: Drug War's New Legal Tactic

title: Finance Briefs
description: Debt

title: Don't Make a Worse Mess of Our Political Mud
description: To the Editor:

title: I.O.C. Focuses on Women
description: They came from 96 countries to attend the first International Olympic Committee conference on women and sport. And when their three days of discussion, commiseration and mutual exhortation came to an end, they walked out of the Olympic museum with a 17-point resolution in their hands.

title: House Candidate's Father Quits As Adviser Over Racist Charges
description: Representative Cynthia A. McKinney, a Georgia Democrat, accepted the resignation of her father from any active role in her campaign today and issued a statement saying that she was embarrassed by ''the racism and anti-Semitism of recent statements by my own father.''

title: G.M. WINS ROUND IN SUIT AGAINST VOLKSWAGEN
description: The General Motors Corporation's espionage case against Volkswagen A.G. will proceed in United States District Court, a Federal judge ruled yesterday. Judge Nancy Edmonds denied a motion by Volkswagen to have the case dismissed. VW had argued that the United States case duplicated a similar lawsuit under way in Germany and that more than 100 witnesses were in Europe. General Motors is accusing VW of espionage, contending that G.M.'s former purchasing chief, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, stole corporate secrets and took them to VW when he switched companies in 1993.

title: Upon the Wicked Stage of Life
description: FROM the back, she could be Jane Fonda, Ann-Margret or Hillary Rodham Clinton on a long hair day. From the front, there's no mistaking her for anybody but Patricia Hearst Shaw, even if her nose is smaller than it used to be.

title: Military Plans Sent Abroad
description: A South Hackensack defense contractor pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to sending plans for American military parts to a Russian company as part of a scheme to have the parts illegally manufactured abroad. The company, the Electrodyne Systems Corporation, had been under contract to deliver $753,000 worth of American-made satellite communications systems called diplexers to the Navy, said Noel Hillman, an assistant United States attorney. Electrodyne's president, Dennis Nathan, also pleaded guilty yesterday to filling a 1993 Naval Research Lab order for 25 American-made amplifiers with mislabeled Ukrainian-made devices.

title: Midtown Block Shaken by Explosions
description: Thousands of office workers were forced to leave several midtown office buildings yesterday afternoon when an underground fire and several explosions shook a midtown Manhattan block during the lunch hour, Con Edison officials said.

title: The 'Ink' Trail, From On, Then Off, Then On Again
description: Visitors to one particular production office at the Radford Studios at CBS here have noticed a much higher-than-average level of activity recently. Gaggles of writers and producers walk faster, dress even more casually and appear paler than usual. Somewhat better-dressed individuals disappear behind closed doors for long periods. Actors awaiting their auditions spill even farther down the hallways than is customary.

title: A Desperate Kemp?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Regional Troupe Leaps Into the National Ranks
description: One of the big success stories in American modern dance, an art form that supposedly flourishes best in New York, is Ohio's very own Dayton Contemporary Dance Company.

title: Miscellany
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, reported that magazine advertising pages in September fell 2 percent from September 1995, to 21,120. For the first nine months of 1996, total ad pages fell 1.1 percent, to 150,251, from the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Post-Civil-War G.O.P. Didn't Diminish Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: From Alaska, Fishes in Search of Loaves
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Sign Pitching Coach
description: Baltimore signed Pittsburgh's pitching coach, RAY MILLER, to a two-year contract yesterday with an option for a third year. Miller, 51, replaces PAT DOBSON, who was dismissed on Tuesday. (AP)

title: 9 Children Are Found Untended; Mother and Friend Are Arrested
description: City social workers found nine young children alone in a dirty South Bronx apartment yesterday and called the police, who arrested the mother and her male companion on child-endangerment charges.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the jazz singer Abbey Lincoln misspelled the given name of a novelist who was among her friends before the singer left New York City for Los Angeles in 1970. The friend is Paule Marshall, not Paula.

title: Special Police Status?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an outbreak of red tide in Texas referred imprecisely to the extent of the shellfish harvesting ban imposed by the state. It extends from Galveston Island south to the Mexican border at Brownsville, but it does not include the Galveston Bay ecosystem.

title: Grant to Opera Program
description: The Opera Program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has received a $1 million grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. The grant, which is to be administered in two parts over the next three years, consists of $750,000 to be used for operating costs and $250,000 in a matching grant for an endowment fund. The grant raises to $94 million the total in a fund-raising drive begun in 1992 by the academy, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to cover operating and restoration costs; the goal is to raise $131 million by the year 2000.

title: Friends Recall Gathering Attended by Rape Suspect
description: It was supposed to be an ordinary night with high school friends.

title: Candidates Fling Barbs and Strive for Folksy Tone
description: They began their debate here tonight by taking neighborly strolls to chat with their questioners, more than a hundred uncommitted San Diego voters.

title: Laura La Plante Dies at 92; Archetypal Damsel in Distress
description: Laura La Plante, an early screen star who made the transition from silent screams to audible sobs and songs, died on Monday at the Motion Picture and Television Fund Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 92.

title: Strawberry Is Planning To Limp Into Series
description: Darryl Strawberry lifted the most scrutinized right toe in New York, planted his foot and unleashed his bat through the strike zone. Over and over, Strawberry tested his fractured big toe during batting practice at Yankee Stadium yesterday and endured minimal pain and decent results. Suddenly, he was walking and talking better.

title: Broadway's Gift for Children
description: Tickets for the most expensive shows on Broadway go for as much as $75. But for one night only, the price of admission will be waived for children attending any one of 23 Broadway and Off Broadway productions.

title: It's Hardly a Super Bowl But the Merchants Smile
description: Three days after the Yankees won the American League pennant, Mitchell & Ness had shipped its entire stock of expensive, authentically styled shirts and jackets to the four New York-area Yankee Clubhouse stores.

title: OLYMPIC FINANCIAL STOCK FALLS AS NO OFFER IS MADE
description: The stock of Olympic Financial Ltd. dropped 16 percent yesterday after the company said a potential suitor had decided not to make an offer. Olympic, an auto financing company, is based in Minneapolis. In August, news that it had been contacted by an unidentified potential buyer sent the company's stock up 36 percent in one day. Yesterday, Olympic shares were down $3.375, to $17.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company's preferred shares fell $16 each, to $78, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Earnings of BankAmerica Fell By 3% in the Third Quarter
description: The BankAmerica Corporation reported today that third-quarter earnings fell 3 percent, as a one-time charge for deposit insurance ate into gains from trading and other nonlending businesses.

title: France May Sell Arms Company
description: The French Government recommended today that the Lagardere group be allowed to buy Thomson S.A., the state-owned defense and consumer electronics company, a combination that would create the world's second-largest defense company.

title: DOLE ATTACKS CLINTON'S ETHICS; PRESIDENT PARRIES ON ECONOMY
description: In a spirited confrontation before the nation's voters, Bob Dole used the final televised Presidential debate last night to attack the ethical and governmental record of President Clinton repeatedly as scandal tainted and undeserving of renewal at the ballot box.

title: UNIT THAT LAYS CABLE UNDER OCEANS TO BE SOLD BY AT&T
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it was putting up for sale a unit that lays cable beneath oceans. The unit, AT&T Submarine Systems Inc., which is based in Morristown, N.J., installed the first trans-Atlantic telephone cable in 1956. The decision to sell the unit follows AT&T's move to split into three companies through the spinoff of its equipment arm, Lucent Technologies Inc., and the plan to sell its ailing computer business, the NCR Corporation. Submarine Systems has annual sales of about $850 million; AT&T did not say how much it hoped to get for the unit.

title: GTE (GTE, N)
description: The GTE Corporation, the nation's largest local telephone company, reported a 9 percent rise in third-quarter earnings yesterday, citing strong demand for new phone lines from people setting up businesses or hooking up computers at home.

title: Panel Urges Sweeping Changes To Increase the Safety of 737's
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today called for sweeping changes in equipment and training on Boeing 737's and certain other planes, in response to a crash in Pittsburgh two years ago whose cause has never been learned.

title: The Presidential Race
description: Indicating Leaders

title: At Last, a Unifying Force in Bosnia: Making Money
description: The Arizona market lies on a vast muddy field next to a NATO checkpoint where American troops sit atop armored personnel carriers, waiting to subject passing cars to meticulous searches for weapons.

title: Once Captives of Dismal Housing, Family Returns to Mexico
description: Juana Castillo sits cross-legged and barefoot on her mother's bed, grinning, her eyes fixed on the one scene she had etched in her mind, detail by detail, when she and her children lived behind a flimsy, padlocked door in a tiny, windowless room in America.

title: To Clint, With Love, From Jazz
description: ''In the Line of Fire'' has a scene in which the camera moves in on a Miles Davis album cover, ''Kind of Blue.'' The shot has little to do with the plot; it is, instead, a cinematic wink from Clint Eastwood, an aging Secret Service agent in the film and a jazz fan of long standing, to all the other fans out there. It's also a sly acknowledgment of the clan of jazz players, whom Mr. Eastwood admires. Tonight at Carnegie Hall, that clan will return the favor. The Carnegie Hall Jazz Band and a score of guest soloists will perform music from his films, which include ''Bird,'' ''Play Misty for Me,'' ''Honky-Tonk Man'' ''White Hunter, Black Heart'' and ''In the Line of Fire.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Hamptons International Film Festival misstated the nationality of the film ''Some Mother's Son.'' It is American, not British.

title: The big drug makers continue to ride a wave of rising sales.
description: PHARMACEUTICAL stocks are on a roll for a third consecutive year, propelled by relatively new products and a renewed ability to raise prices and generally outfox the managed care industry.

title: Pacers' Brown Out of Hospital
description: Indiana Pacers Coach LARRY BROWN was released from St. Vincent Hospital in Indianapolis yesterday following surgery for a hernia and for damaged cartilage in his left knee.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a court decision upholding the dismissal of Judge Marc Mogil of Nassau County Criminal Court misstated the target of a Federal lawsuit he filed and referred incorrectly to its status. The suit was against staff workers for the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, not the commission members, and it was dismissed on Oct. 3.

title: Kemp Backers Still Seeking Pit Bull, but He's Not Biting
description: Among the crowd of elderly Republican Party loyalists who gathered to welcome Jack Kemp to their well-to-do retirement village in suburban Las Vegas, Nev., the other day, most were spoiling for a fight.

title: Administration Moves to Defend Indonesia Policy After Criticism
description: The Clinton Administration today responded to Republican accusations that it had manipulated its trade and human rights decisions in return for campaign contributions from two wealthy Indonesian families.

title: Making Stock Buyers Of Wary Germans
description: Isabelle Klinger has never bought stocks. She views them the same way the vast majority of Germans do: with distrust.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Progress Is Made in Talks On G.M. Strike in Canada

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Chrysanthemums Indoors

title: Kanell Moves Up to No. 2 Spot
description: Two years ago, the backup quarterback Kent Graham did not play in a Giants preseason game against the Carolina Panthers. Coach Dan Reeves told Graham not to be concerned. He just wanted to give Stan White some extra playing time. When asked by reporters about his decision, Reeves said angrily that no one should read anything into the move.

title: Lopez Shuns A Statistic And Sparkles
description: FOR what seemed like forever, they were the Anheuser-Busch Cardinals. Now the corporate beer guys are gone, the regal Clydesdales no longer a part of the Cardinals' post-season extravaganzas. But here in Atlanta, where the National League Championship Series returned last night, Ted and Jane remained a part of the show, even though the team they rooted for is now the Time-Warner Braves.

title: U.S. and French Sniping Heats Up Over Paris's Links to Africa
description: Continuing an unusual diplomatic war of words between Washington and Paris over their relations with Africa, French officials refused today to apologize for remarks by a Government minister suggesting that Secretary of State Warren Christopher visited Africa last week as part of an electoral ploy.

title: Oil Pipeline Measure Aims to Insure Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: New Wheels for Gibbs, Labonte
description: General Motors has landed some proven winners -- JOE GIBBS and BOBBY LABONTE -- to help restore the Pontiac Grand Prix to prominence on the Winston Cup circuit.

title: Bargain U.
description: A recent study by the College Board found that once again the average tuition for four-year colleges in 1996-97 rose above the rate of inflation. Private colleges now cost $12,823 and public institutions, $2,966 -- just under 6 percent more than last year.

title: Pipeline Supervisors Charged With Harming Environment
description: Three people who supervised the construction of the 370-mile Iroquois gas pipeline across New York State were indicted yesterday on felony charges of conspiring to violate Federal laws for the protection of streams and wetlands and the safety of landowners living near the pipeline.

title: PRO BASKETBALL
description: How well John Starks adjusts to his sixth-man role this season will be critical for the Knicks. So far, both the Knicks and Starks have been happy.

title: Absurd Nuclear Games
description: To the Editor:

title: New Fodder for Holyfield
description: EVANDER HOLYFIELD will finally meet MIKE TYSON next month, five years after they first scheduled a showdown, but he is training for a different sort of Tyson. Holyfield has brought in a sparring partner to emulate Tyson going for a quick knockout.

title: Experimental Courts Are Using New Strategies to Blunt the Lure of Drugs
description: Standing in front of the judge in a special legal arena known as drug court, the defendant was on his own to explain why he had been arrested again for drug possession. He said he had picked up a hitchhiker who had been carrying drugs.

title: New Species: A Canadian Gator
description: JESSE PALMER, an 18-year-old from Ottawa, has committed to attend the University of Florida next year, putting him in line to become the first Canadian quarterback in Gator history.

title: The Big Shrug
description: New Yorkers have been debating all kinds of things this week. Should Madonna breast-feed her baby? Did Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy score a good pre-nuptial deal? Will Jerry Hall get the satisfaction of a lucrative post-nup from Mick Jagger? Should Kenny Rogers pitch in the World Series?

title: Narcotics Detective Charged As Part of Drug-Dealing Group
description: A New York City narcotics detective was arrested yesterday and charged with being part of a violent drug-trafficking group that staged a fatal attempted robbery of another dealer and an armored-car robbery that left a guard dead.

title: Mets Seem Interested In Smoltz and Bonds
description: While the Yankees were storming to the World Series, the Mets' brass met for a week in Port St. Lucie, Fla., formulating a plan to create the winner the franchise so desperately wants.

title: MASCO'S STAKE IN AN AFFILIATE TO SHRINK
description: The Masco Corporation agreed yesterday to reduce its stake in an affiliate, Mascotech Inc., for $266 million. Masco, a maker of home improvement products, said it would sell back to Mascotech 17 million Mascotech common shares and warrants to buy 10 million shares. Masco, based in Taylor, Mich., holds about 45 percent of Mascotech. The stock sale would reduce Masco's stake to about 16 percent. Mascotech, also of Taylor, is an industrial products company. Its stock was up 75 cents, to $14.375 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Masco stock was up $1, to $30 a share, also on the Big Board.

title: Content of Round 2 Seems Familiar
description: After a week of tough talk about talking tough, Bob Dole turned out to be a softie with a growl and an occasional joke, and the second debate went over much the same material as the first one, with much the same assertions, claims and phrases.

title: Executive Changes
description: MELVILLE CORP., Woonsocket, R.I., named Thomas M. Ryan to the positions of vice chairman and chief operating officer. Mr. Ryan will also continue as president and chief executive of Melville's CVS drugstore unit.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GEORGE C. WALLACE, the former Alabama Governor who became a symbol of segregation before recanting his views, is flattered that a movie is being made about his life, said his spokesman, David Azbell. But he wants to get a fair shake.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Court Hears Challenge To Anti-Abortion Curb
description: The intersection between the free speech rights of anti-abortion protesters and the right of patients to unimpeded access to abortion clinics is familiar territory for the Supreme Court. The Justices explored it again today, hearing a First Amendment challenge to a Federal court order intended to keep protesters from invading the ''personal space'' of people entering and leaving abortion clinics in upstate New York.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the arrests of two men in a series of window smashings on Los Angeles freeways misidentified an office where a map of the attacks was displayed. It was a California Highway Patrol office, not a state police office.

title: ELTRON INTERNATIONAL AND ZEBRA TECHNOLOGIES TO MERGE
description: Eltron International Inc. and the Zebra Technologies Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to merge. The companies said each Zebra common share would be exchanged for 0.84 Eltron common share. Zebra has almost 16.9 million shares outstanding, meaning its shareholders stand to receive almost 14.2 million Eltron shares, worth about $475.3 million at yesterday's closing price of $33.50 a share. The proposed transaction will be structured as a pooling of interest, which is tax free. Eltron is based in Simi Valley, Calif.; its products include printers for labels and plastic cards. Zebra Technologies, which is based in Vernon Hills, Ill., makes bar-code printers.

title: Investments With Votes As the Interest
description: IF only New York were here.

title: Serving Sweet Revenge While Dishing the Dirt
description: Who would dare to say there's no generosity of spirit in a show that lets Patti LuPone murder both Andrew Lloyd Webber and the composer's pet cat?

title: Afghans, at U.N., Offer a Cease-Fire Plan
description: The Afghan Government that was driven out of Kabul last month by the strict Islamic movement known as the Taliban called today for a cease-fire, the formation of a coalition government and the demilitarization of the country's capital under United Nations protection.

title: $200,000 Raised to Extend Term Limits
description: A group led by City Council leaders announced yesterday that it had raised $200,000 in the last week to finance its effort to extend term limits for the city's elected officials.

title: Jobless Rate Falls in Britain
description: British unemployment fell by a greater-than-expected number of claims in September, bringing the jobless rate to its lowest level in five and a half years. The jobless rate fell from 7.5 percent to 7.4 percent, the lowest since February 1991, the Office for National Statistics said yesterday. September's fall, by 35,600 claims to a total of 2.1 million, was the largest since December 1994. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Counterfeit Series Tickets Sold by Scalpers in Bronx
description: It was, perhaps, inevitable. With World Series tickets as scarce and desirable as pearls in oysters, the city's illicit entrepreneurs might have been expected to recognize and exploit the gap between supply and demand. And indeed, counterfeit World Series tickets have begun to surface, according to the Bronx Borough president, Fernando Ferrer, who said yesterday that a member of his staff bought one.

title: The Attack That Fizzled
description: Letting their hopes shape their predictions, Bob Dole's advisers had promised an all-out assault on President Clinton's character and ethics. But all Mr. Dole could deliver last night, once in the ring, was a series of pawing jabs and rhetorical asides of the sort that work in the Senate's cozy quarters but not in a two-person debate on national television. Mr. Dole gave the public a look at his wit, at his longstanding rejection of bigotry and his high-minded refusal to turn delicate foreign affairs problems into campaign issues. The only thing he failed to do was deliver the galvanizing attack that his strategists say he needed to turn the campaign around.

title: Caution on Myanmar
description: To the Editor:

title: McDaniel Is High On the List For Nets
description: They've all but had their lunch money stolen and sand kicked in their faces. Just part of being a Net. But that pushover image could change if Xavier McDaniel were to join the team as the official bodyguard.

title: Brinkley to Leave Post On ABC's 'This Week'
description: David Brinkley, the longtime anchor of the ABC News Sunday morning program ''This Week With David Brinkley,'' will leave that position on Nov. 10, ABC announced yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: The world's most protracted bridge event may be the Greater New York Bridge Association's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, which began a year ago and is still two or three matches from a conclusion.

title: Using Zimmer's Newscast Simulation Against Him
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey, began broadcasting this 30-second commercial yesterday. Mr. Torricelli's Republican opponent is Representative Richard A. Zimmer.

title: Archer Daniels Takes Steps To Put an Ally On Its Board
description: The showdown is set for today: Institutional investors from around the country are descending on Decatur, Ill., for the Archer Daniels Midland Company's annual meeting, vowing to bring more independent directors onto the board of the scandal-plagued company.

title: Wickes Says Profits Were Overstated
description: Wickes P.L.C. said yesterday that it had overstated operating profit in recent years by $:51 million, or $81 million. Wickes said it had a loss for the first nine months of 1996 and more than doubled its debt. It plans to issue shares to existing holders to refinance the business, its chairman, Michael von Brentano, said.

title: DDB Needham Renames Media Group
description: DDB Needham Worldwide, owned by the Omnicom Group, has renamed its national media services operations Optimum Media and plans to use Optimum Media as a worldwide brand name for the agency's media services.

title: Ex-Colleague Accuses Aides In Argentina Of Corruption
description: In a bitter rebuke of President Carlos Saul Menem's Government, a former Argentine Finance Minister has asserted that members of the Cabinet in which he served for six years concealed corruption and manipulated judges.

title: Penguins Cannot Handle Rangers' Youth Movement
description: Critics of the Rangers often rightly cite their age. The two biggest stars, Mark Messier and Wayne Gretzky, will turn 36 years old in January. And 11 other players on their 24-man roster are at least 30.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INT'L. (CA, N)
description: Computer Associates International, which agreed last week to buy Cheyenne Software for $1.2 billion, reported quarterly earnings of $223 million yesterday in contrast to a loss a year earlier.

title: Garden Events: A Sale, Festivals and Lectures
description: Mums and Bonsai

title: Boy, 13, Held in Joy Ride With School Bus
description: A 13-year-old boy took an empty school bus for a three-hour ride through Garden City Park, L.I., today before becoming frightened and turning himself in at a gas station, the Nassau County police said.

title: The Pop Life
description: Phish Gotta Record

title: One Dispute Settled While Another Begins
description: As one advertising dispute was settled yesterday, another one went to court.

title: Suez Posts Profit For the First Half
description: Compagnie de Suez S.A. said yesterday that it had posted a profit of 772 million francs, or $154 million, in the first half of the year. Analysts called the results a sign that Suez, a financial and industrial holding company, was beginning its long-awaited recovery. The earnings were attributed to lower property-related losses and one-time gains on asset sales. They compared with a loss of 3.98 billion francs a year earlier.

title: Stanley Goldberg, 62, Physicist and Historian
description: Stanley Goldberg, a physicist and historian who studied military science and worked closely with the Federal Government to illuminate its social repercussions, died yesterday at the Hospice of Washington after a sudden illness. He was 62 and lived in Washington.

title: Dredging Plan Near Statue
description: The water surrounding the Statue of Liberty is gradually becoming too shallow for ferry traffic because of a heavy accumulation of silt. Today, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to decide whether to accept $5.6 million from the National Parks Service to dredge Liberty Island's entrance channel, said Bill Cahill, an authority spokesman.

title: U.S. Jury Convicts Mexican on Drug Charges
description: A Federal jury here today found Juan Garcia Abrego guilty of 22 counts of money laundering, drug possession and operating a criminal enterprise that prosecutors say smuggled more than 220,000 pounds of cocaine and 46,000 pounds of marijuana from his native Mexico into the United States over 16 years.

title: 2D-QUARTER LOSS IS EXPECTED AT BORLAND INTERNATIONAL
description: Borland International Inc. said yesterday that it expected a second-quarter loss of 32 to 36 cents a share and that it would dismiss 125 employees, or 15 percent of its work force. Borland attributed the expected loss to a revamping of its sales and marketing department and to slower customer orders. The company, which develops computer software tools, is based in Scotts Valley, Calif. It said it expected to save $15 million to $17 million from the job cuts.

title: Austrian Puzzler: A Jew Marches in Step With the Far Right
description: A perplexing question is hovering over Austrian politics: what, exactly, is the Jewish son of Holocaust survivors doing in political harness with a right-wing insurgent who, only a year ago, was addressing Waffen SS veterans as ''decent folk''?

title: DEVELOPER OF DIABETES DRUG PLANS TO SELL STAKES
description: Amylin Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it would sell up to $15 million in stock, or about 1.2 million common shares, to Johnson & Johnson. Amylin said it had also filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of 1.5 million shares. Proceeds from the sales will be used to finance Amylin's clinical trials of an experimental diabetes drug, pramlintide, which is supposed to improve glucose control in patients using insulin. Johnson & Johnson has teamed with Amylin to develop the drug. After both stock sales are completed, Johnson & Johnson will hold about 10.2 percent of the 30.9 million shares Amylin is expected to have outstanding.

title: Oxford's Expanded Health Plan Is Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Tries Aggressive Campaigning, Politely
description: It was 8 A.M. and Yoshitake Masuhara's campaign car set out through the winding residential streets with four giant loudspeakers on the roof, ready to blare out to the world its weighty campaign message.

title: Tough Campaign Task: Policing Foreign Money
description: The issue of whether Indonesian business interests made improper donations to the Democratic Party has drawn attention to a vexing problem in campaign finance regulation: how to distinguish a legitimate political donation from an illegal foreign contribution.

title: Images of Empty Seats From Term Limits
description: The Coalition for Voters' Choice, formed by City Council members, plans to broadcast this 30-second television commercial, ''Most Countries,'' beginning next week. The coalition is campaigning for a referendum to change the city's term limit law to allow three terms instead of two.

title: Giants Sign Strahan To a Four-Year Deal
description: Defensive end Michael Strahan has signed a new four-year, $12.2 million contract with the Giants that will include a $3.5 million signing bonus.

title: Exchange Chairman Quits
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said that its chairman resigned last night as the exchange's board heard the findings of a committee looking into his investment in the Ashton Technology Group, a company that is developing a computerized trading system for the Philex. Vincent J. Casella, who became chairman earlier this year, was barred from serving on the exchange's governing bodies for three years.

title: Clinton and Arkansas Have Long Ties to Indonesian Family
description: The 10,000 miles between Little Rock, Ark., and Jakarta, Indonesia, shrank when Bill Clinton became President.

title: For Joyner-Kersee, The Longest Jump
description: This was her first basketball game in 11 years and Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the 1988 Olympic champion in the horizontal jump, was having an expectedly delicate time adjusting to the vertical. Her first exhibition in the fledgling American Basketball League produced 2 points and three fouls in 11 minutes, along with mild attacks of nerves and asthma. Rust never sleeps.

title: If Mad Scientists Were Decorators
description: YOU who mourn the passage of high tech, grieve no more. Jan Staller, a Manhattan artist, and Chris Miele, an owner of Regeneration Furniture, are selling enamel-painted steel laboratory cabinets that adapt to kitchen use. The 100 pieces -- used but in good condition, some with heat-resistant black epoxy counter tops -- include drawer and shelf units and sinks. The sleek cabinetry, in blue, gray-green, or blue and white, is $150 a running foot ($175 with counter top). By appointment, at Regeneration Furniture, 38 Renwick Street (Canal Street), SoHo; (212) 614-9577.

title: The Frost Is on the Cardinals: Braves Force Game 7
description: The greatness of a professional athlete does not truly emerge until he or she faces adversity. It is during those times that character is tested and careers are defined.

title: European Aides Accused of Stifling Data on Illness Tied to Cows
description: An investigative committee of the European Parliament has accused senior European officials of stifling scientific findings that might have led to earlier restrictions on British beef, which is suspected of causing human deaths.

title: Ex-Lawyer Charged With Threatening Ex-Lover
description: A former lawyer who gained notoriety for blinding his estranged lover in 1959 and marrying her after spending 14 years in prison, was charged in Queens yesterday with threatening to kill a recent girlfriend who broke off their relationship.

title: For G.O.P. Freshman, Loyalty Vital in '94 Is a Problem Now
description: In a classic display of how to run from his party, Representative Phil English puts President Clinton in his television advertisements and tells fellow Republicans that Mr. Clinton's idea of tax deductions for college tuition is a good one.

title: For CSX Chief, a Big Sales Job to Win Conrail
description: When it comes to dealing with Federal agencies and Washington's corridors of power, there are few executives who have the experience of John W. Snow, the chairman, president and chief executive of the CSX Corporation.

title: Turned Off by Politics? Definitely Not These Veteran Voters
description: At the Rossmoor Clubhouse, Frank Pino and two dozen of his closest neighbors were debating the debates with the gusto of Sunday morning talk-show pundits.

title: School Embezzler Sentenced
description: The nearly $151,000 was supposed to pay for the education of Cranford's schoolchildren. Instead, a Federal jury found in July, Jeanette Nixon, Cranford's school business administrator, spent it on vacations, a Porsche, health club memberships and jewelry.

title: U.S. ROBOTICS SHOWS A NEW, FASTER MODEM
description: U.S. Robotics Inc. displayed a new modem yesterday that can transmit information faster than existing devices, speeding up customers' connections to on-line services and the Internet. The new modem can send data at 56,000 bits a second, leapfrogging current models that transmit at speeds up to 33,000 bits a second. The new modem is expected to be available in January. U.S. Robotics is not the only company that has the technology, though. Lucent Technologies Inc. introduced a chip yesterday that offers the same speed and expects to ship the chip in the first quarter of 1997. Rockwell International Inc. also displayed its own 56,000 bits-per-second chip.

title: Progress in G.M. Strike Talks in Canada but No Accord
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation flew to Toronto today and made progress in negotiations to end a two-week strike by Canadian auto workers. But a settlement remained elusive, making it likely that G.M. will temporarily lay off thousands more American workers.

title: Bond Prices Slip on Fear Of Inflation
description: Treasury bond prices ended slightly lower yesterday, hurt by concerns that the economy was not slowing enough to avoid a pickup in inflation.

title: It's Official: Woods Is on Tour
description: TIGER WOODS is now an official member of the PGA Tour and moving up quickly in the Ryder Cup standing.

title: Officer Breaks Silence in Fatal Shooting of a Colleague
description: A police officer who investigators say they believe mistakenly shot a fellow off-duty officer during a wild shootout in Brooklyn came forward with a confidential statement Tuesday evening, after refusing to talk to superiors for two days, according to senior police officials.

title: Piece of Asphalt Pie
description: LIEUTENANT PETROSINO PARK, where Kenmare and Lafayette Streets meet, is a barren triangle of concrete connecting SoHo and Little Italy. But it may be transformed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: A Masterly Maddux Sinks Cardinals
