description: Cardinals Manager Tony La Russa said Greg Maddux was only slightly better tonight in Game 6 than he was in Game 2 of the National League Championship Series. But, oh, what a difference it made.

title: A Spicier Mix, but Will the Voters Bite?
description: What Bob Dole wants the American electorate to do on Nov. 5 is quite straightforward: he wants it to fire Bill Clinton as the nation's Chief Executive, not something the country does casually.

title: The Spoken Word
description: JOHN LE CARRE, CHRISTOPHER DURANG AND NICKY SILVER, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. Two interview programs, both on Sunday at 8 P.M. Mr. Le Carre, the author, will be interviewed by George Plimpton. Mr. Durang and Mr. Silver, the playwrights, will be interviewed by Joy Behar. Tickets to each event, $18. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COUNTY SEAT STORES, Dallas, which has 740 casual clothing stores throughout the United States, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Company Is Under Inquiry On Prices for Heating Oil
description: A major petroleum company is under investigation over allegations that it bilked New York City out of $1 million by overcharging between 3 and 9 cents for each gallon of heating oil and diesel fuel it delivered, city officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Executives Back Dole Despite Clinton Record
description: If any class of Americans has reason to be content on the eve of this Presidential election, it is probably the nation's top executives. Nearly 9 of 10 say the condition of the economy is ''good,'' up from the nearly half who said so four years ago. A solid majority believes that inflation has been tamed, and many of the companies that the executives run have bullish plans to invest and hire new employees in the coming year, according to a new New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Despite Rumblings, Brown Isn't Looking Over Shoulder
description: Does Giants quarterback Dave Brown hear footsteps?

title: Editor in Chief to Leave Buzz Magazine
description: Allan Mayer, the editor in chief of Buzz, a Los Angeles city magazine, said this week that he would leave at the end of the month because of disputes with the parent company.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Jupiter's Wife

title: The Series Continues to Be Familiar Territory for Braves
description: EXCEPT FOR the St. Louis Cardinals and their partisans, people in and out of baseball looking forward to the World Series generally seemed to prefer the Atlanta Braves as the Yankees' opponents. Last night, they got what they wanted.

title: Now, Torre Can Plan For Atlanta
description: At least Joe Torre now knows where the Yankees will be staying on the road in the World Series. They have hotel rooms in Atlanta. They did not have rooms in St. Louis. Now Torre can plan his itinerary, after the Braves trounced the Cardinals, 15-0, in Game 7 of the National League Championship Series last night.

title: Peso Strengthens and Mexican Stocks Rise
description: Mexican stocks rose for a second day after the peso strengthened and the Bank of Mexico cut borrowing costs, raising hopes that company earnings would benefit.

title: Draft Charge Backfires
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLSTATE CORP. (ALL, N)
description: The Allstate Corporation reported a 34.5 percent decline in third-quarter earnings yesterday because of charges to reduce its earthquake insurance exposure in California and for asbestos and environmental cleanups.

title: Was It High Art or High Crime?
description: WHO needs full-frontal nudity? The most disturbing example of exposed flesh on a New York stage at the moment comes when Daniel Massey removes his gloves in ''Taking Sides,'' the new play by Ronald Harwood at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: Politics and Drug Use
description: To the Editor:

title: On Containing Nationalism in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Benjamin A. Trustman, 92, Lawyer and Florida Land Developer
description: Benjamin A. Trustman, a Boston lawyer and Florida land developer who shared his success to benefit the arts and education, died Oct. 9 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami. He was 92 and had lived in Miami Shores, Fla., since moving from Brookline, Mass., in the 1970's.

title: Investigation Is Widening Into Killing Of an Officer
description: Investigators yesterday questioned yet another person about the shooting death of an off-duty police officer in Brooklyn on Sunday, adding another layer of mystery to the incident, which occurred after at least two officers apparently undertook an unauthorized hunt for a suspected mugger.

title: Two Different Pleas for Change: Excerpts From a Second Senate Debate
description: Following are excerpts from last night's debate in Trenton between Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, and Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Profits Are Down At UPM-Kymmene
description: UPM-Kymmene of Finland, Europe's largest forestry-products maker, said yesterday that its profit after financial items fell to 2.672 billion markkaa, or $582 million, in the first eight months of 1996 from 4.565 billion markkaa, or $994 million, a year ago. Sales also fell, to 33.822 billion markkaa, from 35.616 billion a year ago. The decline in profitability was pronounced in the four months ending on Aug. 31 and is expected to remain on that level this for the year, the company said. (AFX News)

title: One Foe Remains for Yanks: The World Champion Braves
description: Tick, tock. Flip, flop. Joe Torre, undecided manager. With the Yankees' first World Series game in 15 years inching closer, Torre reclined in his office chair yesterday and said he had still not decided whether Kenny Rogers would be on the roster, whether Darryl Strawberry's fractured right big toe would prevent him from playing the outfield or whether Andy Pettitte or David Cone would start Game 1 tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium.

title: French Strike Slows Planes, Trains and Mail in Protesting Cuts
description: A nationwide public employees' strike in France hobbled air and rail service and left schools and post offices operating with reduced staffs today, but it widened rifts in unions about how firmly to resist spending cuts and hiring freezes the French Government says are necessary to get ready for a common European currency in 1999.

title: Art in Review
description: Idelle Weber

title: Isn't Soul Relevant?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Excuse for Bigotry in Georgia Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Home Video
description: Second Lives for TV Films

title: AT&T's Quarter Meets (Lowered) Expectations
description: The AT&T Corporation met Wall Street's recently diminished earnings expectations yesterday, reporting a profit from continuing operations in the third quarter of $1.36 billion, or 84 cents a share.

title: Fonar Settlement With Siemens
description: The Fonar Corporation has reached a settlement with Siemens Medical Systems Inc. on patent litigation related to magnetic resonance imaging technology.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Blue Chips Set Records, But Nasdaq Retreats 9.03

title: Decision Reduces Penalty On Chrysler in California
description: A California regulator yesterday ordered the Chrysler Corporation to halt shipments of cars and trucks to the state for 45 days -- rather than the 60 days that had been proposed -- as punishment for selling 116 used vehicles without disclosing that they had been repurchased under the state's ''lemon law.''

title: YELTSIN ANGRILY ANNOUNCES DISMISSAL OF AIDE HE HAILED AS A LIKELY POLITICAL HEIR
description: Four months after publicly embracing him as a political heir, President Boris N. Yeltsin angrily appeared on national television tonight and dismissed Aleksandr I. Lebed, his frank and aggressive national security chief.

title: How Japan Feeds the Cities, Starves the Farms  To the Editor:    Your Oct. 13 Week in Review article on why so many young people in Japan desert the country for the city takes up the minor reasons but ignores the major one.    As the producer of food, without which the city cannot survive for a day, the country has been indispensable. It still is, but the world trade in food gives people the illusion that if you don't produce food at home, you can always import. As a consequence, primary industries are rapidly losing profitability, and a result is the ''hollowing'' of the Japanese countryside.
description: You might do well to live in the Japanese countryside and farm, as I do, to perceive how the economic system works to depopulate the land, and how it also ''hollows'' the cities through a mechanism called ''urban redevelopment.''

title: Jury in Kelly Rape Case Hears Accuser's Father
description: The father of a young woman who says she was raped by Alex Kelly 10 years ago testified at his trial, describing how his daughter came home, distraught and ''panic-stricken,'' and said she had been attacked by the 18-year-old man, who was their neighbor in Darien, Conn.

title: Still Stubbornly Surly
description: Graham Parker is surly again. His new album, ''Acid Bubblegum'' (Razor and Tie), returns to the stubborn righteousness that has brought him loyal fans for 20 years. When he grew reflective on his previous album, ''12 Haunted Episodes,'' his admirers were bewildered; now he has new diatribes to offer. ''I don't appeal to the masses, and they don't appeal to me,'' he sang at Tramps on Tuesday night.

title: Kansas City Looks for Silver Lining
description: Jazz and food have always been hot in this city, home of Charlie (Bird) Parker and spicy barbecue. Lately the economy has been heating up, too, with a low unemployment rate and a high level of noise coming from new construction sites.

title: Lemaire Plans to Mix It Up With Goalies
description: A great practice put Jacques Lemaire in such a jovial mood today that he admitted to mishandling his goaltenders last season when the Devils failed to make the playoffs after winning the Stanley Cup in 1995.

title: From Spring Fever To Fall Classic
description: THE YANKEES whispered the magical words in February, way back when they were still developing personality and panache and still needed introductory name tags. Softly, wistfully, the magical words would spill out of someone's mouth.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SCOTT TUROW, whose new novel, ''The Laws of Our Fathers,'' is being published today, is seemingly everywhere this week: on ''The Charlie Rose Show'' and ''Good Morning America,'' with appearances yet to come on CNN, the weekend ''Today'' show and Court TV. Add to that book-signings and interviews with newspapers and radio stations around the country and in England and Canada.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The National Trust for Historic Preservation, which was founded in 1949, will have its first chairwoman on Sunday: NANCY N. CAMPBELL.

title: TDK Moves an Account To Ryan Drossman
description: The TDK Electronics Corporation in Port Washington, L.I., which makes audio, video and computer recording products, said yesterday that it had moved its integrated advertising and sales promotion account to Ryan Drossman & Partners in New York from Merkley Newman Harty, a unit of the Omnicom Group in New York. Billings were estimated at $8 million. Ryan Drossman was awarded the account, which had been handled by Merkley Newman since April 1995, without a review.

title: Dole Gives Impetus to Changing the Tax Code
description: In Bob Dole's rhetorical shorthand, the issue comes down to a few snappy phrases that draw sustained cheers whenever he uses them on the campaign trail: a tax system that is ''simpler, flatter and fairer,'' and ''ending the I.R.S. as we know it.''

title: View of Dole From '70
description: Declassified files show that an aide to President Richard M. Nixon said Senator Bob Dole made ''knee-jerk'' defenses of the President. That aide, Donald Rumsfeld, is a top Dole campaign official. Page A24.

title: Clinton, the Everyguy
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Obscure Is Society In a New Tale of Jude
description: Somewhere in the making of ''Jude,'' the new film based on Thomas Hardy's ''Jude the Obscure,'' the inevitability of tragedy seems to have been mislaid. So, when life delivers its cruelest, most devastating blow to the prideful Jude Fawley, his misfortune seems less the logic of ineluctable fate than the byproduct of a few ill-considered words.

title: Wall Street, usually thrilled by merger deals, shrugs at one.
description: DESPITE the general enthusiasm this bull market has offered for many takeover plans, analysts and investors yesterday registered displeasure with both a buyer and seller.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U. of Rhode Island Is Shaken by Players' Assault on Fraternity
description: An assault on a fraternity house by almost half of the University of Rhode Island football team left three fraternity members badly beaten and has left students, faculty members, the football coach and the university president shaken and incredulous at the ferocity of the attack.

title: Suffolk Officers Awarded Large Raise
description: An arbitrator this week awarded Suffolk County police officers an 18.6 percent wage increase over the next four years, raising fears among New York City officials that the increase might complicate negotiations with their officers and spur an exodus from the city force.

title: Reich and Kelly: Old Pals Are Friendly Rivals
description: This is how long Frank Reich and Jim Kelly played together: the Buffalo restaurant where they shared private Friday lunches sent the table and chairs to one of the four Super Bowls the Bills qualified for to help them feel at home.

title: 50 Arrested in Projects Sweep
description: A 200-officer task force swept through two Newark housing projects before dawn yesterday and arrested more than 50 men who had sold guns and heroin in the projects for months, the F.B.I. said.

title: Camden Schools Criticized
description: A state audit released yesterday concluded that the Camden school district was squandering almost $32 million a year and that its hiring practices were rife with nepotism.

title: Art in Review
description: Fred Sandback

title: Artificiality Vanquishes An Authenticity Issue
description: These days, Lorenzo Carcaterra's book ''Sleepers'' is known simply as ''the controversial best seller.'' That's a shorthand way of saying that when this tidily plotted New York story was published as a nonfiction memoir last year, it sounded more Hollywood than Hell's Kitchen and prompted instant skepticism about the author's conveniently cinematic vision.

title: Industrial Output Down In August in Japan
description: Japan's industrial production for August dropped 2.3 percent from the previous month, the second time in three months the key indicator of manufacturing strength has fallen, the Government said yesterday. The decline, which was worse than the 1.9 percent drop the Government announced in a preliminary report on Sept. 30, was a ''temporary'' setback for the economy, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. It was partly caused by exceptionally strong demand for personal computers in June and July, the ministry said.

title: Tax-Deferred Pay for Executives
description: The explosive growth of a form of executive pay known as deferred compensation, provided by at least 24,000 companies in the United States, has enriched high-paid executives, ruined retirement savings of middle managers and acted as a stealth tax on shareholders. Few, if any, of the practices described in a Times series on the subject this week look illegal. But some of the plans amount to self-serving manipulation by privileged top managers who care little for others in their companies.

title: Messages in Strong Images
description: Strong choreographic images dominated the program that Beth Coiner and Aleta Hayes shared on Tuesday night as part of the Splitstream series at Dance Theater Workshop. Both choreographers found it easier to make statements than to develop them.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17

title: Next Time, a Real Debate
description: Bob Dole said more than he knew when he opened the second Presidential debate by announcing that the Atlanta Braves were leading the St. Louis Cardinals in the baseball playoffs. Unscripted, suspenseful, the outcome clearly in doubt -- the baseball game was everything that this year's debates were not. The lack of suspense is partly due to President Clinton's lead in the polls and his telegenic advantages over Mr. Dole. But the debate formats defeated the civic purpose of the enterprise by precluding direct conflict between the candidates while permitting them to be as airy and evasive as they liked.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New York at Rush Hour: Cox Insists His Team Will Be Up to the Task
description: Bobby Cox was thinking out loud about what he and his colleagues would be doing in the next 24 hours or so.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Land and Freedom

title: Latest Data May Indicate The Economy Is Cooling Off
description: Policy makers and the financial markets received a flurry of new reports today suggesting that the economy was cooling from its overheated pace earlier this year.

title: No Headline
description: ''This paper absolutely pinpoints that mutations in lung cancer are caused by a carcinogen in cigarette smoke. It is the smoking gun that makes the connection.''

title: For White House, Lebed's Dismissal Is a Case of Dogs Fighting Under a Carpet
description: Senior American officials have long expected that President Boris N. Yeltsin would eventually oust his national security chief, Aleksandr I. Lebed, but they were surprised by the timing, several said today.

title: Business is Top Campaign Donor
description: A new study of campaign finance, one of the most comprehensive to date, projects that this year, the Presedential race will cost three times more than it did in 1992, and that despite Republican complaints about organized labor's campaign spending, business is by far the largest source of money for all candidates. Article, page A26.

title: Fathers' Phone Conversation Is Disclosed at Trial for Rape
description: Minutes after a 16-year-old girl told her family 10 years ago that she had been raped by an 18-year-old neighbor named Alex Kelly, her father called Mr. Kelly's father.

title: Sulzer to Cut Jobs At Machinery Unit
description: Sulzer A.G. said yesterday that it planned to cut almost a third of its work force at its weaving machinery unit. Sulzer, the third Swiss weaving machinery maker to slash jobs in a shrinking market, will cut a higher-than-expected 950 jobs out of 3,100 at its Rueti unit. That is the fifth major job-cutting program announced in Switzerland this year, a country that had until recently been unaccustomed to mass layoffs.

title: The Republican Error
description: Bob Dole made a fairly good try to list the ethical faults of President Clinton as reasons Americans should not give him a second term. But Mr. Dole did not present reasons to vote for himself that are likely to change what Americans think each candidate could mean to their lives -- faults and virtues all taken into account.

title: Final Approval for Stadium
description: A 6,000-seat minor league baseball stadium will be built on the site of a park along the Newark waterfront after all. Both the City Council and the Essex County Board of Freeholders gave final approval Wednesday to a $22 million project, financed by both the city and the county, that also includes a soccer stadium and a new park.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Sites of Chinatown'

title: HOME HEALTH CARE COMPANY BOUGHT FOR $154.1 MILLION
description: Integrated Health Services Inc. has purchased First American Health Care of Georgia Inc. for $154.1 million. Under the accord, First American agreed to pay $255 million to settle charges that it defrauded Medicare. The purchase makes Integrated Health the fourth-largest provider of home health care services in the country. In February, First American and two of its officers were convicted of Medicare fraud in Federal court in Savannah, Ga. Integrated Health could pay as much as an additional $159.1 million for the closely held First American between 2000 and 2004 if First American meets specified financial goals. Integrated Health, based in Owings Mills, Md., operates about 195 offices in 40 states.

title: Farewell, for Now, to Mr. Lebed
description: A healthier Boris Yeltsin might have prevented the turmoil in his Cabinet and put Aleksandr Lebed's abrasive leadership style to good use. But President Yeltsin is now too weak to quell the ruinous discord in the Kremlin through subtler forms of persuasion, so yesterday he took a shortcut to unity and fired Mr. Lebed.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP. (BT,N)
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that gains in investment banking revenue helped lift its third-quarter profits nearly 14 percent, continuing the industry's trend of solid growth for the three months ended Sept. 30.

title: Bowe to Try Golota Again
description: After his controversial victory over Andrew Golota last summer, Riddick Bowe said he couldn't even go home without hearing about how poorly he had fought. His mother and his nieces and nephews were there to tell Bowe that he was losing when Golota was disqualified for low blows in the seventh round.

title: For Children
description: Just thinking about the World Wide Web for children can make you edgy. So much information! Too many sites! Turn the computer off and read a book instead! But wait, if you take it slowly, one site at a time, you realize that the Web is useful for helping with homework and making pen pals.

title: Virus Linked To Colds May Cure Cancer, Scientists Say
description: Can the virus that causes the common cold also cure cancer? A company that has exploited an odd link between the mildest and the most serious of diseases hopes the answer may be yes.

title: A Clinton Foray Into Republican Territory
description: Charging out of the final campaign debate, President Clinton led a rousing rally today in Ronald Reagan's old bastion of Orange County and began broadcasting a new television commercial in which Mr. Reagan's former press secretary says Mr. Clinton ''had the integrity to do what was right'' in fighting for gun control.

title: Loroupe to Defend Title
description: TEGLA LOROUPE of Kenya will go for her third consecutive title as the women's winner of the New York City Marathon, it was announced yesterday. The marathon is Nov. 3.

title: Sifting Among the Icons for the Key to Johns
description: ONE of the works in the Jasper Johns retrospective opening Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art is a painting from 1961, about the size of a paperback, easy to miss among all the early targets and flags. ''Painting Bitten by a Man,'' like those famous icons, is what its title says: Mr. Johns, or someone, actually took a bite out of the picture, leaving scraped tooth marks, like fossil remains, in the paint. It is not the literalness or the goofy Buster Keatonish humor that's startling. It's the violence: the image takes a moment to decipher, then recalls Francis Bacon's screaming pope but with the scream disembodied, floating eerily in a viscous, slightly sickly gray-green field.

title: Some Final Goodbyes For a Fordham Player
description: On the day Bill Tierney was laid to rest, the broad-shouldered men from Fordham University, football players in suits and ties on a Thursday morning, squeezed into their seats in a packed church to take another step in a time that began when a teammate fell and their lives were changed forever.

title: Spain's Iberia Poised For Profitable Year
description: The Spanish state carrier, Iberia Airlines, earned 10.9 billion pesetas, or $83.8 million, in the first eight months of the year and expects to end 1996 with its first full-year profit since 1989, said Iberia's new president, Xabier de Irala. Iberia foresees a profit of almost 11 billion pesetas for the full year, far more than the 1.5 billion pesetas expected in the reorganization plan that helped turn the company around.

title: Not Even Close: Braves Bronx-Bound After Routing Cards
description: In the hours leading up to Game 7 of the National League Championship Series, most of the talk centered on Braves pitcher Tom Glavine and whether his talented left arm would dominate the St. Louis Cardinals and lead Atlanta to a second straight World Series.

title: Peronists Shun a Rally Honoring Their Founder
description: On this day in past years, masses of Argentines filled the Plaza de Mayo across from the presidential palace to celebrate the events of a night more than five decades ago. On that night, a multitude of workers gathered here to demand that the military Government release Juan Domingo Peron.

title: End of the Road
description: For Clinton-haters it must have been a hard night. For four years they had worked to destroy Bill Clinton's legitimacy as President, growing ever shriller. Now their chosen instrument in the election, Bob Dole, was visibly failing the challenge.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Primal Fear

title: From le Carre, a Tailor Stitching Suits and Intrigue
description: THE TAILOR OF PANAMA

title: The Best Of the World In the Bronx
description: When the Yankees open the World Series tomorrow night, it will be the 87th Series game at Yankee Stadium, which has had more Series memories and moments than any other ball park. And not all were in the Yankees' favor. Here is one man's opinion of the 10 most theatrical Series memories and moments in Stadium history:

title: Wintery Night In Red Square, And Sadness About Lebed
description: There was winter in the air in Red Square tonight, but no fear. Police officers, under orders from Russia's Interior Ministry to increase patrols in Moscow and tighten security at major buildings, shooed reporters away from Lenin's Tomb. But they weren't very vigorous about it.

title: Percussion To Set Feet Dancing
description: As a guitarist, Carlos Santana uses just a few well-worn gambits. He learned keening notes from B. B. King and cascading arpeggios from John Coltrane; he also plays terse melodic phrases and speedy runs. Most of the material for his band, Santana, is two-chord vamps in rock or salsa rhythms, with an occasional blues-based tune. But on Wednesday night at the Beacon Theater, in the middle of a three-night stand, that was all Santana needed to spin out nearly three hours of exhilarating music.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Denise Calls Up

title: Among Glossy Blondes, a Showcase for Brazil's Black Faces
description: Glancing at the rows of magazines lining any newsstand in Brazil, a stranger could mistake this racial rainbow of a country for a Nordic outpost. Slender blondes smile from the covers of fashion magazines, and white faces dominate all but the sports glossies.

title: Love and the Big City, Equally Baffling
description: ''Ed's Next Move'' is an eager little film about Ed (Matt Ross), who comes to New York from Wisconsin and is comically nonplused by big-city ways. He is confounded by unfriendly women, neighbors who aren't neighborly and the strange vegetables and buffalo steaks at Balducci's. What's worse, New Yorkers have no understanding of Ed or where he comes from. Either they confuse Wisconsin with Wyoming or they ask him about cheese.

title: Kelly's Decades Of Distillations
description: SOMETIMES it is true, the emperor has no clothes, or at least not enough to provide adequate coverage. This is the impression often made by Ellsworth Kelly's large and lavish retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum, a show that can move back and forth from ravishing and brilliant to hollow and bland in nearly the blink of an eye.

title: A Solution on Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: Los Angeles Foundation Honors 10 Writers
description: The winners of this year's Lannan Literary Awards include five poets: Anne Carson, Lucille Clifton, Donald Justice, Howard Norman and R. S. Thomas. The fiction writers Tim Pears, William Trevor and David Foster Wallace were also honored, and David Abram and Charles Bowden won prizes for nonfiction.

title: Armor All Buying Car-Rex
description: The Armor All Products Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Car-Rex, a German maker of automotive chemicals, for an undisclosed price. Armor All, a maker of automotive appearance products, said it would merge Car-Rex into its German operations. Car-Rex had 1995 sales of $250 million. Car-Rex, a unit of Werner & Mertz, makes car appearance products, coolants, air freshener and antifreeze.

title: Berthold Goldschmidt, 93; Composer Who Fled Nazis
description: Berthold Goldschmidt, a British composer and conductor of German birth, whose lyrical and often lavishly orchestrated music has been rediscovered in recent decades by both European and American performers after decades of obscurity, died yesterday at his home in London. He was 93.

title: Art in Review
description: Nancy Spero

title: How Japan Feeds the Cities, Starves the Farms
description: To the Editor:

title: Crossroad of Art and Life Where Rap Meets Ballet
description: The choreographer Karole Armitage, like Bertolt Brecht, apparently has something to say about the imperfections of capitalism. But unlike Brecht, a Marxist who was always cogent, Ms. Armitage is a product of an era without ideology.

title: Rangers' Emotions Run High For Blues
description: Some college football coaches motivate players by posting a schedule with a few important games printed in red ink. This is to encourage peak emotion against top rivals.

title: $25 and Under
description: With the first frost of fall comes the instinctive desire for warmth, which requires shelter, food or both. And few people have had as much practice fighting the cold as the Russians.

title: Nets Mulling McDaniel Deal
description: The Nets want the free agent Xavier McDaniel enough to discuss a one-year offer believed to be just above the league minimum of $247,500, but seemed hesitant about wanting to close the deal today.

title: Nixon Memo Criticizes Dole Defenses As 'Knee Jerk'
description: In 1970, a 38-year-old White House aide told President Richard M. Nixon that Senator Bob Dole's ''knee-jerk'' defense of the Nixon Administration was eroding Mr. Dole's credibility as the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a study of television violence omitted a word from a quotation by Vicky Rideout, an official of an advocacy group called Children Now, reversing her meaning. Ms. Rideout said, ''I'm quite concerned that out of 32 children's programs they find only 5 that have no violence.''

title: Business Is Biggest Political Donor, Dwarfing Labor's Contribution, Study Says
description: In one of the most comprehensive studies to date, a private research group projected today that this year's Presidential race would cost $800 million, three times as much as the 1992 campaign, and that another $800 million would be spent on Congressional races.

title: Where Trio Got Its Start
description: The 92d Street Y was the obvious place for the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio to commemorate its 20th anniversary on Tuesday night. It was there that the pianist Joseph Kalichstein, the violinist Jaime Laredo and the cellist Sharon Robinson first performed together in 1975, though their partnership resulted from a last-minute cancellation by the pianist Rudolf Firkusny.

title: The View From New York
description: After a 15-year drought, the Bronx once again plays host to the World Series, and today's preview looks at classic Yankees, present and past. Page B1.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Nuclear Lab To Pay U.S. To Settle Case
description: The University of California has agreed to pay the Federal Government more than $2.7 million for mismanagement of Federal money by Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, officials said today.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 8
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Inside Photography
description: Who knows if the photographer Tseng Kwong Chi would have created his wickedly surrealistic persona -- the enigmatic Chinese in what appears to be a Mao suit as the post-modern Everyman -- if a certain maitre d'hotel in a touristy Manhattan restaurant hadn't treated him the way he did when Tseng showed up in his distinctive uniform.

title: McDonnell Douglas Reports Earnings Are Up by 1.6%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 1.6 percent on improved performance by its military and commercial aircraft businesses.

title: Speak Softly, Run Swiftly, Swing Powerfully
description: BERNIE WILLIAMS, the quiet, erudite center fielder for the Yankees, might have been the last person on the 1996 pennant-winning team you would expect to turn boisterous.

title: In Asia, a War of Past and Present
description: We're so accustomed to thinking of Asian art in terms of its great classical past that a show of new, ''live'' work from the heart of this explosively changing continent is enough to bring on a bout of culture shock. True, in recent years live Asian artists have found a place on the New York scene, but their contributions have been more Western-oriented (no pun intended). And seen piecemeal, they don't have the pizazz of an overall presentation like ''Contemporary Art in Asia: Traditions/Tensions.''

title: British Air Plans Revamping of Unit
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that it planned to revamp its struggling German unit, Deutsche B.A., focusing on domestic flights at the expense of unprofitable international routes. The changes will be accompanied by a reshuffling of Deutsche B.A.'s management. Two senior British Air managers will take on leading positions at the German airline.

title: Dairy Strike Divides 2 Teamsters' Locals
description: A 10-month-long strike against a New Jersey dairy has produced an unusual rift in the teamsters local that represents the striking workers, as the members have mutinied against their leaders and petitioned to oust them.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Big is back. At Maloney & Porcelli in midtown Manhattan, each portion would easily feed three. Everything is oversize at the new Red Eye Grill, too. The handsome restaurant opened a week ago in a space so large that the women seated next to me worried there might never be enough customers to fill it up.

title: MTV takes a breather from the future to review its winning ads.
description: THE cable television network that cultivates an image of being relentlessly focused on the future is taking a rare look back at its past.

title: On Talk Radio, Bob Dole Just Took Off the Gloves
description: Bob from Russell, Kan., was on the line.

title: Gore, Kemp and No Politics for Dinner
description: The annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner has become such a hallowed obligation of Presidential politics that even John Cardinal O'Connor, the host of the event, seemed to forget last night that the two Presidential candidates were not invited this year, a decision in which he played a role.

title: Powerless Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Trans-Atlantic Mix of Parallels and Contrasts
description: THE show ''Views From Abroad: European Perspectives on American Art II,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the second in a series of three exhibitions intended to introduce a dash of trans-Atlantic dialogue into New York's premier bastion of all-American art.

title: Dole Unleashes His Tough Talk On Immigration
description: Diving into social issues he had avoided for most of this campaign, Bob Dole today asserted that President Clinton had bowed to ''militant special interests'' in fighting efforts to ''guard this nation's borders.'' Mr. Dole assailed Mr. Clinton for fighting efforts to cut government medical care for illegal immigrants with AIDS and to bar children of illegal immigrants from public schools.

title: New York City Sues Big Tobacco Companies to Recoup Health Costs
description: New York City sued the major tobacco companies yesterday to recoup the billions of dollars that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the city has spent to care for people with illnesses caused by smoking.

title: KCS ENERGY BUYING OIL AND GAS COMPANY FOR $175 MILLION
description: KCS Energy Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to buy the Intercoast Oil and Gas Company from the MidAmerican Energy Company for $174 million in cash. KCS will also pay MidAmerican a $40 million note and 610,000 warrants on KCS common stock. Intercoast Oil and Gas's holdings include natural gas and oil reserves and 22,000 undeveloped acres in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma and two natural gas marketing units. KCS, based in Edison, N.J., said the acquisition would expand its natural gas and oil base and double its average daily production and its reserves. MidAmerican is a holding company based in Des Moines.

title: Omnicom Forms European Media Unit
description: The Omnicom Group has joined the European media service operations of BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide under an umbrella operation named Optimum Media Direction. The new unit will help handle media services for accounts in 20 countries with billings estimated at $7.1 billion.

title: Looking for a Life but Finding L.A.
description: Mike (Jon Favreau), the loser hero of Doug Liman's irresistible ''Swingers,'' wants to be a stand-up comic and carries business cards with the logo from Groucho Marx's ''You Bet Your Life.'' Too often, in the circles in which Mike tries to travel, this is mistaken for Donald Duck. And it often happens that Mike means to be suave and winds up totally misunderstood. That's the basis for this film's inverted sense of high style, which has such fun with its characters' awkwardness that it turns their square-peg ethos into counter-cool.

title: Houston Is Finally Taking Aim
description: Two games into the preseason, Allan Houston did not feel like himself on the court. He was trying to fit in too much, to be a part of the crowd. He would force the ball inside and pass up open shots instead of merely squaring his body and letting his jumper fly.

title: Daimler Studying Integration of Mercedes
description: The giant German industrial holding company Daimler-Benz A.G. is considering a plan under which its Mercedes-Benz automotive unit would be fully integrated into the parent company, people close to the company said yesterday. Daimler-Benz's chief, Jurgen Schrempp, said earlier this year that he was studying a restructuring of Daimler to make it more responsive and to increase quality.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Remember LORENA BOBBITT? The woman who earned her 15 minutes of fame -- and then some -- when she sliced off her husband's penis in 1993 and was found not guilty by reason of insanity. Mrs. Bobbitt was photographed by Reuters in Ecuador this week having lunch with President ABDALA BUCARAM at the presidential palace in Quito. The president and Mrs. Bobbitt, who was born in Ecuador, will become godparents this week for the daughter of a Quito couple. NADINE BROZAN

title: Queens Contractor Is Accused Of Fraud in Painting Schools
description: A prominent New York City contractor was charged yesterday with defrauding the city on a multimillion-dollar contract to paint hundreds of classrooms in 1995, prosecutors said.

title: Hingis Drives On
description: In the last few weeks she has shopped for a new horse and won a Porsche along with her first professional singles title at Filderstadt, Germany. Now MARTINA HINGIS, the 16-year-old Swiss phenom who reached the United States Open semifinals last month, has become the third-youngest player ever to qualify for the year-end Chase Championships. The Nov. 18-24 event at Madison Square Garden is open only to the top 16 players. Hingis, ranked ninth, qualified by reaching the quarterfinals this week at Zurich.

title: Baseball's Big Show, the Fox Way
description: Baseball's playoff broadcasts proved one thing: NBC and Fox live in different universes. Whereas NBC steadfastly shunned video game-like graphics for a clean, standard approach, Fox has embraced a bevy of toys.

title: A Whisky-Golden Time
description: The news came by telephone, a day before last call. The Lion's Head was closing and the old crowd was gathering on Saturday night to say goodbye. Please come, I was asked. I said I would try.

title: Former Ziegfeld Follies Girl Recalls the Glory Days
description: A pretty girl is like a melody.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Study Finds Few Women In 5 Highest Company Jobs
description: What has long been suspected has now been proven: The top of corporate America is a no woman's land.

title: A.R. Baron Agrees To Settle S.E.C. Case
description: A. R. Baron & Company, a small stock firm that went out of business after the Securities and Exchange Commission charged it with numerous violations of securities laws, agreed yesterday to settle the S.E.C. case against it.

title: Bowing Out With Head High
description: Ozzie Smith made his final appearance of his 19-year career in the sixth inning tonight. When he stepped to the plate in the sixth inning as a pinch-hitter, he tipped his helmet to the crowd at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium and received a standing ovation.

title: Teen-Ager Is Convicted in Token Clerk's Murder
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was convicted of murder yesterday in the death of a subway token clerk whose booth was set afire during a robbery attempt.

title: On Containing Nationalism in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Executives Step Down at Archer Daniels
description: Two senior executives with the Archer Daniels Midland Company -- including Michael D. Andreas, son of the company's powerful chairman -- have stepped down from their jobs in light of a continuing Federal investigation of their possible involvement in price-fixing at the company, a board member said today.

title: Top Democrat Proposes Plan On Preschool Access for All
description: The top Democratic leader in the General Assembly today proposed making preschool available to every 4-year-old in the state, saying that it would ultimately save tens of millions of dollars on education, social programs and prisons.

title: Walter Sencer, 75, Professor at Mt. Sinai
description: Walter Sencer, a neurologist and psychiatrist long associated with Mount Sinai Hospital and School of Medicine, died at the hospital on Monday. He was 75 and lived on the Upper East Side, where he was in private practice for the last 38 years.

title: Bailey's Record Ratified
description: The Canadian sprinter DONOVAN BAILEY's world indoor 50-meter record was ratified yesterday in Monte Carlo, Monaco, eight months after he set it. The International Amateur Athletic Federation approved the record of 5.56 seconds set by Bailey at the Reno Air Games on Feb. 9. (AP)

title: Lagardere Shares Surge On Thomson Purchase
description: Shares in Lagardere SCA surged to a six-year high yesterday after the French Government approved Lagardere's bid to acquire Thomson S.A. on Wednesday. The acquisition of the state-owned Thomson puts Lagardere into the big leagues of the global military industry. Shares of Lagardere rose 23.7 percent, to 165 francs, yesterday. Lagardere plans to sell Thomson Multimedia, Thomson's wholly owned consumer electronics unit, which makes RCA televisions and VCR's and has 14 billion francs in debt to the Daewoo Electronics Corporation of Korea. Daewoo has promised to double the number of jobs in France and invest in the country. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: New York City Sues Tobacco Companies
description: New York City sued the major tobacco companies yesterday to recoup the billions of dollars that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the city has spent to care for people with illnesses caused by smoking.

title: Humor and Energy in Team's Second Spot
description: Standing in the aisle of the Rosebud Theater, the woman at the microphone recently asked a brutally blunt question of Pat Choate, the Vice-Presidential half of Ross Perot's Reform Party ticket: With Mr. Perot's single-digit standing in the polls, how did the two of them plan, after the election, to champion their ideas of fiscal responsibility?

title: Questions of Presidential Character Go Begging
description: To the Editor:

title: Images That Won't Let Go of the Eye
description: Seven years ago, Mary Ellen Mark went to the Great Famous Circus in Calcutta, India, and took a picture of twin dwarfs, Tulsi and Basant, dressed in gorilla suits. In the picture, one twin has his gorilla mask on and cradles a puppy in his arms; the other brother carries his gorilla mask in front of him, so we can see his human head. Of the four faces visible in the portrait -- one human, two gorilla, one dog -- the human face is most disquieting.

title: Corrections
description: A brief theater review on Monday about the musical revue ''Americana'' misstated the given name of an actress in the cast. She is Melanie Farrow, not Melinda.

title: Corrections
description: The Metropolitan Almanac section of the Weather Report yesterday misstated the time of last night's sunset. It was 6:12, not 8:12.

title: LIBERTY MUTUAL BUYING BRAZILIAN INSURER
description: The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company agreed yesterday to buy Paulista de Seguros for $105 million, giving the United States company a foothold in Brazil's expanding insurance market. Controlling shareholders of Paulista Seguros, Brazil's seventh-largest insurer, have agreed to sell their 68 percent stake. Liberty Mutual will offer to buy the shares of about 300 minority stockholders, Antonio Carlos Pereira de Almeida, a vice president of Paulista Seguros, said. Liberty Mutual, based in Boston, is one of the biggest providers of workers' compensation insurance in the United States.

title: Clinton Appearance Planned
description: Apparently not taking his lead among New Jersey voters for granted, President Clinton will return to the state on Sunday. He plans to attend services at the New Hope Baptist Church in Newark and a Democratic Party fund-raiser in Teaneck, the White House said yesterday.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: A General on His Own
description: Cocky and unbowed, Aleksandr I. Lebed announced his presidential ambitions only three hours after President Boris N. Yeltsin angrily dismissed him as national security adviser.

title: INSIDE
description: Zimmer and Torricelli Debate

title: More Town Houses Rise in Raritan Township, N.J.
description: Banking on location, architecture and competitive pricing, a New Jersey developer is building a large town house development in this Hunterdon County community, which has seen its countryside blanketed with attached housing in the last decade.

title: Ex-Pitcher Sentenced
description: JOHN D'ACQUISTO, 44, a former major league pitcher, was sentenced yesterday to 63 months in prison for trying to pass off a forged $200 million certificate of deposit as collateral on a deal with Prudential Securities in New York. The right-hander, who lives in San Diego, pitched for the Giants, Cardinals, Padres, Angels and Athletics from 1973-1982. He was convicted July 3 on one count of conspiracy, one count of uttering a forged security and two counts of wire fraud. (AP)

title: Man Charged in Faking of Nursing Credentials
description: A 36-year-old man who worked for 13 years as a nurse at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Manhattan was accused yesterday of faking credentials to secure his job and win a promotion, according to a complaint filed in Federal Court in Manhattan.

title: On Ukraine's Capitalist Path, Clique Mans Roadblocks
description: Once a closed industrial complex that harbored the Soviet Union's deadliest secrets, this city no longer makes the nuclear missiles that the West lived in fear of. But another danger is emerging here, one that the West and many Ukrainians believe may harm Ukraine itself.

title: After War and Blockade, Crime Frays Life in Iraq
description: The killers got caught because one of them did not mourn.

title: Pearson Picks An American As Executive
description: Marjorie M. Scardino, chief executive of the Economist Group, which publishes The Economist magazine, was named chief executive yesterday of Pearson P.L.C., the British media conglomerate that owns 50 percent of the Economist Group.

title: Harsh Tone Of Campaign Becomes Issue
description: With the election less than three weeks off, last night's debate between the United States Senate candidates in New Jersey focused as much on the tone of the campaign itself as on issues like Medicare and the environment.

title: Officers' Trial in Slaying Stirs Racial Tensions
description: Jonny E. Gammage died in the early morning of Oct. 12, 1995, minutes after the police pulled over the dark blue Jaguar he was driving. On that, everyone agrees.

title: Questions on Ethics Lead to Review of Needle-Exchange Study
description: The National Institutes of Health said today that it would review a needle exchange study it had agreed to sponsor in Alaska after a consumer health group charged that the research was unethical.

title: Tackling the Mysteries Of Human Chemistry
description: Connection is the theme shared by the two one-act plays that John Patrick Shanley has written, directed and assembled under the title ''Missing/Kissing.''

title: Hannah Green, 69, an Author Who Pursued Perfection, Dies
description: Hannah Green, an acclaimed author who wrote one slender novel of such delicately distilled perfection that she could hardly bring herself to compose another, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital in Manhattan, six months after the reissue of her classic work, ''The Dead of the House,'' had been received with almost as much critical enthusiasm as its original publication a generation ago. She was 69 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Credit on Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Maverick Official Quits
description: KEITH GRANT, the Dallas Mavericks' vice president for operations, who had been with the team since its inception 16 years ago, resigned yesterday, three months after being promoted into the position, citing ''an element of burnout.''

title: Adshel Acquires SHF Communications
description: Adshel in London, an outdoor advertising division of More O'Ferrall P.L.C., said yesterday that it had acquired SHF Communications in New York, which specializes in advertising on so-called street furniture like bus shelters and kiosks. The purchase price was $4.5 million.

title: Restaurants
description: Some nights, Jim Mamary stands on the sidewalk in front of his half-empty Sanzin, staring sadly at the people spilling out of Kin Khao across the street. ''I am Stanley Tucci,'' says the 37-year-old restaurateur.

title: A 15-0 Breeze Caps Comeback by Braves
description: The Atlanta Braves, who are to 1990's baseball what the Yankees were for decades, won a seventh-game showdown last night and a trip to New York for the opening of the World Series against the Yankees tomorrow night.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Joe R. Micheletto misstated the name of the company he will head. It is Ralcorp Holdings Inc., not Railcorp.

title: The Same Old Islanders Return to the Coliseum
description: Islanders Coach Mike Milbury was wary of a letdown. His concerns were well justified.

title: The Great Buddhas Wait, Knowing Nothing Lasts
description: In the last 20 years, the Great Buddhas of Bamiyan have been silent sentinels to great turbulence in this valley high in the Hindu Kush.

title: A World And a Wife Collapsing
description: Arthur Miller's ''Broken Glass,'' Sunday's ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation, is troubling in ways that the playwright undoubtedly didn't intend. Set in Brooklyn in 1938, the story juggles monumental tragedy, namely the Holocaust, with the personally unsettling but relatively trivial specter of sexual impotence. The juxtaposition is more often jarring than illuminating.

title: For Both Camps in Final Debate, Hopes, Risks and a Few Surprises
description: ''We're going to tear his face off,'' Scott Reed, the Dole campaign manager, said of the President of the United States in a burst of bravado on the eve of the final Presidential debate.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: History

title: California Journal: A Name to Reckon With
description: When The Wall Street Journal decided to add a special section to its California edition called California Journal, it ran into a little problem that Easterners have encountered for years out West: someone else was there first.

title: Wilson to Take the Field As Mets' First-Base Coach
description: Mookie Wilson, a member of the 1986 world championship Mets and a recent inductee to the club's Hall of Fame, will be part of Bobby Valentine's coaching staff next season.

title: On Their Environmental Records, It Looks Like a Close Contest
description: New Jersey has more than its share of toxic-waste sites, and its defining geographic characteristic -- a long, appealing ocean shoreline -- is threatened by offshore dumping. So it is no wonder that New Jersey voters are concerned about the environment, as are, by extension, its politicians.

title: Prosecutors Backed on DNA
description: For the first time, an appeals court ruled yesterday that evidence from DNA testing could be used to help prosecutors prove the guilt of an accused person. The three-judge panel ruled that DNA evidence had been properly used to prove that Morey Marcus had stabbed a woman in 1989 at a gas station in Rutherford, The Associated Press reported.

title: Corrections
description: The technology column in Business Day on Sept. 30 about astrology enthusiasts who attribute technological mishaps to the motions of the planet Mercury misspelled the name of an ancient Roman architect who described planetary orbits by comparing them to ants crawling on a potter's wheel. He was Vitruvius, not Visuvius.

title: At Silicon Graphics, a Surprise Loss
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. today reported a loss for its first quarter, surprising analysts who had expected a profit even after the company warned last month that its results would fall below their estimates.

title: Art in Review
description: 'The Evidence of Things Not Seen'

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: A Different Kind of Yankee Team
description: EVERYBODY knows there's no crying in baseball. That's what the man told one of the female players in the movie ''A League of Their Own.''

title: New Jerseyans Are Big Givers
description: New Jersey residents have contributed more generously to Presidential and Congressional candidates than residents of all but four other states, a nonpartisan group said yesterday.

title: Police Arrest Brooklyn Man On F.B.I.'s Most Wanted List
description: A man who was on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 Most Wanted List as a suspect in the killing of three people in Bridgeport, Conn., was captured by Federal agents and New York City police officers when they raided a Brooklyn apartment Wednesday night.

title: From Babe to Reggie, Some Yankees Series Memories
description: Starting tomorrow night, the Yankees will be playing in their 34th World Series in the last 75 years, by far the most of any team. Many of those appearances have provided some of the most memorable moments in the entire history of the World Series. Often, those moments have overshadowed other ones that were not only worth noting, but sometimes proved just as critical in Series history.

title: COCA-COLA EXTENDS ITS BUYBACK OF STOCK
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would repurchase as much as 10 percent of its shares in the next 10 years. The new plan authorizes buying back 206 million shares through 2006. Coke has about 44 million shares remaining in its existing repurchase program, increasing its planned buyback to a quarter of a billion shares. Coca-Cola has long been a buyer of its own stock. Since 1984, Coke has repurchased more than 987 million shares, or about 30 percent of its shares, for about $10 each, or $10 billion. Shares of Coke rose 75 cents yesterday, to $49.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Coke would need to spend $12.3 billion to complete its repurchase.

title: Cigar Is Stepping Gingerly On Way to the Cup Classic
description: An international field of 90 thoroughbreds was pre-entered yesterday for the seven races of the Breeders' Cup, including two whose owners paid $200,000 each as a supplemental fee. But the star of the show was the great Cigar, who will try to become the first repeat winner of the Breeders' Cup Classic since the races were begun 12 years ago.

title: All Work For Golfers On Bubble At Disney
description: On the surface, everything is placid and palmy here at Disney World. Pink-skinned tourists are towing kids wearing mouse ears around the Magic Kingdom, the monorails are running on time and the cash registers are whirring.

title: Disregarding The 'Dangers' Of the Bronx
description: MORE than 57,000 people are about to put themselves in mortal peril in the South Bronx, and no one in charge of this city seems to care. They are the fans who, weather permitting, will flock to River Avenue and 161st Street tomorrow night for the first World Series game at Yankee Stadium in 15 years.

title: DIRECT LINK FOUND BETWEEN SMOKING AND LUNG CANCER
description: A team of researchers says it has found a direct scientific link between smoking and lung cancer, a discovery that adds yet another piece to the already substantial evidence that tobacco smoking is a cause of cancer.

title: Raider Fined $50,000
description: Oakland Raiders guard STEVE WISNIEWSKI was fined $50,000 by the National Football League yesterday for two on-field incidents. Wisniewski was fined $30,000 for his third unnecessary roughness penalty of the season. In the fourth quarter of Sunday's game with Detroit, he was penalized for launching himself into a Lion player in a downfield pileup after a pass play.

title: Oh, What Sharp Razors You Have, Grandma
description: If Jakob and Wilhelm Grimm were resurrected, it would be no surprise to find them in Hollywood, making films like ''Freeway.''

title: Robertson Is Convicted
description: Jurors in San Antonio have convicted ALVIN ROBERTSON, a former National Basketball Association All-Star, of one count of burglary stemming from a rampage at his ex-girlfriend's apartment. A seven-man, five-woman jury returned its verdict yesterday afternoon. The trial's punishment phase will begin Monday.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: An Enduring Taste for Williams

title: Savagery Beyond Sense
description: Carlton Brown was trying to piece together a living. He already had a daughter and his girlfriend was eight and a half months pregnant. This was back in August 1992. Mr. Brown, who was 28 years old, drove a passenger van, carrying people along bus routes in Brooklyn for a dollar a ride. The private vans were popular. They were cheaper, more dependable and more comfortable than the city buses. They were also illegal, so the police kept an eye on them.

title: Treasury Issues Post Price Rise
description: Buyers returned to the Treasury market yesterday, bidding up prices, after an avalanche of economic data suggested growth was slowing with little chance of inflation's accelerating.

title: Gone but Not Forgotten
description: ''To Gillian on Her 37th Birthday'' begins with the sight of a couple, David Lewis (Peter Gallagher) and his wife, Gillian (Michelle Pfeiffer), frolicking in the surf. They wear matching khakis and white shirts, looking handsome and misleadingly happy, since Gillian is actually dead.

title: If Tomatoes Could Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbus's Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutbacks at Lehman
description: Lehman Brothers Inc. is shutting its precious metals trading business and dismissing eight people, a spokesman, Bill Ahearn, said yesterday. ''We're focusing on the markets in which we have a really strong position or the opportunity to increase our position,'' Mr. Ahearn said. The company also laid off three workers from its natural gas derivatives team. Mr. Ahearn said the ''internal shift of assets'' reflected an increased focus at Lehman on trading in base metals and oil instead of in precious metals or natural gas. He would not say how much money the commodities unit, makes.

title: Difficult Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: YELTSIN IS BACKED ON LEBED'S OUSTER
description: Russian leaders, from prominent Communists to the most ardent proponents of the free market, joined in rare unity today to support President Boris N. Yeltsin's decision to dismiss Aleksandr I. Lebed, whom they all view warily as a rival for power. Most said the action would bring desperately needed stability at a time when Mr. Yeltsin's future ability to govern remains in grave doubt.

title: Beliefs
description: No one disputes the idea that real evil sometimes produces extraordinary good; it just does not happen often enough. But one recent case is dramatic: the surge of generosity and solidarity arising from the blackened beams and smoking cinders of burned African-American churches.

title: No Headline
description: ''If we'd had a really poor crop, I guess the tendency might be to try to blame it on someone, maybe blame the current Administration. But when the crop is this good, we don't care who's in power.''

title: Ted Turner Denies Push To Drop Fox
description: Ted Turner, the cable entrepreneur who recently sold Turner Broadcasting to Time Warner Inc., told city lawyers yesterday that he did not pressure Time Warner to drop from its New York cable systems a news channel owned by his rival, Rupert Murdoch.

title: Slow Changes in Japan
description: After four Prime Ministers in three years, Japanese voters had hoped that their next parliamentary election might bring a measure of political stability. Instead, balloting tomorrow seems likely to produce a new period of confusion and jockeying among familiar players. All the major candidates say they favor a Japan that is more open and free of regulations, with a foreign policy more independent of the United States. But voters remain conservative and skeptical about the possibilities of reform.

title: Dole Warms to Task Of Attacking Clinton
description: As two hot-air balloons bobbed and weaved behind him, Bob Dole, a shine in his eye and an edge in his voice, taunted the President of the United States today about unexplained foreign contributions to his party. ''Come on, Mr. President,'' Mr. Dole said, punching his arm into the air, enjoying the cheers from his modest crowd. ''Come clean, Mr. President. Come clean, Mr. President!''

title: The Blackhawks Sign Zhamnov for $15 Million
description: ALEKSEI ZHAMNOV practiced with the Chicago Blackhawks yesterday after ending his holdout by signing a five-year, $15 million contract.

title: Kurds Allied With Iraqis Regain Ground
description: Even as the United States tried to broker a cease-fire, the fighting intensified in northern Iraq today, with a Kurdish faction newly allied with President Saddam Hussein launching a counterattack to reverse gains by its rival.

title: Expand Javits Center
description: To the Editor:

title: No Household Names, But Defense Does Job
description: The Giants' defenders have not allowed a touchdown in 12 quarters. The question is -- how exactly are they doing it?

title: Searching for Women In the History of Jazz
description: Janice McNeil ran into a problem when she started putting together an exhibition that celebrated the position of women in the jazz world. Ms. McNeil works with the Smithsonian Institution's American's Jazz Heritage program, the organization that has assembled previous exhibitions centered on Duke Ellington and Louis Armstrong. When she began researching the Smithsonian's jazz holdings, she found virtually no material: no oral histories, no instruments, no recordings. Women had seemingly vanished from the history of jazz.

title: Senators Still a Thorn in the Devils' Side
description: The Ottawa Senators, the underachievers who prevented the Devils from getting a playoff spot last spring, stole a point from the Devils tonight with a 2-2 tie. The only consolation for the Devils, who were beaten by Ottawa in the regular-season finale last season, was that they rallied from a two-goal deficit.

title: Steinbrenner Wants A Talk With Mattingly
description: The former Yankee captain Don Mattingly declined George Steinbrenner's invitation to throw out the first ball before Game 2 of the World Series, because, he said, he does not want to be a distraction. Even so, Steinbrenner said he has made plans to meet with Mattingly and his wife, Kim, to discuss Mattingly's future.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Top Coaches Keep Winning

title: Status and Salaries Are Both in Decline : Chips Down For Teachers
description: PARIS  Zaira Rodriguez Guijarro, an 11-year-old Mexican schoolgirl, perhaps put it best whenUnesco asked children around the world to say what they expected of their teachers.

title: Trade Deficit Narrows, but Just Slightly
description: The nation's trade deficit edged down only slightly in August from its near-record level in July, the Commerce Department reported today, as improvements in trade with Western Europe and Japan were largely offset by growing gaps with other nations, especially China.

title: Czechs Say They Warned U.S. Of Chemical Weapons in Gulf
description: Soldiers whose sole responsibility during the 1991 Persian Gulf war was chemical detection say that American military commanders were repeatedly warned that sensitive detection equipment had identified Iraqi chemical weapons on the battlefield -- and that the toxins were wafting over unprotected American troops.

title: Judge Rejects Plea by One Company in Archer Case
description: A Federal judge here refused to accept a plea of no contest today from Ajinomoto Ltd., the large Japanese agricultural company that has been linked to the growing price-fixing scandal involving the Archer Daniels Midland Company.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Tubbs Charges Dropped
description: A cocaine possession charge against the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion TONY TUBBS, 38, has been dropped because a Hamilton County, Ohio, grand jury declined to indict him, a prosecutor said yesterday. Prosecutors presented evidence to a grand jury after the police in suburban Norwood brought the Oct. 3 charge against Tubbs. But the grand jury decided Thursday there was not enough evidence to support prosecution, said STEVE MARTIN, a spokesman for the county prosecutor's office. (AP)

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Movie Money

title: No Minds Changed In 90 Minutes
description: Kathryn Pennella, 29, an undecided voter from Armonk, N.Y., did not watch the Presidential debates. ''I'm pregnant and in the bed by 9 o'clock,'' she said, strolling toward the food court in the Galleria mall here. Neither did her uncle, Chick Pennella, but he offered no excuses and no apologies. ''I just didn't watch it,'' shrugged Mr. Pennella, a retired brick-layer from North White Plains. ''That's all. I'll probably vote for Clinton. He's already got the job.''

title: Blizzard Storms Past Rage In the First A.B.L. Game
description: No one slam-dunked. Nor did anyone go up over the rim. But the raucous crowd at the Hartford Civic Center loved it all anyway, especially since the home team, the New England Blizzard, beat the Richmond Rage, 100-73, in the inaugural game of the American Basketball League, the latest pro circuit for women.

title: F.C.C. APPROVES CABLE DEAL BY U S WEST
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved an $11.8 billion purchase by U S West Inc. of Continental Cablevision Inc. with a condition. U S West, a phone company, based in Englewood, Colo., must sell all Continental cable systems in its phone service region within 10 months to comply with communications law, it said. The 10-month window is intended to give the company enough time that it is not forced to conduct a ''fire sale,'' the F.C.C. said. The merger, announced in February, ''promotes the deployment of advanced telecommunications services and enhances competition,'' the F.C.C. said. It gives the phone company 4.7 million cable subscribers, making it the country's third-largest cable company after Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner Inc.

title: 2 Israelis Outline New Risk To Electronic Data Security
description: Two of Israel's leading computer scientists say they have found a way to more easily decode and then counterfeit the electronic cash ''smart cards'' that are now widely used in Europe and are being tested in the United States.

title: High Court Justice Won't Reopen Polls
description: The United States Supreme Court has denied a request to order the reopening of various primary-election polling sites in Brooklyn in a State Senate district covering parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: Braves Can See A Place in History Beyond the Bronx
description: Just as Ali needed Frazier and Bird needed Magic, the Braves need the Yankees, or so it seems. In the 1990's Atlanta has won five division crowns, four pennants and is looking to win consecutive World Series titles. Doing that at the expense of the tradition-rich Yankees in a Series that starts in storied Yankee Stadium would make the Braves' previous accomplishments all the more significant.

title: This Time, Perot Is Aiming His Message by Demographics, Instead of Wooing All the Voters
description: At this late stage of the Presidential campaign four years ago, Ross Perot bet his political fortunes on the drawing power of television, investing time and money in ''infomercials'' as well as television news and talk-show appearances and the debates. Speaking in person and in public, as he did today to the Yale Political Union, was something that Mr. Perot and his aides considered to be politics as usual, meriting a lower priority.

title: Lebed Unbound
description: President Boris Yeltsin's dismissal of Aleksandr I. Lebed from his post as chief of Russia's Security Council was more or less preordained and made clear what everyone knew all along: Mr. Lebed wants to be president. But the ousted general, who immediately announced his candidacy for the post, faces a daunting battle.

title: Turning Hopes Into Reality In the Bronx
description: ASTIN JACOBO sat in the bleachers of his favorite Bronx ball park, the Yankees logo on his cap positively glowing in the dusky shadows that descended on this patch of earth. He was in a special place, as hallowed to him as another ball park, where the World Series is to open tonight.

title: Quietly, Sorrowfully, A Jazz Club Dies
description: Rumors of Bradley's demise had been in the air for so long that the club's final night, on Thursday, felt not like a wake or a party but just business as usual.

title: Company Briefs
description: COOKSON GROUP P.L.C., London, a specialist materials manufacturer, agreed to buy GRP Inc., a U.S.-based unit of Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, a French ceramic and glass manufacturer. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about ready-made computer cabinetry misstated the publication date of ''The Home Office Book'' by Donna Paul. It is 1996, not 1966.

title: Love Your City, Love Its Weird Statues
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernard Wexler, 70, a Lawyer Who Helped Reduce Fund Fees
description: Bernard Wexler, a securities lawyer who played a leading role in writing and editing a critical Federal study that led to reforms in the early days of the mutual fund industry, died on Tuesday at the Hospice of Washington. He was 70 and lived in Washington.

title: ROCK
description: Skipping the Doom and Gloom

title: An Ivy-Covered Shell Game
description: When it comes to paying for college, are Americans better off today than they were four years ago? Will they be better off four years from now, if President Clinton is re-elected? The answers, unfortunately, are no and no.

title: COMSAT TO SELL 80% STAKE IN ASCENT ENTERTAINMENT
description: The Comsat Corporation said yesterday that it planned to divest itself of its 80 percent interest in Ascent Entertainment Group Inc. Comsat, based in Bethesda, Md., said Ascent's need for financing was hurting its own ability to expand its core international telecommunications and ventures businesses. Ascent, based in Denver, owns the Denver Nuggets basketball team, the Colorado Avalanche hockey team and a hotel video business. Ascent's recent acquisition of Spectravision is one reason that Comsat expects to report an operating loss in its fourth quarter, Comsat said.

title: The Fight Over Street Art
description: The Giuliani administration was right to crack down on illegal vendors in New York City, especially in densely crowded areas where they pose a safety hazard. But a Federal appeals court has ruled that the city violated the First Amendment by requiring artists to get permits before selling work on the streets. The licensing requirement is a de facto ban on art, the court said, because licenses are nearly impossible to obtain. The city is weighing an appeal to the Supreme Court. But the case has already shown that New York's vending laws are confusing and unfair.

title: Stokes Is Out 2 Weeks
description: Wide receiver J. J. STOKES will be sidelined at least two weeks after dislocating his right wrist during a San Francisco 49ers' practice session. The 49ers' top draft pick in 1995, Stokes was hurt Thursday when he caught a pass and came down hard on his right hand, the team spokeswoman, DARLA MAEDA, said yesterday. (AP)

title: New York Sues Big Tobacco
description: New York City made a smart move this week when it filed suit against eight tobacco companies and two trade associations to recover billions of dollars spent on medical care for smoking-related illnesses. The lawsuit is justified on public health and fiscal grounds.

title: Barkley's Old Nemesis
description: CHARLES BARKLEY, beware. SHANE HEAL has made it to the National Basketball Association.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow in Week's 4th High, Despite Philip Morris Slide

title: Dollar Up vs. Yen in New York and Tokyo
description: The dollar surged against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by Japanese investors seeking higher returns abroad, and by reports showing a narrowing trade gap between the United States and Japan.

title: DEMOCRATS CURB RAISING OF FUNDS BY A TOP OFFICIAL
description: The Democratic National Committee said this evening that it had suspended the fund-raising activities of a senior party official with longstanding ties to a prominent Indonesian family and had asked the Federal Election Commission to begin an expedited investigation to determine whether he had solicited any improper donations.

title: Just Like Miss America
description: Starting next spring, visitors to Atlantic City will be able to simulate the experience of walking down the Miss America runway (except, presumably, for the tears). The state Casino Reinvestment Development Authority has agreed to spend $249,000 to line both sides of a 20-foot sidewalk along Michigan Avenue with 200 rose-colored lights. Running down the middle of the sidewalk will be 75 bronze plaques, one for each Miss America through the year 2000, Frances M. Santoro, the agency's director of economic development, said yesterday. Each plaque will contain the beauty queen's statement about her goals.

title: Faith and Fun Mix in Ellington Rarity
description: Marin Alsop started her Concordia Orchestra in 1984 with the idea of exploring the common ground between contemporary but accessible American symphonic works and more popular forms, particularly jazz and film scores. Now and then, Ms. Alsop moves more audaciously into the jazz heartland, which is what she did on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, when she opened the orchestra's 13th season with a concert devoted fully to selections from Duke Ellington's three Sacred Concerts collections. She gave her strings the night off and augmented the brass, reed and percussion ensemble with the Morgan State University Singers, the pianist Fred Hersch, Jeff Edmond, a tap dancer, and four vocal soloists.

title: Cider From Connecticut Mill Is Linked to E. Coli Outbreak
description: At least six cases of a potentially fatal E. coli bacteria infection have been discovered in New Haven County and linked to the apple cider produced at a small cider mill in Cheshire, state officials announced today.

title: Robert F. Williams, 71, Civil Rights Leader and Revolutionary
description: Robert F. Williams, a civil rights leader turned black revolutionary who lived in Cuba, China and North Vietnam in the 1960's during an eight-year flight from kidnapping charges, died on Tuesday in Grand Rapids, Mich. He was 71 and lived in Baldwin.

title: Afghan Factions Still Fight It Out, but Talk of Peace Continues
description: For the men who gathered to talk in the bazaar of this village today after Friday prayers in the local mosque, the bursts of tank and rocket fire a few miles to the north served as a kind of morbid punctuation. Like most Afghans, the men want peace, and they have a clear idea of how to achieve it.

title: Defense Department Condemns Torture Manual
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tour of the Bronx, No Longer Burning
description: Forget the muggers, the gunfire, the arson fires smoldering on the horizon. Forget the old images of bombed-out streets, of abandoned buildings and ravaged neighborhoods that became a symbol of urban decay in America. On the eve of the 1996 World Series, the South Bronx -- the new, surprising South Bronx! -- had its stuff flaunted for the national news media yesterday.

title: Tired of Campaign Vitriol, Voters Go Negative
description: On the morning after the second televised debate between the two United States Senate candidates in New Jersey, Sadeta Perovic was having breakfast with a neighbor at the Parsonage Diner, talking about why she intends to vote on Nov. 5, but not for either Senate hopeful.

title: New Thai Tourist Sight: Burmese 'Giraffe Women'
description: Machak's initiation into womanhood came a month ago, when she turned 6 and her mother wound a coil of 10 brass rings around her neck, pushing up her chin and pressing down on her chest with their weight.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the release of documents from the Nixon Administration's files and the pending release of tape recordings misstated the background of the development. Former President Nixon sought to block the release of both documents and tapes. A lawsuit by Stanley I. Kutler, a University of Wisconsin historian, led to an agreement to release the tapes.
