The documents were released administratively by the National Archives, not as a result of Mr. Kutler's lawsuit.

title: Sex, Lies and the Courts: A Fury Rises in Belgium
description: Angry firefighters in Liege arrived with sirens wailing, parked 10 fire engines on the main square this week, turned on their high-pressure water jets and hosed down the imposing Palace of Justice. Prosecutors and magistrates inside scrambled to close doors and windows to protect their documents.

title: Tuition Costs:Colleges Open To Bargaining
description: BOSTON  Sticker price,the parlance of the car dealer's showroom,is a new catchword in American higher education.

title: DRAVO EXPLORING POSSIBLE SALE OR JOINT VENTURE
description: The Dravo Corporation, the largest publicly traded United States supplier of lime, said yesterday that it would explore options that include buying another company, forming joint ventures or selling itself. Dravo, based in Pittsburgh, said it had directed Lehman Brothers, its investment adviser, to look for ways to expand its business and increase stock value. That includes the possibility of selling the company, a company spokesman, Ron Sommer, said. Dravo said its operating performance was too sensitive to demand from electric utilities, which account for more than 60 percent of its lime sales.

title: Another Tiger Oversold
description: So we have been deceived all these years about Bob Dole. He is just a paper tiger. Maybe even an old sweetie pie. Certainly a bumbler at the killing game.

title: Blues Hold Another Sniping Match
description: There was Brett Hull -- one moment insisting that he would not air his true feelings about his coach, Mike Keenan, to the news media this season; the next boldly accusing Keenan of trying to trade him for the last two years.

title: The Fenway Conspiracy
description: Since the dawn of time, mankind has been divided into two opposing camps: Yankee fans and Yankee haters. The haters may claim indifference, but that is a ruse -- such people conspire against the Yankees, and have spread myths about the behavior of Yankee loyalists that are unfairly propagated by the national media.

title: For Better Or for Worse With the Bull
description: CAROL WATSON sat in a conference room on the executive floor at Yankee Stadium yesterday morning. Outside, in a suite of offices, the Yankee staff scurried on this mission and that, in feverish preparation for the franchise's first World Series in 15 years.

title: How to Lead a Musical Treasure Hunt
description: The goal of the New York Philharmonic's new ''American Classics'' project is to provide hearings for some undeservedly neglected, mid-century American music. Of course, in recent years the Philharmonic has itself contributed to that neglect with Kurt Masur's programming, which has been Eurocentric and heavily weighted with repertory staples.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: INSIDE
description: Bosnian Serbs Hiding Arms

title: Julian H. Levi, 87, Influential Advocate of Urban Renewal
description: Prof. Julian H. Levi, a Chicago lawyer, educator, city planner and an influential advocate of urban renewal, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco.

title: SHARES OF ONYX UP ON REPORT OF CANCER BREAKTHROUGH
description: The stock of Onyx Pharmaceuticals Inc. soared 58 percent yesterday on news that the company's researchers had genetically engineered a common virus to selectively kill human cancer cells. The engineered virus replicates and terminates P53-deficient tumor cells, which are resistant to chemotherapy and radiation, according to a study published yesterday in the journal Science. The P53-deficient tumor cells are also associated with decreased survival rates in cancer patients. The virus, Onyx-015, was in initial human clinical trials earlier this year for head and neck cancer.

title: Officer Shot Dead in Brooklyn; Suspect Killed by Police Gunfire
description: A New York City police lieutenant, coming to the aid of a woman who said she was being stalked, was shot and killed last night on a residential street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Minutes later the gunman, a 61-year-old parolee with a long history of violence, was killed in a torrent of police gunfire in the lobby of an apartment building a block away.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Chapel in Marlboro, a fundamentalist church in Canton, Ohio, misstated the size of the membership of another church in the city. Membership and weekly attendance at the Savior United Methodist Church in downtown Canton have been shrinking, but since the early 1990's the membership has declined from 1,103 to 987 members, not 370. Average Sunday attendance has declined from 420 to 370 in the same period.

title: State Trooper Is Injured
description: A heavy fog may be to blame for an accident yesterday that left a state police rookie in critical condition, the police said. Trooper Edward J. Fallon Jr., 25, was responding to a report of a prowler at 6:40 A.M. when he lost control of his cruiser on Cumberland County Route 617 and struck a tree, said Trooper Al Della Fave, a state police spokesman.

title: U.S. Energy Chief Rejects Action To Push Heating Oil Price Down
description: Hazel R. O'Leary, the Secretary of Energy, said today that the Goverment would not intervene to ease a sharp rise in heating oil prices.

title: Magda Trocme, 94, Is Dead; Sheltered Victims of Nazis
description: Magda Trocme, a French parson's wife who opened her door to a single shivering refugee in 1940 and helped inspire a movement that saved thousands of Jews and others from the Nazis in World War II, died on Oct. 10 a hospital in Paris. She was 94 and lived in Paris.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 11 about the acquittal of a police officer, Francis X. Livoti, in the fatal choking of a man in the Bronx referred incompletely to the response of the Bronx District Attorney's office to comments the judge made about the prosecution case. The prosecutor who tried the case, Nancy Borko, declined to comment on why the prosecution called as witnesses police officers who said they did not see the choking. But District Attorney Robert T. Johnson did address that issue after the verdict. He said the witnesses were called to help the prosecution establish that only Officer Livoti could have choked the victim, Anthony Baez, and said he believed the case was handled properly.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Thursday about the Presidential debate at the University of San Diego misspelled the name of the theater there in some copies. It is the Shiley, not the Shilaey.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: News Summary
description: International 3-6

title: Hamilton Lines Up Wide-Eyed And Eager
description: Bobby Hamilton understands that no one has heard of him. The Jets defensive end knows he has more fans in the old Amsterdam than he does in New Amsterdam.

title: Turning Fall's Many Colors Into Basic Green
description: In towns and villages from Maine to New York's Catskills, a sure sign of fall has long been the throngs of visitors who come to admire the annual color spectacular put on by dying leaves.

title: Bonds End Mixed, Giving Up Early Gains
description: Prices of Treasury securities closed mixed after backing off from early gains yesterday, as Government reports on employment and trade did nothing to change investors' expectations of slower economic growth and low inflation.

title: JAZZ
description: A 'Rawhide' Roundup

title: British Worried by Falling Standards and School Violence
description: LONDON  Schoolchildren in Britain are failing to performas well as their fellows in Taiwan, China and Korea in several key areas, recent studies show. At the same time, violence and disruption in the classroom are increasing.

title: Genetic Screening: An Unsettling Battle Is Joined
description: LONDON  Five years ago, Jamie Stephenson, a New Hampshire writer and her husband, Jonathan, a dentist, got a nasty shock. Their new health insurer suddenly dropped them after re-examining their file.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Drug Testing in the Home Is a Family Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Selloff Follows Disappointing Earnings at Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation has been spending more and selling less, and investors have registered a resounding cry of disapproval. Yesterday, the document-processing company announced that income from continuing operations had declined to $250 million in the third quarter, from $256 million in the period a year earlier.

title: U.S. Is Asked To Tell Group To Disclose Tobacco Ties
description: The backers of an Oregon ballot measure that would increase the tax on cigarettes charged today that the Tobacco Institute was surreptitiously financing an expensive advertising campaign to defeat the measure.

title: L.I. Company Admits It Sold Medals of Honor
description: A Long Island company that manufactures the nation's most revered military decoration, the Medal of Honor, will plead guilty in Federal Court next month to illegally selling the medals, its lawyer said.

title: Bridge
description: The United States team, which goes into action tomorrow in the world team championship on the Greek island of Rhodes, appears to have a good draw. The strongest team in the team's qualifying group is Italy, but it will also have to face Britain, Norway, Brazil and the Netherlands. The American players, all from the Chicago area, are making their debut at this level. They are Larry Robbins, Jerry Goldfein, Gary Cohler, Jack Oest, Steve Garner and Gerald Caravelli. The top 4 of the 36 teams will qualify for playoffs.

title: Times Co. Posts 37% Rise in Operating Profit
description: The New York Times Company reported improved operating earnings yesterday but said that a write-off of some overvalued assets resulted in a loss for the third quarter.

title: Sister and Brother Testify as Rape Trial Ends First Week
description: Ten years ago in Darien a 16-year-old girl sobbed, ''Oh, my God; oh, my God,'' and lay in a fetal position on her bedroom floor just after she had left Alex Kelly, her sister recalled today.

title: Child Care Should Be Educational, Not Informal
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mets' $6 Million Is Enough For Franco
description: John Franco got the two-year contract he wanted and a nice raise to go with it yesterday when he came to an agreement with the Mets on a deal that could be worth $6 million.

title: Teachers Are the Principal Characters In Five New Television Sitcoms
description: Dennis Rinsler swears these things actually happened when he was a teacher in the New York City public school system:

title: Nets Become Tougher As McDaniel Signs On
description: Duck. Gangway. Fore. Just be warned that Xavier McDaniel is heading to New Jersey.

title: A Good Law Yields More Voters
description: An encouraging new study finds that an impressive 12 million potential voters have been added to registration rolls because of the National Voter Registration Act -- popularly known as the motor-voter law. The new law, which went into effect last year, required states to allow people to register by mail. Citizens now can easily register when they obtain a driver's license or visit other government agencies like unemployment and public assistance offices.

title: A Friendly Touch, to Aid the Hermitage
description: Mikhail B. Piotrovsky is not daunted by the fact that every major New York museum is in the middle of an ambitious fund-raising drive. In fact, Dr. Piotrovsky, the director of the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, wishes them well.

title: Another Rookie Is One Off the Lead at Disney
description: There's a rookie lurking one shot off the lead after two rounds of the $1.2 million Walt Disney World/Oldsmobile Golf Classic. Cocky kid. Long hitter. Streaky putter. Quick smile.

title: A Legal Assault on Affirmative Action
description: WASHINGTON  For more than two decades U.S.colleges and universities have sought to open their doors to growing numbers of students from underrepresented racial and ethnic minority groups throughaffirmative action programs.

title: Funeral for Slain Officer Recalls Success Cut Short
description: As bagpipes breathed a forlorn sigh into the brisk October air, six pallbearers in dress blue uniforms hoisted the coffin onto their shoulders yesterday morning and carried their slain colleague, Police Officer Brian R. Jones, into St. Mark's United Methodist Church in Brooklyn.

title: Bosnian Serbs Said to Hide Big Supplies of Heavy Arms
description: The Bosnian Serbs have far more heavy weapons than they formally declared and have resorted to subterfuge to avoid destroying their excessive stock, said Western officials who have been meeting here for the last two days.

title: Texas Tech Gains Guard
description: The most important block in Texas Tech offensive guard CASEY JONES's career appears to have come in a courtroom, not on the playing field.

title: Mistrial Declared for 2 Officers in Slaying of a Black Motorist
description: A judge today declared a mistrial in a manslaughter trial of two white policemen in the death of a black motorist.

title: Free of Marx, Communists' Stock Is Soaring in Japan
description: As Kazuo Shii's speech boomed over the loudspeaker, a crowd of a thousand bystanders here gathered to listen and laugh, erupting at times in cheers and applause.

title: Talking to France, on Screen
description: Students in East Brunswick public schools will soon be able to converse in French by video with students in France and observe an archeological dig in South America. Beginning this month, the school district will install one of the largest high-speed multimedia networks used by any elementary or secondary school in the country, and the first of its kind in a New Jersey public school system.

title: Feathery Fossil Hints Dinosaur-Bird Link
description: A fossil dinosaur has been found in China that shows traces of feathery down along its spine and sides -- a sign that it may have been an early ancestor of birds. Dinosaur fossils include some remnants of skin, scales and even color patterns, but until now none have shown evidence of feathers.

title: Choreographers' Many Facets, for a Cause
description: There were plenty of choreographic big guns represented in ''Hot Pink Two,'' on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop, part of the Pink Ribbons Project of Dancers in Motion for Breast Cancer. The program opened with Bill T. Jones's stark but passionate ''Red Room.'' Set to music by Robert Longo and Stuart Argabright, the solo was performed by Heidi Latsky, who perfectly caught the balance between implacability and mortal fragility that is epitomized in the dance's closing image.

title: Apple Introduces 2 More Performas
description: Apple Computer Inc. introduced two new Macintosh Performa models today and announced price cuts of as much as 20 percent in its consumer line.

title: Corn Crop Brings Smiles to Nebraska, but Some Are Wary
description: Nebraska has the lowest unemployment rate of any state 2.6 percent, exactly half the national average -- and the next lowest rates can be found just to the north, in the two Dakotas.

title: NAFTA Spawns Special Programs in Trade Law
description: TUCSON, Arizona  Interpretation of the North American Free Trade Agreement will become an increasingly paramount issue as the myriad sections and subsections of the groundbreaking treaty are implemented.

title: Who Makes the Call? A Choice Along the Dial
description: When the World Series begins tonight, weather permitting, two radio teams will vie for listeners: WABC-AM's John Sterling and Michael Kay, the Yankees' team, and the CBS Radio Network's Vin Scully and Jeff Torborg, who will be heard on WFAN-AM.

title: UAL Dismisses Leo Burnett, Its Longtime Ad Angency
description: In a shocking end to one of the longest relationships between a big advertiser and its agency, United Airlines yesterday dismissed the Leo Burnett Company, the Chicago shop that won the carrier's account in 1965 by suggesting that United urge travelers to ''fly the friendly skies.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the dismissal of a top Russian official by President Boris N. Yeltsin referred incorrectly in some copies to the year Mr. Yeltsin was similarly ousted from a high-level Soviet post. It was 1987, not 1988.

title: Yiddish and Toast
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL
description: Discovering Subtle Feelings

title: Torricelli Puts Focus on Education Cuts
description: Following is the latest 30-second television advertisement from the campaign of Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, who is running against Representative Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican, for a United States Senate seat in New Jersey.

title: Howard Stern Stirs Up a Senate Race
description: While some people may be getting tired of the back-and-forth arguments between the candidates for the United States Senate, Howard Stern, the flamboyant radio talk show host, said today that he had not heard enough.

title: 200 New Sites May Hold Key To Flight 800
description: Navy salvage workers have located 200 additional targets on the ocean floor that could contain wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800, increasing investigators' hopes that the unrecovered debris might help them finally determine whether an explosive charge or mechanical failure caused the plane to crash, senior investigators said yesterday.

title: Nicaragua Sour and Unsure As Nation Prepares to Vote
description: This town was known as ''the cradle of the insurrection'' for its role in the Sandinista revolution against the Somoza family dictatorship. Then in 1990, after a decade of Sandinista rule, Masaya helped drive the leftists from power by voting decisively for their opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro.

title: Ban on Public Urination?
description: ''Just don't do it.'' That's the message the Paterson City Council wants to send about urinating in public, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Yanks Dust Off Gloves and Bats And Umbrellas
description: On the day before the World Series, the raucous Yankee clubhouse resembled a bustling subway station, with several reporters crowding each player and barely enough room to open a magazine. There were new World Series caps being distributed, new World Series gym bags by each locker, new concerns about the possibility of rain postponing tonight's opener and old questions about New York's lineup choices.

title: Olivetti Opens Its Board to Foreign Interests
description: Olivetti S.p.A. said today that it had named four new directors to its board in an effort to better represent international investors who own about 70 percent of the company.

title: East Europeans Westernize Curricula
description: BUDAPEST  A remarkable development is occurring in classrooms from Albania to the former Soviet Union: Youngsters are studying law, economics and civics.

title: Company Admits It Sold Medals of Honor
description: A Long Island company that makes the nation's most revered military decoration, the Medal of Honor, will plead guilty in Federal Court next month to selling the medals illegally, its lawyer said last night.

title: Negotiators Try Again To Secure Labor Deal
description: On the eve of the World Series, negotiators in Major League Baseball's marathon labor dispute yesterday began what should be the endgame of their abortive attempt to produce a new collective bargaining agreement. If rain should prevent the World Series from beginning until tomorrow night, some people familiar with the talks feel it is conceivable that the negotiators will have a deal before Andy Pettitte throws the first pitch.

title: Facts and Myths In New York Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprucing Up Giants Stadium
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority closed a $43 million deal yesterday with the Giants and Jets football teams to add 46 luxury suites and 120 club seats to Giants Stadium for the 1998 season, officials said. To cover most of the cost, the authority's board approved a $35 million bank loan to be repaid with revenue from the seating, which will cost up to $350,000 a year for six ''super suites'' and $5,000 for the club seats, said John Samerjan, a spokesman for the authority.

title: A Rare Sighting in South Dakota: An Incumbent in a Battle for Re-election
description: Since World War II, about 80 percent of the United States Senators who have run for re-election have won.

title: News About Clinton And Dole Cools Off In California Media
description: Bob Dole and Bill Clinton may have edged out the chimpanzees but, when it came to local television news coverage here, they were no match for the case of the murdered model or the jurors who will judge a certain former football player.

title: It's a Whine-Free Series, Unlike Last Year's
description: There won't be any crybabies at the World Series this year.

title: Courting Israel and France
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will lead a trade and investment mission to Israel and France shortly after the elections, her office announced yesterday. Accompanied by business executives, trade representatives and educators, the Governor will depart on Nov. 7 and spend six days in Israel, which her office described as one of New Jersey's leading trading partners, and three days in France.

title: World Series Showdown
description: YANKEES

title: Dole's Pregnant Silence
description: Every American, no doubt, has a special memory from the final Clinton-Dole debate -- whether it was that moment when Bob Dole made his Reaganesque announcement of the Braves-Cards score or that mesmerizing interlude when President Clinton recounted his visit to a Chrysler dealership in Japan.

title: Second Debate Met by Indifference, Fixed Minds and Preference for Baseball
description: They heard that Bob Dole went on the offensive on the character issue and they heard that President Clinton seemed cool and unruffled, but they know for certain that Mark Lemke did not leave third base early on a seventh-inning sacrifice fly in Game Six of the National League Championship series, no matter what that near-sighted umpire said.

title: Tackling the Global Gender Gap
description: WASHINGTON  Three years ago government officials in the East African country of Malawi began sending a troupe of actors into rural villages to present dramas on the theme of why girls should be educated. They worked with village leaders to promote girls education and reinforced their effort with a public information campaign using community meetings, radio, comic books and T-shirts.

title: A Cable Monopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shift to Alternative Fuels
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection is seeking proposals for persuading private companies with large fleets of cars and trucks to switch from gasoline to propane or natural gasoline.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Opener Could Be Wet One
description: With a forecast calling for heavy rain today, the first World Series game at Yankee Stadium since 1981 might be washed out tonight. If Game 1 is postponed, tickets for the opener will be honored tomorrow night. Game 2 would then be played Monday night, eliminating a scheduled travel day.

title: Torre Far From Sandlot but Close to Home
description: Cookie Lorenzo and Jim McElroy remember when Marine Park, its 798 acres spilling out into Rockaway Inlet, was all swamp and elephant grass, without a baseball player in sight.

title: Syracuse Loses Tackle
description: The Syracuse starting defensive tackle JEFF DANISH will have season-ending knee surgery on Tuesday to repair a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Danish, a junior, injured his left knee during practices in consecutive weeks in early October. He has not played since Oct. 5 against Rutgers and had 11 tackles and 1 1/2 sacks in three games. (AP)

title: Bob Dole Favored In His Home State
description: Curtis Blake, 38 years old, had finished working the midnight-to-8-A.M. shift at the Certainteed Corporation, a maker of vinyl siding, and was rushing to Carol Lee Donuts on Main Street to pick up an order for his wife before going home to sleep.

title: CULBRO MAY SEPARATE CIGAR AND NONCIGAR HOLDINGS
description: The Culbro Corporation said yesterday that it was considering a plan to separate its General Cigar unit from its noncigar businesses, so that the company could focus on its successful cigar operations. Under the proposal, the maker of Partagas and Macanudo cigars would either sell a stake in General Cigar in an initial public offering or sell shares of Culbro. Culbro, based in New York, would complete the transaction in the first half of 1997. Its stock rose $2.50, to $55.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. More than a year ago Culbro broke off talks to sell part of the cigar unit to Spain's state-owned Tabacalera S.A. for $100 million.

title: Richter Stops 36 As Rangers Get Even
description: A week ago, there was cause for alarm. The Rangers were off to their worst start since 1958-59. There was no cohesion; there were no victories. There was speculation that Coach Colin Campbell's job might soon be on the line.

title: A Federal Prisoner States Her Case
description: MENTION the name Beatrice Codianni-Robles in the Hill and Fair Haven neighborhoods of New Haven and the response is likely to reverberate with strong emotion.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE DOG WITH THE CHIP IN HIS NECK

title: Cezanne Show
description: To the Editor: Seymour B. Kramer's indictment of Philadelphia for his experience at the Cezanne exhibit is an unwarranted rap on the city. Lines of people waited in cold wind and wet snow to enter the Monet show in Chicago. Lines around the National Gallery of Art in Washington stood in freshly fallen snow and bitter cold from as early as 6 A.M. to get into the Vermeer show sometime between 10 A.M. and closing.

title: Hiawatha Goes Hollywood
description: BY THE SHORES OF GITCHEE GUMEE

title: Lethal Legacy to Workers, Communities and the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: DIARY
description: A NEW LOOK

title: French Fries as Hand Food? Perish the Thought!
description: To the Editor:

title: On Civil Rights, Clinton Steers Bumpy Course Between Right and Left
description: In his nearly four years in office, President Clinton has amassed a civil rights record rivaling that of any President in the last 30 years.

title: From the Essence of 7 Months to the Best of 7 Games
description: A baseball season stretches from spring to fall and embraces every type of weather, every range of emotion, every kind of achievement and failure. It is a test of endurance, and this is what it looked like in the Bronx this season, in the painful moments and the quiet ones, in the anger and the sudden exhiliration. For the most part, these are not the images from a Yankee highlight film, just snapshots from a 1996 album that is still awaiting at least a few more pictures.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 20, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Scientists visit a Costa Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs. 2 3 THE JUDGE, by Steve Martini. (Jove, $6.99.) An attorney defends a judge he doesn't like against murder and other charges. 3 1 THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Dell, $7.50.) A troubled woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler in Montana. 4 14 THE FIRST WIVES CLUB, by Olivia Goldsmith. (Pocket, $6.99.) Three women conspire to get even with the men who divorced them. 5 54 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) A murder trial recalls the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. (+) 6 6 THE GREEN MILE: COFFEY ON THE MILE, by Stephen King. (Signet, $3.99.) The sixth and concluding installment of a thriller set on death row. 7 5 THE HEIR, by Catherine Coulter. (Topaz, $6.99.) The stormy courtship and marriage of an earl and his cousin in 18th-century England. 8 29 THE CHAMBER, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $7.50.) A lawyer represents a racist who is on death row for his part in a 1967 bombing. 9 4 COME TO GRIEF, by Dick Francis. (Jove, $6.99.) Sid Halley investigates the suicide of a revered horse-racing figure's mother. 10 1 THE WEB, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $6.99.) Alex Delaware encounters a series of macabre events on a tiny Pacific island. 11 9 MORNING, NOON & NIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $7.50.) The mysterious drowning of a respected tycoon reveals a tangle of scandals. 12 1 INTENSITY, by Dean Koontz. (Ballantine, $7.99.) On a weekend visit to a Napa Valley farm, a young woman contends with a serial killer. 13* 1 FROM THE HEART, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $6.50.) Strong women meet strong men in three short novels. 14 10 THE GREEN MILE: NIGHT JOURNEY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The fifth installment of a serial thriller. 15 1 CHOKE, by Stuart Woods. (Harper Paperbacks, $6.99.) Two Florida detectives investigate the death of an enigmatic millionaire who was married to an adulterous woman. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 6 A CIVIL ACTION, by Jonathan Harr. (Vintage, $13.) A lawsuit brought by Massachusetts householders against industrial polluters. (+) 2 4 A FEVER IN THE HEART, by Ann Rule. (Pocket, $6.99.) Accounts of six crime cases that occurred in Washington and Oregon. 3* 82 REVIVING OPHELIA, by Mary Pipher. (Ballantine, $12.50.) The dangers for teen-age girls. (+) 4 2 HIGH TIDE IN TUCSON, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) Essays about motherhood, nature and other topics by the novelist. 5 28 THE LIARS' CLUB, by Mary Karr. (Penguin, $11.95.) A poet recalls her troubled childhood. (+) 6 21 SLEEPERS, by Lorenzo Carcaterra. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The true story, the narrator claims, of boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take. 7 5 MY POINT . . . AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $6.50.) Observations on life by the television star and stand-up comedian. 8 2 IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.) The First Lady on ways to create a better society for children. (+) 9 2 LONGITUDE, by Dava Sobel. (Penguin, $10.95.) The story of John Harrison, the 18th-century Englishman who invented the chronometer. 10 31 HOW THE IRISH SAVED CIVILIZATION, by Thomas Cahill. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The story of monks who copied Western literature. (+) 11 674 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) Inspiration. (+) 12* 26 PAULA, by Isabel Allende. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) The novelist tells stories of her family's life as she tends her fatally ill daughter. (+) 13* 144 CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (Harper Perennial, $12.) Daily spirituality. (+) 14* 12 MINDHUNTER, by John Douglas and Mark Olshaker. (Drew/Pocket, $6.99.) The memoirs of the former leader of an F.B.I. team that studies the behavior of serial killers and assassins. 15* 19 A GOOD WALK SPOILED, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $13.95.) The P.G.A. Tour. (+) 16* 20 GOD: A BIOGRAPHY, by Jack Miles. (Vintage, $15.) Perceptions of the Old Testament Deity. (+) 17* 108 EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Bantam, $5.99.) A woman's near-death experience. (+) Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 4 IT'S A MAGICAL WORLD, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $14.95.) ''Calvin and Hobbes.'' 2 2 FUGITIVE FROM THE CUBICLE POLICE, by Scott Adams. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) ''Dilbert'' cartoons about life in the office. 3 1 THE RULES, by Ellen Fein and Sherrie Schneider. (Warner, $5.99.) How to snare Mr. Right. 4* 108 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE SOUL, compiled by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Stories meant to ''open the heart and rekindle the spirit.'' (+) 5* 26 DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (M. Evans, $12.95.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)

title: Making Reading A Total Experience
description: THERE are 26 children in Maria Parada's second-grade class and their reading skills range from above grade level to just learning to put sounds together.

title: Giants Go to Washington in a Fighting Mood
description: When we last left the Giants and the Washington Redskins, linebacker Marvcus Patton was using the chin of quarterback Dave Brown for head-butting practice. It seems Patton had taken offense to Brown's feeling a little giddy before last month's game, saying how the Redskins, losers of six straight to the Giants, always seemed to get the Giants pumped up, blah, blah, blah.

title: Cheryl Whaley and Eric Aboaf
description: Cheryl Calloway Whaley, a daughter of Celia A. Rushin and Dr. William H. Whaley, both of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Eric Walter Aboaf, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Aboaf of Tucson, Ariz. Rabbi Harvey J. Winokur officiated with the Rev. Thomas R. Roddy, a Presbyterian minister, at the Fernbank Museum of Natural History in Atlanta.

title: Caryn Kasper And Glen Landow
description: Caryn Beth Kasper, a daughter of Miriam Kasper and Dr. Harvey A. Kasper of Bridgewater, N.J., is to be married today to Glen Jonathan Landow, a son of Linda and Lloyd Landow of Dix Hills, L.I. Rabbi Ronald Isaacs will perform the ceremony at the Jewish Center of Teaneck, N.J.

title: Elegant Offerings With an Elegant Look
description: SOMETIMES it takes a while for a restaurant, even as well-known a one as Stonehenge in Ridgefield, to get it all together.

title: Shannon! Jaycie! Dominique! And Again!
description: GREGORY FILLER IS HAVING A MOMENT. HE IS pointing at a member of this year's women's Olympic gymnastics team as she practices her tumbling runs on the mat. ''Look at her,'' Filler says, awestruck. ''Can you believe what these girls can do? Eight of her on a Vegas stage. That would be my dream.'' It is just five weeks after the Olympics and Filler, a Las Vegas dancer and choreographer, is in Florida with members of the gold-winning team for a 34-city, nationwide exhibition tour -- starring nearly every '96 Olympic gymnast, male and female.

title: When a Sponsor Refuses to Sell
description: CO-OPS and condominiums were insistently touted during the conversion fever of the 80's as an apartment dweller's chance to reap the benefits of enhanced equity, to no longer serve as a funnel into someone else's rental flow, to be part of a community that shared the rewards and risks of home ownership -- and, when the time came, to be able to sell.

title: J. Solomon, 92, Philanthropist And Lawyer
description: Joseph Solomon, a lawyer and philanthropist who supported various educational and medical institutions, died on Oct. 8 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 92.

title: U.S. Airlines Finally Reach Cruising Speed
description: UNTIL recently, the airline industry induced vertigo as few other cyclical businesses could.

title: Beards and Prayers: Matters of Orthodoxy Split Temple
description: The split between factions at the Sikh Cultural Society boils down to a basic religious argument: how orthodox should you be to become a member of the temple?

title: Going for Broke
description: LOSERS are the toxic waste of the gambling industry. Nobody likes to talk about them much in a city where the billions of dollars gamblers leave each year is called the ''casino win.''

title: Talking About New Jersey With the Candidates for the Senate
description: New Jersey, A State of Mind

title: Killing Brings a Brutal End to 4 Decades of Crime
description: A day after he died in a torrent of police bullets, Harvey Richardson continued to cause sorrow and outrage yesterday, as he had through a criminal career that stretched over four decades and ended in the slaying of a New York City police lieutenant on Friday evening.

title: The Fall Season Pays Tribute to Art
description: Opening shows of Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly and women photographers; a new dictionary and a benefit to finance traveling exhibitions.

title: The Flavor of Wild Mushrooms
description: WILD mushrooms are now in peak season. Tennyson once described them as ''carion of some woodland thing,'' but I wonder if the poet ever tasted porcini (boletus edulus, also known as cepes), which have an unforgettable earthy flavor, pure heaven when grilled with lemon and olive oil or sauteed in butter with a little garlic. They also make a wonderful risotto, especially when flavored with white truffle oil (and if expense is no object, topped with a few shavings of fresh white truffle). Surely, Tennyson would not have scorned chantarelles, those orange, feathery trumpets, which are so good tossed with pasta and cream. Wild mushrooms of all kinds, sauteed with potatoes, make a superb fall side dish to go with roasted chicken, beef or fish.

title: Stephanie Kemp, James Loeffler Jr.
description: Stephanie Ann Kemp, an artists' representative in New York, and James Joseph Loeffler Jr., a commodities trading adviser, were married last evening at Our Mother of Perpetual Help Chapel in New Orleans. The Rev. Michael Harrold, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Unseen Father Haunts 2 Siblings
description: LIKE a wild child imprisoned in a lonely dilapidated room, Johnnie Smit is screaming, ''Help!'' His sister, Hester, bursts in, unrecognized after a 12-year absence. ''I'm passing through; it's hello and goodbye,'' she declares. She is there to claim her share of ''the compensation'' supposedly provided by her hated father who lies dying behind a closed door, looked after by Johnnie.

title: A Virtual Secretary Finds You, Even Out of the Office
description: A CLIENT calls your office, but you're out of town. You don't have a secretary, so the message ends up as voice mail. Call forwarding might have connected you and the caller immediately, but it also would have sent through all those nuisance calls that a secretary could screen.

title: Held Hostage In a Project They Kept Up
description: SIX days a week, the Hayes Homes senior citizens sit outside their building to wait for the mail.

title: Clinton Plans Europe Talk, His Aides Say
description: After weeks of Republican assaults on his leadership in foreign policy, President Clinton plans to use a campaign appearance in Detroit next week to deliver an address on the future of Europe and spell out his commitment to the expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to include former Soviet allies, his aides say.

title: Koreans Turn To Picketing Over High Rent
description: The protest held by the somber businessmen and women last Thursday may have looked like any other picketing, but it was culturally out of character for this group. ''Korean people do not do this,'' said Cha Ok Kim, as 40 or so other members of the New York Society of Korean Businessmen marched and displayed signs with slogans like ''We are Good for the Neighborhood! Don't Force Us to Leave!''

title: Sociology Is Fine, But Students Need Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: Minivan Crisis
description: Every year our family of four -- my husband and I and my son and stepdaughter -- climbs into my 1989 Volvo 240 sedan and drives north for two weeks in Vermont. Although there isn't exactly room to spare, the car holds us all comfortably.

title: Bad Weather and Very Good Teams
description: New York does not have an exclusive franchise on poor World Series weather; it just seems that way.

title: Debate on a Name Change for Prestige and Profit
description: This is a village with an identity crisis.

title: Suzanne Rittereiser, R. T. Anderson
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Rittereiser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Rittereiser of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Thomas Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Anderson of Rahway, N.J. The Rev. Richard J. Neilson performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: What Bond Act Might Mean for L.I.
description: WHEN Long Islanders enter their polling booths on Nov. 5, supporters of a $1.75 billion environmental bond act hope that they look upward.

title: Ali Is Still Floating, Now Far Above Reproach
description: Like a holy relic borne overhead through teeming streets, Muhammad Ali continues to make his odd, affecting way above the World Series, through the election campaigns, around boxing, in a spiritual festival of his own. There is even a new shibboleth: ''I wish people would love each other the way they love me. It would be a better world.''

title: Slamming the Door
description: THERE PROBABLY AREN'T MORE THAN A DOZEN people who have read this year's housing appropriations bill, but its eye-straining type breaks new ground in the revision of the social contract. With one obscure sentence, the Federal Government has essentially conceded defeat in its decades-long drive to make housing affordable to low-income Americans. Even in an era of Government retreats this one stands out, both for its importance and its odd election-year invisibility. No one seems to have noticed, least of all the candidates. But two decades of rising rents and falling wages have created record numbers of people, including working people, who can't afford to pay the rent.

title: Suzanne Keating, Stephen Lukens
description: Suzanne Reynolds Keating and Stephen Jeffrey Lukens, both consultants in New York, were married yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Fleming P. Rutledge performed the ceremony.

title: BIG BROTHER IS US
description: Whose privacy (''Big Brother Is Us,'' by James Gleick, Sept. 29)? Last week, AT&T, my long-distance carrier, refused to give me information about my own phone call. After making a call, I requested the cost of the transaction so that I could compare the rate with what AT&T newly announced as ''15 cents per minute. The one-rate program.''

title: First a Firebrand, Then a Romantic. Now What?
description: KRZYSZTOF PENDERECKI, a former firebrand of the avant-garde, has just signed a contract with the Munich Philharmonic that commits him to the production of four traditionally scored symphonies over the next 10 years. ''I wrote five until now, so I will have to write another four, and that will make nine,'' Mr. Penderecki said, speaking from his home in Krakow, Poland. ''I don't think I am supposed to write more than nine,'' he added, echoing Mahler's portentous words of a century ago.

title: Keeping the Cold Out In Winter
description: FEW things are more invigorating than a brisk autumn breeze laced with the scent of recently fallen leaves. Except, of course, when the breeze is coming through the electrical outlet in your living room.

title: Investors Hate Oil, But It Keeps Going Up
description: Markets are amazing things. Sometimes they go up because everyone thinks they will. And sometimes they go up even though no one thinks they will.

title: A Hazardous Profession
description: LOVEJOY

title: Steven Tisch and Jamie Alexander
description: Jamie Leigh Anne Alexander, the daughter of Linda Tanana of Tuscaloosa, Ala., and Edgar Franklin Alexander of Panama City, Fla., was married last evening to Steven Elliot Tisch, a son of Joan Hyman Tisch and Preston Robert Tisch of New York. Rabbi Jerry Winston performed the ceremony at Beaulieu Gardens in Rutherford, Calif.

title: Darwin Family Values
description: BORN TO REBEL

title: Images That Speak of Health and Beauty and Fertility
description: THE Artistry of Traditional African Sculpture'' at the Society of African Missions' African Art Museum (25 Bliss Avenue, Tenafly; 201-567-0450) includes more than 90 works, many on loan from nine private collections. Its curator is Charles Bordogna, who has been the museum's volunteer curator for 15 years.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Rooms With a View
description: I'VE never eaten at Osteria del Circo in Manhattan, but I've heard people talk about the ingenious metalwork by the sculptor J. J. Veronis that brightens the room.

title: Tobacco Lobby Fights for Military Subsidy
description: The tobacco industry is campaigning on Capitol Hill to block a Pentagon plan to raise the price of discounted cigarettes sold in scores of military grocery stores around the world, lawmakers and their top aides say.

title: Sociology Is Fine, But Students Need Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dear Jiang Letter
description: On July 1, 1997, Hong Kong returns to China's control. When President Clinton sees China's President, Jiang Zemin, in the Philippines in a few weeks, it would be useful if he whispered something like this in his ear:

title: More Roads Are Leading to No-Load Funds
description: NOT only are mutual funds increasing in number virtually by the day, but so are the ways in which you can buy them without sales charges, or loads.

title: The Tightrope of Tommy Chan
description: TWO years ago, when M. B. Lee, an influential Chinatown elder, learned that Deputy Inspector Thomas M. Chan was coming to the Fifth Precinct as its first Chinese-American commander, he paid a visit to the inspector's parents in the Alfred E. Smith housing project on the Lower East Side. In Mr. Lee's estimation, it was unwise for their son to accept the job.

title: Why the Bull Is a Compulsive Climber
description: UP, up, up it goes, and where it stops nobody knows. Since stock prices began climbing out of the trough of the 1990 recession, the Dow Jones industrial average has grown at 10 times the pace of the American economy. Perhaps as remarkable, investors have brushed aside every bit of troubling news -- from interest rate increases to the defeat of an incumbent Republican President -- with barely a hiccup. Not once in the last six years have stock prices fallen by as much as 10 percent.

title: THE ARTIFICIAL WOMB
description: It is revealing that this pediatrician admires the technological quest to grow a baby minus the mother but just can't stomach a warm, low-tech act like breast-feeding, which has been the norm throughout human history -- and still is in many societies.

title: Clarence I. Blau, 89, Official in New Deal
description: Clarence I. Blau, one of the eager young lawyers who enlisted in the New Deal in Washington in the 1930's and who later served as a member of the United States Mission to the United Nations, died on Oct. 10 at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 89 and lived in Washington.

title: In Hothouse Of Politics, Signs Sprout
description: For all the attention forcused on the Presidential campaign, there is a lot of other electoral business on the nation's agenda this fall. Elections will be held next month for 34 Senate seats, 11 Governorships and 435 House seats, not to mention 5,989 state legislative seats and thousands of county offices.

title: Making the Switch to the Private Sector
description: DURING his tenure as United States Attorney for the District of Connecticut from 1989 to 1991, Stanley A. Twardy Jr. led a series of tenacious and successful prosecutions against white collar and organized crime. His office pursued and won numerous racketeering, bank and health fraud, corruption and environmental cases.

title: The Whitman Approach To Welfare Reform
description: Governor Whitman has joined with other Republicans to warn voters that President Clinton, if re-elected, would weaken the new Federal welfare law. But Mrs. Whitman herself proposes softening some of the new law's harshest provisions as part of her plan to overhaul New Jersey's welfare program.

title: In Dick Morris Specter, a Vision of Marley's Ghost
description: As Dick Morris wanders lucratively east of political Eden, cast in disgrace from the Clinton re-election campaign, his furtive shadow falls on a busy landscape of young political consultants pondering the tensions between ethics and victory, democracy and celebrity.

title: Nazi's Case Forces Italy To Revisit Sore Subject
description: From his cell at Regina Coeli, the same Roman prison where, 52 years ago, he randomly rounded up victims for one of the bloodiest Nazi reprisals committed in Italy, Erich Priebke told an Italian legislator this week that he now understands what he did wrong.

title: Los Angeles
description: Fall in Los Angeles is known for the warm Santa Ana winds that blow from the Mojave Desert and push Southern California's familiar blanket of haze out to sea. The frequently clear and glorious weather -- which only seems to highlight the seaside and smaller crowds -- makes this perhaps the best season to visit.

title: 5 Trios Arrive on the Scene, Offering Favorites
description: GOOD things come in threes, they say, and five trios enliven the music scene this week. This afternoon at 2:30, the California-based Trio Du Bois, named for its pianist, Rose Ann Wood, but also comprising the violinist Robin Cecil and the cellist Alan Mautner, play chamber music by Schubert, Dvorak, Mendelssohn and more in a free recital at the Warner Public Library in Tarrytown.

title: Sociology Is Fine, But Students Need Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: Scribner's And Benetton
description: To the Editor:

title: At Disney World, A Boardwalk Village
description: Walt Disney World has borrowed from so many cultural sources that it has finally gotten around to one it put a dent into: the old-fashioned mid-Atlantic beach resort. Disney's Boardwalk, a waterfront village that recalls the mood at a 1930's ocean resort, opened Oct. 1 at Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

title: A Showcase for Local Chefs and Local Bounty
description: LONG Island ducks and potatoes are known far beyond our borders. So too are the tiny scallops harvested in Peconic Bay. Add the Island's fish, oysters, clams, cauliflower, corn, tomatoes, broccoli, pumpkins, squash and increasingly well regarded premium wines, and it becomes apparent that there are enough world-class local ingredients to satisfy the most demanding of chefs.

title: Rachel D. Godsil, James S. Freeman
description: Rachel Denise Godsil, a staff lawyer for the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund in Manhattan, and James Shy Freeman, a Ph.D. candidate in the philosophy of religion program at Columbia University, were married yesterday at the Picnic House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The Rev. Joseph Jarman performed the Buddhist ceremony with his wife, the Rev. Thulani Davis-Jarman, the writer and playwright, who is also a Buddhist priest.

title: In October, Baseball Is the Best
description: THE World Series is a reminder that October is when baseball is the best game of all.

title: TV Stations' Ad Logs Show Spending Gap Between Two Candidates in Senate Race
description: In the first six weeks of the campaign for an open United States Senate seat in New Jersey, Representative Robert G. Torricelli significantly outspent his rival, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, in crucial television advertising.

title: Mean and Meaner
description: There was a moment, in the San Diego debate, when Bob Dole actually looked as if he wanted to run and hide behind Jim Lehrer's chair.

title: . . . While in Hoboken, Artists Hold Open House
description: As the art community has grown in Hoboken over the last 20 years, so has the Hoboken Artist Studio Tour. More than 100 artists living and working in the city will show their work and their work spaces today from noon to 6 P.M.

title: On Students Acquiring Reading Skills
description: ''Will All Pupils on L.I. Read by Third Grade?'' The answer is a resounding No! Not if the informtion is representative of the teaching fare. Hasn't anyone heard that California is discarding ''whole-language'' after finding it a dismal failure? And 40 professors of linguistics in Massachusetts wrote their State Commissioner of the fraudulent claims (on linguistic research) of ''whole language'' gurus to try to justify their vacuous deceptions.

title: When Churches Want to Grow and Towns Say No
description: When the St. Mary Coptic Orthodox Church in East Brunswick applied three years ago to build a Sunday school and a parish hall on its own property, the planning board asked for certain alterations. The church made more than 25 changes, spending tens of thousands of dollars, to satisfy the board's concerns about traffic and zoning requirements.

title: Only Auburn's Fans Stop Florida
description: When buses carrying the University of Florida football team pulled up to Ben Hill Griffin Stadium today, they found their path inside the stadium blocked by Auburn fans.

title: Lee Arthur, Leo LaPlante
description: Rosamond Lee Arthur, a private art dealer in New York and Malibu, Calif., was married yesterday to Leo Robert LaPlante, a builder in Malibu. The Rev. Philip A. C. Clarke performed the ceremony at Christ United Methodist Church in New York.

title: Concerns Grow That Doctor-Assisted Suicide Would Leave the Powerless Vulnerable
description: As the debate over doctor-assisted suicide moves through the courts at the judicial equivalent of breakneck speed, ethicists and others say there are troubling concerns that society has yet to consider seriously.

title: A Youth Movement on an Old Team
description: High on the skin of his back, Daniel Goneau wears a cartoon tattoo of Wile E. Coyote. This isn't a plea for a trade to Phoenix. Goneau got the tattoo years ago, when he was a teen-ager in Quebec and the Coyotes were still the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Survival, Barely, in The Great Depression
description: IT is easy to dismiss ''Awake and Sing!''

title: David Viscott, Psychotherapist Of the Airwaves, Is Dead at 58
description: Dr. David Viscott, a practicing psychiatrist and author who provided diagnoses and ''tough love'' therapy to radio listeners as they cruised the Los Angeles freeways, was found dead in his Studio City home on Monday. He was 58.

title: No Headline
description: ''Now, here I am, a Roman Catholic for 45 years, having become an Episcopal priest, standing in the place of a Lutheran pastor. What a witness this is!''

title: The Key to Pumpkin Madness
description: IT was a nasty shock to drive out on the North Fork last Sunday. I had forgotten all about pumpkin madness.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION AND POETRY
description: THE SUBLIME

title: Go From Welfare to Work? Somebody Has to Be Hiring
description: WE don't want to spend all our time and energy answering questions about whether there will be enough jobs,'' said Eileen McGinnis, chief of Governor Whitman's Office of Policy and Planning. ''We want to spend our time making the program a success.''

title: Jeanne Ackman, Robert Haimovici
description: Dr. Jeanne Bari Ackman, a fellow in radiology at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, is to be married today to Dr. Robert Haimovici, an ophthalmologist in Boston. Rabbi Cyrus Arfa, the bride's uncle, is to perform the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Pan Am Announces A Novel Fare Method
description: Pan Am World Airways plans to adopt an unusual fare structure when it ends its introductory fares on Nov. 24.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the 1996 Nobel winners misidentified the group awarding the Peace Prize. It is the Norwegian Nobel Committee; Sweden's Royal Academy of Sciences helps select candidates for some of the other prizes.

title: A Regional Company's Decline
description: THE audience had been seated for half an hour, waiting for the show to go on. Backstage, five members of the technical crew, owed back pay, decreed that it would not. It did not. The crew went home. So did the audience.

title: Get a (Real) Life!
description: To the Editor:

title: Neck That Down
description: ASKED RECENTLY about dependents of Department of Defense civilians remaining in Kuwait, Gen. John M. (for Malchese) Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told Army Times: ''The vast majority, if not all, are on a long accompanied tour. We're going to neck that down to those that are absolutely necessary.''

title: Lauren Herbert, Samuel Rappaport
description: Lauren Herbert, a daughter of April H. Herbert of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and the late Roy A. Herbert, was married yesterday to Samuel Isaac Rappaport, the son of Herma R. and Gersten Rappaport of New York. Jean E. Ellis-La Bossiere, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Pierce House, a Georgian-style house in Lincoln, Mass.

title: Staring Into the Heart of Darkness
description: WITH its modest Victorian architecture and silver spire, the small Catholic church by the railroad tracks could be any rural house of worship, but today it's a crime scene in Tacoma, Wash. Uniformed police direct a tall, dour looking man toward the scorched grass where a priest has been burned at the stake. As officers sift through the ashes for evidence, the man and his colleagues huddle nearby, shaking their heads in disbelief. Then a slow-moving freight train, about a quarter mile long, rumbles down the tracks beyond them, stops, and idles noisily. The uniformed officers look confused. The serious group in plainclothes relaxes. The spell is broken.

title: Wanting Luxury and Being Able to Afford It
description: FOR most couples, buying a house is a matter of scale, observed Shelia Siderow, the owner of Siderow Associates, a residential real-estate concern in Chappaqua. ''The more upscale the home buyer, the more amenities they require,'' she said. ''They want fitness rooms with saunas, fireplaces in the bedrooms, maids' rooms, his-and-her offices, lap pools and cutting gardens. They want it all, and they can afford it.''

title: In Westport, the Arts v. Education
description: IN 1920, in a gray-shingled house near Compo Beach in Westport, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote ''The Beautiful and the Damned.'' In 1950, J. D. Salinger holed up in a house on South Compo Road to write ''The Catcher in the Rye.'' And James White, a native of Westport, recalls chatting with a struggling, young screenwriter named Rod Serling as he labored over ''Requiem for a Heavyweight'' in the Westport Public Library.

title: X-Men's Foe: Spotlight On a Comer
description: Assemblyman Jules Polonetsky sees himself as a muckraking politician, the kind of leader who will not let politics get in the way of principles. When he learned that the X-Men, a security firm affiliated with the Nation of Islam, Louis Farrakhan's group, was patrolling a Coney Island housing complex, Mr. Polonetsky made it his mission to oust the firm, even if he angered tenants.

title: Cezanne Show
description: To the Editor: I have to respond to the letter by Seymour B. Kramer expressing unhappiness over the way the Cezanne show was handled by the Philadelphia Art Museum. My experience in two visits was exactly the opposite. As a tour organizer, I took a group of 92 there in June. We were divided into smaller groups with wonderful guides and all of us had a memorable time. In August I took a busload with timed tickets and again we were able to go right in. This time the gallery was more crowded but no one complained.

title: Ferry Operators Are Confronting An Aging Fleet
description: ON a windy Sunday night passengers on the decks of the Grand Republic ferryboat heading out of Bridgeport, Conn., for Port Jefferson were surprised to see a red tug following closely.

title: THE HALL OF ANTIQUITIES
description: In ''The Hall of Antiquities'' (Sept. 29), Jane and Michael Stern suggest that paint-spattered fur coats will be a thing of the past. We agree. In fact, it seems that the animal-rights movement, not the fur industry, may be in danger of becoming a forgotten relic.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Lowest Air Fares listing on Oct. 6 for the Los Angeles-London route omitted an airline under the heading ''Discount Fare.'' When today's section went to press, the airline, British Airways, matched the lowest available fare of $438. The rate was scheduled to expire on Oct. 16.

title: A Haunted House and Pumpkin-Eating Bears
description: HALLOWEEN is creeping into zoos in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens with activities for children and adults Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Vacant Stores Cause Worry On Upper West Side
description: To the Editor:

title: The Classics, Chilled Out
description: UPDATING THE CLASSICS IS suddenly all the rage. A spiffy new version of ''Romeo and Juliet'' -- with Leonardo DiCaprio and Claire Danes starring as the Dolce & Gabbana-wearing lovers, who live in South Florida -- opened this month. ''Great Expectations,'' with Robert De Niro and Ethan Hawke, will follow next year.

title: Time, Again, to Tuck In the Spring Bulbs
description: JUST a few thoughts on a chore that should be on everyone's mind: bulb planting. Since the days are cooling down and trees are beginning to change color, there should be no time wasted.

title: 2 Ex-Judges And a Lawyer Are Convicted Of Corruption
description: Two former California Superior Court judges and a prominent lawyer were found guilty on Friday in Federal District Court here of conspiring to conduct court affairs through a pattern of bribery and extortion.

title: Ghostly Halloween Goings-On for All
description: HALLOWEEN, often seen as a harbinger of more illustrious holidays, is upon us. It is held in less esteem by many than winter holidays carrying the weight of religion or passing of time, yet Halloween's arrival calls forth fervor from the young and does not require the observance (enthusiastic or less so) of entrenched rituals. Instead, it offers an opportunity to establish new traditions.

title: Condom Crew Caught in Middle on Streets
description: The streets are fraught with peril for the ''condom man,'' as people often refer to Cliff Brown when he approaches with two shiny silver packets and a brochure on preventing AIDS. Strolling through East New York, winding through the courtyards of the giant housing projects that dominate Brownsville, Mr. Brown, 22, said he and his young colleagues have been threatened, mugged at gunpoint and chased out of bodegas by angry drug dealers.

title: Big Mac, Hold the Beef
description: What do you serve at a New Delhi McDonald's? A Maharaja Mac, of course -- it's made with mutton. The restaurant, which opened last week, is the first McDonald's ever not to serve beef or pork.

title: Let's Clear the Political Path To the Future of Television
description: DURING the Presidential campaign debate in Hartford earlier this month, history was made. For the first time in these debates, television was added to the list of most significant domestic policy topics for the American public to consider.

title: The Main Attraction At Disney? It's Woods
description: The folks at Disney World are used to long lines. Good thing. They have them this weekend, and they are not snaking around Space Mountain. They are forming at the top of the leader board for the Walt Disney World/Oldsmobile Classic and at the gates leading to the Magnolia Course where, suddenly, golf has become the main Magic Kingdom attraction.

title: Clare Tuomey, Paul Stafstrom
description: Clare Mary Tuomey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh B. Tuomey of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul William Stafstrom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Stafstrom of Newington, Conn. The Rev. George Hunt officiated at St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J.

title: Bertuzzi Fumes, and Isles Add Loss to Their Vocabulary
description: Watching his team play a spirited game against the Detroit Red Wings tonight, Islanders forward Todd Bertuzzi no doubt wanted to add an uncivil word to Coach Mike Milbury's dictionary.

title: Our Neurotic Miseries
description: To the Editor:

title: On E. 43d St., a Church Is Rising From Its Ashes
description: Msgr. Eugene Clark has been looking for artisans to carve wood sculptures of 10 saints for the Church of St. Agnes, which is being rebuilt in Italian Renaissance style after fire gutted the original building at 141 East 43d Street. So during his trip abroad last week Monsignor Clark planned to talk to woodcarvers at a school in Paris affiliated with the Louvre.

title: Out of the Sandbox and Into Fashion, All by Age 7
description: RACHEL SCHOENAU was not happy about being turned down as a model for a Calvin Klein advertising campaign.

title: THE FUTURE OF NOSTALGIA
description: Keillor has a style that mirrors reality in a way that makes me feel like he's describing my own history and future. I laughed, I cried -- it was better than nostalgia itself.

title: World Series Stands on Its Own
description: THIS is the big time now. Disregard the glut of statistics they have been flinging around on all those networks for the last couple of weeks. Ban the words ''post-season'' from your memory. The real deal is about to begin.

title: Lisa Kaufman And Alan S. Kava
description: Lisa Dale Kaufman, the daughter of Dr. Judy Kaufman and Dr. Stephen Kaufman of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening to Alan Steven Kava, a son of Charlotte and Irwin Kava of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Paul Steinberg performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Ilene M. Rosen and Todd Rowan
description: Dr. Ilene Michele Rosen, a chief resident at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, and Dr. Philip Todd Rowan, an otolaryngologist with a medical group in Edison, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi George Schlesinger performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: The Salvia and The Menorah
description: Your gardening column on salvia (''Love It, Hate It, the Ubiquitous Salvia Persists,'' Oct. 6) brought to mind a fascinating interpretation of the plant developed in Israel.

title: Another View On Heroin Use
description: If heroin use is indeed increasing in Connecticut, as the article ''Heroin Moves In on a New Generation'' (Sept. 8) indicates, it is all the more important that Connecticut citizens know the facts and take practical steps to deal with heroin addition in their state. It is important to keep in mind the following:

title: If Room Prices Keep Rising, So May New Hotels
description: THE hospitality business in New York is booming,'' said Ambrose Cheung, a director of the Lai Sun Development Company of Hong Kong, which led a group that bought the luxury Four Seasons Hotel earlier this year. ''For overseas investors, New York is the prime city of the East Coast of the United States.''

title: North Bellmore Divided Over Use Of Military Base
description: A FORMER military base is dividing North Bellmore. The community was supposed to have devised a plan for the 16.6-acre site that the Federal Government would accept.

title: Sarah E. Winkler, Simon J. Leopold
description: Sarah Ellen Winkler, a daughter of Amelia B. Winkler of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Dr. Marvin H. Winkler of Clinton, Conn., was married last evening to Simon J. Leopold, a son of Joyce Gersten Pariser of Brooklyn Heights and Gregory Leopold of Manhattan. Rabbi Thomas K. Weiner performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: A Growing Number of Black Stars Are Shining in Hollywood
description: IT WAS A TRANSFORMATION that had been in the making for years but didn't become plainly visible until this summer, when every other movie, it seemed, had a black actor in a major role. Now a banner fall season for black actors is under way, and what may have been surprising in June has become accepted fact in October: No longer marginalized in all-black films, no longer relegated to ''buddy'' roles in big-budget action yarns, black actors have become mainstays in mainstream movies.

title: At This Time of Year, Lemke Means Trouble
description: Mariano Duncan could not be blamed if he looked out at the Atlanta Braves' infield during the World Series and said to himself, or to anyone within hearing, ''Oh, no, there he is again!''

title: Italian Dishes With Sparkle and Finesse
description: SAPORE del Mediterraneo breaks the Locust Valley mold of traditional cozy inns and old-line Italian restaurants. This dramatic new spot, with its twin waterfalls splashing into a lighted pool full of wishing pennies, has locals wide-eyed in astonishment.

title: Making History Of the Funniest Kind
description: EVEN in the glory days of his early boffo hits, Neil Simon was often labeled a ''joke machine.'' But the man who would become the most successful playwright in the world was shrewdly biding his time, as if revving up to have the last laugh.

title: Teen-Agers From Milan Learn the American Way
description: ''QUALI sono le tue prime impressioni dell' America?''

title: The 'P' Word
description: POWERTOWN

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION AND POETRY
description: GEYSER LIFE

title: Abuzz About Flights Over the Grand Canyon
description: WHEN President Clinton designated 1.7 million acres of Utah red rock county as a national monument last month, he spoke of the need to preserve places of beauty and solitude. It was a familiar refrain; on Earth Day (April 22), Mr. Clinton said that low-flying aircraft over national parks could ''mar the natural beauty of the parks and create significant noise problems as well.'' Before long, the Department of Transportation proposed regulations for reducing noise from sightseeing aircraft over Grand Canyon National Park, resulting in a shouting match between environmentalists and the air tour business.

title: Building Apartments for the Low-Income Elderly
description: WITH assistance from the city, a developer has begun building apartments for the low-income elderly in residential neighborhoods, with meals and a modest level of personal services.

title: L.I. Appealing to Floridians to 'Come On Up'
description: REMEMBER the airline that encouraged Long Islanders to ''come on down'' to Florida?

title: Suntans and Dates Don't Justify College Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Were Up and Bills Were Down in 1986, but Fans Know the Rest
description: Everybody is moaning. The Bills are 4-2 and some people in western New York growl that they want a new quarterback to replace the one destined for the Hall of Fame. The Jets are 0-7, even if the noise surrounding the Yankees is taking the glare off.

title: Unfettered Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Meghan Dillon, Andrew Stewart
description: Meghan Elizabeth Dillon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Dillon of Oxford, Md., was married yesterday to Andrew McLain Stewart, the son of Susan Hall Horn of Kirkwood, Mo., and Michael McLain Stewart of Fremont, Calif. The Rev. Rod Brown, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Oxford.

title: Ruth E. Hiller, David E. Peck
description: Dr. Ruth Eileen Hiller, a veterinarian, was married last evening to David Ethan Peck, a lawyer. Rabbi Leonard Romm performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Clinton's Record
description: Measured against his predecessors, President Clinton's civil rights record in the last four years is formidable.

title: Historic Rice Plantations Of South Carolina
description: GROWING up in South Carolina, I had driven across the Waccamaw and Pee Dee Rivers where they converge near Georgetown dozens of times. Mounting the bridge that spanned them always meant that we had finally reached the beach. But before Myrtle Beach became a mecca for golfers and sun-tanners, the Grand Strand's swampy southern tip was famous for its rice plantations; by the 1850's, Georgetown County was the western world's top rice producer. Back then, the rivers were as essential to the rice culture as today's highways are to tourism. Broad and smooth, they floated barges heaped with Carolina Gold, a rice variety prized in Europe, making rich the few dozen planters who lived on their banks.

title: 6 Arrested and 2 Hospitalized in Violent Brawl at College
description: They had come to celebrate homecoming and raise some funds for charity. Dressed for a night of hip-hop and dance hits, they thought of a release from classes.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Merlot

title: Puppeteer Specializes In Epics
description: MICHAEL ROMANYSHYN, the executive director of Los Kabayitos Puppet Theater at 107 Suffolk Street on the Lower East Side, has big plans for a tiny place. He will open his performance space this Thursday with a Toy Theater Festival of 19 shows for adults and children, continuing through Nov. 10.

title: Patricia O'Reilly, J. P. Huffstetler Jr.
description: Patricia Egan O'Reilly, a daughter of Gerald Ambrose O'Reilly of Litchfield, Conn., and the late Maureen Buckley O'Reilly, was married yesterday to James Phillip Huffstetler Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Huffstetler of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. James Pilon performed the ceremony at St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church in Sharon, Conn.

title: O'Bannon Is Standing Up And Making Noise for Nets
description: This was no time for Ed O'Bannon to blend in. It was his chance to unfold like a pop-up book, to rise up and show that he can add a dimension to the Nets.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ONE-MAN SHOW

title: Michael Harrison and Nina Lucas
description: Nina Marya Lucas, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert E. Lucas of New Hope, Pa., was married yesterday to Michael J. Harrison, the son of Jane R. Venable-Harrison and Michael R. Harrison, both of Philadelphia. The bride's father, who is a Byzantine Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas of Myra Byzantine Catholic Church in White Plains.

title: THE TRICKLE-DOWN THEORY
description: I am no fan of the dumbing-down of great art, music and literature, but I think Kakutani is a little hard on high culture's envy of mass culture's market share. I teach adolescents, and over the years, I've noticed a number of kids become interested in a serious art genre or musical style after experiencing it first in a movie or on television. You bet there's nothing wrong if ''Four Weddings and a Funeral'' got more people reading poetry.

title: Calypso Club Says Racism Is Behind Quality-of-Life Cries
description: Calypso City, a Jamaica Avenue nightclub popular with fans of chutney and calypso, has become the nemesis of neighbors who have turned their discontent over unruly clubgoers into demonstrations, which in turn have prompted cries of racism from the club's owner.

title: County Attracts Interest for Using Managed Care
description: A YEAR ago, Westchester County embarked on a radically changed method to provide health care to its poor. In a prototype program that operated under a waiver from the Federal Government, the county became the first in the state to mandate that Medicaid recipients receive care through health maintenance organizations and prepaid service plans.

title: Russia Must Eliminate Abuse of the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: America Fattens Up
description: To the G.N.P., the C.P.I. and the R.B.I., add the B.M.I., the Body Mass Index, a number that won't be popular with most of the body politic. For the body politic is made up of too many overweight bodies, a major study found last week.

title: PUNMEISTER
description: In the Army (ours) Counterintelligence Corps, we had our own ''dry martini'' story (On Language: ''Punmeister,'' by William Safire, Sept. 22). During World War II, I met my contact at a London bar. He ordered martinis. ''Dry?'' asked the barman. ''Nein, zwei,'' replied Helmut.

title: It Looked Like Araby, but It Was Really the East End
description: ''THE SHEIK'' is 75.

title: Sun Devils Avoid Upset With Overtime Victory
description: A referee scored a touchdown for Southern California, a running back scored four for Arizona State and overtime took practically until Sunday.

title: A Hard Fought Race That's Costing Millions
description: At first, the retired garment workers gathered at American Legion Post No. 227 seemed unimpressed. Mayor William J. Pascrell Jr. of Paterson had stopped by to give a speech, and as he patted shoulders and pumped hands, the response was tepid.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: THE TRICKLE-DOWN THEORY
description: When I was born in 1947, my father began making two biweekly purchases without fail: a United States Savings Bond and a Classics Illustrated comic book (Culture Zone: ''The Trickle-Down Theory,'' by Michiko Kakutani, Sept. 22).

title: THE CANON
description: I read ''The Next Hundred Years'' from cover to cover. It was fascinating . . . until I came to ''The Canon'' (Sept. 29). There were 23 ''experts,'' six of whom were women, and of those six, three were in fashion. Not a single woman was selected to represent artistic achievements that will last through the next century. Excuse me? What an insult.

title: THE CANON
description: It is unfortunate that some of the experts invited to speculate on the late-20th-century canon chose to be flippant or cynical and suggest works that are banal, trivial or inconsequential, at best. ''Cats''? ''Groundhog Day''? Come on.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Gabrielle Holder, Elijah Turner 3d
description: Gabrielle Liane Holder, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. Samuel R. Holder and Mrs. Holder of Laurelton, Queens, was married yesterday to Elijah Turner 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Turner Jr. of Hesperia, Calif. The Rev. David R. Holder, who is the bride's brother and an African Methodist Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the University Park Country Club in Sarasota, Fla.

title: George Runs Well, Linemen Eat Well
description: The way Houston running back Eddie George is running, he may be on his way to the National Football League offensive rookie of the year honor. He may also be running toward a slimmer bank account.

title: Bad Year for Pumpkins, Not So Bad for Corn
description: The wet, cool summer has reduced New Jersey's pumpkin crop this year to half the nearly 30 million pounds grown last year, or even less. No place was hurt worse than Monmouth County, normally the state's leading pumpkin producer. The county has about 1,000 acres of pumpkins, and farmers there can usually count on 2,000 to 3,000 pounds an acre, said Richard Obal, agriculture agent with the Rutgers Cooperative Extension Service in Monmouth County.

title: Following Trails and Stories, Pound Ridge Man Finds a Lost Village
description: WHAT compels a former photography laboratory owner and current commercial real estate manager for an investment group to dig for facts on old cider mills and gristmills and unearth lost gravesites?

title: Time, Again, To Tuck In Spring Bulbs
description: JUST a few thoughts on a chore that should be on everyone's mind: bulb planting. Since the days are cooling down and trees are beginning to change color, no time should be wasted.

title: A Newspaper Returns Home to Hartford
description: WHEN the prized Hartford Collection of the Hartford Public Library reopens formally in refurbished space this week, there will be one big new piece not yet open to the public: The files of The Hartford Times, once Connecticut's largest daily, which have returned to Hartford 20 years after the newspaper published its last issue on Oct. 20, 1976.

title: THE NEXT HUNDRED YEARS
description: What a magnificent and invigorating issue -- ''The Next Hundred Years'' (Sept. 29).
