It's about time that someone said that the world is nowhere near the apocalyptic predictions that bombard us from every direction. We still have the creativity, mobility and joie de vivre to get us through.

title: Synagogue, Century Old, Told to Move
description: A small Orthodox synagogue has endured for a century on West 103d Street, surviving the demolition of its original building and the conviction of its rabbi in a 1970's nursing home scandal. But the congregation is now fighting eviction by the co-op board that shares its building.

title: When The Market Wasn't for The Masses
description: ''OY, they're zetzing the market, again!''

title: Remembering a Deli Man
description: Abe Lebewohl's murderer has yet to be caught. More than seven months have passed since Mr. Lebewohl, the legendary owner of the Second Avenue Deli, was shot and killed during a daylight robbery on March 4 as he was delivering the day's deposits to an East Village bank.

title: The Reconstruction of a 5-Story Mansion Manque
description: EVEN though the foyer ceiling was blanketed in low-hanging sheetrock, Marcy Balk knew -- or maybe hoped -- that something good lay underneath.

title: Promises Rued
description: Among Republicans, the 1994 Congressional campaign saw a small outburst of candidates' promises that -- unlike ''I care!'' -- were too specific to shrug off later. This year has seen no similar action. Considering the wages of this particular brand of cheek-puffery, it's easy to see why.

title: Maureen McGrath, Thomas Svoboda
description: Maureen McGrath, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Terence J. McGrath of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas F. Svoboda, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Svoboda of Memphis. The Rev. Robert O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. John and St. Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-13

title: Giuliani Denies Conflict Charge
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani responded yesterday to allegations by the cable entrepreneur Ted Turner about the Mayor's connections to one of Mr. Turner's cable rivals, Rupert Murdoch, calling them ''totally, absolutely false.''

title: Would You Fight for These Islands?
description: IT would be hard to imagine a more bizarre scenario for a war between the United States and China: a dispute over a cluster of uninhabited islets in the ocean south of Japan. Of all the spots around the world where the United States may have a commitment to send troops into harm's way, these tiny islands may be the oddest.

title: Freak Love
description: Tyranny of the Normal

title: Unraveling the Regal Pedigree of a Silver Tureen
description: WHEN George Ortiz decided in June to sell a sumptuous 18th-century French silver tureen that had been in his family for more than 40 years, he thought he knew almost everything about the piece and its royal pedigree. But after weeks of the kind of detective work that excites collectors, he learned that while a king had indeed owned the tureen, its origins were less than royal.

title: The Un-Candidate
description: RALPH NADER IS SITTING IN FRONT OF A MIRROR, NOT looking at himself. Fresh from accepting the Presidential nomination of the Green Party U.S.A., he has just finished a very long speech before a very loud crowd, but here in the dingy light of a theater-department dressing room at the University of California at Los Angeles, he gives another, shorter this time.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column of the Travel section last Sunday, about newly designated National Scenic Byways and All-American Roads, misstated the telephone number for the National Scenic Byways Clearinghouse, which provides information about the road program. It is (800) 429-9297.

title: Heidi Howard and Aaron Tandy
description: Heidi Ilena Howard and Aaron William Tandy, lawyers in New York, were married last evening at the Doral Beach Hotel in Miami Beach. Rabbi Gary Glickstein performed the ceremony.

title: More Unforgettable Homework
description: More replies from students, past and present, on the question: What was the best homework assignment you ever had to do? Or the worst? Why?

title: No Name, No Sex but Lots of Style
description: WHAT An eight-pound pewter statuette, with the torso of a human and an electric-guitar bottom, designed for the second VH1 Fashion Awards by Gianni Versace and made by Robert Du Grenier, a SoHo sculptor.

title: THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: The Speaker

title: Nosing Around New York's Water Supply
description: Take it from Wilburt Evans: New York tap water is best served well chilled to preserve its aromatic bouquet of rose petals. Letting it warm up deprives it of the fragrant whiff of Eau de Croton, he says.

title: The Home of the Man Who Planned Chelsea
description: THAT'S the way it usually happens with renovations -- the repairs start before you're finished with the initial project. Steven Shore, a lawyer, was still ironing out the finishing touches on his brick house at 21st Street and Ninth Avenue this spring when the roof started leaking. After that delay he is ready to tackle the final things -- stripping the wooden doorway and repointing the brickwork -- on his gem of a house, built in 1833 as the beachhead for James N. Wells, the man who planned Chelsea.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of cruise ships on Oct. 6 misidentified the operator of the Panorama. It is Classical Cruises and Tours, not Swan Hellenic.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Labor Negotiations Not Rained Out
description: The rain that washed out Game 1 of the World Series did not deter negotiators seeking a labor agreement for baseball, who went back and forth between each other's Manhattan offices yesterday in an effort to work out the few remaining issues.

title: Let's Play None: It's a Washout in the Bronx
description: The World Series has become the Wet Series. Don a raincoat, because it could get worse. The first World Series game at Yankee Stadium since 1981 was scheduled for last night, but it was postponed by excessive rain and the forecast is gloomy for tonight, too. The first pitch in Game 1 might not be thrown until Monday and the series might finish later than any other in history if the bad weather persists.

title: Corrections
description: A report about Rome on Sept. 22, in a roundup of ways to spend a day in each of eight European cities, misattributed the design of an arch over the Via Giulia behind the Palazzo Farnese. The artist is not known, but was not Michelangelo.

title: Correction
description: An article in Westchester and Connecticut copies on Oct. 6 about a controversy over plans for a former college campus in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., misstated the date of a village board election that resulted in a majority opposed to the project. It was in March 1995, not last April.

title: Sara A. Callagy, Nicholas B. Finn
description: Sara Alicia Callagy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Callagy of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Brine Finn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Finn of Sharon, Conn. Msgr. Donald Pryor officiated at the Church of the Resurrection.

title: Q and A
description: London's Film Festival

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Tough Rows to Hoe

title: The Art of the Possible
description: MEMOIRS

title: High Praise And High Goals
description: George Steinbrenner has always enjoyed wrapping himself up in the role of an underdog. Steinbrenner often acts as if he were just like the peddler hustling peanuts outside Yankee Stadium or the vendor hawking beer in the mezzanine. Steinbrenner wants to be an underdog. Of course, the role fits the multimillionaire about as comfortably as a pair of children's mittens.

title: The Sweet and Savory Tastes of Ecuador
description: The name on the sign, Su Bakery, has been known to cause confusion in linguistically diverse Bergen County. Every once in a while, a customer wanders in expecting to find a Korean-run pastry shop. But in fact the name is Spanish, welcoming customers to ''your bakery.''

title: Q. & A.
description: Duplicate Key Denied To Tenant

title: Violence on TV Declines
description: Last season ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox broadcast less blood and gore than the season before, according to a study released last week. But critics and the networks alike were unsure whether the decline was a response to public pressure about violence, or merely a normal shift in programming tastes. As the study's director, Jeffrey Cole of the University of California in Los Angeles, put it, ''Was this the season everyone tried to imitate 'Friends' or is there serious change going on?''

title: THE ARTIFICIAL WOMB
description: Perri Klass's article ''The Artificial Womb Is Born'' (Sept. 29) was as disturbing as she meant it to be. However, her casual invective against prolonged breast-feeding was especially unnerving.

title: In Oradell, the Arts Vie With Electronics . . .
description: For the last few years, the Hackensack Water Company site in Oradell has been a silent giant of old pumphouses and steam engines. But now it is generating some noise over whether it should become a factory or a cultural center.

title: At Englishtown, a Drive-In Sells Stamps to Go (Hold the Fries)
description: The Englishtown postmaster, Louis Thievon, knew he wouldn't be getting much pedestrian traffic when his office was moved outside the quaint old downtown. So when the project engineer, Edward Filapella, laid out the new Englishtown-Manalapan Post Office six years ago, Mr. Thievon asked him to incorporate a car-friendly feature more often found at banks and fast-food restaurants: a drive-in window.

title: Us, Hostile? Want to Make Something of It?
description: DRIVING down the Parkway to Atlantic City on a sunny afternoon this week, I was looking for early-warning signs of hostility. Sure enough, a Mercury hurtled past with a bumper sticker that said: MY KID BEAT UP YOUR HONOR STUDENT.

title: Pataki Vetoes Reassessment Plan
description: Saying it could have ''unintended, devastating consequences for local economies,'' Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed legislation that would have required all land in Westchester to be reassessed over the next five years and would have allowed a shift of some of the tax burden away from homeowners.

title: HIGH IS LOW
description: In celebrating the demise of the distinction between high and low art, Ann Douglas overlooks the crucial fact that all art worth keeping depends on that very distinction (''High Is Low,'' Sept. 29). Yes, Sophocles was popular in his day, as was Aristophanes, who juxtaposed high and low elements with extraordinary skill. But such juxtapositions work by exploiting the perception of a contrast; thus, it is precisely the distinction between high and low art that makes their coexistence both possible and meaningful. The long success of that coexistence suggests that the culture wars do not pit high against low, but culture against nonculture. And if Douglas is right to subsume ghetto rappers under the same rubric (''successful nonwhite writers'') as Salman Rushdie -- that is, if the subliterate now qualifies as literature -- then it is fairly clear which side has won.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: A Long, Winding Path Leads a Fiery Maestro to New Jersey
description: HE HAS COME TO THE New Jersey Symphony like Prometheus, bringing fire. It is in his eyes and his soul, the musicians say, and in his belly. And now they sense the heat of that fire in their sound.

title: Wings on a Bird: School Reform And Diversity
description: IF the primary purpose for convening the Educational Improvement Panel was to demonstrate the range of discordant opinion on the state's public schools, then the panel has been a success.

title: A Sampling of Sample Sales
description: Sample sale season is here. It's the time of year when you can find cashmere sweaters for $30 and leather gloves for $5. It's when designers and manufacturer showrooms open their doors to sell excess inventory to the public. ''This is it,'' said Elysa Lazar, who publishes The S & B Report, the monthly guide to showroom sales in New York, who said there are more than 140 sales expected in November and more than 250 in December.

title: A Big Toe Causes A Lineup Problem
description: Darryl Strawberry, who has worked hard to be a solid citizen, called the question delicate before he even addressed it. Would Strawberry be better suited to starting as the designated hitter in the World Series because of his fractured right big toe?

title: Hugh Ferrand and Susan Murphy
description: Susan Farrell Murphy and Hugh William Edward Ferrand were married last evening in New York. The Rev. Gary G. Seibert performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church of Yorkville.

title: Racism (Cont.)
description: To the Editor: It is regrettable that Ms. Olibrice had such a terrible time on her first trip to Asia and blames it all on racism. People often stare at other people who look different, or say that someone who speaks differently has an accent. In Tokyo once, when I, an African-American woman, size 16, asked a petite Japanese woman for a dress in my size, she asked ''Do you mean king size?'' I was not offended.

title: Capturing the Unposed Instant and the American Landscape
description: Weegee

title: Deborah Penner, Douglas Bernstein
description: Deborah Faith Penner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester S. Penner of Great Neck, L.I., was married there last evening to Douglas Neil Bernstein, the son of Mrs. Harvey Morgan of Kings Point, L.I., and the late Howard Bernstein. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

title: Africa Hears Indifference in a U.S. Offer to Help
description: WITH its more than 50 young and fragile states, for decades Africa has been the theater of as many conflicts, from bloody civil wars to cross-border clashes, as any continent. Throughout, if a single element distinguished African strife, it was foreign involvement.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: While answering a question about transportation between Merida, Mexico, and the Maya ruins in Palenque, the Q & A column of Sept. 1 missed an opportunity to suggest an itinerary that would considerably enhance the trip.

title: Changing Channels
description: BAKER'S DOZEN

title: New Kind of Test For Candidates?
description: The image is a bit jarring at first. A public ceremony in which the Presidential contenders meet to take drug tests?

title: Taking Hold of the Purse Strings, and Holding Their Own
description: THE November issue of Money magazine is a paean to the growing power and independence of women who have taken control of their financial destinies. A 25-page special report -- which gathers the opinions of more than two dozen financial professionals, researchers, academics and individual investors -- covers the bases of this phenomenon and gives standard but sound advice for those who want to jump on the bandwagon.

title: Bringing Classic American Motion Pictures to the TV Screen
description: KATE McENROE, president of the American Movie Classics network, took to the stage at last month's Emmy awards to accept the first President's Award Emmy for programming that addresses social and educational issues. AMC, which plays classic films from the 1930's through the 70's, won for its original documentary, ''Blacklist: Hollywood on Trial.'' The documentary concerned the House Un-American Activities Committee's inquiries into the political activities within the film industry.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: Politics On and Out of Line
description: I HAVE PROGRAMMED my computer to guide me through the season's politics. It yields a private interactive web site that unfailingly tells the truth. Asked Who's Winning? for example, it does not mince words:

title: Willard Simmons, 84, Is Dead; Founded Market Research Firm
description: Willard R. Simmons, a founding partner of W. R. Simmons and Associates Research, the New York marketing research firm, died on Monday at the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond. He was 84 and had been a longtime resident of Mamaroneck, N.Y., before retiring to Whitestone, Va.

title: Wrong Message
description: To the Editor:

title: WEIRDNESS MAKES SENSE
description: Just as Einstein wondered what he would see if he observed an electromagnetic field while traveling at the velocity of light, I wonder what Timothy Ferris would see in a world that followed quantum logic (''Weirdness Makes Sense,'' Sept. 29). It would be a world without victims since nobody could point to another person or thing as being the cause of whatever happened to him. It would be a world in which only success is possible since everyone is creating his reality at every instant. It would be a world without opposites since all opposites are complementary aspects of the same, underlying reality, existing simultaneously as tendencies until an observer decided to focus attention on one of the aspects, transforming it into reality. It would be a world in which words like luck and impossible were missing from the dictionaries. It would be a world, in short, where abundance and personal responsibility were our common birthright.

title: Giving Credit Where Credit Is Due
description: The photographs that appeared on page one with ''Sanford White and His Life Under Scrutiny of Descendant,'' on Sept. 22 caught my eye immediately. Although the print of a woman in golfing clothes with the Shinnecock Hills Club House in the background may have been obtained from the Southampton Historical Society, the credit was incorrect.

title: A Mansion Will Wake Up To Find It's 1908 Again
description: Just as hems rise and fall, only to rise again, architectural styles come and go, only to return. The most dramatic recent case in point may be the building at 49 East 52d Street.

title: Robert Bannon, 86, Researcher in Optics
description: Dr. Robert Edward Bannon, an educator and researcher in optics and optometry, died on Sept. 16 at the Oakwood Health Care Center in Amherst, N.Y. He was 86 and lived in Amherst, near Buffalo.

title: Which Germans?
description: THE POLITICS OF MEMORY

title: Nancy Goldenberg, Adam J. Kansler
description: Nancy Goldenberg, the daughter of Sondra and A. Carl Goldenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Jason Kansler, a son of Bonnie J. Kansler of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and the late Dr. Frederick N. Kansler. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: LONGITUDE: The True Story of a Lone Genius Who Solved the Greatest Scientific Problem of His Time

title: Archer Daniels Midland, Fine-Payer to the U.S.
description: For someone long used to having his way in the complex worlds of business and politics, last week was a shocker for Dwayne O. Andreas, the chairman of the Archer Daniels Midland Company. After more than a year of combating a Government investigation into allegations of price-fixing of agricultural products, Archer Daniels finally folded its cards. It agreed to plead guilty to the crime and pay a $100 million fine -- more than seven times the highest amount ever paid in such a case.

title: Italian Dishes at a Larchmont Makeover
description: KISSES, indeed, to this restaurant's stunning makeover from a nondescript spaghetti parlor into a stylish beauty swathed in white -- filmy swags of drapery, linens, fake leather button-back chairs -- all white, except the luxurious curve of glass-brick walls and sepia wallpaper with Leonardo-like drawings of women's heads floating here and there. As in a Fellini film, a dreamlike quality pervades the slow hours in this small dining room, a fantasy lost when the room fills later with those supping at a more fashionable time.

title: Law Student Sees South Africa Up Close
description: A NOT guilty verdict was rendered last week in South Africa's first attempt to hold senior officials accountable for apartheid-era atrocities against blacks.

title: The Right Stuff About a High School
description: INTEREST in regional magnet schools as an instrument for easing Connecticut's school segregation has been a windfall for High School in the Community. The 26-year-old New Haven school has become the most technologically advanced public school in the state and now has science labs, a library and a gymnasium, which it lacked for its first quarter century. But it has decided to continue to do without a principal.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Doubtful That Dole Can Close Gap
description: As the Presidential campaign enters its final two-week rally, prominent Republicans around the country are increasingly and more openly expressing doubts that Bob Dole can gain enough ground to defeat President Clinton.

title: Bork's Bite
description: SLOUCHING TOWARDS GOMORRAHModern Liberalism and American Decline.By Robert H. Bork.382 pp. New York: Regan Books. $25.

title: The Office Market: Renovation, Not Construction
description: ALTHOUGH there has been a steady growth in demand for prime office space on Long Island, potential rents are still not high enough to cover the cost of new construction, and lenders are not willing to provide financing for new speculative office buildings -- those not preleased to a tenant. Investment capital is flowing instead into the renovation of existing buildings.

title: The Rickety Kelly May Be Down, but He Is Far From Out
description: Jim Kelly often throws parties at his spacious home after Buffalo Bills football games at Rich Stadium. At these affairs, it does not take much to discern whether the Bills had won or lost.

title: Belarus Knight on a Charger Carries Hammer and Sickle
description: With this former Soviet republic teetering on the brink of crisis, thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets today to protest President Aleksandr Lukashenko's plan to gain near absolute power.

title: THE NEXT HUNDRED YEARS
description: I was disappointed to find scant mention of sports in your issue devoted to 2096. As a lifelong Boston Red Sox fan, I was eager to find out if we have a chance of winning the World Series in the next 100 years.

title: Fred Hooper, at 99 Years Young, Still Finds Himself on the Right Track
description: His name is Fred Hooper, he was a construction man who got into horse racing more than half a century ago, he won the Kentucky Derby in 1945 with the first horse he ever owned and he is getting ready to travel to Toronto to run his 4-year-old colt Diplomatic Jet in the $2 million Breeders' Cup Turf on Saturday in Woodbine, Ontario. He is 99 years old, the senior owner of racing thoroughbreds on the planet.

title: Elizabeth Hagerty, Lawrence Dessen
description: Elizabeth Ann Hagerty, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Hagerty Jr. of Sea Island, Ga., was married yesterday to Lawrence Wise Dessen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Dessen of Sugarloaf, Pa. The Most Rev. Patrick V. Ahern performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: A Risky New Role for Mexico's Army
description: Modern Mexico has an admirably strong tradition of civilian control over the military. Mexican generals, unlike those elsewhere in Latin America, neither plot for power nor challenge the orders of the elected Government.

title: Fractured? Jersey City Thrives on Its Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hard Hit And an Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Dese, Dem and Dole
description: FROM the Navy Yard in Williamsburg to the Army base at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn was a borough at war in late 1943. There seemed to be soldiers everywhere: local boys home on leave, others enjoying themselves before shipping out to Europe and thousands more in training in the New York area. Among them was a wide-eyed 20-year-old from a small town in Kansas called Russell, then just another anonymous G.I. who blended in with the crowd of recruits who were training at Brooklyn College.

title: Bronx Precinct Captain Is Shot in the Back
description: The executive officer of one of New York City's most violent and troubled precincts was shot in the back early yesterday as he arrived in an unmarked patrol car at his station house in the central Bronx.

title: With Nazism, A Return to His Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: As Shouts Die Down, Japan Is Ready for National Vote
description: Japanese began filing into polling booths this morning to vote in national elections, the first major test of a new electoral system intended to make the political system more responsive to popular will.

title: Liability Horse
description: Two Dartmouth College fraternity boys recently grew weary of living four to a room in the Alpha Delta house - the frat whose early-60's incarnation inspired the movie ''Animal House'' - so they drew up plans for a treehouse on 15-foot poles, featuring electricity, modem connections, a deck and ... no plumbing. The guys promised to pad to the big house anytime they needed a bathroom. Though the town seemed to buy this idea - the fraternity, which sits on private property, gained a permit - the school did not. ''Sure they would,'' said Sean Gorman, associate counsel for the college.

title: Smiling Through the 60's in Reagan Country
description: DESERT CIVILIZATIONS bequeath spare mysteries for the future: astronomical clocks made of sandstone, bones wrapped with gold, brittle parchment crossed with esoteric glyphs. Archeologists guess what's missing.

title: In Tribute to Ella Fitzgerald, and Yonkers
description: ELLA FITZGERALD now stands next to the Metro-North station in Yonkers.

title: For Bruckner, a Vague Nazi Aura Persists
description: ONE HUNDRED YEARS AFTER his death, Anton Bruckner is still positioned on the fringe of the American symphonic canon, despite having a loyal core of enthusiasts. When Mahler's time came in the 1960's, many believed that Bruckner's would soon follow, but that moment never quite arrived. Beyond the concert hall, Bruckner was shunned by musicologists and theorists. Mere mention of his name at an academic conference inevitably produced a curled lip or a condescending smile.

title: Army Simply Runs Tulane Out of Town
description: Navy has a problem if Army can handle water as well as this.

title: Some People Need a Sermon on the Mound
description: THIS is no time to pull a Yogi Berra, to refuse to set foot in the stadium so long as George Steinbrenner owns the Yankees. Yogi, after all, got to watch many World Series, and from excellent locations. So, if you have Series tickets, go ahead and enjoy them. Make a lot of noise in the Bronx, cheering for all those young millionaires who came here from other places to wear our city's name on their shirts and promote us on the national happy-news network. If you don't have tickets, you should watch the game on television, preferably in glad and noisy company.

title: Lars V. Ahlfors, 89, Pioneer in the Outer Reaches of Higher Math
description: Lars Valerian Ahlfors, a mathematician whose mind plumbed the theoretical outer reaches of higher mathematics, died on Oct. 11 at the Willowood nursing home in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 89 and lived in Boston.

title: Once a Star Everywhere But Home
description: SCOTT WALKER IS PROBABLY THE FINEST, most enigmatic American pop baritone of the last 35 years. At the height of his fame in the mid-60's, hordes of fans mobbed him everywhere he went, tearing off his clothes, pulling out locks of his hair, even removing the upholstery and mirrors of his car as souvenirs. This was in Britain, where Mr. Walker, a crooner with a dark side, became as big a teen-age heartthrob as any of the Beatles. Simultaneously, he earned respect as an artist, influencing David Bowie, Elvis Costello and Jarvis Cocker of Pulp.

title: Luba Khodos, Stuart Evensen
description: Luba Khodos and Stuart Ronald Evensen were married on Friday evening in Weston, Conn. Rabbi Mark Lipson performed the ceremony at Cobb's Mill Inn.

title: Torricelli Attacks Gingrich in a Campaign Among Minorities
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli brought his campaign for the United States Senate here today to one of the nation's poorest cities, appealing to black and Hispanic voters to remain loyal to the Democratic Party because of its support for social programs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Sept. 29 about fall foliage information lines in Rhode Island misstated two telephone numbers. The number for the Rhode Island Division of Tourism is (800) 556-2484; the number for the South County Tourism Council is (800) 548-4662.

title: Focus Shifts To Contests In the House
description: When Mayor Willie Brown of San Francisco, the wily survivor of dozens of electoral contests, heard the other day that Bob Dole had decided to campaign extensively in California despite the long odds against him here, he knew it could mean only one thing.

title: On New Pier, A Necessity Brings Amenity
description: Say, heaven forbid, a smoky fire forced you from your vehicle while you were driving to New Jersey through the Holland Tunnel. Until recently, if you followed the emergency exit signs out of the tunnel, you would find yourself 900 feet off shore from Canal Street on a concrete island in the Hudson River. There, dwarfed by a six-story ventilation structure that looks like a cross between a smokestack and an Art Deco folly, rescue boats would be sent to bring stranded passengers back to land.

title: Winning Formula: Location, Location, Connections
description: In the sprawling financial empire of the Riady family, one of the big-ticket items is an enormous, $700 million power plant being planned in Fujian Province on China's southeastern coast.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Mixing Things Up With a Laugh
description: One of the interesting byproducts of the cable revolution and the explosion in the number of channels has been a more permissive attitude toward the avant-garde, the experimental and -- whom are we trying to impress here? -- the blithely outrageous, the chronically over the top or the merely eccentric.

title: Susan K. Meyers And Ian P. Ratner
description: Susan Kay Meyers, the daughter of Dr. Robert A. Meyers of Ann Arbor, Mich., and the late Norma Van Tuyl Meyers, was married last evening to Ian Peter Ratner, the son of Carol Ratner and Dr. Lynn H. Ratner of New York. Rabbi Mychal B. Springer performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Sociology Is Fine, But Students Need Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: Dealing the Race Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Making It Right?
description: From time to time, consultants have been known to save a company. But their arrival also tends to make workers nervous, and it is not uncommon for employees to start heading for the doors soon after the experts arrive. What happened when consultants came to your office? Did the place clear out? Or did no one take them seriously? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Friendly, Joking Boss And a 'Nice Family Man'
description: Every Thursday at lunch time, Lieut. Federico Narvaez pulled his sensible Chevrolet Cavalier up to his 9-year-old daughter's parochial school and began his favorite shift of the week, as lunchroom monitor. ''The kids loved him,'' said one colleague. ''They would hang all over him.''

title: From Norway, an Unsettling Look at What's Below the Surface
description: ONLY a few paintings are in the exhibition ''Love, Isolation and Darkness,'' the Bruce Museum's survey of the work of Edvard Munch. Yet the show in Greenwich manages to contain the core of his work. Munch's prints are even more trenchant and emotionally wrenching than his paintings, and most of his well-known images are present in the lithographs, etchings, woodcuts and aquatints that make up the bulk of the exhibition.

title: On Balanchine's Turf, Going Beyond His Influence
description: THIS WEEK, Francia Russell and Kent Stowell, the artistic directors of Pacific Northwest Ballet, will bring their company to City Center for the first time, but in doing so they will also be returning home. ''It's where we both danced with City Ballet and spent so much of our early lives,'' Ms. Russell explained.

title: A Smorgasbord of Seawater
description: WHEN I was 5, I used to think heaven was a place my great-grandparents played harps above the clouds. When my kids were toddlers, I thought it must be live-in help. Now I know: Heaven is the Hydrotherapie Doyer bathtub at Les Thermes Marins de Monte Carlo.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: Magellan Wasn't Alone In Portfolio Changes

title: Police Captain Is Shot in the Back in a Troubled Precinct in the Bronx
description: The executive officer of one of New York City's most violent and troubled precincts was shot in the back early yesterday as he arrived in an unmarked patrol car at his station house in the central Bronx. He survived, and the police mounted an intense search for an assailant they said was probably a sniper.

title: Sarah E. Winer, Steven R. Maizes
description: Sarah Ellen Winer, a daughter of Margery Schab of New York and James P. B. Winer of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., is to be married today to Steven Robert Maizes, a son of Jeanette and Howard Maizes of Nanuet, N.Y. Rabbi David E. Greenberg is to perform the ceremony at the Regency Hotel in New York.

title: Job Uncertainty Makes Offers Easier to Refuse
description: AS an advertising executive, Paul Cappelli knows an enticing pitch when he hears one, and over the last five years he's heard a few -- like the one the Leo Burnett Company used to try to lure him from his New York agency to Burnett's Chicago headquarters. He said he was offered a raise and signing bonus that was too good to pass up.

title: Arne Barkhuus, 90, U.N. Health Official
description: Dr. Arne Barkhuus, a retired senior public health official for the World Health Organization and a former professor at Columbia University, died on Sept. 28 at the Ingleside Nursing Home in Old Tappan, N.J. He was 90 and a longtime resident of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Party Animals
description: From the names on the honorary committee alone, Kerwin Briswell knew that the second annual Rheumatologist Ball to Honor Fashion in Dance on Public Television was no time for baby vegetables. In all his years at Victorious Victuals, Briswell had never come across such a cross section of co-chairman talent. The list included Isaac Mizrahi, Isaiah Berlin, Anne Bass, Hootie and the Blowfish, Felix Rohatyn, Steve Rattner, Babe, Judith Jamison, Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy, Henry Louis Gates Jr. and David Foster Wallace.

title: The Limits of Abortion Protests
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments last week on the ''constructive blockades'' used by anti-abortion groups to impede access to reproductive health clinics. These blockades force patients and staff to run a gantlet of intimidation and harassment. The Court should continue to endorse restrictions on the use of this tactic while preserving the free-speech rights of abortion opponents.

title: New Heights for a Diva: RuPaul's TV Talk Show
description: RUPAUL, actor, author, club performer, disco radio disk jockey and, most of all, transvestite diva, is now kicking up his estimable heels as a television talk-show host.

title: Vibrant Florals Come Out in Paris
description: An exuberant clash of flowered patterns, stained-glass colors and kimono silhouettes was the eye-catcher in Paris earlier this month. Rei Kawakubo's ensembles for Comme des Garcons were not worn by models at the fashion shows but by audience members, many of them Japanese women enjoying this vibrant, abstract version of traditional Japanese garb at a time when minimalism dominates fashion.

title: Caste and Sikh Temple Politics May Be Behind Fatal Shooting
description: Just after dusk on the last Sunday in August, a black Chevrolet Blazer cruised down 95th Avenue in Richmond Hill. It pulled up in front of a pale pink bungalow where a group of young men were standing, and a gunman opened fire, killing a 19-year-old Indian immigrant and injuring another man. The next day, Rajwinder Singh, 35, of Richmond Hill, was arrested for murder.

title: New Rochelle Hopes Home Depot Sparks a Revival
description: AFTER trying to establish itself in Westchester for more than three years, Home Depot will finally celebrate the opening on Thursday of a 118,435-square-foot store that officials here hope will turn this city into a regional shopping destination.

title: What in the World's With 'Carmen Sandiego'?
description: DURING A FIVE-YEAR CRIME spree on the popular public-television show ''Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego?,'' the cartoon antagonist and her band of brutish crooks stole hundreds of geographical landmarks and tried to elude real schoolchildren who acted as detectives by answering questions about world culture. Now, abetted by new production technology, Carmen and a new bunch of villains are after history itself.

title: Study Finds Little Change in Federal Prosecution of Drug Cases
description: The Government's prosecution of drug crimes, far from sagging under President Clinton, has continued at about the pace set by President George Bush, according to a study released this weekend.

title: Airlines Test New Scrutiny Of Baggage
description: To reduce the threat of bombs on domestic flights, several small airlines have recently begun verifying that each bag in the cargo holds belongs to a passenger aboard the flight, and on Nov. 1 larger airlines will begin a major study on what it would take for them to do the same, according to the White House commission that was established after the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800.

title: Prep Schools and the Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Fred Feldman, Helicopter Reporter, Dies at 63
description: Fred Feldman, New York radio's first helicopter reporter who spent 16 airborne years monitoring traffic for rush-hour commuters and who invented the term ''rubbernecking delays'' to explain why they would be late for work, died on Friday at his home in Roseland, N.J. He was 63.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ART SALE BENEFIT

title: Jodi Drexler and Bradford Billet
description: Jodi A. Drexler, the daughter of Francine and Halbert H. Drexler of New York, was married last evening to Bradford E. Billet, the son of Francine and Marvin Billet, also of New York. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani officiated with Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich at the Pierre.

title: Transcending a Painful Moment in History
description: BEFORE this story comes around to music, it must work its way through the killing of the Greensboro Five, 17 years ago.

title: Lebed Gets The Boot
description: FIRED but nor forgotten, Aleksandr I. Lebed spent his first day as a private citizen attending a performance of ''Ivan the Terrible'' because, he said, he wanted to learn ''how to rule the state.''

title: Suntans and Dates Don't Justify College Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Storm Batters Region With Rain and Wind
description: A powerful northeaster whipped through the New York region yesterday, bringing record rain and gale-force wind that gusted to 81 miles an hour.

title: Mary Noonan, Mark Robichaux
description: A REPORTER for The Wall Street Journal, Mark Robichaux is known around his office as ''the crazy Cajun.''

title: Correction
description: A Bookend essay on Sept. 15, about book editors in movies and in real life, misstated Goldie Hawn's occupation in the 1991 film ''Deceived.'' She plays an art conservator, not a book editor. A reader's letter dated Sept. 21 pointed out the error, but it was initially misdirected at The Times.

title: Alternatives to Long Island Touted by Other States
description: THERE are several alternatives being promoted to visiting Long Island. For $599 a Revolutionary Fun Package provides four days' admission and lodging for a family of four to Colonial Williamsburg and nearby Jamestown, Yorktown and Busch Gardens and Water Country in Virginia.

title: Abigail Rose, Michael J. Blum
description: Abigail Rose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu Rose of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Joel Blum, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Blum of Hopkins, Minn. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York. Jennifer Blum, a cantorial student and the sister of the bridegroom, took part in the ceremony.

title: Miss Shaughnessy And Mr. Dennis
description: Elizabeth Ann Shaughnessy, a vice president in the global services division at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Jay Dennis, a partner in McKinsey & Company, the management consultants, also in New York. The Rev. Peter Larson performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: Without the Novel, No Movie
description: To the Editor:

title: Amistad Revolt, A Footnote
description: Regarding the article ''Celebrating the Struggle for Justice'' (Sept. 22), about the Connecticut Freedom Trail and the Amistad case of 1839, when a group of Africans led by Joseph Cinque mutinied aboard a Spanish slaveship and eventually won their freedom: For the sake of historical completeness, it might be well to note that when Joseph Cinque returned to Africa, he became a slaver.

title: Paper Their World
description: ''Do you have a cigarette or other product-related illness or injury?'' reads the advertisement that Norwood Wilner has been splattering across Florida newspapers. The ads are working, too: hundreds of potential plaintiffs have called.

title: The Stately Puppets of Sicily
description: MY mother introduced me to the Opera dei Pupi during her first visit to Palermo in 1964. She had collected marionettes in her youth, and although she was lukewarm about my coming marriage to a Sicilian, she was very eager to see the famous Sicilian marionettes perform.

title: New Bosnia Government Shows Few Signs of Life
description: While the nationwide elections last month did not promise a new heaven and a new earth, they at least promised a new Bosnia where ethnic Croats, Serbs and Muslims, who spent four years at war, would have a chance to work together to build a common government.

title: A Silk Road Outpost Of Surprises
description: PEOPLE may climb mountains just because they're there, but most travelers prefer to believe their trips make sense -- neat, narrative guidebook sense. When I pitched up last year in Bukhara on the ancient Silk Road -- the most interesting city in the world, according to a 19th-century visitor -- I had done my reading, in the Cadogan Guide to Central Asia, and thought I knew what to expect. But the experience eluded me the way Wallace Stevens said a successful poem eludes interpretation.

title: Rallying to Stake Their Claim on a Better Future
description: Two rallies, two causes and thousands of individual reasons for joining in: here's a look at two New Jersey residents who decided to stand up and be counted. One traveled to Washington on Oct. 12 for a march to promote Hispanic issues; the other went to the United Nations on Wednesday for a rally observing the first anniversary of the Million Man March.

title: Mr. Gore Goes to Washington, Too
description: THE annual dinner named for the original ''happy warrior,'' Gov. Alfred E. Smith, is a traditional home for the jocular tension of a Presidential campaign. Any controversy is usually generated by the presence of rival candidates on the dais, not by their absence.

title: Tourism Might Just Destroy New York's Flavor
description: To the Editor:

title: Slumping Market Expecting Financial Lift
description: The Bob Marley lyrics ''Get up, stand up/Stand up for your rights'' boom out of one vendor's speakers near the entrance to the Malcolm Shabazz Harlem Market at 116th Street and Lenox Avenue, but the network of stalls is otherwise quiet midway through a mild fall Wednesday afternoon.

title: A Beloved Museum Tiptoes Into The Future
description: ''DEAD CHRIST WITH ANGELS,'' an eerie masterpiece by the Italian Mannerist painter Rosso Fiorentino, hung at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, centered on the marble wall of what was until two months ago the grand tapestry gallery on the second floor. About 30 Renaissance and Baroque masterpieces were already installed in tiers; others waited on trolleys.

title: Libel and the Ballot Box
description: Texas State Representative Sylvester Turner was locked in a close race for Mayor of Houston in 1991. Just days before the election, a local television station, KTRK, broadcast a report that said questions had arisen about whether Mr. Turner might have known details about a staged death and life-insurance swindle involving a law client of his. He wound up losing badly and sued the station.

title: What A Deal! But Somebody Pays.
description: LOOKING for a loan? How do these terms sound? No application forms to complete and no credit checks. Approval is automatic. You can borrow as much money as you want, up to 40 percent of your pay, for as long as you want, at no interest.

title: Jane Hotchkiss, Charles Gordy 2d
description: Jane Chandler Hotchkiss and Charles Burton Gordy 2d were married yesterday. The Rev. Ivan Weiser, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Faith in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: What's a Soccer Mom Anyway?
description: ONCE upon a time, like about three months ago, a soccer mom was just that.

title: A QUESTION FOR: Stephen King
description: Stephen King's 26th novel, ''Desperation,'' was recently published by Viking.

title: The Drama Critic Who Made the Pulse Race
description: IF YOU WERE AN AVID theatergoer in the 1950's and early 60's -- the last boom time for avid theatergoers on Broadway -- you couldn't escape Atkinson and Kerr, the men on the aisle for The Times and The Trib. If, like me, you were stage-struck and didn't live in New York, you simply couldn't live without them. They were the most reliable morning-after witnesses to the thrilling opening nights so tantalizingly out of reach.

title: THE NEXT HUNDRED YEARS
description: Bravo! ''The Next Hundred Years'' was a masterpiece.

title: Great Characters From Ferber's Pen
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Lyon, Author And Scriptwriter, 81
description: Peter Lyon, an author of books, radio scripts and magazine articles, died on Monday at a nursing home in Kingston, N.Y. He was 81.

title: BENEFITS
description: National Actors Theater

title: District's Discord Brings Deja Vu
description: In the two years since Dori Collazo-Baker became the Superintendent of Community School Board 1, math scores in her Lower East Side district have risen sharply. Last year, the scores were up by 11.8 percent, the second-highest jump in the city. Reading scores, while still low, are up slightly. And the district won a coveted $6.1 million grant from the Federal Government this month.

title: Victim of the 50's Blacklist Gets to Tell His Tale
description: DESPITE entreaties from friends and relatives and a standing offer from an editor at a publishing house, Walter Bernstein had resisted chronicling the eight years in the 1950's that he was on the blacklist of movie and television writers and performers.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE BOOK OF THE SPIDER

title: The Bull Keeps Charging Prices will fluctuate.
description: So went the legendary response from J. P. Morgan when he was asked to forecast the stock market. But Mr. Morgan did not live in the 1990's.

title: The Virtuoso of Herald Square
description: THE player stood on the street, tuning his violin. As he did, the short squeaks and groans of bow against strings were barely audible over the traffic roaring by Macy's last Sunday afternoon. Nervously, he paced in front of the Tommy Hilfiger display window, adjusted his tie, tapped his loafer on the sidewalk and muttered: ''Bach. Concerto in A minor.''

title: One View: Stocks Will Keep On Chugging
description: AS chief investment officer of Mellon Private Asset Management, H. Vernon Winters, 55, has $48 billion riding on his thoughts about where the market is headed. One of his convictions is that we have not seen the end of the bull market. But he also believes that future advances will be labored, that investors should look more to foreign stocks, that the market may soon shine on small companies and that, in the near future, active stock-picking may be more rewarding than just playing the indexes.

title: L.I. Girl Strangled, and a Teen-Age Neighbor Is Charged
description: A 17-year-old girl was strangled in a wooded area of Port Jefferson Station, L.I., early yesterday and a 16-year-old neighbor was charged in her murder, the police said.

title: Vintage Glimpses of a Lost Theatrical World
description: MAYBE IT'S THE FACT THAT the century is ending, but everyone I know is desperate for a performing-arts renaissance. New material, new techniques? Sure, I'll take them. But any renaissance worth its name has to be as much about approaching the past as assessing the present and anticipating the future. After all, the word does mean rebirth.

title: Deep in the Mums' Brief Season
description: No flower more typifies autumn than the chrysanthemum. As soon as the breeze carries the first hint of frost, the mums appear. Their helmets of bloom sprout from every pot and window box, repeating at ground level the vibrant colors of autumn leaves.

title: Blood Feuds
description: DEAD SEASON

title: Adult Communities Are Spreading Across the State
description: HAVING rebounded from its recessionary slump, the market for active adult communities in the state is edging forward, stoking developer interest in starting new projects.

title: Please, Murphy, Don't Abandon Us Just Yet
description: DEAR CANDICE BERGEN,

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: All Madden

title: THE FUTURE OF NOSTALGIA
description: Garrison Keillor's vilification of nostalgia as a life style sounds to me like Elvis booing rock-and-roll or Clinton and Dole saying not to vote for politicians (Hindsight: ''The Future of Nostalgia,'' Sept. 29).

title: BEST SELLERS: October 20, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 1 2 DESPERATION, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) Visitors to a small mining town in Nevada encounter terrifying forces. 2 2 2 THE REGULATORS, by Richard Bachman. (Dutton, $24.95.) Killings and other horrors disrupt a quiet suburban town in Ohio. 3 4 4 THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (Viking, $23.95.) The disappearance of a 3-year-old boy brings a family anguish and redemption. 4 3 8 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) Vice President Jack Ryan has problems after the deaths of the President and most of the Cabinet, Congress, the Joint Chiefs and the Supreme Court. 5 5 5 JACK AND JILL, by James Patterson. Ways to improve one's life physically and mentally. 2 3 31 THE ZONE, by Barry Sears with Bill Lawren. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $23.) Diets to prevent disease and enhance mental health. (+) 3* 2 178 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $25.) Improving communication and relationships. (+) 4 4 29 SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+)

title: Low Resale as a Good Deal
description: SOME of the best deals in the car market today may be found on used-car lots, in the form of big, powerful sedans that wear the circular Infiniti emblem.

title: On the Trail of JFK Jr. And His Bride
description: The World Series of celebrity photography began the moment news broke of John F. Kennedy Jr.'s marriage to Carolyn Bessette. A shot of the pair could bring anywhere form $1,000 to six figures, depending on how many rivals got the same picture. Here is the testimony of four players in the elbowing mix.

title: On CD, Orchestras Fall Victim to Their Glorious Pasts
description: THE STRIKING MUSICIANS OF the Philadelphia Orchestra are aggrieved that they have lost their recording contract with EMI Classics. Citing the orchestra's incontestably great recording tradition, that bountiful library begun and cultivated in the epochs of Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy, the suddenly disenfranchised Philadelphians are asking, in essence, ''Is nothing sacred?''

title: Mary M. Langan, Steven R. O'Neil
description: Mary Margaret Langan, a daughter of Marian and Bernard Langan of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Rex O'Neil, a son of Maryann and Ronald O'Neil of Clinton, N.Y. Msgr. John O'Connor performed the ceremony at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.

title: Alison Eidelhoch and Michael Getz
description: Alison Marc Eidelhoch, a daughter of Cecily Eidelhoch and Dr. Lester Eidelhoch of New Hartford, N.Y., is to be married today to Michael Irving Getz, the son of Suecarol and Stuart Getz of Massapequa, L.I. Rabbi Jason van Leeuwen is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Utica, N.Y.

title: Delta Jet Skids Off La Guardia Runway
description: A jetliner carrying 58 people skidded off a runway into a muddy patch of grass after its main landing gear collapsed as the plane arrived at La Guardia Airport from Atlanta yesterday afternoon. All the passengers were evacuated and there were no serious injuries, officials said.

title: Lisa Barnhouse, Steven S. Gal
description: Lisa Andrea Barnhouse, the daughter of Irene Barnhouse of San Diego and the late Andrew Barnhouse, is to be married today to Steven Samuel Gal, a son of Irma and Robert Gal of New York. Rabbi Allen Maller is to perform the ceremony at Greystone Manor, a historic house in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: One Roast at a Time
description: THE SUPPORT GROUP OF RECOVERING HOSTESSES had been meeting for nearly six months before it realized that Elizabeth was lonely for precisely the same reasons she was admired. Her cool pragmatism served her well in the workaday world, particularly when she brought that brisk, bottom-line efficiency to the dinner parties she gave. It made perfect sense to think that Elizabeth had and did it all.

title: Research Subjects, Yes, But Not Guinea Pigs
description: To the Editor:

title: Devoured by Otherness
description: ANNAMBy Christophe Bataille.Translated by Richard Howard.87 pp. New York:New Directions. $15.95.

title: Indonesian Family And Its Rich Empire
description: The Riady family of Indonesia suddenly finds itself at the center of a political uproar in America, with Republicans alleging that its contributions to the Democratic Party have influenced President Clinton's policies toward Indonesia.

title: Jessica Inselbuch And Jan Malasek
description: Jessica Inselbuch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu Inselbuch of New York, was married last evening to Jan Malasek, a son of Jan and Libuse Malasek of Kremze, Czech Republic. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Racquet and Tennis Club in New York.

title: Thomas Willard, 89, Cinematographer
description: Thomas W. Willard, a cinematographer who was among the first to put 16-millimeter film to commercial use, died on Oct. 13 at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Puerto Rico Is Exporting Many Drug-Case Witnesses to Florida
description: Puerto Rico, after struggling with unprecedented waves of drug-related violence as it became a Caribbean drug-smuggling hub in recent years, faced a problem: It had no more room to hide witnesses who testified against drug dealers. But its solution -- shipping many of them to Florida -- has created tension in the state, which is grappling with a drug problem of its own.

title: Brodeur's Night Off Is a Flop
description: Six games into the season Martin Brodeur was permitted to take a night off, something Coach Jacques Lemaire had promised would happen more often this season. But those nights could be long ones for the Devils.

title: How an Internet Wannabe Became an I-Really-Don't-Wannabe
description: I AM definitely not a computer genius. I have trouble setting the clock on my VCR. But since acquiring a computer years back after abandoning my old electric typewriter, I felt I had grown pretty proficient using the thing, though it was mostly for word processing -- meeting deadlines, turning out letters, articles and the like.

title: A Big Toe Causes A Lineup Problem
description: Lemke, the Yankee Fan

title: Days Off and Dampness: Keeping an Emotional Edge
description: The Yankees' week of rest and recuperation was considered medicinal by the walking wounded who needed time to heal between the league championship battle and the World Series.

title: Britain Mulls Handgun Ban
description: Responding to widespread public pressure after the massacre of 16 small schoolchildren and their teacher last March in Dunblane, Scotland, the British Government proposed last week to ban the possession and use of almost all handguns. The exception would be .22 caliber pistols, which would be stored under tight security in accredited gun clubs. Britain's gun laws are already among the strictest in the world. But the parents of the children who were killed by a man who legally obtained four handguns said the Government's proposals did not go far enough, and demanded a ban on all handguns. SARAH LYALL

title: INSIDE
description: Run-Up to Vote in Japan

title: Henry G. Walker Photographer, 75
description: Henry G. (Hank) Walker, a former staff photographer for Life magazine, died on Oct. 13 in Miami. He was 75. The cause was heart failure, according to a statement from Life.

title: Dartmouth Pummels Yale Into The Books
description: Dartmouth 40, Yale 6

title: Are We Master of Our Microbes, or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Poppy vs. Sesame

title: An Eye for African Art
description: ROBERT J. KOENIG had given up being a museum director and was enjoying the relative calm of teaching in a university. So he wasn't looking for a job when he accompanied an art dealer friend who was delivering a sculpture he was lending to an exhibition at the African Art Museum of the Society of African Missions here. Mr. Koenig was impressed by what he saw, but when he learned that the museum was overseen only by a volunteer curator, he realized it needed a full-time director.

title: Revamped Knicks Assessing Strengths
description: BY the time the New York Knicks end their regular season with a game against the National Basketball Association champion Chicago Bulls on April 19, a lot will be known about this team, of which very little is now known.

title: Slovakia's Minorities
description: To the Editor:

title: End Games End in a Huff
description: The 700,000 Russian Jews who settled in Israel in recent years deluged their new homeland with music, math and medicine -- and chess, as Garry Kasparov learned to his dismay last week. In a simultaneous match against 25 Israelis, Mr. Kasparov, widely seen as the world's best player, was besieged by former countrymen, including an all Russian youth team that won the European championship and Natan Sharansky, the former dissident who now sits in the Israeli Cabinet.

title: Gaye Sussman, Jonathan Markson
description: Gaye Sussman, an advertising executive, is to be married today to Jonathan Markson, a packager of book deals. Rabbi Joel S. Goor is to perform the ceremony at the Carlyle in New York.

title: The Title Will Be Decided In the Battles of Midfield
description: The vast majority of soccer games are won or lost in midfield, and the Major League Soccer championship game on Sunday will be no different.

title: How to Fill a Big Screen
description: Though it is hard to think of a more intimate film than ''Brief Encounter'' (1945), David Lean's first hit, he will be remembered nonetheless as a director of epics: ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' (1957), ''Lawrence of Arabia'' (1962), ''Dr. Zhivago'' (1965), ''Ryan's Daughter'' (1970) and ''A Passage to India'' (1984). Kevin Brownlow, the film historian and author of ''The Parade's Gone By,'' a classic study of the silent cinema, shares with Lean a fondness for large enterprises, fastidiousness and a certain old-fashioned reticence about intruding his point of view. The two men are well matched in Mr. Brownlow's gratifyingly comprehensive DAVID LEAN: A Biography (Wyatt/St. Martin's, $40), which is told mostly in the words of Lean, his colleagues and his former wives. David Lean (1908-91), who was born in the London suburb of South Croydon, is introduced as a forlorn middle-class Quaker child, ''dim'' at schoolwork, who, at the age of 13, saw his first movie, ''The Hound of the Baskervilles,'' and was hooked. He began his career as a film editor, and, as Mr. Brownlow observes, since he was an obsessive craftsman he soon became the best film editor in England. Although Mr. Brownlow gives due consideration to Lean's fine Dickens adaptations -- ''Great Expectations'' (1946) and ''Oliver Twist'' (1948) -- the most fascinating chapters focus on the epics, which often were excruciating ordeals, particularly for the actors, since Lean refused to give praise. His volatile collaborations with the screenwriter Robert Bolt and the cinematographer Freddie Young are discussed, as well as Lean's meticulous preparations for every shot. Although presented as a problematic person, Lean becomes more sympathetic as he ages in the course of this very long but compelling book, which should revive interest in a major director's career. Diane Jacobs

title: Iowa Runs, Slips and Slides Past Struggling Penn State
description: The spectators' ponchos, not the leaves, were in peak color today as a cold, driving rain left Penn State and Iowa groping on an afternoon more suited to duck hunting than football. In the end, a trick play, voracious defense and an Iowa race horse prevailed over Penn State's determined plow horse.

title: Defining a Woman's Place in the World as the Very Center of Life
description: IT DOES not take a count to see that a startling majority of artists exhibiting in New Jersey are women: group shows provide evidence enough of the imbalance, and it is grounds for concern. Should men be restored to the scene as wolves have been to the wild -- forcibly?

title: Even Capote Might Have Approved This Version
description: IN A BITING REVIEW, Truman Capote once declared, ''The transposition of one art form into another seems to me a corrupt, somewhat vulgar enterprise.''

title: Hunting Cash, Candidates Follow the Bright Lights
description: CIVICS books say that politicians are in a race for votes. But reality paints a different picture: Campaigning is often more a race for dollars and, by that measure, as in the race for votes, some places are more attractive than others.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Prohibition

title: De Niro Up for 'Empowerment'
description: The 10 groups conditionally selected for first-round financing are diverse indeed, from community-based health-care trainers in East Harlem to the developers of Harlem USA. The recipients represent an effort to balance all the competing visions for where the money should go. But why are Robert De Niro and Drew Nieporent, partners in several wildly successful downtown restaurant ventures, among those who could receive empowerment zone money?

title: Elizabeth Maguire, Malcolm W. Mead
description: Elizabeth Anne Maguire, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Maguire of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Malcolm Winslow Mead, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mead of Etna, N.H. Msgr. William R. Devine performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Peter B. Stube, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: The Journey After the Onset of Leukemia
description: TWENTY months ago, in the middle of her junior year at Daniel Hand High School in Madison, Angela Hubley of Madison was told she had leukemia and that she needed a bone marrow transplant.

title: The Earthy Flavor of Wild Mushrooms
description: WILD mushrooms are now at their peak season. Tennyson once described them as ''carrion of some woodland thing,'' but I wonder if the poet ever tasted porcini (Boletus edulus, also known as cepes), which have an unforgettable earthy flavor, pure heaven when grilled with lemon and olive oil or sauteed in butter with a little garlic. They also make a wonderful risotto, especially when flavored with white truffle oil (and, if expense is no object, topped with a few shavings of fresh white truffle). Surely Tennyson would not have scorned chanterelles, those orange, feathery trumpets, which are so good tossed with pasta and cream. Wild mushrooms of all kinds, sauteed with potatoes, make a superb fall side dish to go with roasted chicken, beef or fish.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Champagne and Martinis At a Chelsea Cabaret Lounge

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: The Secret Attack on Have-Nots
description: As Congress directly assaulted welfare programs, it also indirectly launched a piecemeal attack on the intricate set of subsidies built into health, retirement and education programs through which Americans who are financially well off take some responsibility for helping their less fortunate neighbors. In each of these spheres, Americans have typically operated in common pools, with some players paying more so that other, poorer players can pay less.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SUNSET PARK

title: Wilderness Vs. Houses In the Idaho Mountains
description: iero Piva, a second-generation Stanley rancher, points to the snow-dusted peaks on the northern flank of the Sawtooth Mountains and declares: ''By God, this is the most beautiful scene in the world. This is it right here.''

title: A Big Toe Causes A Lineup Problem
description: 'The Sun Is Coming Out'

title: THE FUTURE OF NOSTALGIA
description: Has anyone else noticed that the only people nostalgic for the 1950's are white men of a certain age? Things were better then, everybody was happy and life was simple. I heard this first from my father, then from Bob Dole and now from Garrison Keillor. As a 33-year-old woman, I doubt that I would have been as happy to have lived at a time when women, after having been told that they were capable of many occupations during World War II, were informed that their place was once again in the home, in the kitchen, in fashions that restricted free movement. And even though I am white, I feel certain that few people of color pine for that time either.

title: Holders of Savings Bonds Get That Sinking Feeling
description: FRAN REYNOLDS is not happy with the United States savings bonds that she bought in the mid-1980's. A few weeks ago, the bonds' 7.5 percent minimum interest rate became a thing of the past. And while there is a new floor, it is a lot lower: 4 percent.

title: BIG BROTHER IS US
description: What did Walt Kelly's Pogo say? ''We have met the enemy and he is us.''

title: Getting To Bradley
description: This in response to the Letter to the Editor ''Public Transportation to Bradley Airpot'' (Oct. 13) regarding our efforts to market Bradley International Airport to residents of Fairfild and New Haven counties.

title: Honoring Women as Keepers of the Home
description: ''CLOSE TO HOME,'' the current exhibition at the Lehman College Art Gallery, has several facets. It is a show about domesticity and also about the use of familiar, humble materials to create what is sometimes genuine beauty. It also reveals the emergence of a feminist attitude that celebrates women's traditional role as keepers of the home.

title: Reclining Woes
description: To the Editor: Why don't the airlines eliminate the tilting back of coach seats, particularly on short domestic flights? The seats are very close together, and when the person in front of you leans his seat way back, he is really taking up your space.

title: New Land Deal to Help Protect Montana River
description: A three-way land deal among the Federal Government, a timber company and an environmental group has protected a 10-mile scenic corridor along one of Montana's most celebrated rivers.

title: Yeltsin Picks an Unassuming, Loyal Legislator to Succeed Lebed
description: Rushing to fill a vacuum in a key Kremlin post but scale back its power, President Boris N. Yeltsin today appointed a mild-mannered, moderate politician, Ivan Rybkin, as secretary of the National Security Council to replace the ousted Aleksandr I. Lebed.

title: Towns Halting Spread of Ferry Service
description: ALTHOUGH Long Island ferry companies, mostly family owned and with roots from the 19th century, are experiencing increased ridership, plans for additional operations are encountering community opposition.

title: Ready to Go In Vietnam: Alas, There's No Market
description: INVESTING in Vietnam is so hard that even J. Mark Mobius is struggling.

title: Two New Mexico Spas
description: YEARS AGO I lived in northern New Mexico. I can't remember why I left, but I know why I return as often as possible; for the exhilarating altitude, the pueblo dances, the smell of pinon fires, the architecture, the green chili and, not least among the pleasures there, for visits to two popular spas. Both Ojo Caliente, an ancient hot spring an hour's drive north of Santa Fe, and Ten Thousand Waves, just three miles from the Plaza, are a part of their neighboring communities, and familiar spa experiences are enhanced here by a significant sense of place.

title: Has Country Music Become A Soundtrack for White Flight?
description: IN THE RECENT acclaimed TBS documentary, ''America's Music: The Roots of Country,'' legend after legend in Nashville's pantheon stared into the camera and proclaimed a debt to traditional black music.

title: Driving Rain and Howling Wind Cannot Stop 5-0 Columbia
description: Columbia's undefeated team found a way to win yesterday under horrendous conditions of wind and rain at Baker Field.

title: Surf's Up (No Sunscreen Needed)
description: YOU see those two blokes who just walked in?'' said Olli Vigors, an owner of Vingt Quatre, London's only 24-hour cafe. ''One's an earl, and the other is a doorman.''

title: Video Guides: A Road Test
description: TRAVEL videos have always seemed to be a genre in search of an audience, never sure whether to focus on armchair travelers, vacationers seeking ''been there, did that'' mementos or cautious planners who want to avoid surprises on their next vacation. Produced either as educational films or by promoters touting specific destinations, the potential of travel videos is their ability to present a more thorough introduction to an area than any guidebook can provide, offering snippets of vicarious reality that can be used as test runs.

title: Accord on Water Supply Is Criticized for Weakness
description: Several environmental groups say they will oppose a hard-won agreement to protect New York City's upstate water supply, arguing that the pact does not do enough to prevent a decline in water quality and that it will postpone by only a few years the need to build a multibillion-dollar filtration system.

title: Spanish Revenge
description: Operas don't often cause as much advance buzz as tropical storms, but ''Florencia en el Amazonas'' -- a new work by Daniel Catan, premiering Friday at the Houston Grand Opera -- is coming close in the Spanish-language press. ''Premiere Mundial!'' blares a recent headline in Semana, a Texas weekly. ''Realismo Magica en Houston.''

title: For 2 Denominations, One Cleric Fills a Need
description: In this farm town of fewer than 2,000 souls, surrounded by lush cornfields and fat cattle, the tiny congregation of Peace Evangelical Lutheran Church prayed for years for a regular pastor who would help bury the dead, baptize the newly born and be around often enough to learn everyone's name.

title: Testimony From the Weary On the Welfare Treadmill
description: THEY are the poor, the jobless, sometimes the lazy, often the diligent. Welfare has kept many of them alive and their families intact.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: The World Wide Web can help travelers prepare for a trip, just as a travel article or book can help them decide on what to see during five days in Tokyo, or three in Rome, or a weekend in Cleveland. Among the more useful tools are the sites being set up by arts institutions.

title: On Students Acquiring Reading Skills
description: In ''Will All Pupils on L.I. Read by the Third Grade,'' $(Sept. 29$), the author noted several Nassau and Suffolk County districts which in May of 1995 less than 85 percent of third-grade students passed the State Reading Test (also known as the PEP Test).

title: Suntans and Dates Don't Justify College Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes Due at Worldwide Plaza
description: An experiment in West Side development is to begin a new chapter in a few weeks when the Blackstone Group, an investment banking firm, is expected to take control of Worldwide Plaza from its mortgage holder, Deutsche Bank, and other investors, according to real estate executives. Blackstone declined comment.

title: TOMORROW NEVER KNOWS
description: Apropos of Victor Navasky's Endpaper ''Tomorrow Never Knows'' (Sept. 29): On the eve of the Wright brothers' historic first flights in 1903, Simon Newcomb, an eminent United States scientist, predicted that the first successful flying machine would be the handiwork of a watchmaker and would carry nothing heavier than an insect. Later he increased the payload: ''It may carry two or three buttons, but will not carry more than four.'' And so it goes.

title: Abortion Is an Issue In Groups' Support
description: WESTCHESTER'S delegations to the State Legislature and to Congress are overwhelmingly in favor of choice on abortion, as are most of their major-party opponents in this year's election.

title: Mental Health Ventures May Gain From New Law
description: THE optimism is guarded, but investors in companies specializing in mental health care hope that a new Federal law will bolster the stocks of their somewhat out-of-favor industry.

title: In G.O.P. Country, Shrugs and Yawns
description: The lunchtime crowd had just relieved Lowery's Seafood Restaurant of several hundred fried oysters -- served with salad, two vegetables and tartar or cocktail sauce on the side -- when William Lowery 4th emerged from the kitchen and, despite the distraction of the nearby cash register, tried to focus on the Presidential election.

title: Downsized Workers Recovered No Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: Restored, Naturally
description: HAVING discovered hot springs only late in life, I have a predilection for them. They relax; they soothe; they restore a sense of primal well-being.

title: When Jeeves and Bertie Break Into Song
description: IN THE RESTAURANT WHERE WE meet, the ubiquitous New York air conditioning is sweeping across the plains of our corner table. I take out a sweater from my briefcase; my English companion unfortunately is not so well prepared for the rigors of man-made weather, which should surprise no American who has spent a hot summer's evening in London searching for any place ''Air Conditioned,'' then settling for ''Air Cooled,'' only to discover that this is but a euphemism for ''Air,'' not necessarily even ''Moving Air.''

title: In the Beginning There Was a Bible Discussion Group. And Then PBS Came Calling.
description: Rabbi Burton L. Visotzky has no patience for piety. That's clear from his passionate outburst on a new PBS program, ''Genesis: A Living Conversation.'' Led by Bill Moyers, Visotzky and six other religious experts are batting Noah back and forth. Samuel Proctor, a former college president and pastor emeritus of Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church, doesn't think God should be condemned for the flood; the story, he feels, does not define God's nature but is merely ''one writer's understanding.'' Visotzky, who has been holding back, finally interrupts. ''Sam,'' he cries, ''why are you so protective of God?''

title: On the Silver Screen, Silence Can Be Golden
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Layovers Can Be Delicious
description: HUNGRY travelers pausing at the world's busiest airport once had few options beyond terminally overpriced fast food. But -- fold up your flight trays -- dining in the vicinity of O'Hare International Airport has improved dramatically. Anyone spending a few hours between connections or overnight at one of the many nearby hotels can be seated in a fine restaurant in 10 to 20 minutes.

title: Remembrance of Corn Pone Past
description: Lots of people dismiss small-town Southern festivals as hokum, but according to ''Ghost Dancing on the Cracker Circuit,'' a forthcoming book from the University Press of Mississippi, these events also constitute serious ''nativistic revitalization movements.'' The book's title is a nod to the poignant ''ghost dance'' phenomenon that gripped 19th-century American Indians, who danced to bring back the buffalo. In the modern analogue, vanished cultural symbols are similarly ritualized, usually by white Southern Smallvillians who hope, in part, to keep their towns alive by ''selling'' extinct traditions. Of course, neither hosts nor fans intellectualize matters this much -- they just like pigs and hillbillies -- but for you brainy folkways buffs, here are highlights from the 1996-97 season.

title: Even the Spirit Is Scaled Down
description: SHORTLY after my early test drive of the redesigned 1997 Infiniti Q45, a new advertising campaign began for the model, the flagship of Nissan's luxury-car division. ''Everything changes but the soul,'' the tagline proclaimed.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION AND POETRY
description: ORIGINAL COLOR

title: The Voters Sober Up
description: Sometimes the best way to understand a Presidential campaign is to imagine how it might feel to have taken a nap in the middle of it.

title: East Islip Becomes Focus of a Battle On Teacher Tenure
description: CONCERNED about jobs, 22 new teachers in the East Islip School District are refusing to discuss publicly the contracts they signed in August that waived their tenure rights.

title: Environmental Bill: The Pros and Cons
description: THERE are those who extol it, those who support it with reservations and others who downright oppose it. But the bottom line is that voters will decide the merits of Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed $1.75 billion Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act when they go to the polls on Nov. 5.

title: Derek Jeter Takes a Swing, and a Collectible Is Born
description: THE numbers are eye-popping. A $12 baseball that left the pitcher's hand on Sept. 6 was worth $500,000 after it landed in the right-center-field stands, smacked there by Eddie Murray of the Baltimore Orioles for his 500th career home run. A 1910 Honus Wagner baseball card, originally given away by a tobacco company, was auctioned last month for $640,500.

description: WILL AMERICA GROW UP BEFORE IT GROWS OLD?

description: THE TAILOR OF PANAMA
