description: To the Editor:

title: So Young, So Fragile, So Vexed About Sex
description: HERE'S THE PITCH: A YOUNG woman and her twin brother are separated during a shipwreck. Thinking the brother is dead, she goes AWOL dressed as a man and winds up on the estate of a pretty young countess, who goes gaga for the girl in disguise. Who, in turn, falls for the hunky royal in the big house next door.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES DRUG-TESTING PLAN FOR YOUNG PEOPLE
description: President Clinton said today that teen-agers should be required to pass a drug test before receiving driver's licenses, and he instructed Administration officials to report to him in 90 days with a plan, including possible legislation, to make such a practice standard around the country.

title: Caste May Be India's Moral Achilles' Heel
description: THE UNITED NATIONS has tackled apartheid, established tribunals to try war criminals in Bosnia and Rwanda, set up truth commissions in Central America and, most recently, warned Islamic zealots in Afghanistan not to suppress the rights of women. But is it ready to take on caste?

title: Tickets, Please
description: To the Editor: Prior to our departure from the United States for a recent trip to Europe my husband purchased European East passes -- the Eastern European version of the Rail Europe pass, valid on national railroads of Austria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia. The conditions, printed on the back, state that these passes must be validated with an official stamp at a ticket window prior to boarding the first train; the conditions specifically mention that a train conductor may not validate a pass.

title: And It's 3, 4 or More Hours Out at the Old Ball Game
description: IN baseball, time trudges on. And on. Games are marathons. No, more than marathons. At least marathons are won in two and a half hours. But ball games go beyond, to three, four hours and more, often just for nine innings. They are epics -- epics within mini-series! -- especially in the American League.

title: Karen Bergman, John Thyfault
description: Karen Lee Bergman, a daughter of Joanne Bergman of Nyack, N.Y., and the late Jules Bergman, was married last evening to John Edmond Thyfault, a son of Maureen and Harold Thyfault of Littleton, Colo. Rabbi Shira Lander officiated at the Yale Club in New York. The Rev. Michael Tueth, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Fordham Surges, But Still Falls Short

title: Scottish Treats
description: To the Editor: We have just returned from a wonderful trip to Scotland. Every place we stayed, whether it was a modest motel in the remote Highlands or a hotel on Prince Street in Edinburgh, had in each room a tray with an electric pot to heat water, tea bags, instant coffee, sugar, milk and packets of biscuits or cookies. A cup of tea and a biscuit late in the afternoon and a wake-up cup of coffee in the morning were amenities that added to the pleasure of the trip.

title: French Fries as Hand Food? Perish the Thought!
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION AND POETRY

title: RACE IS OVER
description: When are you going to get it into your head that when you use the term Jewish or Jew it refers to a religion and not to a race? Why isn't Liza Garcia a Colombian/Scottish/Irish Catholic or Saira Asim a Pakistani/African-American Muslim?

title: Wallace and Knicks Wipe the Slate Clean
description: Perceptions in the National Basketball Association being what they are, John Wallace came to the Knicks labeled as the prototypical rookie of the 90's: quintessential talent, questionable attitude. It was not what he could do for New York that mattered. It was what New York could do for him.

title: A Designer With a Vision of 'Earnest'
description: ONE OF THE MOST ANTICIPATED theater events this season is a century-old comedy playing Off Broadway in a 140-seat house. Oscar Wilde's effervescent social satire, ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' opens on Thursday at the Irish Repertory Theater on West 22d Street.

title: Teen-Ager in Hiding: How Yanks Kept Williams Under Wraps
description: Manny Batista, a scout for the Texas Rangers, knew the highly regarded 16-year-old outfielder was absent from the sandlots of Puerto Rico that summer, but he didn't know what had happened to him. Doug Melvin, now Batista's boss as the Rangers' general manager, disclosed just last week, 11 years later, the whereabouts that summer of Bernie Williams.

title: Irving Granet, Engineer, 72
description: Irving Granet, a mechanical and nuclear engineer who wrote 19 textbooks, died on Oct. 9 in North Shore Hospital on Long Island. He was 72 and lived in North Bellmore, L.I.

title: The Script Is Still Being Written
description: IF Bill Clinton is re-elected in 16 days, he will face a new reality for a politician whose career has always been directed toward the next campaign: At age 50, he will be a lame duck.

title: THE FLIGHT
description: I enjoyed your issue, but I was dumbfounded by your futuristic vacation, ''The Flight'' (Sept. 29), which recommends a trip to Lhasa, Tibet, to ''meditate among the lamas.'' Given China's present policies in Tibet of brutal repression of Buddhism, including systematic shootings, arrests and imprisonment of monks and nuns, and the current proscription of the Dalai Lama's image in monasteries, temples and private homes, it is unlikely that there will be lamas with whom to meditate in 2096.

title: Corrections

And a brief review in the Book Review last Sunday about a new collection of Capa photographs for which the same author wrote the text misstated his first name. He is Richard Whelan.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about black walnuts included an erroneous reference to a nutcracker manufacturer. Although a directory assistance operator could find no reference to it, the company, Potter Walnut Crackers of Sapulpa, Okla., is listed and remains in business. Its number is (918) 224-0567.

description: For frazzled residents of the East Side, there is one shared and intractable fact of life: the mighty Queensboro Bridge, while perhaps necessary for life and liberty, can make the pursuit of urban happiness all but impossible.

title: Thai Barge Procession on Reign's 50th Year
description: There are few things as grand, or as rare to see, as a ceremonial royal Thai barge, a long golden ribbon with its dragon figurehead, its ornate, canopied throne and its rows of red-clad oarsmen.

description: This flashy new community on the edge of the capital city of Jakarta, with its malls, golf courses and roller coaster, is a monument to the rags-to-riches story of one of Asia's most successful family conglomerates, the $12 billion banking, real estate and insurance empire controlled by Mochtar Riady and his sons.

title: Cancer Breakthroughs With One Gene
description: It's been a long time since something so tiny has been as much in the spotlight as the human gene known as p53 was last week. The gene was at the center of two separate cancer investigations.

description: Plunging into a round of late-season politicking in usually Republican strongholds, Bob Dole today warned against rising foreign influence on the Democratic Party, as he again defended himself against President Clinton's assaults on his tax plan.

description: Raymond O. Prada, an acting co-director and chief psychologist of Adult Psychology Services at Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan, died on Oct. 10 at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 60 and lived on the Lower East Side.

description: Phoebe Emily Dominique Louis-Dreyfus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Louis-Dreyfus of New York, and Peter John Eavis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian W. Eavis of Farnham, England, were married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Turrigiano, a minister of the Vineyard Christian Fellowship of Manhattan, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

description: DESPERATIONBy Stephen King.690 pp. New York: Viking. $27.95.

title: Kathleen Belden, Merritt Schoff
description: Kathleen Kernan Belden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Devereaux Belden of Tucson, Ariz., was married yesterday to Peter Merritt Schoff Jr., the son of Abigail Adams Schoff of Greenwich, Conn., and Mr. Schoff of London. The Rev. Charles T. Dougherty performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Shelter Island Heights, N.Y.

title: The News From Amherst
description: Judith Farr's first novel, I NEVER CAME TO YOU IN WHITE (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $21.95), is a daring attempt to flesh out the characters and events in the world of that eccentric genius of Amherst Emily Dickinson. And Ms. Farr pulls it off in style. The author of a scholarly study, ''The Passion of Emily Dickinson,'' Ms. Farr concentrates here on the teen-age Dickinson's brief tenure as a student at Mary Lyon's Female Seminary (which later became Mount Holyoke College) in 1847, a time that is reconstructed in a flurry of fictional correspondence. Ms. Farr handles speculation about Dickinson's sexuality with panache, positing lesbian tendencies but tempering them with other possibilities and -- best of all -- playing down Dickinson's sexual preference as a poetic influence. Spliced in among various letters from midcentury are others written much later by Margaret Mann, a petty schoolmarm who contacts Dickinson's publisher and friend, Thomas Wentworth Higginson, trying to sort out her own muddled memories through a poorly concealed mist of envy. For his part, Higginson counters with evidence of Dickinson's faith and anecdotes about her later days. Dickinson's sister, Lavinia, provides another perspective, and there's even a humorous turn from Dickinson's put-upon cousin Emily Norcross, who suffers as the poet's roommate. Dickinson herself is credited with some letters, perhaps Ms. Farr's most ambitious moments. ''I Never Came to You in White'' is obviously more fanciful than a conventional biography, but the novel's inventions make satisfying reading, providing artful insights into an elusive life. Erik Burns

title: The Basics of Laying Ceramic Tile
description: CERAMIC tile can be used on walls, floors and countertops. Ceramic tile, however, is not flexible, and it should be bonded to a firm base (also called the substrate) that will not bend or flex. In areas where water is a problem, like the bathroom, the base must also be waterproof.

title: Jazz, Bach, A Choral Premiere
description: IT is another busy Sunday, with everything from baroque opera to traditional jazz. At 2 this afternoon, one can choose between a free faculty recital at Yale with the cellist Pansy Chang and the pianist Sara Laimon playing Bach, Beethoven, Chopin and Shostakovich at Sprague Memorial Hall, or the Preservation Hall Jazz Band at the Shubert Theater in New Haven.

title: Pictures From an Institution
description: THE HANDMAID OF DESIRE

title: Northeaster Hits Region With Record Rains and High Winds
description: A powerful northeaster whipped through the New York region yesterday, bringing record rains and high winds that caused thousands of power failures, delayed flights throughout the area and shut down major roadways and subway lines with some of the worst street flooding in four years.

title: Reversal of Fortune
description: CHANCELLORSVILLEBy Stephen W. Sears.Illustrated. 593 pp. Boston:Houghton Mifflin Company. $35.

title: 2 in G.O.P. Seek Assembly Upsets
description: A POSSIBLE strong showing by President Clinton in the county and the power of incumbency makes an upset in this year's Assembly races seem more remote, but two Republican challengers are waging active, well-financed campaigns against the odds.

title: Coupling Rail Companies
description: Ever since Congress cobbled together Conrail in the 1970's out of the ruins of a number of bankrupt Eastern railroads, bigger railroads in other parts of the country have longed to add its near monopoly on freight service in the Northeast to their own networks. Persistent wooing -- and a rich bid of more than $8 billion in cash and stock -- finally persuaded Conrail last week to agree to be taken over by the CSX Corporation. The two expect Government approval by the end of 1997, but not before tough negotiations over how much access other railroads must be given to CSX and Conrail customers to preserve competition. BARNABY J. FEDER

description: The blond-haired woman cracking Borscht Belt jokes and dragging a custom-made pushcart is just a bit over 5 feet tall when she's wearing a hat in the shape of a coffee cup.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: One thinks of the printed word lined up in rows and columns as regular as prison bars. Occasionally, poets have come along to liberate type from the jailhouse of geometry. So have advertising artists and, more recently, computer junkies.

title: Racism (Cont.)
description: To the Editor: Daniella Olibrice (Letters, Sept. 22) does Indonesians an injustice by calling them racist. To be sure, there are racists in Indonesia (how could you ever think that racism was confined to the West?), but in the highly conformist Indonesian culture, anyone who stands out attracts attention. Unlike Americans, Indonesians also have few hang-ups about commenting on one's appearance: fat people are told they are fat, beautiful people they are beautiful, ugly people they are ugly, and people with long noses (like myself and many other Westerners) that they look like cockatoos.

description: Elizabeth Tibbals and Sean Christopher Davy were married yesterday at St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Sea Girt, N.J., by Msgr. Samuel C. Constance.

description: THIS normally placid, self-satisfied town is being torn apart by its perennial civil war.

title: Placid Diversity Convenient to Manhattan
description: FOR days after last month's spectacular explosion, people came to gape at the charred remains of the Hyo Shin Bible Presbyterian Church, still topped by a cross. No wonder. Such excitement is rare in Auburndale.

title: Dirty Looks
description: ON THE T.G.V. FROM AVIGNON TO PARIS, MY husband and I landed in the only remaining seats on the high-speed train, in the middle of the car directly opposite a Frenchwoman of middle years. It was an extremely uncomfortable arrangement to be looking straight into the eyes of a stranger. My husband and I pulled out books. The woman produced a large makeup case and proceeded to freshen up. Except for a lunch break, she continued this activity for the entire three-hour trip. Every once in a while she came up for air and surveyed the car with a bright-eyed glance, but never once did she catch my (admittedly fascinated) eye. My husband and I could have been a blank wall.

title: Hard to Hate the Yankees? These Fans Do Their Best
description: In this season of baseball bliss in New York City, little has been said of a particular brand of New Yorker: a minority, but a well-established one that is suffering mightily at the moment as the Yankees try to dethrone the Atlanta Braves as baseball's world champions.

title: Change the Term Limits Law
description: On Election Day, New York City voters will be faced with a proposal to change the local term limits law by extending the maximum time an elected city official can hold one job from 8 years to 12. On its merits, the proposal is a good one. Unfortunately, its backers have been inept and evasive in pressing their cause. Their behavior has made an otherwise easy decision difficult and somewhat distasteful.

title: Malaysia:Caning for Illegals' Bosses
description: SINGAPORE  Malaysia will soon amend its laws to include caning and imprisonment for anyone employing illegal immigrants or helping to arrange their entry into the country.

title: A Primal Phantasmagoria Not Just for Gamblers
description: Mohegan Sun, the spectacular, Indian-theme gambling casino that opened on Oct. 12 in this small town in southeastern Connecticut, is a dense, exhilarating forest of symbols. Trees right beside slot machines. Immense paintings of flowers over card tables. Cryptic Indian signs interspersed with flashing neon numbers. Images derived from nature -- fish, corn, beans -- are set within a context of heightened artificiality created by stage lights, video screens and the merry abstraction that money becomes here. In the casino's food court, towering foam-rubber pine trees have real pine cones attached to them.

title: Rewriting History Is a Tricky Business
description: The Russian Nobel laureate Andrei Sakharov was known the world over as a dissident and brilliant nuclear physicist. But just what earned him the Nobel Peace Prize cannot be found in Russia's main reference source. The Big Soviet Encyclopedia discussed his civil-rights record with Communist delicacy: ''The Hero of Soviet Labor,'' it read, ''in recent years has left the scientific profession.''

Torricelli and then swept through fund-raising events in Tarrytown and Manhattan intended primarily to help House and Senate candidates.

title: Storm Floods Many Areas And Kills 4
description: The sun peeked out, floodwaters receded, transit and travel resumed and the World Series finally got under way yesterday as the metropolitan area's worst rainstorm in years churned off, leaving almost 52,000 homes still without power, widespread damage from water and wind-toppled trees, and four storm-related deaths.

title: Hearing the Void Gerry Mulligan Left
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center rustled around in the works of the saxophonist and composer Gerry Mulligan for a concert on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, and found everything but Mr. Mulligan himself. Mr. Mulligan, who died in January, was one of jazz's great and distinct soloists; as fine as some of the music at the show was, everyone tiptoed around his absence as a saxophonist. And the inability to deal with him as an improviser pointed out an intrinsic problem with the repertory movement in jazz. Orchestrations can be replayed; the original blend of a band can be suggested. But an improviser's sound and the essential twists and turns of the imagination can't be reproduced.

title: Figuring Out Phone Numbers
description: The Great Area Code Debate could be settled this week. On Wednesday, the state Board of Public Utilities is scheduled to consider -- and maybe vote on -- how New Jersey's next two area codes will be parceled out.

title: Wide Search for Clues In Shooting of Officer
description: Scores of police officers from around New York City poured into the Fordham section of the Bronx, scouring rooftops, knocking on doors and questioning some residents repeatedly in their search for a sniper who shot a uniformed police captain in the back on Saturday morning.

title: Meanwhile, Back in the Newsroom
description: Someday someone may write a play (well, maybe just a folk song) called ''The Epic of Ink.'' The new CBS series ''Ink'' has gone through more development contortions than an episode of ''The X-Files.''

title: For the first time in recent years, the magazine industry is basking in a sunny outlook.
description: IN recent years, the American Magazine Conference has taken place in sunny climates but been clouded by various dismal industry trends: poor advertising sales because of recession, skyrocketing postal rates and paper prices and doom-and-gloom predictions about the death of magazines at the hands of the Internet.

title: Immigrants Fighting Back, As Citizens
description: THIS will seem like a rude question, but do those candidates who are campaigning against immigrants know what they are doing? More to the point, are they looking ahead, past, say, Nov. 5?

title: Police Sniper Case Is City's 2d in '96
description: The shooting of Capt. Steven Plavnick in the Bronx was the second time this year that a New York City police officer had been wounded by a sniper. And in both cases, the gunman remains on the loose.

title: On Trial: Was Glass Half- or Full-Sized?
description: In the courtroom where Alex Kelly is on trial for rape, both the prosecution and the defense have focused on a teen-age drinking game called Quarters.

title: Bill Aims at Young Smokers
description: A measure to further curb juvenile smoking is scheduled to be introduced in the Assembly today. Under the proposal, any program that accepts state funds, including many after-school programs, juvenile homes and youth athletic leagues, would have to ban smoking for teen-agers 17 and under or lose state aid.

title: Wasserstein to Deliver First Lecture in a Series
description: Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright and author, will give the first in a series of four lectures to begin tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at St. Luke's School, 487 Hudson Street, Greenwich Village. Ms. Wasserstein, who won both a Pulitzer Prize and a Tony Award in 1989 for her play ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' will be introduced by another Pulitzer Prize winner, Anna Quindlen, an author and former columnist for The New York Times, who won a 1992 Pulitzer Prize for commentary. The lecture series, which began in 1992, is a fund-raiser for the school.

title: Japanese Give Once-Top Party Big Comeback
description: Results from Japan's national elections on Sunday gave a major victory to the party that has dominated the country for most of the postwar era and that has been most reluctant to open up Japan to far-reaching change.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: New York Economy Starts to Bounce Back

title: Running From The Law
description: Forty years ago, at the height of the Red Scare, conservatives in Congress pressed for laws to strip Federal courts of power to hear cases involving Communist charges. They were angry at decisions that gave a degree of fairness to Americans investigated and punished for suspect beliefs and associations.

title: Torricelli and Zimmer Take Message to Cities
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli received a boost in his campaign for United States Senate today, with a visit from President Clinton and his first major editorial page endorsement.

title: Dance in Review
description: A Mysterious World of Women And Their Emotional Landscape

title: Busting A Cable Trust
description: It is curious that Time Warner is invoking the First Amendment, which protects free speech, to block free speech.

title: Barbarity in Belgium
description: Yesterday's march in Brussels, drawing more than a quarter-million people, was the latest in a series of strikes and protests against a judicial system the vast majority of Belgians consider corrupt. The march follows a high court decision to sack an investigating magistrate who had become a national hero. He uncovered a gruesome pedophile ring and arrested the man who allegedly kidnapped four girls and starved them to death.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Police Comb Bronx in Search of Sniper
description: Scores of police officers from around New York City poured into the Fordham section of the Bronx yesterday, scouring rooftops, knocking on doors and questioning some residents repeatedly in their search for a sniper who shot a uniformed police captain in the back on Saturday morning.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Campaign Issues That Should and Shouldn't Be
description: To the Editor:

title: Workfare's Missing Link
description: The new social contract with welfare recipients will require many more mothers to take jobs. But who will care for their children while they work? There is not enough quality day care now to meet the need, leaving too many children in settings that are not even monitored for minimal safety.

title: Oilers Get a Few Breaks and Roll Past the Steelers
description: Entering this game, the Houston Oilers and the Pittsburgh Steelers knew that neither team would give the other anything. As with most grudge matches, anything would be gained grudgingly.

title: Live on Fox: A Curse From Cox
description: Better living through technology? Viewers of Game 1 of the World Series last night easily heard Atlanta Manager Bobby Cox use a common curse word during pre-game introductions to implore his team to victory.

title: Tiger Woods Adds a Chapter to His Legend
description: If someone had taken this screenplay to Michael Eisner, the Disney chairman probably would have fallen out of his chair, laughing in disbelief at the sheer naivete of it all. There is no way this movie gets made. Disney may deal in fantasy, but what Tiger Woods has done over the course of the last two months makes ''Fantasia'' look like a documentary.

title: Jason Bernard, 58, an Actor In Television Films and Series
description: Jason Bernard, an actor who performed in several television series and had recently been nominated for a Cable Ace acting award, died on Friday at Providence St. Joseph's Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 58.

title: Farrakhan's Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking of the Yankees, What About That Stadium?
description: It has become, at a time of baseball mania in New York, the issue that dare not speak its name: will the Yankees leave the Bronx? Will they get the $1 billion stadium proposed for the West Side of Manhattan? Politicians who only a few months ago were tripping over themselves to guess now recoil into no-comment mode. The focus is on the World Series, they say, and everything else can wait.

title: DOLE URGES ACTION ON CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: Building on a string of recent attacks on Democratic fund raising, Bob Dole today urged changes in campaign finance laws, which he blamed for giving President Clinton an unfair advantage in withstanding the challenge to his office.

title: Ads Get Rougher
description: As the political parties compete with commercials on the nation's airwaves, those pitches are getting more combative. The Republicans are running ads depicting ''labor bosses,'' while the Democrats link rival Congressmen to what they call the extremist agenda of Newt Gingrich.

title: The Braves Quickly Put Their Signature on This Series
description: The Atlanta Braves blistered the BudBall last night in the first World Series game played with a signature on the baseballs since 1991. But before conspiracy theorists begin saying the balls were juiced for the occasion, they should remember that the Braves pounded the Leonard S. Coleman balls pretty ferociously in two of the last three National League Championship Series games last week.

title: Jets Flirt With Victory, But Remain Perfect: 0-8
description: The good moments don't last long enough for the Jets.

title: Afghan Rockets Pound Rebels Holding Airport Near Kabul
description: Rockets slammed into Kabul airport today, opening a new phase in the battle for the Afghan capital only 25 days after the forces of the Taliban religious movement captured the city and imposed a strict Muslim government.

title: Bridge
description: The United States open team struggled in the early rounds of the World Championships here today.

title: Surfers Get a Day in Court
description: Does the United States Constitution guarantee Americans the inalienable right to surf? Three men arrested for riding storm-tossed seas in July will find out today in Municipal Court.

title: Clothing Makers Taking Steps To Limit Child Labor Abroad
description: Fewer children appear to be working overseas to make apparel sold in the United States, as companies facing adverse publicity adopt standards barring such labor in their subsidiaries and suppliers, the Labor Department has found.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: A Continuing Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Do not utter the word ''retirement'' to MILTON BERLE. He may be 88, but he is not exactly lolling in a rocking chair. ''I just pick my spots now to make appearances,'' he said the other day. ''I still do many charitable things and appear in Vegas.''

title: Crowding Is Eased With Less Class Time
description: Just before noon every day at Richmond Hill High School, something takes place that is more familiar to factory workers than to students: the start of the second shift.

title: Despite Concern Over Abuses, Albanian Local Vote Goes Smoothly
description: Voting in local Albanian elections that was watched with unusual concern by international observers appeared to go relatively smoothly today, though the Government took a number of actions before the elections that Western diplomats said appeared intended to undermine voter confidence.

title: Mary Boynton, 85, Blood Bank Director
description: Dr. Mary Heiss Boynton, who directed blood donor programs for the American Red Cross during wartime and later at Lenox Hill Hospital, died on Oct. 8 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Get Riady, Get Set . . .
description: I will now stop using Nixon postage stamps. That's because the Nixon Center for Peace and Freedom is raising money by honoring Lee Kuan Yew, the dictator of Singapore.

title: Earthbound Angel Tangles With Loneliness and Love
description: It is, you must admit, kind of gratifying to see an angel tied up and gagged. The winged messengers have been so visible recently (all those plays, magazine covers and best-selling books) that it's hard not to grin at finding one of them landed for unholy purposes, as he is in Nicky Silver's wildly uneven ''Fit to Be Tied.''

title: A week of changes ended with several agency executives switching, leaving and regrouping.
description: THE action along Madison Avenue late last week was not confined to the skies, friendly or otherwise. As the United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation dismissed the Leo Burnett Company after 31 years to divide its account between Fallon McElligott and Young & Rubicam Inc., there were changes among top executives at several other agencies.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about a Dallas company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection misspelled its name in some editions. It is County Seat Stores, not Country Seat.

title: Jonathan Scoville, 58, Landscape Painter
description: Jonathan A. Scoville, a landscape painter, died on Friday at the Geer Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Canaan, Conn. He was 58 years old and lived in West Cornwall, Conn.

title: Burnett, in Wake of Loss, Plans to Return to Basics
description: The Leo Burnett Company had already warned employees to buckle up their seat belts even before the advertising agency lost the United Airlines account. But with the stunning decision Friday by United to dismiss Burnett after 31 years -- costing the agency an estimated $120 million in billings -- top executives are buckling down to re-emphasize the basics.

title: Foreign G.O.P. Donor Raised Dole Funds
description: Bob Dole, who has been attacking President Clinton for accepting campaign money from foreign contributors, has also accepted major donations from noncitizens. And the vice chairman of his primary-election finance committee was Alfonso Fanjul, a Cuban-born sugar magnate who is an immigrant living legally in the United States.

title: Four Clients Switch to New Shops
description: Four advertisers have changed agencies on accounts.

title: United Rallies, Slides and Heads Its Way to First Title
description: Major League Soccer ended its inaugural season in grand style this evening, when D.C. United rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 3-2 overtime triumph over the Los Angeles Galaxy at Foxboro Stadium. Washington's comeback to capture the league title was heroic, but the real stars in the game were the fans.

title: PAC's Power the Senate Race
description: Special-interest groups are courting both candidates in New Jersey's United States Senate race, but while Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, has scored well with labor unions, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican, has benefited mostly from corporate contributors.

title: Slate Delays Fee for Readers
description: Slate, the Microsoft Corporation's on-line magazine of political commentary, has decided to delay charging its readers a subscription fee for another three months. Slate announced the move on its World Wide Web site last week in a note to readers from the editor, Michael Kinsley.

title: Fund-Raiser for Democrats Now Faces Harsh Spotlight
description: In 1986, when John Huang arrived in Los Angeles as the chief representative of one of Indonesia's wealthiest families, he brought Asian-American business leaders some advice: with skillful organization and well-targeted campaign contributions, they could gain influence to match their new wealth.

title: Albany Lawsuit Seeks Time To Dig for Dutch Artifacts
description: Karen Hartgen kept wondering one thing as she and a team of archeologists recently stumbled across a trove of ancient glass trading beads, smoking pipes and other artifacts during the excavation of an empty lot at Broadway and Maiden Lane:

title: A 'Figaro' And Time's Challenge
description: It is chiefly a time to look forward at the New York City Opera, in the company's first full season with Paul Kellogg as general director. But the schedule was largely fixed, a note in the program reminds the audience, by Mr. Kellogg's immediate predecessor, Christopher Keene, and many of its parts evoke a more distant past.

title: Reeves's Speech Motivates Giants, But a Second-Half Rally Falls Short
description: Gen. Colin Powell was in the luxury box of the Washington Redskins owner Jack Kent Cooke for the game against the Giants at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium today. From one field general to another, Powell would have been proud had he witnessed the most intense and passionate speech Dan Reeves has given as a Giants head coach after a truly horrific first-half performance by his team.

title: A Rise in Visitors, a Shortage of Rooms
description: As an unadulterated Yankee fan who was there for the World Series of 1978 and '81, who went to more than 20 games each summer as a teen-ager, and who now lives in Texas, Lisa Swan thought she knew the rules. Series tickets would be tough, but a hotel room?

title: Sports Service Battles N.B.A. In Round Two
description: He is an obsessive Knicks fan and has to work late. He has no access to a television or a radio, not even a telephone to call Sportsphone. Solution: a new gadget called Sports Trax, about the size of a personal pager, on which he can punch a basketball-shaped button and get the latest score of the Knicks' game, minute by minute, basket by basket.

title: Braves Rookie Leads Assault That Buries Yanks in Opener
description: Andruw Jones was not even in kindergarten the last time the Yankees played in a World Series, but that did not prevent Atlanta's precocious slugger from disrupting their return to baseball's grandest event after 15 lonely years. The 19-year-old Jones hit two prodigious home runs that helped power the Braves to a12-1 triumph at Yankee Stadium in Game 1 of the four-of-seven-game series. The Yankees would have been better off if more bad weather had erupted last night.

title: 31 Republicans Who Lost in 1994 Return in Reruns
description: ''Give us the tools to continue the revolution,'' said Tim LeFever, invoking a concept most other Republican Congressional candidates are avoiding this year.

title: The Jets' Toughness No Shock To Bills
description: On paper, it looked like one of those college matchups that end up 51-0 or 67-13. How could the 0-7 Jets, the least successful and perhaps most battered team in the National Football League this year, hang in against the 4-2 Bills of Jim Kelly, Thurman Thomas, Andre Reed and Bruce Smith?

title: A Nation Ponders Its Growing Digital Divide
description: The Warren County Library serves 7,000 people in rural Georgia. But the distance separating the community library from the information age is measured not in miles but in dollars.

title: October Becomes Cruelest Month for Pettitte
description: There should come a moment later this fall when Andy Pettitte gets to hug the Cy Young award to his chest and remember all that was good about the 1996 season.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: No Agreement In G.M. Strike By Canadians
description: Negotiators trying to end an 18-day strike by Canadian auto workers against the General Motors Corporation made little progress over the weekend, but remained hopeful that a deal might be reached before a deadline of noon Monday.

title: No Headline
description: ''The difference between then and now is that in those days, as America was gaining jobs, New York was losing jobs. We don't gain them at quite the same rate as the rest of America, but at least we are moving in the same direction.'' MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI $(B6:4$)

title: For Fans at Game, New Jersey's Out
description: As the Yankees played -- and lost -- their first World Series game in 15 years, many fans interviewed at the game said they opposed having the team relocate to New Jersey, though some said they would not mind a move to Manhattan.

title: A Political Fight Marks a Coming of Age for a Silicon Valley Titan
description: Think of it as the end of innocence for Silicon Valley.

title: WALL ST. PROFITS LEAD A RECOVERY IN NEW YORK CITY
description: The economy of New York City, which has foundered since the recession of the early 1990's, has begun to crawl back toward prosperity, largely because of rising profits on Wall Street.

title: F.T.C. Approves Sale by B.A.T.
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. has received Federal Trade Commission approval to sell six discount cigarette brands and a North Carolina factory to Commonwealth Brands Inc., a small Kentucky tobacco company.

title: Villain Is Dioxin. Relocation Is Response. But Judgment Is in Dispute.
description: Day after day for 40 years, the dark pine logs lay gleaming in the Florida sun, stretching back to the rail tracks almost as far as the eye could see.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD WESTENBURG is returning tonight to Central Presbyterian Church on Park Avenue at 64th Street, where he served as organist and choirmaster from 1964 to 1974, to help it celebrate its 175th anniversary. He will conduct the Musica Sacra, a choir he founded in 1966, in a concert featuring music by Charles Ives. Mr. Ives was organist and choirmaster there at the turn of the century.

title: In Final Rounds, Rivals Wield Bare-Knuckle Ads
description: The two major parties are closing the fall campaign for the House of Representatives with an advertising war that makes their last two years of legislative struggle look almost genteel.

title: Teen-Ager Charged in Strangling of Neighbor, 17
description: As his mother sobbed in the courtroom, a 16-year-old was ordered held without bail yesterday on charges that he strangled a Long Island high school student after she rejected his advances.

title: Drug Center Meets Resistance From Prosecutors
description: When it opened last fall, New York State's new drug program for prisoners was supposed to represent a leap in thinking about criminal justice. The center would be the state's first attempt to divert about 3,400 addicted felons a year away from teeming prisons and into treatment.

title: Right to Bear Arms Is a British Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: Colorado Likely to Ban Traps Used on Wildlife
description: Almost 175 years after Jim Bridger and his buckskin-clad mountain men explored the Rocky Mountains in search of beaver pelts, the residents of modern Colorado are poised to ban lethal trapping in their state.

title: NCR Spreads Its Wings (Flight Insurance, Anyone?)
description: Lars A. Nyberg, the chairman of the NCR Corporation, is sunk deep into a plush red chair in the ornate music room of Moraine Farm, the luxurious 1920's mansion once owned by Col. Edward A. Deeds, a long-ago chairman of the company that was then known as National Cash Register.

title: Edith Penrose, 81, Dies; Business Trend Expert
description: Edith Tilton Penrose, an American-born British economist who was an authority on corporate growth and on oil, died on Oct. 11 in Waterbeach -- near Cambridge, England -- where she lived. She was 81.

title: U.S. Said to Favor a Delay In Bosnian Municipal Vote
description: In the face of Bosnian Serb intransigence and logistical nightmares, senior Clinton Administration officials have concluded that the municipal elections in Bosnia scheduled for next month, and already postponed once, should be put off again if a ''face-saving'' way can be found for doing so, American officials here and in Washington said today.

title: Paradoxes in Rebellion Against Hitler
description: PLOTTING HITLER'S DEATH

title: Braves Starters Crave Getting First Strike
description: MOST pitchers think about getting strike three, but in the World Series opener last night, John Smoltz was more concerned with getting strike one.

title: Russian Taxes Discourage Entrepreneurs
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Mouths of Babes
description: For the 11 or 12 airheads who still are not sure that smoking causes lung cancer, we now have a direct scientific link between a toxic chemical in cigarette smoke and the malignant tumors that have caused such agonizing deaths for so many.

title: Pivotal Figures of Newspaper Series May Be Only Bit Players
description: As Federal and state drug-enforcement agents closed in on a busy Nicaraguan cocaine broker here 11 years ago, they made him an offer they thought he could not possibly turn down.

title: Dead Language? Irish Soap Opera May Wake It Up
description: From before the time of Christ until about 150 years ago, the dominant language of Ireland was Gaelic, an Indo-European tongue that can sound by turns as harsh as the Atlantic winds whipping this town on the western coast or as gentle as mist settling most mornings on the rocky countryside.

title: Face Lift at Apple
description: Exponential Technology Inc., a small Silicon Valley chip maker, is planning to introduce a new version of the Power PC microprocessor Monday that could well mark the return of Apple Computer Inc. as a personal-computer industry innovator in 1997.

title: Hey, Buddy, Can You Spare a Ticket?
description: The bartering for tickets to Game 1 of the World Series yesterday began on the platform of the 161st Street subway station and stretched around Yankee Stadium.

title: Teen-Age Brave Homers Like a Vet
description: Much of the Atlanta Braves' sustained success in the 1990's has been a result of their uncanny ability to develop, through their minor league system, players who turn potential into production once they reach the major leagues.

title: For Jets Receiver, This Loss Hurt Worse Than All the Others
description: WHEN you play for a woeful franchise like the Jets, there are not many losses you can say actually ''hurt.'' Over time, the team assumes a collective numbness, as if shot up with emotional Novocain. The team becomes oblivious to the pain of losing. Each week becomes an exercise in rationalization.

title: Competing Versions Of Poem By Nobelist
description: There was a wee contretemps in the literary world last week when The New Yorker and The New Republic inadvertently published the same poem by Wislawa Szymborska of Poland, winner of this year's Nobel Prize for Literature. Not only that, but the two translations had subtly different tones, and the endings, depending on how seriously one takes these things, had slightly different meanings. In the end, though, the whole matter proved to be something of a post-structuralist's dream.

title: Maybe it's time to see the Internet as a what's-in-it-for-me pipeline.
description: THE Internet and the World Wide Web continue to spew forth new businesses at a volcanic rate. And in the heat of the moment, it is often difficult to know what shape all that lava might take as it cools.

title: Rangers' Streak Ends at 3
description: The Rangers helped christen the Tampa Bay Lightning's new arena tonight, and in the process found themselves used as foils.

title: Though Evidence Is Thin, Tale of C.I.A. and Drugs Has a Life of Its Own
description: Over the years that Beverly Carr has lived in South-Central Los Angeles, she has seen crack cocaine rage through her neighborhood like a violent storm, littering the streets with young bodies, battering schools and homes, tearing families from their hinges.

title: Head of Charles Is Canceled
description: The Head of the Charles Regatta was a victim of this past weekend's heavy rains, as the 32d racing of the rowing event was canceled. With 4,500 participants registered to race in 16 categories in Cambridge, Mass., the regatta committee tried to salvage some racing, but by 10 A.M. yesterday announced the cancellation.

title: Evasion on Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Releasing Medical Files
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton to Tell Central European Lands NATO Has Room for Them
description: NATO diplomats said today that President Clinton would use a campaign speech in Detroit on Tuesday to reassure Central European countries anxious to join the alliance that they will soon be welcome.

title: Of Murder, Memory And a Body With a Story
description: Dr. Samantha Ryan (Amanda Burton), call her Sam, was born in Belfast and now works in Cambridge, England, as a forensic pathologist. As the hero of the limited A&E series ''Silent Witness,'' a co-production with the BBC, Sam carries even more emotional baggage than Helen Mirren's Jane Tennison on ''Prime Suspect.'' But, of course, she manages remarkably well.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Giuliani Withdraws Support For State Senator in Brooklyn
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, saying that a third-party candidacy in a State Senate race could result in a Democratic victory, said yesterday that he was withdrawing his endorsement of State Senator Robert J. DiCarlo in a three-way race for a seat representing sections of Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GIOVANNI ALBERTO AGNELLI, Mrs. Agnelli's nephew, the son of her brother Umberto, made news himself yesterday, when The Daily Telegraph of London reported that he will marry FRANCES AVERY HOWE. Heir to the Agnelli dynasty, he will become president of Fiat in 1998, following the retirement of his uncle GIANNI AGNELLI, 73.

title: A Family Approach to Selling a State Bond Act
description: Two 30-second television commercials on the environmental bond act have been produced for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. The advertisements, running on New York City and Long Island stations, were financed by Renew New York, a political action committee controlled by Mr. D'Amato. The Senator's family is featured in them, including this one:

title: B Sky B Denies Report Of a Bid for Pearson
description: A report in The Independent newspaper in Britain yesterday said that the broadcaster B Sky B was in the early stages of planning a bid worth more than $:4 billion ($6.4 billion) along with an unnamed American media company for the British media company Pearson. But B Sky B, in which the News Corporation has a 40 percent stake, denied the report. B Sky B's chief executive, Sam Chisholm, said there were no talks taking place about a bid for Pearson.

title: No Mechanical Failure Found In Early Look at Jet Landing
description: Crash investigators have begun analyzing the ''black boxes'' from the Delta Air Lines jetliner that came in too low at La Guardia Airport on Saturday, shearing off its wheels and landing on its belly, and they have reached a preliminary conclusion that until the impact, the plane showed no mechanical malfunction, officials said.

title: Rare Bay Owl Found by Chance
description: SINCE 1951, the only known specimen of the Congo bay owl had been a stuffed bird sitting in a Belgian museum. Now the elusive bird has made another documented appearance, this one brief and serendipitous.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about campaign appearances in New Jersey by Ralph Nader, the Presidential candidate of the Green Party, misstated the day of one appearance and rendered incorrectly the name of the university where it will take place. The institution is Montclair State University, not Monclair State College; Mr. Nader's appearance there is today; it was not yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Don't Ask' Policy Stands

title: Afghan Hanging Rouses a Debate on U.N.'s Role as Protector
description: The jarring image of the battered body of a former President of Afghanistan hanging from a traffic-control box in Kabul, the capital, has reopened debate about the role of the United Nations as the protector of someone who is requesting help and asylum.

title: More Companies Are Relying On Private Weather Forecasters
description: Jon B. Davis says that every school paper he ever wrote, from second grade on, was about the weather. If it snowed at night while he was growing up just west of here in suburban Des Plaines, he stayed awake to collect hourly accumulation data.

title: Through Life and Strife, The Tales of a Family
description: THE FAMILY MARKOWITZ

title: Eurotunnel to Cut A Fifth of Work Force
description: Three weeks after evading bankruptcy with a debt reorganization, Eurotunnel said yesterday that it would cut a fifth of its work force to speed up its drive to profitability. The debt-burdened operator of the English Channel tunnel said 657 jobs out of more than 3,500 would be done away with over the next 14 months as part of a process begun nearly a year ago.

title: The Virgin in 17th- and 20th-Century Works
description: Singing is such an art unto itself -- one builds the instrument as well as uses it -- that musicianship seems at times a welcome accident to the essential matters of breath control and diaphragm support. Christine Brandes, a young soprano who appeared at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night, sings well, makes music and understands how to do both.

title: Federal Subsidies to States Tell Half the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: City Ethics Panel Rules for Giuliani in Time Warner Cable Case
description: The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board dismissed a complaint against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday, saying that the Mayor did not have to recuse himself from decisions involving Time Warner just because his wife works for the company's competitor, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

title: Evacuating Endangered Kurds
description: Over the weekend, the United States evacuated from northern Iraq about 600 members of two C.I.A.-financed groups opposed to Saddam Hussein. The evacuation was not the first from the Kurdish zone. Two weeks after Mr. Hussein invaded northern Iraq at the invitation of one faction of Kurds, the United States brought out the Kurdish employees of its intelligence, military and relief agencies and their families, a group of about 2,100. But other endangered Kurds the State Department said it would protect, workers for American-financed relief groups, are still waiting.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Eight months ago, when NANCY NOVOGROD, the editor in chief of Travel and Leisure, and her staff began planning the magazine's 25th anniversary party, the Queen Elizabeth 2 seemed the perfect site. In fact, more than 1,200 people accepted the invitation to the celebration on Saturday.

title: P.& G.'s Crest in China
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that it had begun sales of Crest toothpaste and toothbrushes in 500 cities throughout China. The move to national distribution follows months of preliminary sales in about a dozen cities in three Chinese provinces, a P.& G. spokesman, Don Tassone, said. The Crest items are the first health care products to be introduced in China by P.&G.

title: Inquiry in T.W.A. Crash Is Still a Team Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: USAir Profit Surges 57% For Quarter
description: USAir Group Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose 57 percent in the third quarter, reflecting strong demand for international flights.

title: ZORAN AGREES TO ACQUIRE COMPCORE MULTIMEDIA
description: The Zoran Corporation, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Compcore Multimedia Inc., a privately held maker of compression software, for about $57 million in stock. Zoran makes integrated circuits for use in digital video and audio compression applications like video editing. Zoran said it would exchange 0.6408 common share for each share of Compcore. Zoran's stock fell $1.25 a share, to $18.75, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: U.S. Envoy to Mideast Talks Leaves Without Hebron Pact
description: The American mediator in the Israeli-Palestinian talks announced today that he was leaving for Washington without a deal on Hebron in hand, prompting each side to blame the other for the delay.

title: Magazine Executives Are Appointed
description: Three executives have been named to positions at magazines.

title: For the Philharmonic, It's Harmony On Stage And Sour Notes Off
description: Kurt Masur was facing the music, and sweet music it was. When the maestro of the New York Philharmonic, flanked by his managerial partner and sometime nemesis, Deborah Borda, engaged the public at a question-and-answer session in Avery Fisher Hall this month, the sole critique came from a subscriber who asked why the players had treated rapturous audiences in Europe this summer to repeated encores while, he complained, ''I applaud and cheer and never manage to elicit an encore.''

title: Kittles Sharp in Nets' Defeat
description: The Nets got a pleasant glimpse of what Kerry Kittles can do in a close game tonight. And the rookie exhibited a bit of leadership as well. Kittles scored 18 points -- including 4 in the fourth quarter -- although the Nets lost in overtime to the Orlando Magic, 104-103, before 17,248 at the Orlando Arena.

title: In Creating Russia's 'Sesame Street,' Letter 'D' Stands for Difficult
description: Their parents' idea of American culture usually comes straight from watching Russia's most popular television shows: ''Dynasty,'' ''Baywatch'' and ''Beverly Hills 90210.''

title: Some Sticky Questions for the Press
description: ''Why America Hates the Press,'' the title of tonight's punchy edition of ''Frontline,'' is slightly misleading. The press is represented by a highly unrepresentative gabble of famous and rich television personalities. These talk-show showboats are criticized for the way they do their jobs, for their prosperity and for the company they keep; instead of being the little guys' watchdogs, it is asserted, they have become the fat cats' lap dogs.

title: New Arrest in Killing at Sears
description: A third suspect was arrested on Saturday in the April 19 robbery and slaying of an off-duty Teaneck police officer who was moonlighting as a security guard at a Sears store in Hackensack, the F.B.I. said yesterday. The suspect, Kevin Lee, 23, of Hackensack was arrested at his girlfriend's town house in Princess Anne, Md., said Special Agent Larry Foust, an F.B.I. spokesman in Baltimore.

title: Japanese Election's Outcome Strengthens Premier's Position
description: Flush from his victory in a national election on Sunday, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto began piecing together a coalition today that will enable him to form a new government and rule Japan in the years ahead.

title: DANAHER CONSIDERING ACQUISITION OF TYLAN GENERAL
description: The Danaher Corporation and Tylan General Inc. have a confidentiality agreement that will allow Danaher time to evaluate a possible acquisition of Tylan. In a Federal filing yesterday, Danaher said it had received information through the confidentiality agreement. Tylan General's chief executive, David Ferran, is leading a separate group that is seeking control of the company. Danaher, based in Washington, makes telecommunications test equipment and Sears Craftsman tools. Tylan General, based in San Diego, makes instruments used in the manufacture of flat panel displays and fiber optic cables. It had a market capitalization of slightly more than $100 million after its stock closed at $13, down 12.5 cents a share.

title: MOLTEN METAL'S SHARES FALL ON FEDERAL FINANCING CUTS
description: The shares of Molten Metal Technology Inc. plunged 49 percent yesterday on news that reduced financing from the Energy Department for radioactive-waste research would lower its earnings in the third and fourth quarters. Shares in Molten Metal fell $13.875, to $14.25, in Nasdaq trading of 5.7 million shares. Molten Metal told analysts that its revenue from Government-financed research and development would not meet expectations for 1996. The Energy Department will give it only $8 million of the $20 million it had expected for research into recycling of radioactive scrap metal, Benjamin Downs, a company spokesman, said. Molten Metal, based in Waltham, Mass., sells services for preventing pollution and treating hazardous and radioactive waste.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: An Irresistible Object

title: I.B.M's Profits A Shade Better Than Forecast
description: I.B.M. reported solid but unspectacular third-quarter earnings yesterday, led by strong sales of computer hardware and services. But upbeat comments from the company's management touched off a rally that sent I.B.M. shares soaring to their highest point in more than five years before most of the gains were lost in later trading.

title: Candidates and A.D.M.
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentucky Drops Coach
description: BILL CURRY, who has a 23-51 record in his seventh season at Kentucky, will be fired at the end of the season, the Kentucky athletic director C.M. NEWTON announced yesterday.

title: Police Rule Out Rooftop Sniper in Shooting of a Captain
description: Police investigators have concluded that the sniper who shot a police captain in the Bronx on Saturday fired one bullet from the street and not from atop a nearby apartment building, as originally suspected. That suggests, senior police officials said, that the shooting may well have been a spontaneous attack by someone acting alone and not part of an organized plot.

title: No Headline
description: ''We've been treating clients like children. But children don't get jobs. Children get taken care of by their parents. We must treat clients as adults, not as children. To tell people the new rules is a very adult thing to do.''

title: Once Again, Zimmer Hits '93 Speech By Torricelli
description: Locked in one of the closest Senate races in the country, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican, called a news conference today to repeat his attack on his Democratic opponent for giving a speech three years ago to a group that included people tied to the Hamas terrorist group.

title: Orsatti Opens Another Agency
description: Lou Orsatti, a former managing partner at Orsatti & Parrish in Boston, has teamed up with Partners & Simons, a Boston agency, to open Orsatti & Partners, a shop in Cambridge, Mass., that specializes in direct and data base marketing.

title: Fehr Finally Talks With Selig
description: Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, had his long-awaited meeting with Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, yesterday. Sort of.

title: Pharmacia & Upjohn Seeks to Sell a Unit
description: The Swedish-United States pharmaceutical company Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. may sell all or parts of its Pharmacia Biotech operations, a company spokesman said yesterday. The spokesman, Soeren Densjoe, said the company had hired the investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston to come up with alternatives.

title: Ending Brawls at Montclair
description: Officials at Montclair State University pledged yesterday that strict security measures will be imposed at the next fraternity-sponsored party at the student center. Two students were stabbed and six people arrested last Friday during a brawl outside a sold-out party.

title: McGriff's Bat Heats Up After Cool October Start
description: There was a time during the National League Championship Series when it was unclear whether Braves first baseman Fred McGriff was a participant or a bystander. He had just 1 hit in his first 10 at-bats in that series, a key reason the St. Louis Cardinals jumped out to a three-games-to-one lead.

title: Success Is Still A Rumor For Jets
description: Coach Rich Kotite thought he had it all figured out three games ago.

title: U.S. Women Lead Pool In World Bridge Contest
description: The United States women's bridge team has started well in the World Championships here, but the open team is struggling.

title: Russian Scenes With Heart, Elegance and Control
description: There is a song by Tchaikovsky -- Sergei Leiferkus sang it at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday -- that translates roughly ''Amid the Din of the Ball.'' What a small masterpiece of musical drama it is. A protagonist looks across a room and loves from afar. Private thoughts push public clamor to the background. The bright festive busy-ness is evoked; indeed, it cannot be ignored. But now it must be made to occupy a space in the back of the mind, as something half-apprehended.

title: Oilers Hope to Prove Lame Ducks Can Soar
description: What if the Oilers won a game and no one heard how?

title: Dr. Robert Maynard Giller, 54, An Author on Diet and Nutrition
description: Dr. Robert Maynard Giller, a New York physician and medical nutritionist whose dietary directives made him a popular author among the figure-conscious and highly stressed in Hollywood and elsewhere, died in a car accident on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey on Saturday. He was 54 and lived on the Upper East Side and in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Phone and Data Network Deal Bets on Appeal of the Internet
description: Betting that future Internet traffic will fill communications pipelines as fast as they can be built, the Frontier Corporation and the Qwest Communications Corporation announced plans for a $2 billion national network to carry telephone conversations and data.

title: Vendex Completes Sale Of Stake in Retailer
description: Vendex International N.V. said yesterday that it had completed the previously announced sale of its stake in Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer N.V. bringing in net proceeds of 484 million guilders ($279.8 million) for a profit of about 130 million guilders. Vendex owned about 36 percent of the 11.8 million shares outstanding and sold them at 117 guilders a share. Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer, one of the largest retailers in the Netherlands, owns F.A.O. Schwarz, the toy store chain.

title: MORNINGSTAR WILL ACQUIRE PRESTO FOOD PRODUCTS
description: Morningstar Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Presto Food Products Inc., a closely held maker of frozen toppings, creamers and frozen desserts, for $133.5 million in cash. Morningstar, based in Dallas, makes flavored nondairy creamers and other products. Presto, based in La Puente, Calif., sells unflavored creamers, mostly on the West Coast. The two companies ''are highly complementary to each other in terms of what they do and in terms of their geographic distribution,'' Lou Pellicano, senior vice president of Morningstar, said. Morningstar shares rose $1.625, to $15.25, a 52-week high, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Michael H. Cardozo 4th, 86, Professor and Lawyer Active in Government Service
description: Michael H. Cardozo 4th, who in six decades as a lawyer held numerous Government positions and was a law professor and law school administrator, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 86.

title: Dole, Clinton and Asian Money
description: In normal circumstances, Bob Dole would have no standing as an advocate of campaign-finance reform. If he is a passionate believer in cleaning up campaigns, he kept it a secret during his years as a Senate leader. Instead he had a hearty appetite for strings-attached corporate money, just as his party was a major beneficiary of some of the foreign contributions he now wants to outlaw.

title: Former South Africa Police Chief Admits Role in Terrorizing Blacks
description: The wall of silence surrounding the role of top apartheid-era leaders in atrocities against blacks began to crack today when the former chief of South Africa's police force admitted that he had ordered at least two notorious acts of sabotage, and had done so with the approval of Cabinet-level officials.

title: Clinton Camp Accuses Dole Of Hypocrisy on Donations
description: The Clinton campaign accused Bob Dole today of making a last-minute conversion to the cause of campaign finance restrictions and released a new television commercial accusing Mr. Dole and the Republican Party of accepting $2.4 million in donations from ''foreign interests.''

title: Sale of 10% of ENI Under Way in Italy
description: The sale of up to 10 percent of the Italian energy company ENI S.p.A. for as much as 6 trillion lire ($3.9 billion) started yesterday. The offering, the largest equity sale so far this year in Europe, started when Italy's banks opened for business yesterday and ends on Friday.

title: Korean Air to Make Parts for Boeing
description: The Korean Air Lines Company, South Korea's national airline, has agreed to supply the Boeing Company with wing flaps and tips for a Boeing aircraft under development. A formal signing of the agreement will take place tomorrow, a spokesman at Korean Air said yesterday. The contract is expected to be valued around $600 million.

title: Microsoft Proves Even Stronger Than Wall Street Had Expected
description: In a year when it has remapped its business future to cope with the explosive growth of the Internet, the Microsoft Corporation is getting plenty of mileage from its traditional market, reporting fiscal first-quarter earnings yesterday that beat the estimates of Wall Street analysts.

title: 220,000 Hutu Flee Fight Between Zaire and Tutsi Settlers
description: More than 220,000 Hutu refugees have abandoned their camps in eastern Zaire and are streaming into the hills to escape an increasingly violent conflict between Zairian soldiers and local guerrillas, a United Nations official said today.

title: A 'Shadow Government' With a Shadowy History
description: The State Security Council, which came into existence in 1972, was given such expanded powers by ex-President P. W. Botha that it was known for a decade as South Africa's shadow government.

title: Objections to 'Megan's Law'
description: A lawyer representing paroled sex offenders who have had to register with state authorities argued before an appeals court yesterday that implementing ''Megan's Law'' would impose further punishment on people who had already served their sentences. The lawyer, James Ryan, said he could document 21 instances in which parolees living quietly had been harassed or assaulted, The Associated Press reported.

title: Battle in Washington Brings Soul-Searching
description: Backed by 15,000 volunteers, Ellen Craswell stunned the Republican Party in this state when she eked out a victory in the primary election for governor last month.

title: No Outfield Needed With Maddux
description: It is Oct. 21, 1997, and the Atlanta Braves are in the World Series. So what else is new?

title: Kabul's Islamic Rulers Face Rivals' Guns and Growing Popular Discontent
description: The boy standing on a chair beside a busy intersection was only 13, and he was weeping. Along with a 19-year-old youth beside him on another chair, the boy had been caught gathering scrap iron from a ruined palace. Their punishment was to stand in humiliation for hours before a crowd at a busy Kabul intersection, their faces blackened with oily mud.

title: The N.B.A. Fouls Free Speech
description: The National Basketball Association's regular season does not begin until Nov. 1. But an important legal contest involving basketball, and potentially other professional sports as well, has been unfolding in Federal courtrooms in lower Manhattan. So far, free speech and the dissemination of sports news are taking a beating.

title: Will the two agencies newly assigned to the United Airlines account fly in formation?
description: UNITED AIRLINES, in making the startling decision last week to divide its account between two agencies after dismissing the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, selected a pair of shops that have enjoyed separate skeins of robust gains in billings.

title: Mideast Issues Raised In Campaign for Senate
description: The tight race for the Senate seat from New Jersey centered on foreign policy yesterday, with Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican nominee, repeating his attack on his Democratic opponent for giving a speech three years ago to a group that included people tied to the Hamas terrorist group.

title: Job for a President
description: The contenders have been uninspiring, the ''debates'' dreary, the intellectual level ranged from vapid to embarrassing -- but the Presidential campaign has brought one important benefit to the country.

title: Cast of Many, Ghost Included
description: Although his ''American Landscape'' was a solo dance program, Jeffrey Werbylo filled the stage with many people at Performance Space 122 on Saturday night. There was even a ghostly presence.

title: Women Honored
description: The swimmer AMY VAN DYKEN and the Olympic basketball gold medalist TERESA EDWARDS shared the honor of sportswoman of the year at the Women's Sports Foundation's 17th annual dinner last night.

title: Indian Tribes' Creationists Thwart Archeologists
description: Dr. Robson Bonnichsen, director of the Center for the Study of the First Americans at Oregon State University in Corvallis, was excavating a 10,000-year-old archeological site in Montana several years ago when his team discovered that the area was littered with ancient human hairs. The archeologists realized with excitement that the hairs' DNA content could be studied for clues about the origins of the prehistoric people who once lived there.

title: Accounts
description: Mintz & Hoke Advertising and Public Relations, Avon, Conn., was awarded two insurance accounts with combined billings estimated at $2.5 million: Industrial Risk Insurers, Hartford, and Middlesex Mutual Assurance Co., Middletown, Conn. Both had been in-house.

title: Smokers' Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Sleepers' Debate Renewed: How True Is a 'True Story'?
description: ''Sleepers,'' the No. 1 film at the box office over the weekend, begins with a narrator's saying, ''This is a true story about friendship that runs deeper than blood.''

title: Viacom Termed Close to Deal For Control of USA Network
description: Viacom Inc. is close to an agreement to pay MCA $1.45 billion and exchange its 50 percent interest in the Sci-Fi Channel for the 50 percent of the USA Network it does not already own, executives close to the discussions said yesterday. These executives cautioned that the final details of the agreement had yet to be ironed out.

title: G.M. and Canadian Union Press for Deal to End Strike
description: Representatives of the General Motors Corporation and the Canadian Automobile Workers union were unable to resolve tonight a few remaining issues in a 19-day strike, as G.M. cut production at four more American assembly plants and temporarily laid off nearly 11,000 more American workers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a legal dispute between the National Basketball Association and a sports statistics company over the dissemination of game scores referred incorrectly in some editions to Robin Bierstedt, the deputy general counsel of Time Inc., who was quoted on the First Amendment implications of the case. She is a woman.

title: Neither Side Takes High Road in Ads
description: When Bob Dole left the Senate in May, President Clinton sent him a gracious letter. ''On behalf of a grateful America, as you retire from the Senate, I thank you for your service,'' he wrote.

title: Open a Vein And Root
description: The first-inning run -- fine, chalk it up to nerves. Braves 2, Yankees 0 in the third -- O.K., give the Braves some credit; they're a good team.

title: Ethanol Program Saves Taxpayers' Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Harrick Cleared
description: U.C.L.A. basketball Coach, JIM HARRICK, has been cleared by the Pacific-10 Conference of violating National Collegiate Athletic Association rules in the sale of a car he owned to the sister of a top recruit, it was announced yesterday . Both the conference and the university looked into the sale of a car by Harrick's son, GLENN, to LISA DAVIS-HODOH on Sept. 20.

title: Sensuality, Not Practicality
description: During the haute couture shows in January, when Vogue magazine held a party for Lisa Marie Presley in Paris and invited the usual fashion insiders and hovercrafts, Amber Valletta arrived wearing a sheer gray polka-dot ruffled dress designed by John Galliano for Givenchy. It seemed that Shalom Harlow had grabbed the dress Ms. Valletta planned to wear, or something to that effect.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: TV Screen Opens Onto Internet
description: MICROSOFT recently demonstrated a redesigned version of its Microsoft Network (MSN) on-line information service, one that transforms the computer network into something strikingly like a television network.

title: Indianapolis Star Column Brings Second Thoughts and Apology
description: What does a newspaper do when it finds that its arithmetic of fairness doesn't add up? On Sunday, The Indianapolis Star apologized, upsetting some reporters and raising a question, quickly rejected by the paper, about political influence on the paper's coverage by its controlling family.

title: Radisson Picks Ingalls for Hotels
description: Radisson Hospitality Worldwide in Minneapolis, a unit of the Carlson Companies, has named Ingalls Advertising in Boston to handle advertising for its Radisson hotel division, which had been handled by the Sawtooth Group in Woodbridge, N.J., for five years. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $6 million. The decision came after a five-month review that had been narrowed to Ingalls, a division of Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, and one other finalist, Martin/Williams Advertising in Minneapolis, a unit of GGT Group P.L.C.

title: M.L.S. Is Encouraged, But Remains Cautious
description: Major League Soccer's first season has encouraged its officials to increase spending and improve several areas for next season and beyond. But the league's hierarchy is still firm about sticking to its original long-term business plan.

title: A Television Hit
description: Fox generated a preliminary 17.0 overnight Nielsen rating for Game 1 of the World Series on Sunday, 5 percent above last year, when the Braves-Indians Game 1 appeared on ABC. It is the highest Game 1 rating since 1991 on CBS.

title: AGGRESSIVE TURN BY DOLE APPEARS TO BE BACKFIRING
description: Bob Dole's sustained two-week assault on President Clinton's ethics appears to have backfired, with the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll finding that Mr. Dole did not improve his standing and even damaged his image among voters.

title: 5 Seated in Security Council After Intensive Manuevering
description: After an unusually intense campaign for five rotating seats on the Security Council, member countries today elected Costa Rica, Japan, Kenya, Portugal and Sweden. Their two-year terms begin on Jan. 1.

title: European Tone for Breeders' Cup
description: Two planeloads of race horses from England, Ireland and France landed today to provide instant international tone for the first Breeders' Cup program to be staged outside the United States.

title: One Step Forward, Two Steps Back With I.B.M.
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation consistently brings out new Thinkpad notebook computers that are inventive, well made and a pleasure to use, though not entirely free of problems. The company's desktop machines are a different story. Its latest models are in the all-black Aptiva S line, machines in a minor league of their own.

title: Smokers' Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: A notable trend toward the upgrading of corporate credit.
description: THE rising stock market is having a very positive effect on American companies: corporate credit quality, as measured by changes in bond ratings, appears to be better than ever.

title: Alliance of G.O.P. and Cuban-Americans Shows Rift
description: At a recent citizenship ceremony, Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen called the 2,500 immigrants from 83 countries taking the oath of allegiance ''the embodiment of the American dream'' and assured them that ''the promise of America is so great because of people like you.''

title: If a Tree Falls, Should Its Neighbors Too?
description: FROM a seaplane, Moosehead Lake sprawled steely gray under a dark, drizzly overcast. But autumn's brilliant hues made it seem as if full sunlight were bathing the trees of the Maine woods: red, orange and yellow hardwoods covering the mid-slopes of the northernmost Appalachians, set off by dark green conifers on the ridges and in the valleys.

title: President of City Technical College Resigns After an Audit
description: The president of New York City Technical College in Brooklyn has resigned and has agreed to repay about $50,000 that he had spent from the college's endowment fund.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP. (UK,N)
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported a 41.9 percent decline in third-quarter net income yesterday, citing lower prices for one of its major products and higher raw material costs.

title: With Softer Tone, Dole Turns to Economy
description: After a weeklong assault on President Clinton's ethics, Bob Dole downshifted today and went back to extolling his economic package as his bus caravan rolled through the brilliant fall foliage of southern Michigan.

title: Besting an Evil Ogre in Ancient Scotland
description: Rousing old-fashioned storytelling is happily mingled with modern stage wizardry and grand-scale puppetry in ''The Crown of Destiny.'' The combination, rounded out with music and dance, makes for delightful family entertainment in that handsome, historic setting, the New Victory Theater, on West 42d Street in the renascent Times Square.

title: Elections Fail to Clarify Outlook for Japan
description: As Japan has wallowed through the last few years of economic stagnation and political turmoil, corporate executives have looked to its Government for two things -- stable and strong leadership, and economic deregulation that would lay the groundwork for Japan Inc. to roar again in the 21st century.

title: In Split-Ticket Haven, Democrats' Hopes Run High
description: If this year's Congressional elections are to determine whether the Republican takeover of 1994 reflected a true realignment rather than a temporary protest, the voters in North Carolina's Fourth Congressional District may provide much of the answer.

title: James Francis Brady, 86, Classics Professor
description: Dr. James Francis Brady, a classics professor, writer and translator whose 46-year tenure made him one of the longest-serving educators in the history of Fordham University, died on Friday at his home in Hartsdale, N.Y. He was 86.
