title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the publication of different translations of a poem by the Nobel laureate Wislawa Szymborska misspelled the surname of the literary editor of The New Republic, where one of the translations appeared. He is Leon Wieseltier.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Integrated Health to Buy Coram in $280 Million Deal

title: A Pre-Game Film Session Seemed to Boost Brown
description: Last week after the loss to Philadelphia, Giants Coach Dan Reeves did something he has not done all season long. He pulled his three quarterbacks, his position coach, Steve DeBerg, and his offensive coordinator, George Henshaw, into a room and they watched film together. They talked about the good, the bad, the ugly, everything.

title: Exploring, Improvising and Remembering
description: Betty Carter

title: Jewish Cemetery Is Desecrated in Argentina, the Third This Year
description: A major Jewish cemetery was desecrated over the weekend, the third such attack in Argentina this year, raising fear among Jews and anger that the Government seems to be doing little to stop the anti-Semitic assaults.

title: Graffiti 'Art'? Issue Deserves A Sharp Stake
description: PICTURE the ancient Romans, their lands freshly sacked, inviting the Visigoths in to explain their invasion techniques over coffee, complete with earnest elaborations on the merits of one form of defilement versus another. Picture that, and you have a sense of a symposium on graffiti held over the weekend at the Museum of the City of New York, on upper Fifth Avenue, right by a mailbox covered with illegible scrawls.

title: Scientists Succeed In Growing Bone
description: IT was one of the first medical observations: that human bone is one of the few tissues that can regrow after injury. Hippocrates knew it and hoped that somehow that power could be harnessed for healing.

title: TWO CANADIAN FERTILIZER COMPANIES TO MERGE
description: Agrium Inc. has agreed to take over Viridian Inc. for $1.2 billion Canadian ($887.4 million), in a deal that would create one of the largest fertilizer companies in North America. The companies said on Sunday that their boards had approved the merger, which will create a company with more than $2 billion in revenue. Agrium, based in Calgary, Alberta, and Viridian, based in Toronto, said that on completion of the merger, Viridian shareholders would receive 0.975 Agrium common share for each Viridian share held.

title: Norsk Hydro Profits Plunge 45% in Quarter
description: Norsk Hydro A.S., Norway's largest industrial company, said yesterday that its profit fell 45 percent in the third quarter as big declines in metal and chemical prices offset better oil and gas earnings. Profit fell more than expected, to 909 million kroner ($141 million), from 1.658 billion kroner a year earlier. Third-quarter sales rose 11 percent to 20.17 billion kroner.

title: A Sixth Sense and Sensibility
description: The blind judge banged his leg into a metal folding chair in his office as he made his way to court. An hour or so later, as he passed through that way again, he banged into it a second time.

title: Flying Reptiles Pose Evolutionary Puzzle
description: ONE of the most successful orders of animals, the flying reptiles known as pterosaurs, thrived for 135 million years and diversified into some 85 species, some as small as sparrows, some the size of airplanes.

title: Q&A
description: Stone Weights

title: Anticolonial U., Now a Hotbed of Business Majors
description: In the old days, Fidel Castro and Yasir Arafat walked the halls as guests of Patrice Lumumba University. And in the dormitories, the talk among students was of revolution and of radical plots to shake off colonial and imperial masters.

title: The Knicks Get Hurt Again As McCarty Injures Foot
description: As the preseason hits the halfway point, the Knicks' bumps and bruises keep adding up. The rookie Walter McCarty injured his right foot in practice today.

title: California Dreaming?
description: Is it the polls or is it panic? Desperation or determination?

title: Hardaway Speaks Out on O'Neal
description: The departure of Shaquille O'Neal remains a sensitive subject in the Orlando Magic's locker room.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Countries Without Borders
description: The last few weeks have witnessed another step in the dissolution of Afghanistan, a country that has never been much more than a buffer between empires and whose fragile alliance of ethnic groups was riven by Soviet occupation and civil war.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise On the Big Board Yet Again
description: Open positions of short sales rose to record levels in the most recent month, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday. The run-up, the third consecutive record advance, occurred even as major market averages set new highs.

title: Ralston to Retire
description: JOHN RALSTON, the only active member of the College Football Hall of Fame, will retire as San Jose State's football coach after the season.

title: Rape Defendant Weighs Risk of Testifying
description: With the prosecution in the Alex Kelly rape case expected to rest as early as Tuesday, his lawyers must decide soon whether to take the gamble of putting Mr. Kelly on the stand.

title: Federal Subsidies to States Tell Half the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Grammy Host to Return
description: Ellen DeGeneres, the sitcom star, will be the host of the 39th annual Grammy Awards on Feb. 26, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced yesterday at Madison Square Garden, site of the ceremony. Ms. DeGeneres was also the host this year. The Grammys will be televised on CBS under a new agreement that will keep the show on the network for five years. This year's Grammy show on CBS drew an audience that was 30 percent larger than last year's. Grammy nominees will be announced on Jan. 6. The academy said it was unsure whether any tickets would be made available to the public.

title: TJX SELLING CATALOGUE UNIT TO BRYLANE
description: The TJX Companies said yesterday that it would sell its Chadwick's of Boston catalogue business to Brylane L.P., an apparel catalogue retailer in New York, for $328 million in cash, notes and receivables. TJX, which operates the T. J. Maxx and Marshalls chains, said it expected the sale to result in a gain of $125 million, or $1.39 a share. Brylane will pay $223 million in cash and $20 million in a convertible subordinated note. TJX is based in Framingham, Mass.

title: Devils Demote Dunham
description: The Devils abandoned the idea of a three-goalie system yesterday by assigning MIKE DUNHAM to their top affiliate in the minor leagues without giving him a chance to play a single minute in the league.

title: Patterns
description: New Designs at Samsung

title: At Sea in Sweat World
description: Beth asked me to drop by and talk politics with Charlie. ''It might get his mind reset,'' she said. Charlie's mind had been down since Sunday. Another case of sports overload.

title: TCI and Lodgenet Enter Joint TV Venture
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said today that it would invest $40 million in a joint venture with the Lodgenet Entertainment Corporation to provide direct broadcast and interactive television services to apartment buildings.

title: People
description: David Tanzer, chief operating officer at Channel One Network, New York, a unit of K-III Communications Corp., was promoted to president and chief executive, succeeding Ed Winter, who was promoted to chairman, a new post.

title: Lawsuits Over Jet Crash Blame T.W.A. and Boeing
description: A lawyer representing 25 families of victims in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 filed lawsuits yesterday against Boeing and T.W.A., advancing the theory that the plane was destroyed by a mechanical malfunction that could have been prevented.

title: Burden of Welfare Changes Falls to State Case Workers
description: When Susan A. Christie teaches state employees about the new Federal welfare law, she clucks her tongue and moves her hand to imitate the action of a metronome.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DYNATECH CORP., Burlington, Mass., a global communication equipment company, has sold the assets of its Unex Corp. unit to GN Netcom, Eden Prairie, Minn., a subsidiary of GN Noridic Group of Denmark. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Not Your Ordinary Sweater
description: Knits are on the high end of the fashion barometer this year, which means that a long, lean sweater, belted over a skinny skirt or tucked into trousers, can conveniently take the place of a jacket.

title: Warning on Water Supplies
description: The building boom that is coming to Atlantic City could overtax the region's water system, officials of the State Department of Environmental Protection and the Atlantic City Municipal Utilities Authority members warned yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress Laura La Plante on Thursday misspelled the surname of her first husband. He was William Seiter.

title: Yanks Need Comeback Almost as Big as Cone's
description: The Norwich Navigators baseball cap rests on the top shelf of David Cone's dressing stall in the Yankee clubhouse, a reminder of where he has been in the past six months, when the notion of pitching in October 1996 was a fantasy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SUSANNA AGNELLI, who was the Foreign Minister of Italy until June and who was a senator and a mayor during more than 20 years in Italian politics, does not seem the type of public figure to be unnerved by the prospect of delivering a speech.

title: Bomb Threat Clears Station
description: Pennsylvania Station in Newark was evacuated for a half-hour during the evening rush yesterday because of a bomb threat, officials said. A man anonymously called the Amtrak reservation center in Fort Washington, Pa., at 5:05 P.M., saying there was a bomb aboard a Philadelphia-bound train departing New York's Pennsylvania Station at 5:15 P.M., said Maureen Garrity, a spokeswoman for Amtrak.

title: Small-Business Owners Prepare for a Megabattle
description: With the City Planning Commission expected tomorrow to approve the Giuliani administration's plan to allow suburban-style megastores in manufacturing areas, the proposal appears headed for a fierce battle before the City Council.

title: Braves Not '86 Red Sox Or '85 Cards
description: INSTEAD of a tomahawk in the Braves' uniform logo, it should be a scalpel because the Yankees are in surgery.

title: World Series Opener Possessing Little Drama Curtails Camera Creativity
description: The Yankees were in trouble Sunday night well before losing, 12-1, to Atlanta when two of their stalwarts faltered. First, the public-address announcer, Bob Sheppard, announced New York's lineup out of order, placing Paul O'Neill ninth, not seventh. Then Robert Merrill, our operatic link to Francis Scott Key, sang, ''O'er the ramparts we watched/Were so 'blassally' (?) streaming.''

title: Carnegie Foundation Picks New President
description: The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching has chosen a Stanford University professor of education as its new president.

title: Integrated Health Services in Expansion
description: Integrated Health Services Inc., a home health care and specialized nursing home company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Coram Healthcare Corporation, a troubled, debt-laden home care company, for about $280 million in stock, creating one of the largest companies that provide care for patients whom hospitals no longer find profitable.

title: North Korea May Be Set to Test-Fire Missile Able to Reach Japan
description: North Korea may be preparing to test-fire a missile capable of reaching Japan, adding to anxieties here about tensions on the Korean Peninsula, American and Japanese officials say.

title: Contractor Guilty of Defrauding City
description: A prominent Queens contractor pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding New York City on a $3.7 million dollar contract to paint hundreds of classrooms in 1995, and agreed to forfeit $1 million the School Construction Authority owes it, officials said.

title: No Headline
description: The parceling out of the old Soviet Union has not diminished the domination of its descendants. At the 1996 Olympiad, which finished on Oct. 2 in Yerevan, Armenia, the Russian team, led by Garry Kasparov, ran away with the gold medal, scoring 38 1/2 of a possible 56 points.

title: Hawaii Phone Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: INGRAM BOOK CO., La Vergne, Tenn., a wholesaler of trade books and textbooks, promoted Lavona Russell to president. She has been senior vice president of operations.

title: No Rushing Pettitte
description: Andy Pettitte threw only 52 pitches in two and one-third innings in Game 1 on Sunday, but Torre said it was very unlikely he would bring Pettitte back on two days' rest for Game 4. ''I thought about it last night,'' Torre said. ''I'll still need a pitcher for Game 5. It would be Kenny Rogers in Game 5, otherwise it would be Jimmy Key on two days' rest and that's not going to happen. I don't think that gains us anything. At this minute I don't see the advantage to it.'' JACK CURRY

title: Justices Reject Challenge to Gay Policy
description: The Supreme Court today turned down the first constitutional challenge to reach it under the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy that presumes that acknowledged homosexuals are unfit for military service.

title: Unusual Effort By Endowment And Agency
description: An unusual partnership between a Federal agency and a private foundation will provide nearly $10 million over the next five years to support research in the humanities, it was announced yesterday.

title: Jeter Expects to Play Tonight With Bruised Wrist
description: The Yankees and Braves exchanged hit batsmen last night in Game 2 of the World Series, and the designated targets were two of the more highly touted rookies of 1996.

title: Ruth Farkas, 89, Nixon's Ambassador to Luxembourg, Dies
description: Ruth Lewis Farkas, who was appointed Ambassador to Luxembourg in 1973 after she and her husband, the founder of the Alexander's department stores, contributed $300,000 to President Richard M. Nixon's re-election campaign, died on Friday at the Park Avenue home of her son Robin. She was 89.

title: Hayden's Neighbors Fear Changes Would Bring Pollution and Traffic
description: What you have here, then, is what looks like one of those familiar huffy neighborhood showdowns where residents get bent out of shape upon hearing that, say, a nuclear waste dump or a maximum-security prison is to be built down the block.

title: Japan's Nichiei Finance Is in Bankruptcy
description: The Nichiei Finance Company, a nonbank financial service company, said it filed for bankruptcy today with the Yokohama District Court. The company has total debt of $1.5 billion, Nichiei said in a statement. Nichiei also has provided other companies with loan guarantees of $7.3 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the landscape painter Jonathan Scoville, who died on Friday at the age of 58, partially misstated the cause of death. It was indeed pneumonia after a long illness, but no surgery was involved.

title: Into the Power Vacuum
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockies' Walker Injured
description: LARRY WALKER, who missed two and a half months of the 1996 season with a broken left collarbone, separated his right shoulder during a weekend fishing trip near Vancouver, British Columbia, Colorado Rockies officials said. Walker, a Vancouver native, returned to Denver yesterday for an examination. It is unknown whether he will need surgery, but he is expected to be ready by spring training in February.

title: All That Momentum Is Gone Now
description: THE shortstop, who had been so sure of himself, was flopping around on the left-field grass, and the center fielder, who had been so sure of himself, was flopping around in center field, in the very same inning.

title: Ease Limits on Tax-Deferred Pay for Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Leads Rare Coalition For Bond Act
description: One morning last week, Gov. George E. Pataki strode serenely into the heart of what was, just three months ago, enemy territory: the midtown offices of 1199 National Health and Human Service Employees Union.

title: Struggling for Hits in Cy Young Territory
description: Two games into the World Series, the Atlanta Braves had established their intent to continue two impressive trends: great pitching and lots of hitting.

title: Check Forger Is Sentenced
description: A 38-year-old nurse who altered taxpayers' checks to the Internal Revenue Service so he could cash them at a bank in Livingston was sentenced yesterday to 15 months in prison. The nurse, Peter Odafe Obebeduo of the Bronx, had pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in June to intercepting three checks worth $89,000 in 1991 and changing ''I.R.S.'' to read ''Idris F. Mohammed'' or ''Iurus Products.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about physician-assisted suicide misidentified the state whose assisted-suicide law was overturned by a Federal appeals court. It was Washington, not Oregon. The article also referred imprecisely to the court taking the action. It was the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which handles cases from Washington and eight other states; it is not an Oregon court.

title: Government Is Quickly Using Power of New Immigration Law
description: In the three weeks since President Clinton signed a bill changing immigration rules, the Justice Department has gone to Federal court to seek the dismissal of four of five class-action lawsuits filed on behalf of hundreds of thousands of aliens who say the immigration service unfairly denied them eligibility for legal residence.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: West Virginia

title: Mechanics, Technique and Heart. Oh My!
description: With all the attention being paid to what Tiger Woods does -- He hit it where? Nobody's ever hit it there! -- very little notice has been taken of exactly how he does it. Is he a freak of nature? Is he, as Golf Digest magazine asks on the cover of its November issue, Superman? Is there some ''secret,'' like Hogan's, that has contributed to this most auspicious professional debut of his?

title: Food and Foreign Tobacco Help RJR Nabisco's Gain
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation announced yesterday that profits were increasing in its Nabisco food unit and its international tobacco business. But the company's third-quarter results were marred by continuing erosion in its domestic cigarette business.

title: British Petroleum In China Venture
description: The British Petroleum Company and the Shanghai Petrochemical Company have agreed to form a $2.5 billion joint venture to build an ethylene plant in Shanghai, the companies said yesterday. Each partner will hold a 50 percent stake in the venture, with B.P. providing cash and technology and Shanghai Petrochemical contributing some existing plants. The project will have a capacity of 637,000 tons of ethylene annually, B.P. said.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Yankees on Brink After Going 0 for the Bronx
description: Officially, the Yankees can still win the World Series. Unofficially, Greg Maddux might have helped conclude their special season last night with a brilliant performance that steered the Braves to a 4-0 victory in Game 2 at Yankee Stadium.

title: J. Bracken Lee Is Dead at 97; Was Blunt Governor of Utah
description: J. Bracken Lee, a conservative Republican who was Governor of Utah, Mayor of Salt Lake City and a foe of income taxes, foreign aid and even of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Salt Lake City. He was 97.

title: Who's on the Attack?
description: Bob Dole has been getting the attention, and negative reaction, for his new attack strategy, but President Clinton's advertisements have had a hostile tone all along.

title: RIGHTIST IS VICTOR OVER SANDINISTAS IN NICARAGUA VOTE
description: Decisively rejecting a bid by the former guerrilla fighters of the Sandinista National Liberation Front to return to power through the ballot box, Nicaraguan voters have instead turned further to the right, electing a candidate who advocates untrammeled free enterprise and a closer relationship with the United States.

title: Agency to Hire Ross Roy Staffers
description: Fitch Inc., a corporate identity and design company, is opening an advertising agency by joining forces with employees who had worked at the Ross Roy Communications unit of the Omnicom Group in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: Wet Region Cleaning Up After Furious Northeaster
description: There was a constant buzz of chain saws clearing away fallen trees and the drone of pumps emptying flooded basements as residents of this shorefront community continued to clean up today from the weekend storm that drove several hundred people from their homes.

title: LILLY PAYING FOR OBESITY AND ALZHEIMER STUDY
description: Eli Lilly & Company has reached a five-year deal to pay Neurocrine Biosciences Inc. $74 million in cash to develop new drugs for obesity and Alzheimer's disease, the companies said yesterday. The accord provides financial and scientific backing for new compounds that Neurocrine is testing to treat those diseases, which are both linked with depressed levels of a hormone, called corticotropin releasing factor, or C.R.F. Neurocrine, based in San Diego, is a four-year-old biotechnology company developing drugs for disorders of the central nervous system and the immune system. Under the pact, Neurocrine will receive $22 million in initial fees and financing, including $10 million the first year.

title: L.I. Lab Increases Hanft Byrne Billing
description: Twin Laboratories Inc. in Ronkonkoma, L.I., said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Hanft Byrne Raboy Abrams & Partners Inc. in New York by naming that agency to handle advertising for sports nutritional products, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million. The account, which includes products like Ultra Fuel and Diet Fuel, had been handled by Greenstone Roberts Advertising in Melville, L.I., which continues to handle advertising for vitamins and mineral supplements sold by Twin Laboratories. Hanft Byrne, formerly Slater Hanft Martin, was awarded the additional assignment without a review; the agency already handles brands for Twin Laboratories like Nature's Herbs and Alvit Teas.

title: Initial public offerings, coming your way over the Internet.
description: DO people really want to buy stock in a new company over the Internet? This week, Leo J. Feldman is finding out.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Once again, SHIRLEY MacLAINE has had to defend her Malibu, Calif., home from fires roaring along the Pacific coast, The Associated Press reported yesterday. On Monday, she and her neighbors hosed down their roofs as burning ashes fell.

title: Poor Start Spells the End for the Islanders
description: Last Friday, Coach Mike Milbury ran the Islanders through a practice centered around a dictionary. Milbury would read his players definitions of words he thought were key to their psyches, then have them skate the length of the ice to let those definitions sink in.

title: NEC Technologies Reviews Its Account
description: NEC Technologies, a division of the NEC Corporation that makes computer peripheral products, said yesterday that it had begun a review on its account, which has been handled by Hampel/Stefanides in New York for two years. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: State Dept. Becomes Cooler To the New Rulers of Kabul
description: After a brief flirtation with the Muslim movement known as the Taliban as the apparent victor of the civil war in Afghanistan, the Clinton Administration has decided to keep the Taliban at arms' length.

title: Prekindergarten-Plan Protest
description: Parents hoping to preserve public education for 4-year-olds delivered petitions with 1,800 signatures to the Township Council and Board of Education last night. Last month, the board voted to stop paying for the district's $1.5 million prekindergarten after this year. But under pressure from the parents' group, the board and Township Council agreed to seek ways to keep the 25-year-old program going. A task force had its first meeting last night.

title: Clinton Pursues Party Sweep Without Whispering a Hint
description: Something is conspicuously missing from Bill Clinton's speeches in these concluding weeks of the 1996 campaign. As much as he wants his party to recapture control of the Senate and the House of Representatives on Nov. 5, he is careful to avoid explicitly partisan appeals.

title: Gastineau to Fight Highsmith
description: When MARK GASTINEAU played defensive end for the Jets (1979-88), he was outrageously flamboyant. He is still living and thinking on the brink.

title: Help Wanted: Bulldozers
description: My favorite moment during the San Diego Presidential debate was when, with only 14 minutes to go before the close, the moderator, Jim Lehrer, scanned the audience and plaintively asked: ''Does anybody have a foreign-affairs question?''

title: Citing Gun Control Efforts, Bradys Endorse Torricelli
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for Senator, picked up the endorsement today of James S. Brady and his wife, Sarah, once staunch Republicans, for his repeated work for gun control legislation.

title: Wymberly deR. Coerr, 83, Ex-U.S. Envoy to Uruguay and Ecuador
description: Wymberley deRenne Coerr, an American career diplomat who was Ambassador to Uruguay and Ecuador in the 1960's, died on Oct. 5 in a hospital in Ajijic, Mexico, where he and his wife had rented a house for three months. He was 83.

title: A Drug-Treatment Compromise
description: Law enforcement officials all over New York State are crying out for drug-treatment money. Their argument is that treatment is both cheaper and more effective for addicted criminals. Yet despite the demand for treatment slots, a new state-run drug program is being drastically underused because local district attorneys find it inadequate. This has angered state officials. Both sides need to stop bickering and move toward compromise.

title: Ads Showing Dead Fetuses Stir Uproar
description: Disgusted by a televised anti-abortion advertisement that shows the remains of dead fetuses, viewers, many horrified that young children are watching, have been bombarding two local stations here with complaints.

title: Sentencing Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cut Above the Rest, the Secret of Butchers and Bistros
description: IT'S a restaurant steak, not a steakhouse steak. It's not a big slab of steak but a smaller, succulent morsel of meat. And, propelled by chefs and eaters alike, affordable, flavorful hanger steak is moving across the country almost faster than people can eat it.

title: Hate the Yankees? Does a Baritone Roar?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Commercial Misleading, Election Finance Expert Says
description: Accusing President Clinton of making ''an unauthorized, misleading and dishonest use of a statement I made,'' a noted campaign finance expert requested today that Mr. Clinton drop the statement from a commercial attacking Bob Dole.

title: Big Drug Companies Announce 3d-Quarter Earnings Gains
description: Four of the world's biggest drug companies posted stronger third-quarter earnings yesterday, which were driven by surging sales of their leading drugs and newer products.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Salomon's Weak Profit Again Surprises Wall Street

title: Fritz and Ingeborg Kahlenberg, Dutch Wartime Photographers
description: Fritz and Ingeborg Kahlenberg, exiled Germans who met during World War II as members of Hidden Camera, a Dutch Resistance group that documented the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands, died this month at New York University Hospital within two weeks of each other.

title: Minivan Service for Disabled
description: In addition to equipping most of its buses with lifts for wheelchair accessibility, New Jersey Transit deploys minivans to transport people with more severe disabilities anywhere along standard bus routes. The vans make about 700 trips a day in south and central New Jersey, said Ken Miller, a transit spokesman.

title: Yanks Have Come Back Before
description: This is the 34th time the Yankees have been in the World Series, and the seventh time they lost the first two games. Three times they recovered to win the Series: in seven games in 1956 against the Brooklyn Dodgers, in seven games in 1958 against the Milwaukee Braves and in six games in 1978 against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Lotus Cars Says It Seeks Only a Partner
description: Lotus Cars Ltd., the closely held British sports car and consulting company, said yesterday that it was in talks with the Malaysian auto maker Proton, on what it termed a ''technical collaboration.''

title: UAL's Profit Surged 30.8% In 3d Quarter
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said today that earnings rose 30.8 percent in the third quarter as higher traffic offset rising fuel prices.

title: Interleague Play in Doubt
description: The revolutionary concept of interleague play will remain on baseball's drawing board instead of being implemented next season if owners and players don't complete a new labor agreement in the next couple of weeks, the acting commissioner acknowledged tonight.

title: Putting Values in Classroom, Carefully
description: When a public elementary school in this affluent Detroit suburb recently adopted a policy of ''character education,'' every class was to spend a few weeks on each of several values: respect, citizenship, caring, responsibility, trustworthiness, fairness and justice.

title: Scourge, and Sometime Victim, of the Sandinistas: Jose Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo
description: Almost as soon as he became Mayor of Nicaragua's capital in 1990, Arnoldo Aleman set about erasing all signs of the 11-year tenure of the Sandinista National Liberation Front. Revolutionary murals were painted over, Sandinista loyalists were stricken from the municipal payroll, and free gas and light service to the tomb of the front's founder was cut.

title: No Thanks, Saints Official Says
description: The New Orleans Saints found another person who doesn't want to coach the team. One day after the head coach, JIM MORA, suddenly resigned midway through his 11th season, his longtime friend CHET FRANKLIN -- the Saints' director of pro personnel -- refused yesterday to step in to lead the team for the final eight games.

title: Neagle Ready to Fulfill a Dream
description: Atlanta's Denny Neagle is in his first World Series and said he's still a bit stunned to be playing baseball ''instead of working on my golf game and watching the game on television.''

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: On Being a Woman, In Body, Mind and Spirit

title: For Color and Charm, The Timbre of Wood
description: It may not have been Marion Verbruggen's intention to explore the relationship between medium and message in her solo recorder recital on Sunday afternoon at Corpus Christi Church, but the works that framed her program inevitably brought the matter to mind. Ms. Verbruggen, a Dutch player who has made a series of exemplary recordings for the Harmonia Mundi label, opened her recital with a set of Telemann Fantasies that are heard more frequently on the modern flute these days, and closed it with a transcription of Bach's Cello Suite in C (BWV 1009).

title: Aid Sought for Flood Victims
description: Some New Jersey residents were still unable to return to flood-ravaged homes yesterday as Gov. Christine Todd Whitman asked the Federal Small Business Administration to make low-cost loans available to homeowners and businesses affected by the heavy rainfall. The state has yet to compile figures on the amount of damage incurred throughout the state. But in Manville alone, the damage was estimated at $5.3 million, said Tom Bittle, Somerset County's deputy emergency management coordinator. In neighboring Bound Brook, which also suffered heavy damage when the Raritan River overflowed, about 30 residents evacuated from their homes were still at the local high school yesterday, said Lieut. Kenneth Winters of the Bound Brook Police.

title: Plea Is Renewed for Brazilian Devaluation
description: Rudiger Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who is known for predicting the devaluation of the Mexican peso, said yesterday that Brazil's currency was seriously overvalued.

title: Pipeline as Neighbor
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Errs on Teen-Age Drug Test Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N.'s Urban Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: AL HIRSCHFELD, 93, the artist and caricaturist, and LOUISE KERZ, 60, a research historian in the arts, are scheduled to marry this afternoon, bringing a long friendship to a romantic conclusion.

title: Economic Sobriety
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicaragua's New President
description: Nicaragua has suffered through more than its share of abrupt ideological shifts in recent years. In a 1979 revolution it lurched from the right-wing dictatorial dynasty of the Somozas to the leftist Sandinista regime under Daniel Ortega. Then in 1990 the Sandinistas were displaced in the country's first democratic election by Violeta Chamorro, who wore white and made reconciliation her theme. In the latest turn, a man with authoritarian tendencies, Arnoldo Aleman, was elected President on Sunday.

title: California Fires Scorch 35,000 Acres
description: From Big Sur to San Diego, California firefighters pitted their water-scooping planes and shovel-wielding brawn today against a half-dozen blazes that seared 35,000 acres in the most destructive wildfires the state has seen in three years.

title: Strawberry's Mantra: Remember the '86 Mets!
description: The first time Darryl Strawberry had the privilege of playing right field in Game 3 of a World Series, he and his team were trying to recover from two consecutive losses at home. As Yogi Berra said, there is such a thing as deja vu all over again, and it came around and grabbed Strawberry last night.

title: Northern Telecom's Earnings Soar
description: Northern Telecom of Canada said yesterday that earnings rose 34 percent in the third quarter. The company, a provider of telecommunications equipment, said net income rose to $112 million, or 43 cents a share, from $80 million, or 32 cents, in the similar period a year earlier. The company reports its financial results in United States dollars.

title: Dole Shows High Spirits Across Michigan
description: A couple of times today, Bob Dole was suddenly electrified with enthusiasm, all in the spirit of insisting that he would win the election, even though the polls show him falling increasingly behind.

title: Looking Inward, Understanding Strange Worlds
description: DR. OLIVER SACKS was in a hotel in McLean, Va., for a national conference of the Tourette Syndrome Association several years ago, and the joint, he said, was jumping. Touretters, with their multi-layered compulsions, tics and spontaneous utterances, filled the hotel with an exuberant pathology of disinhibition. Their spirit was infectious.

title: Mafia's Tell-All, Forgive-All Mood Is Unsettling Italy
description: When a Mafia don wrote a letter this week publicly forgiving his wife's killer, Italian prosecutors were naturally a bit skeptical.

title: Rogers Gets a Wish; Torre Wants His, Too
description: Kenny Rogers finally talked. Rogers, who is starting Game 4 Wednesday night, had declined to meet with the news media before the Yankees won Game 3.

title: John Hillaby, 79, a Naturalist; Took Readers on Exotic Treks
description: John Hillaby, a naturalist and long-distance walker whose lively books on backpacking through Africa, Britain and Europe earned him an international following, died on Friday in York, England. He was 79.

title: Oakley Knows the Knicks Aren't a Special Team Yet
description: Breaking down the complex issues of team sports as only he can, Charles Oakley tonight proclaimed that fans should not pay much attention to glossy magazines that tout the Knicks as a special team.

title: Retailers Find Users Puzzled as Industry Deregulates
description: Like every other business in this gritty industrial town, the Tingley Rubber Corporation used to buy its natural gas from the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

title: Clinton Urges NATO Expansion in 1999
description: In a rare turn to foreign policy on the campaign trail, President Clinton today called for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to extend full membership to a first group of former Soviet bloc nations by the spring of 1999, the 50th anniversary of the Western military alliance.

title: Environmentalists Ante Up To Sway a Number of Races
description: The nation's best-known environmental group began running a radio advertisement in New Hampshire this week accusing the incumbent Republican Senator of taking positions favored by business groups to pay them back for campaign contributions.

title: Amid Theme Restaurants, the People's Hall Lives
description: WHERE have Anais Nin, Richard Nixon and Hot Tuna all appeared -- besides in some truly bizarre dream best kept between yourself and your analyst? Hint: it's a Times Square theater that doesn't have the phrase ''All Live'' on its marquee.

title: Ordway Early Favorite In Breeders' Juvenile
description: Was that next year's Kentucky Derby winner out there on the Woodbine track early this morning, flying half a mile in 48 seconds four days before the Breeders' Cup Juvenile?

title: Food Notes
description: Tomatoes Aid Pasta

title: Gasoline Surges on Report Of Venezuela Refinery Woes
description: Gasoline prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a refinery in Venezuela, the world's largest, shut a gasoline-making unit for at least two weeks for repairs.

title: The Little Town That Said No
description: About a half-century ago, the State of Connecticut put up cribbing -- a lattice of concrete beams -- along a couple of miles on Route 4 in my town, Cornwall. The cribbing has worked pretty well to keep Dean Hill from washing down over the road. Now the State Transportation Department is talking about spending $1 million to replace the cribbing with a concrete wall.

title: Court Says Polluted Sites Can Have Assessments Cut
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that owners of properties polluted by hazardous wastes can obtain reductions in their local tax assessments to reflect the lower values of contaminated properties, even if they are responsible for the contamination.

title: Jet Strong Safety Earns Time Out for Pampering
description: A little more than a dozen hours after the Jets' 25-22 last-minute loss to the Buffalo Bills on Sunday, Victor Green turned up at the Jets' complex. Team meetings, tape watching and weight lifting would come later. Green had greater priorities.

title: Falcons and George Formally Split
description: The 0-7 Atlanta Falcons waived a disenchanted JEFF GEORGE yesterday, ending a stormy relationship that led to the quarterback's suspension, then his release.

title: Quarter Profit Up 28% At Asea Brown Boveri
description: ABB Asea Brown Boveri said yesterday that its net profit rose 28 percent in the third quarter, as expected, as lower costs and higher productivity in emerging markets more than offset lower income from power generating and transport.

title: In Minnesota Race, Negative Ads Outnumber the Lakes
description: On the screen are a faded Capitol on a gray background and a cartoon figure with the distorted face of Senator Paul Wellstone. With clown music playing, a cartoon arm pops out holding a sign reading, ''LIBERAL.''

title: Canoist Disappears in River
description: A television news reporter and cameraman watched helplessly yesterday as a man whose canoe had capsized struggled against a heavy current in the swollen waters of the Raritan River and then disappeared.

title: A Split Personality: D.H., Then No D.H.
description: WHEN the Yankees won here last night, 5-2, their pitchers were in the batting order. And with the bases loaded and two out in the fourth inning, David Cone slashed what was almost a double inside the third-base line off Tom Glavine's fastball.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Philip Morris Reports Strong Earnings
description: Buoyed by profits in its premium-segment cigarette businesses and the growing strength of its Marlboro brand, the Philip Morris Companies announced strong third-quarter earnings yesterday that paradoxically led to a sell-off of the company's shares.

title: B. F. GOODRICH IS SELLING ITS SEALANTS AND COATINGS UNIT
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Tremco Inc. sealants and coatings unit to RPM Inc. of Mentor, Ohio, allowing Goodrich to concentrate on specialty chemicals and aerospace. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed, but Goodrich said it expected to report a gain on the sale. The transaction is subject to regulatory approval, the companies said. Tremco, based in Cleveland, had revenue of $350 million in 1995; it employs 1,700 people and has operations in the United States and 16 other countries. RPM specializes in industrial coatings, sealants and waterproofing. Its brand names include Rust-Oleum, Stonhard and Carboline.

title: Pacific Gas and Electric to Sell 4 Power Plants
description: The nation's largest utility, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, said yesterday that it would sell four power plants as part of its plan to comply with California's effort to open the state's utilities to competition.

title: Park Comes Tumbling Down
description: This is the first time the World Series has been played in a ball park during its last year of existence -- in fact, in its last three days of existence. After this week, Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium will be torn down and the Braves will move across the street to Olympic Stadium, which is being remodeled for baseball.

title: No Jobs, No Peace
description: Palestinians hoped that the Oslo peace accords would bring prosperity and compensate for the economic devastation of the intifada.

title: It's Ball Four Again, but This Is Not Seattle, and Cone Survives
description: Shades of Seattle.

title: WESTINGHOUSE NEARING ANNOUNCEMENT ON ITS FUTURE
description: The chief executive of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Michael H. Jordan, said last night that a decision on a possible reorganization of the company might be announced as early as next month. Many analysts expect the company to split itself into two publicly traded companies, one a media company and another consisting of the five businesses that make up its industries and technology group. Westinghouse bought CBS last year and is in the process of acquiring Infinity Broadcasting. ''We will announce sometime later in the fourth quarter, perhaps next month, and it probably will be fairly obvious what we're doing,'' Mr. Jordan told a conference in New York sponsored by Nationsbanc Capital Markets Inc. In the meantime, he said, the company was running a project at its Pittsburgh headquarters intended to get people responsible for the industrial side of the business to run it as if it were a separate $5 billion company.

title: Digital Posts A Big Loss, And Stock Hits Two-Year Low
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation stunned Wall Street yesterday by reporting a quarterly loss that was more than three times what most analysts had forecast. The news sent Digital's stock plunging 23 percent to its lowest point in two years and raised serious questions about management's ability to sustain a turnaround that stalled earlier this year.

title: Sumitomo Copper Trader Seized on Forgery Count
description: Yasuo Hamanaka, the former Sumitomo Corporation copper trader who exerted enormous influence on world copper markets even as he piled up $2.6 billion in trading losses, was arrested in Japan today on forgery charges.

title: Lead-Eating Mustard Plants Give Zimmer a Campaign Cue
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate for the Senate from New Jersey, stopped by a news conference at an abandoned battery factory here today to praise a company that is using mustard plants to soak up the lead in the soil.

title: Drug Used in Emergencies Despite Warnings
description: Medical emergencies caused by very high blood pressure are often treated with a drug that is neither safe nor effective for the condition, a new study reports.

title: G.O.P. Pushes Congress Strategy That Shuns Dole
description: Republican campaign operatives are urging their party's Congressional candidates to cut loose from Bob Dole and press voters to maintain a Republican majority and deny a re-elected President Clinton a ''blank check.''

title: Reporter Wins Court Case
description: In 1993, Michael Moore, then a reporter at The Cranbury Press, a weekly, wrote a series of articles detailing charges of sexual harassment and fiscal mismanagement by the Monroe Township police chief, Richard C. Garvey. In retaliation, the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey said in a lawsuit, the police staged a news blackout, refusing to give Mr. Moore any information.

title: F.B.I. Official to Plead Guilty to Destroying Files on 1992 Siege
description: A senior official at the Federal Bureau of Investigation has agreed to plead guilty to obstruction of justice for destroying an internal review of the deadly 1992 standoff on a remote Idaho mountainside, Federal officials said today.

title: Group of Leading Blacks Urges Campaign on AIDS Awareness
description: Warning of a worsening AIDS epidemic among minorities, black leaders from the worlds of government, academia, religion and medicine gathered today at Harvard University to urge blacks, who they said had been in denial about the crisis, to mount a campaign against the disease.

title: Cone's Arm and Backbone Give Yanks Life
description: David Cone gave the Yankees hope again tonight, hope that their October might still produce another frenzied finish in their favor and hope that they could still win the World Series.

title: Presenting the brew that wants to make Manchester famous.
description: A POPULAR, award-winning campaign for a British brew is being exported to America along with the product it's pitching.

title: Cone Pitches the Yankees To Victory Over the Braves
description: They didn't wait 15 years to go through a World Series without winning, so tonight the Yankees bounced back into contention for baseball's championship by stopping a blistering Braves hitting attack and figuring out ways to score against Atlanta's awesome pitchers.

title: Stevens Playing With Injury
description: Scott Stevens, the captain and spiritual leader of the Devils, revealed today that he had been playing with a great deal of pain in his right shoulder from a bone bruise he suffered on opening day in the victory over Detroit.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results yesterday misstated the winning New York Numbers entry for Monday in some editions. The correct number is 791, not 449.

title: Homeless Man Is Convicted in Firefighter's Death
description: A homeless man on parole for drug charges, who set a fire of animal fat to keep warm inside an abandoned building, was convicted of murder yesterday in the death of a Queens firefighter who entered the burning building to search for victims.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Director Faces Fight to Keep Job
description: OLLAN CASSELL, the longtime head of track and field in the United States who achieved a narrow victory in becoming executive director two years ago, has another fight on his hands to his preserve his job.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MIKE WALLACE is to be honored at the Waldorf-Astoria this evening, but not for his television accomplishments. Rather, he will receive the 1996 David Mahoney Prize from the Harvard Mahoney Neuroscience Institute at Harvard Medical School for his efforts to remove the stigma from depression. It is something he knows well.

title: U.S. Study Backs Implantable Insulin Device
description: AN electronic pump the size of a hockey puck can greatly improve the treatment of diabetes, researchers are reporting today in The Journal of the American Medical Association. Surgically implanted under the skin and programmed to release insulin into the abdominal cavity, the pump frees patients from having to give themselves shots several times a day to lower the high levels of blood sugar that are the hallmark of the disease.

title: Manhattan Is Chosen For Offices By Publisher
description: The Addison-Wesley Longman Publishing Company has leased 58,206 square feet at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, a 1.1-million-square-foot office building between 46th and 47th Streets.

title: Let Driver Have Sabbath Off, Court Tells Transit Authority
description: The Transit Authority should have done more to give a bus driver who is a Seventh-day Adventist time off on Saturday to observe the sabbath, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: Baltic Minority Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Troubleshooter Discovers Big Trouble From Allies on Cuba
description: Two months ago, President Clinton handed a top Commerce Department official, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the knotty task of placating America's trading partners infuriated by a new law that punishes certain foreign companies doing business in Cuba. On his first diplomatic shuttle abroad, he was pelted with eggs in Mexico.

title: Fox's Familiar Faces At Play in No Ted Zone
description: Media world-conspiracy theorists believe that Fox is purposely not showing Ted Turner, the Braves' owner, during World Series telecasts. The truth is, Fox is not ignoring him. How can anyone ignore Ted? Not with Ted insulting Rupert Murdoch, Fox's owner, at every turn these days in their continuing blood feud over why Time Warner (which now owns Turner Broadcasting) refused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's entreaty to put the Fox News Channel on its cable system.

title: For the Farming Life Now, Who'll Give Tuppence?
description: The six-axle rigs lumbered past the brick entrance to the Bridgwater Livestock Market as the sun took the shudder out of the dewy West Country morning.

title: Mahler Paired With Mozart
description: Many composers have professed a love for Mozart, but Mahler went further than most. As a conductor, he did much to move Mozart's operas toward the center of the repertory. In his Fourth Symphony, Mahler set the pattern for the 20th-century habit of Mozartean neo-Classicism. Even on his deathbed, he was heard to repeat Mozart's name obsessively. It's appropriate, then, that the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra paired the Mahler Fourth with Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 24 in a concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: Hamilton Out For 3-4 Weeks
description: The Giants, who have been having trouble winning games when healthy, were dealt a blow yesterday when Keith Hamilton, their right defensive tackle, had arthroscopic surgery to remove torn cartilage from his left knee.

title: So Many Rules, So Little Time
description: THERE is a certain kind of woman who is given to long, tousled hair, sheer black panty hose and acting maddeningly elusive to every man, from the security guard at work to the cute guy eyeing her over his double latte at Starbucks.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: Peering Into the Past And Embracing the Present

title: Transit Pact Is Approved By Workers
description: New York City's transit workers have narrowly approved a labor contract that allows welfare recipients to be used to clean subways and buses, after repeated warnings that failure to make concessions could lead to thousands of layoffs.

title: Small Gain for U.S. Team In World Bridge Play
description: The United States open team improved its position slightly today at the World Bridge Championships, winning matches against India and Mauritius, but losing to the Netherlands.

title: Five From ABC Charged In Case of Secret Taping
description: John Stossel, an ABC News reporter, has been charged with illegally tape recording a Baltimore doctor without her permission for a report he was preparing for the news magazine ''20/20.''

title: Black-Bean Cakes and a Versatile Salsa
description: Now that beans are a staple in the diets of many Americans, they are fairly easy to find in supermarkets. But they are often loaded with sodium, so if you want to lower the salt content in this recipe, stock up on no-salt-added beans.

title: Credit Cone With a Save For the Series
description: JOE TORRE was convinced that David Cone was telling him the truth. Or maybe he just wanted David Cone to say he was fine. They were not necessarily the same.

title: Executive Changes
description: COMPUSERVE CORP., Columbus, Ohio, said its international president, Steven P. Stanbrook, was leaving to lead the European operations of S. C. Johnson & Son.

title: OCEAN REEF OFFERS $100 MILLION FOR JAN BELL MARKETING
description: Ocean Reef Management Inc., a closely held investment fund, made a friendly cash offer yesterday of about $100 million, or $4 a share, for Jan Bell Marketing Inc. Jan Bell, which distributes jewelry to wholesale clubs and mass merchandisers, said that its board would respond to the offer ''as promptly as practicable.'' Ocean Reef is a Miami-based investment fund. Jan Bell, which is based in Sunrise, Fla., lost $75.1 million last year on sales of $305.7 million. The company's stock rose 43.75 cents yesterday to $3.0625.

title: Who Says Women Can't Do This Job?
description: ONCE a month on the average over the last year, Smith & Wollensky, a steakhouse on Third Avenue, has run a full-page advertisement in The New York Times, depicting some of its waiters and citing their long years of service. No waitresses appear.

title: Hevesi Says Cable Plan Apparently Violated City Charter
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that the Giuliani administration apparently violated the City Charter when it tried to put a new 24-hour news station started by Rupert Murdoch on a city-run cable channel.

title: A Million Channels and Nothing On
description: It's time to grapple with all the negative advertising, name-calling and attempts to change the system. I'm not talking about the Presidential campaign, but about a much more colorful and significant brawl: the cable news wars.

title: Big Fund Manager Acquired in Italy
description: Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. of Italy said yesterday that it had paid 325 billion lire ($213 million) to acquire Prime Gestioni S.p.A., a fund management company controlled by Fiat S.p.A., and to increase its stake in Prime Augusta Vita S.p.A., the life insurance subsidiary of Prime Gestioni, to 40 percent from 18 percent.

title: Rivals With Bold Visions for London
description: University classmates and work associates 30 years ago, professional rivals and competing celebrities now, Norman Foster and Richard Rogers have become the two most famous architects in London by building just about everywhere else.

title: Bosnia Municipal Elections Face New Postponement as Serbs Balk
description: Municipal elections in Bosnia will be postponed for the second time, at least until the spring, because the Bosnian Serbs are clinging to their decision to boycott the vote, international officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: ''At Halloween, some of our deepest fears are brought out from under the bed and confronted, but kind of in a playful way. The fact that people enjoy it doesn't mean it's not an important thing.''

title: An Endangered Species: Rock Clubs in New York
description: New York City may be one of the cultural capitals of the world, but it's not always easy to present culture here. Rock clubs in particular find that, even as competitors like the Academy and Roseland are being converted to other uses, staying in business is a daily challenge.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Whitman Unveils Plan To Overhaul Welfare
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed legislation yesterday to overhaul New Jersey's welfare program, including a $150 million increase in spending for support services to help move welfare recipients into the workplace. The Governor said the money would come from a variety of sources, among them closing local welfare offices, tougher enforcement of child support laws and additional Federal aid. Mrs. Whitman described her proposal as softening some of the harshest provisions in the new Federal welfare law for the state's 110,000 families and 30,000 individuals dependent on welfare benefits.

title: Hope for Hebron Turns U.S. Aide Around
description: Instead of boarding his midnight plane home on Monday night, Dennis Ross, the American peace mediator, made a last-minute decision en route to the airport to stay in Israel after learning that Israelis and Palestinians had made significant progress in talks on Hebron.

title: Free Rupert Murdoch!
description: How do New Yorkers pick a dog in this fight?

title: When Drug Treatment Is Better Than Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Ask Other Pilots About Storm Before Crash
description: To determine whether wind shear was a factor in the crash of a Delta Air Lines jet on Saturday at La Guardia Airport, investigators today began interviewing the crews of three planes that landed immediately ahead of it.

title: Jeter Tapes Wrist and Plays
description: Shortstop Derek Jeter, who bruised his left wrist after being hit with one of Greg Maddux's pitches in Game 2, had the wrist taped tonight and said: ''It's stiff, but it's nothing to worry about. We got to play.''

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: An Uncomprehending Attitude Behind Sexual Harassment

title: Westchester Hamlet Fears an Invasion by Starbucks
description: While other communities may gird themselves against the arrival of commercial behemoths like Home Depot or Price Club, here the enemy is relatively small, seemingly innocuous and even coveted in many corners of suburbia.

title: Nice Job by Glavine, But Nice Isn't Enough
description: Though he was a loser in the World Series for the first time since 1992, Tom Glavine said he was not disappointed by his performance tonight in Game 3.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: This Time, Braves Squander Chances
description: Andruw Jones knew the pitch was outside. He didn't need to see an instant replay or get confirmation from anyone on the bench. It should have been ball four, Jones insisted. But Tim Welke, an American League umpire, saw it differently.

title: Accounts
description: Mystic Coast and Country, North Stonington, Conn., to the Hughes Agency, Norwalk, Conn., to handle tourism advertising for the group, which represents 32 towns in southeastern Connecticut and western Rhode Island. The account, with billings estimated at $1 million, had been at O'Neal & Prelle, Hartford.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Day Off Is Hardly A Ranger Holiday
description: That cracking sound wasn't from a whip. It was made by the stick of Colin Campbell, the Ranger coach, when he slapped it in anger against the ice. And he shouted the word ''lazy,'' among others, to his players today at Playland Ice Casino.

title: Chirac and Israelis Irritated Over Visit
description: Exasperated by overbearing Israeli security during a tour of Jerusalem's crowded Old City today, President Jacques Chirac of France threatened at one point to cut short his already contentious visit.

title: Early Music Gets a Surge Of Energy And Money
description: It is the story of early music in New York writ small: The Gotham Early Music Foundation, starting its first season of concerts with three programs by the Tallis Scholars this week, found itself going head to head with at least one and possibly two games of the World Series, tonight and tomorrow. The appearance of the Yankees in the series maximized the distraction for New Yorkers, although no one named Gotham could very well complain about that. As the final touch, a northeaster forced a rescheduling of series games, thus threatening a clean sweep of Gotham nights, beginning on Monday.

title: RANGE IS EXPANDED IN FEDERAL SEARCH FOR VICTIMS OF GAS
description: The Pentagon said today that it would notify 20,000 veterans of the 1991 gulf war -- four times the number previously announced -- that they might have been exposed to nerve gas and blistering agents when a battalion of American combat engineers blew up an Iraqi ammunition depot that was later determined to have contained chemical weapons.

title: It's the Season of Ghosts, Goblins and Green
description: There is plenty of candy. There are pumpkins painted or plain, real or pre-carved plastic. There are costume kits -- cats and bunnies, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole.

title: Robinson to Miss Start of Season
description: DAVID ROBINSON will be out of the San Antonio Spurs' lineup up for as long as a month because of a strained lower back, General Manager GREGG POPOVICH said yesterday. The All-Star center will spend the next week undergoing rehabilitation at the Kerlan-Jobe Clinic in Los Angeles and could miss the Spurs' first 10 regular-season games.

title: Olivetti to Sue Former Executive
description: Olivetti S.p.A. said yesterday that it would seek damages of 100 billion lire ($62 million) from its former chief operating officer, Renzo Francesconi, for saying that the company's losses were worse than reported.

title: Way Down South In the Land of Cliches
description: The Civil War cliches hummed through the balmy October air like Minie balls (Cliche No. 1) as the Yankees stumbled bleeding into Atlanta for Game 3 of the World Series tonight. The North-South witticisms do not fit, really, since there are as many Yankees -- and people from even more distant lands -- in Atlanta as there are sons and daughters of the South, (Cliche No. 2) but it is fun for people here to pretend.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: Behind Hardened Hearts, A Fiery Spirit

title: Netscape Revenue Quadruples in Quarter
description: Declaring it has made significant inroads into the corporate software market, the Netscape Communications Corporation said yesterday that revenue quadrupled in the third quarter as it reported earnings that were slightly higher than estimates.

title: BEHAVIORAL HEALTHCARE ADDS PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS
description: Community Psychiatric Centers said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its psychiatric operations in the United States to the Behavioral Healthcare Corporation for between $130 million and $165 million. Community Psychiatric, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev., said the price would include $60 million in cash and Behavioral Healthcare stock and stock equivalents valued at $70 million to $105 million. After the transaction is completed, Behavioral Healthcare of Nashville would have 38 hospitals and 4 residential treatment centers in 18 states and Puerto Rico.

title: Whitman Proposes Aid to Help Welfare Recipients Work
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed legislation today to overhaul the state's welfare program by shifting about $150 million in spending to child care, transportation, job placement and other support services to help move welfare recipients into the workplace.

title: Rookie's Road to Receptions Is a Slow One
description: Early in the season, Amani Toomer was told that he was the Giants rookie designated to bring doughnuts for the veterans the following morning. Toomer scrambled to make it happen, but as a result he arrived at an 8 A.M. team meeting at 8:03. His coaches were not happy, and he was fined.

title: No Need for Singapore to Follow U.S. Lockstep
description: To the Editor:

title: Frail, Strong and Dance Incarnate
description: ALVIN AILEY

title: Cathay Pacific and Swissair plan to test an airborne A.T.M. that will exchange currencies.
description: DESPITE the space squeeze aloft, cabins on international flights may soon have in-flight A.T.M.-type machines that dispense foreign currencies at exchange rates comparable to those in airports.

title: Police Officer's Gun Is Used in Suicide
description: A rookie police officer assigned to Harlem was suspended without pay yesterday after a bartender committed suicide with the officer's handgun, police officials said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Military and Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: These Potatoes Aren't Mashed, Baked or Fried
description: VODKA, the diminutive of voda, meaning water in Russian, is supposed to have originated in that country in around the 14th century. Although vodka is usually made from grain, the notion persists that it is made from potatoes, probably because potatoes were occasionally substituted when grain was scarce.

title: New Englanders Cleaning Up After 3 Days of Downpours
description: Three days of torrential rains across New England unleashed widespread flooding, leaving at least 120,000 people around Maine's largest city without water and stranding dozens of people in shelters.

title: DURACELL BUYS A SOUTH KOREAN BATTERY BRAND
description: Duracell International Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Sunpower, a South Korean battery brand, and related assets from the STC Corporation for 90 billion won, or $109 million. Duracell, which is based in Bethel, Conn., expects the acquisition to increase its share of the South Korean consumer battery market to about 45 percent from 9 percent. STC, based in Seoul, South Korea, has a 36 percent market share. Duracell would market both Duracell brand and Sunpower brand batteries in South Korea. Alkaline batteries sold in South Korea under the Duracell brand name would be imported.

title: Officer Charged With Sale Of Secrets to Drug Gangs
description: A New York City police officer was arrested yesterday and charged with supplying confidential information, including names of witnesses and informants, to a violent crack-cocaine gang based on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: Adelphi Panel Estimates Severance Payout
description: Raising new questions about the compensation Adelphi University has given its president, the head of a state panel said yesterday that the president would get $2.7 million in severance, sabbatical and pension payments if he serves out his contract to the year 2001.

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Milken Accepts Longer Probation
description: Michael R. Milken has agreed to a six-month extension of his probation while the Securities and Exchange Commission continues to investigate whether he has violated a prohibition against involvement with securities.

title: A Candidate For Congress, Sin Ingles
description: ''YO escribo y leo el ingles perfectamente,'' Carlos Munoz said with a confident wave of the arm. ''El unico problema es para hablar.''

title: Health Costs Pose Problems For Millions, A Study Finds
description: A new study by researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health says that 31 percent of Americans were without health insurance or had difficulty getting or paying for medical care at some time in the last year.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Act on Indonesia
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole Tax Plan Would Shelter Some Gains
description: Bob Dole has added a potentially far-reaching and controversial element to his economic package, promising that he would act immediately to exempt from capital gains taxes any inflation-induced increase in the value of land, homes, businesses, stocks or other assets.

title: Less State School Aid Seen
description: When inflation and enrollment increases are taken into account, most school districts will experience a loss in state aid under the $4.2 billion school financing plan developed by the Whitman administration, an independent policy research group said yesterday.

title: Threat to Veto Anti-U.S. Effort Is Seen as a Retreat From Maastricht : Danes Upset EU's Unity on Cuba Trade
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union's attempt to defend itself from U.S. sanctions on companies that trade with Cuba has suffered a potentially fatal setback from a legal quarrel that also has broader implications for European integration, EU officials said Tuesday.

title: Pages to Entice the Most Jaded Cook
description: AMONG this season's new cookbooks is ''The Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Cookbook'' by Mary Hale and Chris Miller (Citadel Press, $12.95). Some will undoubtedly find it useful. But my problem is chronic cookbook fatigue syndrome, the best remedy for which may be to ignore cookbooks and just order Chinese food.

title: Williams Is Hitting Again, and Nobody's Hitting Lloyd
description: The Yankees finally got to perform a victory dance in the World Series after defeating the Atlanta Braves, 5-2, tonight.

title: Doctor Details Teen-Ager's Injuries in Darien Rape Trial
description: A gynecologist testified today that the 16-year-old who said she was raped by Alex Kelly 10 years ago was injured and terrified after what the doctor called ''her night of horror.''

title: Tomba Injured in Spill
description: ALBERTO TOMBA, the world and Olympic ski champion, fell in a training run yesterday on the Tonale glacier in Italy, bruising his left knee and spraining a wrist. He should be back on the slopes in a month, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. (AP)

title: McCann-Erickson Has Virginia Office
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide said yesterday that it had opened an office in Arlington, Va., that would focus on handling the retail portion of the USAir Inc. account. In a consolidation in July, McCann-Erickson, which had handled the corporate portion of the account, was also awarded the retail portion, formerly at Earle Palmer Brown in Bethesda, Md.

title: Ferrer Renews Campaign to Keep the Yankees in the Bronx
description: The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, renewed his call yesterday for the Yankees to stay in the Bronx instead of moving to Manhattan, saying that an enhanced Yankee Stadium would save hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars.

title: Sorting Out Medicare
description: Democratic political candidates have accused their Republican opponents of proposing to cut health benefits for the elderly by hundreds of billions of dollars. The Republicans yell foul, contending that they are not cutting Medicare, only slowing its growth, and that the Democrats are distorting the truth.

title: INSIDE
description: Turnaround in Mideast Talks

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORP., New Haven, said it planned to acquire the remaining 63.5 percent of the Woodbury Telephone Co. it does not already own for $30 million in stock.

title: Salomon Reports Surprising Earnings Drop of Nearly 60%
description: Salomon Inc., which seems to have a habit of surprising Wall Street every three months, did so again yesterday, reporting earnings for the third quarter that were much lower than expected.

title: G.M., Union Set Accord In Canada
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Canadian Automobile Workers union tentatively agreed today on a new three-year labor contract, settling a 20-day strike that closed assembly plants and parts factories across Ontario and Quebec and, in a ripple effect, idled nearly 20,000 workers in the United States and Mexico.

title: He Is Not Exactly Cigar, But Then Again, Who Is?
description: A 7-year-old gelding who hasn't raced in more than a year and who hasn't won in three years created a news media sideshow at Woodbine Racetrack this morning after his trainer said he would run the horse in the $2 million Breeders' Cup Turf on Saturday if he could raise the $20,000 entry fee.

title: Wine Talk
description: ACCORDING to the latest issue of Esquire, one of this year's trendy wines is ''old vine zinfandel.''

title: California wine makers' talents turn to olive oil.
description: CALIFORNIA, which was once better known for its olives than for its grapes, is reclaiming its heritage. A number of new olive oils are being made, and although they don't match the very best oils from Europe, many of them are quite good.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Sabatini to Announce End To Her Career Tomorrow
description: Argentina's finest tennis female export, Gabriela Sabatini, initially hailed as the rival most likely to challenge Steffi Graf for dominance of their sport, is expected to announce her retirement tomorrow morning at Madison Square Garden.

title: Virtualizing Virtually Everything (Even a Dog)
description: ''Scientific American Frontiers'' begins its new season by sending Alan Alda, its affable explorer, into the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's celebrated Media Lab. There he finds all manner of virtual reality, including a virtual dog and a virtual hamster. If you are not impressed by the significance of what the young computer whizzes are up to, that probably betrays a want of virtual imagination.

title: Putting the emphasis on assisted living with M.S.
description: A TENTH person with multiple sclerosis recently used the services of Dr. Jack Kevorkian. Ten of the 41 people whom the Michigan doctor has helped to commit suicide have chosen death over trying to live with the disabilities that can accompany multiple sclerosis. The publicity each case has received, say some people who believe living with the disease can almost always be productive and satisfying, is sending the wrong message: a message of hopelessness and helplessness.

title: Faith Meets Complexity in Renaissance Venice
description: Renaissance church music may seem either too elevated or too dusty, depending on one's point of view, to be the heart of a thriving cottage industry, but Peter Phillips has shown that the commercial rewards of this vast repertory can match its artistic ones. With the Tallis Scholars, the English a cappella ensemble he started in 1973, he has systematically revived composers whose names fill history texts but whose music is not well known. He started Gimell Records, in 1981, to document his group's performances, and a Gimell publishing imprint for his scholarly writings.

title: N.C.A.A. Effort to Raise Academic Standards Leaves Many Top Students on Sidelines
description: With a 3.9 grade point average in high school and admission to the highly selective Air Force Academy, Chris Rohe isn't exactly anyone's stereotype of the dumb jock sliding through school while he majors in football.

title: Wang Li, 75, an Architect of the Cultural Revolution, Dies
description: Wang Li, one of the most fervent radicals of China's Cultural Revolution, who helped Mao Zedong overthrow many of his rivals in the Communist Party leadership before Mao turned on him and imprisoned him, died on Monday. He was 75.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: MACERICH ACQUIRES THE VALLEY VIEW CENTER IN DALLAS
description: The Macerich Company, a real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it had bought the Valley View Center mall in Dallas for $85.5 million. The identity of the seller was not disclosed. Macerich, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., said the 1.6-million-square-foot mall had total annual sales of more than $230 million. With the acquisition, Macerich owns 18 malls and 3 community centers.

title: Lowest Night Series Rating Is Enough to Place Fox First
description: There was bad news and good news for Fox's broadcast of Game 2 of the Yankees-Braves World Series. It generated the smallest Nielsen rating ever in prime time for the fall classic, but it won Monday night for the network.

title: NEW YORK ZONING AGAINST SEX SHOPS IS UPHELD AS FAIR
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice upheld the new city ordinance intended to restrict X-rated businesses yesterday, denying a request from store owners to block the law, which takes effect on Saturday.

title: Torricelli Addresses Cuban-Americans On Union City Visit
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli criticized his Republican opponent in the United States Senate race today for failing to back a Federal law against drunken driving by teen-agers and also campaigned in New Jersey's large Cuban-American community, making an appearance with an influential Miami-based exile leader who has drawn criticism for intimidating opponents.

title: Thurmond's Robust Legend Shields Him at 93
description: Some 300 townsfolk had gathered for Strom Thurmond Appreciation Day at Strom Thurmond High School here in the Senator's hometown, just off Exit 5 of the Strom Thurmond Highway.

title: Women's N.B.A. Takes First Big Step
description: Sheryl Swoopes and Rebecca Lobo faced a medium-sized contingent of microphones and note pads yesterday at the Official All-Star Cafe in Times Square. Swoopes and Lobo, two high-profile members of the United States women's basketball team, were the first two players to sign with the Women's National Basketball Association. The league, with eight as-yet-undisclosed N.B.A. clubs sponsoring teams, will begin play on June 21, 1997.

title: Game 3 TV Rating Highest
description: The Yankees' 5-2 victory over the Braves Tuesday night in Game 3 of the World Series generated a 17.5 Nielsen for the Fox network, its highest rating in the Series so far, but below the 20.0 for the same game a year ago on ABC.

title: Vote of Support On Tobacco Guidelines
description: The North American members of Worldwide Partners, a group of independent agencies, have voted to support proposed voluntary guidelines to regulate the advertising and marketing of tobacco products to minors.

title: Race and the Death Penalty
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court appointed a special master yesterday to study data compiled by the court's administrative staff showing that race is likely to be a factor in a death penalty verdict. After completion of the review by Richard S. Cohen, a retired Appellate Division judge, the court will consider whether race played a role in the death sentence for Donald Loftin, a black man who was convicted of killing a Lawrenceville gas station attendant during a 1992 robbery, said Bob Seidenstein, a spokesman for the court. Last month, the court canceled a scheduled hearing on the impact of race on juries after the defendant in that case, Joseph Harris, collapsed in his prison cell and died.

title: Ex-Mayor Indicted in Biloxi Killings
description: The mob-style killings of a respected City Councilwoman and her judge-husband have haunted people here for nearly 10 years, unwelcome reminders that this Gulf Coast casino boomtown was not so long ago a vice haven, a nest of illegal gambling and protection rackets.

title: Curacao Celebrates
description: Magda Rafael thought the local sports bar might be too small to watch the newest hero of Willamsted, Curacao, play in the World Series. So the island's sports commissioner invited the country to the stadium.
