title: Nothing Special Read Into Game 5 by Smoltz
description: Even though it will be the last game ever at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium, and possibly his last game in an Atlanta Braves uniform, John Smoltz said he isn't thinking about the additional significance of Game 5 of the World Series tonight.

title: Trends: Lean, Clean, But Clearly Not Mean
description: A new style is struggling to be born at High Point as about 2,300 furniture makers trundle out their new goods for the 70,000 buyers, editors and designers attending the International Home Furnishings Market, which ends on Friday.

title: Who's the Man? Tiger Woods Is the Man
description: In the front row of the parking lot outside the Tudor clubhouse at Southern Hills Country Club, the future of the PGA Tour could be read on the signs. Placards marking side by side spaces were lettered ''Tiger Woods'' and ''Rules.''

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Setting Limits for Children
description: To The Home Section:

title: Kenyans Enter City Race
description: MOSES TANUI and EZEKIEL BITOK, the 1-2 finishers in this year's Boston Marathon, will lead a powerful Kenyan contingent in the Nov. 3 New York City Marathon. Another Kenyan, COSMAS NDETI, a three-time winner of the Boston Marathon and third in this year's race, is also entered. (AP)

title: DU PONT (E.I.) DE NEMOURS & CO.(DD,N)
description: The Du Pont Company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 17 percent on the strength of its oil business and solid sales of some chemicals.

title: Hungry for a Cigarette? Have a Salad Instead
description: LEAVE it to the British artist Damien Hirst, he of the cows cut in half and suspended in tanks of formaldehyde and spectral heads made of wax and blood, to create equally visceral dishes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 9 about American Brands' planned spinoff of its British tobacco business misidentified the company that agreed in 1994 to indemnify American Brands against potential lawsuits. The agreement, as part of the sale of another tobacco unit, the American Tobacco Company, was made by the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company, not B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. of Britain. Brown & Williamson is a subsidiary of B.A.T.

title: Najibullah's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI PLANS VENTURE WITH SYLVAN LEARNING
description: The MCI Communications Corporation plans to announce today that it will invest $10 million in a ''distance learning'' partnership with Sylvan Learning Systems Inc., which offers tutoring services to schoolchildren and administers standardized educational tests over computer networks. Sylvan executives said the new operation, Caliber Learning Network, would deliver university courses and corporate training to adults at 50 interactive-video centers across the nation by the end of next year. In exchange for a 20 percent stake in the new venture, MCI will also guarantee $20 million in financing, said Douglas L. Becker, president of Sylvan, which is based in Columbia, Md.

title: Plan to Let Nature Rule Worries Investors and Homeowners
description: Picture this scenario of life along the New Jersey coast in 50 years: The Atlantic Ocean is about eight inches higher than it is now and several yards farther inland. The storms that batter the shoreline are far more destructive. And houses now on the most vulnerable parts of the coast are flooded.

title: Honoring a Man of Music With (What Else?) Music
description: In his first 90 years, Joseph Machlis played the piano, taught music, translated 16 opera librettos and wrote six novels and the best-selling music-appreciation textbook of all time.

title: The New Face of Europe's Far Right
description: Austria's far-right Freedom Party continued its troubling electoral climb in voting earlier this month. Confounding predictions that it had reached the natural limits of its support, the Freedom Party pulled within striking distance of the country's two mainstream parties in elections for the European Parliament and did almost as well in Vienna's municipal elections. If it makes further gains in the next parliamentary election, the party may get a chance to form a government.

title: SHARES OF CYBERMEDIA RISE 30% IN FIRST TRADING
description: The shares of Cybermedia Inc. closed almost 30 percent above their offering price yesterday in their first day of trading. The company makes software that solves computer problems. Its stock closed at $20.75. Cybermedia, based in Santa Monica, Calif., sold 2.5 million shares at an offering price of $16 each, to raise $40 million. It had been expected to sell two million shares at $11 to $13 each. The sale represents a 22 percent stake in the company. Cybermedia's products allow PC users to diagnose and solve computer problems without the help of technical support personnel. The company has sold more than one million copies of its First Aid software.

title: DOLE ASKS PEROT TO QUIT CAMPAIGN AND ENDORSE HIM
description: In the latest sign of Bob Dole's struggle to overcome an increasingly dire electoral picture, his campaign manager met late today with Ross Perot to try to persuade the Texas billionaire to abandon his third-party bid for the White House and throw his support to Mr. Dole.

title: Fabrics spun from cork, steel and (gasp) polyester.
description: THE story of this year's crop of new fabrics is the story of odd marriages. Given the evidence seen at Design New York, a three-day, trade-only home furnishings fair that closed on Oct. 10, these unions have a promising future.

title: Price of Heating Oil Declines As Worry Over Supply Eases
description: Heating oil prices retreated yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as a surge in refinery production helped swell inventories in the Northeast. On other markets, coffee prices rallied.

title: Conservation Woes
description: To The Home Section:

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Craftsman of Corporate Culture
description: Wall Street was unenthusiastic today about AT&T's appointment of John R. Walter, the chairman of R. R. Donnelley & Sons, as its new president and future chief, citing in part Mr. Walter's lack of experience in telecommunications.

title: Thermador Names A New Agency
description: The Thermador unit of the Masco Corporation, which makes premium-priced appliances, said yesterday that it had selected Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., to handle its account, with billings estimated at $2 million to $4 million. The account had been handled by the Ross Roy Communications unit of the Omnicom Group in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., which resigned after eight months to focus on its Chrysler Corporation accounts.

title: On Patrol to Help Those Who Cannot Help Themselves
description: EVERY Thursday, Mavis Owen makes a four-hour journey from floor to floor of the Florence Nightingale Health Center, at Third Avenue and 97th Street. Offering a smile, a wave, a touch on the arm, a ready ear, she is a sunburst in the lives of the frail and elderly residents. But when she sees or hears or just plain senses something wrong, the smile vanishes, her eyes narrow and she marches determinedly toward the nearest aide or nursing station. The staff at Florence Nightingale has learned to pay heed. Her concerns carry the force of law.

title: A Blue Line Forms in Queens to Salute a Fallen Comrade
description: In a Queens neighborhood of plain brick buildings and well-tended sidewalks, 12,000 police officers stood motionless yesterday, block after block after block, their white-gloved hands at their sides, their chins held resolutely high.

title: Tyson Selling Beef Plants
description: Tyson Foods Inc. said this week that it would sell four beef-processing plants to management of its Gorges/Quick-to-Fix unit, under Tyson's plan to focus more on poultry. Terms were not disclosed. Tyson said the plants, which are in Harlingen and Garland, Tex., and in Sioux Center and Orange City, Iowa, employ about 1,200 people.

title: No Headline
description: ''People say, you know, he didn't like black people. But he knows I'm 100 percent black and he sure did pay me respect. You have to praise the bridge that carries you across.''

title: Steinbrenner Cracks a Smile
description: No hairs were out of place, no extra lines were across his forehead and no wrinkles were in George Steinbrenner's blue blazer. But that was after the Yankees had miraculously rebounded from a 6-0 deficit to shock the Braves, 8-6, in Game 4. That was when Steinbrenner finally managed to relax and exhale.

title: Police Commander Suspended in Bronx
description: The commander of a Bronx police precinct has been removed from his post while the department investigates allegations that he manipulated crime statistics to exaggerate his precinct's drop in crime, police officials said yesterday.

title: 4 Win Prizes for Latin American Reporting
description: Four newspaper journalists -- two from the United States and one each from Mexico and Costa Rica -- have won the 1996 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes from Columbia University for distinguished reporting on Latin American affairs.

title: 49ers to Start Young
description: STEVE YOUNG will start Sunday despite continuing problems with a groin strain, and the San Francisco 49ers yesterday signed GINO TORRETTA to bolster their injury-shaken quarterback corps.

title: A Warrior Architect Wrestles His Demons
description: ONCE a week around nightfall, just as sensory overload and burnout set in, Douglas Cardinal leaves his office near the Mall carrying only a bundle of sweet grass and sage. He drives across the Potomac River, past the chaste white-columned mansions of senators, to an inconspicuous, turtle-shape structure he has built in a dense wood by a stream.

title: Clinton Praises Welfare Bill In a Conservative Region
description: In the continuing battle for the nation's fourth-largest state, President Clinton touted his welfare policies in this conservative region of Florida today, a morning after wooing Cuban-Americans at a late-night visit to Miami's Little Havana.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Flowerless Vines

title: C. Woodruff, 74, A Leader in Labor And Women's Issues
description: Constance Woodruff, who was active in labor and women's issues and was a Democratic Party stalwart, died on Saturday at St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark. She was 74 and lived in West Orange, N.J.

title: Officials Say Disputed Rule Might Have Saved Jet
description: Twenty-four years ago, the Federal Aviation Administration proposed requiring airlines to use a technique already in place on some military aircraft to prevent fuel-tank explosions -- a process that might have prevented the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, according to Federal officials investigating the crash.

title: Calendar: Sale, Talks And Tours
description: Crafts on Park Avenue

title: AT&T, in Flux, Goes Far Afield To Find Leader
description: The AT&T Corporation reached far outside its world of telephone wires yesterday to name John R. Walter, chairman of the commercial printing giant R. R. Donnelley & Sons, as its president and future corporate leader.

title: Smits Is Still Not Ready
description: RIK SMITS hasn't recovered from Sept. 8 foot surgery and the Indiana Pacers' coach, LARRY BROWN, isn't counting on having the 7-foot-4-inch center available to start the season on Nov. 1. ''I have no idea,'' Brown said yesterday in response to a question about when Smits would be able to play. Smits had surgery on both feet and still has not worked out. (AP)

title: Pier Is Losing a Sculpture
description: How's this for an art-world rarity? A public sculpture that no one wants removed.

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: In the Clutch, Grammar Saves the Poem
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivalry at Philharmonic
description: To the Editor:

title: Joyce Theater Buys Dia Dance Space in SoHo
description: The Dia Center for the Arts building at 155 Mercer Street, one of the city's most important homes for new dance, has been bought by the Joyce Theater for $1.5 million. The building, just south of Houston Street, has been renamed the Joyce SoHo. The acquisition was announced yesterday at a news conference at the downtown theater.

title: Tougher Tax Assessment on Restaurant Tips Is Rejected
description: In a major victory for owners of the nation's 375,000 restaurants, a court with nationwide jurisdiction has struck down a technique by the Internal Revenue Service for assessing taxes that the service says has contributed to a sharp jump in reporting of tips.

title: Voters Facing A Record Year For Initiatives
description: With state legislators increasingly trying to avoid voting on issues like taxes, term limits, campaign finance and tort reform, voters in 20 states will decide 90 citizens' initiatives on Election Day, making 1996 a possible banner year for this form of end-run governance, particularly in California and much of the rest of the West.

title: Deli Ticket Offer
description: The Second Avenue Delicatessen in New York City made an offer earlier in the week through a newspaper advertisement that anyone bringing in a ticket stub from one of the Yankees' winning Series games would get a free one-pound salami.

title: Some Fancied Horses On Outside Looking In
description: The post-position draw today for the seven Breeders' Cup races left some horses marooned for Saturday's card and set the stage for a blistering early pace in the $1 million Sprint.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday about a symposium on food and agriculture sponsored by the American Institute of Wine and Food misstated the day of the event. It is Saturday, not tomorrow, from 8 A.M. to 2 P.M., at the French Culinary Institute, 462 Broadway (at Grand Street). Tickets, which include lunch, cost $50; the reservation number is (212) 447-0456.

title: Man Is Sentenced in Attacks in Queens
description: A 27-year-old Queens man who attacked 11 women after ambushing them in apartment hallways and elevators was sentenced in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday to 20 to 40 years in prison.

title: Borg Bankruptcy Sought
description: Creditors of the former Swedish tennis star BJORN BORG said yesterday that they were seeking to have Borg declared personally bankrupt.

title: Zimmer Spotlights Eyeglasses Factory As a Success Story
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican, took his campaign for the United States Senate to South Jersey today, stopping at two businesses to meet with employees and to show his support for small but thriving companies.

title: Enter Simon, Blowing His Own Horn
description: REWRITES

title: Many Will Gain by Education Tax-Credit Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: WCI STEEL PLANS TO RETURN TO PRIVATE OWNERSHIP
description: WCI Steel Inc. said yesterday that its board had approved a proposal to revert to private ownership in a transaction that could be worth as much as $55 million. The plan was proposed earlier this month by the closely held Renco Group, which owns 84 percent of WCI's common stock. Renco offered to buy the remaining 16 percent of WCI, an maker of flat-rolled steel based in Warren, Ohio, for $10 a share in a offer to its shareholders. WCI's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $9.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Renco owned WCI as a closely held company until its initial public offering in 1994.

title: With the Palestinians, Chirac Scores a Hit
description: With flags and fanfare, President Jacques Chirac of France today became the first head of state to address the Palestinian legislative council, treating the Palestinians to a rare feast of support and succor.

title: In Milwaukee, School Choice With Caution
description: JAMES SONNENBERG, a school principal in Milwaukee's sad inner city, has the grim look of a man who is purposefully holding up a crumbling wall and knows that the odds are against him. He is an advocate of public education in a city at the center of the country's restless experimentation with school choice. Gritty, otherwise unremarkable Milwaukee has vouchers, charter schools and privately financed scholarships for parochial education, the idea Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has in mind for New York.

title: Norfolk Starts Bidding War For Conrail
description: Opening a multibillion-dollar bidding war to be the dominant rail freight company east of the Mississippi, the Norfolk Southern Corporation offered yesterday to pay $9.15 billion for Conrail Inc., topping last week's offer for the railroad from CSX Inc. by more than $1 billion.

title: Chinese Growth At 9.6% a Year
description: China's economy grew at an annual rate of 9.6 percent in the first nine months of the year as rising inventories and the arrival of foreign capital masked sluggish demand.

title: Slower Revenue Growth In Quarter at WPP
description: WPP Group P.L.C., the world's largest advertising and marketing company, said yesterday that its third quarter revenue rose 8.1 percent, a slower rate of growth than earlier in the year.

title: Esiason Fades Back and Falls on the Jets
description: Boomer Esiason said today that he had bittersweet memories of the Jets and sharp feelings for Coach Rich Kotite. They were triggered as he contemplated watching his former team on Sunday from the Cardinals' sideline.

title: WABAN PLANS TO SPIN OFF B J's WHOLESALE CLUB
description: Waban Inc. said yesterday that it planned to spin off B J's Wholesale Club, separating the profitable warehouse stores from the lagging Home Base home-improvement chain. The spinoff to shareholders would create a publicly traded company called B J's Wholesale Club Inc. Waban, based in Natick, Mass. plans to change its name to Home Base Inc. B J's has about $2.7 billion in annual sales and operating income of $95.4 million. Under the deal, Waban shareholders will receive one share of B J's Wholesale Club for each Waban share. Waban's stock rose $3.375, or 14 percent, to $27.25.

title: Bayonne in Ocean Liner Plan
description: If this ship comes in, it will be a doozy. A New York company trying to build the world's biggest ocean liner wants to berth it during the warm weather at Bayonne's soon-to-be-decommissioned Military Ocean Terminal. Today, the World City Corporation will present to the city's Base Re-Use Commission the awesome prospect of the America World City, a 21-story-high, quarter-mile-long, 6,200-passenger floating resort and conference center that is a billion-dollar Federal loan guarantee away from reality.

title: $505 Million St. Jude Deal For Maker of Defibrillators
description: St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that its Pacesetter subsidiary would acquire Ventritex Inc. in a stock swap valued at $505 million. Ventritex, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is a leading maker of implantable heart defibrillators, which are small devices that deliver a jolt of electricity to stabilize a racing heart.

title: A Regional Troupe Nurtured to a New Height
description: The pickings have been unusually slim on the ballet scene this fall. But the Pacific Northwest Ballet from Seattle, which made its Manhattan debut on Tuesday night at City Center, would stand out in the richest of seasons.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the third-quarter results of the Netscape Communications Corporation misstated the company's revenue. It was $100 million; the $23.3 million figure represented the revenue a year earlier.

title: Fox Finally Puts an End To the Owner Blackout
description: All of Atlanta breathed a sigh of relief during Game 4 of the World Series when, at 9:08 last night, Fox Sports deigned to display the visage of Ted Turner, the Braves' owner; his wife, Jane Fonda, and Gerald Levin, the chairman of Time Warner, putatively Turner's boss these days. Not a word was mentioned by the Fox announcers, but Fox had clearly lifted the No Ted Zone in effect since Game 1. Ted reappeared 201 minutes later, smirking in the 10th inning after the Yankees took the lead by 8-6, which was the final score.

title: Stopping Sanders Is Job One For Giants
description: Barry Sanders human? Can't be. But the Detroit running back, destined for the Hall of Fame, is having a mediocre season. At least for him.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Life is too full not to select your friends,'' FLEUR COWLES proclaimed on Wednesday evening as she rose to respond to toasts at a dinner given in her honor by one of the select, W. RANDALL JONES, the founder and chief executive of Worth magazine. ''Those I care about, I care very much about, but there is not time for anybody else.''

title: Former Culbro Official Convicted of Fraud
description: A former executive of the Culbro Corporation, the New York-based cigar maker, has been convicted of Federal mail fraud charges stemming from a fake-invoicing scheme that cost Culbro nearly $1 million.

title: Transactions
description: Auto Racing

title: Vote Yes on the Bond Act
description: In 1990 New Yorkers narrowly defeated a proposed bond act providing $2 billion in long-term capital to preserve open space and otherwise enhance New York State's environment. The voters will have a chance to rectify that error on Nov. 5. This year's ballot includes a proposal that would allow the state to sell $1.75 billion in bonds for many of the same projects that were left unfunded six years ago. New Yorkers, who have approved nine other environmental bond acts in this century alone, can honor their long tradition of stewardship by voting yes.

title: POP
description: Traditional Thai Repertory: Its Rules and Its Freedoms

title: Western Wildfires Near Record Season
description: The fires ravaging Southern California's bone dry suburbs are providing a blazing finale to the nation's worst wildfire season since 1952.

title: INSIDE
description: Chirac and Palestinians

title: Okla. State Coach Resigns
description: As much as he still loves college baseball and coaching, GARY WARD's back won't let him. Ward, 56, resigned yesterday after 19 years and 953 victories at Oklahoma State, saying his ailing back had become too much of a burden.

title: After the Storm, Still No Calm
description: BARELY bloodied and always unbowed, Dr. Joycelyn Elders can still tell a good story on herself. The former Surgeon General, who was forced to resign after saying masturbation ''is part of human sexuality and perhaps should be taught,'' sat at her kitchen table here recalling a recent trip to the grocery store.

title: Seahawks, Chiefs Fined
description: Ten Seattle Seahawks and seven Kansas City Chiefs were fined a total of $73,000 by the National Football League for skirmishes in last Thursday night's game between the teams. The N.F.L. said yesterday that COREY HARRIS and DEAN WELLS of Seattle were fined $5,000 each for unnecessary roughness and that WINSTON MOSS was assessed $5,000 for fighting. MARCUS ALLEN of the Chiefs was fined $5,000 for fighting and CHRIS PENN $5,000 for unnecessary roughness. (AP)

title: Jones Copying Jones
description: The Game 1 hero, Andruw Jones, showed up for tonight's game with his uniform pants legs pulled up to the knees and several inches of blue socks showing, much like Braves third baseman Chipper Jones. The 19-year-old outfielder's explanation was simple: ''My pants with the long legs are dirty.''

title: After Setbacks, DiCarlo Presses Drive for Votes
description: It was daybreak yesterday and State Senator Robert J. DiCarlo had already spent more than an hour shaking hands at a subway station, urging the bleary-eyed and the barely responsive to vote for him in the three-way race for the 23d District seat.

title: Kitsch, Funk and Show Biz From Phish
description: Bluegrass topped by a klezmer tune, mock-classical counterpoint dissolving into free-form a cappella vocals, pop lounge songs and light funk, blues guitar licks and bombastic rock vamps -- Phish's concert at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday had all that and more in nearly three hours of benignly virtuosic music.

title: The Yankees Survive Their $20 Million Man
description: IT has come to this in the age of ludicrous sports salaries. As a last resort, with the World Series in danger of slipping away, Joe Torre was forced to start a pitcher who is being paid $20 million for four seasons -- and the Yankees managed to survive his woeful game.

title: A Pregnancy Hormone Is Found to Reduce an AIDS Cancer
description: The purplish skin tumors of Kaposi's sarcoma, the most common form of cancer among people with AIDS, often yielded to injections of a hormone produced in pregnancy, according to preliminary findings from a small study.

title: THOMAS H. LEE EQUITY FUND TO BUY SYRATECH
description: A fund affiliated with the Boston financier Thomas H. Lee said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Syratech Corporation, a household-products maker, for about $281 million. The Thomas H. Lee Equity Fund III L.P. plans to pay $32 a share for Syratech, based in East Boston, Mass., which makes gifts, silverware and Farberware pots and pans. The stock jumped $4.875, or 18.6 percent, to $31.125. Syratech, which had revenues last year of $169.5 million, has been on an acquisition spree. Recent purchases include Farberware; the Silvestri unit of FFSC Inc., which distributes ornaments and other gifts, and C. J. Vander Ltd., a silverware maker.

title: POP
description: Who Believes in Romance?

title: Arlene Wanderman, Food Promoter, 60
description: Arlene Wanderman, an editor and public relations executive who was the American spokeswoman for the International Olive Oil Council, died on Monday at Beth Israel North Hospital. She was 60 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Working Overtime, Just Like the Big Guys
description: A once-invisible rule was on display last weekend, after weeks of some vague understanding that major college football teams would no longer settle for tie scores. It wasn't the first time there had been overtime games at the Division I-A level since the rule was put in place this season, but the previous outcomes were either obscure or limited in their impact.

title: Almost Tragic
description: The only real question for Bob Dole now is not whether he can win California or save the House.

title: Asterix in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte H. Dinger, 66, Collector of Carousel Horses, Dies
description: Charlotte H. Dinger, a New Jersey housewife who a paid a chance visit to a Philadelphia antiques shop in 1972 and walked out with the foundation of an unlikely collection and an even less likely career, died on Saturday at a hospital near her home in Morristown, N.J. She was 66, and known as the nation's leading collector and foremost authority on antique carved horses and other carousel art.

title: Saints Put Venturi at Helm
description: The New Orleans Saints' new coach is RICK VENTURI. Venturi, the team's linebackers coach, was appointed interim head coach yesterday, two days after JIM MORA's abrupt resignation and one day after another candidate rejected the job.

title: A Setback For Perelman Affects Tactic On Mergers
description: The Delaware Supreme Court, an important jurisdiction in business law, has handed down a ruling that legal experts say is likely to put a damper on two-step mergers, in which an acquirer first gains control of a company and then forces a merger.

title: Mr. Murdoch's Rage
description: In the annals of temper tantrums, it would be hard to match Rupert Murdoch's fit over being shut out of Time Warner cable television in New York City.

title: Former Basketball Star Charged in Murder
description: Richie Adams, a former collegiate basketball star who was drafted for the pros, was arrested last night and charged with murdering a 14-year-old girl whose badly beaten body was discovered a floor below Mr. Adams's apartment in the South Bronx earlier this month.

title: J. Lyndon Shanley, 86, Expert on Thoreau
description: J. Lyndon Shanley, a professor emeritus of English at Northwestern University and a specialist in the writings of Henry David Thoreau, died on Tuesday at the Wagner Health Center in Evanston, Ill. He was 86.

title: Woman's Life of Protesting Ends in a Suicide of Flames
description: Kathleen Chang was an eccentric to some and a valiant voice for social justice to others, but she was hard to ignore: in the summer, she wore a bikini to her protests, in the winter, leotards. Sometimes it was a suit of faux marijuana to grab attention for the one-woman political demonstrations she staged for 15 years on the University of Pennsylvania campus.

title: ABC Official to Head Disney Syndication Unit
description: Walter C. Liss Jr., who has managed WABC, ABC's flagship television station in New York, for 10 years, was promoted yesterday to be chairman of Buena Vista Television, the television syndication arm of ABC's parent corporation, the Walt Disney Company.

title: Discrimination May Affect Risk of High Blood Pressure in Blacks
description: The risk of high blood pressure among blacks appears to be affected by experiences with racial discrimination and whether people challenge unfair treatment, researchers said today.

title: U.S. Archives Describe Contents of Nazi Hoard
description: In the waning days of World War II, United States soldiers found a large cache of art and gold hidden in German salt mines, including dental fillings apparently ripped from the mouths of Holocaust victims, according to a recently declassified Government document.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a quarterly loss reported by the Digital Equipment Corporation misstated the percentage drop in the company's stock price on Tuesday. It was 16 percent, not 23.

title: Cable Concern's Shares Slide
description: The shares of Tele-Communications Inc. reached their lowest point in more than four years today amid concern that rising expenses will weaken the cable TV company's cash flow and lower its debt rating.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP., Seal Beach, Calif., which is in the aerospace, electronic and automotive industries, acquired Autarky Auto Products, a leading supplier of window regulators in India. Terms were not disclosed.

title: GEAC COMPUTER TO BUY DUN & BRADSTREET SOFTWARE UNIT
description: The Geac Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's software unit for $191 million. Geac, based in Markam, Ontario, said it would pay $150 million cash and give Dun & Bradstreet a $41.25 million note. Dun & Bradstreet Software, based in Atlanta, offers financial, human resources, manufacturing and other business-related computer applications. The unit has annual revenue of about $325 million. The deal supersedes an earlier one to sell the unit to Bain Capital Inc. for $160 million in cash and $50 million in preferred stock. The sale of the software company is part of the parent company's plan to split itself into three publicly traded entities.

title: DEAN WITTER, DISCOVER & CO. (DWD,N)
description: Dean Witter, Discover & Company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 9 percent, because of gains in its securities and credit operations.

title: Going, Going, Gone: Where's The Baby?
description: WHEN the Bauhaus and avant-garde furniture cache assembled over the last 30 years by Torsten Brohan, a German businessman, goes on the block at Sotheby's in London on Nov. 1, even modernists who think they have seen it all will probably be surprised.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a caption yesterday about the visit of President Jacques Chirac of France to the Muslim Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City misstated his reaction afterward. During the visit, he did angrily protest what he saw as excessive security measures by Israel, but he did not later apologize for his anger. As the accompanying article noted, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel apologized to Mr. Chirac.

title: Outlook Good On Treating Lyme Disease
description: A new study on the treatment of Lyme disease offers reassurance for parents: infected children seem to do just fine with the standard therapy, two to four weeks of oral antibiotics.

title: Megastore Plan Advances
description: The New York City Planning Commission passed Mayor Giuliani's plan to allow warehouse-style stores in manufacturing areas. But it could face a tougher fight in the City Council. Page B1.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Another Designer Is Dusted Off
description: LAST year, it was Samuel Marx. This summer, James Mont. So, who is the latest obscurity being reclaimed from American design's dustbin? Tommi Parzinger, who believed that artists should create everyday objects for ''the man with the normal income.''

title: Harte-Hanks Buying Marketing Company
description: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. in San Antonio said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Marketing Communications Inc. in Kansas City, Mo., a data base marketing services company, for about $33 million in cash and short-term notes. Larry Hawks, 41, will continue as president of Marketing Communications, which has 300 employees and estimated revenue of $28 million from clients like the American Home Products Corporation and the Frigidaire Company unit of White Consolidated Industries.

title: Bridge
description: Almost at the midpoint of qualifying play in the world team championships here, only one of the two United States teams seems likely to qualify for playoffs beginning Tuesday.

title: Dole Plans $4 Million in California Ads
description: Planning a huge shift of resources in the last two weeks of the campaign, Dole officials say they will spend $4 million on advertising in California, praising Bob Dole for his honesty and his tax plan while accusing President Clinton of lying and of failing to halt illegal immigration.

title: In the Clutch, Grammar Saves the Poem
description: To the Editor:

title: Destitute Ex-Contras Demand U.S. Aid
description: After the leftist Sandinista Government was voted out of office in 1990, more of the American-backed anti-Sandinista fighters known as contras settled here than in any other place in Nicaragua. Most are destitute, and many are crippled -- their limbs, sight or overall health destroyed by a decade of civil war.

title: More Area Codes Planned
description: Faced with the prospect of the 201 and 908 area codes running out of numbers by next year, the Board of Public Utilities voted yesterday to split the calling regions and create two new area codes. More than four million customers will get new area codes when the change goes into effect next May. The new codes will be optional for six months and then mandatory beginning in November.

title: Learning to Rebuild South Africa, Brick by Brick
description: Isaac Makoko is building a brick wall. If it isn't straight, he will have to tear it down and begin again. If he gets it right, he has the pleasure of watching the next trainee dismantle it. It's easy -- his mortar is actually mud.

title: Ex-N.B.A. Draftee Is Charged In Murder of Teen-Age Girl
description: Richie Adams, a well-known former high school and collegiate basketball star, was arrested last night and charged with murdering a 14-year-old girl whose badly beaten body was discovered earlier this month in his South Bronx building.

title: New Finding Bolsters Mad-Cow Link to Humans
description: A British scientific team says it has strong evidence linking so-called mad cow disease, a deadly brain disease of cattle, to a similar disease in humans.

title: AT&T's Romancing of Its New President
description: One by one on the evening of Oct. 15, the AT&T Corporation's 13 directors slipped through the rotunda tearoom of the Pierre Hotel, down a narrow passage to two private rooms below. There, each met John R. Walter, the man they were about to hand a job that was, for the moment, both the best and the worst corporate America had to offer. In one room, they traded chitchat and talked with him individually, probing to see if this was really their man. Then each director adjourned to the room next door, where dinner and more talk with Mr. Walter, en masse, awaited.

title: Crew Agrees With Feldman On Charters For Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and the president of the city teachers' union, Sandra Feldman, said at a conference of educators and business leaders yesterday that they would support the establishment of charter schools, the innovative public schools that are granted autonomy in exchange for making a commitment to meet rigorous standards.

title: TELEPORT COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE EASTERN TELELOGIC
description: Teleport Communications Group agreed yesterday to buy the Eastern Telelogic Corporation, a local exchange carrier in Philadelphia, for $233 million. In the first of two steps, Eastern Telelogic will redeem the shares of its stock not held by Comcast CAP, a company in which the Comcast Corporation holds a 51 percent stake and Teleport holds a 49 percent share. Then, Teleport will swap 2.8 million of its class A shares for Comcast's 51 percent stake in Comcast CAP. Shares of Teleport rose 25 cents, to $23.875. Teleport, which provides businesses with direct links to long distance companies, also agreed to assume about $45 million of Eastern Telelogic debt.

title: Pursued Driver Kills Himself
description: A 19-year-old Maryland man driving a stolen car and being pursued by the Sayreville police on the Garden State Parkway fatally shot himself in the head yesterday after his car rear-ended another car at the Raritan Toll Plaza, police said.

title: Abrupt End To a Case Of Looted Treasures
description: A Federal judge in Sherman, Tex., yesterday dismissed on a technicality charges against two elderly Texans and their former lawyer that they had illegally conspired to sell priceless medieval treasures from the cathedral in Quedlinburg, Germany. The artworks had been stolen in the closing days of World War II in Europe.

title: Ukraine Walks Shaky Tightrope Between NATO and Russia
description: Caught between a beckoning West and a volatile Russia reluctant to let loose its former province, Ukraine finds itself at the heart of a strategic tug of war.

title: Wide Protests Seen Today In German Sick-Pay Dispute
description: IG Metall, Germany's largest union, said today that big rallies were planned nationwide on Thursday to protest possible cuts in sick pay, after the collapse of talks with employers aimed at resolving the matter.

title: The Dumbest Answers
description: On Oct. 15 Yasir Arafat told a widely telecast press conference that he wanted U.S. peacekeepers in Hebron. The Palestinian leader said he had told the Israelis: ''O.K., why not call upon the international presence with the participation of the American Army?'' An Israeli spokesman rejected the proposal as a ''non-starter.''

title: Economic Scene
description: SINCE August, Bob Dole has been trying to sell the virtues of ''supply side'' tax cuts to a skeptical public. Mr. Dole's call for ''a new Independence Day for the American taxpayer,'' it seems, has effectively been parried by President Clinton's warning that the Dole economic plan ''would blow a hole'' in the deficit.

title: Torre Sets Cool, Calm and Confident Tone
description: The Yankees, following the lead of their manager and spiritual leader, were emotional in the initial phases of the post-season.

title: The Movements of Earth and Water
description: Caryn Heilman stands out for her reserved yet piquant performing with the Paul Taylor Dance Company. Ms. Heilman's presence -- and some celestial singing by Mor Dior Bamba -- were high points of a program of choreography by Ms. Heilman and Nadine Helstroffer that was presented on Sunday night at the Taylor studio.

title: Girlfriend (Then and Now) of Suspect Testifies for the Defense in Darien Rape Case
description: Ten years ago, Amy Molitor was a high school girl from Darien when her boyfriend, Alex Kelly, was charged with raping another girl in the Molitor family's Jeep Wagoneer.

title: Why Character Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility to Refund $77 Million
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company agreed yesterday to refund $77.5 million that it had charged customers to cover costs associated with its out-of-commission Salem nuclear plants. If the State Board of Public Utilities approves the settlement the utility reached with the Division of the Ratepayer Advocate, its 1.9 million customers will get a 12.5 percent reduction in their January and February bills ($20 in all for residential customers).

title: MOLTEN METAL TECHNOLOGY PLANS STOCK REPURCHASE
description: Molten Metal Technology Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as two million shares, or 8.5 percent of its stock, which plunged 49 percent on Monday after it said the Department of Energy would give the company only $8 million of an expected $20 million to research the recycling of radioactive scrap metal. The drop pared $326 million from the company's market value. The waste processing company in Waltham, Mass., said it expected to complete the repurchase, worth about $26.8 million at yesterday's price, in a year. It has 23.5 million shares outstanding. Molten Metal stock rose $1.016, to $13.39, in trading of nearly 1.6 million shares.

title: Zoning Plan for Warehouse-Style Stores Is Approved and Sent to Council in Close Vote
description: A divided City Planning Commission approved Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to allow sprawling warehouse-style stores in manufacturing areas around the city yesterday. It rejected pleas that neighborhoods should have a larger voice in whether an individual store is appropriate for their area.

title: Swiss Used Nazi Victims' Money For War Payments, Files Reveal
description: The unclaimed accounts of presumed Holocaust victims were used to ease Switzerland's postwar compensation disputes with Poland and Hungary under secret agreements, according to documents made public today by a Swiss historian.

title: Nissan is changing the rules for car ads by rolling out entertaining spots using toy characters.
description: ROB SILTANEN, a creative director and copywriter at TBWA Chiat/Day, says he started out with the idea of remote control toy cars. Then he thought about live-action figures. And then one of those figures driving the car. An idea was born.

title: Two Sides List Views in Fight Over Cable TV
description: Continuing a fight over whether Rupert Murdoch's news channel will be seen in much of New York City, the Giuliani administration and Time Warner issued dueling legal briefs yesterday to bolster their stances on the legality of the Mayor's plan to show the channel on a cable station run by the city.

title: On This Night, Wohlers Can't Save Braves
description: Mark Wohlers is the surest thing the Braves have amid a suspect list of relievers in their bullpen. It's not uncommon for him to be mentioned in the same breath with the heralded starters Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine and John Smoltz. That's how much the Braves think of him.

title: An Architect Always Ready for His Close-Up
description: WHEN the architect Morris Lapidus set out to design a hotel, he thought in cinematic terms. ''I imagined myself the set designer for a movie producer who wanted to create a hotel that would make a tremendous impression on the viewers,'' he said.

title: Maidenform Unit Picks Blum/Herbstreith
description: Maidenform Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had named Blum/ Herbstreith in New York as the first agency to handle advertising for its Self Expressions brand of lingerie. Billings were estimated at $1 million. Manette Scheininger, the marketing vice president for Soft Expressions, said the decision came after a three-month review that also included five undisclosed agencies. Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York continues to handle advertising for the Maidenform brand of lingerie and intimate apparel.

title: Grace Bessay, 84; Fought Government For Cape Cod Shanty
description: Grace E. Bessay, who won a prolonged legal struggle to keep the Federal Government from ousting her from a two-room summer shanty on Cape Cod, died on Oct. 10 in Cambridge, Mass. where she had her main home for 50 years. She was 84.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Hi, I'm Bob, and I'll Be . . .

title: Mayor Warns Unruly Fans
description: Yankee fans had better learn to behave themselves when the World Series returns to New York on Saturday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani warned yesterday.

title: Shouts, Skates and Other Surrealities
description: The territory is familiar for the first third or so of ''La Tristeza Complice'' (''The Shared Sorrow''), presented by Les Ballets C. de la B. on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, where the company performs through Sunday. Dancers are ranged about an uninviting, prop-cluttered space that might be a factory or street-corner construction or the waiting room of a bus terminal or asylum. A mild-looking man shifts from playing the harmonica to ranting in apparent gibberish at the audience. From time to time, dancers roller-skate by, yell and assault one another. We are in that magically all-purpose theatrical setting known as the surreal real world.

title: History Puts a Sharp Focus on Afghans' Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: RHONE-POULENC RORER INC. (RPR,N)
description: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. reported a 19.5 percent increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday, despite a costly recall of a drug used to treat shock, trauma and burns. The biggest shareholder in the drug maker, which is based in Collegeville, Pa., is the French chemical giant Rhone-Poulenc S.A.

title: Rating Lowered On AT&T Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, a credit agency, yesterday lowered by one notch its rating on the AT&T Corporation's $9 billion in long-term debt, attributing the move to concern about increased competition, and expenses from its new wireless and local telephone services.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 16 about horse racing in Texas misstated the amounts of simulcast betting expected and realized at Lone Star Park. Officials expected $1.7 million a week, not a day, and the park is bringing in $3 million a week, not a day.

title: Willy-Nilly Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Long List of Evidence Is Cited as Case Against Simpson Opens
description: Blood, gloves, socks, shoes, fibers, hairs the lead lawyer in the civil suit against O. J. Simpson opened his case today with an encyclopedic list of physical evidence, including material never introduced by the unsuccessful prosecutors in last year's criminal trial.

title: For Yanks, Game Isn't Over Till They Win It in the 10th
description: It will be remembered as the most rewarding victory of the season. It will be remembered for the way the Yankees miraculously rallied from a 6-0 deficit to beat the Atlanta Braves, 8-6, with Game 4 of the World Series ending this morning in 10 memorable innings. Now it is a three-game series to determine the best team in the sport.

title: DIAMETRICS MEDICAL IS NEGOTIATING FOR PFIZER UNIT
description: Diametrics Medical Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating with Pfizer Inc. for the purchase of its Biomedical Sensors Ltd. unit for an undisclosed amount, but the company did not give further details. Pfizer's Biomedical Sensors, based in Britain, developed in-body systems for continuous monitoring of blood and tissue, Diametrics Medical said. The market for such products in the United States is estimated at about $360 million and is expected to grow to $630 million by 2000, the company, based in St. Paul, Minn., said.

title: Live and on Tape, the Capitals Rip the Rangers
description: The Washington Capitals brought the National Hockey League's worst record into Madison Square Garden last night and beat the Rangers with 60 minutes of intense effort and one significant officiating decision.

title: Polygram to Cut Jobs In a Revamping
description: The Dutch entertainment company Polygram N.V. said yesterday that it planned to cut about 400 jobs worldwide and charge $90 million against earnings in a revamping of its recorded-music business. The company, which employs 12,000 people over all and is a unit of Philips Electronics N.V., expects its 1996 operating earnings before the charge to be flat or slightly below 1995.

title: Yankees Are Puttin' On The Leyritz
description: WHETHER the Yankees or Braves win this World Series, last night's fourth game is the one that will be remembered and dissected in the years to come. And in all the bars now and to come.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KATHLEEN LANDIS won't have to contend with the sound of whirring blenders, clattering china or diners' conversations as she sings and plays the piano on Sunday evening.

title: Hearing a Conductor's Passion
description: Among the major conductors of recent decades, Colin Davis, who turned 69 last month, is the most enigmatic. His work has unquestionable strengths: commanding technique, keen intelligence and musical sensitivity. Yet his performances often have a quality of reserve that is at its best magisterial, and at its worst lethargic.

title: People
description: Patrick Pitcher, president and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide Canada, Toronto, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was named chief executive of Asian operations in Hong Kong, succeeding Peter Watkins, who is leaving for a job outside advertising.

title: Singapore Doesn't Claim to Be Model for Anyone
description: To the Editor:

title: The Queen of the Fillies Versus King of the Colts
description: Yanks Music, who already reigns as queen of the 3-year-old fillies in North America, drew a bead on an even grander target today when she was entered in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic against 13 colts, including Cigar.

title: UNISYS CORP. (UIS,N)
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it had made progress in the third quarter with its new business-unit structure, which it formed at the beginning of this year, with revenue up in each of the three divisions.

title: Volvo Operating Profit Off as Truck Sales Fall
description: Volvo A.B., Sweden's biggest vehicle maker, said yesterday that third-quarter operating profit plunged 98 percent as falling truck sales in the United States dragged the truck division to a loss.

title: Shares of SAP Fall On Quarterly Growth
description: Shares in Germany's high-flying software company SAP A.G. fell yesterday after the company reported weaker third-quarter growth and shaved its earnings estimates. SAP, the world's leading manufacturer of client-server business application software, cut its previous forecasts of 40 percent profit growth after reporting that growth in earnings and sales had slowed considerably in the third quarter.

title: Once an Empire
description: To the Editor:

title: Kurd Rivals In North Iraq Said to Agree To Cease-Fire
description: After nearly two weeks of attacks and counterattacks, the two Kurdish factions battling for supremacy in northern Iraq agreed to a cease-fire today, easing, at least for now, American fears that the renewed fighting could tempt Iraq into intervening in the Kurdish enclave again.

title: Wave of Strongmen Make West Africa Their Oyster
description: When State Department planners sat down to work out an African itinerary for Secretary of State Warren Christopher's first trip to the continent, seeking to play up news of positive change in each of Africa's regions below the Sahara, West Africa presented a special problem.

title: Kemp R. Niver, Cinematographer, 84
description: Kemp R. Niver, a cinematographer and film historian, died on Oct. 15 at the Country Villa Nursing Center in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Democrats Return Trafficker's $20,000 Gift
description: The Democratic National Committee has returned a $20,000 campaign contribution from Jorge Cabrera, a convicted drug trafficker serving a 19-year prison sentence here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T Names President And Market Cries Sell

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: An Anniversary Present Makes Its New York Debut

title: Unforgiving Spain Pursues Argentine Killers
description: Almost every day Esperanza Labrador needs to unlock her grief and rage by crying a little. Even though her husband and two sons were murdered 20 years ago, it has been hard for her to accept that they are dead and their killers are free. Then there are the words that haunt her from the day the Argentine military handed over two of the three bodies, ''This has been a regrettable mistake.'' The body of one son has never been found.

title: Pressure On Pettitte To Win An Edge
description: For seven innings Wednesday night, it seemed that the Yankees would have to turn to an old security blanket to assure that Game 5 of the World Series wouldn't be their last.

title: Pataki Vetoes Bill That Would Let Solar Panels Earn Credits on Energy Bills
description: Siding with the state's electricity industry, Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed legislation that would have allowed homeowners with solar panels on their roofs to send power back to their utility company and get credit on their electric bills.

title: Pension Parity
description: What's really going on with those deferred-compensation packages we've been reading about? You know, the plans that supposedly give top managers a big tax break?

title: Illinois Lawmaker Proves a Tough Target for G.O.P.
description: For nearly 50 years, since the Truman Administration, the voters of Illinois's Ninth Congressional District have been sending Sidney R. Yates to represent them in Washington, where he has been an unabashed liberal voice.

title: Caught Between 2 Systems, Mongolia Scrapes By
description: In the mornings, as the first rays of sunlight hit the abandoned coal plant that looms nearby like an oversized skeleton, Nangil scampers down into the open coal pits that puncture a broad plain of rolling grasslands, racing to claim a spot where she and her family can dig out small chunks of coal, sold at day's end for less than a penny a pound.

title: Caribbean Nations Find Little Profit in Aiding U.S. Drug War
description: Hoping for American gratitude and assistance, the English-speaking countries of the eastern Caribbean have in recent years devoted larger portions of their meager budgets to fighting drug trafficking. But now, to the dismay of many in the region, the United States is responding with a policy of economic retrenchment.

title: Stocks Slip in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 78.66 points, or 0.37 percent, to 21,003.49. On Wednesday, the Nikkei fell 41.53 points.

title: Torre Wins the Game of Cat and Mouse
description: Bobby Cox, the unflappable manager who has guided the Atlanta Braves into four of the last five World Series, should have quit while he was ahead. Well, he would like to have quit while he was ahead. But Cox threw bad relief pitching after good -- actually awful after outstanding -- and the Yankees shocked the Braves on Wednesday night and tied this World Series at two games each.

title: Nationalism Bites Back
description: The Chinese have an old saying: When you ride a tiger, it is hard to dismount. China is now riding the tiger of nationalism, and unless it soon realizes how damaging its actions are to its own interests, it may be too late to get off.

title: Disturbance in Florida Follows Shooting by Police
description: A crowd of more than 200 people here, enraged when a white police officer shot a black man to death after a traffic stop, burned buildings and cars and threw bricks and bottles for hours last night and early today.

title: Devils Find The Answers For a Victory
description: Jacques Lemaire kept looking for answers. The Devils' coach kept shuffling his lines, searching for the right combination of players to produce a goal. The Devils had created chance after chance, but had produced only one goal in just under 47 minutes and were locked in a 1-1 tie with the San Jose Sharks.

title: Inside Art
description: Need Rm; Never Mind Vu

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 9
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: John Family Recalls New York's Support
description: Travis John is a healthy 17-year-old who wants to play baseball in college. You would never know that 15 years ago, he fell 37 feet from a third-floor window in his family's vacation house in New Jersey, bounced off the fender of a car, swallowed his tongue, then lay in a coma for 17 days.

title: T.W.A. Chief Quits After Report of Loss
description: Jeffrey H. Erickson, widely credited with reviving the financial fortunes of Trans World Airlines Inc. and just as widely rebuked for his company's response to the crash of Flight 800 three months ago, abruptly announced his resignation as president and chief executive yesterday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Multiplicity

title: Torricelli Takes On Zimmer on Medicare
description: This is the latest 30-second television advertisement from the campaign of Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat, who is running against Representative Richard A. Zimmer, Republican, for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey:

title: People
description: * Jose Manuel Cubas, president and chief executive at Foote, Cone & Belding Latin America, Miami, a unit of True North Communications, was promoted to the new post of chairman. Scott Hollingsworth, senior vice president for the Andean Pact markets and Puerto Rico, was promoted to succeed Mr. Cubas.

title: USAir Will End Pacts With British Airways in March '97
description: The USAir Group Inc. said yesterday that it would end its code-sharing and frequent flier agreements with British Airways P.L.C., effective March 29, 1997, because of British Air's proposed broad marketing agreement with American Airlines.

title: Zaire Fighting Endangers Refugees, U.N. Says
description: Hundreds of thousands of Hutu refugees and Zairians fleeing fighting in eastern Zaire are threatened with hunger and epidemics, aid agencies say.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bronx Grand Jury Indicts Officer in Shooting Death
description: From the day Patrick Phelan died last January of a gunshot wound to the eye, many residents in the Norwood section of the Bronx openly scoffed at the Police Department's claim that the shooting was a suicide.

title: 37 Bids for Charter Schools
description: Thirty-seven groups have applied to form New Jersey's first publicly financed but privately operated charter schools, the State Education Department said yesterday. Of the applications, 21 were from urban communities, including 6 from Jersey City, where the public schools are under state control, said Peter Peretzman, a spokesman for the department.

title: Dassault Systemes Says Profit Rose 35%
description: Dassault Systemes S.A., a French developer of computer-aided design and engineering software, said yesterday that its profit rose 35.3 percent in the third quarter as it continued to see strong sales growth. Net income of 72.9 million French francs ($14.2 million), or 1.42 francs a share, in the period, was up from 53.9 million francs, or 1.05 francs a share, a year earlier.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Columbia

title: 'Soft Money' Far Outpaces Other Gifts in Presidential Race, U.S. Reports
description: Donations to political parties that go indirectly to the Presidential candidates have more than doubled from the last Presidential race and are the biggest source of financing in the current campaign, according to the latest Government campaign finance reports.

title: PEROT TURNS DOWN DOLE PLEA TO QUIT, CALLING IT 'WEIRD'
description: Ross Perot today dismissed Bob Dole's move to persuade him to withdraw from the Presidential race as ''weird and totally inconsequential,'' fanning an already heated debate about why Mr. Dole dispatched his campaign manager to try to win the Texan's endorsement.

title: Bob Dole's Lie
description: We shrug off many shady things that politicians do in election campaigns. But what about using a deliberate lie to attack an opponent? Have we become so coarsened in our politics that we no longer care about that?

title: Adding Flights to Outflank Rivals in Business Market
description: When American Airlines added another daily flight between Dallas/Fort Worth and Chicago this month, it was not exactly an aviation landmark. American already flew 26 round trips on that route every business day.

title: Home Video
description: Animated titles, most of them from Disney, continually cross the video scene, of course, but this month there are some twists, not to mention some head-to-head competition between a couple of Academy Award winners.

title: There's Something Verboten in Illyria
description: Illyria, that Shakespearean hotbed of thwarted desire and sexual dissimulation, is a brooding coastal landscape of mist-shrouded cliffs and Gothic revival architecture in Trevor Nunn's voluptuously atmospheric film version of ''Twelfth Night.'' Moping about in her castle, Olivia (Helena Bonham Carter), a beautiful bereaved countess mourning the recent deaths of her father and brother, hides her grief behind a heavy black veil. When she removes it, her hair is a mass of Aubrey Beardsley tendrils, her lips curled into a sullen pre-Raphaelite pout. As she throws her head back in an exaggerated gesture of romantic agony, one's first impulse is to run for the smelling salts.

title: Mystery, Aggression And Mating Rituals
description: Even among the typical smirks and knowing glances of those who surrounded her onstage in Pina Bausch's pieces at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the 1980's, Meryl Tankard stood out for her sassy sophistication.

title: A Culture Ignored Except for Its Icons
description: DAY after day, the minutiae of contemporary art in New York City are examined with avid, high-stakes attention. Tempests are stirred up in teapots, winners and losers pronounced. Meanwhile, whole cultures slip by unnoticed, as if they barely existed.

title: Dole's Harder Row
description: The Dole campaign's effort to have Ross Perot leave the Presidential race appears to have made things more difficult for Bob Dole. News Analysis, page A28.

title: Torricelli Focuses on Foe's Medicare Votes
description: Rep. Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, reached out for support from elderly voters today, attending a rally at a senior center here and releasing a new television advertisement attacking his opponent for voting to contain the growth of Medicare.

title: Compaq Shakes Up Its Top Management
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation has been known for having one of the most stable management teams in the volatile personal computer industry. Not anymore.

title: Corrections
description: The front-page part of an article about the funeral of a New York City police lieutenant was omitted from some New Jersey copies yesterday. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: 100 Days of Police Progress
description: The Newark police have seldom had much to brag about, but yesterday the new police director, Joseph J. Santiago, said he had made progress during his first 100 days. The police have been responding to calls for help up to 75 percent more quickly since he took office in July, Mr. Santiago said. In June, it took officers 128 minutes to respond to a call; by September, response time had dropped to 33 minutes, he said. Mr. Santiago attributed the improvement to the reassignment of more than 175 officers from desk jobs to street patrol and better maintenance.

title: Sandinistas Are Shaken By Election
description: Running as a revolutionary in 1990, with all the levers of state power at his disposal as the incumbent, Daniel Ortega Saavedra of the Sandinista National Liberation Front obtained 41 percent of the vote in presidential elections here. This week, after packaging himself as a European-style Social Democrat, he won just over 38 percent.

title: Brain Surgery for Armstrong
description: The top American cyclist, LANCE ARMSTRONG, who revealed earlier this month that he has testicular and abdominal cancer, underwent brain surgery to remove two lesions, according to his agent.

title: Zimmer Says Democrat's Vote Raised Prices
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer held up an 18-ounce jar of peanut butter today in a supermarket here and said it would cost 33 cents less if his Democratic opponent for United States Senator had voted to end price supports to peanut farmers this year.

title: Bridge Team's Hopes Fading
description: The United States women's team continues to play strongly in the world championships here, but the hopes of the open team are fading.

title: $20.4 Million for Gilkey In Four-Year Mets Deal
description: The Mets could not risk the possibility of losing outfielder Bernard Gilkey through free agency this winter. Not from a performance standpoint. Not from a public-relations standpoint.

title: Big Vote for Davey Johnson
description: DAVEY JOHNSON will be back to manage the Baltimore Orioles in 1997, even though he did some things the team's owner, PETER ANGELOS, did not like. Angelos said yesterday that he was annoyed by Johnson's tendency to criticize some players through the news media, and the owner wondered why the manager openly talked about shearing the $50 million player payroll. But he said Johnson would fulfill the second year of his three-year contract.

title: Funds Sought for State Dome
description: Corporations will be asked to shell out $2 million to help refurbish the dilapidated State House dome, and the state's First Husband, John Whitman, has been put in charge of the fund-raising campaign, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday. The Treasury Department will kick in another $10 million, the Governor said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Mr. Perot's Moment
description: In asking Ross Perot to drop out of the Presidential race and endorse the Republican ticket, Bob Dole has accomplished what many political experts thought was impossible this late in the election season. He has refocused attention on Mr. Perot.

title: Accounts
description: * United States Defense Department, Washington, to Bates U.S.A., New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., as the first agency to handle the Defense Reutilization and Marketing Service account. Bates already has the department's joint recruiting and advertising account. Billings were estimated at more than $8 million.

title: Sex-Shop Law Is Postponed By State Judge
description: A New York appellate judge issued an order yesterday postponing enforcement of the city's new law restricting X-rated businesses. The ruling gives sex shops at least two months more in business while they appeal a lower court decision that upheld the law.

title: Using Genes as a Clock, Study Traces Animal Life Back a Billion Years
description: New molecular research shows that the first simple forms of animal life, progenitors of creatures small and great, from beetles to humans, may have appeared on earth more than one billion years ago, about twice as early as once widely thought.

title: Pettitte's Arm Was Great, But His Glove Was Better
description: His manager said he wasn't Andy Pettitte on the mound in his last game, but to hear some of his teammates talk about him, he wasn't Andy Pettitte out there last night either.

title: Father of Accused Testifies in Rape Trial
description: Alex Kelly's father said today that his son denied an accusation of rape in the early-morning hours after he drove a 16-year-old girl home from a party in Darien a decade ago.

title: Podiatrists to Form Nationwide Union; A Reply to H.M.O.'s
description: With doctors struggling to cope with the sweeping changes brought about by managed care, associations representing most of the nation's podiatrists announced yesterday that they were forming the first nationwide labor union for doctors.

title: Whoopi Goldberg's Turn To Try a Gender Bender
description: If you're a star who is dying to explore the cross-dressed land of ''Tootsie,'' ''To Wong Foo'' and ''Mrs. Doubtfire,'' you had better choose an amusing character of the opposite sex to play. That's one of the lessons of ''The Associate,'' the movie in which Whoopi Goldberg finally takes the plunge into comic transvestism and misses the mark.

title: After 188 Days in Space, U.S. Astronaut Readjusts to Earth
description: Shortly after returning to Earth last month from an 188-day sojourn in space, Shannon W. Lucid said today, she briefly panicked about having lost her muscular strength.

title: U.S. Senate Race Is Latest in a Long Line of Rough New Jersey Campaigns
description: It is hand-wringing time in the race for the United States Senate in New Jersey.

title: The Madison Ave. Sandinista
description: You can blame it on packaging. The Daniel Ortega who was defeated in Nicaragua's presidential elections by the conservative former Mayor of Managua, Arnoldo Aleman, was the victim of an image makeover gone berserk.

title: Keep in Mind
description: HAUNTED CASTLE AND SIXTH ANNUAL HALLOWEEN PARADE AND PUMPKIN SAIL, both sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. The castle is open tomorrow, 1 to 4 P.M., at Belvedere Castle (midpark at 79th Street), Central Park, and is to feature Vit Horejs and his marionettes; a story hour and ''Bats in the Belvedere.'' Free. On Sunday, the annual pumpkin sail is at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street and Fifth Avenue, Central Park, and consists of a costume parade, a carved-pumpkin sail on the Harlem Meer (take your own pumpkin, under 10 pounds; it will not be returned), storytelling, treats and even Snoopy and Charlie Brown. Free, 3:30 to 6 P.M. Information (and number to call to register for the sail): (212) 860-1370.

title: Glorious Jottings of a Genius
description: HE rarely finished anything he started, he was frequently distracted by inconsequential minutiae, and he has vexed scholars for four centuries with his cryptic eccentricities. But Leonardo da Vinci embodied the very spirit of the Renaissance, and his brilliantly erratic career is the subject of a fascinating new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan.

title: Wrong Time to Expand NATO
description: Expanding NATO into Central and Eastern Europe may be a popular idea in the Midwest and other parts of the country with large numbers of ethnic voters. President Clinton told an audience in Detroit this week that he would press for the admission of some new NATO members by 1999. Bob Dole favors expansion by 1998.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Ukraine's relationship with Russia and NATO misspelled the surname of the Russian Ambassador to Ukraine. He is Yuri Dubinin, not Dobrinin.

title: Giants Want to Rework Contract With Hampton
description: Already feeling the squeeze from a salary cap that will leave them little money to shop for free agents or sign their own players, the Giants are now making and contemplating some very interesting moves that could affect them over the next several years.

title: Environmental Equity
description: To the Editor:

title: To Gingrich, Elections This Year Are Like 'Whitewater Canoeing'
description: Even Newt Gingrich has no clear idea how this election will turn out.

title: Who Needs Baseball? Apparently, Not NBC
description: Stop the baseball contract -- Don Ohlmeyer wants to get off. The president of NBC's West Coast division said the divisional and league playoff telecasts depressed prime-time ratings at the No. 1 network, disturbing the Must See TV juggernaut.

title: Braves Are Mookified In Farewell
description: HIS name should be on everybody's lips by now, the symbol of rash and painful unpredictability in the World Series. What happened to the Boston Red Sox in 1986 could be happening to the Atlanta Braves.

title: Deutsche Bank Says 9-Month Profit Rose 9%
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. said yesterday that its profit rose 9 percent in the first nine months of the year to 1.53 billion marks ($2.33 billion). Fourth-quarter results should be in line with those of the year so far, a spokesman for the bank said.

title: Smoltz's Feet Betray His Arm and His Bat
description: JOHN SMOLTZ'S pitches were fast. His bat was fast. But his feet weren't quite fast enough.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Stock Market Falls Again, Ending Below 6,000 Level
description: The stock market recorded its biggest loss in seven weeks yesterday as lower worldwide sales from the Procter & Gamble Company confirmed for some investors that companies will have a hard time matching profit expectations next year.

title: G.M. MAKES SOME PROGRESS IN TALKS WITH AUTO WORKERS
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union made slow progress in labor talks yesterday as G.M.'s Canadian workers began returning to factories after a 20-day strike. But the effects of the Canadian strike continued to ripple through G.M.'s United States operations. G.M. closed a small-car factory in Lordstown, Ohio, yesterday for as much as two weeks when it ran out of parts from Canada, and it is expected to close a large car factory in Flint, Mich., early next week. Each of the factories has about 5,000 workers. The Lordstown factory makes the Pontiac Sunfire and the Chevrolet Cavalier, which are in the highly competitive and generally unprofitable small-car segment of the market. The Flint factory makes the Pontiac Bonneville and the Buick LeSabre, for which G.M. has ample inventories. By closing these factories, G.M. can make sure that the first parts produced by the returning Canadian workers will go to factories making more profitable models.

title: Parole Reform Is Sought
description: The fatal shooting of a Gloucester County police officer by a biker who had just been released from a Pennsylvania prison and a killing spree by an Atlantic City parolee that resulted in seven deaths prompted a number of lawmakers to call for an overhaul of the parole system.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Disorders of All Kinds Plague Dole Campaign
description: Bob Dole took the stage in New Hampshire one Sunday afternoon to announce that his campaign was embarking on a new line of attack: it is time, Mr. Dole declared, to reform the campaign finance laws, principally by barring immigrants and corporations from writing checks to political candidates.

title: Yankees Have Ability to Play Like Two Teams Within a Team
description: Thanks to some adroit trades by General Manager Bob Watson and the deep pockets of the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees can boast of two teams within a team, each radiating equal candlepower.

title: Diner's Journal
description: It was just a few days old, but when I called Fred's to get a lunch reservation, the woman on the other end of the phone said she could take us only at 11 or 1:45.

title: Dancing With the Devil
description: From Washington comes word that the Democratic National Committee has returned a $20,000 campaign contribution from a convicted drug trafficker.

title: China Concedes Blood Serum Contained AIDS Virus
description: Earlier this year, without providing the health care system with a reason, China's Ministry of Public Health ordered thousands of state-run medical institutions to stop using a certain brand of a common blood product called serum albumin, which is produced by a military-run factory, and to destroy all remaining stocks.

title: President Shadows Dole as a Son of the South
description: President Clinton continued his can-do tour of the old Confederacy today, chasing Bob Dole from Alabama to Louisiana in support of Democratic Congressional candidates and trying to prove that when it comes to reclaiming Southern states from the Republicans, he is not just whistling ''Dixie.''

title: Steinbrenner Splits, But His Ghost Remains
description: George Steinbrenner returned to New York before Game 6 of the World Series, continuing his post-season trend of leaving cities just as the Yankees were about to play important games.

title: Pocketbook Issues Are Focus in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey race may be one of the most combative in the nation, but to followers of the state's political history, that should come as no surprise. Yesterday, both candidates gravitated toward economic issues.

title: In Africa With Ali and the Rope-a-Dope
description: Spirits are elusive.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Craft

title: Statoil of Norway Posts 42% Profit Rise
description: Statoil, Norway's state-owned oil company, said yesterday that its pretax profit jumped 42.4 percent in the third quarter as higher oil prices and wider refining margins offset a drop in chemical earnings. Statoil, based in Stavanger, said pretax profit in the quarter rose to 4.7 billion Norwegian kroner ($728 million) from 3.3 billion a year ago. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Pope Bolsters Church's Support For Scientific View of Evolution
description: Nearly a century and a half after Darwin's ''Origin of Species,'' Pope John Paul II has put the teaching authority of the Roman Catholic Church firmly behind the view that the human body may not have been the immediate creation of God, but is the product of a gradual process of evolution.

title: Asian Utility Sees Rival to Southern's Bid
description: Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd. said yesterday that another party might challenge the Southern Company's $2.7 billion bid. A bidding war may help shareholders of the power company -- including the biggest, Hopewell Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong -- land a higher price. Two weeks ago, Hopewell agreed to sell control of the power company to Southern, based in Atlanta.

title: Samuel Eisenstein, 83, Psychoanalyst-Psychiatrist
description: Samuel Eisenstein, a psychoanalyst and psychiatrist in Los Angeles and past president of the Southern California Psychoanalytic Institute, died on Oct. 14 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: In an Ohio County, the Issue Is Public Buses, Not the Presidential Race
description: The most compelling national issue that the people of Stark County face come Nov. 5 is not, ''Who will be President?'' (Bill Clinton is looking awfully strong in Stark County.) It is, ''Will there be any more public buses here?''

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some things never change. After an intensive two-month search for a slogan for The New York Times on the Web, the newspaper announced yesterday that it had chosen -- surprise, surprise -- ''All the News That's Fit to Print.''

title: Is It a Global Market for Campaign Gifts, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Mountains Of the Minuscule
