description: IF you've ever wondered just what Joseph Conrad's unfortunate Mr. Kurtz looked like when he muttered ''the horror, the horror,'' you might (believe it or not) check out the expression on Nancy Marchand's face when a certain piece of news is delivered in Tony Walton's revival of ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' which opened last night at the Irish Repertory Theater.

title: Vickrey's Zeal Remembered At Columbia Memorial Service
description: What excited William Vickrey the most when he won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science earlier this month was not the personal fame or fortune that came with the prize, but the platform it provided to sell his ideas about how economics can improve society.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood

title: Harold Hughes, Iowa Trucker Turned Politician, Dies at 74
description: Harold E. Hughes, a truck driver who went on to overcome alcoholism and become Governor of Iowa and a Senator, only to quit politics in the mid-1970's and work with alcoholics and religious groups, died yesterday at his home in Glendale, Ariz. He was 74 and moved to Arizona a decade ago.

title: HARNISCHFEGER DISMISSES 500 AT UNIT AND PLANS CHARGE
description: Harnischfeger Industries Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 500 jobs, or 7 percent of the work force, at its Beloit Corporation unit in an attempt to improve profitability at the maker of pulp and paper machinery. Harnischfeger said it would take a charge of up to $32 million, or about 65 cents to 70 cents a share, in the fourth quarter ending next Thursday to pay for the moves. Harnischfeger, based in Milwaukee, also makes mining and material handling equipment. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Harnischfeger rose 37.5 cents, to $39.50.

title: Year After Rabin Fell, Israel Is No Closer to Unity
description: At the spot where Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated last year, someone put up a homemade sign today, above the flowers and candles brought by crowds of Israelis who gathered to mark the Jewish calendar anniversary of the Prime Minister's death.

title: I.M.F. May Suspend Loan Over Russian Tax Evasion
description: Worried by Russia's persistent failure to collect the taxes it needs to pay the costs of governing, the International Monetary Fund is expected to suspend further disbursement of a crucial $10 billion loan, officials said today.

title: Nasdaq Stock Market Reports Drop in Uncovered Short Sales
description: The Nasdaq stock market reported yesterday that the short interest in Employee Solutions more than doubled in the month ended Oct. 9, to 6.7 million shares from 3.3 million. The stock ended that period at $18.375, and has kept rising since, to the point at which it now trades at about 50 times estimated earnings for this year.

title: Grissom Knows The Score: It's 'E-8'
description: ''E-8. E-8.'' That's how Marquis Grissom, the Braves' center fielder, put it in accepting the blame for his error in the fourth inning that led to the only run in the Yankees' 1-0 victory over the Braves tonight in Game 5 of the World Series.

title: Chief Resigns At Cordiant Unit
description: Compton Partners Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York said yesterday that George Guimaraes, its president and chief executive, had resigned after two years. Mr. Guimaraes, 52, said he would disclose his future plans within the next couple of weeks.

title: USG OFFERS $50 MILLION FOR REST OF CGC
description: The USG Corporation said yesterday that it would offer $66 million (Canadian), or $50 million (United States), to acquire all of the shares it does not already own in CGC Inc. USG is the nation's largest maker of gypsum wallboard and related products. CGC, a Canadian rival, said it had recommended that shareholders accept the offer. USG, which currently has a 76 percent stake in CGC, offered 11 Canadian dollars for each CGC share outstanding.

title: Giuliani Plans A New Effort For Arresting Of Fugitives
description: In an effort to round up hard-core criminals, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday a new push to apprehend thousands of fugitives who typically commit crimes after jumping bail or disregarding orders to appear in court.

title: Perot Sees Moral, Ethical and Criminal Problems for Clinton
description: In one of his sharpest attacks to date on President Clinton, Ross Perot today asserted that Mr. Clinton faced ''huge moral, ethical and criminal problems'' and predicted that a second term would be consumed by ''a second Watergate'' and ''a constitutional crisis'' in 1997.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Eraser

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Home for a Writer, but Not a Theater

title: Art in Review
description: Dawoud Bey

title: Venezuela, in Rare Austerity, Is Tempted by Oil Windfall
description: Venezuela is grappling with an enviable problem: what to do with $2.5 billion in unexpected oil wealth.

title: Labor Deal Hopes High After Meeting
description: As a deadlocked World Series reached the exciting stage of a fifth game, negotiators for baseball's owners and players appeared to shatter their two-and-a-half-year deadlock today and lay the groundwork for the labor peace that has eluded an industry long wracked by labor strife.

title: Barber Missing From Heisman Race
description: He has put up big numbers, he has taken down school records and he has a great nickname. So what doesn't Virginia tailback Atiim Kiambu (Tiki) Barber have? He doesn't have the Heisman Trophy -- or even a favored place in the discussion of the leading candidates for the job.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PERFORMANCE FOOD GROUP CO., Richmond, which distributes food and food related products, agreed to purchase the assets of McLane Food Service, of Temple, Tex., the food-service unit of McLane Co., which is owned by Wal-Mart Stores Inc., for $30 million in cash.

title: Morrison Facing a Setback
description: A bloody gash could stop the comeback of TOMMY MORRISON, but the heavyweight fighter who is infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, appeared confident yesterday as he announced his return to the ring for a bout in Japan.

title: Courts Clearing Way for Punitive Damages From Brokers
description: As a result of new rulings in New York State courts, investors who think they have been robbed by their brokers now appear free to seek punitive damages in arbitration, something the industry has bitterly fought.

title: In Atlanta Games, Yanks Sweep the Gold
description: The Yankees left New York on Monday night hoping they could rescue their season and at least usher the World Series back to Yankee Stadium this weekend. They felt listless and lethargic and knew they had an incredible task ahead of them against the defending champion Braves.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO.(PG, N)
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported a 9.3 percent profit increase yesterday, to a record $979 million, in the latest quarter despite a decline in worldwide sales.

title: No Headline
description: ''Fresh knowledge leads to recognition of the theory of evolution as more than just a hypothesis.''

title: Fans and Fanfare for Mikhail Gorbachev, Author
description: The tapes were rolling, the cameras were zooming and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, was preparing to discuss his newly released memoirs on national television yesterday when the makeup artist noticed a hint of shadow.

title: The Pentagon Tries to Kick the Habit
description: In an effort to cut down smoking among military personnel, the Pentagon wants to end discounted prices on tobacco products sold in military grocery stores. The tobacco lobby, and some members of Congress, complain that the Pentagon has not followed proper procedures. Whether it did or not, the Pentagon has the right idea.

title: No Short List of Reasons to Doubt C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Gender and the S.A.T.
description: To the Editor:

title: A Frustrated Dole Asks Why Some Voters Aren't
description: A seething Bob Dole issued a ''wake-up call'' to the nation today, warning that President Clinton did not reflect America's values and that the liberal media were protecting the ''disgrace'' of his Administration.

title: Restaurants
description: The review was already written when the call came: the chef was leaving.

title: On the Bumpy Road to Magic Healing
description: Why would a 16-year-old killer dying of a rare abdominal cancer take his oncologist hostage and go on a mad dash from Los Angeles to Arizona in search of a magic healing lake? And why would that doctor, after enduring his patient's relentless abuse, suddenly start to believe in that magic lake, embrace his captor like a brother and rob a hospital supply room to keep him alive?

title: Art in Review
description: 'Les Levine: Media Mind'

title: Leonard Is Coming Back So He Can 'Go Out as Me'
description: He will be a middle-aged middleweight. Sugar Ray Leonard pulled his George Foreman impersonation today and announced another comeback at the age of 40. His retina is attached, his opponent is handpicked and his entourage includes a 2-year-old: his granddaughter.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about John Stossel of ABC News and four others who have been charged with illegally taping an interview with a doctor misidentified the program on which the interview is to appear. It is part of a special report by Mr. Stossel, not yet scheduled; it is not for the ABC news magazine ''20/20.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Pope Shows How Faith And Evolution Coexist
description: Pope John Paul II's statement yesterday acknowledging that evolution is ''more than just a theory'' is unlikely to change significantly the teaching of evolution in Roman Catholic schools, where it is already a standard part of the curriculum.

title: Simpson Defense Opens With Scathing Portrait of His Ex-Wife
description: Besmirching the late Nicole Brown Simpson's image as criminal defense lawyers never did, O. J. Simpson's lead civil-suit lawyer portrayed her today as a party-hearty, heavy-drinking, troubled woman who had had an abortion and a string of lovers but was still helplessly hung up on Mr. Simpson.

title: For Children
description: Halloween in New York City is so widespread that you would have to be flying off on a broomstick to miss the goings-on.

title: Exploring the Dangers of Knowing Too Much
description: FORBIDDEN KNOWLEDGE

title: U.S. Must Hold China To Hong Kong Pledge
description: To the Editor:

title: Service Programs Are Promoted
description: A publishing company, an advertiser and a retailer are participating in separate programs aimed at helping the needy, teen-agers and children with H.I.V.

title: Unexplained Holes Remain in Fuller Genetic Map
description: Researchers creating detailed maps of the sequence of human genes have have found that in genes as well as in geography, things are not spread evenly in the landscape. Rather, some genes are packed into populous centers like cities, while others are dispersed across relative wildernesses.

title: TCI Strives To Ease Jitters Among Wary Cable Investors
description: When John C. Malone flew from Denver to Phoenix yesterday afternoon to speak to Wall Street analysts at a media conference sponsored by Bear, Stearns & Company, he could have brought along a full company of firefighters. The president of Tele-Communications Inc. needed to put out more than a few fires among the company's jittery shareholders.

title: Coach Wants Toughness From the Nice-Guy Knicks
description: The personality makeover is fine, Jeff Van Gundy insists. These Knicks seem to always get along. They have been polite and congenial, and respectful of their teammates less than a month after being together.

title: Mattress Maker Narrows Review
description: The Select Comfort Corporation in Minneapolis, which makes adjustable mattresses, has named three finalists in a review to choose its first agency. Harold Levine, a consultant in Westport, Conn., who is helping to manage the review, identified the finalists as Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York; Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, which is owned by Havas Advertising, and Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass. A decision is expected by late November. Select said its plans called for advertising spending of $15 million to $20 million.

title: Hall of Fame Selections
description: The shot-putter DALLAS LONG and the pole-vaulter DON BRAGG, Olympic gold medalists and world record-holders, were elected to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame yesterday in Indianapolis. Also voted in were two coaches, VERN WOLFE and CLEVE ABBOTT.

title: Medical Student Forced Into a Hospital Netherworld
description: In July, Leonard Drey got high marks as a senior medical student at Coney Island Hospital, treating patients with heart disease and AIDS.

title: Imperial Chemical Says Profit Fell 47%
description: Imperial Chemical Industries said yesterday that its profit before exceptional items and taxes fell 47.2 percent in the quarter on weaker prices for its products and high prices for crude oil. The company earned $:131 million ($208 million), on sales of $:2.67 billion in the three months ended Sept. 30. A year earlier the company earned $:248 million on sales of $:2.62 billion.

title: PATH Trains Streamlined
description: Starting Sunday, weekend PATH riders will no longer have to change trains at Grove Street to get from Hoboken to the World Trade Center, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. The new direct service, already offered on weekdays, will run every half hour from 6 to 9 A.M. and 9 P.M. to midnight, and every 15 minutes from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., said Gwen Williams, a Port Authority spokeswoman. The agency also said morning rush-hour express trains from Newark to the World Trade Center, offered on a trial basis for the last six months, would run permanently.

title: Don't Bar Legal Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: Cigar Again Facing A Two-Pronged Assault
description: Two months after Cigar and his 16-race winning streak were bushwacked by the California-based horse Dare and Go, they are back on stage for the return match. And two days before the rematch in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic, their two trainers were talking today like old combatants who share a certain history.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the third-quarter results of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation misstated the consensus earnings estimate of Wall Street analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. It was 55 cents a share. (The 63-cent figure is First Call's estimate for the fourth quarter.)

title: Jets Confront Biggest Task: Overcoming Mental Fatigue
description: Game in and game out the Jets must manufacture their own enthusiasm. In losing eight consecutive games, there have been few electric-charged moments. It is a major reason for their failure.

title: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES INC. (LU,N)
description: Capitalizing on its recent independence to make new deals with old competitors, Lucent Technologies Inc. posted strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, sending its shares to their highest price since trading began in them in April.

title: Undercover Policeman Is Shot By Colleague in Drug Search
description: An undercover police officer conducting a search in a dark, cavernous Brooklyn drug hideout was shot once in the chest on Wednesday by another officer responding to a robbery call at the same location. But the wounded officer's bulletproof vest saved his life, the police said yesterday.

title: Future Hazy For System To Guide Ship Traffic
description: A system for guiding oil tankers and other ship traffic in harbors around the country, deemed crucial after the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989, was deleted from the Federal budget last month, and experts say prospects for the system, on which the Coast Guard has spent $25 million, are uncertain.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Dip Below 6,000 In Biggest Loss in 7 Weeks

title: Former Jail Guard Convicted
description: Arnaldo Ortega, an inmate at the Hudson County Jail serving time for burglary, asked prison guards for a blanket. Instead, the guards at the jail, then situated in Jersey City, beat him to death with their fists and a fiberglass baton.

title: News Corp. to Cash In On Stake in B Sky B
description: The News Corporation disclosed a plan yesterday to mortgage part of its 40 percent stake in British Sky Broadcasting in a move to cash in on B Sky B's heady share price. The News Corporation plans to sell $1 billion of preferred securities in B Sky B, a satellite broadcaster. Under the plan, institutional investors could buy securities and warrants to buy ordinary shares or American depository shares in B Sky B.

title: GOLDMAN AGREES TO BUY LIBERTY INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT
description: Goldman, Sachs Group L.P. said yesterday that it would acquire Liberty Investment Management Inc. in the latest step to increase its asset management business. A person familiar with the deal said the price was $60 million in cash. Acquiring Liberty, a Tampa, Fla.-based money manager with about $5.4 billion in assets, mostly stocks, will bring Goldman's assets under management to about $90 billion. Goldman itself forecast in a report last year that a spate of mergers in the asset management industry would leave 20 to 25 companies, each with at least $150 billion under management, dominating the industry by the year 2000. Liberty was spun off from Raymond James Financial Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., in 1994 and manages stocks for United States-based institutional investors.

title: U.S. Delays Arms Delivery to Bosnia Over Aide's Ties to Iran
description: The United States has shipped to Croatia most of $100 million worth of tanks and other weapons intended for Bosnia's military, but is refusing to turn over the materiel until the Bosnian Government agrees to certain conditions, including the dismissal of a military official accused of having ties to Iran, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Sabatini, Lacking Competitive Fire, Calls It Quits at 26
description: She had talent, beauty and an uncommon athleticism that sent her into the top 10 of women's tennis at age 15 and kept her there for a decade. Had there been an award for congeniality, she would have won that as well. But Gabriela Sabatini didn't have everything, and the one championship ingredient she lacked, a hearty killer instinct, took its toll over the years and was ultimately responsible for her decision to retire from tennis at 26.

title: Science and the Native American Cosmos
description: To the Editor:

title: Woodstock: Old-Time New-Age Karma
description: BACK in the 1980's, I was walking down a street in Woodstock when a Volkswagen microbus pulled over and the scraggly haired driver asked, ''Can you tell me where the rock festival was?''

title: Boeing Profits Jump 13% in Quarter as Jet Orders Climb
description: The Boeing Company reported a 13 percent gain in third-quarter earnings yesterday, meeting most analysts' expectations, but its shares fell on concerns about profit margins as the company seeks to bolster production.

title: $25 and Under
description: Sex and Gender

title: Rangers Skate and Struggle for an Answer
description: A day after another defeat, Rangers Coach Colin Campbell's ire had not abated.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Delta Reports Strong Gain On Increase In Traffic
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that earnings increased 32 percent in its most recent quarter, continuing a season of strong earnings by the nation's largest air carriers.

title: Energy providers are beginning attempts to get warm and fuzzy.
description: CALIFORNIA consumers will be among the first in the nation to choose their power supplier when electric utilities are deregulated there beginning in 1998.

title: Ancients, Briefly Modern and Human
description: LUCKY for us, the Metropolitan Museum of Art seems to have worried that people might overlook the opening of its handsome ''New Amarna Galleries,'' proclaimed by a big banner at the front door. After all, the redesigned and reinstalled gallery, accompanied by a tiny study gallery, is little more than a drop in the bucket of the Met's vast Egyptian wing: it measures 1,100 square feet and features 63 objects from the 18th Dynasty, most of which have previously been on view.

title: Great News for Europe: A Cold and Rainy Cup
description: The English trainer John Gosden stood bravely against the morning chill at Woodbine today and was warmed by the weather. It was windy, teeth-chattering cold, and drizzling. Just like back home, which should help an already formidable European bloc in Saturday's Breeders' Cup races.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Could the Marx Brothers be speaking the language of love? Certainly a limited understanding of English was no impediment to romance at the first meeting in July of STANLEY BRECHNER and OKSANA KINKER at a performance of ''The Cocoanuts,'' the Off Broadway musical about the comedic brothers.

title: No Easy Explanations For Dole's Perot Gambit
description: Since early summer, the season of promise when political hopes bloom along with the roses, Bob Dole has been trying to do something -- anything -- to alter the shape of a Presidential campaign whose basic configuration has not changed since the end of the primary elections.

title: Maine Should Focus on Full Forest Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Won't Sweat It
description: Jimmy Key, the Yankees' starter for Game 6 on Saturday, said he was not daunted about pitching against Greg Maddux, the Braves' four-time Cy Young Award winner and the winner of Game 2.

title: Lehman And Singh Set Scene With a Tie
description: On the sort of day that might have inspired an oil by Renoir or Morisot, with shafts of sunlight breaking through fall leaves and bathing the Southern Hills Country Club in a sort of dreamy glow, Vijay Singh and Tom Lehman engaged in a little artistry of their own today.

title: When Lawyer and Co-op Board Clash
description: What happens when a seasoned real estate lawyer -- a man the trial judge called ''aggressive'' and ''savvy'' -- takes on his own co-op board?

title: New Times Square Tower Lures a Key Tenant
description: Adding the prestige of a major law firm to the renewed glamour of the Times Square area, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom has agreed to lease space in a new building to be constructed on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets.

title: Gulf War Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Tainted Blood in China

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Drug Gangs Accused Of Child Courier Use
description: Members of two Manhattan drug gangs that prosecutors said used children to transport heroin were charged yesterday with multiple counts of narcotic trafficking.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Yankees Notebook article yesterday about Chipper Jones, the Atlanta third baseman, misidentified the 1995 National League rookie of the year. He was Hideo Nomo of the Los Angeles Dodgers, not Jones.

title: Chiseling for Jewelry, Ending Up With Pastry
description: ''Palookaville,'' Alan Taylor's sly, loping comedy about three unemployed buddies who prove to be the most inept thieves ever to hack their way through a brick wall, is set in contemporary Jersey City. But the drab, working-class world they inhabit with surprisingly good cheer feels more like a small Italian town in the 1950's than a decaying industrial city of today.

title: Inmates Find Brief Escape in Rodeo Ring
description: Nick Nicholson dreamed of being a cowboy when he was a child in Walkill, N.Y. He had to kill a man in Louisiana to see that dream come true.

title: Promises Yield to Old-Fashioned Politics
description: Two months ago, Gov. William F. Weld and Senator John Kerry were widely lauded for their extraordinary agreement to limit spending in their fiercely competitive Senate race to $6.9 million apiece, of which no more than $5 million may be for paid advertising and no more than $500,000 may come from personal money.

title: Yanks Win a Seat-Squirmer To Move a Game From Title
description: The Yankees snatched an electrifying 1-0 victory from the Atlanta Braves in the fifth game of the World Series tonight, thanks to the brilliant pitching of the Yankees' starter, 24-year-old Andy Pettitte, and an outfield error that led to the game's only run.

title: Yeltsin and Ukrainian Find Few Solutions on Fleet Issues
description: Seeking to ease tension between their nations, President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine met with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia outside Moscow today to discuss the fate of Russian bases and warships in the Black Sea.

title: United Fights Back With Western Shuttle
description: On the West Coast, United Airlines decided two years ago that to hang onto its business travelers in the face of competition from low-cost Southwest Airlines, it had to go beyond saturation scheduling and create a true shuttle.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Treasures From the Asia Society'

title: Science and the Native American Cosmos
description: To the Editor:

title: Willie Horton Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrat Attacks Ad for Bond Act as an Illegal Plug for D'Amato
description: The 30-second television spot shows Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and his family strolling on a beach, running on the sand, sipping from a water fountain and hugging. His daughter, Lorraine, tells what her dad has taught her and describes him as a ''fighter.''

title: Exorcising Cocaine Demons
description: Many a film maker enthralled by a short story or a novel has tried to capture its magic on screen only to fall short, and John L'Ecuyer is no exception.

title: United by the Spirit of Protest
description: THE strident, message-heavy work of the Mexican muralists -- Diego Rivera, Jose Clemente Orozco, David Alfaro Siqueiros and others -- had a lot of influence on American artists during the Depression-blasted 1930's. Among those affected was a small group of black artists interested not only in social reform but also in addressing their own racial identities. For them, the Mexicans' luridly polemical frescoes, paintings and prints, which glorified folk culture and lambasted the evils of capitalism and racism, had strong appeal as the basis for a ''language of protest.''

title: Diana Trilling, a Cultural Critic and Member of a Select Intellectual Circle, Dies at 91
description: Diana Trilling, an uncompromising cultural and social critic and a member of the circle of writers, thinkers and polemicists of the 1930's, 40's and 50's known as the New York intellectuals, died on Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. She was 91 and lived in Manhattan.

title: City's Image Plays Well At Baker Field
description: FOR a moment the other day, it looked as if a headline on the sports pages contained a typo. It said that Columbia University's football team had a 5-0 record this season.

title: In Space and Out of Luck
description: A lot of Americans come up with lame excuses for not going to the polls on Election Day. But not John E. Blaha: his problem is that he is stuck in space.

title: Philips Posts Unexpectedly Steep Drop in Earnings
description: Philips Electronics N.V., the giant Dutch electronics company, shocked investors yesterday by reporting an unexpectedly big plunge in third-quarter profits and providing clear evidence that its troubles are far from over.

title: The Chirac Caper
description: Yasir Arafat stood in Bethlehem to proclaim that only one word guides the Palestinian movement: Jihad, jihad, jihad.

title: Art in Review
description: Lucian Freud

title: Next in Jet Crash Inquiry: Scallop Dredges
description: Federal law enforcement and transportation officials plan to decide today how to proceed with two new steps in the investigation of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800: the use of scallop dredges to scrape up any last pieces of sunken debris on the ocean floor, and an expansion of the jigsaw-puzzle-like reconstruction of the jet.

title: The Evil That Lurks All Around
description: Fox Broadcasting shouldn't let Chris Carter out of sight of its executive suite. He created ''The X-Files,'' the phenomenally successful series about paranormal oddities like, gulp, aliens. And this evening he's weighing in with a new series called ''Millennium,'' which, limiting itself to mere earthlings, tackles nothing less than the existence of evil in our midst.

title: A Scoffer at Albania's Old Regime Scolds the New
description: When Fatos Lubonja, in his 13th year as a political prisoner, was allowed to move from a hard-labor camp to the relative luxury of solitary confinement in a cell, he seized on an idea for a novel about the absurdities of Communism.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The New Yorker magazine said yesterday that JOE KLEIN, the Newsweek political columnist, would be joining its staff as the new Washington correspondent.

title: A School Where Anything Goes
description: Here is a self-graded, one-question, multiple-choice examination:

title: News Summary
description: International A3-12

title: School Nights Are Chaotic When Series Runs Late
description: Anthony Criscione, 13, did his math homework during commercials, pressing the mute button on the remote control to help his concentration, then turning the sound back up so as not to miss a moment of the Yankees' breathtaking comeback.

title: A Recent Fox Alumnus to Lead HBO Pictures
description: Seven weeks after resigning as president of Fox Entertainment, John A. Matoian was named president of the HBO Pictures division of Home Box Office, the premium cable network's chairman, Jeff Bewkes, announced yesterday. Mr. Matoian will also head HBO NYC Productions, the network's New York-based production company.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with the continuation of an article about the economic rebound in New York City misstated the timing of the most recent recession in the city. It began in 1989 and lasted until 1992; it did not occur in 1988. In some editions the chart also misstated the hotel occupancy rate for 1988. It was 75 percent, not 80.

title: Stronghold in 1992 Mostly Ignores Perot
description: On the morning after the 1992 Presidential election, Waldo County, Me., could easily have been called Perot County. With 36.2 percent of the county's vote, Ross Perot defeated Bill Clinton and George Bush.

title: Guerrillas Pounce at Loehmann's Manhattan Opening
description: There are those who give lip service to loving good bargains, and then there are guerrilla shoppers. The two are rarely confused.

title: Specter Gives His Support To Zimmer, A 'Moderate'
description: Declaring that the United States Senate does not have enough moderate Republicans, Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican from Pennsylvania, traveled across the Delaware River today to endorse a fellow Republican, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, for the United States Senate.

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing minute-by-minute changes in the Dow Jones industrial average reflected outdated figures in some editions. The version showing a close of 6,081.80 was for Wednesday's trading. Thursday's close was 5,992.48.

title: Home-Field Disadvantage Could Go Either Way
description: THE Braves have the Yankees right where they want them -- at Yankee Stadium.

title: Further Whitewater Inquiry Is Authorized
description: A special three-judge panel today authorized the Whitewater independent counsel to investigate whether Bernard W. Nussbaum, the former White House counsel, was truthful in Congressional testimony about F.B.I. files that were improperly obtained by the White House.

title: $39 Million for What?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hugh J. Davis, 69, Gynecologist Who Invented Dalkon Shield
description: Dr. Hugh J. Davis, the Johns Hopkins gynecologist whose acclaimed invention of the Dalkon Shield as a safer and more effective birth control device proved disastrous to thousands of American women, died on Wednesday at his home on Gibson Island, Md. He was 69.

title: Johnson Disagrees
description: MAGIC JOHNSON, for one, believes TOMMY MORRISON should stay retired.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Reminder
description: Standard time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow, and clocks are set back one hour.

title: Indogate's Drive-by Victims
description: It's not in the selfish interest of either major party to drain the bottomless sewer of corporate money that is the lifeblood of American politics. That's why 10 days from now, when the campaign of 1996 at last disappears officially into the memory hole, this month's talk of campaign-finance reform may vanish as quickly as Bill Clinton's second-term promises and Bob Dole's ''Just don't do it!'' anti-drug program.

title: DOLE IS IMPLORING VOTERS TO 'RISE UP' AGAINST THE PRESS
description: Sounding like a crusader, Bob Dole implored his audiences today to ''rise up'' against the nation's news organizations, which he said were protecting the Clinton Administration, and be outraged that President Clinton had, in Mr. Dole's words, violated the public trust.

title: State of Emergency Declared After Rioting in Florida
description: An uneasy calm prevailed here today after a night of disturbances that ignited 28 arson fires, led to 20 arrests and shook an area better known for its retirement homes than for racial tensions. Still, city officials declared a state of emergency to guard against any flare-up of the violence.

title: Mafia Seeks To Oust Gotti, Officials Say
description: Since being convicted of Federal murder and racketeering charges in 1992, John Gotti has continued to rule the Gambino crime family from a tiny cell in a maximum security prison in Illinois, officials say. But that, they say, is about to end.

title: A G.O.P. Senate Fund Controlled by D'Amato Aided New York State Candidates
description: The National Republican Senatorial Committee, headed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, spent $137,000 on the campaigns of three candidates for judgeships in upstate New York, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Cash Going to Stock Funds Fell Sharply in Latest Week
description: Mutual fund investors, who normally view market milestones as a signal to increase their buying, sharply slowed their new purchases of stock funds in the week after the Dow Jones industrial average first topped 6,000.

title: Time Inc.'s Editor of New Media Plans to Resign
description: Paul Sagan, the president and editor of new-media at Time Inc. announced yesterday that he planned to resign from the company at the end of the year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks End Down for Week, As Mutual Fund Flows Fall

title: Injuries' Cause Is Disputed By a Doctor
description: A gynecologist called by Alex Kelly's lawyers testified today that the injuries sustained by the 16-year-old girl who said Mr. Kelly raped her could have been normal results of first-time sex.

title: Company Briefs
description: AEP INDUSTRIES Hackensack, N.J., said it would close its packaging plant in North Andover, Mass., which it acquired when it purchased Borden Inc.'s Global Packaging division on Oct. 11. About 360 employees will be laid off.

title: Reggie, Billy, the Clipper and Ol' Pete
description: IN the hours before a Game 6 of the World Series, the anticipation of instant theater isn't quite the same as it is before a Game 7, but tonight's game at Yankee Stadium, with Jimmy Key hoping to outpitch the Braves' Greg Maddux, will be historic or haunting.

title: Oklahoma Clears Black In Deadly 1921 Race Riot
description: Seventy-five years after the fact and six decades after his death, a black Tulsa businessman has been cleared of wrongdoing in connection with one of the deadliest race riots in American history.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with an article about the financial problems of rock clubs in New York City misstated the the total cost of promotion in some editions for a typical capacity concert at one club, Irving Plaza, in Manhattan. Other figures in the chart, based on the incorrect figure, were also in error.

title: INSIDE
description: Mass Protest in Canada

title: On One Evening, Anyway, Not a Bit of Balanchine
description: Pacific Northwest Ballet took a bold but necessary step on Wednesday night. It offered a program without a single work by George Balanchine on it.

title: Albania's Old Habits
description: Many formerly Communist societies are now finding that junking their totalitarian governments was easy compared with getting rid of totalitarian thinking. Although Albania now has the infrastructure of a European democratic system, its politics offer proof of this discrepancy. Last Sunday's reasonably free and fair local elections, marred by the Government's veto of impartial observers and some incidents of intimidation, were an unusual piece of positive news about Albanian democracy.

title: Debating the Change in Law on Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Wired Ventures Withdraws Initial Offering for 2d Time
description: Wired Ventures Inc. said today that it had withdrawn its initial public offering for a second time, citing a market unreceptive to Internet-related companies.

title: Banker Pleads Guilty
description: A former president of the defunct Suburban National Bank in Hillsborough admitted in Federal court yesterday that he had defrauded his bank by obtaining $1.3 million in loans for partnerships in which he had an interest, prosecutors said. Joseph Sullivan, 50, also a former Mayor of Hillsborough, had concealed his role in these businesses from the bank's board of directors, said Deborah Gannett, an assistant United States attorney.

title: H. P. Minsky, 77, Economist Who Decoded Lending Trends
description: Hyman P. Minsky, an economist and professor who explained, in path-breaking research, how lending patterns and mood swings can push an economy into speculative booms or steep declines, died on Thursday at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Rhinebeck.

title: In China's Outlands, Poorest Grow Poorer
description: Life is unimaginably hard in the burnt umber hills of this part of northwestern China. In four of the last five years there has been no harvest and millions of poor farmers are living in a state of hunger, poor health and illiteracy that in some areas approaches the deprivation levels of China's great famine in the late 1950's.

title: Visiting Monk Seeks to Bring City Serenity
description: FINDING the path to the East hasn't ordinarily been a problem for Matthieu Ricard, considering that he moved to India from France in 1972 to become a Buddhist monk. But finding an address on East 23d Street, as he discovered the other day on his way to a meeting, required a special kind of contemplation.

title: Clinton, in an Artful Campaign Trip to Georgia, Urges a Tutor Plan for Young Readers
description: During a single hour in downtown Atlanta today, President Clinton managed to make a big splash in a Southern state he wants to win, sit silent as a surrogate slashed away at Bob Dole, chasten a heckler and put in a plug for a Democratic Senate candidate who does not want to be seen as too much in his shadow.

title: Jets Are Talkin' Baseball in Locker Room
description: Only a few days ago, the Jets and the Yankees had the same winning percentage: .000. But now the Yankees have become the Jets' role model.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an order by an appellate judge postponing enforcement of New York City's new law restricting sex-related businesses referred incorrectly in some editions to the lawyer for the New York Civil Liberties Union who argued on behalf of customers of the businesses. It was Beth Haroules, a staff attorney for the group, not Norman Siegel, the executive director.

title: Lonne Elder Memorial
description: A memorial service for the playwright Lonne Elder 3d is to be held on Monday at 7 P.M. at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, the New York Public Library, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, at 135th Street, Harlem. Mr. Elder died in June at the age of 69.

title: Teaching Is No Sitcom
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Natural Gas Surges as Traders Rush to Get Ahead of Winter
description: Natural gas prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as distributors raced to secure supplies before colder weather arrives.

title: Water Main Break on East 60th St. Disrupts Subway and Businesses
description: A rusty, 69-year-old water main cracked early yesterday under East 60th Street in Manhattan, spewing a foul-smelling muck of water and sewage into one of the busiest subway stations and disrupting train service for almost six hours into the early part of the morning rush.

title: Lord Gladwyn Is Dead at 96; Briton Helped Found the U.N.
description: Lord Gladwyn, a patrician diplomat who helped draft the Charter of the United Nations and served as Britain's representative at the organization in the early days of the cold war, died on Thursday. He was 96.

title: At 89, Using 30's Devices With an Aura Of Today
description: The first thing to notice about the alto saxophonist Benny Carter, who is 89, is that he sounds genuinely like a player of his time, the 1930's. He is a master of old-fashioned artifice, for whom the expression of ''natural'' voice isn't the main criterion; one senses that his feeling never quite displaces his technique. But the result is consistently and amazingly fresh and modern. In his quartet's early set at Iridium on Tuesday night, he played anything but straight melody: timelessly shocking manipulations were thick in the air.

title: Two Takes on the Devil: The Charms of the Seedy Give Way to Sunday Best
description: When the devil sings the blues in the 1995 recorded version of ''Randy Newman's 'Faust,' '' he sounds like someone you might stumble across in a murky, stale-smelling bar in that desperate hour before last call.

title: Not Just a Game, This Series Is a Tussle of Two Cities
description: When the Atlanta Braves returned from New York City up 2-0, the talk was of a historic World Series sweep, comparisons with the 1927 Yankees and the baseball dynasty of the 90's.

title: Many Catholics Welcome Pope's Statement on Evolution
description: From a Roman Catholic day school to a downtown church to a center for senior citizens, Catholics of all ages said here today that they accepted and even welcomed Pope John Paul II's decision this week that the Roman Catholic Church should treat evolution as a theory backed by scientific research, and not just a hypothesis.

title: A Natural Staggering
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Enough News, Already
description: To the Editor:

title: Eat and Be Thin. What's the Catch?
description: How's this for a diet? Eat all you want, 12,000 calories a day and more, if you like. Devour haunches of turkey, mounds of corn and wash the whole thing down with gobs of whipped cream. Snack between meals out of giant bags of chips. Just don't say no.

title: Now, the Endgame: Yanks Want One More
description: The Yankees spent a day without a baseball game pondering the enviable position they had ascended to, thinking about making this weekend one they will remember forever and dreaming about making New York the home of the best team in the world. A triumph over the Atlanta Braves tonight or tomorrow, nine fluid innings of baseball, will make them World Series champions.

title: Bridge
description: The United States open team won two matches today at the world championships and tied one, but made few gains on the leaders. After 23 of 35 rounds, it is 12th in its qualifying pool with 393 victory points. The leaders are Israel, 450.5; Italy, 447; Iceland, 436, and Taiwan, 433.5.

title: Perot Stronghold in '92 Largely Ignores Him in '96
description: On the morning after the 1992 Presidential election, Waldo County residents could have christened their Down East enclave Perot Country. Ross Perot finished first here, beating Bill Clinton and George Bush as he did in 13 other counties around the nation.

title: No Headline
description: ''These are the marks of a caring society and -- no offense -- what sets us apart from the United States.''

title: In Japan, Democracy Also Rises
description: After Japanese voters put the Liberal Democratic Party back in power this week, you had to wonder whose funeral you had wandered into. Reform is dead, commentators declared on both sides of the Pacific, and nothing ever changes with those frustrating Japanese.

title: Czech Ministry to Examine Ailments of Gulf Veterans
description: The Czech Defense Ministry has announced that it has ordered medical examinations for all Czech soldiers who served in the 1991 Persian Gulf war in light of recent reports that many of the veterans may have fallen ill from exposure to Iraqi chemical weapons.

title: Giants Lose Toomer And Sparks To Injuries
description: The news has been mostly bad all season for the 2-5 Giants. And today, with injuries to two key players, cornerback Phillippi Sparks and wide receiver/kick returner Amani Toomer, their fortunes took a drastic turn for the worse.

title: Keep Malls in Suburbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton Plans Visit
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will be in New Jersey on Sunday to urge supporters not to be complacent about the outcome of the Nov. 5 election and to campaign for Representative Robert G. Torricelli. The First Lady will appear at the Pavilion at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, said Jo Astrid-Glading, a campaign spokeswoman.

title: In a House Ruled by Men, 23 Women Break In
description: Nobody looks less like a politician than Kiyomi Tsujimoto. For starters, she's a she.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Marquee Football Fight

title: LARGEST SHAREHOLDER REDUCES ITS VOTING STAKE
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company said yesterday that its largest shareholder had cut its voting stake in the company to 10.1 percent. Crown Cork said the shareholder, the French concern Compagnie Generale d'Industrie et de Participations, or C.G.I.P., had lowered its stake by selling 9.25 million Crown Cork common shares and 3 million preferred shares in a secondary offering, which raised about $560.6 million. C.G.I.P. previously had a 19.9 percent stake in Crown Cork. Crown Cork, based in Philadelphia, supplies packaging products to consumer marketing companies.

title: Transit Agency Plans Its First Volume Discounts
description: For the first time, the New York City Transit Authority will offer riders volume discounts, selling 11 fares for the price of 10 starting late next year or early in 1998, in what amounts to a partial rollback of last year's 25-cent fare increase, transit officials said yesterday.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Judge Orders 2 Separate Trials For Oklahoma Bomb Suspects
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered separate trials for the two men charged with bombing the Oklahoma City Federal Building in 1995, ruling that a joint trial would present an unacceptable risk of prejudice to both of the accused, Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols.

title: Torricelli Vows to Support Casino Interests
description: In a church just blocks from the glimmering casinos that line the boardwalk, Representative Robert G. Torricelli boasted today of his work to protect this city's gambling industry and of his longtime support from casino owners.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about recent rulings by New York State courts on the arbitration of investors' complaints referred incorrectly to a proposal to limit punitive damages in such cases. The proposal -- by a commission headed by David Ruder, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission -- called for restricting such awards to twice the amount of compensatory damages, with a ceiling of $750,000. It did not propose that the ceiling be whichever of two figures was greater -- $750,000 or twice the compensatory damages.

title: Talks to Settle Cable Dispute End Abruptly
description: Talks on a settlement between Viacom Inc. and MCA suddenly broke off yesterday, sending the dispute between the two partners over control of the USA Network back into court in Delaware.

title: Maintain a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Much Ado About Time
description: At noon tomorrow in New York City, local apparent sidereal time will be approximately 1:29. The Julian Day will be 2450384, which is the number of days since high noon on Jan. 1, 4713 B.C. That was the last time the 28-year solar and 19-year lunar cycles began on the same day as a 15-year Roman tax cycle, an anachronistic coincidence first noticed by the percipient Scaliger in 1583. If one probes a little deeper into the subject of time, one discovers leap seconds and negative leap seconds and International Seconds. There is a Modified Julian Date and a Truncated Julian Date. Greenwich Mean Time has a familiar, prime-meridian ring to it, but, alas, it has been replaced by Coordinated Universal Time, which sounds as though Earth controls the clockwork in the distant cosmos.

title: The Labor Deal Hinges On the Word From Selig
description: Even with a negotiated deal ready to be reduced to writing, the tenuous peace between baseball's club owners and players remained subject to one word from Bud Selig yesterday: either yes or no.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7

title: Jimmy Heath's Birthday Gig
description: Jimmy Heath likes to separate the sections of a big band, letting the reeds chatter from one side while the trumpets and trombones mark off their territory from the other.

title: Rangers' Latest Loss Leaves Campbell Shaking His Head
description: Colin Campbell's patience is wearing thin. The Rangers' coach cut short a post-game news conference tonight after another loss.

title: More Scholarly and Luxurious, Art Gallery Catalogues Move Upmarket
description: NEW YORK  In growing numbers, art gallery catalogues are undergoing a transformation that has in effect spawned anew literary genre.

title: Revised Data Show Layoff Rate Constant in 1990's
description: Despite the economic recovery and substantial numbers of new jobs, the rate of layoffs in the work force in the middle of the decade remained roughly constant compared with the early 1990's, according to revised figures released today by the Labor Department.

title: 16-Year Sentence for Beating
description: Nearly three years ago, Mariko Westbrook was riding a Newark bus when she was severely beaten and kicked by a woman who took offense at something she said. Ms. Westbrook, 66, the mother of Peter Westbrook, an Olympic fencing champion, died four days later.

title: Contest in Tampa Area Reflects G.O.P. Hopes and Anxieties
description: ''I'm not running to represent a party. I'm running to represent this district,'' said the Congressional candidate, sounding, except for a mild Southern accent, like a Yankee Republican warding off the Gingrich taint.

title: A Biblical Call for Reconciliation in the Middle East
description: In the difficult Middle East peace effort, control of the West Bank city of Hebron has emerged as a particular challenge. Hundreds of Jewish settlers live in enclaves there, amidst tens of thousands of Palestinians. The Israeli Government has delayed pulling out its army, angering the Palestinian Authority.

title: Fighting and Ejections? It's Rockets vs. Knicks
description: Less than three years ago, the Knicks and the Rockets waged a seven-game scrum for the National Basketball Association title, a bump-and-grind series the rest of America deemed unattractive, almost thug-like. Tonight at the Summit, basketball between the two teams sank to another ugly level, and the game didn't even count.

title: HEALTH SYSTEMS TO GET STAKE IN NEW JERSEY COMPANY
description: Health Systems International Inc., based in Woodland Hills, Calif., said yesterday that it would buy a 40 percent stake in a New Jersey managed care company for $30 million as part of its expansion into the Northeast. Health Systems will buy $30 million of subordinated debentures from FOHP Inc., the parent company of First Option Health Plan, based in Red Bank, N.J. The debentures are convertible to shares that will give Health Systems a 40 percent stake, and Health Systems has an option to buy another 20 percent of FOHP. First Option, which is owned by its doctors and hospitals, had revenue of $111.4 million in 1995.

title: CHARTWELL AND MOBIL IN TRUCK STOP VENTURE
description: The Mobil Corporation and Chartwell Investments Inc. said yesterday that they had purchased a majority stake in Petro Stopping Centers L.P., a truck stop operator, for $285 million. Mobil and Chartwell said the transaction consisted of the purchase of the partnership interests in Petro held by the Fremont Group and a separate stock investment. Petro operates and franchises 43 large truck stop travel plazas across the United States. Chartwell Investments Inc. is a New York-based investment firm with holdings in heating oil distribution, parking lots, convenience stores and retail gasoline sales. Fremont is an investment arm of Bechtel Group Inc.

title: A No-Brainer
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Create a Real Housing Crisis
description: New York City has been attracting about 100,000 immigrants a year since the 1980's, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. And for the most part, it is recent immigrants who live in the city's most crowded and dilapidated housing.

title: Lehman in Control, But Woods Loses His
description: There was a rude intrusion of reality into the dreamlike proceedings at the Tour Championship at Southern Hills Country Club today.

title: Milestones and Missteps on Immigration
description: By all measures, the Clinton Administration has poured more money and political capital into addressing immigration problems than any other administration in recent times.

title: It's Deja Vu: The Braves Have Been Here Before
description: This is a familiar feeling for the Atlanta Braves.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TOP GAMES

title: Chubb Said To Consider Selling Units
description: The stock of the Chubb Corporation, one of the largest insurance companies in the country, jumped 12 percent yesterday after analysts said the company was considering selling its poorly performing life insurance and real estate subsidiaries.

title: Protesters Take to Streets to Defend Canada's Safety Net
description: Canadians do not easily take to the streets; it's just not their way. But today thousands of angry people paralyzed parts of Canada's largest city to protest government actions that they say threaten the core of what Canada stands for.

title: L.I. District Weighs Hiring Of Business to Run School
description: The Roosevelt School District, the first public school system to be taken over by New York State, is debating another first -- hiring a private company to manage one of its elementary schools.

title: Let Cable TV Subscribers Pick Their Channels
description: To the Editor:

title: A Widening Popularity Brings Acquisitions
description: Organic food used to mean mottled produce, granola and maybe a seaweed cocktail. Today, there's an organic merlot to go with your organic fettucine Alfredo, and a dish of organic mango gelato for dessert.

title: Shula Nominated
description: DON SHULA, who retired as the winningest National Football League coach in history, heads the list of those nominated for the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Shula was among 10 nominees announced Thursday who are eligible for election for the first time.

title: A Tour for Strong Men in '97
description: Bjarne Riis, the Dane who won this year's Tour de France, watched with excitement today when the route and difficulties of the 1997 race were unveiled at a special presentation.

title: Debating the Change in Law on Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Plans for the New Planetarium: Celestial or Just Starry-Eyed?
description: To the Editor:

title: PETSMART AGREES TO ACQUIRE PET CITY HOLDINGS
description: Petsmart Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Pet City Holdings P.L.C. in a stock swap valued at $229.4 million, giving the company a base for a planned expansion in Europe. Petsmart, a pet-supply retailer based in Phoenix, will issue 0.3214 common share for each Pet City ordinary share, or about 7.8 million of its 105.7 million common shares outstanding. The acquisition requires approval by 75 percent of the ordinary shares of Pet City Holdings and approval by the High Court of Justice in England and Wales. Pet City Holdings is Britain's largest specialty retailer of pet goods, with 50 superstores. Petsmart operates 311 superstores in 33 states.

title: Car and Baby Taken But Baby Is Returned
description: A car with a 10-month-old girl in it was stolen yesterday in Queens. The child, but not the car, was recovered safely a short time later.

title: Zaire War Breeds a Human Catastrophe
description: A human disaster looms in eastern Zaire.

title: Mr. Dole's Tax Plan Gets Worse
description: Bob Dole made his ill-advised tax-cut plan worse this week when he tacked on an idea trumpeted by his running mate, Jack Kemp. Mr. Dole agreed to ''index'' the tax on capital gains -- which would allow investors to subtract out inflationary gains before they calculate their profit from selling stocks and bonds. Indexing sounds fair. Indeed, a carefully designed indexing plan could be defended. But the Dole-Kemp plan gives investors an unwarranted tax holiday and creates a destructive loophole in the tax code.

title: Icahn Re-enters Fray to Press RJR to Spin Off Food Business
description: The investor Carl C. Icahn has increased his stake in the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, and in Federal filings disclosed yesterday said that he was pressuring the company to spin off its food unit from the company's tobacco operations immediately.

title: Desperation and The Green Mile
description: Millennium fever possesses popular culture like a doomsday virus, and no writer is chasing the pathology more determinedly or baroquely than Stephen King. ''Desperation'' and ''The Regulators'' -- mammoth novels released on the same day under different names from separate publishers yet featuring interlocking plots and dust jackets -- rehearse Armageddon with violence and sensationalism rarely approximated (even by Mr. King). Apparently indisposed to coast on the bloody laurels of this double apocalypse, over his summer vacation Mr. King also issued a lower-key six-part serial, ''The Green Mile.''

title: Kemp Hits Back at Republicans Who Despair
description: Jack Kemp today delivered one of his most spirited defenses of the beleaguered Republican Presidential ticket and of his running mate, Bob Dole, castigating Republicans who he said had ''run away.''

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Pots and Kettles

title: Gulling The Rubes
description: Down on the government -- that's the place to be this year. Big government, big bad government -- that's what's darned near ruined America, isn't it? ''Too much government'' -- that's the answer to give when the reporters and the pollers barge into the beauty parlor asking what's wrong with America.

title: In a Brahms Concerto, The Battle Is Joined
description: The New York Philharmonic offered an energizing contribution to this season's Brahms centenary commemorations on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, when Krystian Zimerman was the soloist and Herbert Blomstedt the conductor in the Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor.

title: Pressures Over Crime Are Cited In Faking
description: Two days after a Bronx police commander was removed from his precinct because of suspicions that he had falsified reports to exaggerate a drop in crime, investigators have determined that he apparently doctored reports on several crimes, but not the most serious ones, like murder, senior police officials said yesterday.

title: Differing Personalities United in Beethoven
description: Within the period-instrument movement, Malcolm Bilson, the fortepianist, and Anner Bylsma, the cellist, are equally renowned. Yet they have quite different musical personalities. You would think they might not get along as collaborators.

title: Going the Extra Mile to Give Heroes Blemishes
description: The shrewdest dramas of the past few years have sneered at the cliche of the unblemished hero. While ''Homicide'' and ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' focus on the neuroses and insecurities of their star detectives, ''EZ Streets'' goes beyond that, creating a world where both cops and criminals are more likely to be corrupt than not, where no one can be trusted. ''EZ Streets'' may sound depressing, but its fiercely dark vision keeps viewers off-kilter and engaged and makes this one of the season's most exciting new series.

title: Premiums Down, Benefits Up
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had some good news yesterday for New Jersey businesses. She said that premiums for worker's compensation will be reduced by 11.2 percent in 1997, saving employers a total of $218 million.

title: In Secure Midwest, Gore Focuses on Congressional Seats
description: In a brisk swing through Michigan and Ohio, Vice President Al Gore cheerfully campaigned today as much for the local Democratic candidates as for himself and President Clinton.

title: Judge J. Daniel Mahoney, 65, Founder of Conservative Party
description: Judge J. Daniel Mahoney of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, a founder of the New York State Conservative Party, died on Wednesday at Griffin Hospital in Derby, Conn. Judge Mahoney, who lived in Huntington, Conn., was 65.

title: The Stadium Can Produce Odd Effects
description: THE prospect of being at Yankee Stadium tonight is awesome -- and a little unnerving.

title: U.S. AND NATO PLAN NEW BOSNIA FORCE
description: Although the White House has maintained a deliberate silence for fear of provoking pre-election controversy, the United States and NATO have begun preparations to field a smaller but still sizable international peacekeeping force in Bosnia that would include at least 5,000 American troops.

title: TV and Public Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCK OF ETEC SYSTEMS IN SHARP DECLINE
description: The stock of Etec Systems Inc. tumbled 35 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, said it expected its first-quarter earnings to be below Wall Street's estimates. Etec, based in Hayward, Calif., attributed the disappointing results to delays that pushed shipments scheduled for the first quarter into the second quarter. The company cited longer-than-expected testing and calibration on the equipment for the delays. First Call Inc. had forecast Etec Systems to earn 38 cents a share for the three months ending next Friday. A year-ago, Etec Systems earned $2.7 million, or 18 cents a share, on revenue of $24.7 million.

title: Chirac's Goal: Bigger Mideast Role
description: Pressing for a greater role for Europe in the American-dominated Middle East peace negotiations, President Jacques Chirac of France showed during a six-day trip through the region this week that Europe might not be ready to be a player, but that France was -- as an outspoken advocate of Arab causes.

title: Taken Hostage at the Airport
description: Some friends from Moscow once introduced me to a lovely Russian custom. Before embarking on a trip, you sit quietly for a few minutes on your suitcase to guarantee a safe return and to get into a meditative frame of mind for the journey.

title: National G.O.P. Panel Aided Local Campaigns
description: The National Republican Senatorial Committee, headed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, spent $137,000 to help three candidates for judgeships in upstate New York, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission. The donations broke no laws and did not violate committee policy, but aides to one G.O.P. Senate candidate questioned the use of such funds for local races.

title: Conscious Consumers
description: What exactly is organic food? The organic label indicates that the ingredients were farmed and processed without chemical additives -- no pesticides, no animal-growth hormones, no artificial preservatives.

title: Leaflets Allowed in Mall
description: In 1994, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that malls had to allow political groups to pass out leaflets. But the court also said that owners could establish rules to govern the pamphleteers' activities.

title: Prices of Treasury Bonds Rise On a Weakness in Home Sales
description: Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, erasing an early loss, as a slump in sales of existing homes helped ease concerns over inflation.

title: Biggest Victory for Torre Family: Heart Transplant Arrives on Time
description: For a family and a tiny Brooklyn neighborhood whose life is baseball, it was the timing that convinced them that Someone up there must be a fan.

title: Responsible Sex-Shop Limits
description: New York City's effort to limit the proliferation of sex-related businesses in the five boroughs won an important legal victory this week. A state Supreme Court justice denied a request from owners of X-rated stores to block a strict new zoning law whose goal is to limit the harmful impact of pornography shops on neighborhoods while still respecting freedom of expression.

title: Homosexuals in All Their Diversity
description: Begin with a puny budget, considerable resistance and no big names. Add an emotion-laden subject terrain, and the story of ''In the Life,'' a lesbian and gay bimonthly magazine, begins to look like one of those Judy Garland and Mickey Rooney movies in which the scrappy kids decide, against crazy odds, to put on a show.

title: Cone Prepares for Game He Doesn't Want Played
description: David Cone conceded yesterday that he would be in an awkward position when the Yankees play the Braves in Game 6 of the World Series at Yankee Stadium tonight. Obviously, Cone will be cheering for the Yankees to clinch. But there will also be a part of him acting as if there will definitely be a Game 7.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO ADD JEFFERSON BANCORP
description: Bidding to expand its presence in Florida, Colonial Bancgroup of Montgomery, Ala., agreed to acquire Jefferson Bancorp Inc. for almost $71.7 million in stock and assume options on Jefferson shares worth about $4.4 million. Colonial will exchange shares to equal $18.90 for every Jefferson share and stock options. The transaction will be accounted for as a pooling of interests, which reduces the amount of good will that Colonial Bank will have to pay down. Miami-based Jefferson Bancorp operates nine branches in south Florida.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a headline yesterday about tainted blood products in China referred incorrectly in some editions to the date of the first published reports on the case. A brief front-page summary of the article, and a News Summary entry, also included the error. The reports appeared in June 1996, not August 1994.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: From Artists to Zygouries, for $8,000
description: It may be unfair to approach Grove's new Dictionary of Art through a forest of statistics, but the numbers are hard to ignore. This result of 14 years of work and a $50 million investment includes 34 volumes, weighs 187 pounds and occupies 5 feet 8 inches of bookshelf space. Inside its pages are 26.3 million words and 15,000 illustrations.

title: Union Sets Sunday Night Deadline for G.M.
description: The United Auto Workers union imposed a deadline of Sunday night for settling contract talks with the General Motors Corporation, setting the stage for a strike if negotiators fail to reach an agreement.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Recycling Trip Backfires
description: Shoppers in Atlanta thought they were being responsible citizens when they returned tens of thousands of plastic bags to the Winn-Dixie supermarkets for recycling. But, after a long and circuitous trip to Asia, the ultimate destination for the polyethylene bags will be an incinerator in Newark, where they are due to arrive today, an environmental organization said.

title: Cigar's Last Turn for Home Has Everybody's Attention
description: Sunny skies, mild weather, a sellout crowd of 40,000 and a sentimental farewell to the great Cigar are expected on Saturday when Woodbine race track plays host to the first Breeders' Cup to be run outside the United States.

title: Crash Inquiry to Expand Reconstruction of Jet
description: Suggesting how confounding the mystery of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 has become, Federal officials have tentatively decided to take a series of new steps in the inquiry, including reconstructing a large section of the Boeing 747 that exploded on July 17 and blowing up another 747 to test various theories about the crash.

title: No Headline
description: ''Do something menial for a month -- clean the yard, make sure the septic tank is working, chop down limbs, round up stray dogs. Then get busy very, very quickly.''

title: Politicians Go Negative, And Voters Go Elsewhere
description: A lot of voters are standing in what one pollster, Janice Ballou, calls the ''mushy middle'' when it comes to making a decision about whom to support in the United States Senate race.

title: Dark Horse Picked for AT&T
description: After talking to some of America's biggest corporate names, AT&T last week gave its top job to John R. Walter, chairman of the commercial printing giant R. R. Donnelley & Sons. The reaction among AT&T watchers was summed up by an executive headhunter: ''Who?''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 29 with an article about Civil War battlefields referred incorrectly to a monument at Gettysburg. It honors all 32 North Carolina regiments that fought in the battle, not just the 32d North Carolina Regiment.
