How to make your instincts serve you usefully in everyday life. (+)

title: The Art of Eccentricity
description: In the judgment of the English critic F. R. Leavis, the Sitwells -- Edith, Osbert and Sacheverell -- belonged ''to the history of publicity, rather than of poetry,'' so perhaps it is only fitting that while most of their books are out of print, their exploits remain a subject of continuing interest. Their eccentric appearance, outrageous opinions and prominence in fashionable bohemian circles made them the Andy Warhols of their day; they even dabbled in what might be called performance art (their most famous collaboration, the 1923 ''Facade,'' featured Edith wailing her poems through a megaphone, from behind an elaborately painted curtain, to the accompaniment of ''experimental'' music by William Walton). And like Warhol, they exerted a considerable influence on the avant-garde of their time. It is this influence that is the subject of THE SITWELLS: And the Arts of the 1920s and 1930s (University of Texas, paper, $34.95), a pictorial biography by Sarah Bradford, Honor Clerk, Jonathan Fryer, Robin Gibson and John Pearson. Apart from innumerable pictures of the trio in languid poses and peculiar get-ups, their expressions always appropriately bored and impossibly aristocratic, there are also photographs of Sitwell friends and associates like Evelyn Waugh, Cecil Beaton and the young Dylan Thomas. Detailed in the captions and accompanying text are tales of the threesome's longstanding feuds with those who dared to mock their pretensions to genius, among whom were not only Leavis but D. H. Lawrence, Noel Coward, Aldous Huxley and Wyndham Lewis. Indeed, it sometimes seems as though the main occupation of the three was devising vendettas against anyone who failed to share their high opinion of themselves; archetypally English though they were, they lacked that most English of attributes, a sense of irony, especially where their own reputations were concerned. After a while, the account of their endless campaigns to promote themselves, furious indignation at every imagined slight and spiteful denunciations of their critics becomes more than a little tiresome; readers may find themselves sympathizing with the reviewer who called one of Osbert's books ''a long-drawn-out whine . . . a tedious and tortured tale of trivial complaint.'' Evelyn Toynton

title: Someone's Melody Is Another's Discord
description: To the Editor:

title: From Hen Man to Hit Man
description: A FATHER'S KISSES

title: Islanders Fail to Win It But at Least Avoid a Loss
description: With fewer than 12 minutes remaining in regulation time this afternoon, it appeared that the Islanders could end a three-game losing streak and that goalie Tommy Salo might earn his first National Hockey League shutout.

title: BASEBALL'S GLORY DAYS ARE . . . NOW
description: Barra's article is a fine antidote to all the baseball-bashing one hears. The mythology that glorifies the past at the expense of the present also includes the equally asinine notion that something called baseball is responsible for the antics of players, coaches, umpires, owners and fans. When Roberto Alomar spit in the face of an umpire, once again baseball was seen as shooting itself in the foot. Did anyone decry the irresponsibility of basketball when Dennis Rodman head-butted a referee?

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SOUTH BRONX

title: Staring at the Sun
description: Wild Indians & Other Creatures

title: The Worst Job in The World?
description: During the early months of the Clinton Presidency, when the White House was mired in aborted appointments -- Lani Guinier, Kimba Wood, Zoe Baird -- the nomination of a longtime immigration expert named Doris M. Meissner sailed through the Senate. As Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, she would have a high-profile job that has always been controversial: keeping open America's front door while slamming shut the back.

title: Linked to Apple but Trying to Branch Out
description: WHILE scores of analysts mull over the fate of troubled Apple Computer, some investors are taking a look instead at companies that are related to Apple. They want to see if those enterprises are as endangered as Wall Street may think.

title: Only in California, Apres-Face-Lift Spas Thrive
description: ''PLEASE whisper,'' the sign at the little door of the Hidden Garden warns visitors. ''The princess is sleeping.''

title: In the Fall, Fairs Are a Lure for Thousands
description: MORE than 20 fairs and festivals drew thousands of Long Islanders out of their homes this month to sample and taste, pick and husk and generally welcome the fall season.

title: Going Ape
description: DEMONIC MALES

title: Patriarch
description: FOUNDER

title: Union Leader Urges Companies to Forge Alliance With Labor
description: John J. Sweeney used his first anniversary as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to tell business leaders that the labor movement wants to help American businesses compete but will also continue pressuring companies to give workers more money, training and power.

title: So Many Changes, But All for the Better
description: A RECENT visit to La Marmite in Williston Park resembled an episode from ''The Twilight Zone.'' Everything at the 22-year-old restaurant looked the same, but it is a different place.

title: The Class Work Is Not Just Political
description: To the Editor:

title: DOLE IS CONTINUING ATTACKS ON PRESS AND THE PRESIDENT
description: On a bus trip through the verdant Central Valley of California, where 10 percent of this state's voters live, Bob Dole continued trying to stir up ''outrage'' today at the Clinton Administration, offered a rare mention of Hillary Rodham Clinton and harshly criticized the President's lack of military service.

title: Generation X Is Getting a Financial Life
description: GENERATION X'ERS are:

title: Success of Welfare Law Isn't Caseworkers' Job
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, Zito Wins At the Cup
description: Just as victories in the Triple Crown races had been the highlight of Nick Zito's training career, the Breeders' Cup had been a yoke. He had two Kentucky Derby victories, and another in the Preakness Stakes. But like a clock, each year he would spring forward and fall back.

title: Settling for Truth in the Quest for Justice
description: TELLING the truth about past atrocities is the way for a brutalized society to bind up its wounds, the theory goes. Now South Africa has seen glimpses of the best this technique can offer: An army general admitting he was the one who gave the order to fire on unarmed demonstrators at Bisho in 1992, and a police captain who helped kill 13 women and children asking the victim's families to ''consider forgiving me.''

title: The Charge Was Rape; The Issue Was Timing
description: On April 14, 1985, a 16-year-old girl -- M. K., in court papers -- was walking home with a girlfriend from a part-time job at the Monmouth Arts Center when a boy they knew invited them to a party at his house.

title: What the Princetons Need Is a Debate, Not a War
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Classic Upset, Cigar Runs Third to Alphabet Soup
description: Cigar rolled over a mile and a quarter of Canadian soil to a third-place finish in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic today in what was probably the final race of a historic career.

title: Do I Hear 400,000 Miles? For Frequent Fliers, New Ways to Splurge
description: DAVID RIMMER is using his frequent-flier miles for a trip to the moon. Never mind that the journey will be aboard a space shuttle simulator at Space Center Houston. It will still be an adventure for Mr. Rimmer, and for the airline industry, which has recently been offering fantasy trips in exchange for miles.

title: A Woman for All Seasons
description: MARY THROUGH THE CENTURIESHer Place in the History of Culture.By Jaroslav Pelikan.Illustrated. 267 pp. New Haven:Yale University Press. $25.

title: THE BODY POLITIC
description: I must respond with bewilderment to Susanna Moore's essay ''The Body Politic'' (Style, Oct. 6). What is she saying? That we cannot be interested in the accomplishments of the First Lady but instead look to her to fulfill the 1950's sex-limited role as national paper doll?

title: Halloween Lingers Past the Day With Witches Play at Emelin
description: HALLOWEEN will howl on a bit longer for children who attend the second annual production of ''The Witch Who Was Afraid of Witches'' next Saturday at the Emelin Theater here. The play is a musical adaptation of the best-selling children's book of the same name by Alice Low, a Briarcliff Manor resident. Ms. Low, the author of 24 other books for children and teen-agers, will autograph books at both performances, which will take place at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M.

title: Food Stamps Are Deli's Undoing
description: The Around the Clock deli opened on 106th Street and Amsterdam Avenue three years ago, and since then neighbors often voiced suspicions that drugs were bought and sold inside the store. Acting on various tips, the police raided the deli a few times, turning up, they say, drug paraphernalia and illegal guns.

title: Ideological Pressure Intrudes on Acclaim
description: They dance on New York's most famed stages and organize the latest downtown art exhibitions. They perform in respected tiny theaters and play their music in big outdoor spaces. They are young and talented and they are Cuban. Unfailingly, they draw big crowds.

title: Prosecutors Declare Guard Isn't Suspect In Atlanta Bombing
description: Clearing away the suspicions that had turned a security guard from hero to pariah, the Justice Department today declared that Richard A. Jewell was no longer a suspect in the July 27 bombing at Centennial Olympic Park.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: In a Police Series, a Delicate Balancing Act
description: THERE was a time on television when the long-running dramatic series was a kind of immutable universe unto itself, with shows like ''Perry Mason,'' ''The Fugitive'' and ''Hawaii Five-O'' creating a constellation of stars that never changed, revolving around a single story told over and over again. In the case of ''Gunsmoke,'' this went on for decades.

title: 'After All, Fashion Is Art'
description: WHILE the big parties of the week were all about fashion, the art world had a quieter (but no less high-powered) gathering on Wednesday at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea. But even there, some fashion people showed up to hobnob in the same space where Calvin Klein will hold his show on Friday.

title: No Matter How You Slice It, We Are Big
description: To the Editor:

title: Marion D. Cuyjet, 76, Pioneer In Teaching Black Dancers, Dies
description: Marion Durham Cuyjet, a pioneering teacher of black dancers, died on Oct. 22 at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. Mrs. Cuyjet was 76 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Susan McLaughlin, Eric von Coelln
description: Susan Elizabeth McLaughlin, a daughter of James R. McLaughlin of Huntington, L.I., and the late Kathryn B. McLaughlin, was married last evening to Eric Christian von Coelln, the son of Patricia and Fredrick E. von Coelln of Fullerton, Calif. The Rev. Orlanda R. Brugnola, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the 24 Fifth Avenue Ballroom in New York.

The true story, the narrator claims, of boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take. 2 83 REVIVING OPHELIA, by Mary Pipher. (Ballantine, $12.50.) The dangers for teen-age girls. A poet recalls her troubled childhood. (+) 5 3 HIGH TIDE IN TUCSON, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) Essays about motherhood, nature and other topics by the novelist. 6 5 A FEVER IN THE HEART, by Ann Rule. (Pocket, $6.99.) Accounts of six crime cases. 7 6 MY POINT . . . AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $6.50.) Observations on life by the television star and stand-up comedian. 8 3 LONGITUDE, by Dava Sobel. (Penguin, $10.95.) The memoirs of the former leader of an F.B.I. team that studies the behavior of serial killers and assassins. 14* 145 CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (Harper Perennial, $12.) Daily spirituality. (+) 15* 109 EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Bantam, $5.99.) A woman's near-death experience. (+) 16* 18 SPONTANEOUS HEALING, by Andrew Weil. (Fawcett, $12.95.) How the body heals itself. (+) 17* 27 PAULA, by Isabel Allende. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) The novelist tells stories of her family's life as she tends her fatally ill daughter. The authors offer 35 ''time-tested secrets for capturing the heart of Mr. Right.'' 2 5 IT'S A MAGICAL WORLD, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $14.95.) A new collection of ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 3 3 FUGITIVE FROM THE CUBICLE POLICE, by Scott Adams. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) title: THESE SHOES PINCH
description: Fifty years after Mao condemned foot-binding -- the custom of folding, wrapping and sometimes cracking a woman's foot to stunt its growth -- it appears to be back.

title: Army's Wishbone Continues Rolling
description: It quickly became apparent to the 16,543 rain-drenched fans at Yager Stadium that Miami could do no more against Army's wishbone attack than the first six teams that had faced the Black Knights this season.

title: Sanitizing History On a Postage Stamp
description: LISTEN hard enough and you might hear a faint wheeze and rumbling cough from across the ocean. That's Andre Malraux rolling over in his grave.

title: Louise Kerz and Al Hirschfeld
description: Louise Kerz, a theatrical historian in New York, and Al Hirschfeld, the caricaturist, were married on Wednesday at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the temple's senior rabbi, performed the ceremony in his study.

title: Consular Help
description: To the Editor: On Sept. 22 you reported on what happens were you to lose your passport and you stated there was a 24-hour turnaround time. This is not quite accurate.

title: A Tale of 2 Towns
description: IT'S an average size plot of land by Long Island standards, 100 by 130 feet. On it stands an aging two-story house with extra front doors and partitioned-off hallways that indicate it housed far more than the original family who built it. The house, two blocks from where the comedian Eddie Murphy grew up, is being renovated. So are the grounds, which were once a mass of weeds and discarded beer bottles. But on this one-third of an acre in Roosevelt, much more is being repaired than just rotting timbers and an overgrown lawn.

title: No Matter How You Slice It, We Are Big
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich and Foe Spar in Spirited Debate
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and his Democratic opponent, Michael J. Coles, sparred Friday night in a fiery debate in which Mr. Coles blamed Mr. Gingrich for last year's Government shutdowns and Mr. Gingrich repeatedly characterized Mr. Coles as a liberal.

title: You Think Daylight Time Is Hard?
description: WHAT A 25-hour clock. That's no mistake -- each minute is 2.4 seconds shorter. (It's $59.95, plus $5.95 for shipping and handling, from the Circadian Clock Company, P.O. Box 7806, Dallas 75209.)

title: A Virtual Playground in Piccadilly Circus
description: The Trocadero in London's Piccadilly Circus has stepped decisively into the future with the opening of Segaworld, an indoor theme park with hundreds of Sega video games and six virtual-reality rides.

title: It Was Ever Thus
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Florida State Avenges Virginia Loss
description: Florida State got its revenge for its only Atlantic Coast Conference loss ever, but Seminole Coach Bobby Bowden found out that the days when the Seminoles could romp through the A.C.C. are fading.

title: KAREN CARPENTER'S SECOND LIFE
description: After reading Rob Hoerburger's article ''Karen Carpenter's Second Life'' (Oct. 6), I popped a Carpenters tape into the stereo and sang along with my karaoke microphone for the next 40 minutes.

title: The Reluctant Poet
description: ''The Greta Garbo of World Poetry,'' trumpeted a headline in the Italian daily La Repubblica; it has so far been easily the most amusing among the attempts of the news media worldwide to attach some identity tag to this year's Nobel laureate in literature. What makes the comparison genuinely funny is that it's true and untrue at the same time. Those who know Wislawa Szymborska personally will be the first to admit that she indeed has something of the famous Swede's charm and subtlety. Yet her reticence and dislike of being in the spotlight have never turned her into a recluse. Wit, wisdom and warmth are equally important ingredients in the mixture of qualities that makes her so unusual and every poem of hers so unforgettable. We love her poetry because we instinctively feel that its author genuinely (though by no means uncritically) loves us.

title: Oblivious Father
description: A REGULAR GUYBy Mona Simpson.372 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Lehman Widens Gap Between Him And the Rest
description: When he won the British Open in July, Tom Lehman confirmed to the rest of the world something he already knew -- that he had truly become a player. Now, after shooting a flawless round of 64 in the third round of the Tour Championship, he has shown everyone that he is on the verge of becoming golf's player of the year.

title: Shuttered Restaurant May Return, With Smaller Footprint
description: On the southeast corner of 23d Street and 10th Avenue, at the end of a long line of graceful row houses, stands an eyesore -- a shuttered restaurant whose closed cafe juts out onto the sidewalk. Empty since May 1993, it is now a padlocked shack with rotting, peeling wood and spray-painted graffiti.

title: So Which John McSorley Opened That Ale House?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Church Is Restored at Polytechnic
description: A landmark Greek Revival church that was once a shelter for escaped slaves has been restored and turned into a student center at Polytechnic University in downtown Brooklyn.

title: When Superstores Were Truly Super
description: My mother tells me we never shopped at S. Klein's on Union Square. J. W. Mays on 14th Street, yes; Orbach's on 34th Street, yes. And E. J. Korvette's, occasionally, although only after it moved to Fifth Avenue. My mother further reminds me that when we did stop in at discount stores like Mays (as best as I can recall, the jingle went, ''At Mays each day is sale day all day long/And 20 million customers can't be wrong!'') or Orbach's, we shopped only in the exclusive sections where every saleswoman knew us by sight.

title: The Spying Game
description: Secret agencies U.S. Intelligence in a Hostile World.

title: Eva R. Hoffman, Stephen T. Collins
description: Eva Randy Hoffman, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Barnett E. Hoffman of Highland Park, N.J., is to be married today to Stephen Timothy Collins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Timothy Collins of Fenwick Island, Del. Rabbi Yakov R. Hilsenrath is to perform the ceremony at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Miss Vincent, Mr. Mockridge 4th
description: Caroline Talman Vincent, a daughter of Robert C. Vincent Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and Chestertown, Md., and the late Barbara M. Vincent, was married yesterday to Oscar Alling Mockridge 4th, the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Mockridge 3d of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Terence Elsberry performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew in Bedford.

title: THE REHNQUIST REINS
description: The efforts of the Chief Justice to limit habeas corpus appeals in order to uphold the sovereignty of a state seem to ignore the fact that we are one nation and that the rights of one citizen should not be less than the rights of another, merely on the basis of which state has put him in chains. If that were the case, then it could reasonably be argued that any state could deny extradition. Would Rehnquist defend the sovereignty of a state in denying extradition from a non-capital-punishment state to a capital-punishment one? This is a two-edged sword that no sophism can ignore.

title: Jail Killings In Venezuela Reveal Fight For Power
description: The death in a Caracas prison of 25 inmates, burned alive in their cell by National Guardsmen three days ago, has become a lightning rod for the strains and rivalries that lie behind the misery of Venezuela's prison system.

title: A Silent Choir
description: MODERN AMERICAN RELIGIONVolume 3: Under God, Indivisible, 1941-1960.By Martin E. Marty.Illustrated. 548 pp. Chicago:The University of Chicago Press. $34.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 8 about San Francisco hotels referred incorrectly to the Sheraton Palace. A reader's letter dated Sept. 10 points out that Queen Victoria was never a guest there. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: The Tortoise Catches Up
description: If you imagine mutual fund investing as the age-old race between the tortoise and the hare, which would you bet on: high-octane growth funds, which buy shares of companies with rapidly growing earnings, or slow-and-steady value funds, which buy out-of-favor stocks with low valuations?

title: Shift of Second-String Quarterbacks Affects Brown, Too
description: It wasn't so much a statement as it was a warning. Hey Stan, something may be coming down soon. So be ready. And watch your back.

title: Going Bankrupt: The Scarlet 'B' or the Great Escape?
description: Q. I've built up a heavy credit card debt load and can't seem to meet even the minimum monthly payments. Is declaring bankruptcy a practical solution?

title: Consultant Takes Own Marketing Advice
description: ONCE a marketing man, always a marketing man. Kenneth Rockwell, spent more than 20 years as a vice president and marketing director at BBD&O and Carl Ally advertising agencies, later became a marketing consultant and eventually his own client.

title: A Private Enclave Draws a Line in the Sand
description: The sequestered community of Sea Gate, surrounded by fence, white beach and a rocky coastline, has always been private because of its borders. Now, its residents say, a new jut of beach on the neighborhood's edge is compromising the 98-year-old sanctuary.

title: So, Smoking Causes Cancer: This Is News?
description: WAS it really news to anybody, as headlines proclaimed a little more than a week ago, that smoking causes lung cancer?

title: Please Hold, Mr. President
description: Amid the celebration and commotion in the Yankee clubhouse, the White House was calling Joe Torre.

title: Call Him Special; Not, Please, a Specialist
description: MUSICIANS DO not like being called specialists, even though they may invest enormously of themselves to master the music of a particular period, genre or composer. Call me a great Baroque interpreter, the thinking seems to go; just don't label me a Baroque you-know-what.

title: Magnetic North
description: Selected StoriesBy Alice Munro.545 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Hoping for a Fair Telecommunications Giant
description: WHEN the Telecommunications Reform Act of 1996 became law this year, it was touted as a straight shot to a better existence. Legislators and the media rhapsodized about better service, cheaper rates and technological advances. There were some voices, but not many, concerned about unprecedented concentrations of media power.

title: Mariana Nolan, Anthony Geffen
description: Mariana Celeste Nolan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nolan of New York, was married yesterday to Anthony Denis Henry Geffen, a son of Maureen Buckley of London and the late John Geffen. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: U.S. Bridge Team Wins 2
description: Two big victories against strong teams, Britain and Norway, kept American hopes alive here today in the World Bridge Championships, but a loss to Hungary was an unexpected setback.

title: Claire E. Fleming, P. B. Newman 4th
description: Claire Elizabeth Fleming, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Fleming of Philadelphia, was married last evening to Phillip Barbour Newman 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Newman 3d of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Nov. 5 and All That
description: FAITH AND TREASONThe Story of the Gunpowder Plot.By Antonia Fraser.Illustrated. 347 pp. New York:Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $27.95.

title: Government Raises Estimate On Soldiers Exposed to Gas
description: The news seemed grim enough last June when the Pentagon announced that about 350 American soldiers may have been exposed to nerve gas when they blew up an Iraqi ammunition depot in 1991. But the number of potential American victims has grown.

title: Memorials That Forget
description: RONALD REAGAN so loved a good joke, even on himself, that it must be doubly rued that, in his twilight years spent in Alzheimer's suffering, he cannot fully savor the humor in the mammoth Federal office building under construction on Pennsylvania Avenue with his name all over it.

title: Bookshelf
description: ONE POTATO: A Counting Book of Potato Prints. Written and illustrated by Diana Pomeroy. Harcourt Brace. $15. (Ages 3 to 8) The secret to this pretty book about quantities of fruits and vegetables, from the solitary potato to 10 cherries, 40 grapes and 100 sunflower seeds, is that the illustrations were made entirely with potato prints, a technique that youngsters can learn to use from the instructions supplied.

title: dressing dangerously
description: An action thriller in which our heroine risks life and limb to change clothes in a heartbeat.

title: Another View Of a Dog Track
description: Now that the less-than-one-year-old Shoreline Star Greyhound Park and Entertainment Center is about to go belly up (''A Dog Track's Woes Added to a City's,'' Oct. 13), those politicians and business leaders who predicted it would mean economic revitalization for a deteriorating city seem to be nowhere to be quoted.

title: Statement On Jewell
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by United States Attorney Kent Alexander:

title: Gay Leaders Look to the Ballot Box
description: Through decades of fighting discrimination, anti-gay violence and, most recently, AIDS, gay and lesbian New Yorkers learned that often the most effective way to shake up the status quo was through street protests and similar activism. But not until recent years did gay leaders learn to use the ballot box as a vehicle for change.

title: How to Use and Apply the Many Varieties of Solvents
description: A SOLVENT is a substance, usually liquid, that will dissolve another substance. All do-it-yourselfers buy and use a number of solvents. Some are used for cleaning, others to thin paint, shellac or varnish. Choosing the right solvent can make a job easier; using the wrong one can damage tools or a project.

title: Prudent on Peacekeepers
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Newark May Eliminate Rush-Hour Bus Lanes
description: For eight years, Newark's dedicated bus lanes have made life easier and faster for the 55,000 bus riders who pass through the city daily. But this month, the Newark City Council passed a resolution eliminating rush-hour dedicated bus lanes on Market Street and Broad Street from 4 to 6 P.M. Instead, it will permit curbside parking for a 90-day trial.

title: Q. & A.
description: Lists of Foreclosed Homes

title: A Psychiatrist Talks About Social Policy
description: AFTER a career as a child psychiatrist, international consultant and clinical professor of child and adolescent psychiatry at the Yale Child Study Center, Dr. Herbert S. Sacks will become president of the 41,000-member American Psychiatric Association in the spring.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Educating Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: At One With Salmon, As Its Time Runs Out
description: It had rained all afternoon, but it was quiet in the tiny cabin when I awoke from my troubled sleep. Outside, bright tatters of cloud were hung up in the pines on the steep mountainside, and the hale scent of evergreen lay over the Matapedia River. It would be a fine evening for salmon fishing, and suddenly I knew just where I was going -- to my favorite pool, a pool that I had not fished for much too long a time. It isn't a famous pool, nor a grand or breathtaking one. But this pool always has something silver and elusive in it: my memories.

title: The Deadliest Holiday
description: I DIDN'T notice it at first, but my neighborhood is one big kindergarten. It's all those decorations -- the flags and streamers and door art -- that herald each season. We advance from shamrocks, tulips and Easter eggs through beehives, pumpkins and cornucopias before arriving, triumphantly, at Santa Claus and mistletoe.

title: The Swiss and Holocaust Money
description: Switzerland's image of probity took a further knock last week with disclosures that money from the dormant accounts of presumed Holocaust victims had been used to settle compensation disputes with Hungary and Poland.

title: Jamaica to Play Host To Top Chefs in January
description: A four-star faculty of chefs will discuss new trends in cooking, shortcuts in the kitchen and other culinary topics at the Sandals Cooking Academy in Montego Bay, Jamaica, from Jan. 12 to 16. Cooking classes and demonstrations, competitions and tours to local markets will also be on the agenda for the school, which will be held at the Sandals Royal Jamaican Resort.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 13 about upgrading office buildings misidentified the organization responsible for renovating the Empire State Building. It is the Empire State Building Corporation, not W&M Properties.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: YOU ALONE ARE DANCINGBy Brenda Flanagan.University of Michigan, paper, $13.95.

title: Your Mission, Should You Accept It
description: Whoever wins next week's Presidential election will have to immediately launch an intense round of diplomatic negotiations. Sitting across the table from the next President in these negotiations will be the prickliest of foes: some will be Neanderthals who make the Afghan Taliban mullahs seem like progressives; some will be power-mad egomaniacs; only a few will be allies. The President won't need Air Force One to get to these talks, though. The limo will do. He will, however, need a translator. Because the President's first foreign affairs negotiation is going to have to be with the 105th Congress.

title: In Alaska, Thinking of the Island
description: THIS end of the woodpile hasn't seasoned long, but that's all right. If the winter isn't too severe and I keep the house on the cool side, I won't have to touch these rounds. Still, if I split them up maybe they'll dry a tiny bit more in the short time left before freeze-up.

title: Joumana Rizk and Han Yong
description: READING Joumana Rizk's resume might make some people feel they would have to lose 20 pounds, buy couture clothing and start an art collection before even speaking to her.

title: Fordham Snaps 8-Game Skid
description: Fordham scored on its first five possessions yesterday and went on to crush Georgetown, 46-6, for its first victory of the season.

title: Emily B. Mayers, Lance F. Klima
description: Emily Beth Mayers, a daughter of Stephanie and Bruce Mayers of Sands Point, L.I., was married last evening to Lance Frank Klima, the son of Gloria Leidenheimer of Mosspoint, Miss., and Dr. Edward F. Klima of Skaminia, Wash. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Quiet Town Weighs Abolishing Police
description: As far as the police chief here can recall, the last murder in these wooded hills was two summers ago. Once, back in the 80's, a prostitute was arrested for solicitation. And this year, the number of reported rapes stands at two.

title: Black Mark for the F.B.I.
description: The senior ranks of the F.B.I. continue to be haunted by 10 fateful days four years ago on a remote Idaho mountainside known as Ruby Ridge.

title: An Imperfect Game Keeps Buckeyes' Record Perfect
description: Still perfect, but light years from Pasadena on New Year's Day, the Ohio State Buckeyes today exhibited the dominance that makes them a national championship contender and the sloppiness that vexes their following.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: Who Decrees the Country's Good?
description: BRINGING back ''First Lady'' in connection with the Presidential race must have seemed like a sure thing. Someone had to do it. What Yale Repertory didn't count on was the tepidity of the play and the torpidity of the race.

title: Chirac Removes France as Honest Peace Broker
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LOW TIDE IN THE DESERTNevada Stories.By David Kranes.University of Nevada, paper, $15.

title: 2 Taxpayer Groups Endorse Zimmer; 2 Church Organizations Back Torricelli
description: New Jersey's candidates for the United States Senate received key, but unsurprising, endorsements today, as two taxpayer groups announced their support for the Republican candidate, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, while members of two statewide church organizations endorsed the Democratic candidate, Representative Robert G. Torricelli.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a meeting between Presidents Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine referred incorrectly to the resort town of Sochi, the site of an earlier meeting between them. It is in Russia -- not in Crimea, which is a part of Ukraine.

title: Amid an Improving Climate, REITs Grow Steadily
description: I REALLY did not want to do $330 million in acquisitions in one year,'' said Scott Rechler, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Reckson Associates Realty Corporation. ''We really had planned to do only $100 million, but some strategic opportunities became available, so we took them.''

title: Classical Briefs
description: BERLIOZ: 'HAROLD IN ITALY,'

title: Canon Shots
description: The Opening of the American Mind

title: Nancy J. Cohen, David Chamides
description: Nancy Jill Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Cohen of Ventnor, N.J., is to be married today to David William Chamides, the son of Eugene Chamides of Somerset, N.J., and the late Lucia F. Chamides. Rabbi David Posner is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Using Ghouls to Get to God
description: HALLOWEEN is the Devil's holiday. Some Christian churches believe this glorification of evil should be discouraged or stamped out. But others embrace Halloween, slightly adjusted.

title: Welfare Dollars Saved In 'Finger Imaging'
description: A PILOT fingerprinting project to ferret out fraud in welfare payments has saved county taxpayers an estimated $4.2 million since the program started about 18 months ago, a Social Services Department official said recently.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: From Serge With Love
description: Grab this. ALEXANDER NEVSKY is a towering adventure epic from the Soviet Union about a medieval warrior prince who routed barbarian German hoards from his homeland. The star is Nikolai Cherkassov, a real Russian Superman: a handsome aristocratic giant and fine actor. The great Serge Eisenstein directed this 1938 classic with stately tyle and an eye for human detail, including the climactic battle (above) on a frozen Lake Peipus, a sequence that will knock your socks off. Sounding through it all is a marvelous score by Serge Profkofiev. Don't let this masterpiece pass you by - SATURDAY at 7 P.M. on BRAVO.

title: For Both the Arabs and the Israelis, Jerusalem Is Where the Heart Is
description: It is a city with no river, no major airport, not much industry, little strategic significance and too little water. Yet of all the issues separating Jews and Palestinians, none approaches the passions fired by Jerusalem.

title: Copenhagen
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Copenhagen'' by Eric Sjogren (Aug. 25) and wish to add one exhibition not mentioned.

title: After Their Fast Start, the Braves' Luck Goes South
description: It was just one play, but it served as an illustration of how things went so wrong for the Atlanta Braves in the final four games of the 1996 World Series.

title: On Madison Avenue, Sometimes Less Is Less
description: SUDDENLY, WE ARE MINIMALIST TO THE max. After a decade of opulence, goes the theory, we are ready for clean, cool, uncluttered lines, for basics, for escape from the clutches of the overwrought stage sets that have constituted design for so much of the recent past.

title: Paying the Piper, and the Bills, for Salem Nuclear Reactors
description: They were planned before nuclear became a bad word: twin reactors expected to supply cheap, clean energy to New Jersey. It was the late 1970's, before Chernobyl brought fear, and energy deregulation made them less attractive.

title: Matching the Right Apple to the Dish
description: YES, apples do have a season, and that time is now. Apples are the one fruit best if not eaten dead ripe. They can be stored for long periods, but they have the best texture and flavor soon after harvest.

title: Japan's Shaky Coalition
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan won a landmark re-election victory in national elections last week. His Liberal Democratic Party is now by far the biggest political player, but it is still a dozen seats short of a majority in Parliament. And although his party was strengthened, its coalition partners had their wings clipped. Mr. Hashimoto spent the week trying to sustain the three-party coalition that would enable him to form a Government.

title: Color It Black and Orange
description: Do you plan to do anything special to celebrate Halloween? If you're a grown-up, how has Halloween changed since you were a child?

title: Corrections
description: The Word for Word column last Sunday, about a computer user's unsuccessful efforts to get on the Internet, omitted the description of the author, Robert Riche. He is a writer whose most recent novel is ''Poppy & Me, the Last Word on George Bush.'' He lives in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Princetonians in Costume Just Want to Have Fun
description: David Kaley, a Princeton University senior, had to struggle to hide his dark hair under a blond wig and cram his feet into high heels.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Last Happy Occasion

title: Key West
description: A construction boom has been sweeping Key West, the southernmost Florida key, since a arson fire in 1995 destroyed five businesses, including the Copa, its best known gay dance club. Antonia's, a popular restaurant, has reopened in a copy of the landmark building destroyed in the fire. The new Copa opened this month, a mammoth two-story structure with five bars and an outdoor deck overlooking Duval Street, the city's main thoroughfare. Just down the street is a Ripley's Believe It or Not museum, and a Hard Rock cafe was inaugurated Oct. 18.

title: Classical Architecture: Style and Vocabulary
description: The style and vocabulary of classical architecture will be explored next weekend in two days of workshops, lectures and tours sponsored by the Institute for the Study of Classical Architecture.

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Smoltz and Belle: Cream of Free-Agent Crop
description: If someone eagerly gave Kenny Rogers $5 million a year for four years, what would he be willing to give John Smoltz? The pitcher, about to become a free agent, will probably soon find out.

title: The Mood Turns Lush
description: ENTER the martini bar at the Four Seasons Hotel.

title: More Than Just the Fellow With the Peach Baskets
description: The National Basketball Association will unveil its 50th anniversary season this week with a celebration linking the league's past and present. But the roots of basketball go much deeper, and no figure remains more prominent than James Naismith, the sport's founder. One man Naismith deeply affected was John McLendon, one of basketball's most respected coaches, especially at Tennessee State, which from 1957-59 became the first school to win three consecutive National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics titles. In an excerpt from an unpublished autobiography, McLendon talks of his relationship with the legendary Naismith while attending Kansas University more than 60 years ago.

title: BASEBALL'S GLORY DAYS ARE . . . NOW
description: Baseball's glory days may be now, as Allen Barra claims, but does anyone care (''Baseball's Glory Days Are . . . Now,'' Oct. 6)?

title: Consular Help
description: To the Editor: Suzanne Car michael's informative Practical Traveler column, ''Help Abroad in Emergencies'' (Sept. 22) will be welcomed by both first-time and seasoned travelers. Her report presents a comprehensive list of the wide range of emergency services provided to American citizens by their embassies and consulates throughout the world.

title: There Is Still a Task for a Basic Typewriter
description: JUST as the rotary phone is still holding on, so the typewriter clings to life with surprising tenacity.

title: Where Perot Ran Strong, Loyalties Persist
description: Stark is a political swing county where a lot of people -- 25 percent of the voters -- supported Ross Perot for President in 1992. As a result, it is an easy place to find a lot of people who are deserting Mr. Perot in 1996. Their reasons break down into four basic categories.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 32 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the 1946 film ''Great Expectations'' misidentifies the actress shown with John Mills. She is Valerie Hobson, not Jean Simmons.

title: Pulling Rabbits Out of Hats and Other Magic Bits
description: MATTHEW SLAINE of Greenwich stood before his audience, dressed in a flashy red bow tie and suspenders. Before he began his performance, he issued a warning: ''To all you young children out there, don't try this at home.''

title: War Leaves Fatal Scar On Industry In Bosnia
description: In a factory the size of a stadium, in a nearly silent complex that used to crank out 50,000 Volkswagens a year, about 200 of the 9,000 former workers are back.

title: Tides of Change in Troubled St. Petersburg
description: After the arson and violence in this city's streets two nights ago, residents and officials here are just coming to grips with the unrest, which some say underscores the changing character of an area many still regard as a placid, picturesque town.

title: Sound Bites From the Boss
description: AS Election Day draws near, I've been thinking that some of my former colleagues in the corner offices of America's biggest companies may have heard one too many speeches from the men vying for the Oval Office. If so, here's how one such chief executive's annual State of the Corporation Message might sound:

title: Hillary W. Veeder, John W. Dietz
description: Hillary Wood Veeder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Greig Veeder of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to John William Dietz, the son of Judge and Mrs. John Anthony Dietz of Honeoye Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Margaret S. Austin performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh.

title: A RETURN TO GLORY
description: From every poignant moment to every marvelous play to every memorable rally, the Yankees' season unfolded like some unbelievable baseball fairy tale. Again and again, the Yankees outdid themselves in inspiration and in achievement, and last night at Yankee Stadium the Yankees provided a joyous conclusion to their special story last night.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Children's Books
description: BELLE PRATER'S BOY

title: Warring Generations in a Real Estate Dynasty
description: IN Act I of ''Old Business,'' Abe Fleischer, the lord of the real estate sharks, is on the phone with his heir-apparent son, David. The beloved telephone console in Abe's luxury office buzzes in calls from his lawyer and his doctor; most others are put on hold.

title: Shooting Manhattan
description: JOHN WALSH came to New York University's film school as a bright-eyed freshman from Tarrytown, N.Y. Before long he had befriended Sally Roy, a classmate from Hartford who was originally a drama student but switched to film after realizing that a stage career meant she'd have to work nights.

title: Letting the Camera Take Part in the Dance
description: PAUL TAYLOR, THE EMINENT American choreographer, appropriately lives in a house that is eminently American. It is a landmark brownstone in lower Manhattan, and it is not the sort of place where one would find a television in the drawing room. Indeed, the drawing room, with its venerable furniture, carpets and artwork, is not the sort of place in which it feels natural even to mention television.

title: Kurt Freund Dies at 82; Studied Deviant Sexual Arousal
description: Kurt Freund, a psychiatrist who helped make sexual arousal, especially deviant arousal, a subject for serious scientific inquiry by developing a way to measure the penile response to erotic stimuli, died on Wednesday at his home in Toronto. He was 82.

title: California Dreamin'
description: Blue Sky Dream

title: A Winning Hand
description: CYNDY VIOLETTE works weekends only, from late Friday night to early Saturday morning, then from Saturday afternoon sometimes around the clock to late Sunday night.

title: Arrests Add to Idaho's Reputation as a Magnet for Supremacists
description: First, the Aryan Nations arrived in northern Idaho. Then a Christian Identity church moved in. And in 1992, the standoff at Ruby Ridge drew national attention.

title: A Monument To Modesty
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Seeks to End Link Of Mob to Food Markets
description: In a new tactic to combat organized crime's influence at New York City's five major wholesale food markets, the Giuliani administration wants the authority to investigate and ban officials of unions who represent market employees and are suspected of having ties to the mob.

title: Roar Lion Roar
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Courtney Byrne, Allan A. Trent
description: Courtney Elizabeth Byrne, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul I. Byrne Jr. of Old Tappan, N.J., was married yesterday to Allan Alfred Trent, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Trent of Highlands, N.J. The Rev. Clement Cardillo performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange, N.J.

title: In a 'Village' Enclave, 15 Remarkable Rowhouses
description: THINK of a tiny resort village at the end of the summer, like Main Street in Nantucket: The residents breathe a sigh of relief as cold weather arrives.

title: A Player on Teams Ranging From 80 to 3
description: TAKE a breather, soccer moms, while the spotlight seeks out a tiny bloc whose collective vote wouldn't make even a sliver on a pie chart. It's Met moms, the busy Metropolitan Opera soloists with families.

title: By the Way, Giuliani Backs Kemp (and Dole)
description: With a little more than 200 hours left before the Presidential election, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ended months of hand-wringing yesterday and endorsed the Republican Presidential ticket of Jack Kemp and Bob Dole, virtually in that order.

title: Hubert Newcombe Alyea, 93; Made Chemistry a Lively Art
description: Hubert Newcombe Alyea, a professor emeritus of chemistry at Princeton University who invented a method of teaching science and regaled generations of students with his high-spirited ''tricks with Mother Nature,'' died last Saturday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 93.

title: Indeed, Less Is More
description: I CAN'T see it. After test-driving two versions of the redesigned 1997 Toyota Camry, I still can't tell how the midsize family sedan was ''de-contented,'' the auto industry's clunky term for reducing the cost of manufacturing a car.

title: Working for the Community While Working for a Diploma
description: When Beverly Johnson was a middle school student at the Pingry School in Martinsville, she was not exactly thrilled about the community service requirement. ''It was something that people thought was akin to slave labor,'' she said.

title: What's a Conservative?
description: THE WORLD TURNED RIGHT SIDE UP

title: Ecstatic Fans Ask: Does It Get Any Better?
description: Tom Fischetti clutched a small sheet of paper in his right hand as he watched the last outs of the Yankees' clinching World Series victory last night.

title: Hartsdale Man Excels in Home Electronics
description: WHEN he was 6, Albert G. Langella of Hartsdale read a book about Thomas Edison and then tried to reinvent the light bulb. As a second grader at Public School 14 in Yonkers, he won first prize in the science fair by building a two-story electric elevator. Also as a child, by using spare telephone parts, he built his own battery-powered private telephone network for the children in his neighborhood.

title: In the Green Room With a View
description: The White House added the first painting by a black American artist to its permanent collection last week. The landscape by Henry Ossawa Tanner, ''Sand Dunes at Sunset, Atlantic City,'' will hang in the Green Room.

title: Shining a Light on the Mind of a Genius
description: FOR ALL OF ITS SMOOTH, sometimes overheated craftsmanship, Ronald Harwood's ''Taking Sides,'' now at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, accomplishes a feat not often witnessed in our commercial theater: it simultaneously illuminates the complex character of a great artist and preserves the integral mysteriousness of his mind.

title: Practitioner of a Lonely Art
description: WHEN most people picture a poet at work, they think of someone sitting alone in a silent room, writing. And that's not wrong. But for David Shapiro, a Newark-born poet and art critic who teaches art history at William Paterson College, it's only half the story.

title: 3 Contenders In 19th District See Victory As Theirs
description: AS Election Day approaches, the race for Congress in the 19th District remains one of the most highly contested in the New York City and Hudson Valley areas, with each of the three main contenders claiming that victory will be theirs.

title: The Song of the Sirens
description: FORBIDDEN KNOWLEDGE

title: Once Burned, The First Wife Is Twice Shy
description: OLIVIA GOLDSMITH vividly recalls the moment she came to terms with the disintegration of her marriage: it was during a winter's walk 12 years ago along East 77th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues.

title: Garden State? The Image Is Closer to Crab Grass
description: IN HIS LYRICAL, SENTIMENTAL essay ''Here Is New York,'' E. B. White revealed with consummate grace and clarity what most New Yorkers, native or adoptive, seem to understand but do not often express:

title: Elizabeth A. Berns, Douglas R. Korn
description: Elizabeth Anne Berns, the daughter of Dr. Barbara A. Berns and Bertram M. Berns of San Jose, Calif., was married last evening to Douglas Robert Korn, a son of Carole and Ronald Korn of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Michael Shiftan performed the ceremony at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco.

title: Aljancic and Dartmouth Setting Up a Showdown in Ivy
description: Dartmouth 38, Cornell 21

title: Board Can't Unlock Its Deadlock
description: For years, entrenched community school leaders in West Harlem have bickered and sparred among themselves, but rarely have they faced any real opposition. Now, that's changing. In May two incumbents were unseated and in August the board president was removed by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew amid conflict-of-interest charges. For the first time in a decade there is a genuine split on School Board 5.

title: On a Slice of the Whitney Estate, a New Subdivision
description: ALMOST a century after William C. Whitney bought 630 acres here for a country estate, the once-huge holding that lay south of Northern Boulevard and east of Glen Cove Road has dwindled to 10.5 acres. All but one of its many houses and outbuildings have been sold off.

title: Where the Rich Live, and Live Well
description: WITH a straw basket under his arm, Helmut Ludl recently strode through the aisles of the Hay Day market here assembling the weekend's menu: aged beefsteaks, the largest and freshest shrimp money can buy, imported French cheeses, exotic fruits and vegetables and some wickedly delicious treats from the bakery counter. When he finally made his way to the checkout counter, the last concern on the chief executive officer's mind was how much it would cost.

title: For New Haven, a Million-Square-Foot Indoor Mall
description: SEVENTEEN large enclosed malls might be thought to be enough for a small state like Connecticut. But plans are well advanced for a million-square-foot complex in New Haven, facing the harbor at Long Wharf. It is being hailed as the salvation of a city too long becalmed in the economic doldrums.

title: As I Lay Dying
description: This Wild Darkness

title: Items From F.D.R.'s Catalogue
description: It's been said that if Franklin Roosevelt had not become President, he still might be remembered as one of America's greatest collectors. ''He just liked stuff,'' concurs Geoffrey Ward, a Roosevelt biographer. So does Donald S. Carmichael, a corporate executive who began collecting F.D.R. memorabilia in 1932. Now 82, Carmichael sold everything last year to Glenn Horowitz, a rare-book dealer; starting Friday, 129 catalogued items will go on sale at Horowitz's New York gallery. Does this represent a grave loss to the public? Verne Newton, director of the Roosevelt museum at Hyde Park, N.Y., isn't concerned. ''I don't fight over every item,'' he says. ''We'd need a warehouse to hold it all.'' Here's a sampler.

title: In Stamford, a Brew Pub in an Old Bank
description: STAMFORD has a new brew pub downtown, called the Bank Street Brewing Company, and it is not just on Bank Street, it's inside what was once the Citizens Saving Bank.

title: SHIRT RIFT
description: David Winkle's T-shirt reading I'm Not Gay, but My Boyfriend Is'' was too outre for Cedar Point Amusement Park officials, who asked the 20-something Winkle to leave. Now he's back with a $25,000 discrimination suit. The Sandusky, Ohio, park forbids profane shirts, but Scott Schwab, Winkle's lawyer, cites homophobia and uneven monitoring'' of the rules. The latter charge is based on street-level lawyering. On a recent recon mission, Schwab spotted 16 clearly obnoxious shirt slogans, including several that can't be reprinted here. Among the tamer outrages: Coed Naked Firefighting and one we would proudly wear at Mardis Gras--Thank You for Not Projectile Vomiting.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Distant Friends and Intimate Strangers

title: KAREN CARPENTER'S SECOND LIFE
description: Hoerburger gave us a sensitive portrait of Carpenter and her difficulties with anorexia nervosa and bulimia. I wish to add a caution to his comment regarding her use of ipecac. He notes, ''Taken in high quantities, it can cause a potassium deficiency, which can lead to heart arrhythmia.''

title: A Sad Absence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Why Bob Dole Can't Be Reagan
description: TWO summers ago, early in his latest quest for the Presidency, Bob Dole appeared before a gathering of the Republican National Committee. ''I'm willing to be another Ronald Reagan,'' he offered, ''if that's what you want.'' Of the hundreds of thousands of words the candidate has uttered since then, few pack nearly as much irony.

title: How Congress Curtailed the Courts' Jurisdiction
description: WILLIAM E. MORRIS was preparing to argue his first Supreme Court case a few months ago when the winds of change blowing from Washington reached his office at Southern Arizona Legal Aid in Tucson.

title: Postage To-Do: The Flim-Flams Brought by the Mailman
description: SO far this year, the United States Postal Inspection Service has received well over 400,000 complaints about scams in the mail. Last week it released the ''five biggest lies told to consumers,'' a list of the most common ploys used by con artists to fleece the unsuspecting via the mail. Here are excerpts from typical letters. TOM KUNTZ

title: Police Salaries Likely to Move Higher
description: AN arbitrator's decision on a four-year contract for the Suffolk County police ushers in an era of $70,000-a-year officers, upsetting county officials and inspiring predictions that the added expense will lead to tax increases.

title: Showing Wood's Adaptability to Needs
description: A Walk in the Woods

title: Miss Alexiades, Dr. Armenakas
description: Macrene Renee Alexiades, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Alexiades of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Noel Anthony Armenakas, the son of Dr. Anthony E. Armenakas of Brooklyn Heights and Athens, and the late Stella D. Armenaka Bishop Alexios of Troas performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Body Bizarrely Found in Mexico Is Telling No Tales
description: More than two weeks have passed since investigators unearthed a decomposed body on a horse ranch in a cool valley above Mexico City where Raul Salinas de Gortari, the elder brother of the former President, used to jump his thoroughbreds. But they have made no progress in learning who the dead man is or how the body arrived at the site.

title: Deferred Compensation for the Masses: A Plum at a Price
description: AT the upper reaches of corporate America, deferred compensation is all the rage. In this simple but lucrative tax maneuver, senior executives let the company keep some of their pay. They avoid paying taxes until years later, when they get the deferred pay along with the money the company has earned on the funds.

title: Nostalgia for Old Toilet May Be Excessive
description: To the Editor:

title: A Village Where Families Dig In Roots
description: ISLAND PARK, once a vacation spot for city residents, is now a solidly middle-class year-round community where generations of families have dug in roots.

title: Gay, Indeed, But Not for Laughs
description: To the Editor:

title: At Coke, Less Fizz Than Met The Eye
description: In a world where a failure to meet quarterly profit forecasts can be punished brutally by Wall Street, stuffing can seem like a wise, if risky, tactic.

title: Sharon A. McGee, Peter C. Crary
description: Sharon Anastasia McGee, the daughter of Drs. Ellen and Howard McGee of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Christopher Crary, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Crary of Canton, N.Y. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: STOLEN CHILDHOOD

title: THE KINDEST CUT
description: As a woman two months away from her 50th birthday and weeks away from a radical modified mastectomy and reconstruction, I was a prime audience for Bloch's article.

title: Father on Board: Vacation With Caution
description: THERE they lolled in the azure waters off Grand Cayman, the extended family at repose. My stepmother held my 3-year-old son in the gentle shore break. My wife, Cynthia, broke the surface from snorkeling to announce she had just sighted a turtle. And my father, not one to fear ultraviolet rays after 73 years of unprotected tanning, tilted his head toward the sun.

title: The Yankees Got Better And Better
description: THE old champions are the champions once again. For the 23d time since they got the hang of it, the Yankees have won the World Series, this time with a 3-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves last night that could have stopped a few hearts that were not certifiably just out of the shop.

title: There's No Justice
description: Arthur J. GoldbergNew Deal Liberal.By David L. Stebenne.Illustrated. 539 pp. New York:Oxford University Press. $45.

title: Poor Who Qualify Will Get Repairs in Home Heating
description: AS winter approaches, there are those whose homes require more money for heat than they can afford. To ease the fear of frigid nights and chilly days, Westhab, a nonprofit housing-development company, is offering free engery-efficiency evaluations and subsequent repairs to people who meet income requirements.

title: Women in Misery, All in the Name of Beauty
description: IN ''THE WAITING ROOM,'' THREE women from different centuries wait to see a doctor, each seeking a cure for maladies they have endured in the name of ''beauty.'' An 18th-century Chinese woman, whose feet were bound at age 5, has developed gangrene. A tightly corseted Victorian wife suffers from 19th-century hysteria. And an American secretary, who has undergone extensive cosmetic surgery, including breast implants, is told she has cancer.

title: Gauging the Rubin Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: The Answer is National Standards
description: AMONG THE ISSUES THAT CONCERN MOST AMERICANS, EDUCATION HAS MOVED TO THE top of the list, ranking in some polls above the economy, the environment or even crime. Bill Clinton and Bob Dole have made it a major issue in the Presidential campaign, but their oratory has become so similar and so insular as to cloud rather than clarify their differences. The education debate has been reduced to a single issue, ''choice,'' which both candidates have claimed as their own, grabbing on either side of the term and pulling, like two kids with a beach towel in a game of tug of war. But neither candidate is addressing the problems in most classrooms. I learned about them firsthand in 1992 -- from boats.

title: Candidates Both Try to Appear Hawkish on Tax Cuts
description: When it comes to taxes and the Federal budget, Representative Robert G. Torricelli says, there is really little separating him from Representative Richard A. Zimmer, his opponent for the United States Senate seat from New Jersey.

title: THE KINDEST CUT
description: Melissa Bloch suggests that she owes her midlife rejuvenation to a bout with breast cancer and a mastectomy (Lives: ''The Kindest Cut,'' Oct. 6). While I applaud her determination to grab life in the face of her own mortality, I am jarred by the superficial and material focus of this effort. Are we to embrace the prospect of a life-threatening disease as an exciting opportunity to redefine ourselves in the context of tummy tucks, hair dye and spandex? I would have hoped that by 1996 women could achieve a positive self-image without having ''perky'' breasts at 50.

title: Mom. Apple Pie. A Nun?
description: Candidates like to snuggle up to lovable symbols, but Representative Michael Flanagan, a Republican incumbent from Chicago, has worked a bold new totem into his campaign: Mother Teresa. So charge his critics, anyway. Just before Congress adjourned this month, Flanagan pushed through a measure making Mother Teresa an honorary United States citizen, marking only the third time Congress has bestowed its Hon. Cit. decree. Flanagan's opponent, Democratic State Representative Rod Blagojevich, is calling it awfully cute stuff for a politician whose North Chicago district holds America's second-largest Catholic archdiocese. This must be said carefully, however. A spokesman for Blagojevich calls Mother Teresa ''a wonderful person,'' but quickly adds, ''Would Mother Teresa support cutting heating assistance to the poor?''

title: School District 15, Shockwaves Over an October Surprise
description: For nearly nine years, as superintendent of Community School District 15, William Casey acquired a reputation for raising test scores and securing outside grants. Now a majority on the newly -elected school board has agreed to solicit applications for his job.

title: Art D'Lugoff Lands on His Feet
description: ON 52d Street, known in the 1940's as Swing Street for its many jazz clubs, the latest -- and only -- nightclub is jumping. Inside, behind a new brownstone exterior reminiscent of the street's jazz heyday, a bearded man pounds the linen-covered table in front of him with his open right hand and lustily croaks a Beatles refrain along with the singers on stage.

title: The Title Is From Dickens, The Look From Donna Karan
description: NIGHTFALL HAS advanced under the vaulted entrance to the Chambers Street subway station. In the semi-darkness a gang of urchins, sauntering through, is diverted by a table brimming with meats and pastries, cheeses and fruits.

title: Female Trainer Breaks Ground
description: For the past three years, Lit de Justice had been the mischievous kid you want to get mad at, but simply cannot. He was so talented, and so playful, that his frequent flashes of brilliance helped offset his obstinate personality.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Health Nut?

title: Justices Defer a Review
description: When the awkward political compromise known as ''don't ask, don't tell'' became official Government policy toward homosexuals in the military, Lieut. Paul G. Thomasson, a 10-year Navy veteran and highly rated pilot, decided to tell. More than two years later, he is managing a Washington restaurant.

title: Collaboration on Chapin Album
description: A STUFFED teddy bear sits on the seven-foot-wide grand piano in Jon Cobert's living room here, and a bust of Beethoven overlooks an array of electronic musical equipment downstairs in his home studio. These seeming incongruities are more appropriate than they appear at first glance because Mr. Cobert, originally a student of classical music, has performed in concerts and on albums for children and adults with the folk singer Tom Chapin. He has also composed and played hundreds of advertising jingles.

title: John A. Cook Psychoanalyst, 85
description: John A. Cook, an investment banker turned doctor, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Selig, Contradicting Negotiators, Says There Is No Deal
description: The players' labor leader publicly acknowledged for the first time yesterday that he and the owners' chief negotiator have reached a deal on a new collective bargaining agreement, then clearly placed the onus for the future of the deal on Bud Selig.

title: Classical Briefs
description: CHARPENTIER: 'MESSE DE MINUIT POUR NOEL,' OTHER WORKS

title: Attracting Bird Life
description: ALTHOUGH most of the songbirds have flown to warmer climes by now, much of the avian population is hanging around for the winter, some having come down from more northerly areas.

title: War Against a Beach Campaign
description: Anne Winkler is one of those dedicated ocean lovers who lives on the beach year round and would never dream of abandoning her three-story, cream-shingled house, even as the beach around her drops away and storms bring water through her doorway.

title: Recitals to Open in Riverdale House
description: HOME, church and school are pillars of American life, and this week they yield bountiful music. Today at 2 P.M. a private Georgian-style residence overlooking the Hudson in Riverdale is the setting for Chamber Music in Great Homes, the first of four recitals sponsored by the Bronx Arts Ensemble. The Vivaldi-Granados-Brahms program features the oboist Ariana Ghez, winner of the ensemble's 1996 Young Artists Competition, the guitar duo of Jose Gonzalez and Rafael Picorelli and the pianist Allison Brewster Franzetti. For location and reservations, call (718) 601-7399.

title: Apples of the Season, Used in Main Dishes
description: YES, apples do have a season, and that time is now. Apples are the one fruit best if not eaten dead ripe. They can be stored for long periods but they have the best texture and flavor soon after harvest.

title: Old-Time Neighborliness in a Memphis Development
description: THIS city's top tourist draw may always be Elvis, but people more fascinated by houses and community design have been coming to see a different kind of attraction: Harbor Town, a 130-acre development that seeks to re-create some of the sociable traits of places built 70 to 100 years ago.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Jury Duty (Screen Div.)

title: A G.O.P. Stronghold Starts to Lean Toward the Democrats
description: The sugar maples that line the roads here are a blaze of gold and red. The farmhouse where Robert Frost once lived and wrote poems has closed to visitors for the season. So has Clam Haven, the seafood shack down the road.

title: All Roads Lead to Mintz
description: THE MIDAFTERNOON SUN SLANTS across the kitchen table, illuminating a basket of ripe cherry tomatoes and the pestle with which Sidney Mintz has crushed a handful of cardamom pods. He settles into a chair and carefully arranges two paper towels under his hands. He begins peeling and husking, sending a wave of the cardamom's peppery lavender scent across his kitchen in Baltimore.

title: Sea Changes In Insuring By the Coast
description: WHILE the winds of Hurricane Andrew, which decimated parts of south Florida four years ago, have long disappeared from the weather map, they are still affecting homeowners who were fortunate enough to have avoided them the first time around.

title: Untangling New York's Housing Web
description: A RECENT series in The New York Times documented in heart-rending detail the squalor in which many low-income New Yorkers are forced to live (''Barely Four Walls: Housing's Hidden Crisis,'' Oct. 6-11).

title: Popping Corks, Tears And a Man on a Horse
description: In the end only George Steinbrenner had any tears left to shed.

title: Of Pound-Sweets and a Tipsy Woodchuck
description: OPALESCENTS, Russets, Northern Spies, Sheepnoses and Twenty-Ouncers. These are just a few of the apples that people once munched, or put into pies and sauces. Today the orchards where such apples grow are fewer, and commercial orchards are filled mostly with what have become standard varieties, like McIntoshes and Macouns.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: CRUISE

title: My Kingdom For a Hearse
description: OPHELIA will sing her mad lament behind a bar as Lady Macbeth scrubs damn spots from her hands at a nearby sink when the Faux-Real Theater Company stages ''William Shakespeare's Haunted House.''

title: Bias and Blood Pressure
description: Racial discrimination, and how people react to it, appears to be an important influence on high blood pressure among blacks, according to a study by researchers from the Harvard School of Public Health and the Kaiser Foundation Research Institute.

title: Study of Personal Chaos Offered by Fleetwood
description: DAVID is the social reformer whose dreams of bettering the world -- a scheme to redevelop a slum in South London -- shut out bureaucratic reality, historical portents and human aftershock. Jane, his wife, is an anthropologist who would rather study people than help them.

title: Gourd Family, Warts and All: A Genial Expose
description: Every year, I like to grow some weird plant, and now I have luffa gourds drying on a fence at the family farm in Maryland. I always thought luffa sponges -- those bristly things so good for reaching your back and giving the whole body a vigorous rubdown -- were found in the ocean. They just look like something that would float around with the jellyfish and the seaweed.

title: Robert Stovall Jr., Kathleen Brennan
description: Kathleen Brennan and Robert Henry Stovall Jr. were married yesterday in New York. Msgr. Lawrence M. Connaughton performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church of Yorkville.

title: Nancy J. Perry, Gregory Graham
description: Nancy Jean Perry, a magazine editor, and Gregory Frank Graham, a chef, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Mark Hallinan performed the ceremony.

title: Harold Feinberg, 74; Conducted Studies On Protecting Heart
description: Harold Feinberg, a professor of pharmacology who conducted early studies of basic biological mechanisms that protect the heart during open heart surgery, died on Oct. 11 at the University of Illinois Hospital in Chicago. He was 74 and lived in Chicago.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: DIARY
description: LOOKING FOR NO. 1

title: Eating Well In The Tropics
description: ''YOU don't go to the Caribbean for the food.'' I've made the excuse for years. So what if it's Mount Gay rather than merlot? Canned peas rather than mesclun? That was before my husband, daughter, son-in-law and I went to Anguilla last winter.

title: Easing the Re-Use of Once-Polluted Industrial Sites
description: FOR the last 12 years the big industrial plant on Finderne Avenue in the Somerset County community of Bridgewater has sat vacant, idled by time and environmental concerns.

title: How the Money Was Spent in Previous Environmental Bond Acts
description: WITH a bond act to clean water and air on the ballot for Nov. 5, questions are being raised about the state's record with previous environmental bonds.

title: Blessed Ease, Sweet Privay
description: AT about 5 P.M. on my first full day at Petit St. Vincent, I stood on the hilltop deck of cottage 21 -- a glass of cold white wine in hand, gentle ocean breezes in my face, looking at the Atlantic Ocean and listening to its tranquilizing roar and the rustle of tropical leaves -- and decided to make a journal entry. I wrote, ''Don't tell me this isn't worth $550 a day.'' That day, the only human beings I had come in contact with were two room service waiters, a housekeeper and one fellow guest, who happened to be taking an afternoon walk on the beach at the same time I was. We had smiled and nodded.

title: India's Caste System Bears Legal Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: What Makes a Toy Fun? Ask a Child Who Wants to Own It
description: Dressed like a big sister home from high school, Amy Pace asked six 5-year-old girls what their favorite colors were.

title: Spiritual Signposts
description: CHASING GRACEReflections of a Catholic Girl, Grown Up.By Martha Manning.225 pp. San Francisco: HarperSanFrancisco. $20.

title: Mexico, Both Sides of the Border, From the Century's First Half
description: TRAVEL to new territory sometimes prompts artists to change their styles radically. What most often occurs, however, is a variation of the way an artist has typically worked. Primarily it's the addition of local color in all senses of the term -- and that situation is much in evidence in ''Modernists in (New) Mexico'' at the Whitney Museum branch in Stamford.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SIMON WIESENTHAL

title: Angela David, Thomas Beatty
description: Angela Marie Flores David, a daughter of Dr. Maria Luisa Flores and Dr. Eriberto T. David, both of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday to Thomas Joseph Beatty, a son of Josephine Beatty of Granby, Conn., and John Beatty of Manchester, Conn. The Rev. William Dean performed the ceremony at Olde St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A question for: William Joyce
description: William Joyce, a writer and illustrator whose children's books have sold half a million copies, worked on the design team for ''Toy Story.'' His most recent book is ''The Leaf Men,'' published by HarperCollins.

title: Mississippi Sludge
description: UPROAR AT DANCING RABBIT CREEK

title: William C. Bark, 87, A Stanford Professor
description: William Carroll Bark, professor emeritus of medieval history at Stanford University, died on Oct. 11 at a convalescent home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 87 and lived on the Stanford campus.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 6 about companies conducting business on the Internet misstated the World Wide Web address for WebToad Advertising of Hartford. It is:

title: Are These Changes Necessary?
description: Your company has hired consultants to fix the damage you didn't think you caused. But you never know. It could be months before they announce their findings and distribute the blame. What happened when consultants came to your office? Did you or anyone else head for the exits? And did your bosses take the consultants' recommendations seriously? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Menu That Changes With the Seasons
description: ONCE a restaurant is established, many owners assume they can walk away and take the well-earned break. Few businesses are as unforgiving as restaurants, and owners who devote fewer than almost all their waking hours to their work is the sure way to financial disaster. And so it is heartening to find Goldie's in its sixth year. It was a hit when it opened and it has remained so clearly because of Deborah Goldstein -- Goldie herself, a hands-on owner, always there to see that the place stays that way.

title: INSIDE
description: Death of an Afghan Village

title: KAREN CARPENTER'S SECOND LIFE
description: I don't know if I will purchase Karen Carpenter's ''new'' album. I feel her best work was with her very controlling, genius brother, and I'd like to remember her for many of the most beautiful (albeit, some of them trite) songs ever recorded. ''Rainy Days and Mondays'' is possibly the finest ''pop blues'' song of all time.

title: Two Paths That Clash on the Playing Field
description: With the Dallas Cowboys clashing with the Miami Dolphins today, with Jimmy Johnson and Jerry Jones igniting a new phase of their rivalry, the past week has been full of reflection for two men bound together by their insatiable desire to win and by strong-willed personalities that make them more alike than different.

title: One Juliet Has the Vapors, Another Packs a Gun
description: THE EVENING NEWS COMES ON. The anchor reads the lead story: Two teen-agers have committed suicide. Their parents had been enemies for years.

title: Phoenix Theater Shuts Doors but Will It Be Able to Open Again?
description: THE audience had been seated for a half-hour, waiting for the show to go on. Backstage, five members of the technical crew, owed back pay, decreed that it would not. It did not. The crew went home. So did the audience.

title: Samuelsson Out for Six Weeks
description: In the wake of the Rangers' penalty-killing nightmare of a game against Florida, the team now must do without one of its top defenders for at least six weeks.

title: Clinton Co-opts Crime Issue, With Emphasis on Victims' Rights
description: President Clinton challenged states today to do more to help victims of gang-related violence, suggesting they earmark 10 percent of new Federal money available for victim services -- or about $44 million -- for that purpose.

title: I Need This Job: Commuting to the Stage
description: A BIG satchel in one hand and a plastic mug of strong tea balanced in the other, Lisa Monacelli, 25, hurried from the house she shares with her fiance in Bloomfield. It was a cold morning, and she was dressed in layers: long print skirt, heavy socks, baggy gray sweatshirt, sweater, jacket and boots. Her curly black hair was pinned back.
