title: Lighting The Way Into A Sense Of Space
description: THE HOUSE LIGHTS DIM. The stage becomes the arena where life takes hold and grows and changes. Sharply defined or radiating light, bodies inhabit a sudden early morning or a dark theatrical night, in a green jungle, on a hectic city sidewalk or in some hidden place of memory or the soul. And somewhere in real time, a choreographer and a lighting designer have worked hard to create that moment loaded with information and filled with casual grace.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday with an article about efforts by the Greater Brownsville Youth Council to educate young people about drug use and AIDS misidentified two people pictured. The woman at the left was Jesenia Casiano, a senior peer educator with the council. The man at the center, looking at a brochure from the council, was unidentifed.

title: Blankets That Tell The Tales Of Their People
description: GEORGE GUSTAV HEYE HAD an irrepressible appetite for American Indian art. An electrical engineer and heir to a Standard Oil fortune, he spent much of his wealth amassing a million objects. Today, a century after Heye began buying them and nearly 40 years after his death, some of the rarest and most beautiful of his pieces are being exhibited for the first time.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted last Sunday for a picture with an article about the caste system in India. The photographer was Robin Grauband.

title: U.S. Must Stop Exporting the Tobacco Plague
description: To the Editor:

title: Commissary Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO MAKE A PH.D. MATTER
description: Readers who have written to complain about my article on the oversupply of Ph.D.'s take the view that the market will solve this problem (''How to Make a Ph.D. Matter,'' Sept. 22). People have been saying that for 20 years. The market hasn't solved the problem, and the reason is that more and more people want a graduate education, whether they become professors at the end of it or not. Why not welcome these students by making graduate school a more focused, affordable and humane experience? Some people worry that three years of intensive course work is insufficient to prepare students for scholarship. Fine. Add on a fourth year of directed research. But eight years is too much.

title: WILD ABOUT FUR
description: You think you're obsessive about your Halloween costume? Meet A.J. Skunk, the anthropomorphic alter ego of James Firmiss, a 30-year-old doctoral candidate at the University of Wisconsin. Firmiss is part of a growing national subculture of furry-suit hobbyists who don pelts, whiskers and tails year-round. They hold conventions -- ''conFURences'' -- and use the Internet to swap stories about the fun of role playing as otters, foxes and beavers. What's the payoff? The cathartic release of a hidden self, says Firmiss, who will strut his skunky stuff Thursday in downtown Madison, Wis. ''The biggest difference between A.J. and me,'' he says, ''aside from the fact that we're not the same species, is that A.J. is more expressive about his emotions.''

title: THE REHNQUIST REINS
description: Your comparison of Antonin Scalia with the ''sad career of another brilliant judicial failure, Felix Frankfurter,'' seemed unfair to both judges. And certainly Scalia's endorsement of Frankfurter's adherence to the doctrine of judicial restraint (that divisive social issues almost always should be deferred to Congress, other legislatures and the people for their resolution as ''political questions'') ought not have subjected Scalia to your characterization of him as ''one angry man.''

title: How to Use And Apply Solvents
description: A SOLVENT is a substance, usually liquid, that will dissolve another substance. All do-it-yourselfers buy and use a number of solvents. Some are used for cleaning, others for use as paint, shellac or varnish thinners. Choosing the right solvent can make a job easier; using the wrong one can damage tools or a work project.

title: Spending for Open Land Lags, a Report Says
description: Connecticut ranks next to last among 11 Northeast states in the percentage of its land preserved for open space, according to a new report by a coalition of conservation groups.

title: 'At Least Our Students Come to Class'
description: YOUR article on University Heights High School (''Forget Pearl Harbor,'' Oct. 6), where I teach, was structured to highlight a national debate about what to teach and how to achieve high standards. There is a lot more to be heard, seen and experienced at the school than you describe.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: WITH special effects so routine these days, it's fascinating to see the impact they have on four outstanding older movies this week.

title: Warlord's Son Pursues Peace as a Rector
description: Founded in 1702 by the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts as a mission of the Church of England, St. George's Parish could have hardly imagined itself conquered by a Chinese-American rector some 300 years later .

title: Mentoring to Go On Despite Crash
description: ANGEL R. is grieving. The 13-year-old boy is a resident at Abbott House, a center for troubled youths situated on about 16 acres here.

title: George Clinton, the Reigning Hippie of Funk
description: WHEN JERRY GARCIA died last year and the Grateful Dead disbanded shortly thereafter, the question arose as to who would inherit the band's legacy of freewheeling, anything-goes music. Jam bands like Phish, Blues Traveler and God Street Wine, with their hippielike following of young fans, are certainly among the contenders. Perhaps the most unlikely candidate is the legendary George Clinton and his P-Funk All-Stars.

title: THE BODY POLITIC
description: Moore needs to look at the wives of our candidates with a less jaundiced eye. I would call Hillary Clinton hip -- her look is sure, smart and chic; Tipper Gore, jaunty and concerned; Elizabeth Dole, matronly and nice; Joanne Kemp, athletic and sharp.

title: Gauging the Rubin Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: 'We Can Handle This'
description: Life as We Know It

title: Kate B. Enroth, Dana L. Schmaltz
description: Kate Bower Enroth, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Dana Larkin Schmaltz, an associate at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the New York investment bank. The Rev. Andrew F. Kline performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Thomas in Hanover, N.H.

title: Crime
description: Contrary to popular notions about the tastes of upper-class English gentlemen in the stuffy age of Queen Victoria, the most attractive and eligible men in Anne Perry's historical mysteries seem bored with decorative, submissive beauties. They're at it again in WEIGHED IN THE BALANCE (Fawcett Columbine, $23), passing up the dolls in favor of exotic creatures like Countess Zorah Rostova, an expatriate noblewoman who comes to Sir Oliver Rathbone with the accusation that an exiled prince of her obscure German principality has been murdered by the woman for whom he renounced his crown. Bowled over by ''the laughter and the intelligence in her . . . the sheer vibrancy of her character,'' the besotted solicitor hires William Monk (''a private investigator of other people's sins and troubles'') to save Countess Zorah from a slander case by looking into her shocking allegation.

title: In a Different Guise
description: To the Editor:

title: Tropical Gothic
description: THE GARDEN OF THE PEACOCKSBy Anthony Weller.290 pp. New York:Marlowe & Company. $22.95.

title: Boggs Takes a Ride
description: Wade Boggs was not the star of the game as the Yankees won the World Series last night, but he was the obvious star of the post-game. Boggs's impromptu decision to join a police officer aboard his horse made him the most daring and most recognizable Yankee during a memorable post-game gallop around the rollicking Yankee Stadium.

title: Bench Congestion Draws Tickets
description: The latest illegal scourge in Greenwich Village, prompting ticketing blitzes and heated community meetings? The bench.

title: Buyer's Goal at Parkchester: Restoration of a Mini-City
description: ''I HOPE they'll be fair and honest,'' said Mary Ann Wright.

title: Comeback Is Complete: Yanks Win the Series
description: Ending years of futility and self-doubt, the Yankees defeated the Atlanta Braves 3-2 in a taut thriller last night to win their first World Series title in 18 years.

title: An Old Autograph Book And an Un4got10 Rose
description: THIS was going to be my redemption. Forty-five years after I had been too shy to ask many of the girls to sign my blue, zippered, leatherette autograph album, I would have a second chance. That special class for the gifted and fat, which bonded forever at Stephen A. Halsey Junior High School 157, Queens, was reuniting.

title: So Which John McSorley Opened That Ale House?
description: To the Editor:

title: L.H. Weinstein, 91, Advocate for Jews
description: Lewis H. Weinstein, a retired lawyer and advocate of Jewish causes, died on Wednesday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.

title: Bus Garage Setting to Reflect Grass-Roots Theme at Arts Gala
description: IT is that time of year again: the Westchester Arts Council is preparing for its yearly gala. Every fall, those who follow such things begin wondering: where will the council hold its dinner dance this time, and what will the theme be?

title: If They Look Familiar, It's Because They Are
description: YOU KNOW THEM. The minute they show up on screen you recognize their faces, those wonderfully expressive yet Everyman faces that make such an indelible imprint on the celluloid landscape. You can't recall their names, but you're positive you've seen them before -- and you probably have.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: I Am DangerousStories.By Greg Johnson.Johns Hopkins University, cloth, $35; paper, $13.95.

title: Hank Williams. Garth Brooks. BR5-49?
description: LATE ONE AFTERNOON IN AUGUST 1995, TIM DUBOIS AND THE FOLKS AT THE Arista/Nashville record company began trickling into Robert's Western World, a combination honky tonk and seedy boot store with ridiculous, turquoise-colored booths and ancient bar stools in sunflower patterns. DuBois, a former songwriter (''She Got the Gold Mine -- I Got the Shaft''), senior financial analyst at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas and accounting professor, sat at the first table sipping a Miller Lite and staring at the ratty blue stage where five young musicians in Salvation Army Western wear were ripping through a manic set of primordial rockabilly and country music from the 40's, 50's and 60's. The music was so antediluvian that today's slick country radio would find most of it as alien as a Kurdish folk song.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-14

title: Cooling Off on Barbados
description: I AM one of those pale New Englanders who loves water and seacoasts, but isn't much of a beach person. So when my husband suggested that we take our baby daughter and visit the Caribbean island of Barbados for our winter vacation in February, I tried to persuade him to consider someplace slightly less tropical, like Norway or Denmark.

title: A Celebration of Crafts In Philadelphia
description: The 20th Annual Philadelphia Museum of Art Craft Show, an exhibition and sale of crafts by over 200 artists, will be held at the Pennsylvania Convention Center from Nov. 6 to 10. Proceeds will be used to buy works for the museum's permanent collection, to pay for conservation projects, and to support special exhibitions and programs.

title: Two for the Color, and Recycled Objects
description: MELISSA BARBIERI, an artist who lives in Greenwich, trained as a classical portraitist in the Italian Renaissance style and derives her greatest satisfaction from painting religious and other heroically inspired figures on giant, stretch canvases.

title: Scary Duds and Sweet Teeth
description: Thursday is trick-or-treat night. Here's what some staples of the holiday are selling for around the city:

title: What Airlines Owe Passengers
description: FLIGHT delays and cancellations are the Achilles' heel of air travelers, annoying inconveniences exacerbated by airlines that are not always forthright about what they will or can do for stranded passengers. Although no Federal law mandates specific remedies for delayed or canceled flights, airlines offer an assortment of so-called ''amenities'' from securing seats on their next flight or that of another airline, to free or discounted hotel rooms, meals, phone calls and other services.

title: Julia A. McGrath, M. T. McTernan
description: Julia Ann McGrath, the daughter of the late Barbara and James McGrath, was married yesterday to Michael Thomas McTernan, a son of Catherine and James McTernan of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Raymond Byrne, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church in Point Lookout, L.I.

title: Yankees Discover That Maddux Is Human
description: Who said Greg Maddux doesn't need outfielders? Who said he wears a blue-and-red costume with a cape and the letter ''S'' on his chest?

title: Only One Symbol?
description: To the Editor: On the Practical Traveler column dealing with accidents and hijacking of planes (Sept. 29), the illustration showed tombstones with crosses.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: The Same Comfort Food, Minus the Grunge Decor

title: Passport Office Adds A '900' Phone Number
description: The demand for passports, new and renewed, continues unabated, setting records each quarter, which means that busy signals and people left hanging on the 15 regional telephone lines are also on the increase. Faced with this overload, the Passport Office of the State Department is taking a new route. Information will be easier to get, but the applicant will pay for it, by using a 900 phone number. The State Department goal is to have the service support itself through the 900-number charges.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WILD WEST SHOWS AND THE IMAGES OF AMERICAN INDIANS, 1883-1933

title: BIll Clinton for President
description: Today we endorse the re-election of President Bill Clinton. Readers of this page will know that we share many of the public's concerns about Mr. Clinton's resoluteness and sensitivity to ethical standards in government. But our endorsement is delivered in the unequivocal confidence that he is the best candidate in the field and in the belief that because he has grown in the job he can build on the successes of his first term while correcting its defects. Toward that end, our endorsement comes with a set of recommendations for how Mr. Clinton can, before Election Day, address voters' concerns about his personality and character.

title: Going the Distance Against AIDS
description: CARPINTERIA, Calif.

title: Duty Calls: Here a Fire, There a Flood
description: WHO Ralph Tamcordo, 39.

title: Bedtime for Bozo
description: Like millions of Americans, I grew up loving clowns. I loved going to the circus as a child and watching clowns get mercilessly yet painlessly bopped on the head by swinging buckets and out-of-control ladders. I can still remember the feeling of horror -- mixed with secret delight -- the first time I saw a clown threaten to toss water onto a crowd, only to throw confetti instead. And when, as an adolescent, I first learned to juggle (with a handful of oranges that soon turned to pulp), it was a defining moment of my life. Suddenly I was on the other side of the illusion.

title: Albanians, Cash-Poor, Scheming To Get Rich
description: Gjergi Peci, a poet and translator, sat in his easy chair and explained how, like hundreds of thousands of his countrymen, he could afford to relax, not work too hard and even buy a grander place in the future.

title: Nancy Brennan, Robert D. Wintz
description: Nancy Carol Brennan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Brennan of Fairport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Dillon Wintz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Wintz of Convent Station, N.J. The Very Rev. Dr. James Annand performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HALLOWEEN SPIRIT

title: Rewarding Creativity And Deeds Well Done
description: Honors galore for the worlds of art, dance, design and community relations.

title: So Many Quarters, So Little Time
description: THE Mohegan Sun opened just over two weeks ago, but Dorothy Martin has already scoped out her lucky slot machines. She found two in the Summer Pavilion, under the foam rubber trees, and a few more in the heart of Winter. ''This is my favorite so far,'' she says, perched on the edge of her stool in the Summer Pavilion. She won $10 on the first quarter token she fed into this machine, $5 with her second-favorite slot. These are sure signs of good things to come. ''Oh, saying that might jinx it,'' she says with a Phyllis Diller laugh.

title: The Road To the Title
description: IN THE REGULAR SEASON, THE YANKEES' TRADEMARK WAS simple: Grab the lead and hold onto it. That's what they did in the American League East race, where they took over first place in April and never let go. That's what they did in the late innings of game after game, with Mariano Rivera and John Wetteland never letting the other team catch up.

title: Manipulation in a Most Deliciously Spooky Way
description: IF a ghost play trades in the unexpected, then ''The Woman in Black'' comes as a surprise twice over. For Stephen Mallatratt's adaptation of Susan Hill's novel, which has been running in London more than eight years, is less a matter of plot and denouement, of thrills and chills, than an exercise in style and set-up.

title: Elusive Heels To Click Together
description: Accessories are picking up where minimal fashion leaves off, and Prada's new shoe design has stolen the spotlight. The richly embroidered, flower-appliqued shoes with an antique leather finish are so successful that they have become extremely hard to find; they sold out in the designer's 65 boutiques worldwide within a week. And replacements are coming in a trickle because the elaborate workmanship makes production slow. The shoes come in four styles, but the most popular are the Mary Janes. Women stopped on the street both in New York and in Paris spoke of finding the shoes as if they had won the lottery. One woman from New York, after an elaborate search, found hers in a Texas store. A woman in Paris said she snatched up the only pair in a Prada shop there, even though the shoes were a size too small. And on Tuesday, a woman who had waited two months paid her $510 and rushed out of the Prada shop on East 57th Street, proudly holding up her treasure. Can the knockoffs be far behind?

title: An Afghan Village, Destroyed at the Hands of Men Who Vowed Peace
description: In a country where at least 10,000 villages have been bombed, shelled and burned into rubble, the razing of one more hamlet can pass almost unnoticed. For hundreds of thousands of Afghan families who have lost their homes, the anonymity of the loss only adds to the pain.

title: Suspense Is Over: Wetteland Named the M.V.P.
description: The Yankees, who tried to convince the world all season that a most valuable player could have two heads, saw one of their nominees honored last night as the most valuable player of the World Series.

title: Genia Robinor, Pianist, 95
description: Genia Robinor, a pianist and teacher, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 95 and lived in Manhattan.

title: D-I-V-O-R-C-E ... N.Y.
description: 1. New York's Divorce Magazine, making its

title: Ms. Churchill, Mr. Gomez
description: Rebecca Anne Churchill, the daughter of Marcia Knott Churchill of Arlington, Va., and Neil E. Churchill of Doylestown, Pa., was married yesterday to Laurence Michael Gomez, the son of Roberta B. Honig of Brooklyn and the late Ronald H. Gomez. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: The Key to Rebecca
description: REBECCA WESTA Life.By Carl Rollyson.Illustrated. 511 pp. New York: Scribner. $35.

title: So Which John McSorley Opened That Ale House?
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Twist: Spread the Wealth
description: Even though he is not running for office, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York has already raised $6.7 million for his next campaign. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat in a Brooklyn district considered safe, has a war chest of $4.4 million -- the biggest in the House. And in Louisiana, Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, who faces no opposition, has $743,000 on hand and is giving much of it to other Republican candidates.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 1 about the Silent March, a demonstration in Washington against gun violence, with shoes of victims laid out in front of the Capitol, misidentified the sponsor. It was the Committee for the Silent March, not Americans Against Gun Violence.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about political donations to the Dole campaign by noncitizens reversed the identities of the Fanjul brothers of Palm Beach, Fla. Jose Fanjul, not Alfonso, served as vice chairman of Bob Dole's primary finance committee and is a Republican Party contributor. Alfonso is a Democratic Party supporter.

title: Can Nudity Be Speech? What a Jury Concluded
description: Depending on whom you ask, the question in front of the jury this week in the People v. Shilling and Moore was either an open-and-shut misdemeanor case or a challenge to the First Amendment.

title: Sarah Hall, Eric Zohn
description: Sarah Hall is to be married today to Eric Zohn. The Rev. Susan Marlan, an interfaith minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Well, Palestinians Enjoyed His Visit
description: HAD he been the president of any country other than France, Jacques Chirac might have provoked considerably more fury in Israel.

title: Burned Firefighter Wins Lawsuit Claiming Gear Was Inadequate
description: In a decision that could force New York City to pay several million dollars in damages to firefighters hurt on the job, the state's highest court has let stand a verdict in which a Queens firefighter was awarded $400,000 for severe burns suffered because the Fire Department did not provide him with fire-resistant overalls.

title: A Yellow Light Is Blinking For a Sizzling I.P.O. Market
description: DESPITE a splash of cold water this summer, the market for initial public offerings is threatening to boil over again. And that means investors who are not careful may get burned. For, among this year's record number of new ventures, there are many that have little to show in sales or profits, but carry big price tags nonetheless.

title: Miss Holahan and Mr. Beall
description: Eileen Susan Holahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Holahan of Lakewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew Lester Beall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Beall of Shutesberry, Mass. The Rev. David Brown, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony in the William Spencer Boyd Memorial Chapel at the Asheville (N.C.) School.

title: The Boy Who Would Be President
description: GOOD EVENING MR. & MRS. AMERICA, AND ALL THE SHIPS AT SEA

title: Trouble Spots on the Roadways to Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Brooks O. Bishop, Allison A. Ritch
description: Allison Adair Ritch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Ritch of Kissimmee, Fla., was married yesterday to Brooks Osborn Bishop, the son of Mrs. Wynant D. Vanderpoel 3d of New York and Warner B. Bishop of Cleveland. The Rev. Donal Curran officiated at All Saints Episcopal Church in Winter Park, Fla.

title: Time to Make the Dumplings
description: Clean, subtle Cantonese; oil-strong Hunan; spicy Sichuan: these cooking styles have had their New York moments. But with Shanghai emerging as one of the most powerful cities in the world, the culinary trend of the moment in New York's Chinese restaurants is Shanghai's rich, bold cuisine. And its hallmark is xiao long bao, or soup dumplings: delicate pouches that, almost magically, hold a mouthful of scalding, savory soup as well as a pork meatball. Sometimes, they are flavored with crab.

title: F.B.I. Asks Families of Crash Victims About a Beige Bag
description: Relatives of passengers who died in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 were questioned by F.B.I. agents for the first time last week and were shown photographs of an unidentified beige bag that was believed to have been located near the epicenter of the explosion.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HOPPER HOUSE ART

title: Hey, Men! Your Turn.
description: Historically, one of womankind's big complaints about men has been that they shirk responsibility for birth control. Men usually just burp and laugh, but they have also legitimately pointed to a dearth of options. That's changing -- these days, researchers are coming up with plenty. And though some might sound . . . unpleasant, women can respond: Too bad. So were medieval chastity belts.

title: Screening From the Right
description: Socially responsible investing is usually seen as a liberal approach, one intended to avoid supporting companies that pollute, discriminate or profit from war. Now there is a way for investors with a conservative bent to apply their convictions.

title: No Litmus Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Turf of the Gifted Becomes Quicksand for Superintendent
description: Of the city's 32 community school district superintendents, James E. Mazza, the leader of District 3 on the Upper West Side and Harlem, is fairly well regarded by educational watchdogs outside the district. They see him as a progressive advocate of small schools, allowing students to attend classes outside their neighborhoods and school-based budgeting. But some District 3 parents who have watched him in action for three years complain that Mr. Mazza is a ''caretaker,'' not a visionary magnet for talent like his counterpart in District 2, Anthony Alvarado.

title: Q and A
description: Hiring Guides in Sorrento

title: Searching for Sandburg
description: THE OTHER CARL SANDBURG

title: An Artist, Legally Blind, Sees Nuance
description: Matthew Feinman could once stand an arm's length from his paintings -- brush in hand, splattered apron around his waist -- to add a defining line or a stroke of color. But these days the artist, 71, has to position himself just an inch from the easel, peering through glasses as thick as the bottom of Coke bottles to make out lines. He often switches to a special pair of bifocals to help him distinguish colors.

title: What 'Looking for Richard' Overlooked
description: To the Editor:

title: On Blades en Masse, Weekly
description: Richard Rubel, wearing only a pair of shorts, in-line skates and wrist guards, seemed as impervious to the chilly autumn wind as to the curious stares from strangers who passed him and some 30 other in-line skaters gathered on a recent Tuesday night on West 72d Street.

title: Leaving the Past to Die
description: Born in 1960 in a small town near Shanghai, Yu Hua belongs to a generation of writers who reached artistic maturity in the years preceding the Tiananmen massacre in 1989. And the eight stories in THE PAST AND THE PUNISHMENTS (University of Hawaii, cloth, $32; paper, $14.95) have left Socialist Realism far behind. Fluidly translated by Andrew F. Jones, they show the influence of certain foreign authors like Kawabata and Borges -- whose works became available in Chinese for the first time in the 1980's -- but the dominant tone is established by traditional elements like ghost stories and numerology. (Several important characters in ''World Like Mist,'' for example, are identified only by single-digit numbers.) Personality means little in this fictional world; surface is all, and it can be graphically cruel. In the Kafkaesque title story, a scholar has come to the unsettling conclusion that ''the essence of human wisdom is the art of punishment.'' Whether this proposition is true or not, Yu Hua's characters punish one another with abandon. In one story, an ancient fortuneteller is said to have lived so long because ''he had been able to force each of his first four children back into the nether world,'' thus capturing their vital energies for himself. Political allegory is not entirely absent in these pages, and the story called ''1986'' deals directly with the devastating effects of the Cultural Revolution. In it, a young teacher is driven insane by the Red Guards, from whom he escapes to wander the countryside. Years later, he reappears in his hometown, but the people there have chosen to forget the past. Eventually, the madman becomes such a nuisance that he is bound with rope and left to die. Like the scholar in the title story, his special research interest had been the history of punishment through the ages. William Ferguson

title: LET OUR CHILDREN GO
description: I was disappointed by John Tierney's column ''Let Our Children Go'' (The Big City, Oct. 6). In it, he was careful to avoid the real issue of how New York can improve public education and instead sought a narrower agenda. Clearly, he is more concerned with grandstanding than in addressing the crisis facing our public schools. It is unfortunate that when public leaders speak out on serious issues, some journalists choose to attack the individual rather than examine his ideas. While Tierney masterfully continues to spin stories and hurl insults, another child is being left behind.

title: France and Italy Just Got Closer
description: Travel between France and Italy has become speedier. New trains -- French TGV's and Italian ETR's -- began running between the two countries at the end of September. The trip between Paris and Turin on a TGV, which travels at a top speed of about 185 miles an hour, now takes 5 1/2 hours, down from almost 7 hours, and the trip between Paris and Milan now takes 6 hours and 40 minutes, down from 7 1/2 hours.

title: A Jets Era of Ups and (Mostly) Downs
description: Steve Gutman is a vilified non-football man in a football world. He runs the Jets.

title: Puerto Rico, Beyond The Mountains
description: PUERTO RICO lies near the midpoint in the long arc of Caribbean islands. It has palm trees, beaches and pina coladas like most of its neighbors. But it doesn't have their cachet. Indeed, many Caribbean sun-seekers treat it like a revolving door, pushing through the Luis Munoz Marin International Airport on the way to Grenada, St. Kitts or the cruise ship pier in Old San Juan.

title: Alison R. Freed, Jay P. Greenberg
description: Alison Ruth Freed, a daughter of Maya Freed Brown of Woodmere, L.I., and Samuel B. Freed of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married last evening to Jay Paul Greenberg, a son of Helaine and Robert Greenberg of Parsippany, N.J. Rabbi Shlomo Gertzulin performed the ceremony at Congregation Ohr Torah in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Opening the Door With Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Battery Reminder
description: Standard time resumed at 2 A.M. today, and clocks should be set back an hour. Fire officials recommend using the time change twice a year, when daylight time starts and ends, as a reminder to change batteries in smoke alarms.

title: The Winner Is ... Fashion
description: THE network that invented the short attention span can surely understand how much things can change in one year, particularly when the things in question involve mass media, music and fashion.

title: Public Pays for the Learning-Disabled to Attend Private Schools
description: Hundreds of parents of learning disabled children in New York City are placing them in private schools and successfully applying to have the public school system pay the annual cost of $20,000 to $60,000 a child.

title: BENEFITS
description: Cabaret for a Cure

title: Jennifer Romano, Mark C. Redman
description: Jennifer Romano, a daughter of Marie and George Romano of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Colvin Redman, a son of Evelyn and Colvin Redman of Franklin Square, L.I. Msgr. John F. McDermott performed the ceremony at the Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. Byron H. Brown, an Episcopal minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: THE REHNQUIST REINS
description: Nowhere is it easier to gain a reputation for ''brilliance'' than in law and politics (''The Rehnquist Reins,'' by David J. Garrow, Oct. 6). Justice Antonin Scalia is certainly Exhibit A. His abrasiveness toward his colleagues might perhaps be forgiven if his thinking approached anything resembling consistency, let alone brilliance.

title: PARTIES PRESSING TO RAISE TURNOUT AS ELECTION NEARS
description: The final 10 days of the 1996 campaign are shaping up as a furious struggle by the two parties and their allies to get their supporters to the polls, in the face of widespread indications that sagging voter interest may well diminish turnout.

title: Farmers Market Freshens Ossining's Image
description: AMONG the shoppers and browsers at the Ossining Farmers Market one recent Saturday morning were Sean and Rosa Villalobos, a young couple from Thornwood. They were making their first visit to this community's popular gathering spot.

title: Miss Stephenson and Mr. Roche
description: Christina Cunningham Stephenson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garrick C. Stephenson of New York, was married yesterday to Bernard Pierre-Denis Roche, a son of Edmee de Lorme Roche of Grenoble, France, and the late Col. Louis Roche. The Rev. Antoine Guggenheim performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Philippe du Roule in Paris.

title: In Blairstown, Looking for Good Homes for Retired Racehorses
description: Judith Bokman appreciates the beauty and grace of horses. She has worked with them for years, and her veterinarian husband, Dr. Stephen Bokman, works at the Meadowlands Racetrack in East Rutherford. It was natural for her to become concerned about what happens to the Standardbreds from the racetrack circuit in New Jersey and elsewhere when they are no longer competitive. The end can be an unhappy one, except for the very few at the top of the line that are put out to stud.

title: Tattoo Can Be a Ticket To Hepatitis, or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a Success, but Is That Enough
description: ONE MORNING 12 YEARS AGO, a celebrated stage and film director, an award-winning playwright, a hot young director from Chicago and a wealthy patron of the arts gathered for breakfast at the Carlyle Hotel in New York to ponder a question that had bedeviled the theater world for years: Could that perennial basket case of the American stage, the Vivian Beaumont Theater, be saved?

title: Enterprise Growth Fund
description: ASTUTE mutual fund investors looking for a way to combat the market's vagaries often use a combination of growth and value investing.

title: Ways to Expand on Nature's Care of Bird Life
description: ALTHOUGH most of the songbirds have flown to warmer climes by now, much of the avian population is hanging around for the winter, some having come down from more northerly areas.

title: Marie Ennis, William Stivale Jr.
description: Marie Theresa Ennis and William Joseph Stivale Jr., specialists in historic preservation, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York. The Rev. Robert O'Hare performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday with an article about a dispute within the Sikh Cultural Society in Richmond Hill, Queens, reversed the identities of the two faction leaders. Mohinder Singh, of the Lubanha faction, was pictured on the left; Harpeet Sing Toor, of the Jat faction, was on the right.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Cabernet Sauvignon

title: The Case of the Missing Woman
description: THE moon is full, the house is still and the cat keeps jumping at his shadow. What a great night for a TV mystery!

title: Jennifer Murray, Richard Roebuck
description: Jennifer Alden Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Alden Murray Jr. of Annapolis, Md., was married yesterday to Richard Miller Roebuck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Manning Roebuck Jr. of Baltimore. Msgr. Kenneth W. Roeltgen performed the ceremony at the Church of the Little Flower in Bethesda, Md.

title: MIXED MEDIUM
description: Print ads for Athol Dickson's first novel, ''Whom Shall I Fear,'' call it the only ''Southern gothic'' murder mystery for ''the Christian market.'' This means that along with uplifting dialogue (''Have you prayed about this anger you feel?''), readers get moonshine, a crooked sheriff and (gulp) a redneck crucifixion scene that would put Flannery O'Connor to shame. Dickson, a Texan, says he's striving for the crossover appeal of the singer Amy Grant, but he has

title: Record Fires in California
description: It was fire season again in southern California last week as wicked Santa Ana winds off the desert spread the sparks across more than 37,000 acres in a half-dozen spots, wreaking the most destruction in three years and injuring six firefighters, one critically. In the millionaire haven of Malibu, polo ponies were spooked but only five houses were destroyed.

title: Women, the Issues And the Elections
description: AS the 1996 campaign season draws to a close, women's advocates in Connecticut say this may be remembered as the Year of the Woman Voter. Women's groups that are active politically are poised to capitalize on state and national polls that give President Clinton a large lead over Bob Dole.

title: Gail Farfel, Klaus Sonnenleiter
description: Dr. Gail Meredith Farfel, a neuropharmacologist at Pfizer in New York, is to be married today to Klaus Wilhelm Sonnenleiter, a founding partner in the Media Machine, an Internet consulting firm in New York. Rabbi Charles Lippman is to perform the ceremony at the Pearl River (N.Y.) Hilton.

title: Storm-Sunk Attractions
description: I WAS scared. I felt like a frightened minnow swimming down the barrel of a 10-gauge shotgun. Or a yellow-bellied Santa Claus descending a very dark chimney upside down. I was scuba diving off St. Thomas, and the immediate objective was a submerged freighter that had to be entered by swimming headfirst through its smokestack from top to bottom.

title: 18th Century Grist Mill Gets a Lease Renewal
description: ONE of the few 18th-century tide-powered mills on the East Coast has been restored by the Nature Conservancy on its original site in Huntington Harbor.

title: After Years of Illness, Pianist Reunites With Chopin
description: AS the summer changes to autumn, and the sunlight on green changes to sunlight on red, I listen to Byron Janis's new recording of Chopin. At different times of the day I will turn on the tape, in which certain chords have taken on a certain familiarity of treatment. The chords seem to deepen each time I re-enter the music, as if all the previous hearings have entered my skin.

title: Angry Mrs. Mingus
description: The first time Sue Mingus got caught stealing bootleg recordings of her late husband, the legendary jazz bassist and composer Charles Mingus, was in 1991. As she strode out of Paris's largest record store, guards pounced and confiscated three Mingus CD's she carried in plain view. The store manager started dialing the cops; Mingus suggested he also call Parisian newspapers, TV and Tempo, the premier French jazz magazine, so she could inform everbody that the store was selling pirated jazz. ''When he heard that,'' says Mingus with satisfaction, ''he just glared and left the room.''

title: Who Asked Them? Who Didn't?
description: ANY day now, a reporter will reach for the phone and call a previously undiscovered professor/ lawyer/resident scholar, who will say something clever about something or other and land in the reporter's article. The article will alight in a database, where 10 more reporters will find it and reach for the phone. ''I read your quote,'' they will say, by way of introduction. Then they will quote him again.

title: Mavericks Are Threatening The G.O.P.'s Hold on Idaho
description: Finding a Democrat in this state after the electoral wipeout of 1994 used to require a mining light and compass. Republicans thought they had created a single-party utopia, where President Clinton is bashed round-the-clock on talk radio.

title: Bringing Up Citizens
description: IT'S 2016, and even though Election Day is several weeks away, voters can be sure of one thing: the next President of the United States will be a woman, maybe even a woman who used to be Governor of New Jersey.

title: This Must Be the City's Only Accordion-Erhu Duo
description: A few months ago, Cesar Reyes was looking for a good spot to play his accordion in the Times Square subway station when he came upon Gang Zhao making exotic music on his two-stringed erhu.

title: BATHROOM LIBERATIONISTS
description: I had always wondered what a Borough President contributes in return for a six-figure salary, plus perks (Letters, Oct. 6). So I am indebted to Ruth Messinger for letting us know how she spends her time, in her response to John Tierney's Big City column ''Bathroom Liberationists'' (Sept. 8). If a Republican officeholder were to squander precious funds on stalls for ladies' rooms in theaters, she would be called an elitist capitalist.

title: The Bonus Isn't Reserved for Big Shots Anymore
description: A SMALL shoe store rewards workers each week for exceeding the previous week's sales. A big company cuts a special check for employees in January, using a complex formula based on last year's operating profits. No matter how simple or sophisticated, each plan is a form of bonus pay, a fact of life for more and more Americans.

title: Half Caf, Half Decaf . . .
description: UNTIL a few years ago, there were several places in my town where you could go for coffee. Where you went depended on lots of factors, among them your age, income, political orientation and general outlook on life, as well as whether you smoked.

title: How to Use and Apply Varieties of Solvents
description: A SOLVENT is a substance, usually liquid, that will dissolve another substance. All do-it-yourselfers buy and use a number of solvents. Some are used for cleaning, while others are intended for use as paint, shellac or varnish thinners. Choosing the right solvent can make a job easier, while using the wrong one can damage tools or a work project.

title: Helen Lee, David Warren
description: Helen Lee, an art adviser in New York for private collectors and corporations, and David Robert Warren, an investment banker in New York, are to be married today at the James Burden Mansion in New York. Jone E. Johnson, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, is to perform the ceremony.

title: New Jersey Doctor Is Slain
description: A New Jersey physician was fatally shot in his Lower East Side office late Friday during an apparent robbery, the police said.

title: Upper West Side: Expanding Choices
description: CAFE ST. JOHN ++

title: Neighbors Bury Solid Waste Plan For 'Putrescibles'
description: Residents of the West Village are relieved that a local recycling company has dropped its plan to open Manhattan's first privately owned solid waste transfer station, a place where garbage trucks would have temporarily deposited rotting food trash before trucking it to landfills.

title: Restoring The House of Rothschild
description: GO back to the 1880's, at Waddesdon Manor, one of more than 45 mansions once owned by the legendary Rothschild banking family. A typical day, the story goes, began with a servant entering a guest's bedroom.

title: Dana A. Pesky, W. H. Herrman 2d
description: Dana Allison Pesky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Pesky of Sands Point, L.I., was married last evening to William Henry Herrman 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herrman of New York. Rabbi Judith S. Lewis performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about 10 businesses and community groups recommended for financing by the board of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone misstated the neighborhood of one group, the Isabella Geriatric Center, at 550 Audubon Avenue. It is in Washington Heights, not Central Harlem.

title: A Room at the Top
description: RECLINING on a blue canvas deck chair atop her own private sea of silver, Dee Christy Briggs surveyed the territory.

title: Talking Upheaval On Capitol Hill
description: THE Brookings Institution held one of its solemn, history-laden conferences Friday about Presidential transitions. But before the first hour passed, everyone was talking about Congress instead.

title: The Pope Pronounces Evolution Fit
description: Roman Catholics never really had as much trouble with Darwinism as did more fundamentalist brands of Christianity. Still, in his 1950 encyclical, ''Humani Generis,'' Pope Pius XII cautioned that while the faithful might regard evolutionary theory as just that -- a ''serious hypothesis'' -- they should not proclaim it as ''certain doctrine.''

title: What's the Word?
description: A brief history of changing fashions in the use of the superlative.

title: Sometimes, Passing Up Tax Breaks Is the Best Strategy
description: IMAGINE that a prized tax benefit will disappear in three years. And imagine that a costly tax penalty is being suspended for three years. Should financial consultants brace for a host of clients trying to exploit this window of opportunity?

title: A Fishing Trip, by F Train
description: He stood on a crowded subway platform in the Union Square station, a lone fisherman fully equipped with rod and reel and bait bucket, waiting for an uptown Lexington Avenue express. And where was he going?

title: How Mary Cameron Got Her Roof (It Took a Village)
description: MARY CAMERON needed a roof. Bill Weiner was not about to rest until she got one.

title: 'Keeping Cold Out In Winter'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Retrospective as the Portrait of a Career
description: LOIS DODD is a realist painter whose subjects are modest in the extreme: broken windows, falling trees, plainly appointed rooms and landscapes distinguished by their lack of distinguishing features. But because she paints imaginatively, with wit and a thorough knowledge of art history, her work -- featured in a 25-year retrospective at the Trenton City Museum -- becomes an absorbing and pleasant challenge.

title: Vertical Reality
description: AN OBJECT FOR your consideration: the pressurized sky lobby.

title: Israeli Tourism Officials Count Their Losses
description: FOR Israel's tourist industry, the images of Palestinians and Israelis shooting it out last month made a bad year worse.

title: 14 Senators Retire: Some to Write, One to Marry
description: Paul Simon bought a brown tweed sport coat so he would look like the college professor he once was when he starts teaching again next semester. Hank Brown borrowed his daughter's resume to figure out how to write one of his own.

title: Ms. Bentel, Mr. Carpenter
description: Maria Elisabeth Bentel, the daughter of Maria and Frederick Bentel of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Sebastian Bundy Carpenter, the son of Harlow Carpenter of Kensington, N.H., and the late Martha Goldsberry Carpenter. The Rev. Joseph Schlafer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Great Camp Sagamore, a historic house on Raquette Lake in upstate New York.

title: A Rembrandt Evolution, Etching Light Out of the Dark
description: FOR THE STRONGEST SENSE OF Rembrandt as a living, thinking artist, nothing quite beats his etchings. And when it comes to seeing Rembrandt etchings in the United States, nothing at all beats the Pierpont Morgan Library, which has the largest collection in North America. For the first time in nearly 25 years, the Morgan has put a good chunk of its holdings on view through Jan. 5 in ''A Fine Line: Rembrandt as Etcher.''

title: Crime in France
description: To the Editor: We have been visiting the Cote d'Azur in June for 17 years. Overall, our holiday expectations have been fulfilled. Two years ago, we began to sense a slight lack of security. My wife had her wallet and passport stolen. This year, we had two experiences, two days apart.

title: Barneys Begets Loehmann's
description: Loehmann's arrived in Manhattan last week, on the very spot where Barneys was born, at 16th Street and Seventh Avenue. Barneys is keeping part of the space.

title: Remembering the Blacklist
description: Among the casualties of the blacklisting of American writers in the late 40's and the 1950's was the writer Walter Bernstein, who was responsible for dozens of television and movie scripts. One of his most memorable screenplays was for the 1976 movie ''The Front,'' starring Woody Allen and based on Mr. Bernstein's own experiences during the blacklisting period. In this excerpt adapted from his new book, ''Inside Out: A Memoir of the Blacklist,'' to be published next month by Alfred A. Knopf, he describes the events preceding the making of that film.

title: Amy B. Lewin, Matthew Knauer
description: Dr. Amy Beth Lewin and Dr. Matthew Jay Knauer, both psychologists, were married last evening at the Puck Building in New York. Rabbi Norman R. Patz performed the ceremony.

title: Soccer Moms
description: AS THE PRESIDENTIAL campaign of 1996 enters its final week, its most powerful catch phrase has just been determined. Neither candidate coined it. No commentator had a hand in it. The phrase is to this campaign what gender gap was to the Bush-Clinton coverage in 1992 and the catch phrases angry white male and Contract With America were to the 1994 Congressional contest.

title: The New Latin Ideology: Get Real
description: NOW that a coffee grower has trounced an erstwhile revolutionary in Nicaragua's presidential election, all three of the Central American countries wracked by leftist insurrection throughout the 1970's and 1980's will be governed by right-wing presidents.

title: Hybl Is Elected U.S.O.C. Head
description: Bill Hybl was narrowly elected today as president of the United States Olympic Committee at the organization's annual Congress of affiliated sports.

title: The Race to Fill Dole's Senate Seat Is Testing the Appeal of Conservatives
description: It has been 64 years since Kansans elected a Democrat to the United States Senate.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Leaving The Hammock Behind
description: YES, it's still permissible to relax on a beach in the Caribbean. But to lie there all day might be a bit embarrassing. Physical exertion, or what sounds suspiciously like it, is on the march, by mountain bike, parasail, jet ski, kayak and dive boat.

title: Valley Boy
description: Talk about your grapes of wrath.

title: Hastings Reaches Pact to Clean Up A Waterfront Site
description: IT has taken five years, cost the village $105,000 in legal fees and involved a spontaneous-combustion fire last fall that burned for a week, but a settlement has been reached to clean up the 73,000 cubic yards of waste piled about 17 feet high in a waterfront warehouse here.

title: Fox Cameras Looked In All the Right Places
description: In the end last night, as Game 6 wound to a close, Fox Sports played it smartly, as the director, Bill Webb, cut unerringly to the right shots, and the announcers said the right things, then shut up when the pictures had more to say. There was a tight close-up of Wade Boggs wringing his hands and Andy Pettitte praying, smiling and averting his eyes. A split screen of Yankee pitcher John Wetteland and Luis Polonia facing off in the ninth inning. The Yankee owner, George Steinbrenner, shaking hands with press pals -- yes, he seemed to have a few last night -- after Polonia struck out.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: KAREN HORNEY: A Psychoanalyst's Search for Self-Understanding

title: Appalachia Comes to Croton Falls
description: ''FOXFIRE'' pays homage to the land and the air and the orchards and the mountains -- mostly, the mountains -- of Appalachia ''where you can listen to the quiet.''

title: Dowtown Brooklyn: The Promise and the Peril
description: Since the construction of the Pierrepont Plaza office tower near the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1989, Downtown Brooklyn has witnessed an infusion of millions of dollars in public funds. Its goal: to lure back large-scale private investment. In 1990, the 16-acre giant known as Metrotech opened its doors. Now, aided by more than $50 million in city subsidies, construction is under way on the Renaissance Plaza hotel and office complex on Adams Street. A major face lifting has been proposed for the Federal courthouse nearby. On Nov. 7, the Atlantic Center mall is to open. Next door, the Brooklyn Academy of Music plans to unveil a bookstore and cafe next year, followed by the construction of a cinema.

title: Think a Football Coach's Tenure Is Short? Not on This Field
description: SONNY COUGHLIN can certainly relate to the Hamden Hall Country Day School varsity football team. After all, the team is something of a throwback -- its starting members play offense and defense, out of necessity because of a shortage of players.

title: A Vote for Rivers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Vehicle Pollution Testing Is Delayed by Dispute
description: WAITING is a common theme in stories about the State Department of Motor Vehicles. And the latest story is about a new emissions testing program that is said to be more convenient and more effective in detecting pollution than the test currently used. The program, delayed for three years, is scheduled to begin early next year. But there are questions about it that are still unresolved, and more waiting is a possibility.

title: High Season For the Secret Service
description: THE MONTHS LEADING UP TO A Presidential election are high season for the United States Secret Service, a time when its 2,060 agents are most taxed, keeping their eyes peeled for trouble so that the candidates can brave the American public and, they hope, emerge unscathed. Signed into life by Abraham Lincoln on the very day he was shot, the Secret Service stuck to tracking counterfeiters until William McKinley was assassinated in 1901, when it took to guarding Presidents. Candidates were added to their duties the day after Robert F. Kennedy was gunned down on June 5, 1968.

title: Correction
description: A review on Sept. 29, about Dr. Helen Caldicott's autobiography, ''A Desperate Passion,'' included an erroneous reference, based on the first page of the book, to the nationality of the novelist Nevil Shute, the author of ''On the Beach.'' Shute (whose full name was Nevil Shute Norway) was an Englishman, not an Australian.

title: Censored by His Own Regime
description: The Unknown Lenin

title: Mayor Seeks to Oust Mob From Markets
description: In a new tactic to combat organized crime's influence at wholesale food markets, the Giuliani administration wants the authority to ban union officials who represent market employees and are suspected of mob connections. The request is in the draft of a proposed law that would empower the city to expel union officers connected to Mafia figures or to corruption.

title: The Russian Symphony, Russian Composers
description: THE State Symphony of Russia can be heard this afternoon at 3 in Jorgensen Auditorium at the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

title: Wetlands Are Turning to Asphalt, Filled in a Parcel at a Time
description: When a health clinic sought Federal approval to build on one of the wetlands nestled among the malls, homes and hotels of this seaside town, the Army Corps of Engineers had no objection. At a loss of less than six acres of swamp, the project was deemed to do little environmental harm to the local watershed, which drains into a sensitive estuary of Gulf Coast bays and bayous.

title: America's Favorite Hearse To Join the Dearly Departed
description: SUBURBAN great-grandparents and Florida retirees will not be the only ones mourning when the last Cadillac Fleetwood rolls off the assembly line late next month. The coach makers who rebuild these behemoths into hearses, limousines and flower cars will be left scrambling to replace them.

title: Patricia Hughes, A. R. Whittemore
description: Patricia A. Hughes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Hughes of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Anthony R. Whittemore, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony D. Whittemore of Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. David Sellery officiated at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: G.O.P. Hopes for Senate Ride on Pollster's Tactics
description: In Minnesota, round-the-clock television advertisements call Senator Paul Wellstone ''embarrassingly liberal'' and ''ultraliberal.''

title: Beatlemania Revisited: Hit or Hubris?
description: THIS TIME LAST YEAR, the Beatles publicity machinery was stoking the fires of 60's nostalgia to prepare the way for ''The Beatles Anthology,'' a project to be released on video and in three CD installments throughout 1996. Assembled at Apple, the Beatles' own company, the ''Anthology'' video would run a staggering 10 hours (4 1/2 of which were previewed in a three-night Beatlemania television blitz on ABC last November), and would offer the definitive word on the musicians whose songs and social pronouncements defined their time.

title: A Mother's View of a Career From Home
description: PATRICIA COBE of Edgemont and Ellen H. Parlapiano of Eastchester sensed they were part of a trend. Before their children were born in the early 1980's, they worked full time out of the house; now they work at home, usually around their children's schedules.

title: Rivals Use Same Pitch: They Are the Voice of Moderation
description: Kathleen A. Donovan might be the only New Jersey Congressional candidate who sewed a Halloween costume for her son this year (he is going as a skunk), and she is surely the only one who got her picture in Glamour magazine. In the November issue, a glowing blurb declares Ms. Donovan, a Republican running in the state's Ninth District, ''New Jersey's new power woman.''

title: U.N. Pulls Out Aid Workers as Chaos Grows in Eastern Zaire
description: Eastern Zaire descended further into chaos today, as the United Nations evacuated Western aid workers from Bukavu, leaving half a million Hutu refugees to fend for themselves. An unidentified band of soldiers attacked another refugee camp near Goma, sending 195,000 more refugees fleeing, United Nations officials said.

title: Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: I greatly enjoyed ''The Best Days Out on the Town'' (Sept. 22). The Amsterdam itinerary is what I would recommend with one important addition -- a visit to the Anne Frank House (263 Prinsengracht) -- within easy walking distance of Dam Square.

title: An Italian Questions The Pope
description: DARIO FO, the celebrated trouble-making Italian playwright, is having his say at Yale a year late and not in person.

title: Dershowitz v. Toobin
description: To the Editor:

title: Can a Collector's House Be a Home?
description: A COLLECTION -- BE IT BOOKS, records or teapots -- is an annex built next to the mind. It is our tastes, our knowledge, our prejudices made palpable. Who am I? I shall tell you up to a point. Then look at what I have gathered here.

title: Educating Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Whistling Past the Graveyard
description: HIGH LONESOMEBy Barry Hannah.230 pp. New York:Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.

title: Joe and Frank Torre's Dreamland
description: WITH two out in the ninth inning and the Braves' tying run on second and the go-ahead run on first, Mark Lemke lifted a towering foul ball that just eluded the stretched-out glove of third baseman Charlie Hayes and clunked into the Atlanta dugout.

title: Her Greatest Role
description: Eva Le Gallienne

title: Linit's Foot Helps Keep Columbia Undefeated
description: Matt Linit came through again for Columbia.

title: Kirsten Headley, Matthew D. Eyles
description: Kirsten Amanda Headley, the daughter of Carol and Joseph C. Headley of Columbia, Mo., was married yesterday to Matthew David Eyles, the son of Dagnija and David L. Eyles of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Ralph D. Anderson performed the Lutheran ceremony in the Notre Dame Chapel of Trinity College in Washington.

title: Round 4 Gets Washed Out
description: Just about the only thing that could have stopped Tom Lehman's march to victory in the Tour Championship today -- rain, lightning and thunder -- did just that.

title: Car Wash Blues
description: In homage to their victory, Knicks forward Charles Oakley plans to sponsor a Yankee Day at one of his local car washes in either the Bronx or Yonkers. Asked if he might give fans with ticket stubs from any World Series game a discount, he said he was thinking about it.

title: Limits on Compensation
description: Employers would be protected from having to pay workers compensation benefits for workers suffering from smoking-related illness under a bill that goes before the Senate Commerce Committee today. The rationale behind the bill is similar to one the state used in the lawsuit it filed recently against the tobacco companies looking to relieve taxpayers of some of the burden for treating illnesses caused by smoking.

title: Savoring the Moment With Beer and Bargains
description: There were the bon vivants who remained anchored to their bar stools, hoisting just one more brew in honor of the Yankees, and the potatoes who remained rooted to their couches, hitting the rewind button to revel in that final foul ball.

title: Politics Makes Strange Anything
description: ''Politics is all about begging,'' explains a fast-talking pol in the town of Norman, Okla., one of the stop-offs in ''Politics 101,'' a peppy tour of the election-season handshake circuit. On display in Norman, in the wards of Chicago and on the byways of Providence, R.I., are candidates who still dredge for votes the old fashioned way, one voter at a time.

title: Meteorology and Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cable TV Fight, New York Insults Free Press
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''This has brought back so much camaraderie to the city. It gives us that old time feeling of New York, the way it used to be.'' JOE CAMMARATA, an Emergency Medical Services worker in Brooklyn. $(A1:2$)

title: Series of Right Moves Started With an Unlikely One
description: MAYBE it became lost in the euphoria of their World Series triumph, but the Yankees came up with a new relief-pitching pattern in their conquest of the Atlanta Braves. All season the Yankees had used Mariano Rivera and John Wetteland as a late-inning tandem to stop any threats or thoughts other teams had of staging comebacks. But Manager Joe Torre called on the tandem only once in the six games of the World Series, saving it for the finale at Yankee Stadium on Saturday night.

title: The Bible, a Perennial, Runs Into Sales Resistance
description: For professional Bible-thumpers -- whose task it is to promote the world's longest-running, recession-proof best seller -- this is a strangely sluggish season for marketing God's word.

title: Improved Brakes for Trains
description: In the wake of a train collision in February that killed three people, New Jersey Transit is giving high priority to installing automatic brakes on its lines, The A.P. reported yesterday. The agency plans to have an automatic safety system on all its commuter lines by mid-1998, eight years ahead of schedule, said its executive director, Shirley DeLibero.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about John Gotti's leadership of the Gambino organized crime family misstated his age. He turned 56 yesterday, not 55.

title: A Final Settlement for 7 Tons of Nazi Gold
description: PARIS  The United States, Britain and France are about to close a chapter in history by distributing the last seven tons of bullion in their postwar pool of Nazi gold, worth about $86 million

title: Warning on Bog Cleanup
description: Federal and state agencies have spent more than $45 million cleaning up contaminated soil in Marlboro's Burnt Fly Bog. But unless voters approve two public questions on environmental spending next Tuesday, the effort to clean up PCB contamination at the bog and dozens of other sites will be endangered, say state environmental officials who plan to lead a tour of the bog today.

title: Ruth Waxman, 80, Lecturer on Judaism
description: Ruth Waxman, who played a prominent role in Conservative Judaism, died on Oct. 18 at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 80.

title: A Team for New York in the 90's
description: What a perfect way to end an invigorating, heart-stopping season. A scrappy New York Yankees team that specialized in coming from behind, finding new ways to win and dominating its opponents on the road during the post-season finally won the big one Saturday night in venerable Yankee Stadium. After 18 years of frustration, the Yankees are once again the major league champion.

title: Kelley Blue Book Tests the World Wide Web as a Distribution Source
description: As a favor, an auto dealer agreed to buy the five-year-old metallic brown Mercedes Benz owned by Robert S. Kelley's wife for ''five back,'' industry parlance for $500 below Blue Book retail price.

title: AT&T Choice In Hindsight: Did Search Go Astray?
description: Judging by the stock market's reaction, there has been yet another case of crossed wires at the beleaguered AT&T Corporation, which has gone through restructurings, downsizings and divestitures to little avail.

title: From Penderecki, a Mob That Howls or Whispers
description: Postwar music was the time of toolmakers. New instruments were invented to make new sounds; new ideas of what music actually was flew back and forth across the world. Krzysztof Penderecki had one of the brighter ideas: a kind of guided orchestral chaos, blocks of ordered tone and color built from haphazard detail. A fellow practitioner, Iannis Xenakis, used schools of fish as his metaphor; the school has a definable size, shape and velocity of its own even as its constituents swim individually within it.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There may be more than six degrees of separation, but American Presidential candidates with ties to royalty have a distinct advantage over those bereft of noble connections. Or so says HAROLD B. BROOKS-BAKER, publishing director of Burke's Peerage, the British authority on aristocratic genealogy.

title: Three-Month and Six-Month Bills Will Be Auctioned This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: A Night to Remember For a Team That Wouldn't Quit
description: Perhaps the only word heard more frequently than ''character'' in the days leading up to the Yankees' inspirational World Series comeback against the Atlanta Braves was the word ''team.''

title: No Sleep and a Lot of Tears Makes for a Festive Treat
description: The Yankees' triumph, the all-night victory party and the day after melded into a long, happy blur for the extended members of the Torre household yesterday, who woke to find that they had become the city's first family of baseball, at least for a time. The truth be told, many in the family got almost no sleep to wake up from.

title: Cigar Fought, but Seemed to Have Lost Some 'Electricity'
description: On the day after he ran third in the Breeders' Cup Classic to the 19-1 long shot Alphabet Soup, the champion Cigar rested before returning to New York while his trainer admitted that time and toil had finally robbed the mighty bay horse of his invincibility.

title: Stanford White, as Voracious in Art as in Life
description: THE ARCHITECT OF DESIRE

title: Dole Assails White House as 'Animal House' of 'Elitists'
description: Bob Dole unleashed a stinging volley of attacks on the Clinton Administration today, describing it as a ''group of elitists who have never done anything.'' At one point Mr. Dole called the White House an ''animal house,'' yet he gloated that on Election Day, he would wait up to hear that California went Republican and then, as the future President, he would ''drive by the White House and honk!''

title: Internet Stocks See Ardor Cool On Wall Street
description: Wall Street has been good indeed to the high-technology establishment this year. The stock prices of companies like Intel, Microsoft and Oracle are up 50 percent or more, and even stodgy old I.B.M. has seen its shares bid up nearly 40 percent.

title: Murrell Gains 199 Yards, And Jets, Finally, a Victory
description: It took a record rushing performance by Adrian Murrell, but after 336 days the Jets, finally, have won a game.

title: In Dole's Hometown, a White-Knuckle Finish
description: To find the heart of Bob Dole's hometown in these last unsettled days of his campaign, do not go to Dole headquarters on Main Street. Or to the afternoon coffee-and-pie gatherings of the town elders at Meridy's. Or even to the V.F.W. hall with the plaque honoring Dole outside and old war friends inside.

title: Envoy's Visit May Pave the Way for a Papal Trip to Cuba
description: In what Roman Catholic Church officials and diplomats describe as a prelude to a possible meeting next month between Pope John Paul II and President Fidel Castro of Cuba, the Vatican's foreign minister is in Cuba on a five-day visit. In a reversal of attitude, Government officials there have openly welcomed him.

title: Daily Ritual Precedes Silence by a Defendant
description: Alex Kelly is in charge of the mints.

title: Most Improved French Wine? Try Montmartre '95
description: A section of Paris animated by artists, tourists, and a spirit of fierce independence is now trying to bring back something it was famous for in Roman times -- winegrowing.

title: Nextel Narrows Its Review
description: Nextel Communications, a wireless communications company in McLean, Va., named three finalists for its account, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Bosnia Is Strewn With Danger as Resistance and Blunders Delay Mine Clearance
description: When the West turned to the question of helping Bosnia's people reclaim their fields, their homes and their schools after three and a half years of war, it became clear that the most immediate obstacle was the widespread presence of land mines.

title: Ohio State and Pace Merrily Barrel Along
description: ORLANDO PACE was too fast to score a touchdown on Saturday afternoon.

title: Zimmer Distances Himself From Dole
description: The Republican candidate for Senate in New Jersey, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, distanced himself from the flagging Presidential candidacy of Bob Dole, saying it would not be unusual for voters to pick Bill Clinton for President and himself for senator. In doing so, Mr. Zimmer subscribed to a national trend among Republican candidates of trying to limit the damage from an anticipated Dole loss.

title: Justice and Najibullah
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Talks Stall, and U.S. Mediator Says He's Going Home
description: After shuttling on Sunday between Haifa and Gaza in a last minute attempt to bridge remaining gaps in a Hebron agreement, Dennis Ross, the American mediator, announced early today that he was leaving for Washington without an accord.

title: Hoping to Bolster Its Hold on School Computers, Apple Introduces a Cheaper Model
description: Hoping to strengthen its foothold in the $4 billion educational computing market, Apple Computer Inc. plans to introduce today a new kind of computer for elementary and high schools that will sell for about half the price of current multimedia systems.

title: G.O.P. Seems To Gear Ads To Dole Loss
description: House Republicans, implicitly conceding Bob Dole's defeat in the Presidential race, are undertaking a television advertising campaign to argue that a Republican Congress is needed to deny President Clinton ''a blank check.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Hooray, Fans! Now Get Set For the Bill
description: THIS may seem like crepe-hanging, what with the Yankee celebrations still in mid-swing, but it is not too early to think about the billion-dollar hangover that may follow the party.

title: In Battleground State, Weapons Are Falling Silent
description: What happens when a Presidential campaign all but disappears?

title: Gretzky In Control as Rangers End Losing Skid
description: One goal and three assists were not the only highlights of Wayne Gretzky's performance last night when he helped the Rangers to a 6-4 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: The Internet needs technological innovation and social transformation.
description: ''WHEN I get starry-eyed,'' one scientist recently wrote, ''I think of the Web as an information analog of the medieval cathedrals -- something the whole culture contributes to and participates in.''

title: After a Sit-In, Racial Tensions Persist at a SUNY Campus
description: Anthony J. Benardello is a 37-year-old former Army Ranger who opposes affirmative action and calls advocates of multiculturalism ''white haters'' who want ''white oppression taught from a leftist perspective.''

title: Familiar Hero to Warn Bosnian Children About Mines
description: In a novel partnership between diplomacy and the entertainment industry, the United States plans to send to Bosnia this week more than half a million comic books to teach children about the dangers of land mines.

title: Sara Lee Unit Drops Ammirati Puris
description: Sara Lee Bakery and its agency, Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, said that after six years they had mutually decided to part ways on their account. As a result, the account, with billings estimated at $12 million, has been placed in review.

title: Catching Up on the Web
description: After a late start, the state government sites on the World Wide Web are seeing brisk traffic, officials said Friday. The sites for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and 19 state departments have been averaging 38,000 visits a day, said Amy Collings, a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department, which oversees the sites. The figure is a count of pages accessed, not of individual users.

title: Chief of a WPP Unit Joins Y. & R. Office
description: Austin McGhie, chairman and chief executive of the Cole & Weber unit of the WPP Group in Seattle, is leaving that agency after three years to head the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Inc., as president and chief executive.

title: Elderly Are Going Elsewhere
description: New Jersey is graying, but not as quickly as the rest of the country, the United States Census Bureau reported last week. According to the bureau, the proportion of New Jerseyans over 65 is expected to increase from 13.7 percent in 1995 to 17.3 percent by 2025. But other states are likely to experience a much greater jump, the bureau said, causing New Jersey to drop from 15th place in the nation to 40th.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Business Day on Oct. 16 showing the principal rail lines owned by the CSX Corporation and Conrail Inc. included a track erroneously. The track that runs along Florida's eastern coast from Jacksonville to West Palm Beach is owned by the Florida East Coast Railway, not CSX.

title: Chinese Nationalists Aren't Pawns of Beijing
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton as a Military Leader: Tough On-the-Job Training
description: In his first term as President, Bill Clinton, who came to power having commanded nothing bigger than the Arkansas National Guard, has confronted national security problems that would have bedeviled a battle-hardened cold warrior.

title: After Torre Pinches Himself, the Yanks Are Still Champions
description: Joe Torre was so emotionally drained Saturday night that he left Yankee Stadium with his soiled and sweaty Yankee uniform on.

title: Dr. Stanley Lamm, 95, Founder of Institute
description: Dr. Stanley S. Lamm, the founder and director emeritus of the Lamm Institute for Child Neurology and Developmental Medicine at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, died on Oct. 18 at the Judson Retirement Community in Cleveland. He was 95 and lived in Brooklyn Heights until five years ago, when he retired from practice.

title: Incinerator Vote Is Near
description: Mercer County's Board of Freeholders could vote tonight on whether to go ahead with plans to build a $140 million trash incinerator that has already generated a lawsuit. The incinerator, planned for Hamilton Township, has been challenged by Princeton township and Princeton borough because neither wants to send waste to the incinerator and neither wants to pay for its construction. A public hearing on the issue, which was started earlier this month, is to resume tonight.

title: Card Discount Is Broadened To Commuters
description: When New York City's transit system begins in 14 months to offer its first volume discounts, a new discount will also be given to Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North commuters who are also regular users of the city's subways and buses, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Et Tu, Cybernetica Machina User?
description: It was the repository of all Western culture. The fall of the Roman Empire couldn't destroy it. It flourished in the Middle Ages, boomed in the Renaissance, endured the birth of European Nationalism and has weathered this century of indifference and neglect. Is the Computer Age likely to put an end to it?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 14 about a decline in advertising pages in The New Yorker omitted ad page figures for this year, to date, for two competing magazines, Harper's and The Atlantic Monthly. Through September 1996, advertising pages in Harper's were up 1.85 percent, and pages in The Atlantic were down 13.5 percent, according to Media Industry Newsletter.

title: Two inventors contend that the V-chip is an idea they've seen before -- in their own patent.
description: IN this election season's first Presidential debate, President Clinton trumpeted his support for the V-chip, a technology that allows parents to filter out broadcast and cable television programs they deem inappropriate for their children. Back in February, Congress passed a law requiring that all televisions sold in 1998 be equipped with a V-chip.

title: CLINTON CAMPAIGN PUTS AN EMPHASIS ON FEMALE VOTERS
description: Seeking to insure a strong turnout from a crucial voting bloc, President Clinton made a special appeal to women today by highlighting Government efforts to fight breast cancer and telling a rally audience in Virginia that the election ''is not about party, it's about you.''

title: Colorado Referendum
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Hoguet, 82, Lawyer in Cold War Case, Dies
description: Peter W. Hoguet, a lawyer, economist and investment banker who figured in a cold war incident -- the defection of Oksana S.
