Kosenkina, a Soviet schoolteacher who jumped from a window of the Soviet Consulate in New York City in 1948 -- died on Tuesday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Bridge
description: The United States women's team qualified for a playoff spot at the World Championships here today, while the American open team was still in the hunt.

title: An Oracle-Netscape Tie-In Will Seek to Curb Microsoft
description: Oracle and Netscape Communications plan on Monday to endorse each other's flagship products, with the aim of building a broad alliance intended to counter the attempt by Microsoft to become the dominant Internet software company.

title: Uncertainty Looms as Mexicans Forge Their Yearly Economic Pact
description: The peso is unsteady and so is the health of Fidel Velazquez, the 96-year-old labor leader who has kept Mexico's unions under control for decades. Working Mexicans are waiting impatiently for relief from an economic recovery that shows up in the statistics but not in their pockets.

title: There's More Than Mere Sod in the Great Lawn's Repair
description: If Central Park's Great Lawn had been in a backyard somewhere, the owner might long ago have erected a high fence around it, or perhaps paved it and painted it green. Its surface had become pounded hard as asphalt, pocked with sinkholes and almost totally denuded of grass. Since the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, park officials concede, it had received essentially no care.

title: 2 Killed in Plane Crash
description: Two people were killed and the pilot was critically injured when a single-engine plane crashed yesterday afternoon. The Associated Press reported that the plane took off from Camden County Airport and was in the air less than 15 minutes before it went down in a wood, landing upside-down with its wings broken off. Federal Aviation Administration officials said the plane was a YAK-18, a Russian-made military trainer registered in the United States as an experimental aircraft. The F.A.A. has given no cause for the crash, but a witness told reporters that the plane had radioed back to the airport that it was having engine trouble.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Lippo Suction
description: In 1994, a former U.S. naval officer named Nicholas Eftimiades, who now works for our Defense Intelligence Agency, wrote and cleared an article titled ''Chinese Intelligence Operations'' for the Naval Institute Press.

title: A Man's Life Turned Inside Out By Government and the Media
description: Two days after Richard A. Jewell found the bomb that later exploded during the Olympic Games here, he received a telephone call from a Georgia Bureau of Investigation agent whom he considered a longtime friend.

title: Confession Raises Questions in Shooting of Japan's Police Chief
description: Scores of police officers searched a river bottom today for a pistol used in the attempted assassination of the national police chief last year, signifying possible further progress in one of Japan's great criminal mysteries.

title: I.B.M. and Toshiba Gain in Strong Global Market
description: The global market for personal computers continued to see strong growth in the third quarter, according to figures from the market research firm Dataquest, with I.B.M. and Toshiba showing the sharpest increases and Apple Computer and Packard Bell the biggest losses in market share in the United States.

title: Can Repulsive TV Ads Teach Something?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Search for the Next 'Doonesbury'
description: Life is not all about laughter for the comic strip distributor these days. Each day brings another flood of awful drawings of cutesy animals and mostly stupid humans from people who fancy themselves the next big thing in jokes. The market is shrinking as newspapers die or merge and many editors are too afraid of reader complaints to take a chance on a new feature anyway, let alone compete for one.

title: Drawing Away From Dole
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, distanced himself from the flagging candidacy of Bob Dole, and said it would not be unusual if New Jersey voters picked Bill Clinton. Article, page B4.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Yankee Boss Reaches Crossroads in the Bronx
description: AS usual, the Boss had the answers. He knew what had cured -- at least temporarily, pending vexing litigation -- the aching elbow of Graeme Lloyd.

title: Reporters Who Root Make Fox Look Bad
description: To comprehend how upbeat, even understandably parochial feelings about the Yankees' winning the World Series became mindless excess, one had to watch WNYW-TV/ Channel 5's ''news'' coverage following Fox's post-game show.

title: In the 'New York, New York' 90's, Winners Abound
description: THE Giants won't win 'em all, but at least the Jets won't lose 'em all. The Mets don't know how to win. The Knicks are starting all over. The Rangers are on thin ice. The Islanders might as well be on ice. Across the Hudson, the Devils are trying to get out of a trap and the Nets, well, until proven otherwise, the Nets are the Nets.

title: Have you heard 'Living Single' is back on Fox? (By the way, who's on first?)
description: IF you watched the Fox Network's telecasts of the World Series, you know that ''in a season of massively hyped series,'' ''Millennium'' is a show ''that really delivers''; that you should not risk missing ''what everybody will be talking about on Monday'' because ''The X Files'' has ''been abducted'' from Friday to Sunday night, and that ''Living Single,'' where the characters are ''young and they're funny,'' returns on Halloween night.

title: The Lions Outhustled In the Dome
description: This is an image that might endure in the minds of the Lions for months to come: Giants defensive lineman Ray Agnew, after picking off a pass, rumbling 34 yards for a touchdown, his 285-pound body running so slowly it seemed the feat couldn't be captured on an hourlong highlight show. As if Detroit's 35-7 loss this afternoon to the Giants wasn't bad enough, here's some lineman scoring a touchdown.

title: No 'Greater China'
description: To the Editor:

title: Looted by Its Own Officials, Bulgaria Faces the Day of Economic Reckoning
description: As the pale fall light faded into evening, Anna Penkova and her son, Kostadin, hurried to saw and stack the last branches of a poplar tree that will help warm their home in the village of Dragor in the months ahead. For the first time in 26 years, they said, they cannot afford heating oil and will rely entirely on wood, stolen from a nearby forest.

title: Like Others, Zimmer Draws Back From Dole
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, distanced himself today from the flagging Presidential candidacy of Bob Dole.

title: Winking At Karadzic
description: The Clinton Administration says its policy toward the accused Bosnian Serb war criminals Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic is that they will be arrested if encountered by soldiers of the Dayton Implementation Force in Bosnia. But that is not the real policy, as the following story shows.

title: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a quotation sampler from Bob Dole on Tuesday misidentified the city in which he spoke. It was Westerville, Ohio, not Detroit.

title: Baby Is Found Left in a Box, Just Hours Old
description: A healthy baby girl only a few hours old was found yesterday in a cardboard box outside an apartment building in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: A Suitor Woos Bayonne With a Grand Plan
description: John S. Rogers, who plans to build the world's biggest ocean liner, stood behind the lectern in the City Council chambers here and addressed the audience in measured tones.

title: Robert Torricelli for the Senate
description: One of the nastiest campaigns in the country has been fought this year by two New Jersey Congressmen running for the seat held by Senator Bill Bradley, who is retiring. Representatives Robert Torricelli, a Democrat, and Richard Zimmer, a Republican, come across as scorched-earth partisans who have brought no honor to New Jersey this year. The call as to which to endorse is a close and not particularly pleasant one.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: How Public Art Turns Political
description: Until late summer, the organizers of a Holocaust memorial here, the brainchild of Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi hunter, were worried because everything was going so smoothly with the project that it seemed it might not elicit any comment. Now the project, which was to have been dedicated in November, is facing a shower of 11th-hour attacks and construction delays that will last until at least the spring.

title: More Than Winners
description: For one day, New York was like Emerald City.

title: Giants Actually Seem to Have Fun; For Lions, Though, There's Only Misery
description: It was nice to be a Giants player or fan yesterday afternoon. Detroit offered a refreshing respite from the humdrum affairs of a normal Sunday afternoon. A typical Giants game is filled with a tedious offensive display, combined with just enough defensive errors to cause teeth grinding. All of that is usually followed by a hollow loss.

title: Fight Europe Rightists With Even More Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Telephone Tag For President
description: President Clinton took time out today to put in calls to the winners and losers of the World Series.

title: Charles Barrett, Architect, 40
description: Charles Barrett, an architect who was highly regarded as an architectural draftsman, died on Oct. 19 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami. He was 40 and lived in Miami Beach.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about preparations by the United States and NATO for a peacekeeping force in Bosnia next year misstated the location of recent discussions on the issue. Defense Secretary William J. Perry attended alliance meetings in Bergen, Norway; Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, met with NATO foreign ministers in the United States. The talks were not at NATO headquarters in Brussels.

title: Still going after laughs, ESPN decides that it hasn't heard enough of Robert Goulet's baritone.
description: MORE people than ever are hearing Robert Goulet's booming baritone. But they aren't listening to songs of love and legend from ''South Pacific'' or ''Man of La Mancha.'' Now the 62-year-old troubadour is swinging with nutty ditties for 18- to 25-year-olds to promote ESPN's college basketball schedule.

title: Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg, a Conductor, 69
description: Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg, a mathematician, conductor and lawyer, was found dead last Monday at his home in Amagansett, L.I. He was 69.

title: It's Autumn in New York, And Triumph Is in the Air
description: They called it historic, majestic, sublime. They compared it to Christmas morning as a kid or the best birthday ever. They said it was like a wedding day or winning the lottery. New Yorkers were gleefully lost among the metaphors yesterday, but any way you looked at it, the New York Yankees were the toast of the town -- and it was strong stuff, like the fumes of that first whisky.

title: Tragedy as the Stuff of a Song Cycle
description: In a departure from her usual cabaret haunts, Andrea Marcovicci sings the part of Anne Frank tonight at Alice Tully Hall in the New York premiere of a song cycle based on the diary of the teen-age Jewish girl who lived in hiding in Amsterdam until she was betrayed and transported to a Nazi concentration camp, where she died. ''It's as if an older Anne is looking back on her life, as if she still exists now,'' Ms. Marcovicci said of the work, ''I Am Anne Frank,'' written by Enid Futterman with music by Michael Cohen.

title: Virtual Casino Is Coming, but Regulation Is Still a Big Question
description: There are few patches of legal turf the states guard more fiercely than gambling, which is why it seemed strange this summer when the National Association of Attorneys General urged the Federal Government to seize control of wagering on the Internet -- even though hardly anyone was doing it.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI

title: Ohio County Reluctantly Tilts Toward Clinton
description: In this place that votes as America does for President, Bill Clinton is winning the Battle of the Lesser Evils, stealing away Republican support that Bob Dole must have and attracting many of the independents it takes to carry a swing county.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 145.44, or 0.70 percent, at 20,885.41. On Friday, it fell 263.52.

title: Perry Denies Pledging to Keep U.S. Troops in Bosnia in 1997
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry has not indicated an American commitment to retain peacekeeping troops in Bosnia through 1997, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: Drama, and a Mom-and-Pop Approach, for Balanchine
description: The Pacific Northwest Ballet from Seattle, which closed its enthusiastically received season yesterday, has a wider repertory than this Manhattan debut would indicate.

title: Kansas Utility Extends Bid
description: Western Resources Inc. extended its $1.9 billion tender offer for the Kansas City Power and Light Company yesterday, a move that may lead to the first hostile takeover of an electric company in at least 36 years.

title: Cable TV News Competition Spills Onto the Web
description: MSNBC recently posted a spreadsheet on the Internet for calculating your monthly savings from cutting back on coffee, bagels and movies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Leda, a dog who has a role in a revival of Elmer Rice's Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''Street Scene,'' which opens tonight at the Theater Row Theater on West 42d Street in Clinton, may not be aware of it, but she will have an actress with an unusually distinguished lineage at the other end of her leash: LINDA POWELL.

title: From African Tangle, Explosion
description: In the Great Lakes region of East Africa, what was a series of small ethnic conflicts in different countries has in recent days become a firestorm threatening to engulf the region, a group of interconnected wars set in motion by the longstanding enmity between members of the Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups in Rwanda and Burundi.

title: The Importance of Holding Back Tears
description: Lynda Obst acknowledges that she has teetered perilously close to breaking her first commandment for women in Hollywood: ''Thou shalt not cry at work.''

title: Johnson's Ex-Players Show Him How It's Done
description: The final two minutes were ticking away, the Cowboys were beating the Dolphins by 29-10, and Dallas had the ball at the Miami 7. This was a perfect time for Jerry Jones and Barry Switzer to rub it in against Jimmy Johnson. A final fling of a pass into the end zone? A field-goal attempt? Make it 36 points? Make it 32? No. Dallas quarterback Troy Aikman simply kneeled after the snap. Three straight times, in fact.

title: Braves Leave Empty-Handed but Full of Kind Words
description: The Atlanta Braves left New York yesterday morning without the World Series trophy they had hoped to win, but with respect for the team that did capture the championship.

title: Braves' Trash Talk Provided a Spark for Yanks
description: Publicly, several Yankees said Jim Leyritz's three-run homer off Mark Wohlers, which helped the Yankees storm back from a 6-0 deficit to win by 8-6 in Game 4, was the turning point in the World Series. Privately, one Yankee said the turning point came in Games 1 and 2 when the defending champion Braves destroyed them and displayed no respect.

title: Barbara C. Salken, Law Professor, 49
description: Barbara C. Salken, a professor at the Pace University School of Law in White Plains, died on Oct. 17 at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla. She was 49 and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 16 about a move by magazine editors to preserve independence referred incorrectly to a comment by David J. Pecker, president and chief executive of Hachette Publications Inc., after he removed an article from Premiere magazine. Mr. Pecker said that he regretted the editors' subsequent departure; he did not regret having ordered the editors to remove the article.

title: Washington Is Producing Apple Crop In Quantity
description: Washington is harvesting what is likely to be the state's largest apple crop, using advanced technology and economies of scale that may make the family-run orchard a thing of the past here as well as in other apple-growing regions in New York and Michigan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. and Auto Workers Struggle to Resolve Pact

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Zaire's Killer Camps
description: You know things have become unusually ugly in Central Africa when United Nations and international relief workers start pulling out.

title: An Old Law Chastises Pregnant Teen-Agers
description: Seven months' pregnant and 17 years old, Amanda Smisek received a court summons last spring charging her with a crime she had never learned about in high school: fornication.

title: Endorsements for President
description: A sampling of newspapers:

title: Character Question Fails To Catch Public Interest
description: As a vexed Bob Dole issues his ''wake up'' call to voters to demand they heed his attacks on President Clinton's worthiness, Dr. Diana B. Carlin is wakeful to the point of epiphany.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: General Motors and U.A.W. Negotiate Past the Contract Deadline
description: Top officials of the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers continued negotiating after their labor contract expired at 11:59 P.M. Sunday, as workers at several G.M. factories were waiting with picket signs in the event of a possible strike.

title: 2 Players Act as if Deal Has Already Been Made
description: Under terms of the deal that the acting commissioner, Bud Selig, said has not been reached, two players facing restrictions under the old contract were among five players who filed for free agency yesterday on the first day of the filing period.

title: Exploring the Grisly Fantasies of an Average Guy
description: About 70 minutes into Penn Jillette's new play, ''Recreation,'' a strip-joint operator played by Andrew Totolos suddenly turns to the audience and says, ''Let's slow things down a bit.''

title: An Effective Global Court
description: Ever since the conclusion of the Nuremberg tribunals that brought Nazi war criminals to justice, the United Nations has debated whether to establish a permanent international criminal court. The idea is a good one. With cold war obstacles gone, the U.N. now has the chance to take some practical steps toward creating a viable tribunal.

title: A Story Where the Telling Itself Has Raised Many Questions
description: Both articles in The Atlanta Journal received prominent treatment, but in the route from the first to the second lies one of the most-discussed cases of reporting in recent memory.

title: First Lady Asks Women to Vote for Torricelli
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton came to southern New Jersey today, with its large number of undecided voters and suburban women, the most sought-after group this election year, to urge them to vote for her husband and for Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate.

title: On Road to Suburbia, a Town Loses Its Charm
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Stanley May Face Two-Year Penalty
description: Morgan Stanley & Company may be blocked from conducting negotiated municipal bond sales for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and state agencies after a top official of the firm inadvertently made a political contribution that was not allowed under industry rules.

title: For Congress From New York
description: New York City's 14 Congressional races all feature entrenched incumbents who appear to be facing little or no serious challenge. But there are a handful of interesting races in the surrounding suburbs. These are our recommendations.

title: SERVICE EXPERTS TO ACQUIRE 18 SERVICE CENTERS
description: Service Experts Inc. of Nashville said yesterday that it was acquiring 18 heating, ventilating and air-conditioning service centers for about $57.2 million in stock and cash. The company said it would acquire the independent companies for $11 million in cash and stock worth $46.2 million. The 18 service centers have annual revenue of $68 million, which Service Experts said would double its revenue on a yearly basis. The companies being acquired are members of Service Experts' consulting group and wholly owned subsidiary, Contractor Success Group. Shares of Service Experts rose $4.50 yesterday, to $26.75. On Aug. 25, the company had its initial public offering of 2.25 million shares, priced at $13.

title: DANCE
description: A Dedication to Emotion

title: Time-Zone Caper: Suspect Is Arrested In Testing Scheme
description: A California man has been arrested and charged with helping students cheat on standardized exams for graduate school, using an elaborate scheme that took advantage of time- zone changes, coded pencils and expert test-takers who telephoned the answers to the West Coast where the tests were being given on the same day.

title: Medicare Trust Fund Ends Fiscal Year With a $4.2 Billion Deficit
description: The Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for the elderly spent $4.2 billion more than it received in taxes and other income in the last fiscal year, the Clinton Administration reported today. And it is expected to run larger deficits in coming years.

title: Fewer Northeasters Pound U.S., but Punch Is More Powerful
description: FOR people who have suffered through the gales, heavy rains, floods, deep snows, property destruction and lost power of the nasty northeasters of the 1990's, there is little comfort in the fact that recent decades have seen fewer of these classic storms. That is because northeasters in general are more severe than they used to be.

title: DOLE SEES FAILURE OF THREE DECADES IN ANTI-BIAS FIGHT
description: Bob Dole today declared that a generation of affirmative action programs, including many he had backed, had led down a ''blind alley in the search for equal justice.'' He said the Government's sole obligation should be to guard against explicit discrimination and provide assistance based on economic need, but not race or sex.

title: Wake Up, America!
description: Wake up, America! Why doesn't America wake up?

title: Wheat Falls on Expectation Of Abundant World Crops
description: Wheat prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as concerns grew that a larger worldwide crop would make competition stiff for American exporters.

title: A Bill for the Working Poor
description: People who leave the welfare rolls to take jobs that pay less than a subsistence wage should be given state assistance to pay for basic living costs, a Republican state senator said yesterday. Senator Robert W. Singer of Lakewood introduced a bill last week that would provide $40 million this year to help the 220,000 families that are classified as working poor. Assistance would be provided until a family of four had an income of $1,650 a month.

title: Steep Drop Is a Surprise, and a Mystery, Too
description: By almost any statistical measure, the reduction in the Federal budget deficit, hailed by President Clinton today, is impressive: it has dropped to its lowest level in 15 years, so low that the United States now has the smallest deficit -- as a percentage of its economy -- of any of the world's largest industrialized nations.

title: After 10 Years, 'Miz' Is Replacing Cast
description: In a surprise move, John Caird, the co-director of ''Les Miserables,'' has informed the musical's cast that it will be replaced in late January by a new company. The sweeping change, unheard-of for a Broadway production, was announced by Mr. Caird to the 37 actors after Sunday's matinee. The new cast is to give its first performance on March 12, the 10th anniversary of the musical's opening night on Broadway.

title: Playing of Flute May Have Graced Neanderthal Fire
description: IN the evening by firelight in their caves and rock shelters, the Neanderthals sometimes relaxed to the sound of music after a hard day at the hunt. They took material at hand, a cave bear's thigh bone, and created a flute. With such a simple instrument, these stocky, heavy-browed Neanderthals, extinct close relatives of humans, may have given expression to the fears, longings and joys of their prehistoric lives.

title: Bulgarian Opposition Candidate Leads After First Round of Presidential Vote
description: In a protest against the ruling party of ex-Communists, Bulgarians gave the opposition candidate for President, Petar Stoyanov, a strong lead in Sunday's vote, preliminary results showed today.

title: Your Best Face on The Web
description: IF you are one of the two or three people who do not have their own pages on the World Wide Web, perhaps it is the thought of having to learn HTML that is stopping you. The Hypertext Markup Language is not as arcane as C++, but it does involve learning things like

title: Morey Amsterdam, Comedian and Joke Encyclopedia, Dies
description: Morey Amsterdam, the wisecracking comedian who began telling jokes in vaudeville, thrived in the heyday of radio and lasted into the era of television on ''The Dick Van Dyke Show,'' died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was in his 80's.

title: So You Think You Want to Direct
description: WHAT, as they say in Hollywood, a concept! It must have sounded thrilling in story conferences: a CD-ROM game where you take on the role of a promising film director and work your way up from low-budget quickies to multi-million-dollar extravaganzas. But Steven Spielberg's Director's Chair (from Knowledge Adventure Inc., for Windows and Mac) suggests that the road from idea to screen can be bumpy even for those driving Porsches.

title: At Head of the Parade, It's Torre
description: So many moves molded the Yankees into World Series champions. So many moments shaped their magically successful season. So many men and so many memories. But only one manager, Joe Torre. The soothing manager with the calm demeanor and the Midas touch uttered the right words, made the gutsy calls and left his indelible imprint on the 1996 team. Torre led; the Yankees followed.

title: Socially Conscious Lyrics, And Always Ready to Party
description: When an audience member told Fishbone's manic singer, Angelo Moore, that the Yankees had won the World Series during the Saturday night triple bill of Fishbone, De La Soul and the Goodie Mob at Roseland, Mr. Moore jumped around the stage with sarcastically feigned excitement. Fishbone, a Los Angeles band blending ska, punk, funk and metal, doesn't need an excuse to party. For 11 years its shows, full of celebratory and silly anthems enlivened by quick-rhythm guitars and energetic horn blasts, have been among rock's wildest and most fun. At the same time, the band has always brought socially conscious lyrics about prejudice, alcoholism and warmongering to the surface in the midst of the jubilation.

title: Jet Makes an Emergency Landing at Kennedy
description: An American Airlines jet made an emergency landing on a runway at Kennedy International Airport last night after its landing gear developed a problem, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an ''American Place''article yesterday about voter opinion in Stark County, Ohio, referred incompletely to a poll conducted jointly by The Times and Ohio State University. Prof. Paul J. Lavrakas, director of the survey center at the university, and Prof. Gerald M. Kosicki of the school of journalism and communication took part in the polling.

title: Budget Pressures in Plainfield
description: The local government in Plainfield will shut down on Friday if the City Council does not approve a one-month spending measure the night before. A majority of the Council has objected to a provision in the stopgap spending plan calling for about 20 layoffs and to Mayor Mark Fury's failure to introduce a permanent budget until three months of the fiscal year had elapsed, said Elizabeth Urquhart, the president of the Council. Thomas Morrison, the city's finance director, said that without the temporary budget, the city would not be able to meet its $1 million biweekly payroll.

title: Last-Minute Support for Dole, Early Support From D'Amato
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's muted weekend endorsement of Bob Dole and Jack Kemp paid its principal political dividend yesterday when Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, his longtime rival, agreed to support the Mayor's re-election bid next year.

title: Business Groups Try to Forge a Unified Political Front
description: To Representative Greg Ganske of Iowa, a freshman Republican locked in a tight re-election race, the commercial that popped up on his television screen in Des Moines a few Sundays ago was like manna from heaven.

title: Woman Killed by Car, but Baby Is Saved
description: A woman from Brooklyn who was eight months pregnant was struck and killed by a car yesterday, but doctors and nurses at the Maimonides Medical Center saved her unborn baby.

title: No Commitment, No (Gasp!) Wetteland?
description: General Manager Bob Watson said the Yankees have exercised Darryl Strawberry's $750,000 option for next season and that they would also exercise Dwight Gooden's $2 million option for 1997 if he passes a physical examination. But the futures of John Wetteland and Jimmy Key remain very uncertain on the day New York is honoring the World Series champions with a ticker-tape parade.

title: Lawsuits by Guard Would Face Obstacles
description: Mr. Jewell's case raises serious questions about the role of the media in reporting confidential law-enforcement information about suspects, experts said. But because Mr. Jewell made himself available for interviews in the days he was being hailed as a hero for directing the police to the bomb and helping to evacuate the area, Mr. Walsh said, he might be viewed as having been a public figure when he was first identified as a suspect. Libel law makes it harder for someone deemed a public figure to sue for libel.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Derring-Do, Without Cliches,

title: Britain Seeks Informers To Fight Welfare Fraud
description: The caller seemed unsure about the nature of the fraud, though she was certain a fraud was being perpetrated.

title: Divided District, Distinct Candidates
description: If New York State had a version of the Mason-Dixon Line, dividing its urban Democratic south from its rural Republican north, it might well run through the serpentine 26th Congressional District.

title: Testing Two Cliches About Russians
description: It was a joy to hear Yevgeny Svetlanov and the State Symphony Orchestra of Russia settle into Tchaikovsky on Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, and at least one listener was a little sorry about that. It is too easy for Americans, whose orchestras take the world as their oyster, to hold foreign orchestras to stereotyped specialties. Who would expect a Russian orchestra to play, say, Mahler?

title: U.S. Charges AMR On Sabre System
description: The AMR Corporation and Sabre Group Holdings, its affiliated computer reservations system, violated laws prohibiting unfair and deceptive advertising, the Department of Transportation said today.

title: Belle Files To Become Free Agent
description: Ellis Burks, who under the pending labor agreement could have become a free agent, agreed yesterday to remain with the Colorado Rockies for $8.8 million over two years. At the same time, Albert Belle of Cleveland, who wants more than that sum per year, topped a list of 17 players who filed for free agency.

title: Q & A
description: Ladybugs at Home

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday showing examples of high-frequency airline routes referred imprecisely to some available fares. They were those that a business traveler could have booked at a particular time on Wednesday for travel on Thursday, with no advance purchase or other restrictions. Travelers, however, may be quoted higher or lower unrestricted fares on these flights, depending on passenger volume.

title: No-Nonsense Ex-Principal Backs Zimmer On Crime
description: Joe Clark, the former bat-wielding high school principal who gained national prominence for his tough disciplinary tactics, is like a campaign talisman for Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Jet Car Reaches 675 M.P.H., Then Crashes
description: An effort to recapture the world land speed record ended abruptly today when a jet-powered car driven by Craig Breedlove veered out of control in a high-speed run and was damaged.

title: Labor Leader Accused of Looting Union Fund
description: Frederick W. Devine, who until June drew an annual salary of $410,000 as the head of the carpenters' union in the New York City area, was indicted yesterday on state charges of stealing $240,000 from union and management funds to finance a regal spending spree.

title: This Millennium Will Be Televised
description: Times Square, which prides itself on being New Year's Eve Central, has big plans for Dec. 31, 1999, the day the world will flip over the calendar to another 1,000-year chapter. It plans a 24-hour party, celebrating the end of the millennium (actually a year early) in each of the planet's 24 time zones, starting in Fiji west of the international date line and continuing around the world to American Samoa.

title: For Big Labor, And New Chief, A Time to Smile
description: John J. Sweeney was at large today out on the political landscape, a meek-looking man who smiles more like a parish pastor tending his flock than the campaign guerrilla strategist who is furiously denounced by Republicans across the country as the bare-knuckled ''Boss of Big Labor.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about olive oils produced by vintners misstated the telephone number of the B. R. Cohn Winery in Glen Ellen, Calif. It is (800) 330-4064.

title: Race to Lead Hong Kong Stokes Fear of the Future
description: There have been no balloons, no bunting and no brass bands. No babies have been bussed, no handshakes at the rope line, and no rallies have jarred Hong Kong's single-minded pursuit of wealth.

title: POP
description: Signature Works of the 80's

title: Perot Says Inquires Would Hobble a Clinton Second Term
description: Ross Perot predicted today that the Whitewater investigation and related inquiries would develop into ''Watergate II'' if President Clinton was re-elected, and asserted that Mr. Clinton should have done ''the responsible thing'' by stepping down.

title: No Headline
description: ''We're probably the only cafe in town washing our hands in spring water.''

title: Wife of Olympic Official Is Fined
description: JULIE POUND has been fined $2,000 for a run-in with an Atlanta police officer during the Olympic Games. Pound, the wife of the International Olympic Committee vice president DICK POUND, pleaded guilty last week to charges of failure to comply with traffic instructions and disorderly conduct, said her lawyer, JIM MARTIN. He said she was fined $1,000 on each count.

title: Shares of ENI Climb After Sale
description: Shares in Italy's state-controlled ENI S.p.A. rose yesterday on the Milan stock exchange when trading started after a second stock sale by the oil and gas giant. The stock gained 20 lire, to 7,190. The sale of 14 percent of ENI was Italy's largest privatization. The Treasury Minister, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, said the sale had raised at least 7.7 trillion lire, or $5 billion.

title: The Titanic as Symbol, Weightier Than the Ship
description: DOWN WITH THE OLD CANOE

title: Dole Ads Vie With Radio Cacophony
description: In the service of Bob Dole, an ominous baritone had just accused Bill Clinton of coddling illegal immigrants with criminal records. But the next sound heard on KFI-AM radio was an explosive guffaw.

title: Missed Mideast Chance
description: With the departure of an American mediator early today without a deal on an Israeli pullout from the West Bank city of Hebron, Israelis and Palestinians fell into their familiar recriminations, each side accusing the other of preventing agreement.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-10

title: Elderly Voices for Medicare Repair
description: During a break in their aerobics class at a local gymnasium, elderly people here complained this week that neither President Clinton nor Bob Dole had seriously addressed the financial problems that face Medicare, the health insurance program they adore.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about news coverage of Richard A. Jewell, the security guard who was cleared as a suspect in the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta, referred incorrectly to the newspapers in which his situation was reported. The first article appeared in The Atlanta Journal and the other in its sister publication The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, not in The Journal.

title: Pitt Looks to Nebraska for an A.D.
description: STEVE PEDERSON, the associate athletic director at Nebraska, will succeed OVAL JAYNES as Pittsburgh's athletic director. Pederson, 39, was selected after a two-month search that followed Jaynes's resignation. Jaynes was recently hired as Idaho's athletic director. Pederson, who will begin his new job Dec. 1, faces the task of rebuilding what once was one of the East's top collegiate programs. Pitt is 2-6 in football and has had only one winning season since 1990, and the basketball team has won only 20 games in Coach RALPH WILLARD's first two years on the job. (AP)

title: Ewing Among All-Time Selections
description: PATRICK EWING is among the 50 players chosen as the greatest in National Basketball Association history, selected by a panel of news media, former players, former coaches and current and former team officials.

title: Why Leonardo Used a Mirror to Write
description: To the Editor:

title: Morrison Pleads Guilty to Firearm Charge
description: The heavyweight TOMMY MORRISON received a six-month suspended sentence and a $100 fine yesterday after pleading guilty to transporting a loaded firearm in Jay, Okla., in July.

title: As Fighting in Zaire Spreads, Rwanda Rules Out Talks
description: As fighting continued to spread chaos in eastern Zaire, Rwanda today rejected a United Nations proposal for peace talks with that country, saying it was not responsible for a revolt by members of the same ethnic group that controls the Rwandan Government.

title: Excerpts From Dole's Address on Affirmative Action
description: Following are excerpts, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, from a speech by Bob Dole yesterday in San Diego, where he endorsed a California ballot initiative that would bar all state-sponsored affirmative action programs.

title: Israel's Central Bank Announces Rate Cut
description: The Bank of Israel said yesterday that it would pare three-tenths of a percentage point from its discount rate next month, resisting pressure for a deeper cut. The new discount rate, which goes into effect on Friday, will be 15.2 percent, compared with the current rate of 15.5 percent. This is the fourth consecutive reduction; the discount rate has been cut 1.8 percentage points in four months.

title: Judge Questions Giuliani's Basis for Aiding Fox News Channel
description: Opening a hearing over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to help the media magnate Rupert Murdoch, a Federal judge expressed skepticism yesterday about the legality of the Mayor's plan to place Mr. Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel on a city-run cable station.

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Suspect Tells of Ordeal

title: Barkley Fight Costs Oakley Two Games and $11,000
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy pleaded for his team to be more aggressive last week, explaining that the Knicks needed to develop an ornery disposition on the court to go along with their talent. Charles Oakley promptly obliged, escorting Charles Barkley to the floor a day later in Houston during a preseason game.

title: No End to Images for Halloween 'Hell Houses'
description: To the Editor:

title: So Many Miles On the Way To This Title
description: A little over a month ago, Darryl Strawberry took time to remember what it was like to roll down Manhattan's canyon of heroes under a storm of ticker tape with the 1986 World Series champion Mets.

title: Henkel Offers $1.12 Billion For Loctite
description: Henkel K.G.a.A., the German consumer products manufacturer, said yesterday that it had made a $1.12 billion offer for the Loctite Corporation, a specialty chemical maker based in Hartford.

title: MAZDA SUED BY 14 STATES OVER ADVERTISEMENTS
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation of America is being sued by 14 states that contend the auto maker used false and deceptive ads to lure consumers into expensive car lease agreements. The suits contend Mazda's ''one penny, or zero down'' advertising campaign earlier this year led consumers to believe they would get a new car for next to nothing, when the leases in fact cost about $900 in fees and payments. The company, based in Irving, Calif., had no immediate response. Joining Illinois in similar legal actions are Arizona, California, Connecticut, Hawaii, Idaho, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, Nevada, Ohio and Washington.

title: POP
description: A Singer Revealing Herself,

title: In Conservative Wyoming, the Lines Are Blurring
description: Hardly any state is more Republican than Wyoming.

title: Discovery of Breast Cancer Gene Produces Clues but No Answers
description: JUST two years ago, a team of scientists won a fevered race to find an elusive gene that causes breast cancer in women who inherit it. And researchers hoped, with bated breath, that it might be the answer to breast cancer.

title: Trail Blazers Suspend Rider for Opener
description: The Portland Trail Blazers suspended ISAIAH RIDER for their season opener in Vancouver on Friday night for failing to show up for the team's final exhibition game, against the Seattle SuperSonics, on Sunday. Rider missed the team bus, and later told team officials that a cab had taken him to the wrong hotel.

title: From Talk To Murder, Via TV
description: A courtroom is a place of clear-cut questions and answers, including one that the prosecutor in a Pontiac, Mich., murder trial asked a television producer yesterday.

title: Jets May Lose Lewis for Year
description: The Jets said today that Mo Lewis, their weakside linebacker, had torn the pectoral muscle on the left side of his chest. A team spokesman said the situation ''is not looking good'' and said ''there is a distinct possibility'' that Lewis would need season-ending surgery.

title: George P. Oslin, 97, Executive Who Put Songs Into Telegrams
description: George P. Oslin, the Western Union executive who created that durable art form, the singing telegram, in the grim Depression year of 1933, died on Thursday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 97.

title: Oil Price Rise Stirs Concerns Of Forecasters
description: The $4-a-barrel increase in oil prices since June, while modest compared with the surges that led to or worsened the recessions of the 1970's, 1980's and 1990's, is beginning to worry forecasters.

title: PRIDE PETROLEUM TO BUY FRENCH DRILLING COMPANY
description: The well-servicing and drilling contractor Pride Petroleum Services Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the French drilling company Forasol-Foramer N.V. for about $281 million in cash and stock. The combination would create a company with more than 700 drilling rigs and with expected revenue of more than $750 million a year, Forasol said. Pride Petroleum, which is based in Houston, said the deal would increase the percentage of its revenue generated from offshore operations to 30 percent from 13 percent. Forasol stockholders would receive 0.66 Pride Petroleum common share and $6.80 cash for each share held. Shares of Forasol jumped $2 yesterday, to $15.875. Shares of Pride rose 62.5 cents, to $15.875.

title: Scholars Debate Roots of Yiddish, Migration of Jews
description: TRYING to trace the ancient roots of a modern language is always a maddeningly ambiguous and uncertain enterprise. With Yiddish, the language of the Ashkenazic Jews of Central and Eastern Europe, the task is even harder because of the horrifying fact that most of the speakers were exterminated in the Holocaust.

title: Beethovenizing a Publisher's Little Tune
description: The ''Diabelli'' Variations are inspired as much by confinement as freedom of movement. Sixteen bars of waltz time -- a publisher's tune and part of a sales promotion to which Schubert, Czerny and an 11-year-old Liszt also contributed -- go nowhere on their own and say little for themselves. Beethoven was solicited for only one variation, but with characteristic obsessiveness wrote 33.

title: Dangerous Delay on Hebron
description: Just a few days ago Israeli and Palestinian negotiators seemed close to agreement on withdrawing Israeli troops from most of the West Bank city of Hebron, as called for in the Oslo peace agreements. But now the talks have stalled. The key Palestinian decision-maker, Yasir Arafat, is off on a weeklong trip to Europe and President Clinton's mediator, Dennis Ross, is returning to the United States for consultations. An agreement still seems within reach. But given the high potential for violence in the region, further delay is dangerous.

title: A Team You Almost Had to Like
description: For a while, Alan Leidner's romance with the Yankees turned stormy.

title: Blood-Testing Fraud Alleged
description: The owner of a Pennsylvania testing laboratory was indicted yesterday and was accused of billing the New Jersey Medicaid program $313,233 since April for tests on blood samples bought from drug addicts and submitted under the names of patients, prosecutors said.

title: Act II: Enter the Second Lines
description: As painful as it is to contradict F. Scott Fitzgerald, it sometimes seems that American life is becoming nothing but second acts.

title: Singapore Airlines Shows 7.2% Rise in Net
description: The shares of Singapore Airlines Ltd. fell yesterday after the company posted a 7.2 percent increase in profits for the six months that ended on Sept. 30, compared with expectations for gains of more than 14 percent. It earned less money per mile flown and paid higher fuel prices.

title: Jets Bring Out Creative Side of Cross
description: Randy Cross is familiar with Hades. As a player he toiled for the pre-Bill Walsh, 2-14 San Francisco 49ers of 1978, which he claimed underachieved more than the 0-14 Tampa Bay Buccaneers of 1976. As a CBS analyst, he was a big man in the Bays -- Green and Tampa -- when the former was as wretched as the latter.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter by Dick Thornburgh, published on Friday, misstated his criticism of the Thomas L. Friedman column ''A Dear Jiang Letter.'' Mr. Thornburgh believes that appointing a new legislature in Hong Kong is not China's ''business'' and that Mr. Friedman was wrong to say that it is.

title: Harding Helps to Save Woman's Life
description: TONYA HARDING, a villainess in public minds during an Olympic figure skating fiasco with NANCY KERRIGAN in 1994, was being saluted as a hero yesterday, after helping to save a woman's life Sunday night at a bar in suburban Portland, Ore., near her home. Shortly after Harding and her godmother LINDA LEWIS stopped at the Lost and Found Saloon to play video poker, ALICE OLSON, 81, collapsed and stopped breathing. Harding called 911 with her cellular phone and administered mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. Olson, who suffers from heart problems and diabetes, was treated at a hospital and released yesterday. (AP)

title: Unicef Head Says Thousands of Children Are Dying in Iraq
description: About 4,500 children under the age of 5 are dying every month in Iraq of hunger or disease, Carol Bellamy, the executive director of Unicef, said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AVACIR AVILA, a shopkeeper in Rosario do Ivai, a tiny village in the state of Parana, in southern Brazil, discovered recently that he was officially dead.

title: In His Own Words
description: RICHARD A. ZIMMER

title: Paper Blizzards: A New York Tradition
description: The tradition of ticker-tape parades began spontaneously enough in 1886, when a group of downtown office workers emptied their stock tickers and rained the contents down onto a parade for the dedication of the Statue of Liberty. Then, in 1919, the city's official greeter, Grover A. Whalen, institutionalized the parades, making them the norm for aviators, soldiers, sports heroes and virtually all visiting heads of state, from the obscure to the historic. Here is a sampling of parades past.

title: On Preserving That Palace of Pinstripes
description: LAST spring, this column asked, Why shouldn't the Yankees move from the Bronx to a world-class new stadium in Manhattan? The column also answered its own question, advocating a move with reasoned arguments, persuasive statistics and a dash of savvy New York philosophy.

title: Calenergy Offers to Buy British Utility
description: The Calenergy Company of Omaha offered yesterday to acquire Northern Electric P.L.C. of Britain for $1.23 billion. Though Northern rejected the offer as too low only hours later, Calenergy said it planned to bring its offer directly to shareholders of the British company.

title: Swiss Bank Reports Gain in 9-Month Profit
description: Union Bank of Switzerland, the country's biggest bank, said yesterday that its operating earnings for the first nine months of 1996 had exceeded last year's profits, but third-quarter earnings were below those in the previous quarters. Union Bank said it expected a good full-year result even though provisions tied to bad loans in the shrinking Swiss economy were ''significantly higher'' in the first nine months and would limit operating profits for the last year.

title: Accounts
description: Long Island Savings Bank, Melville, L.I., a subsidiary of the Long Island Bancorp, to Warwick Baker O'Neill, New York, to handle its account, previously handled by Emmerling Post, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Those Chilly Sheets
description: Ghosts walk on Halloween, thus supporting my opinion that for pure stupidity you can't beat your typical ghost. When I become a ghost, the Fourth of July is the day on which I'll do my walking, thank you.

title: Tandem, in Transition, Names a President
description: Looking to reinvigorate its franchise selling high-performance computers to blue-chip customers, Tandem Computers Inc. yesterday named Enrico Pesatori, a former top executive at the Digital Equipment Corporation, as its new president and chief operating officer.

title: Fallon McElligott Executive Switches
description: Steve Sjoblad, managing director at Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, will join Fallon McElligott Berlin, its affiliate in New York, in the new position of president.

title: The Yankees: The People and the Moments That Made a Season Full of Stories
description: When the last out of the World Series fell safely into the glove of New York's Charlie Hayes late last Saturday night and the Yankees had won their first title in 18 years, few words were necessary to tell the story. As the players rushed to the mound and built their pyramid of arms and legs, the frenzied Yankee Stadium crowd provided all the communication necessary with a sustained roar that filled the night air.

title: Honor the Witch
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope to Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: An Atrium for the Citadel of Capitalism
description: In a development plan that would drastically alter the look and street life of the historic core of the city's financial district, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it hoped to expand its cramped trading floor with a glass-enclosed eight-story atrium over Broad Street.

title: A Spectator's Guide
description: a ticker-tape parade honoring the World Series champion New York Yankees begins at 11:30 A.M. at Battery Park in lower Manhattan and travels north on Broadway, the city's Canyon of Heroes, to Chambers Street. Following the parade, each Yankee will receive a key to the city at a rally outside City Hall which is expected to start at 1:30 P.M.

title: Jury Service Less Onerous, Report Says
description: Jury duty, long the dreary bane of New Yorkers, has become significantly less onerous, thanks to changes in the system since 1993, with people called less often and for shorter periods, according to a report issued yesterday by the court administrative office.

title: Patterns
description: Making Macy's Easier

title: Russian Rockets Get Lift in U.S. From Cautious and Clever Design
description: THE Russians lost the cold war, but they are starting to win the international race to fire hundreds of new satellites and spacecraft into the heavens, challenging Western rocket scientists and companies for launching jobs worth billions of dollars.

title: Sun Offers Lower-Cost Computer for Networking
description: The effort to convince corporate America that the cost of computing can be drastically reduced will begin in earnest today, as Sun Microsystems Inc. announces its strategy for the so-called network computer.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS DROPS PLAN TO BUILD JUMBO JET
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it was dropping plans for a new jumbo jetliner, all but conceding that business to the Boeing Company, to concentrate on making military aircraft and smaller passenger planes. McDonnell Douglas, citing the large investment in development and infrastructure the venture would have required, made the cancellation announcement just one month after disclosing plans for the jet. Shares of McDonnell Douglas, which is based in St. Louis, fell $1.125 yesterday, to $52.

title: Documents Rebut White House on Ex-Trade Aide
description: A few days after leaving the employment of an Indonesian billionaire to become a trade official in the Clinton Administration, John Huang attended at least two meetings at which important Indonesian trade issues were discussed, newly released Commerce Department documents show.

title: D.M.V. Reviews Access
description: The state's Division of Motor Vehicles said yesterday that it would stop supplying 741 registered companies and individuals with driver information by telephone, pending a review of how each subscriber uses the information. The move came after The North Jersey Herald and News reported that two of the clients, Compinstall Inc. of Brooklyn and Dig Dirt Inc. of Berkeley Heights, advertised the sale of New Jersey driver information, said John Graf, a spokesman for the division. The agency's action affects private detectives, insurance companies and others. Companies that are denied telephone access after the review will still be able to get the information one case at a time by making a written request, Mr. Graf said.

title: Undermining France
description: To the Editor:

title: Tramping With Chic
description: Boots for fall are either ankle-high, to wear with pants and long skirts, or knee-high, to wear with shorter skirts. Toes are squared and heels are thick, not spindly, in any height that pleases.

title: Coca-Cola Expands Role of Lowe Unit
description: The Coca-Cola Company, in another shuffling of assignments among its many agencies, said yesterday that it had named the Lowe & Partners/SMS unit of the Lowe Group in New York, which handles Diet Coke, to handle creative responsibilities for Coca-Cola Light, the name under which Diet Coke is sold in many overseas markets. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Rayovac Account Is Under Review
description: The Rayovac Corporation said yesterday that it had placed the account of its battery and flashlight products in review after 13 years at FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Police Captain Is Suspended Over Statistics
description: A police commander, a 30-year veteran of the department, was suspended yesterday on charges that he falsified reports to show a greater reduction in crime in the South Bronx, police officials said.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sunday about the new Kmart in Manhattan misspelled the name of a now-defunct New York discount department store. The store was Ohrbach's.

title: PALL IN STOCK DEAL FOR GELMAN SCIENCES
description: The Pall Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Gelman Sciences Inc. for about $33 a share in stock, or $264 million, bolstering its position as a leading maker of disposable filters and membranes used in health care and fluid processing. Pall, based in East Hills, L.I., outbid an offer made in August by Australia's Memtec Ltd. Pall stock could be exchanged for Gelman stock at a ratio that would depend on the average closing price for Pall shares for 30 days before a Gelman shareholders meeting in late November. Shares of Gelman rose 25 cents yesterday, to $30.125. Shares of Pall fell $1.125, to $25.25; American depository shares of Memtec jumped $5.50, to $34.75.

title: Prodigy Executive Takes Post at G.E.
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had hired Prodigy Inc.'s chief operating officer, William J. Lansing, as head of corporate business development.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Calenergy in $1.23 Billion Offer for British Utility

title: Passion Spills Out of American Design
description: Within American fashion beats a heart as criminally passionate as any in France. The Bernadette Corporation, Kenneth Richard and Mark Whitaker (actually an Englishman who commutes between London and New York) had their hearts all over their courageous spring collections.

title: Chiu-an Wang, 82, Retired Boston Surgeon
description: Chiu-an Wang, a retired chief of endocrine surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital and clinical professor at Harvard Medical School, died on Thursday in Fox Hill Village, a retirement community in Westwood, Mass. He was 82 and formerly lived in Cambridge and Lexington, Mass.

title: Albert G. Hill, 86, Who Helped Develop Radar in World War II
description: Albert G. Hill, a professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who played an important role in the development of radar in World War II, died on Oct. 21 at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 86.

title: Corrections
description: A photography listing in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday misstated the opening date for ''Maria Callas: 40th Anniversary Celebration,'' an exhibition of work by Paul Seligman at the Modernage Gallery. It is today, not Thursday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AGCO CORP., Duluth, Ga., a maker of agricultural and related replacement parts, said it planned to buy the Latin American agriculture equipment maker Deutz Argentina S.A., for an undisclosed price.

title: Director of Justice Resigns Albany Post
description: Paul Shechtman, New York State's director of criminal justice and the chief architect of Gov. George E. Pataki's crime policies, announced today that he was resigning.

title: Governor's Back Strain
description: A strained back continued to plague Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday, forcing her to spend a second day in bed, a spokeswoman said. Mrs. Whitman canceled a scheduled announcement about an agreement with Okidata, an electronics company, that will keep 600 jobs in the state, said the spokeswoman, Jayne Rebovich. Ms. Rebovich said the Governor went hiking in the Highlands region on Saturday, but said it was not clear that she had injured her back during that trip.

title: At Churches Across the Nation, Christian Coalition Flexes Political Muscles
description: In a room above the pastor's office at the Bellevue Christian Center, Doug Patton unfolded a map of Nebraska's Second Congressional District, marked by dozens of blue dots, and held it aloft for 18 Christian Coalition volunteers to study.

title: Darwin Under the Microscope
description: Pope John Paul II's statement last week that evolution is ''more than just a theory'' is old news to a Roman Catholic scientist like myself.

title: Pied Piper Of Cable Beguiles Rivals' Children
description: It used to be simple. Children watched television on Saturday mornings. Cartoon fare was what they were given, and cartoon fare was what they watched.

title: A Lesson in Politics
description: South Hunterdon Regional High School students were pulled into the 12th District Congressional race yesterday after a candidate, Mike Pappas, missed a debate that had been scheduled for weeks.

title: Broken Water Mains Sow Familiar Chaos
description: Three of New York City's brittle, aging water mains broke after a device that regulates pressure gave way, causing a chain reaction that flooded the streets of lower Manhattan, left homes and businesses without water for most of the day and snarled traffic for hours.

title: Ewing Ices Queasy Bradley
description: Tonight's final tuneup before the regular season revealed a Knicks team in need of a few final touches, while the Nets could use an entire finishing coat.

title: Microsoft And Intel Shift PC Strategy to Meet Network Threat
description: Hoping to blunt potential competition from the emerging ''network computer'' standard endorsed by Sun Microsystems, Oracle, I.B.M. and others, the powerful PC axis of Microsoft and Intel announced a strategy today to reduce the cost of owning and using personal computers.

title: Russia to Give U.S. Museum Files Detailing Nazi Crimes
description: The Russian Government said today that it would hand over to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum 15,000 pages of documents describing Nazi atrocities that had until now remained buried in the archives of the former K.G.B.

title: As Torricelli Leaves Town, Supporter Attacks His Foe
description: With a little more than a week to go before the Nov. 5 election, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, was in California, meeting with potential campaign contributors and attending a $500-a-person cocktail party held on his behalf at Universal Studios.

title: France and Europe Have Role in Mideast Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: More Than Panthers Loom Over Rangers
description: The National Hockey League office said yesterday that it is reviewing Sunday's finish of the Rangers' 6-4 victory over the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden.

title: Stock Fund Cash Flows Seem Slower
description: Seasonal investor nervousness, dwindling contributions to 401(k) retirement plans and uncertainty about the short-term direction of the stock market have combined to take some of the spark out of cash flows into equity mutual funds in October.

title: Stain on American Troops Spreads Across Japan
description: When officials sought a new place in Japan for American troops to practice artillery fire for eight days a year, this remote farming town seemed a likely candidate.

title: Attacking the Environmental Bond Act
description: The following 30-second television advertisement attacking the $1.75 billion Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act has begun running on Long Island and across the state north of New York City. The spot was paid for by a group called a Bunch of New Yorkers Who Like the Environment but Know the Bond Act Is a Big Waste of Money, financed by most of the same wealthy executives behind Change-N.Y., an antitax group.

title: Fontes Lands on the Lions' Bad Side
description: Coach Wayne Fontes may have slipped the noose around his own neck Sunday when he humiliated quarterback Scott Mitchell with a bizarre yo-yo routine in the Detroit Lions' 35-7 loss to the Giants.

title: For Jets, One Victory And a Chance to Dream
description: When the Jets returned from road games earlier this season, players said that the flights were marked by self-castigation and plenty of could haves, should haves and would haves.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Selling Shares, Russian Gas Monopoly Generates Its Own Fuel
description: Few Russian companies are able to entice Westerners to line up to buy their shares, given the unstable political and economic situation in the country. But investors raced to buy the initial public offering of Gazprom, Russia's huge natural gas company, today and paid a premium for the shares when trading opened in London.

title: Ex-Union Head Stole Funds, Officials Say
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan said that Frederick W. Devine, who until June drew an annual salary of $410,000 as the head of the carpenters' union in the New York City area, siphoned off $240,000 from union funds that were intended to create jobs for unemployed carpenters.

title: Beware of Questions in New York Bond Measure
description: To the Editor:

title: In Houston, a Premiere Of a Mexican's Work
description: Contemporary opera in Mexico has not been thriving. And what there is, Mexico's neighbor to the north has largely ignored. So the world premiere of Daniel Catan's ''Florencia en el Amazonas'' at the Houston Grand Opera on Friday night was, in part, an attempt to rectify past neglect. This production, also sponsored by the Los Angeles Music Center Opera, the Seattle Opera and the Opera de Colombia, is said to be the first Spanish-language opera by a Mexican composer to be commissioned by American companies.

title: Merrill Announces Successor for Top Posts
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that David H. Komansky, its president and chief operating officer, would succeed Daniel P. Tully as chief executive at the end of the year.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: U.S. to Face Guatemala

title: Chess
description: The gold medal winners in the 1996 Olympiad were certainly a surprise.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about the newest outbreak of fires in Southern California referred to the casualties incorrectly in some copies. A death did not occur.

title: First Lady Appears at a Rally To Praise and Support Bredes
description: Nora Bredes is widely viewed as an underdog in her bid to recapture New York's First Congressional District for the Democrats. But her chances were encouraging enough for Hillary Rodham Clinton to devote precious hours campaigning here in the Presidential race's final week.

title: American Express Net Is Up, But Its Revenues Are Flat
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, as its investment services unit continued to outperform its credit card operations.

title: Women Gain Bridge Finals
description: One American team will compete in playoffs here Tuesday in the World Bridge Championships, but the other fell short. The United States women's team, which won its qualifying pool on Sunday, will play a quarterfinal match against the Netherlands.

title: Shared Views
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: MAYA ANGELOU, the poet, is doing double duty at the United Nations today. At 1:15 this afternoon, she is being sworn in as the American Ambassador to Unicef. At 5 P.M., she is to moderate an awards ceremony at which JULIE ANDREWS, the actress, will present achievement awards to three women's organizations sponsored by the United Nations Development Fund for Women. Speakers at the ceremony are to include BOUTROS BOUTROS-GHALI, the Secretary General of the United Nations, and, via video, HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON.

title: Miriam Kressyn, 84, Mainstay of Yiddish Theater
description: Miriam Kressyn, a star of the Yiddish stage and, along with her husband, Seymour Rechtzeit, a primary force in the survival of Yiddish theater in the United States, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On Nov. 30 in Hong Kong, GONG LI, the Chinese movie star, who is in ''Temptress Moon,'' the new movie directed by Chen Kaige, will have a delayed wedding reception to celebrate her marriage to OOI HOE-SEONG, a Singapore businessman. The wedding took place early this year, said a spokesman for the actress. The location of the wedding reception has not been disclosed. ELAINE LOUIE

title: 2 Languages in Montreal
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Ex-Sumitomo Trader Will Plead Guilty, His Attorney Says
description: Former Sumitomo Corporation copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka will plead guilty to forging the names of his superiors on documents, his attorney said today.

title: MERCANTILE IN $855 MILLION DEAL FOR MARK TWAIN
description: Seeking to strengthen its position in its home state of Missouri, Mercantile Bancorporation said yesterday that it would acquire Mark Twain Bancshares Inc. for $855 million. Mercantile agreed to pay 0.952 share for each share of Mark Twain, an offer worth about $49.50 a share based on Friday's prices. Mark Twain shares rose $3.625 yesterday, to $46. Shares of Mercantile fell $2, to $50. Mercantile and Mark Twain are based in St. Louis. Mark Twain, with $3.1 billion in assets, has 39 branches, mostly in the St. Louis and Kansas City areas. Mercantile, with $18.2 billion in assets, has about 440 branches in Missouri, Illinois, Iowa and Arkansas. Mercantile said it would carry out the transaction tax free.

title: Your Best Face on The Web
description: IF you are one of the two or three people who do not have their own pages on the World Wide Web, perhaps it is the thought of having to learn HTML that is stopping you. The Hypertext Markup Language is not as arcane as C++, but it does involve learning things.

title: He Felt Much 'Like a Hunted Animal'
description: Leveling a blistering attack on the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the news media, Richard A. Jewell today held an emotional news conference that laid the groundwork for lawsuits against those who had portrayed him as the leading suspect in the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park in July.

title: SportsTuesday
description: New York will salute the Yankees with a ticker-tape parade today. A special section begins on page B1.

title: Lesson: Avoid Graves
description: As the world slouches toward the millennium, television's selling of otherworldly phenomena accelerates. Extraterrestrials inhabit series like ''The X-Files'' and ''Dark Skies.'' Paranormal activity is the very stuff of ''Millennium'' and ''Profiler.'' Prime time seems determined to scare viewers silly.

title: The Yankees conquered the world, only to find that baseball doesn't sell the way it used to.
description: WILL the Yankees' victory parade today include a phalanx of pitchmen in pinstripes marching up Madison Avenue? That seems as likely as Ted Turner's agreeing to sell the Atlanta Braves to Rupert Murdoch.

title: Pakistan Is Coping With Effects of Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: Punt It? Punt It. Punt It? Punt It.
description: Ask 900 other coaches, said West Virginia Coach Don Nehlen, and every one would have made the same decision. Punt.

title: Water-Main Breaks Disrupt 30 Blocks in Lower Manhattan
description: Three of New York City's brittle, aging water mains broke early yesterday after a device that regulates pressure gave way, causing a chain reaction that flooded the streets of lower Manhattan, left homes and businesses without water for most of the day and snarled traffic for hours.

title: U.A.W. Says It Will Work Without Pact During Talks
description: The United Automobile Workers said today that it would continue to negotiate with General Motors and keep workers on the job without a contract, while scheduling a meeting of senior union leaders on Saturday.

title: Young Receiver Fuels Giants' Momentum
description: At one point this season, wide receiver Thomas Lewis was fed up. With everything, really. There was a time when he contemplated not speaking with the news media because he thought he was getting unnecessarily and unfairly criticized. But instead of going into his own little world, he focused on football. The result? He has emerged a solid receiver.

title: Clinton Hails Drop in Deficit, Declaring 'America's Awake'
description: As his quest for re-election moved into its final week, President Clinton today pointed to new figures showing that the Federal deficit had dropped to its lowest level since 1981 and proclaimed, ''America's awake and moving in the right direction.''

title: On Israel's Side
description: To the Editor:

title: The F.B.I.'s Latest Lapse
description: If the Federal Bureau of Investigation is lucky, the debate over the hounding of Richard Jewell will focus on the press coverage of the case. But the more important story here is the conduct of the F.B.I. Based on Kevin Sack's reconstruction of the Jewell investigation in yesterday's Times, the F.B.I. of the 90's looks very much like an agency that has not learned from the excesses of the 60's and 70's.

title: Simon's Seat Up for Grabs
description: Labels belong on soup cans, so please, says the Democratic Representative Richard J. Durbin, do not tag him with one, especially not ''liberal.'' These days, it makes him nervous. He hopes to become the next United States Senator from Illinois, and he wants everyone to know that he stands chest-deep in the mainstream.

title: The Food Is Serious (The Fun Is, Too)
description: If Tribute is your destination, give yourself an extra 10 minutes. Chances are you'll pass it once or twice. The understated restaurant sits sandwiched between a Marathon gasoline station and a Best Western on a busy road in Farmington Hills, Mich., a suburb of Detroit. There are few clues to Tribute's treasures, but once you enter the restaurant, you know you've arrived.

title: Don't Surrender to Lower Housing Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Trains Its Lights on A Master Of Shadow
description: Move over, Jane Austen: here comes Henry James.

title: Starting the Day With Some Spice
description: For 31 years, traditional Southwestern food has drawn New Mexicans for lunch and dinner to Rancho de Chimayo, a family restaurant nestled in the hills between Taos and Santa Fe. Now the restaurant has added breakfast, with variations on its New Mexican specialties.

title: Graham Swift's 'Last Orders' Receives the Booker Prize
description: ''Last Orders,'' Graham Swift's novel about a journey to Kent by four Londoners to fulfill a friend's dying wish by scattering his ashes into the sea, won the 1996 Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious literary award, tonight.

title: Matchup for the Ages Is Revisited by N.B.A.
description: Bill Russell and Wilt Chamberlain stood side by side yesterday at a podium, commanding the attention of everyone in the room. For Chamberlain, being that close to Russell, his longtime nemesis, brought back haunting memories.

title: SHARES OF DSP COMMUNICATIONS DECLINE 32%
description: DSP Communications Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., agreed yesterday to buy a rival wireless equipment maker, Proxim Inc., for $400 million in stock, causing a plunge in DSP shares on concern that the price is too high. Proxim's stockholders will receive 0.70 DSP share for each share, valuing the transaction at $26.25 a share. Proxim stock closed at $21.50, up $2.797, a sign that investors have doubts that DSP will end up paying what it is offering. DSP shares plunged $17.125, or more than 32 percent, to $35.25. Proxim, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes equipment used to provide wireless data services.

title: Private Contracts Don't Help Public Schools, Report Says
description: A new study of efforts to privatize public education concludes that experiments have thus far failed to show any substantial results toward improving education or cutting costs.

title: Interest Rates Drop Sharply In Bond Rally
description: Prices of Treasury securities reached their highest levels in six months yesterday, as new data on employment costs and consumer confidence increased investors' expectations that inflation would not accelerate.

title: A Parade of Pride in Yankee Triumph
description: With its lungs and its heart, New York City at its effulgent extreme saluted the triumphant Yankees yesterday in a rousing ticker tape parade up lower Broadway's Canyon of Heroes.

title: Democrats Release Records
description: After criticism, the Democratic Party made public an accounting of its contributions for the first two weeks of October. Page A18.

title: Big Swiss Brewery Cuts Jobs and Capacity
description: Feldschlosschen-Hurlimann Holding A.G., Switzerland's largest brewer, said yesterday that it would cut a fifth of its work force and reduce brewing capacity by a third in an effort to restore earnings growth. A charge of 315 million Swiss francs ($249 million) will be taken against earnings for the fiscal year. Some 680 jobs will be cut, while capacity will disappear at breweries in Zurich, Bern and Fribourg.

title: Vice Problem? Round Up The Usual Detectives!
description: Sometimes a little scandal doesn't hurt a show. Months ago, when CBS stations saw the pilot of ''Public Morals,'' Steven Bochco's new sitcom set in the vice squad of the New York City Police Department, there was a mini-outcry about the show's vulgar language and salacious content. The truly offensive aspect of the show, though, was that it was excruciatingly unfunny.

title: For Congress From Connecticut
description: Connecticut has long been fortunate in the generally high quality of its Congressional delegation, and once voters have chosen a House member, they tend to keep him or her in office a long time. All six Congressional races this year feature veteran incumbents. Here are our recommendations in three of the more competitive contests.

title: Calipari's Frustration Is Growing Each Day
description: Perhaps it's the realization that these players don't always raise their hand, take notes, or stay after the bell rings. This isn't like college for John Calipari, whose growing frustration with the pro mentality seemed to snap when he kicked guard Khalid Reeves out of the Nets' practice today.

title: Yet Another Sex Difference Found: Gaining Relief From a Painkiller
description: WHEN President Clinton first uttered the remark ''I feel your pain'' back in 1992, he may have set himself up for years of razzing and mockery, but in one sense, at least, he was right: the person he was addressing, an irate AIDS activist, was male.

title: News Corporation Promotes 2 Executives to Top Posts
