description: In a move that underscores the growing importance of film and television programming at the News Corporation, the company yesterday promoted Peter Chernin, the chairman of the 20th Century Fox unit, to the newly created position of president of the News Corporation.

title: Lonrho Chief Sells Stake and Steps Down
description: Lonrho P.L.C. said yesterday that its chief executive, Dieter Bock, had sold his 18.3 percent stake in the company to the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa for $:257.4 million ($411 million) and would step down from his post. Lonrho said Mr. Bock would become deputy chairman and a nonexecutive director. He will be replaced as chief executive by Lonrho's deputy managing director, Nicholas Morrell.

title: Plain Old Milk? Not Anymore
description: Those who remember the days when supermarkets offered only two kinds of milk, whole or skim, probably remember the Yankee's winning the World Series on a regular basis, not just every 18 years.

title: Dodge pushes its campaign for the pickup truck to a new frontier: ads without cowboys.
description: IT used to be that you could count on seeing a couple of cowboys in almost every new ad for a pickup truck.

title: Childs Out Five Games
description: Chris Childs, who wanted so badly to run the Knicks' offense opening night in Toronto, will miss at least the first five games of the season.

title: Hubbell Settlement With Rose Law Firm
description: Webster L. Hubbell, a former Associate Attorney General, will pay the Rose Law Firm $400,000 in restitution of money he admitted stealing from clients and the firm, according to documents filed today in United States District Court here.

title: Union Bank Official Is Charged with Fraud
description: The Union Bank of Switzerland said yesterday that its private banking unit, the Cantrade Private Bank Switzerland (C.I.) Ltd., and one of its officers had been charged with fraud by the police on the Channel Island of Jersey. The bank identified the officer as Peter Stoneman and said he had been suspended pending resolution of the charges against him.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BREED TECHNOLOGIES INC., Lakeland, Fla., which manufactures automotive crash sensors and airbag systems, acquired the steering wheel unit of United Technologies Corp., for an undisclosed amount.

title: Ten Chosen to Receive Whiting Writers' Prizes
description: Ten writers have been named to receive the annual Whiting Writers' Awards, $30,000 prizes given by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation to worthy emerging writers. These are the recipients and their works.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: 3 Paul Taylor Dances That Define 3 Decades
description: ''The Wrecker's Ball,'' tonight's ''Great Performances'' presentation on PBS, nudges the long distinguished ''Dance in America'' portion of the series onto still another exceptionally rewarding level.

title: Zimmer Has Set Aside Calm for His Political Passions
description: Like many things about Richard A. Zimmer, the farm he calls home, with its 152-year-old clapboard house and rusty, rooster-shaped weather vane, can easily be misunderstood. Although he and his family have lived here for 20 years, Mr. Zimmer has never actually been much of a farmer.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: It's the Media, Stupid
description: If any American has the right to cry in public about the abuse he's taken from the press, it's Richard Jewell, who, after ''88 days of hell,'' now takes his place in history as the latest torture victim of our permanent O. J. media culture.

title: Direct Marketing Awards Presented
description: FCB Direct in New York, a unit of True North Communications, has taken top honors, winning four awards, at the 67th annual International Echo Awards competition sponsored by the Direct Marketing Association.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Giants' Toomer Out for Season
description: The Giants' improved kick-return game got thrown for a sizable loss yesterday when the team announced that the knee surgery wide receiver Amani Toomer underwent late Monday will force him to miss the rest of his rookie season.

title: Heating Oil Supplies Climb As Eastern U.S. Stays Warm
description: After months of dwindling inventories and rising prices, supplies of heating oil and diesel fuel climbed sharply in the last week, continuing a recent turnaround, the American Petroleum Institute reported late yesterday.

title: Two Referendums Are Kept Off the Ballot
description: New York State's highest court dealt a fatal blow yesterday to a lawyer's efforts to place two referendums on the Nov. 5 ballot -- one creating a $100 limit on campaign contributions to city officials and another requiring public debates for all city candidates who take public financing.

title: NBC Says It's Still Angry
description: NBC is still upset at Major League Baseball for allegedly reneging on a deal to let it televise Game 4 of the Texas-New York division series in prime time. Angry enough to sue? ''We were all in shock over that,'' said Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports. ''We're exploring every possibility so in the future, we're not forced to put on a lesser game.'' Instead, NBC broadcast a St. Louis-San Diego game, while ESPN telecast the Yankee game at 1 P.M., directly against a Baltimore-Cleveland game on ESPN2.

title: Decision of a Lifetime, Possibly Three Lifetimes
description: Benoit Jacquot's small, dazzling film ''A Single Girl'' is so buoyant, sharp-eyed and casually sexy it comes closer than any recent movie to capturing the essence of youth itself. Set in contemporary Paris, this life-on-the-run portrait of a woman of 19 or so, filmed in real time, puts you in the shoes of its impetuous central character during the hour it takes her to arrive at a major life decision. The movie, much of which was shot with hand-held cameras, is so fast on its feet that you find yourself almost breathless as the cameras follow her around the city.

title: Mariners Get the Expos' Fassero
description: The Montreal Expos, continuing to shed top players before they become high-priced players, traded their top pitcher yesterday and had two other players file for free agency.

title: Candidate Gets Recipient View of Welfare
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer was touting the role he played in changing welfare and proudly observing a new computerized welfare services system today when his otherwise well-orchestrated event hit a slight glitch.

title: There Was Plenty of Cheering in the Anchor Box
description: Can any station -- let alone six -- make live parade coverage fascinating for two and a half hours? Not really.

title: Winning Streak at Fox
description: The World Series did more than give the Fox network its first weekly ratings victory (while also sending CBS and then ABC to their first fourth-place finishes). The momentum from the series helped Fox achieve initial success for the two biggest programming moves it made this season.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Peter W. Hoguet, a lawyer, economist and investment banker who was involved in the defection of a Soviet schoolteacher from the Soviet Consulate in Manhattan in 1948, misspelled the teacher's surname in some editions. She was Oksana S. Kosenkina, not Kasenkina.

title: Blues Get Turgeon and Trade Corson
description: The St. Louis Blues yesterday acquired the center their star wing, BRETT HULL, has wanted, getting PIERRE TURGEON from the Montreal Canadiens in a five-player deal.

title: The Clinton Factor Fuels Final Tactics In New Jersey Race
description: With polls showing President Clinton enjoying a strong lead in New Jersey, the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate is counting on the Clinton-Gore ticket to help sweep him into office, while advisers to his Republican opponent are worried that a Clinton landslide could sweep their candidate away.

title: Miscellany
description: Beaucoup Chapeaux, Dallas, a broadcast production service company, opened an office in New York.

title: Nice, Humble Yanks? Time to Recall the Zoo
description: Enough of this love fest already. The Yankees have become so cloyingly sweet that it makes one long for the days of George and Billy and Reggie.

title: G.M. Workers Walk Off Job At Two Plants
description: Workers abruptly walked off the job this evening at General Motors' most profitable assembly plant and one of its most important parts factories, as the United Automobile Workers union sought a showdown with the world's largest auto maker over job security.

title: Falsified Data Found in Gene Studies
description: Dr. Francis S. Collins, the head of the Government's project to map all human genes, said yesterday that he was retracting five research papers on leukemia in leading scientific journals because a junior colleague had fabricated data.

title: Scenes From the Yankees' Parade
description: Like all great public events, the New York Yankees' victory parade was not a single experience, but thousands of separate adventures. Some, of course, were more desirable than others.

title: NEXTEL BUYING 81% OF WIRELESS VENTURES OF BRAZIL
description: Nextel Communications Inc. of Washington said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 81 percent of Wireless Ventures of Brazil Inc., a mobile radio operator, for $186 million in stock. Wireless Ventures owns or has options to acquire 1,300 channels throughout Brazil in areas where more than 60 million people live. The company is principally owned by Telecom Ventures, the indirect majority shareholder of LCC International Inc., a wireless engineering consulting services company in Arlington, Va.

title: Rangers Tie Florida At Its Own Hard Game
description: Wayne Gretzky was everywhere. Brian Leetch was flying like the Brian Leetch who captained Team USA to the World Cup championship last month. The Rangers were keeping pace with, and at times even dominating, the unbeaten Florida Panthers last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: MANULIFE OFFERS $343 MILLION FOR REST OF ALTAMIRA
description: Manulife Financial said yesterday that it would pay more than $460 million (Canadian), or $343 million, for the 70 percent of Altamira Management Ltd. that it does not already own. Manulife Financial, a unit of the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company, said that it would offer $32 (Canadian), or $23.70, a share, in an effort to gain control of Altamira, an institutional money manager. Manulife's new offer is said to be $2 higher than its original offer, made earlier this month. Two groups opposing Manulife's takeover offer are the Almiria Capital Corporation, which owns 30.5 percent of Altamira, and Altamira's founders, who own about 11 percent of the shares.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Four Strong Designers Soften a Bit
description: THE winds of fashion may have changed direction for many designers, who have veered from uncompromising androgyny to unfettered femininity, but for others there has merely been a lessening of velocity, from stiff winds to gentle breezes. A new softness is blowing through the collections of the designers Mary McFadden, Yeohlee, Gemma Kahng and Han Feng, whose strong signatures have undergone a welcome tempering for spring.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 22 about United Nations activities in Afghanistan referred incorrectly to the leader of one of the three major Afghan factions. He is Abdul Rashid Dostum, not Massoud Dostum.

title: Seek Shelter if the Medium Is the Irritant
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense in Rape Trial Suggests Accuser Had Used Cocaine
description: A toxicologist testified for the defense today that the blood of the 16-year-old who said she was raped by Alex Kelly a decade ago showed that she had used cocaine and marijuana in the hours before the incident.

title: Compaq Computer Enters Work Station Fray
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced its first line of work stations here today, with five models priced from $4,300 to $10,200. Compaq said the work stations were available immediately.

title: David Solinger, 90, Art Collector And Whitney Museum President
description: David M. Solinger, a lawyer and art collector who became the first president of the Whitney Museum of American Art from outside the Whitney family, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Militia Leader Denies Kidnapping Attempt
description: Bo Gritz, the militia movement leader, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he tried to kidnap two boys caught up in a custody battle here. He again insisted that he was only trying to publicize claims that the children now lived with pedophiles.

title: Bid Is Dropped For Asian Utility
description: The YTL Corporation said today that it had abandoned plans to buy Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd. from Hopewell Holdings Ltd. after Gordon Wu, the founder of Hopewell, would not guarantee his support.

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR all intents and purposes, it's just another hillside vineyard, perhaps a bit more angular than most. Out among the vines a couple of men in straw hats work steadily under the blazing sun. A hawk wheels lazily overhead, a quail rustles in the dry chaparral.

title: Insurers Returning To Poor City Areas
description: Insurance companies, which virtually wrote off the inner city in favor of the suburbs and wealthy pockets of cities, are now rediscovering poor and working-class urban neighborhoods.

title: Stiff Challenge to a Democratic Freshman
description: In the great Republican Congressional landslide of 1994, 13 Democrats vying to become House freshmen somehow dodged the avalanche and squeaked into office.

title: Fund Raising Is Another Escoffier Dish
description: AUGUSTE ESCOFFIER is best known for having created peach Melba and the chef's toque, but it turns out that he may also have been responsible for the rubber-chicken circuit.

title: Morey Amsterdam, Comedian And Joke Encyclopedia, Dies
description: Morey Amsterdam, the wisecracking comedian who began telling jokes in vaudeville, thrived in the heyday of radio and lasted into the era of television on ''The Dick Van Dyke Show,'' died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was in his 80's.

title: Influx of Immigrants Is Changing Electorate
description: When the Michigan Democratic Party held its convention in September, Marianne Yared McGuire, an Arab-American, was not shy about using her ethnicity to persuade some party leaders to back her bid for a nomination to the State Board of Education. ''I told them they needed an Arab-American on the ticket to get Arab-Americans to go out and vote Democratic,'' she said.

title: Cheese Guide: Fresh, Weighty and Sharp
description: OWN a guide to cheese? Chances are it is not as complete or up to date as the new ''Cheese Primer'' by Steven Jenkins (Workman, $16.95). This is not a handy pocket-size volume but a heavyweight written with gusto by one of the country's most respected authorities. A serious reference, as well as a delightful browse, it gives history, anecdotes and country-by-country descriptions of nearly 1,000 cheeses, plus tips on buying, storing and using cheese, all of this accompanied with forceful opinions.

title: Chinese Court Finds Dissident Guilty and Gives 11-Year Sentence
description: A Chinese court today convicted the dissident Wang Dan of plotting to overthrow the Government and sentenced him to 11 years in prison, among the harshest sentences given to any of the student leaders of the 1989 democracy movement at Tiananmen Square.

title: Protest and Possible Profit Bring Back the Insurers
description: On a chill, gray morning seven months ago, State Farm raised its red and white banner in the heart of Harlem, on 125th Street, where shops like Ben & Jerry's and Capezio's alternate with boarded-up buildings, storefront churches, luncheonettes and used-furniture stores. It was the first time the company, the country's biggest insurer of homes and automobiles, had ventured into the neighborhood.

title: A NATO Expansion: Now, or Never?
description: To the Editor:

title: Eyeless in Hebron
description: If Israelis and Palestinians fail to come to agreement on power-sharing in Hebron, the peace process will go into a nosedive, with all the dangerous consequences that entails. The devil in Hebron is not in the details. It's in the failure of both sides to see the big picture.

title: Dole Says Vow To Trim Taxes Means Victory
description: Relaxed, warm and witty before a Republican audience in the conservative heart of Southern California, Bob Dole today returned to what had once been the foundation of his campaign -- a 15 percent tax cut -- to predict that that promise alone would elect him to the Presidency next week.

title: Sweet Science Becomes A Sour Subject on Ice
description: After two players fight during a Rangers game at Madison Square Garden, the video screen on the scoreboard shows appropriate film clips to celebrate their behavior.

title: Ewen Dingwall, 83, Force Behind Seattle Fair
description: Ewen C. Dingwall, the municipal impresario credited with transforming the 1962 Seattle World's Fair from a civic pipe dream into a glittering reality that helped establish the city's reputation as a cultural oasis, died on Friday at a Seattle hospital. He was 83.

title: Bears Lose Cox and Vikings Lose Smith
description: The Chicago Bears and Minnesota Vikings both lost key players in Monday night's 15-13 Bears victory. The Bears lost linebacker BRYAN COX indefinitely because of a broken thumb that will require surgery and the Vikings lost ROBERT SMITH for the season due to a torn medial collateral ligament in his left knee and at least a partial tear of the posterior cruciate ligament.

title: Complexity And Illusion
description: EVERY so often a designer rises to the true challenge of fashion, proving that with ingenuity and hard work it is possible to make clothes that meet the moment and more: modern but feminine, gentle but strong, fragile but concealing.

title: Developing a Taste for Organic Milk
description: FOR years, people thought of milk as the perfect food -- perfectly healthful and perfectly safe. They were wrong on both counts.

title: Cuba Suspends Three Players for Life
description: Three Cuban baseball players -- including two highly regarded amateurs -- were suspended for life by their country's sports authority yesterday and a Cuban-American was arrested in Mexico City on charges of trying to help players defect.

title: Gates of Microsoft Gives $15 Million to Harvard
description: Bill Gates, the founder and chief executive of Microsoft, who has been criticized for saying it would be years -- even decades -- before he started giving away his billions, yesterday announced his fifth multimillion gift to a university: $15 million to Harvard for computer science and engineering programs.

title: Whooping, Hollering And Holding Back Tears
description: ''Beautiful song,'' muttered Thirsty Dave Hansen, hanging on to his microphone with both hands and staring into the middle distance as Western Caravan's twin fiddles started up the opening riffs of ''The Moment I Lost You.'' Every Monday night, this 10-piece country band led by the guitarist Whit Smith beams a sorrowful glow across the slim dimensions of the Rodeo Bar. The band has played steadily in New York for two years, and there are inside jokes, nonchalant gestures and a lot of muttering amid the good musicianship -- signs that a band knows what it's doing.

title: No Headline
description: ''I have never seen a ticker tape like this, and I think I've been in a few of them.''

title: Playing Defensively
description: For years, fare discounts have been held up to New York transit riders as their Grail, the reward for the virtues of budget cuts and a huge investment in an electronic farecard system. But the payoff was always postponed.

title: Radiation Leak Reported at Site Of Nuclear Test
description: The environmental group Greenpeace says the biggest and most bitterly opposed nuclear test in the history of American underground testing, on an Aleutian island in 1971, produced radiation that is escaping into the surface environment.

title: U.S. Women Lead Dutch In World Team Bridge
description: The United States women's team was strongly placed in the quarterfinal stage of the World Bridge Championships here today. With 48 deals of a scheduled 64 completed, the team, which has a New York nucleus, led the Netherlands by 54 imps.

title: Whitman's Still at Home
description: Back pain kept Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in bed for a third day yesterday. The Governor did some work at Drumthwacket, the Governor's mansion in Princeton, and hopes to resume an abbreviated schedule tomorrow or Friday, said a spokeswoman, Jayne Rebovich.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: The former Mobil Building, largely vacant in the 90's, gets a new tenant, American Airlines.
description: THE former Mobil building has picked up yet another tenant: American Airlines has leased 43,000 square feet at the 1.6 million-square-foot office building at 150 East 42d Street, which has been largely vacant for much of the 90's.

title: Germany May Fail To Meet Currency Rule
description: Six leading German economic research organizations said yesterday that they thought Germany would fail to meet a key requirement for admission into the European currency union planned for 1999. Countries desiring to become members of the currency project are supposed to reduce the ratio of their government deficit to gross domestic product to a maximum of 3 percent in 1997. In their annual report, Germany's economic institutes predict the ratio in Germany will be 4 percent this year and 3.5 percent in 1997.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The presentation of an award normally places the winner in the spotlight and entitles him or her to at least a moment of ego gratification.

title: Promotions At Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies promoted Samuel Molinaro Jr. yesterday to chief financial officer, a title previously held by William Montgoris.

title: Bring On the Rating Kings
description: Just when the broadcast networks are recovering from the prime-time interruption of the World Series they must now gear up for the start of the November ratings sweep, a monthlong pseudo-event during which ratings-desperate network executives turn their bags of programming tricks inside out.

title: In Turnabout For Workers, Wages Grow More Slowly
description: Despite the strongest labor market in at least seven years, the growth of American workers' wages and benefits slowed in the third quarter, the Government reported today. The slowdown partly undercut earlier indications that workers were beginning to enjoy increases in pay that outpaced the rise in the cost of living.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the prospects for a libel action in the case of Richard A. Jewell, the Atlanta security guard who was cleared as a suspect in the Olympic bombing, misstated the given name of the Manhattan libel lawyer who commented. He is John Walsh, not James.

title: Penalize Landlords
description: To the Editor:

title: America Online Announces A Newer Transformation
description: Last month, when America Online Inc. introduced new software, a new advertising campaign and a new listing on the New York Stock Exchange, the chairman, Stephen M. Case, called the changes ''a new AOL.'' Yesterday, with the disclosure of another spate of sweeping announcements, he delivered what might be called the new new AOL.

title: Kemp Ruffled by Reports of Republican Pessimists and His Being a Defeatist
description: In the waning days of the Presidential campaign, Jack Kemp has found himself on the defensive, piqued by attacks from some Republican naysayers and smarting at questions about his loyalty to his running mate, Bob Dole.

title: High-speed access to the Internet is beginning to be a feature in some hotel guest rooms.
description: THE cyberspace revolution is venturing into new territory, as hotels begin to offer special telephone lines in guest rooms for high-speed Internet access similar to that already found in some hotel business centers.

title: Senate Race Looks to Clinton
description: With polls giving President Clinton a strong lead in New Jersey, the Democratic Senate nominee is counting on the Clinton-Gore ticket to help sweep him into office, while advisers to the Republican candidate are worried that a Clinton landslide could sweep away their candidate.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Styles pages on Oct. 20 about children and fashion misstated the name of a children's clothing manufacturer. It is Les Tout Petits, not Le Tout Petite.

title: Personal Health
description: DECADES of medical wariness about using drugs for weight loss seem to have melted away with the introduction of two new prescription regimens that offer the appetite control of amphetamines but without the frightening side effects and addictive properties of these dangerous drugs.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Prof. Francis Loewenheim, 69, An Expert on Diplomatic History
description: Francis L. Loewenheim, a longtime Rice University professor who was an authority on modern diplomatic history, died on Oct. 17 at the Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 69.

title: Donna Karan stock takes a beating after earnings report.
description: DONNA KARAN must hope that the fashion mafia will take a kinder view of her spring clothing line than Wall Street did of her third-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: Cowboys Wake Up And Find Themselves
description: The Dallas Cowboys have become fat, lazy and complacent. They are toast. They are done.

title: Ontario Case Tests Religious-School Financing
description: As American candidates debate vouchers for parochial schools, a different sort of debate over religious-school financing is playing out in Canada. Non-Roman Catholic parents in Ontario are suing the government to get what Catholic parents have always had: public financing for their religious schools.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Let it not be said that power players in Washington lack a sense of humor about themselves. Some 500 government officials and journalists, including MADELEINE ALBRIGHT, the United States Representative to the United Nations; ANN STOCK, the White House social secretary; LLOYD N. CUTLER, the former counsel to Presidents Clinton and Jimmy Carter, and SHELDON HACKNEY, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, laughed heartily at a performance Monday in the National Press Club of a radio play called ''This Town.''

title: In Search of Bats
description: Just in time for Halloween, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg plans to catch a bat -- and call attention to the Federal Endangered Species Act. The Senator will visit an abandoned mine at dusk today to try to net an Indiana bat, one of 28 believed to live in the cave. About 500,000 Indiana bats exist in the United States, but few are found in the East.

title: Newest Laker Celebrity Will Smile at the Hard Feelings in Orlando
description: He fled the Orlando Magic for the Magic Johnsons, and, on the flight out west, his 22EEEEE's even fit in the overhead compartment. He left behind his childish things -- a Porsche, a front-yard miniature golf course, Nick Anderson -- and was greeted at the Forum by a single-file line of people wielding credit cards. The arena was soon a sellout -- which is exactly what the city of Orlando called him, a sell out -- and Shaquille O'Neal's 24th year on Earth was bound to be full of slings and arrows (and free throws).

title: Devils Are Nearly Defenseless In Boston
description: The Devils are often said to have the best corps of defensemen in the National Hockey League, but a few more performances like tonight's will put an end to that reputation.

title: Pilot's Errors Are Blamed In '95 Crash
description: Federal safety officials have concluded that the pilot of a Tower Air plane that slid off a runway at Kennedy International Airport last December made two critical mistakes as he tried to lift the plane off the ground, and they said the accident raised troubling questions about the young airline.

title: Aircraft Deal With Chinese Is Questioned
description: Nearly two years ago the McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced a deal with China that seemed like a victory for both American commercial diplomacy and the aircraft maker's work force: a $1.6 billion order for 40 airplanes, half of them built in California, half in Shanghai.

title: Debate Over Transit Station
description: A groundbreaking ceremony was held yesterday for a New Jersey Transit station that is expected to ease overcrowding at the station in Princeton Junction. The $38.8 million Hamilton Transit complex, on the Northeast Corridor line, is expected to be completed in early 1999, transit officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on Sunday about the Columbia-Yale football game referred incorrectly in some editions to the players and the action. The picture showed Jason Bivens of Columbia trying to avoid a tackle by Kevin O'Callahan of Yale, not Jay DuPertuis of Columbia congratulating his teammate Bobby Thomason.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: The City Plays Hooky To Venerate Its Heroes
description: ''We played hooky to see our rookie,'' declared the handmade sign floating dreamily in the hands of a teen-age girl at Bowling Green.

title: More Hope on M.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Without Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Clean Campaigns Now
description: In defending its fund-raising, the Clinton Administration said that John Huang, who collected campaign money from Indonesian tycoons, was not involved in Commerce Department meetings on Indonesia. Those assurances turned out to be false. As Stephen Labaton reported in The Times, Mr. Huang, an employee of the wealthy Riady family before he worked at Commerce, attended two meetings on Indonesian trade issues.

title: Talking to Truckers
description: Trucks rumbled onto the New Jersey Turnpike 23,382,574 times in 1990, but the figure fell 10.8 percent in 1991 after the Turnpike Authority doubled commercial tolls. Some trucks returned eventually, but never to the previous level. To discuss ways to bring back truckers, who now use free routes, the Turnpike Authority has invited industry representatives to a conference today. Sam Cunninghame, president of the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, has asked the authority for volume discounts on tolls and fuel. The authority is trying to negotiate lower rates with its fuel supplier, but agreements with bondholders limit discounts on tolls, said Lynn Fleeger, a spokeswoman.

title: More Flagstar Work For Foote, Cone
description: The Flagstar Companies said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with the Santa Ana, Calif., office of Foote, Cone & Belding by naming that agency to handle advertising for the Coco's Bakery Restaurants chain. The account, with billings estimated at $10 million, had been at Evans, Hardy & Young Inc. in Santa Barbara, Calif., for eight years.

title: Man Charged With Perjury in Bombing Case
description: A taxi driver from San Antonio, Tex., has been charged with lying to a Federal grand jury about a trip to Pakistan with a man who was later convicted of conspiring in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center in Manhattan.

title: A Ruling on Satellite Service Limits TCI's Options
description: If Tele-Communications Inc. is still determined to be a full-fledged player in the high-powered satellite television business, it may no longer have a choice but to strike a deal with Rupert Murdoch and MCI.

title: Picking Up Endorsements
description: If editorial boards decided elections, Kathleen A. Donovan would have little to worry about in her bid to replace Representative Robert G. Torricelli. Ms. Donovan, a Republican, was endorsed by The North Jersey Herald and News yesterday. The Record of Hackensack and The Star-Ledger of Newark have already endorsed her over the Democrat, Steven A. Rothman. Mr. Rothman's campaign manager, Michelle Sobolewski, played down the endorsement. She said Mr. Rothman had received 75 percent of the endorsements so far, and was supported yesterday by the New Jersey Council of Senior Citizens and the Armenian National Committee.

title: LVMH to Buy Duty-Free Empire for $2.47 Billion
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods conglomerate, has signed an agreement to buy a controlling interest in DFS Group Ltd., the lucrative empire of duty free shops, for $2.47 billion, DFS announced yesterday.

title: Above It All: A View to Suit Any Spectacle
description: PAUL ADAMS wasn't moved by the cheers that echoed through lower Manhattan yesterday, where praise and confetti were heaped upon the triumphant Yankees. He's British and admits to a certain stiff-upper-lip reserve, which may explain why he stayed above it all, keeping a respectful distance from the fan-fueled pandemonium.

title: CLINTON PUTS STING INTO RARE ATTACK ON DOLE'S RECORD
description: President Clinton momentarily abandoned his air of sailing above the partisan fray today and, goaded by hecklers supporting the Republican ticket, lashed out repeatedly at Bob Dole's voting record in the Senate.

title: Since July Riot, Indonesia Cracks Down on Private Aid Groups
description: ''Every time the doorbell rings,'' said the young man, ''I remember everything.''

title: Infant in Car Accident Dies; Driver Is Charged in Killing
description: A baby who was removed from his dead mother's womb on Monday afternoon, after she was killed by a car in Brooklyn, died yesterday in a hospital, and the driver was charged with two counts of manslaughter.

title: Executive Changes
description: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC., Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., said its president and chief executive, Patrick F. Brennan, 65, would retire on Dec. 31. Gorton M. Evans, 58, an executive vice president, will succeed him.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Dollar Bill

title: U.N. Investigating Rwanda War Crimes Tribunal Officials
description: Officials who run the day-to-day operations of the Rwanda war crimes tribunal are under investigation by the United Nations chief inspector after complaints of victimization of staff members, unexplained delays in procuring equipment and obstruction of efforts to publicize major genocide trials that begin this week.

title: Stepfather Is Sentenced to Prison In Abuse of Girl Who Later Died
description: The case of Elisa Izquierdo, the 6-year-old girl whose death at the hands of her mother last year caused outrage over the failures of the city's child protective agency, officially ended yesterday when a judge sentenced her stepfather to prison for repeatedly banging her head against a concrete wall.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Bartender Is Robbed
description: Two men held up a bartender at the Tavern on the Green restaurant in Central Park last night and then robbed the taxi driver in whose cab they fled, the police said.

title: A Saks Solo Effort Seen in Buying Barneys
description: Saks Fifth Avenue has significantly weakened its ties with the Isetan Company of Japan, the adversarial partner of Barneys New York, and is moving ahead on its own in its attempt to buy Barneys, people close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Theater in Review
description: Horses and Dogs and Clowns,

title: Giuliani, Exultant, Takes It Personally
description: It was more than an elected official's natural attraction to a winner, more even than one man's passionate 47-year infatuation with a particular baseball club.

title: Kohl Is an Iron Man, but the Price Is High
description: Helmut Kohl, who presided triumphantly over Germany's reunification in 1990, is about to become his country's longest serving Chancellor since Bismarck, who first fused the land 125 years ago.

title: From Neighborhood To Grande Cuisine
description: TRAVEL is transforming. It turned Consuelo Vanderbilt into the Duchess of Marlborough and John Bryan, the Texas businessman, into the man who will forever be known for having nibbled on the Duchess of York's toes.

title: When New Is Old and Modern Is History
description: The turn of the century is sure to obliterate pigeonholes, overturn cherished notions and require new modes of thought. (The turn of the millennium is simply too much to contemplate.) Certainly, the adjective ''20th-century'' will lose much of the fearsome edge it has held for many music lovers. And what meaning can ''modern'' and ''contemporary'' possibly retain?

title: New Services Aimed At the Not-So-Rich : Chasing A Broader Client Base
description: PARIS  Exclusivity used to be the lure for private banking, but competition from up-market clearing banks and asset management groups is forcing many private banks to widen their scopeto include middle net worthcustomers.

title: Sassy and Teen Will Be Merged
description: Sassy magazine, which introduced sexually explicit topics to the market for teen-age readers, will be folded into Teen magazine after its December issue, according to a person close to the Petersen Publishing Company, which owns both publications.

title: Bye Weekend for the Jets Is Bringing a Mixed Blessing
description: Let's say your business is having a bad year, but holiday time arrives and you have a few days off. Do you relax and regenerate or do you go to the office every day and try to get the business healthy?

title: Big Turnout Should Turn The Corner
description: THE world champion Yankees set an attendance record yesterday. Three and a half million people, as estimated by New York's most esteemed pollster, Rudolph W. Giuliani, crammed lower Manhattan to salute the crowned kings of baseball.

title: Silence at the Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: Torricelli Reiterates His Support for Gun Controls
description: Using a table laden with confiscated assault weapons as a backdrop, Representative Robert G. Torricelli reiterated today that he was a staunch advocate of gun control laws while accusing his Republican opponent in the race for the Senate of being a friend to gun lobbyists.

title: Ericsson's 3d-Quarter Profit Up 28 Percent
description: Ericsson A.B., the telecommunications equipment supplier, said today that its third-quarter pretax profit jumped 28 percent as rising demand for mobile telephones increased sales.

title: Public Asked to Let Council Linger
description: Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, may not be running for re-election this year, but for months he has been campaigning furiously nonetheless.

title: For the Players, Adoration, Adulation and Even Some Marriage Proposals
description: Kenny Rogers sat atop the sparkling blue-and-white parade float, waving a gigantic Yankee flag back and forth. David Cone stood on the edge of the same float, fixed his stare on the fans as they hung to stoplights or leaned out office windows, and pointed and clapped in appreciation. Derek Jeter blushed as wailing teen-age girls treated him like a rock star and held up placards with marriage proposals.

title: INSIDE
description: Walkouts at 2 G.M. Plants

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11

title: Doctor Says No
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS TO ACQUIRE PREMIER BANKSHARES
description: First Virginia Banks Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Premier Bankshares Corporation for $160.4 million in stock. First Virginia plans to pay 0.545 share for each of Premier's 6.65 million outstanding shares. The stock of Premier Bankshares rose $4, to $23, in Nasdaq trading. First Virginia gained 25 cents a share, to $44.875. First Virginia will issue about 3.62 million shares, and concurrently, it will increase its stock repurchase program by another 1.9 million shares, to 4 million shares. Premier Bankshares, based in Bluefield, Va., operates three bank subsidiaries with 376 branches. First Virginia, based in Fairfax, operates 21 bank subsidiaries.

title: A NATO Expansion: Now, or Never?
description: To the Editor:

title: War Crimes Tribunal Would Inflict More Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: Mother and Family in a Tizzy

title: An Anarchic Visionary's Protest Against Evil
description: A white woman wearing frumpy 1950's clothes is standing at the kitchen table discussing her complicated feelings about her son's leaving for college. Her black husband sits at her side, deep in thought. ''Believe me,'' she sings, ''I've had a ball on this planet. Sure, it takes a while to discriminate between the components. But in the end it's worth it. What else is there, really? Without the phenomenon of attraction nothing could possibly stay in place, let alone evolve. All of these matters affirm the variables underlining perceived existence.''

title: From 'Les Miserables' To Just Plain Miserable
description: A sweeping change in the cast of ''Les Miserables,'' with many actors suddenly dismissed from their roles, has left the company confused and upset. Some have been in the cast for years and thought of themselves as having continuing employment. With the announcement on Sunday that they would lose their jobs on Jan. 26, they will be looking for work, reading Backstage and going to auditions for other shows.

title: Sonic Assault
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ban on Foreign Gifts Could Be Tricky, Experts Say
description: In the closing days of the Presidential race, few debates have been as loud -- and as unexpected -- as the furor over campaign contributions from foreign business interests.

title: Top Woman At Microsoft To Leave Soon
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that Patty Stonesifer, its highest ranking woman, had resigned as part of a shake-up that will centralize power in the hands of Paul Maritz, the executive who has guided the company's operating systems business.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Saks and Neiman Marcus Are Said to Vie for Barney's

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a possible penalty faced by Morgan Stanley & Company in underwriting Massachusetts bonds referred incorrectly in some editions to the percentage of the state's bonds sold by competitive bidding this year. It is 60 percent, not more than 80 percent.

title: Salomon Stock for Buffett
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. will convert $140 million of its preferred stock in Salomon Inc. into common stock rather than cash, Salomon said yesterday.

title: Parody, Wit and Elegance
description: THE only obstacle more daunting for designers than bad design is good design. A year after the immeasurable power of Gucci's and Prada's strong suits swept the fashion arena, designers are understandably fighting their way onward. It's going to be a rough battle.

title: Vermont Parents Ask State to Pay Catholic School Tuition
description: Across Vermont, 90 towns and villages are too small to support a local high school. Children attend elementary school in town, but when they get to ninth grade, they go to a neighboring public high school or to private secular school. In either case, the state pays their tuition.

title: Send-Ups on Election Night
description: With ABC, CBS and NBC committed to covering the election results on Tuesday, and Fox showing the movie ''Beethoven'' for the fifth time on broadcast television, executives at UPN are downright gleeful about their prospects for that night.

title: Who Counts in South Africa? Finally, Everyone
description: ''Yes, I've been counted this time,'' said Jabulani Mhlambi, 25, a citizen of this vast city inhabited by a soon-to-be-determined number of people. ''I was counted last time, too,'' he added, pointing skyward. ''By airplane.''

title: EX-C.I.A. ANALYSTS ASSERT COVER-UP
description: Two intelligence analysts who resigned earlier this year from the Central Intelligence Agency say the agency possesses dozens of classified documents showing that tens of thousands of Americans may have been exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons during the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

title: Growth in Downtown Brooklyn Is Still Looking Up, Planners Say
description: Just south of the Atlantic Avenue railway station, where city-owned urban renewal property sat vacant for 30 years, a new complex of oversized suburban-style stores is to open next week.

title: F.B.I.'s Interview in Bombing Is Investigated by Justice Dept.
description: The Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation have opened an internal inquiry into whether F.B.I. agents violated agency guidelines when they subjected Richard A. Jewell to a highly deceptive interview about the bombing at the Olympics in July, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Tuning Out Free Speech
description: As the legal and public relations war between Time Warner and the Fox News Network rages, both sides are claiming the mantle of the First Amendment. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Fox's champion, asserts that adding Fox's supposedly unique presence to the potpourri of cable offerings would serve the interest of diversity: more voices offering more views. Time Warner claims protection from government interference in its decisions on what to broadcast.

title: Food Notes
description: A Chelsea Harvest

title: Spicy Marinade for Quick Flavor
description: Soy sauce offers a way to impart a great deal of flavor to meat in a short time. You can use any kind of steak in this recipe, but flank steak is the most tender and has the least fat. The creaminess of the potato-broccoli salad dressing provides a nice contrast to the spicy teriyaki seasoning.

title: A Winery For Food Buffs
description: When Lolly and Jim Mitchell, who founded Sakonnet Vineyards in Little Compton, R.I., in 1975, wanted to sell the property 12 years later, their neighbors Susan and Earl Samson were ready to buy.

title: AMR Said to Be Seeking $10 Billion Order
description: American Airlines wants to buy at least 100 new jets worth more than $10 billion and is in talks with the Boeing Company about an order, people familiar with the airline say.

title: Schoolgirl Is Headed for Penn State
description: ERIN DAVIS, an outstanding scholastic distance runner from Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has accepted a scholarship offer from Penn State. Davis has won three state cross-country championships and three 3,000-meter track championships during her career. As a freshman, she won a national cross-country title. (AP)

title: SYSTEMIX'S INDEPENDENT DIRECTORS REJECT SANDOZ OFFER
description: Systemix Inc. said yesterday that its independent directors had rejected Sandoz Ltd.'s unsolicited offer to acquire the rest of the research company for about $67 million. Systemix's stock closed down $1.75, at $14.25. Sandoz, the Swiss drug company, already holds a 73 percent stake in Systemix, which researches gene therapies for cancer, AIDS and genetic diseases. Sandoz made the proposal in May, sending Systemix shares soaring 71 percent. In June, five shareholder suits were filed to block the proposal. Sandoz said it would review Systemix's decision before taking further action.

title: Down the Homestretch They Come, With Clinton Looking, Well, Presidential
description: This is customarily the most intense and frantic leg of a Presidential campaign: one week in which travel schedules get ripped apart, new advertisements are put on and pulled off the air on an hour-by-hour basis and the attacks and counterattacks on the stump get even harsher.

title: UNOCAL MIGHT SELL ITS 76 PRODUCTS REFINING BUSINESS
description: The Unocal Corporation said yesterday that it might sell the 76 Products Company, its West Coast marketing, refining and transportation arm. The petroleum company said it was studying options for making 76 Products an independent company. Possible actions include an initial public offering, a joint venture, or an outright sale. As a first step, Unocal said it would make 76 Products a wholly owned subsidiary and transfer its West Coast refining, marketing and transportation assets to the subsidiary by the end of the year. Shares in Unocal, based in El Segundo, Calif., were up $1.25, to $36.75.

title: Purging the Nightmare Of a Storied Estate
description: SUZANNAH LESSARD'S literary lurch between obsessive writing and writer's paralysis ended when she chose to break the well-bred silence of her clan.

title: Theater in Review
description: Yes, She's a 'Latina Lesbian,'

title: I.N.S. Chief Plays Down Fears That Many Criminals Got Citizenship
description: Responding to Republican assertions that the immigration service had allowed thousands of criminals to become citizens, the agency's Commissioner said today that a preliminary review had found ''no evidence that significant numbers'' of law breakers, if any, were granted citizenship.

title: Baring Teeth In the Drug War
description: Bob Dole calls President Clinton's drug policies ''soft'' and ''liberal,'' a betrayal of what he says is the successful legacy of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush. In fact, the Clinton Administration has taken the Republican drug war to soaring new heights of Draconian ineffectiveness.

title: A Hand Truck and an Arrest
description: A customer in a hardware store was intrigued by a hand truck she saw there yesterday: it belonged, she told the police, to her employer, the Newark Housing Authority. A subsequent search of ACL Hardware on Springfield Avenue found about $50,000 worth of merchandise and supplies stolen from the Housing Authority, the public schools and other city agencies, the police said. The owner, Aurilio Candelaria, 58, was charged with receiving stolen property. TERRY PRISTIN

title: When Loroupe Runs, the Women of Kenya Run Along With Her
description: A native of Kenya, Tegla Loroupe knows nothing about the Yankees or the World Series, but she is entirely familiar with victory parades. After she won the New York City Marathon for a second time last November, she was given a welcome that stretched like a distance run for 18 miles to her village of Kapenguria near the Ugandan border.

title: Woods's Father Is Released From Hospital
description: TIGER WOODS's father, EARL, was discharged from a hospital in Tulsa, Okla., yesterday after spending four days undergoing tests and observation for chest pains.

title: After Criticism, Democrats Release Record of Donors
description: Hoping to tamp down questions about its fund-raising activities, the Democratic Party abruptly reversed itself this evening by making a public accounting of its pre-election contributions for the first two weeks of October, when it raised $10.1 million.

title: Medical Marijuana Use Winning Backing
description: The Clinton Administration has condemned it as a cynical hoax, the Republican Presidential candidate, Bob Dole, has denounced it as dangerous, and in a letter released today, former Presidents George Bush, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter call it a threat to the public health of ''all Americans.''

title: Uneventful Day Before Rough Landing
description: The American Airlines jet that made an emergency landing at Kennedy International Airport on Monday night after its front wheels failed to descend had taken off and landed several times that day without any problem, airline officials said yesterday.

title: Graham Aims to Prove Something to Reeves
description: This is about the paths that two careers, which were once intertwined, have taken. This is about making something from nothing. Of saving a career. And getting even.

title: After 70 Years, Tooting One's Horn
description: Although he can still slip into the same red jacket and natty jodphurs -- some of them checkered -- he wore as a cover boy on the cover of New Yorker and as a poised ''To Tell the Truth'' contestant 40 years ago, the century's most famous ringmaster hung up his horn in 1990. His lungs do not pack the same punch they used to. Now Honey Craven, the man renowned as the best carriage horn blower on the horse show circuit, saves his breath for chats.

title: Lenin Paints Himself Black With His Own Words
description: THE UNKNOWN LENIN

title: Bathrooms Get Help With Space
description: IN the history of housing, there has never been a bathroom with enough storage space. Or a linen closet that's been close enough to a bathtub.

title: G.O.P. Pushes Candidates for a Court That Has Thwarted Pataki
description: New York State's judicial races have long been modest affairs, rarely spawning the kind of expensive advertising wars that are the hallmark of modern political campaigns.

title: Corrections
description: A review on the Fashion page in The Living Section yesterday about designers who have taken a softer direction for their spring collections in the current round of New York shows misstated the surname of the designer who showed movie-star evening dresses. He was Bob Mackie, not Morris.

title: Lenient Sentences for 2 in Journalist's Killing
description: A Federal judge showed leniency yesterday in sentencing two people for conspiring in the killing of a crusading anti-drug journalist, despite an impassioned plea from the victim's companion and business partner, who said the defendants' expressions of remorse rang hollow.

title: Home-Sales Report Sends Bonds Lower
description: Treasury prices turned lower yesterday, hurt by a housing sales report that was stronger than expected.

title: Luxury-Brand Connoisseur Behind a Bid for DFS Group
description: Step into any big airport's duty-free shop or stroll along the plush avenues of Paris, London, Vienna or New York and they will be there in some fancy shop: Moet, Hennessy, Guerlain, Christian Dior, Givenchy and Louis Vuitton. They are all products of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton of France, the world's largest luxury-goods conglomerate, and of Bernard Arnault, who controls it.

title: Medicare Patients in H.M.O.'s Win a Case
description: In a major victory for consumers, a Federal judge has expanded the rights of Medicare patients in health maintenance organizations, saying they are entitled to immediate hearings whenever they are denied medical services.

title: Axime Makes Offer For Rival Sligos
description: Axime S.A. offered yesterday to buy Sligos S.A. in a friendly takeover valued at about $700 million that would create France's biggest computer services company. The combination would be Europe's second-biggest provider of computer services to banks, with annual sales exceeding 6 billion French francs ($1.2 billion). (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Tharp With New Tools: Hymns and a Pirelli Tire
description: A kinder, gentler Twyla Tharp was in evidence in the program presented here by the new Tharp! company on Tuesday night. Is the world ready for such a change in a notoriously peppery iconoclast?

title: No Pledge on Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: China on Tables And Under, Too
description: THE Limoges porcelain maker Bernardaud has opened a New York flagship store that features its famously traditional place settings in a modernized sense of place. Its six rooms were conceived by Olivier Gagnere, a designer who is a founder of the New Baroque style in France. ''I wanted the shop to resemble rooms in a home,'' he said.

title: The Agony of Defeat, Physiologically Speaking
description: WHY MICHAEL COULDN'T HIT

title: ROCKWELL PLANS LAYOFFS AND EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss about 1,400 workers, most outside the United States, as it stops making certain truck and transportation products. The company employs about 56,000 people. Rockwell said it would take a fourth-quarter charge against earnings of $74 million, or 34 cents a share, which would be offset by a gain of $76 million, or 35 cents a share, from tax gains and insurance claims. It did not say which products would be discontinued. Rockwell plans to release its fourth-quarter earnings report next month. The company also said its shareholders would vote on Dec. 4 on the Boeing Company's proposal to acquire its aerospace and military businesses for $3.2 billion.

title: On clear-cutting, economists can't see the forest or the trees.
description: THE issue drawing many voters to the polls in Maine next week will not be taxes, Medicare or Presidential ethics, but clear-cutting: the practice of harvesting acres of timber at a time rather than selectively culling mature trees.

title: Lorenzo De Versace
description: ''MANY of the artists I have dealt with on this house have been very, very difficult to work with, but not Julian,'' said Gianni Versace, trying to coax a smile from the unyielding lips of Julian Schnabel, the plate-smashing painter and film maker known for his perpetual scowl.

title: New Foe for Morrison
description: A new opponent was found for TOMMY MORRISON, the heavyweight who is infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and it appears he will be a much more difficult foe than the one Morrison was supposed to meet in Tokyo this weekend.

title: After 7 Terms, a Tougher Race for a Gingrich Fan
description: In a year when Newt Gingrich has been the voodoo doll of Democratic Congressional campaigns, Representative Nancy L. Johnson would appear to be as ripe a target as any Republican incumbent in the land.

title: Lotus Development Plans New Software for Internet
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said yesterday that it would strip out some of the crucial technology behind its popular Notes software and sell it as a separate product to give people a much greater ability to exchange data over the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about preparations by the United States and NATO for a peacekeeping force in Bosnia next year misstated the role of Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, and misstated the location of the talks. Mr. Berger was not involved in discussions on the subject with NATO foreign ministers. And the meetings were in Bergen, Norway, not at NATO headquarters in Brussels.

title: Perot Challenges President
description: Ross Perot challenged President Clinton tonight to join him for an hour on network television on the night before Election Day to answer Mr. Perot's questions about his record.

title: Casino Granted a License
description: A company run by Sol Kerzner, a South African casino developer, was granted a temporary license yesterday to run a gambling hall at Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel. The State Division of Gaming Enforcement is investigating allegations that in 1986 Mr. Kerzner bribed an official of a tribal homeland in South Africa to obtain a casino license.

title: Surgery for Lemieux
description: Abdominal surgery on CLAUDE LEMIEUX was successful yesterday, but the Colorado Avalanche right wing is expected to be sidelined for 10 to 12 weeks. Lemieux incurred the injury Oct. 5 in Dallas. (AP)

title: If the Vote Splits
description: If all the prophecies self-fulfill, then the top priority of Bill Clinton's second term will to be avert retribution for the actions of his first.

title: The First to Scream
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: F.B.I. Official Pleads Guilty

title: After a Life In Front Of a Camera, A New One Behind It
description: In an elegant white-clapboard country house, with acres of green lawn sprawling down a hillside from its flagstone patio to a pond below, amid the lush horse country here, Christopher Reeve this fall began his new career as a film director.

title: No Child Is an Island
description: To The Home Section:

title: MICHAELS STORES FORESEES BIG THIRD-QUARTER LOSS
description: Michaels Stores Inc. predicted yesterday that it would have a bigger-than-expected third-quarter loss and said it would close four stores in 1997. Michaels said it would report a loss of $1 to $1.50 a share in the quarter that ended on Sunday, compared with a profit of 14 cents in the comparable quarter last year. Analysts had expected the company, an arts and crafts retailer, which is based in Irving, Tex., to lose 4 cents a share. Since the loss will put the company in default of its bank loan agreement, Michaels said that it was discussing waivers with its lenders. The company's stock fell $1.906 a share, to $10.

title: For One Dole Aide, Optimism Is Unavoidable
description: Bob Dole trails in the polls; former advisers and fellow Republicans are flinging eggs at the campaign; aides are throwing up their hands while the campaign's messages shift by the day, and its schedule, it seems, by the hour. And Mr. Dole has taken to attacking the press.

title: Australia Is Set to Reduce Power of Unions
description: Australia is on the verge of a major overhaul of its restrictive industrial relations system next year after a compromise in Parliament. The overhaul reflects the coalition Government's drive to increase productivity and reduce union power.

title: Heading for Hopeless, but Not Gone Yet
description: You know this guy. He was the brooding one who sat behind you in homeroom in 10th grade, the one who wore the day-old T-shirts and never combed his hair. A born follower, he was the first to snicker at scatological jokes and the last to give up comic books.

title: Behind Dole's California Strategy: A Bid to Save His Campaign
description: Until a month ago, the conventional political wisdom among Republican leaders was that Bob Dole could win the Presidency on Nov. 5 without carrying California and its biggest-in-the-nation haul of 54 Electoral College votes. All he had to do, the reasoning went, was run well elsewhere, particularly in Republican strongholds in the South and the Midwest.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Fifteen years ago, when he was struggling to get his writing published, VICTOR MARTINEZ scraped together enough money to come to New York from California for the first time. ''New York is a mythical city for me, the center of literature in the country,'' he said yesterday in a telephone interview from his home in San Francisco. ''I wanted to see where so many writers come from.''

title: Officer Admits Misconduct
description: A trial of a Fair Lawn police officer accused of holding a loaded gun to a dispatcher's head in December 1993 ended abruptly yesterday when the officer pleaded guilty to official misconduct. Under the plea bargain, Matthew M. Talty will not have to serve time, but he agreed never to seek another job as a police officer. According to David Nathanson, an assistant prosecutor for Bergen County, Mr. Talty locked the dispatcher, Brian Shore, in a bear hug, pointed the gun and joked, ''I had a rough day today; I have to take a life.''

title: West Point Accuses Cadet of Raping Another Cadet
description: The Army charged a 22-year-old senior at the United States Military Academy at West Point yesterday with raping another cadet. West Point officials said it was the first time in the 20 years since West Point began admitting women as students that a cadet had been accused of raping another.

title: Our Own Agendas
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Crack Down on an Obscure Shiite Militant Group
description: As part of a crackdown on opposition groups in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi authorities have arrested scores of members of a little-known Shiite Muslim organization that calls itself the Saudi Hezbollah, Shiite leaders said here today.

title: $12.7 Million Awarded to Man Shot by the Police
description: A 50-year-old chocolate factory worker who was shot five years ago by the police in a case of mistaken identity, rendering him a paraplegic, has been awarded $12.7 million by a jury that decided the officer had fired his gun unnecessarily because his life was not in danger.

title: Merrill Lynch tries on a new image by promoting a museum's show about Leonardo da Vinci.
description: MERRILL LYNCH is bullish on Leonardo. Specifically, Leonardo da Vinci and the scientific manuscript he bequeathed to the world, known as the Codex Leicester. Merrill Lynch & Company is spending $300,000 on an advertising campaign to publicize the new celebration of the Codex at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. The exhibition opened Saturday and will end Jan. 1.

title: Back to School For Grown-Ups
description: THE year was 1981, and Jennifer George was finishing four years at Sarah Lawrence College. The images she absorbed then -- the college girl as preppy, the feminist intellectual, the woman in a man's world, albeit an elite one -- all came flooding back when she took her teen-age niece to look the school over recently.

title: Talk-Show Host Is to Testify in Trial
description: Jenny Jones, the host of a syndicated television talk show, will testify today in the trial of a guest on her show who is accused of murdering another guest who announced his homosexual attraction to him.

title: RENAISSANCE COSMETICS TO BUY P.& G. FRAGRANCES
description: Renaissance Cosmetics Inc., a closely held fragrance company based in Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy several fragrance brands from the Procter & Gamble Company for $41.5 million. The brands include Navy, Jaclyn Smith's California, California for Men and Toujours Moi. In 1995, the fragrances generated about $27 million in United States sales and $52.1 million in worldwide sales for P.& G., which is based in Cincinnati. P.& G. had said in June that it was trying to weed out minor brands to focus on its Cover Girl and Max Factor cosmetics.

title: Bear Shifts Surgery Date
description: BRYAN COX's thumb is broken in three places, but he said yesterday he is changing the date for surgery and plans to play Sunday against Tampa Bay. The surgery the Chicago linebacker expected to have tomorrow, which would have forced him out of Sunday's game, will now take place Monday. After consultations with numerous specialists, he decided to give it a try against the Buccaneers. Doctors have approved his decision. Cox broke the bone at the base of his left thumb in the Bears' victory Monday in Minnesota. (AP)

title: Job Shifting Is Big Issue In G.M. Talks
description: The showdown between the United Automobile Workers union and the General Motors Corporation this autumn is often described as a struggle over corporate downsizing and job security, but as striking workers here are quick to volunteer, the dispute is also about whether corporations owe easier jobs to older workers.

title: TOWER SEMICONDUCTOR REJECTS CHAPMAN BID
description: Tower Semiconductor Ltd. has rejected a takeover proposal of $10 a share, or a total of $132 million, from Chapman Capital L.L.C., Chapman said yesterday. Tower's chairman, George Morgenstern, said that the proposed price was inadequate and that the company, which produces chips, was confident of its future. Tower's shares fell 75 cents to $6.75, which reflects the ex-dividend date yesterday on a special $1.50-a-share payout declared on Oct. 22. Robert L. Chapman Jr., managing member of Chapman Capital, proposed the takeover in an Oct. 10 letter to Mr. Morgenstern.

title: Fed Loosens Rules on Banks And Securities
description: The Federal Reserve's Board of Governors voted today to knock down some of the walls that separate banks from securities affiliates, allowing companies like J. P. Morgan and Bankers Trust New York greater freedom to market and develop investment products.

title: Leon Lewis, 81, Radio Talk Host
description: Leon Lewis, a veteran radio talk-show host in New York City, died on Sunday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Centers That Did Not Hold
description: THINGS undone were memorialized in two pavilions at the Sixth International Biennial of Architecture in Venice, which runs through Nov. 17.

title: Chinese Verdict Points to an Era Of Harsh Rule
description: With a harsh court verdict today that will send the former student leader Wang Dan to prison for 11 years, China's Communist Party leadership may have silenced the last of its prominent critics at home and ushered in an era of authoritarianism that leaves only commerce to occupy the Chinese.

title: 12 Teachers Are Suspended
description: Twenty-five Newark public school employees, including 12 teachers, were suspended with pay yesterday because the authorities suspect that they took kickbacks from a psychologist in return for posing as his patients in an insurance fraud scheme. The psychologist, Carl Lichtman of Ridgewood, admitted in May that he billed state insurance carriers for hundreds of therapy sessions that never took place and gave 25 percent of the claims back to his ''patients.'' Prosecutors said Dr. Lichtman, who faces six years in prison, also paid patients referral fees of up to $750 for recruiting new participants.

title: Saves (53, in All) and a Beauty by Rangers' Richter
description: Goaltending was clearly the difference tonight when the Rangers and Devils met for the first time this season at Continental Arena. While Mike Richter was brilliant for the Rangers, the Devils' Martin Brodeur was so ineffective he was pulled before the game was 22 minutes old.

title: Now for the Dividends in Spending Derby
description: Stars were relocated. Power was shifted. Major risks were taken. Money, money and more money was spent.

title: Big Business And Kremlin: Togetherness Has Its Pitfalls
description: In a move that enraged the Kremlin's enemies and bewildered even some close allies, one of Russia's richest businessmen and an important financial backer of President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election campaign has been appointed deputy chief of the National Security Council.

title: Education and Earth
description: To the Editor:

title: French Said to Know That Official, Now Dead, Spied for Soviets
description: A top French counterintelligence official said today that France's Defense Minister in the early 1980's was later reported by Eastern European intelligence services to have worked as a paid political informant for them years before he held the defense post.

title: Senior F.B.I. Official Pleads Guilty to Cover-Up on Idaho Siege
description: A senior executive of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today pleaded guilty to destroying an internal report critical of the agency's performance in a 1992 standoff with a white separatist at his remote Idaho cabin.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLENBOROUGH REALTY TRUST INC., San Mateo, Calif., a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy five offices in California, Arizona and Utah for $25 million from a unidentified real estate company in California.

title: Faith Restored
description: To the Editor:

title: California Pandering
description: A certain sadness attaches to Bob Dole's last-ditch efforts to narrow the Presidential race. In his scramble for votes, Mr. Dole is rewriting history -- his own and the nation's -- and repudiating what had been a strong record on civil rights during most of his three decades in Congress. It is not a pleasant sight.

title: 5 Days to Go: What Do We Want? Or Deserve?
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines to Meet Over Oil Prices
description: The International Air Transport Association will convene an extraordinary meeting next month to discuss how airlines can offset the effects of rising oil prices.

title: Chicago Fails to Get a Spot As W.N.B.A. Charter Team
description: The Women's National Basketball Association yesterday announced its eight charter cities, and the surprise was that Chicago was not among them.

title: Once a Democratic Stronghold, Arkansas Finds Each Party's Position Precarious
description: Twenty-two years ago, a brash young law professor, just returned to Arkansas by way of Georgetown, Oxford and Yale, started his political career here in the northwest Arkansas hills. He challenged a popular Republican incumbent in the Third Congressional District.

title: Dole's Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rapper Caught Up in Violence. Sound Familiar?
description: There are plenty of ways to identify ''New York Undercover,'' the Fox network's unjustly neglected hip-hop police drama, as the work of Dick Wolf, who is also responsible for ''Law and Order.'' Tonight's tip-off comes right away, with the disclaimer: ''The following story is fictional and does not depict any actual persons or events.'' (Shouldn't those words come with a graphic, maybe a giant winking eye or crossed fingers?)

title: Novel Use of Clean-Water Loans Brightens Outlook for a River
description: In a new use of loan money available through the Federal Clean Water Act, environmental officials have agreed to buy water to help restore one of Nevada's most important rivers.

title: In Darien Rape Case, Fight Centers on One Expert's Drug Test
description: The prosecution in the Alex Kelly case tried today to block defense lawyers from presenting evidence to the jury that suggests the 16-year-old girl who said Mr. Kelly raped her had used drugs in the hours before the incident. But the day ended without a ruling from the judge.

title: COMPUSA INC. (CPU,N)
description: CompUSA Inc. said yesterday that its profits more than doubled in the latest quarter, exceeding forecasts, but the computer retailer's stock plunged after its chief executive expressed caution about the holiday shopping season.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Business Day yesterday showing the number of homes insured through a last-resort insurance plan in each ZIP code area of New York City misidentified a neighborhood in Queens that has a high concentration of such homes. It is Far Rockaway; East Rockaway is in Nassau County.

title: Torricelli's Wide-Reaching Goals Inspire and Enrage
description: It is little wonder that Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, likes to muse about great moments and great people in history.

title: Dole's Character Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Refugees Are Caught in Central African Crossfire
description: Her baby boy died in her arms as she trudged across the border from Zaire this morning. He was not yet 2, a tiny victim of an intensifying war battering this part of Central Africa.

title: Key Becomes the First Yankee to File for Free Agency
description: Jimmy Key, the winning pitcher in the game that made the Yankees World Series champions, yesterday became the first member of the team to declare free agency. Coincidental with his filing, baseball's ranking statistics were released, and they show how far Key has fallen in the last two years.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP., Houston, named Robert M. Devlin, company president, as chief executive. The company also said Mr. Devlin would replace retiring chairman Harold S. Hook as chairman next year, at the annual shareholders meeting. James S. D'Agostino Jr., chairman and chief executive of the company's life insurance unit, will succeed Mr. Devlin as president.

title: Bryn Terfel, a Study in Dramatic Contrasts
description: Some singers, though blessed with beautiful voices, must work hard to bring profile and character to their singing. Bryn Terfel, the Welsh bass-baritone who made his much-anticipated Carnegie Hall recital debut on Tuesday night with the pianist Malcolm Martineau, faces almost the opposite challenge.

title: G.M.'s Choice For Brazil Work
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it has further expanded its relationship with D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles by naming Salles/D.M.B.& B. in Sao Paulo, Brazil, to handle a new nationwide regional marketing program in Brazil. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: A Principled Life
description: To The Home Section

title: PACIFIC REHABILITATION IN TALKS WITH HORIZON
description: The stock of Pacific Rehabilitation and Sports Medicine Inc. soared 32 percent yesterday after the company said it might be acquired by the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation. Under the deal being discussed, Horizon/CMS, an owner of nursing homes based in Albuquerque, N.M., would pay $6.50 for each Pacific Rehabilitation share, or a total of $53 million. Pacific Rehabilitation of Vancouver, Wash., operates physical therapy clinics. Its shares rose $1.25, to $5.125.

title: Arthur B. Treman Jr., 67, Ex-Investment Banker
description: Arthur B. Treman Jr., a former New York investment banker with Dillon, Read & Company who remained active in community service, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 67.

title: The Start Of Something Big 'n' Tall
description: THE opening game, Knicks at Toronto, is the same. So is the date, Nov. 1. But when the National Basketball Association celebrates its 50th birthday tomorrow night, not much else is the same.

title: C. P. McHugh, 93, Chemical Engineer
description: Charles P. McHugh, a chemical engineer who devised a method to coat steel with vulcanized rubber to protect it from corrosion, died on Friday of heart failure in Eustice, Fla., where he moved after his retirement in 1971. He was 93 and previously lived in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Man Held in Killing After Daughter's Assault
description: A Brooklyn man with no prior criminal record was charged with murder after the police said he stormed into the streets near his home in Bedford-Stuyvesant on Monday and killed a 17-year-old youth who he thought had sexually assaulted his 14-year-old daughter.

title: Home for Teen-Age Mothers Tries to Break Welfare Cycle
description: Katie Cameron, a mother at 18, and her toddler son, Shaun, sleep under the glow of the stars that she pasted on the ceiling of their tiny bedroom. From the wall over the head of her bed, she took a framed document, a high school diploma dated July 28, 1996.

title: Ewell Blackwell, Pitcher, 74; Noted for His Whip-Like Style
description: Ewell (the Whip) Blackwell, a fastballing sidearm pitcher of the late 1940's and early 1950's who came within two outs of throwing consecutive no-hit games for the Cincinnati Reds, died Tuesday in Hendersonville, N.C. He was 74.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: HIGH COURT ASKED TO REVERSE RULING IN A RELIGION CASE
description: Invoking a highly unusual procedure to reopen an 11-year-old Supreme Court case, the Clinton Administration has asked the Court to overrule a 1985 decision barring public school teachers from traveling to parochial schools to offer federally financed remedial classes and counseling.

title: Party Aide Now in Eye of Storm Frequently Visited White House
description: John Huang, the senior Democratic finance official at the center of questions about the party's fund-raising activities, was a frequent guest at the Clinton White House even as he was raising millions of dollars for the 1996 election effort, according to Government records.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Candidates Shift to a More Positive Tone, Emphasizing Their Views on Education
description: The United States Senate campaign took a decidedly positive turn today, with both candidates making appearances that promoted their records on education and both beginning to broadcast positive television advertisements after weeks of barraging viewers with mostly negative campaign spots.

title: Pro-Union Republicans Feeling Betrayed in Congressional Races
