description: Representative Bill Martini of New Jersey likes to tell union members that he lined up so much Republican support for the labor-backed bill to raise the minimum wage that he was one of only two Republican freshmen invited to the bill-signing ceremony.

title: Evocative Lauren And Jet-Set Kors
description: THE mantra for those hoping to offset the Italian invasion this week has been, ''Fashion is international now.''

title: What a Mayor Wants to Tell Washington
description: AS the campaign for President entered its final days, as Bob Dole railed at voters to ''wake up'' (and vote for him), and President Clinton trolled for conservative votes with boasts of his new welfare law, the Mayor of one of the country's poorest, most dangerous cities sat in his office and talked about what he would like to hear from the candidates.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH RETREATS TO 2.2%
description: In one of the last major indicators of the country's economic performance before the Presidential election, the Commerce Department today reported a sharp slowdown in economic growth in the third quarter of the year, but no sign of a revival of even modest inflation.

title: Student's Parents Sue School
description: The parents of an 11-year-old Point Pleasant boy who is temporarily disabled because of recent leg surgery have sued school officials in Bay Head, accusing them of discriminating against their son by demanding the authority to expel him without stating a reason.

title: Gilbert Mudge, 81, A Medical Professor
description: Dr. Gilbert Horton Mudge, a professor emeritus of medicine and pharmacology who was a former dean of Dartmouth Medical School, died on Monday at his home in Lyme, N.H. He was 81.

title: Third Period Is No Charm for Isles in Tie With Whalers
description: One of these days, the Islanders are going to figure out that there are 60, not 40, minutes in a hockey game.

title: Precinct in Beating Case Goes on Guard
description: At the entrance to the 46th Precinct station house in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, two police officers stood guard, both equipped with hand-held metal detectors.

title: With Star Support, Francona to Manage Phils
description: Helped by a ringing endorsement from Michael Jordan, Terry Francona was named manager of the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday. He replaced Jim Fregosi, who was dismissed when the season ended.

title: Calendar: Crafts Sale, Exhibitions And Tours
description: Artists' Open House

title: Not for Women Either
description: To The Home Section:

title: Events: Design Talks, Classes and Costume Show
description: Writers at Noon

title: Judge Throws Out Conviction in Child Molestation Case
description: A Manhattan judge has overruled a jury and thrown out the conviction of a man who was charged with raping a 6-year-old relative, ruling that the child could not properly testify against the man.

title: People
description: Donald S. Montgomery was named to the new post of senior vice president and creative director at Toth Design and Advertising, New York. He had been vice president and creative director at the Arnell Group, New York.

title: Who Was That Masked Woman?
description: I live in a small town that happens to be on East 86th Street in Manhattan. It has friendly neighbors, big trees, plenty of local gossip and even a cordial policeman whom we all call Ron.

title: D'Amato Doubts Stadium Will Move to West Side
description: With the World Series won and the victory vigorously celebrated, the next act in the Yankees drama -- to resolve once and for all whether the team will stay in the Bronx -- has begun to unfold. And Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has taken an early public position that a new stadium on the West Side of Manhattan will never happen.

title: Russia Will Put Off Signing Agreement on Missile Systems
description: Without a clear explanation to the United States, Russia has backed away from signing an agreement on non-strategic missile defenses allowed under the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, senior Administration officials said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Carnegie Hall has been a constant presence in the life of State Senator ROY GOODMAN. ''I first went there when I was 5 with my parents, for a symphonic concert,'' he said yesterday, ''and it's been part of my bloodstream ever since.''

title: This New House
description: No matter which party gains control of the House of Representatives next Tuesday, the institution is likely to be radically different from the present Congress, both in its dynamics and legislative scope. But the institution will still be largely defined by Newt Gingrich, if only in reaction to him.

title: Labor Flexes Financial Muscle to Raise Stakes Against G.O.P. in Congressional Fights
description: Here in Michigan's Eighth District, as in more than two dozen other Congressional districts nationwide, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s huge Labor '96 effort has roughly leveled the financial playing field, wiping out the advantage incumbents almost always hold and blacking their eyes in the process.

title: Queensboro Battle: Residents, 1; City, 0
description: After relentless complaints from residents about severe traffic problems on the Upper East Side, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that city officials made a mistake when they changed the Manhattan entrances onto the Queensboro Bridge and promised to restore the original traffic pattern in two weeks.

title: Publisher to Defy C.I.A. and Release Data on Iraq Chemical Arms
description: More than 200 American intelligence reports about the 1991 Persian Gulf war that were removed from public inspection earlier this year by the Pentagon are scheduled to be released again this week -- but not by the Defense Department.

title: Whitman Plans to Visit Israel
description: Despite a back injury that has kept her at home since Sunday, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman hopes to resume a full work schedule by Monday and still plans to leave for Tel Aviv next Thursday to begin a 10-day trade mission to Israel and France, her office said yesterday. Mrs. Whitman does not know what caused the injury, said a spokeswoman, Jayne Rebovich.

title: Bridge
description: The United States women's team leads Austria by 13 imps after 64 of 96 deals in a semifinal match in the World Women's Team Championship here today.

title: Angela Perez, an Advocate For the Disabled, Dies at 49
description: Angela Romano Perez, an advocate for the disabled whose life was a model of the personal independence, responsibility and achievement she championed, died on Friday at the Cabrini Hospice in the Gramercy Park area of Manhattan. Ms. Perez, a lifelong resident of the Upper East Side, was 49.

title: HICKS, MUSE ACQUIRES DEL MONTE UNIT IN MEXICO
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the Del Monte Foods Company's food processing unit in Mexico for an undisclosed sum. Productos Del Monte S.A. de C.V. has annual sales of about $40 million and the largest share of Mexico's market in ketchup, bottled salsa and canned corn, Hicks, Muse said. The acquisition is the company's third in Mexico in three months and expands its branded food businesses. The acquired company will be managed by New York-based C. Dean Metropoulos & Company, an affiliate of Hicks, Muse. Metropoulos is investing a smaller amount as well. Del Monte is a privately held company based in San Francisco.

title: The Giants Are Looking Into a Return to the Past
description: Concerned about playing their receivers on special teams and risking them to injury, the Giants are considering signing a name from the past. Remember Gary Downs?

title: Giuliani and Council Agree On Bill Requiring Debates
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council have agreed on a bill that would require candidates for mayor, comptroller and public advocate to participate in debates starting with next year's election as a condition for receiving public campaign dollars.

title: For Congress From New Jersey
description: New Jersey voters face interesting choices in several races, between Democrats pledging to overturn the radical Republican agenda and Republicans who describe themselves as fiscal conservatives but who also support the environment, gun control and abortion rights. Here are our endorsements in some competitive races in the state.

title: New Museum With Quirks
description: THE caryatid crowd is at it again. This weekend, classically inclined architects and designers from around the country -- the new old fogies -- will be flocking to New York City for a series of workshops, tours and lectures sponsored by the Institute for the Study of Classical Architecture. Among other things, they will study ''moldings terminology'' and master the rudiments of scagliola -- fondly called ''scag'' -- a vanishing ornamental technique in which plaster is veined to resemble marble.

title: German Judge Rules G.M., in Discussing Suit, Didn't Slur VW
description: A German judge threw out Volkswagen A.G.'s defamation suit against the General Motors Corporation today, giving G.M. its third courtroom victory this month in its industrial-espionage case against VW.

title: Party Coffers Keep Growing In Last Days Of the Races
description: In the aftermath of the Democrats' recent imbroglio over whether to release pre-election campaign finance data, the numbers that have been made public reveal a larger truism about political fund raising: donations are richest in the final days of a campaign.

title: At His Farm, Zimmer Shows His Concern for the Environment
description: This is a 30-second commercial that Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican running for the Senate in New Jersey, began broadcasting yesterday.

title: Woman Who Took Girl for Abortion Is Guilty in Custody Case
description: In a case an abortion rights lawyer called the first conviction of its kind, a Pennsylvania woman who took her son's 13-year-old girlfriend to New York State for an abortion has been found guilty of interfering with the custody of a minor.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CONSIDERS SALE OF UNIT
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation said yesterday that it was considering selling its mutual fund business. The savings institution, based in Chatsworth, Calif., said it was also considering setting up a joint venture to help run the unit called the Sierra Capital Management Corporation. Sierra oversees about $3.4 billion in assets in more than 15 mutual funds. Great Western said it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it look for a possible buyer or joint venture partner. Sierra Capital would probably be worth about $50 million, said Geoff Bobroff, a fund industry consultant in East Greenwich, R.I. Shares of Great Western fell 25 cents, to $27.375.

title: Clinton's Great Strength
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Charges Insider Violation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint today against an employee of the Octel Communications Corporation, accusing him of trading on inside information about a software delay announced last week.

title: Chem International: then (75 cents) and now ($9.375).
description: WHAT'S the difference between a small company selling for pennies a share, and one selling for $9? Promotion.

title: Man Killed as Boom Collapses at Harlem Construction Site
description: One worker was killed and another was critically injured yesterday when the boom of a contractor's truck collapsed at the site of a street-reconstruction project in Harlem.

title: China's Politics of Punishment
description: By sentencing the most prominent democratic activist of the Tiananmen Square generation to a new 11-year prison sentence yesterday, China's authoritarian Government once again demonstrated its intolerance of peaceful political dissent and its contempt for the United States. It is increasingly hard to see how Washington can move toward closer relations with a regime that so brazenly abuses human rights.

title: KMART EXPANDS DUTIES OF U.S. OPERATIONS CHIEF
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it had promoted Warren Flick to the newly created post of president of its 2,020 Kmart stores in the United States, as well as chief operating officer of those operations. Mr. Flick, who joined Kmart in December 1995 as president and general merchandise manager of the American stores, has been the architect of many of Kmart's merchandising changes in the last year in an effort to lift sagging sales. The new post gives him additional responsibility for the operations of the American stores, not just merchandising, presentation, promotion and advertising, which were his previous responsibilities. Some analysts called the promotion largely symbolic, because Mr. Flick, a highly regarded merchant, has often been viewed as the No. 2 executive at the company, behind Floyd Hall, the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: No Headline
description: ''We are going to win this election, Mr. Lincoln.''

title: Expected Papal Visit Could Be Pivotal for Cuba and Church
description: With the announcement in Havana on Tuesday that a visit by Pope John Paul II to Cuba is now in the works, the Pope has proved once again that papal trips can make powerful politics.

title: Seles Suit Hearing Begins
description: Court proceedings began yesterday in a civil lawsuit filed by MONICA SELES against the German Tennis Federation over her 1993 stabbing. Seles is seeking damages for lost income, and is blaming the federation for lack of security.

title: Safeway Offers $1.6 Billion for the Rest of Vons
description: Safeway Inc. said yesterday that it was offering to buy the two-thirds of the Vons Companies it did not already own in a $1.6 billion stock deal that would create a supermarket powerhouse on the West Coast.

title: From Heartbreak Hill, To Streets of New York
description: He is linked inexorably by his three consecutive victories to the Boston Marathon. Even his son is inseparable from the race, bearing as he does the name Gideon Boston. But Cosmas Ndeti of Kenya has been hearing the whispers, that he is a one-marathon wonder, that, sure, he can win in Boston, but he cannot win anywhere else.

title: Torricelli Contrasts His and Foe's Stances on Gun Control
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democrat running for the Senate in New Jersey, began broadcasting this 30-second commercial yesterday.

title: Holdout Was for Hope at Tampa Bay
description: It was not just the money.

title: Jent May Make Team
description: Chris Jent has a good chance to make the Knicks' 12-man roster for Friday night's opener in Toronto.

title: Thomas Frank, 55, A Top Manager Of Mutual Funds
description: Thomas A. Frank, a mutual fund manager for the Dreyfus Corporation who specialized in buying stocks of small, fast-growing companies, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 55.

title: Hey, Big Spender
description: To the Editor:

title: Clothing Will Be Tax-Exempt for a Week
description: The City Council yesterday approved a weeklong exemption from the New York City sales tax on clothing in January, matching a similar move by the State Legislature.

title: For Teen-Agers, Too Much to Do, Too Little Time for Sleep
description: LONG after the rest of the family has settled down for the night, Julie Clark, 16, of Weston, Conn., is often still awake, doing homework. When she finally does climb into bed shortly before midnight, she stuffs sponge earplugs into her ears and puts on a black eye mask with a fuzzy lining so that she can fall asleep fast.

title: The Pop Life
description: ''When the music's over, turn out the lights,'' Jim Morrison sang in 1967. But that's just not true anymore. Today, for most groups, when the music's over, the lights come on, and it's time to be introduced to music-business people, conduct interviews, sign autographs and make career decisions. There is a widespread misconception that becoming a pop star means a lifetime of no work and all music and play. The truth is, in today's super-saturated media environment, signing with a major label means more non-musical work than ever.

title: When Sigs Were Sigs
description: To The Home Section:

title: Queensboro Bridge Entrances Will Exit
description: In a city full of traffic-weary -- but traffic-resigned -- New Yorkers, some Upper East Side residents yesterday achieved what seemed like the unachievable: they received a rare apology from City Hall and a promise to ease weeks of gridlock around the Queensboro Bridge.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the critic and writer Diana Trilling on Friday omitted part of the title of a collection of her essays. It is ''We Must March My Darlings.''

title: Christopher to Go Ahead With Visit to China
description: Calling the battle for human rights and democracy in China a ''long-term struggle,'' the Clinton Administration today condemned the harsh sentence meted out to a former student leader, Wang Dan, but said Secretary of State Warren Christopher's visit to China in mid-November would go ahead as scheduled.

title: Bank of England Raises Key Rate
description: The British Government raised the nation's base lending rate a quarter of a point yesterday, to 6 percent. It was the first increase in the rate, which the Bank of England uses for loans to commercial banks, since February 1995. The previous rate of 5.75 percent was set in June.

title: Back to the Big Barn in Manhattan
description: Frank Sinatra's rendition of ''New York, New York'' provided the soundtrack, and a panorama of horses, from regal jumpers to frilly Saddlebreds to spin-on-a-dime quarterhorses with cowboys aboard, provided earnest entertainment.

title: Hearing Begins on Toll Case
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority began a hearing yesterday on complaints against the State Transportation Commissioner, Frank J. Wilson, by a company that wants to install an electronic toll collection system for the state's three toll roads. The company, Lockeed Martin IMS, of Teaneck, has accused Mr. Wilson of discussing his job prospects with two companies tied to bidders for the contract.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bay Networks Finds Its New Chief at Intel
description: After a lengthy search, Bay Networks Inc., the troubled computer networking company, finally landed a new chief executive yesterday, naming David L. House, a 22-year veteran of the Intel Corporation.

title: Coach Calipari, Reeves And the Nets Make Up
description: The Nets sported a different mood ring today, a lighter and brighter shade compared to Tuesday's dark hangdog look that followed a grueling workout and Coach John Calipari's stunning decision to kick Khalid Reeves out of practice.

title: Bal Harbour Dreamin'
description: Bob Dole grumbles that The New York Times is not looking with favor on the idea of a Dole Presidency.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about preparations by the United States and NATO for a peacekeeping force in Bosnia next year misstated the role of Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, and misstated the location of the talks. Mr. Berger was not involved in discussions on the subject with NATO foreign ministers. And the meetings were in Bergen, Norway, not at NATO headquarters in Brussels.

title: Despite Change at Top, Deutsche Bank Stays on Course
description: For Hilmar Kopper, chief executive of Deutsche Bank A.G., the snub by Daimler-Benz was one more jarring wake-up call.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: The (Quiet) Return Of the 'Barbarians'
description: JUST a few years back, when it seemed furniture design couldn't get any nuttier, Neotu, the Paris-based gallery of art furniture, closed its SoHo branch, perhaps chastened by recession and the appetite for shabby comfort. The gallery is making a quiet comeback in a gentler venue: the walkup of its owners, Gerard Dalmon, left, and Pierre Staudenmeyer, at 409 West 44th Street. An appointment is recommended, but it is worth a visit to see new designs by Bonetti & Garouste and other once-intimidating ''New Barbarians,'' which look just shy of cheery. Neotu, (212) 262-9250, will exhibit at the Seventh Regiment Armory modernism show, Nov. 13 through Nov. 17.

title: Unable to Learn 'Forza,' Pavarotti Will Sing 'Ballo'
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that it would replace the production of Verdi's ''Forza del Destino,'' which was scheduled for revival in January, with a revival of ''Ballo in Maschera.'' The reason for the change is that Luciano Pavarotti, who was to have starred as Don Alvaro in ''Forza,'' has been unable to learn the role. Instead of allowing Mr. Pavarotti to bow out entirely, the company opted to replace ''Forza'' with an opera the tenor already knows.

title: Saatchi Shakes Up San Francisco Office
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. changed top management yesterday at its San Francisco office, which recently lost several accounts.

title: FIDELITY CAPITAL TO SELL 25% OF NETWORK PROVIDER
description: Fidelity Capital, a unit of Fidelity Investments, the largest United States mutual fund company, said yesterday that it plans to sell 25 percent of Colt, a wholly owned European business network provider, valuing the company at $645 million, two people familiar with the company's plans said. Executives at Fidelity, owned by the FMR Corporation, could not be reached for comment. Fidelity Capital has invested $100 million in Colt since it founded the company in 1992 to take advantage of the deregulation of the British telecommunications market.

title: Where Gas Guzzlers Live On, Kings of the Road
description: When Salomon Romero bought his Chevy Malibu 22 years ago, it must have been a beautiful moment.

title: Kenneth Koch Wins Prize for Poetry
description: Kenneth Koch, the poet and writer, is the winner of the 1996 Rebekah Johnson Bobbitt National Prize for Poetry for his 1994 book ''One Train.'' The $10,000 award is given biennially by the Library of Congress for distinguished writing by an American poet.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday referred erroneously to Representative Gary Franks, Republican of Connecticut, as an opponent of abortion rights. Mr. Franks is pro-choice.

title: 'Seinfeld,' a Short Kvetch From Bizarre to Bizarro
description: The current season of NBC's ''Seinfeld,'' its eighth, began pointedly with an episode entitled ''Bizarro Jerry.'' After last season's finale, in which the fiancee of George (Jason Alexander) unexpectedly died after licking the toxic adhesive on cheap wedding invitations he insisted on buying, ''bizarro'' is an understatement when it comes to this truly wacky series. Even ardent fans cringed. Now, after the departure of Larry David, a creator, it's a question of whether ''Seinfeld'' is tumbling toward an episode called ''Jerry Finito.''

title: A Coca-Cola Executive Is Joining BBDO
description: David Wheldon, a top executive at the Coca-Cola Company who was promoted only a month ago, said yesterday that he would leave to join BBDO Worldwide, a leading agency for a Coca-Cola rival, Pepsico Inc.

title: POLAROID TO SELL UNIT AND TAKE EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The Polaroid Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its medical diagnostic photography unit for an undisclosed price to Sterling Diagnostic Imaging of Glasgow, Del., to try to cut costs and increase film sales. The company also said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of as much as $20 million to cut jobs in its Helios Laser Imaging unit and write down inventory, among other costs. The company would also buy a stake of no more than 15 percent in Sterling's parent, the SDI Holdings Corporation. Polaroid stock rose $1.125 to $40.875.

title: Netscape Stock Sale Planned
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation and four of its shareholders plan to sell five million shares, raising as much as $235 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: A Whole Planet For a Patient
description: I KNEW she would be wearing pearls. And sure enough, when Dr. Helen Caldicott materialized in front of East Hampton's movie house on a crisp fall afternoon, beneath her coat she wore simple black with, yes, a string of pearls.

title: As Many Teams Reload, the Bulls Remain the Target
description: The N.B.A. celebrates its 50th anniversary tomorrow when the Raptors play host to the Knicks in Toronto. That was also the site of the league's first game (Nov. 1, 1946), in which the Knicks played the long-defunct Huskies. Beacause of the large number of free agents and talented rookies available this summer, many teams made bold moves they hope will give them a shot at the N.B.A. championship. Here is a quick look at the NBA divisional races listed in projected order to fininsh.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Every Parent's Nightmare, Howling Into the Darkness
description: Halloween came early when Marilyn Manson performed at Roseland on Tuesday night. Audience members arrived in mascara, white face, lace and leather to match the more professionally costumed ghouls in the band.

title: In Computer Era, Power Glitches Are More Critical
description: Glitches in the power system like the one that hit New York City yesterday are no more common now than they were in the past, experts say, but they are more painful.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about Webster L. Hubbell, the former Associate Attorney General, misstated the amount of restitution he will pay to the Rose Law Firm, which refunded money he now admits to having stolen from clients. It is $300,000, not $400,000.

title: South African Police Colonel Jailed for Life in Apartheid Killings
description: Saying many of the defendant's actions had been cruel, calculated and without any sympathy for the victims, a South African judge today sentenced the former head of a notorious police assassination squad to two life sentences and more than 200 years in jail.

title: Clinton Opens Hard Charge In Drive for Majority of Vote
description: With ebullient invocations of the future and what his spokesman called ''a certain wistfulness,'' President Clinton embarked today on a final, frenetic campaign swing whose 6-day, 15-state, 20-stop itinerary belies his large and longstanding lead in the polls.

title: Tank Probes Ruled Out as Cause of Jet Crash
description: Safety investigators searching for the cause of the explosion on Trans World Airlines Flight 800 have tentatively ruled out two recently recovered fuel tank probes after finding that they showed no evidence that they produced an electrical spark that might have set off the explosion.

title: If Character Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: The Writer's Chair Is Everywhere
description: IF imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, Ralph Lauren must be bursting his buttons.

title: The Rangers' October Ends on a High Note
description: The opening month of the season was long and wretched for the Rangers, but they ended it reasonably respectably. Last night's 6-1 victory over the Devils left them with a 5-6-3 record and riding a three-game undefeated streak after slogging through 20 games in the first 40 nights.

title: Heating Oil Price Plunges On Report of Jump in Supply
description: Heating oil prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report that showed a sharp gain in inventories.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Oct. 23 about hanger steak misspelled the name of a co-owner of the restaurants Les Halles and Le Marais. He is Philippe Lajaunie. The article also misidentified the owners of Park Bistro. They are Max Bernard and Jean-Michel Diot, not Mr. Lajaunie and his partner, Jose Mei relles.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Growing Hostas From Seed

title: DOLE ASSERTS DATA ON ECONOMY SHOW RECESSION IS NEAR
description: After a midmorning visit for prayer and reflection at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, Bob Dole headed south today and seized on news of sluggish economic growth to warn that a recession was waiting over the Election Day horizon.

title: Now at the Mall: Housing
description: THE architect Dennis Wedlick, 37, had tongue planted firmly in cheek when he came up with this: like a ship in a bottle, his 2,600-square-foot timber-frame show house for Country Home magazine will rise under the roof of the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn. The magazine calls it a ''Scandinavian cottage for the 21st Century.'' But Mr. Wedlick, who has a deft hand with romantic, vernacular styles, has playfully interpreted early 20th-century lakeside bungalows, using overscale bold trim instead of delicate filigree, large window walls instead of multipaned sashes, and brightly colored interiors with white-washed woods instead of dark paneling. ''Hopefully, this will end the country's obsession with hunter green,'' he said. The house will be open from Nov. 15 to Jan. 31.

title: Panther Center Suspended
description: The Carolina Panthers center CURTIS WHITLEY has been suspended for four games for an alcohol-related problem.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economic Growth Slowed To 2.2% in Third Quarter

title: Blip in Power Has Big Effect Across Region
description: It lasted for a fifth of a second, but a dip in electrical power today caused by an explosion and smoky fire at a Consolidated Edison substation here touched millions of people throughout the New York region, stalling trains, making computers crash and causing lights, and some hearts, to flutter for an instant.

title: G.O.P. and Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Bethlehem Decides to Leave The Structural Steel Market
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the last major steel producer to do battle with the minimills for the structural steel market, has conceded defeat. The company said yesterday it would sell four unprofitable units, including its structural steel mill.

title: Taiwan Denies Offering Donation to Democrats
description: The current furor in the United States over foreign contributions to the Democratic Party was largely ignored in Asia until today, when a senior official in the governing Nationalist Party here denied accusations that he had offered to donate $15 million to President Clinton's re-election effort or to the Democratic Party.
